title: Mobile Robot Localization via Indoor Positioning System and Odometry Fusion
summary:
Accurate localization is crucial for effectively operating mobile robots in
indoor environments. This paper presents a comprehensive approach to mobile
robot localization by integrating an ultrasound-based indoor positioning system
(IPS) with wheel odometry data via sensor fusion techniques. The fusion
methodology leverages the strengths of both IPS and wheel odometry,
compensating for the individual limitations of each method. The Extended Kalman
Filter (EKF) fusion method combines the data from the IPS sensors and the
robot's wheel odometry, providing a robust and reliable localization solution.
Extensive experiments in a controlled indoor environment reveal that the
fusion-based localization system significantly enhances accuracy and precision
compared to standalone systems. The results demonstrate significant
improvements in trajectory tracking, with the EKF-based approach reducing
errors associated with wheel slippage and sensor noise.

AI.tldr: EKF fusion of ultrasound IPS and wheel odometry yields improved indoor localization accuracy.
AI.motivation: Indoor mobile robot localization is challenged by GPS unavailability, sensor noise, and wheel slippage. Integrating an ultrasound-based IPS with wheel odometry leverages complementary strengths to achieve more accurate positioning.
AI.method: Fuse ultrasound IPS measurements with wheel odometry data using an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF). Validate the approach in a controlled indoor environment and compare against standalone IPS or odometry to assess improvements in localization and trajectory tracking.
AI.result: Fusion-based localization significantly enhances accuracy and precision, mitigating wheel slippage and sensor noise effects; trajectory tracking errors are reduced compared with single-sensor systems.
AI.conclusion: An EKF-based fusion of IPS and odometry provides robust, reliable indoor localization for mobile robots, illustrating the benefits of sensor complementary fusion in indoor environments.

authors: Catur Hilman A. H. B. Baskoro
title: Nonlinear Model Predictive Control with Single-Shooting Method for Autonomous Personal Mobility Vehicle
summary:
This paper introduces a proposed control method for autonomous personal
mobility vehicles, specifically the Single-passenger Electric Autonomous
Transporter (SEATER), using Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC). The
proposed method leverages a single-shooting approach to solve the optimal
control problem (OCP) via non-linear programming (NLP). The proposed NMPC is
implemented to a non-holonomic vehicle with a differential drive system, using
odometry data as localization feedback to guide the vehicle towards its target
pose while achieving objectives and adhering to constraints, such as obstacle
avoidance. To evaluate the performance of the proposed method, a number of
simulations have been conducted in both obstacle-free and static obstacle
environments. The SEATER model and testing environment have been developed in
the Gazebo Simulation and the NMPC are implemented within the Robot Operating
System (ROS) framework. The simulation results demonstrate that the NMPC-based
approach successfully controls the vehicle to reach the desired target location
while satisfying the imposed constraints. Furthermore, this study highlights
the robustness and real-time effectiveness of NMPC with a single-shooting
approach for autonomous vehicle control in the evaluated scenarios.

AI.tldr: An NMPC framework with single-shooting for a differential-drive autonomous transporter (SEATER) enables real-time, constraint-satisfying navigation to a target pose, validated via Gazebo/ROS simulations with obstacle avoidance.
AI.motivation: To achieve robust, real-time autonomous navigation for single-passenger electric vehicles by combining nonlinear model predictive control with a single-shooting solution to the OCP, enabling obstacle avoidance and adherence to non-holonomic dynamics.
AI.method: Apply nonlinear model predictive control using a single-shooting approach to solve the optimal control problem (OCP) as a nonlinear program (NLP) for a differential-drive, non-holonomic vehicle; utilize odometry data as localization feedback; enforce constraints (e.g., obstacle avoidance) and guide the vehicle to the target pose. Implemented in Gazebo and ROS.
AI.result: Simulation studies in both obstacle-free and static obstacle environments show the NMPC with single-shooting can drive the SEATER to the desired location while satisfying constraints, demonstrating robustness and real-time performance.
AI.conclusion: The NMPC with single-shooting is a viable and effective control strategy for autonomous SEATER-type vehicles in the evaluated scenarios, offering real-time, constraint-compliant navigation; potential extensions include dynamic obstacles, uncertainty handling, and hardware experiments.

title: ReSeFlow: Rectifying SE(3)-Equivariant Policy Learning Flows
comment:
This work was submitted to 2026 IEEE International Conference on
  Robotics & Automation
summary:
Robotic manipulation in unstructured environments requires the generation of
robust and long-horizon trajectory-level policy with conditions of perceptual
observations and benefits from the advantages of SE(3)-equivariant diffusion
models that are data-efficient. However, these models suffer from the inference
time costs. Inspired by the inference efficiency of rectified flows, we
introduce the rectification to the SE(3)-diffusion models and propose the
ReSeFlow, i.e., Rectifying SE(3)-Equivariant Policy Learning Flows, providing
fast, geodesic-consistent, least-computational policy generation. Crucially,
both components employ SE(3)-equivariant networks to preserve rotational and
translational symmetry, enabling robust generalization under rigid-body
motions. With the verification on the simulated benchmarks, we find that the
proposed ReSeFlow with only one inference step can achieve better performance
with lower geodesic distance than the baseline methods, achieving up to a 48.5%
error reduction on the painting task and a 21.9% reduction on the rotating
triangle task compared to the baseline's 100-step inference. This method takes
advantages of both SE(3) equivariance and rectified flow and puts it forward
for the real-world application of generative policy learning models with the
data and inference efficiency.

AI.tldr: Rectifying SE(3)-Equivariant Diffusion Models for fast, geodesic-consistent policy generation in robotic manipulation; ReSeFlow achieves one-step inference with substantial error reductions.
AI.motivation: Reduce inference time and preserve symmetry so policies generalize under rigid-body motions, enabling robust long-horizon planning in unstructured environments.
AI.method: Introduce rectified flows into SE(3)-equivariant diffusion pipelines to form ReSeFlow; use SE(3) equivariant networks; ensure geodesic consistency; achieve one-step inference.
AI.result: In simulated benchmarks, ReSeFlow with a single inference step attains better geodesic distance than 100-step baselines; up to 48.5% error reduction on painting task and 21.9% on rotating triangle.
AI.conclusion: Marries SE(3) equivariance with rectified flow for fast, data-efficient generative policy learning in robotics; shows potential for real-world deployment.

title: Advancing Audio-Visual Navigation Through Multi-Agent Collaboration in 3D Environments
comment:
Main paper (15 pages). Accepted for publication by ICONIP(
  International Conference on Neural Information Processing) 2025
summary:
Intelligent agents often require collaborative strategies to achieve complex
tasks beyond individual capabilities in real-world scenarios. While existing
audio-visual navigation (AVN) research mainly focuses on single-agent systems,
their limitations emerge in dynamic 3D environments where rapid multi-agent
coordination is critical, especially for time-sensitive applications like
emergency response. This paper introduces MASTAVN (Multi-Agent Scalable
Transformer Audio-Visual Navigation), a scalable framework enabling two agents
to collaboratively localize and navigate toward an audio target in shared 3D
environments. By integrating cross-agent communication protocols and joint
audio-visual fusion mechanisms, MASTAVN enhances spatial reasoning and temporal
synchronization. Through rigorous evaluation in photorealistic 3D simulators
(Replica and Matterport3D), MASTAVN achieves significant reductions in task
completion time and notable improvements in navigation success rates compared
to single-agent and non-collaborative baselines. This highlights the essential
role of spatiotemporal coordination in multi-agent systems. Our findings
validate MASTAVN's effectiveness in time-sensitive emergency scenarios and
establish a paradigm for advancing scalable multi-agent embodied intelligence
in complex 3D environments.

AI.tldr: MASTAVN introduces a scalable, two-agent audio-visual navigation framework that enables collaborative localization and navigation toward an audio source in 3D environments, leveraging cross-agent communication and joint audio-visual fusion to improve efficiency.
AI.motivation: Single-agent AVN struggles in dynamic 3D settings that require rapid, coordinated actions, which are critical in time-sensitive tasks such as emergency response.
AI.method: Proposes MASTAVN with cross-agent communication protocols and joint audio-visual fusion within a Transformer-based architecture; evaluates in photorealistic simulators Replica and Matterport3D, comparing to single-agent and non-collaborative baselines.
AI.result: Achieves significant reductions in task completion time and higher navigation success rates compared to baselines, highlighting improved spatiotemporal coordination.
AI.conclusion: Spatiotemporal coordination is essential for scalable multi-agent embodied navigation; MASTAVN validates the effectiveness of collaborative strategies in complex 3D environments and offers a paradigm for multi-agent embodied intelligence in time-sensitive scenarios.

title: Mixture-of-Visual-Thoughts: Exploring Context-Adaptive Reasoning Mode Selection for General Visual Reasoning
summary:
Current visual reasoning methods mainly focus on exploring specific reasoning
modes. Although improvements can be achieved in particular domains, they
struggle to develop general reasoning capabilities. Inspired by this, we
propose a novel adaptive reasoning paradigm, Mixture-of-Visual-Thoughts (MoVT),
which unifies different reasoning modes within a single model and guides it to
select the appropriate mode based on context. To achieve this, we introduce
AdaVaR, a two-stage Adaptive Visual Reasoning learning framework: different
modes are unified and learned during the supervised cold-start stage, and the
mode selection capability is induced via an RL process with a carefully
designed AdaGRPO algorithm. Extensive experiments show that AdaVaR effectively
guides the model to learn and differentiate multiple modes and perform
context-adaptive mode selection, achieving consistent improvement across
various scenarios, highlighting MoVT as an effective solution for building
general visual reasoning models.

AI.tldr: Proposes Mixture-of-Visual-Thoughts (MoVT): an adaptive reasoning framework that unifies multiple reasoning modes within a single model and selects the appropriate mode by context.
AI.motivation: Current visual reasoning methods optimize for specific reasoning modes and struggle to achieve general, context-aware reasoning capabilities across diverse tasks.
AI.method: Two-stage AdaVaR: a supervised cold-start stage to unify and learn multiple reasoning modes within MoVT, followed by a reinforcement learning stage using AdaGRPO to induce context-driven mode selection.
AI.result: Empirical studies show AdaVaR enables learning and differentiating multiple modes and performing context-adaptive mode selection, yielding consistent improvements across varied scenarios.
AI.conclusion: MoVT with AdaVaR constitutes a promising approach toward general, context-aware visual reasoning models by integrating multiple reasoning modes and enabling adaptive mode selection.

title: Localizing Adversarial Attacks To Produces More Imperceptible Noise
comment:
Published, CC BY-NC 4.0; includes 2 figures and 1 table;
  InceptionV3/ImageNet evaluation
summary:
Adversarial attacks in machine learning traditionally focus on global
perturbations to input data, yet the potential of localized adversarial noise
remains underexplored. This study systematically evaluates localized
adversarial attacks across widely-used methods, including FGSM, PGD, and C&W,
to quantify their effectiveness, imperceptibility, and computational
efficiency. By introducing a binary mask to constrain noise to specific
regions, localized attacks achieve significantly lower mean pixel
perturbations, higher Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratios (PSNR), and improved
Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) compared to global attacks. However, these
benefits come at the cost of increased computational effort and a modest
reduction in Attack Success Rate (ASR). Our results highlight that iterative
methods, such as PGD and C&W, are more robust to localization constraints than
single-step methods like FGSM, maintaining higher ASR and imperceptibility
metrics. This work provides a comprehensive analysis of localized adversarial
attacks, offering practical insights for advancing attack strategies and
designing robust defensive systems.

AI.tldr: Localized adversarial attacks using a region-restricting mask reduce perturbations and improve perceptual metrics (PSNR/SSIM) but require more computation; iterative methods (PGD/C&W) fare better under localization than FGSM.
AI.motivation: Addresses the underexplored area of localized adversarial noise, systematically evaluating FGSM, PGD, and C&W to quantify effectiveness, imperceptibility, and efficiency, with implications for defense design.
AI.method: Introduce a binary mask to constrain perturbations to specific regions and compare FGSM, PGD, and C&W against global attacks. Measure mean pixel perturbation, PSNR, SSIM, and Attack Success Rate (ASR), along with computational cost. Analyze robustness of single-step vs iterative methods under localization.
AI.result: Localized attacks achieve significantly lower mean perturbations and higher PSNR/SSIM than global attacks, but incur higher computational cost and exhibit a modest drop in ASR. Iterative methods (PGD/C&W) are more robust to localization constraints than FGSM, maintaining higher ASR and perceptual-quality metrics.
AI.conclusion: Provides a comprehensive analysis of localized adversarial attacks, offering practical insights for developing stronger attack strategies and informing robust defense design; localization presents a trade-off between imperceptibility, success rate, and computation.

title: Pathological Truth Bias in Vision-Language Models
comment:
10 pages, 12 figures. Code for MATS released at
  https://github.com/thubZ09/mats-spatial-reasoning
summary:
Vision Language Models (VLMs) are improving quickly, but standard benchmarks
can hide systematic failures that reduce real world trust. We introduce MATS
(Multimodal Audit for Truthful Spatialization), a compact behavioral audit that
measures whether models reject visually contradicted statements, and two
metrics Spatial Consistency Score (SCS) and Incorrect Agreement Rate (IAR).
Instruction tuned generative VLMs (LLaVA 1.5, QwenVLchat) exhibit very low SCS
and high IAR, while contrastive encoders (CLIP, SigLIP) are far more robust.
Activation patching causally localizes failure loci (mid to late cross
attention for generative models, pooled projection components for contrastive
models) and suggests concrete repair paths.

AI.tldr: A compact behavioral audit (MATS) evaluates whether Vision-Language Models reject visually contradicted statements. It finds instruction-tuned generative VLMs have poor truthfulness (low SCS, high IAR) while contrastive encoders are more robust; activation patching localizes failure sites and guides repairs.
AI.motivation: Benchmarks often miss systematic, real-world failures in multimodal truthfulness. A compact, interpretable audit can reveal where models fail and guide targeted improvements to trustworthiness.
AI.method: Introduce MATS with two metrics (Spatial Consistency Score and Incorrect Agreement Rate). Evaluate on instruction-tuned generative VLMs (LLaVA 1.5, QwenVLchat) and contrastive encoders (CLIP, SigLIP). Use activation patching to localize failure loci: mid-to-late cross-attention for generative models; pooled projection components for contrastive models; derive concrete repair paths.
AI.result: Generative VLMs exhibit very low SCS and high IAR, indicating susceptibility to visually contradicted statements. Contrastive encoders show stronger performance with higher SCS and lower IAR. Activation patching causally localizes failures to specific architectural components, suggesting targeted repair strategies.
AI.conclusion: MATS provides a compact, actionable audit for truthfulness in Vision-Language Models. Findings point to architecture-dependent failure loci and offer concrete directions to improve robustness through targeted modifications to cross-attention or projection components.

title: Large Language Models for 3D IC Space Planning
summary:
Three-dimensional integrated circuits (3D ICs) have emerged as a promising
solution to the scaling limits of two-dimensional designs, offering higher
integration density, shorter interconnects, and improved performance. As design
complexity increases, effective space planning becomes essential to reduce dead
space and ensure layout quality. This study investigates the use of large
language models (LLMs) for 3D IC space planning through a post-order slicing
tree representation, which guarantees legal space plans while aiming to
minimize dead space. Open-source LLMs were fine-tuned on large-scale synthetic
datasets and further evaluated on MCNC-derived 3D benchmarks. Experimental
results indicate that the proposed framework achieves a favorable balance
between runtime efficiency, legality, and dead-space reduction, with
zero-dead-space layouts obtained in a significant portion of test cases under
practical runtime budgets. Beyond synthetic benchmarks, the method generalizes
to MCNC cases such as ami33 and ami49, though larger and irregular instances
remain challenging. The approach also shows potential for cross-domain
applications, including logistics and 3D object placement, where spatial
efficiency is critical. Overall, the results suggest that LLM-based space
planning can serve as a data-driven complement to traditional electronic design
automation (EDA) methods, providing new insights for scalable 3D layout
generation.

AI.tldr: LLM-driven 3D IC space planning using a post-order slicing tree yields legal, low dead-space designs with practical runtimes; generalizes to MCNC ami33/ami49; larger/irregular instances remain challenging; potential cross-domain applications.
AI.motivation: Address 3D IC scaling limits by reducing dead space and improving layout quality. Use data-driven LLMs to complement traditional EDA methods in space planning for 3D designs.
AI.method: Represent space planning with a post-order slicing tree. Fine-tune open-source LLMs on large-scale synthetic datasets. Evaluate on MCNC-derived 3D benchmarks (including ami33/ami49) for legality, dead-space reduction, and runtime. Explore generalization to cross-domain placements.
AI.result: Achieves a favorable balance between runtime efficiency, legality, and dead-space reduction. Zero-dead-space layouts achieved in a significant portion of test cases under practical runtimes. Generalizes to MCNC cases such as ami33 and ami49, though larger/irregular instances remain challenging.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based space planning can serve as a data-driven complement to traditional EDA methods for scalable 3D layout generation, with potential applications beyond electronics (e.g., logistics and 3D object placement).

title: Can Large Language Models Develop Gambling Addiction?
summary:
This study explores whether large language models can exhibit behavioral
patterns similar to human gambling addictions. As LLMs are increasingly
utilized in financial decision-making domains such as asset management and
commodity trading, understanding their potential for pathological
decision-making has gained practical significance. We systematically analyze
LLM decision-making at cognitive-behavioral and neural levels based on human
gambling addiction research. In slot machine experiments, we identified
cognitive features of human gambling addiction, such as illusion of control,
gambler's fallacy, and loss chasing. When given the freedom to determine their
own target amounts and betting sizes, bankruptcy rates rose substantially
alongside increased irrational behavior, demonstrating that greater autonomy
amplifies risk-taking tendencies. Through neural circuit analysis using a
Sparse Autoencoder, we confirmed that model behavior is controlled by abstract
decision-making features related to risky and safe behaviors, not merely by
prompts. These findings suggest LLMs can internalize human-like cognitive
biases and decision-making mechanisms beyond simply mimicking training data
patterns, emphasizing the importance of AI safety design in financial
applications.

AI.tldr: LLMs can exhibit human-like gambling biases and risk-taking that intensify with autonomy; they can be analyzed via cognitive-behavioral and neural-level methods, raising safety concerns for financial AI.
AI.motivation: As LLMs are adopted in finance, understanding whether they adopt pathological decision-making patterns is crucial for risk management and responsible AI design.
AI.method: Slot-machine style experiments to identify human gambling biases (illusion of control, gambler's fallacy, loss chasing); allow models to set targets and bets to study autonomy effects; neural analysis with a Sparse Autoencoder to see if abstract decision-making features govern behavior beyond prompts.
AI.result: Increased autonomy led to higher bankruptcy rates and more irrational behavior; behavior is driven by abstract decision-making features rather than mere prompts; LLMs can internalize human-like cognitive biases.
AI.conclusion: AI safety and governance must consider such biases in financial contexts; design safeguards to prevent pathological decision-making in LLMs used for decision support or autonomous trading.

title: In-Context Learning can Perform Continual Learning Like Humans
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) can adapt to new tasks via in-context learning
(ICL) without parameter updates, making them powerful learning engines for fast
adaptation. While extensive research has examined ICL as a few-shot learner,
whether it can achieve long-term retention and cross-task knowledge
accumulation when multitasks arrive sequentially remains underexplored.
Motivated by human memory studies, we investigate the retention characteristics
of ICL in multitask settings and extend it to in-context continual learning
(ICCL), where continual learning ability emerges through task scheduling and
prompt rearrangement. Experiments on Markov-Chain benchmarks demonstrate that,
for specific large-language models, ICCL benefits from distributed practice
(DP) in a manner analogous to humans, consistently revealing a spacing "sweet
spot" for retention. Beyond retention performance, we propose a human-retention
similarity metric to quantify how closely a continual-learning (CL) method
aligns with human retention dynamics. Using this metric, we show that
linear-attention models such as MAMBA and RWKV exhibit particularly human-like
retention patterns, despite their retention performance lagging behind that of
Transformer-based LLMs. Overall, our results establish ICCL as both cognitively
plausible and practically effective, providing an inference-only CL paradigm
that mitigates catastrophic forgetting and addresses the stability-plasticity
dilemma in conventional CL methods.

AI.tldr: ICCL enables long-term retention and cross-task knowledge gain for LLMs via task scheduling and prompt rearrangement; distributed practice yields a retention 'sweet spot'; human-like retention patterns emerge, especially in linear-attention models; inference-only CL mitigates forgetting and supports stability-plasticity.
AI.motivation: Investigate whether in-context learning can support long-term retention and cross-task knowledge accumulation in multitask sequences, drawing inspiration from human memory studies, and assess how prompt design and task scheduling affect retention.
AI.method: Experiments on Markov-Chain benchmarks with multiple LLMs; induce ICCL through task scheduling and prompt rearrangement; test distributed practice effects; develop a human-retention similarity metric; compare linear-attention models (MAMBA, RWKV) against Transformer-based LLMs.
AI.result: Distributed practice reveals a spacing sweet spot for retention in ICCL; continual learning reduces catastrophic forgetting and improves cross-task retention; linear-attention models show more human-like retention dynamics despite lagging in raw retention performance; a human-retention similarity metric quantifies alignment with human memory patterns.
AI.conclusion: ICCL is both cognitively plausible and practically effective, providing an inference-only continual learning paradigm that mitigates forgetting and addresses the stability-plasticity dilemma in conventional CL methods.

title: Scale and Rotation Estimation of Similarity-Transformed Images via Cross-Correlation Maximization Based on Auxiliary Function Method
comment: accepted to APSIPA ASC 2025 (to appear). 5 pages, 4 figures
summary:
This paper introduces a highly efficient algorithm capable of jointly
estimating scale and rotation between two images with sub-pixel precision.
Image alignment serves as a critical process for spatially registering images
captured from different viewpoints, and finds extensive use in domains such as
medical imaging and computer vision. Traditional phase-correlation techniques
are effective in determining translational shifts; however, they are inadequate
when addressing scale and rotation changes, which often arise due to camera
zooming or rotational movements. In this paper, we propose a novel algorithm
that integrates scale and rotation estimation based on the Fourier transform in
log-polar coordinates with a cross-correlation maximization strategy,
leveraging the auxiliary function method. By incorporating sub-pixel-level
cross-correlation our method enables precise estimation of both scale and
rotation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves
lower mean estimation errors for scale and rotation than conventional Fourier
transform-based techniques that rely on discrete cross-correlation.

AI.tldr: Fast joint scale-rotation estimation with sub-pixel precision using Fourier transform in log-polar coordinates and auxiliary-function cross-correlation.
AI.motivation: Image alignment requires robust handling of scale and rotation variations, which traditional phase-correlation cannot address. Accurate alignment across viewpoints is critical in medical imaging and computer vision.
AI.method: Transform images to log-polar coordinates and apply Fourier-based cross-correlation to detect scale and rotation as shifts in log-polar space; maximize a cross-correlation using the auxiliary function method and incorporate sub-pixel cross-correlation for precise estimates.
AI.result: Experimental results show lower mean estimation errors for scale and rotation compared with conventional Fourier-transform-based methods that rely on discrete cross-correlation.
AI.conclusion: The approach delivers accurate, efficient joint estimation of scale and rotation, improving image alignment when scale/rotation changes are present and suggesting wide applicability in CV and medical imaging.

title: Multiscale 2-Mapper -- Exploratory Data Analysis Guided by the First Betti Number
summary:
The Mapper algorithm is a fundamental tool in exploratory topological data
analysis for identifying connectivity and topological clustering in data.
Derived from the nerve construction, Mapper graphs can contain additional
information about clustering density when considering the higher-dimensional
skeleta. To observe two-dimensional features, and capture one-dimensional
topology, we construct 2-Mapper. A common issue in using Mapper algorithms is
parameter choice. We develop tools to choose 2-Mapper parameters that reflect
persistent Betti-1 information. Computationally, we study how cover choice
affects 2-Mapper and analyze this through a computational Multiscale Mapper
algorithm. We test our constructions on three-dimensional shape data, including
the Klein bottle.

AI.tldr: 2-Mapper extends Mapper to reveal 2D features and 1D topology; provides parameter selection tools via persistent Betti-1 and uses Multiscale Mapper to study cover effects; validated on 3D shapes including Klein bottle.
AI.motivation: Mapper is a foundational tool in exploratory topological data analysis for connectivity and clustering, but choosing parameters remains problematic and higher-dimensional features are hard to detect. This work proposes 2-Mapper to observe two-dimensional features and one-dimensional topology, with a principled way to select parameters.
AI.method: Construct 2-Mapper by leveraging higher-dimensional skeleta to capture clustering density. Develop parameter selection guided by persistent Betti-1 information. Analyze cover sensitivity using a computational Multiscale Mapper. Validate on three-dimensional shape data, including the Klein bottle.
AI.result: Provide tools for selecting 2-Mapper parameters based on persistent Betti-1, and characterize how cover choices affect 2-Mapper outputs through a Multiscale Mapper framework. Empirically demonstrate the approach on 3D shapes, showing the ability to detect nontrivial topology such as the Klein bottle.
AI.conclusion: 2-Mapper offers a principled extension of Mapper to capture 2D features and 1D topology, with interpretable parameter guidelines and a multiscale analysis method to understand cover effects. The framework is validated on complex shape data, including the Klein bottle.

title: Self-driving cars: Are we there yet?
summary:
Autonomous driving remains a highly active research domain that seeks to
enable vehicles to perceive dynamic environments, predict the future
trajectories of traffic agents such as vehicles, pedestrians, and cyclists and
plan safe and efficient future motions. To advance the field, several
competitive platforms and benchmarks have been established to provide
standardized datasets and evaluation protocols. Among these, leaderboards by
the CARLA organization and nuPlan and the Waymo Open Dataset have become
leading benchmarks for assessing motion planning algorithms. Each offers a
unique dataset and challenging planning problems spanning a wide range of
driving scenarios and conditions. In this study, we present a comprehensive
comparative analysis of the motion planning methods featured on these three
leaderboards. To ensure a fair and unified evaluation, we adopt CARLA
leaderboard v2.0 as our common evaluation platform and modify the selected
models for compatibility. By highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of
current approaches, we identify prevailing trends, common challenges, and
suggest potential directions for advancing motion planning research.

AI.tldr: A unified, cross-benchmark comparison of motion planning methods across CARLA, nuPlan, and Waymo Open, using CARLA leaderboard v2.0 as the common evaluation platform to reveal strengths, weaknesses, and directions for future work.
AI.motivation: Address fragmentation across major driving benchmarks by providing fair, standardized evaluation to identify gaps and guide progress in motion planning for autonomous driving.
AI.method: Collect state-of-the-art motion planning models from the three leaderboards, adapt/modify selected models to be compatible with CARLA leaderboard v2.0, run standardized evaluations, and perform cross-benchmark analysis.
AI.result: The study clarifies prevailing trends and common challenges in current motion planning approaches, indicates cross-benchmark generalization capabilities, highlights scenario-specific difficulties and domain gaps, and provides recommendations for future research directions.
AI.conclusion: A common evaluation platform enables fair comparisons, accelerates progress, and helps pinpoint gaps to guide the development of robust, transferable motion planning algorithms.

title: Hilbert: Recursively Building Formal Proofs with Informal Reasoning
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate impressive mathematical reasoning
abilities, but their solutions frequently contain errors that cannot be
automatically verified. Formal theorem proving systems such as Lean 4 offer
automated verification with complete accuracy, motivating recent efforts to
build specialized prover LLMs that generate verifiable proofs in formal
languages. However, a significant gap remains: current prover LLMs solve
substantially fewer problems than general-purpose LLMs operating in natural
language. We introduce Hilbert, an agentic framework that bridges this gap by
combining the complementary strengths of informal reasoning and formal
verification. Our system orchestrates four components: an informal LLM that
excels at mathematical reasoning, a specialized prover LLM optimized for Lean 4
tactics, a formal verifier, and a semantic theorem retriever. Given a problem
that the prover is unable to solve, Hilbert employs recursive decomposition to
split the problem into subgoals that it solves with the prover or reasoner LLM.
It leverages verifier feedback to refine incorrect proofs as necessary.
Experimental results demonstrate that Hilbert substantially outperforms
existing approaches on key benchmarks, achieving 99.2% on miniF2F, 6.6% points
above the best publicly available method. Hilbert achieves the best known
result on PutnamBench. It solves 462/660 problems (70.0%), outperforming
proprietary approaches like SeedProver (50.4%) and achieving a 422% improvement
over the best publicly available baseline. Thus, Hilbert effectively narrows
the gap between informal reasoning and formal proof generation.

AI.tldr: Hilbert is an agentic framework that combines informal reasoning and formal verification to improve Lean 4 proof generation, achieving state-of-the-art results on miniF2F and PutnamBench.
AI.motivation: Current prover LLMs struggle to match general-purpose LLMs in natural language on formal proofs, while informal LLMs can reason but lack guarantees. There is a gap between informal reasoning and formal verification that needs bridging.
AI.method: Hilbert orchestrates four components: (1) an informal LLM for mathematical reasoning, (2) a specialized prover LLM optimized for Lean 4 tactics, (3) a formal verifier, and (4) a semantic theorem retriever. If the prover cannot solve a problem, Hilbert recursively decomposes it into subgoals solvable by the prover or reasoner LLM, using verifier feedback to refine proofs.
AI.result: On miniF2F, Hilbert achieves 99.2% (6.6 percentage points above the best publicly available method). It achieves the best known result on PutnamBench. It solves 462/660 problems (70.0%), outperforming SeedProver (50.4%) and yielding a 422% improvement over the best publicly available baseline.
AI.conclusion: Hilbert effectively narrows the gap between informal reasoning and formal proof generation and sets new state-of-the-art results on important formal-proving benchmarks.

title: Communication-Efficient and Interoperable Distributed Learning
comment: Preprint version. Submitted for peer review
summary:
Collaborative learning across heterogeneous model architectures presents
significant challenges in ensuring interoperability and preserving privacy. We
propose a communication-efficient distributed learning framework that supports
model heterogeneity and enables modular composition during inference. To
facilitate interoperability, all clients adopt a common fusion-layer output
dimension, which permits each model to be partitioned into a personalized base
block and a generalized modular block. Clients share their fusion-layer
outputs, keeping model parameters and architectures private. Experimental
results demonstrate that the framework achieves superior communication
efficiency compared to federated learning (FL) and federated split learning
(FSL) baselines, while ensuring stable training performance across
heterogeneous architectures.

AI.tldr: A framework enabling collaborative learning across heterogeneous model architectures via a common fusion-layer output, allowing partition into personalized base blocks and modular generalized blocks; shares fusion outputs to preserve privacy and reduce communication, aiming to outperform FL and FSL baselines while maintaining training stability.
AI.motivation: Address interoperability and privacy challenges in cross-architecture collaborative learning, while reducing communication overhead inherent in Federated Learning and related methods.
AI.method: Introduce a fixed-dimension fusion-layer output that all clients agree on. Each model is partitioned into a private base block and a generalized modular block. Clients exchange only fusion-layer outputs rather than model parameters, enabling heterogeneity, modular composition during inference, and privacy preservation. Evaluate on heterogeneous architectures against FL and FSL baselines, focusing on communication efficiency and training stability.
AI.result: Demonstrates superior communication efficiency compared to FL and FSL baselines, with stable training performance across heterogeneous architectures.
AI.conclusion: This approach shows promise for cross-architecture collaborative learning by decoupling model specifics from joint inference via a shared fusion output, enabling privacy-preserving, communication-efficient collaboration; potential trade-offs include the design of the fusion layer and its impact on model expressiveness.

title: Robust Object Detection for Autonomous Driving via Curriculum-Guided Group Relative Policy Optimization
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) excel in vision-language reasoning
but often struggle with structured perception tasks requiring precise
localization and robustness. We propose a reinforcement learning framework that
augments Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with curriculum-based data
scheduling and difficulty-aware filtering. This approach stabilizes
optimization under sparse, noisy rewards and enables progressive adaptation to
complex samples. Evaluations on autonomous driving benchmarks demonstrate
substantial improvements in detection accuracy and robustness. Ablation studies
confirm the importance of reward design, KL regularization, and curriculum
pacing for convergence stability and generalization. Our findings highlight
reinforcement-driven optimization with structured data curricula as a scalable
path toward robust and interpretable multimodal detection.

AI.tldr: A reinforcement learning framework that enhances Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with curriculum-based data scheduling and difficulty-aware filtering to improve robust multimodal detection, showing improved accuracy and robustness on autonomous driving benchmarks, with ablations highlighting reward design, KL regularization, and curriculum pacing.
AI.motivation: MLLMs excel at vision-language tasks but struggle with structured perception requiring precise localization and robustness; optimization with sparse/noisy rewards remains challenging. A curriculum-driven RL approach could stabilize training and enable progressive handling of complex samples.
AI.method: Augment GRPO with curriculum-based data scheduling and difficulty-aware filtering within a reinforcement learning framework; include KL regularization and structured data pacing to stabilize optimization under sparse/noisy rewards and adapt to increasingly difficult samples.
AI.result: Substantial improvements in detection accuracy and robustness on autonomous driving benchmarks; ablation studies confirm the importance of reward design, KL regularization, and curriculum pacing for convergence stability and generalization.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcement-driven optimization with structured data curricula offers a scalable path toward robust and interpretable multimodal detection in real-world tasks such as autonomous driving.

title: The Road to the Closest Point is Paved by Good Neighbors
summary:
$\renewcommand{\Re}{\mathbb{R}}$Given a set $P$ of $n$ points in $\Re^d$, and
a parameter $\varepsilon \in (0,1)$, we present a new construction of a
directed graph $G$, of size $O(n/\varepsilon^d)$, such that
$(1+\varepsilon)$-ANN queries can be answered by performing a greedy walk on
$G$, repeatedly moving to a neighbor that is (significantly) better than the
current point. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first construction of
a linear size with no dependency on the spread of the point set. The resulting
query time, is $O( \varepsilon^{-d} \log \Psi)$, where $\Psi$ is the spread of
$P$. The new construction is surprisingly simple and should be practical.

AI.tldr: A linear-size directed graph enables (1+ε)-ANN via a greedy walk, with query time O(ε^{-d} log Ψ) and no dependence on data spread.
AI.motivation: To achieve near-optimal ANN search with linear-space, avoiding traditional spread-dependent trade-offs and large pre-processing, while keeping the query process simple and practical.
AI.method: Construct a directed graph G on the n points with O(n/ε^d) edges such that a greedy walk from any query point moves to progressively better points, ultimately yielding a (1+ε)-approximate nearest neighbor. The graph is designed to be independent of the dataset's spread. The walk requires repeatedly moving to a neighbor that is significantly closer to the nearest neighbor, leading to a logarithmic factor in the spread.
AI.result: Queries can answer (1+ε)-ANN via a greedy walk on G in time O(ε^{-d} log Ψ); graph size is O(n/ε^d). The construction is linear in size and does not depend on the spread, and is claimed to be surprisingly simple and practical.
AI.conclusion: This work provides a simple, linear-sized, spread-free graph-based approach for (1+ε)-ANN with provable query bounds, suggesting a practical alternative to traditional, spread-dependent ANN structures and opening avenues for further empirical validation and extensions.

title: Persistent Autoregressive Mapping with Traffic Rules for Autonomous Driving
summary:
Safe autonomous driving requires both accurate HD map construction and
persistent awareness of traffic rules, even when their associated signs are no
longer visible. However, existing methods either focus solely on geometric
elements or treat rules as temporary classifications, failing to capture their
persistent effectiveness across extended driving sequences. In this paper, we
present PAMR (Persistent Autoregressive Mapping with Traffic Rules), a novel
framework that performs autoregressive co-construction of lane vectors and
traffic rules from visual observations. Our approach introduces two key
mechanisms: Map-Rule Co-Construction for processing driving scenes in temporal
segments, and Map-Rule Cache for maintaining rule consistency across these
segments. To properly evaluate continuous and consistent map generation, we
develop MapDRv2, featuring improved lane geometry annotations. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that PAMR achieves superior performance in joint
vector-rule mapping tasks, while maintaining persistent rule effectiveness
throughout extended driving sequences.

AI.tldr: PAMR: a persistent autoregressive framework for jointly mapping lane vectors and traffic rules across driving sequences, using Map-Rule Co-Construction and Map-Rule Cache; evaluated on MapDRv2 with improved lane annotations, achieving superior joint vector-rule mapping and persistent rule effectiveness.
AI.motivation: Safe autonomous driving requires accurate, persistent HD-map construction and enduring awareness of traffic rules across extended driving sequences, not just instantaneous classifications or purely geometric maps.
AI.method: PAMR introduces autoregressive co-construction of lane geometry and traffic rules. It processes scenes in temporal segments via Map-Rule Co-Construction and maintains rule consistency with a Map-Rule Cache across segments. Evaluation uses MapDRv2, a dataset with improved lane geometry annotations.
AI.result: Experimental results show PAMR achieves superior performance on joint vector-rule mapping and preserves rule effectiveness across long sequences.
AI.conclusion: PAMR enables persistent, integrated map-rule representations for autonomous driving, with MapDRv2 supporting robust evaluation of continuous map generation.

title: Toward a Theory of Generalizability in LLM Mechanistic Interpretability Research
summary:
Research on Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly focuses on identifying
mechanistic explanations for their behaviors, yet the field lacks clear
principles for determining when (and how) findings from one model instance
generalize to another. This paper addresses a fundamental epistemological
challenge: given a mechanistic claim about a particular model, what justifies
extrapolating this finding to other LLMs -- and along which dimensions might
such generalizations hold? I propose five potential axes of correspondence
along which mechanistic claims might generalize, including: functional (whether
they satisfy the same functional criteria), developmental (whether they develop
at similar points during pretraining), positional (whether they occupy similar
absolute or relative positions), relational (whether they interact with other
model components in similar ways), and configurational (whether they correspond
to particular regions or structures in weight-space). To empirically validate
this framework, I analyze "1-back attention heads" (components attending to
previous tokens) across pretraining in random seeds of the Pythia models (14M,
70M, 160M, 410M). The results reveal striking consistency in the developmental
trajectories of 1-back attention across models, while positional consistency is
more limited. Moreover, seeds of larger models systematically show earlier
onsets, steeper slopes, and higher peaks of 1-back attention. I also address
possible objections to the arguments and proposals outlined here. Finally, I
conclude by arguing that progress on the generalizability of mechanistic
interpretability research will consist in mapping constitutive design
properties of LLMs to their emergent behaviors and mechanisms.

AI.tldr: Proposes a five-axis framework for generalizing mechanistic claims across LLMs, and empirically tests 1-back attention across Pythia seeds/sizes, finding strong developmental consistency but limited positional consistency, with larger models showing earlier, steeper, higher 1-back attention; argues for mapping design properties to emergent behaviors to improve generalizability.
AI.motivation: Currently, there are no clear principles to determine when mechanistic findings on one model generalize to other LLMs, hindering robust interpretability and cross-model insights.
AI.method: Propose five axes of correspondence—functional, developmental, positional, relational, and configurational—for generalization. Empirically analyze 1-back attention heads (attending to previous tokens) across pretraining seeds for Pythia models at 14M, 70M, 160M, and 410M parameters.
AI.result: Developmental trajectories of 1-back attention show striking consistency across models; positional consistency is more limited. Seeds of larger models exhibit earlier onsets, steeper slopes, and higher peaks of 1-back attention.
AI.conclusion: Advancing generalizability in mechanistic interpretability requires mapping constitutive design properties of LLMs to their emergent behaviors and mechanisms; progress hinges on cross-model generalization grounded in these design-property mappings.

title: On the Capacity of Self-Attention
summary:
While self-attention is known to learn relations among tokens, we lack a
formal understanding of its capacity: how many distinct relations can a single
layer reliably recover for a given budget?
  To formalize this, we introduce Relational Graph Recognition (RGR), where the
key-query channel represents a graph on $m$ items with $m'$ directed edges,
and, given a context of items, must recover the neighbors of each item. We
measure resources by the total key dimension $D_K = h\,d_k$. Within this
framework, we analytically derive a capacity scaling law and validate it
empirically. We show that $D_K = \Theta(m' \log m' / d_{\text{model}})$ is both
necessary (information-theoretic lower bound) and sufficient (explicit
construction) in a broad class of graphs to recover $m'$ relations. This
scaling law directly leads to a new, capacity-based rationale for multi-head
attention that applies even when each item only attends to a single target.
When embeddings are uncompressed ($m = d_{\text{model}}$) and the graph is a
permutation, a single head suffices. However, compression ($m >
d_{\text{model}}$) forces relations into overlapping subspaces, creating
interference that a single large head cannot disentangle. Our analysis shows
that allocating a fixed $D_K$ across many small heads mitigates this
interference, increasing the number of recoverable relations. Controlled
single-layer experiments mirror the theory, revealing a sharp performance
threshold that matches the predicted capacity scaling and confirms the benefit
of distributing $D_K$ across multiple heads.
  Altogether, these results provide a concrete scaling law for self-attention
capacity and a principled design rule for allocating key-query budget across
heads.

AI.tldr: Introduces Relational Graph Recognition (RGR) to quantify self-attention capacity: derives a tight capacity law D_K = Θ(m' log m'/d_model) for recovering m' directed edges, and shows distributing the key-query budget across multiple heads mitigates interference under compression; single head suffices without compression and when embeddings are uncompressed and m = d_model.
AI.motivation: To formalize how many distinct relations a single self-attention layer can reliably recover under a given resource budget, addressing a gap in theoretical understanding and guiding architectural design.
AI.method: Analytical derivation of a capacity scaling law using information-theoretic arguments, with explicit constructions proving sufficiency; broad class of graphs (including permutations) analyzed; controlled single-layer experiments validate the threshold; comparison of compressed vs uncompressed regimes; exploration of multi-head budget allocation.
AI.result: Establishes D_K = Θ(m' log m'/d_model) as a necessary and sufficient condition to recover m' relations for many graphs; provides a capacity-based rationale for multi-head attention; shows compression introduces interference that multiple smaller heads can mitigate; empirical results reveal a sharp capacity threshold that aligns with theory.
AI.conclusion: Gives a concrete, scalable law for self-attention capacity and a practical rule for allocating key-query resources across heads, informing design choices especially under dimensional compression.

title: Graph-Theoretic Consistency for Robust and Topology-Aware Semi-Supervised Histopathology Segmentation
summary:
Semi-supervised semantic segmentation (SSSS) is vital in computational
pathology, where dense annotations are costly and limited. Existing methods
often rely on pixel-level consistency, which propagates noisy pseudo-labels and
produces fragmented or topologically invalid masks. We propose Topology Graph
Consistency (TGC), a framework that integrates graph-theoretic constraints by
aligning Laplacian spectra, component counts, and adjacency statistics between
prediction graphs and references. This enforces global topology and improves
segmentation accuracy. Experiments on GlaS and CRAG demonstrate that TGC
achieves state-of-the-art performance under 5-10% supervision and significantly
narrows the gap to full supervision. Code is available at
https://github.com/hieuphamha19/TGC.

AI.tldr: Topological graph constraints (Topology Graph Consistency, TGC) are introduced for semi-supervised semantic segmentation in pathology, enforcing global topology by aligning Laplacian spectra, component counts, and adjacency between prediction and reference graphs, yielding state-of-the-art results with limited labels.
AI.motivation: Dense, pixel-level annotations are costly in computational pathology, and pixel-consistency-based SSL often propagates noisy labels and yields fragmented or topologically invalid masks; enforcing global topology can improve segmentation quality under limited supervision.
AI.method: Construct and align prediction graphs with reference graphs by matching Laplacian spectra, component counts, and adjacency statistics, integrating these graph-theoretic constraints into the SSL framework to enforce global topology in segmentations.
AI.result: On GlaS and CRAG datasets, TGC achieves state-of-the-art performance under 5-10% supervision and significantly narrows the gap to full supervision.
AI.conclusion: Topology-aware graph constraints improve semi-supervised segmentation in computational pathology and can substantially reduce annotation needs; code is publicly released.

title: TACO-Net: Topological Signatures Triumph in 3D Object Classification
summary:
3D object classification is a crucial problem due to its significant
practical relevance in many fields, including computer vision, robotics, and
autonomous driving. Although deep learning methods applied to point clouds
sampled on CAD models of the objects and/or captured by LiDAR or RGBD cameras
have achieved remarkable success in recent years, achieving high classification
accuracy remains a challenging problem due to the unordered point clouds and
their irregularity and noise. To this end, we propose a novel state-of-the-art
(SOTA) 3D object classification technique that combines topological data
analysis with various image filtration techniques to classify objects when they
are represented using point clouds. We transform every point cloud into a
voxelized binary 3D image to extract distinguishing topological features. Next,
we train a lightweight one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D CNN)
using the extracted feature set from the training dataset. Our framework,
TACO-Net, sets a new state-of-the-art by achieving $99.05\%$ and $99.52\%$
accuracy on the widely used synthetic benchmarks ModelNet40 and ModelNet10, and
further demonstrates its robustness on the large-scale real-world OmniObject3D
dataset. When tested with ten different kinds of corrupted ModelNet40 inputs,
the proposed TACO-Net demonstrates strong resiliency overall.

AI.tldr: TACO-Net introduces a topology-informed pipeline that voxelizes point clouds, extracts topological features via filtration, and classifies with a lightweight 1D CNN, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy on ModelNet40/ModelNet10 and strong robustness to corruptions.
AI.motivation: 3D object classification faces challenges from unordered, irregular, and noisy point clouds. Conventional point-based deep nets struggle to capture global structure and are sensitive to noise. Topological data analysis (TDA) can provide robust, permutation-invariant features that encode global shape information.
AI.method: Convert each point cloud to a voxelized binary 3D image, apply topological data analysis with multiple filtration techniques to extract distinguishing topological features, and train a lightweight 1D CNN (TACO-Net) on these features for classification.
AI.result: Achieves 99.05% on ModelNet40 and 99.52% on ModelNet10, claiming state-of-the-art performance; demonstrates robustness on OmniObject3D; shows resiliency across ten corrupted ModelNet40 inputs.
AI.conclusion: The approach delivers SOTA 3D object classification by combining TDA-derived features with a compact 1D CNN, achieving high accuracy and robustness while enabling efficient deployment; supports the promise of topology-guided representations for real-world 3D data.

title: Towards Developing Standards and Guidelines for Robot Grasping and Manipulation Pipelines in the COMPARE Ecosystem
comment:
The 3rd AAAI Fall Symposium on Unifying Representations for Robot
  Application Development (UR-RAD), Arlington, VA, USA, November 2025
summary:
The COMPARE Ecosystem aims to improve the compatibility and benchmarking of
open-source products for robot manipulation through a series of activities. One
such activity is the development of standards and guidelines to specify
modularization practices at the component-level for individual modules (e.g.,
perception, grasp planning, motion planning) and integrations of components
that form robot manipulation capabilities at the pipeline-level. This paper
briefly reviews our work-in-progress to date to (1) build repositories of
open-source products to identify common characteristics of each component in
the pipeline, (2) investigate existing modular pipelines to glean best
practices, and (3) develop new modular pipelines that advance prior work while
abiding by the proposed standards and guidelines.

AI.tldr: The paper reviews ongoing COMPARE Ecosystem efforts to standardize modular components and pipelines for robot manipulation, via repositories, best-practice analysis, and development of compliant modular pipelines.
AI.motivation: To improve compatibility and benchmarking of open-source robot manipulation software by establishing component- and pipeline-level standards for modularization.
AI.method: 1) build repositories of open-source products to characterize each pipeline component; 2) examine existing modular pipelines to extract best practices; 3) develop new modular pipelines that conform to the proposed standards and guidelines.
AI.result: A progress report summarizing work-to-date: identified common characteristics of components, distilled best practices, and created new modular pipelines aligned with standards.
AI.conclusion: The work establishes groundwork for standardized modularization in robot manipulation and outlines ongoing development to expand repositories, practices, and compliant pipelines.

title: JE-IRT: A Geometric Lens on LLM Abilities through Joint Embedding Item Response Theory
summary:
Standard LLM evaluation practices compress diverse abilities into single
scores, obscuring their inherently multidimensional nature. We present JE-IRT,
a geometric item-response framework that embeds both LLMs and questions in a
shared space. For question embeddings, the direction encodes semantics and the
norm encodes difficulty, while correctness on each question is determined by
the geometric interaction between the model and question embeddings. This
geometry replaces a global ranking of LLMs with topical specialization and
enables smooth variation across related questions. Building on this framework,
our experimental results reveal that out-of-distribution behavior can be
explained through directional alignment, and that larger norms consistently
indicate harder questions. Moreover, JE-IRT naturally supports generalization:
once the space is learned, new LLMs are added by fitting a single embedding.
The learned space further reveals an LLM-internal taxonomy that only partially
aligns with human-defined subject categories. JE-IRT thus establishes a unified
and interpretable geometric lens that connects LLM abilities with the structure
of questions, offering a distinctive perspective on model evaluation and
generalization.

AI.tldr: JE-IRT introduces a shared geometric embedding space for LLMs and questions, where question direction encodes semantics and norm encodes difficulty; model correctness arises from geometric interactions, enabling multidimensional, interpretable evaluation, OOD insights, and scalable generalization.
AI.motivation: Traditional LLM evaluation collapses diverse abilities into a single score, obscuring their multidimensional nature; a unified, interpretable framework is needed to capture semantics, difficulty, and their interactions.
AI.method: Propose JE-IRT: jointly embed LLMs and questions in a common space; semantics are encoded by the direction of question embeddings while difficulty is encoded by their norm; correctness on a question is determined by geometric interaction between model and question embeddings; study out-of-distribution behavior, relation between norm and question difficulty, and generalization by adding new LLMs via a single embedding; analyze an internal taxonomy of LLM abilities.
AI.result: Directional alignment explains out-of-distribution behavior; larger norms consistently indicate harder questions; the space supports generalization by fitting a single embedding for new LLMs; an LLM-internal taxonomy emerges that only partially aligns with human-defined categories; reveals a unified geometric lens linking abilities to question structure.
AI.conclusion: JE-IRT provides an interpretable, unified geometric framework for LLM evaluation and generalization, transforming how model abilities are connected to question structure and enabling topical specialization over a single global ranking.

title: Boundary on the Table: Efficient Black-Box Decision-Based Attacks for Structured Data
summary:
Adversarial robustness in structured data remains an underexplored frontier
compared to vision and language domains. In this work, we introduce a novel
black-box, decision-based adversarial attack tailored for tabular data. Our
approach combines gradient-free direction estimation with an iterative boundary
search, enabling efficient navigation of discrete and continuous feature spaces
under minimal oracle access. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method
successfully compromises nearly the entire test set across diverse models,
ranging from classical machine learning classifiers to large language model
(LLM)-based pipelines. Remarkably, the attack achieves success rates
consistently above 90%, while requiring only a small number of queries per
instance. These results highlight the critical vulnerability of tabular models
to adversarial perturbations, underscoring the urgent need for stronger
defenses in real-world decision-making systems.

AI.tldr: Proposes a black-box, decision-based adversarial attack for tabular data that uses gradient-free direction estimation and iterative boundary search to perturb both discrete and continuous features, achieving high success rates with few queries across diverse models, including LLM-based pipelines.
AI.motivation: Adversarial robustness in structured/tabular data is underexplored compared to vision and language, yet real-world decision systems rely on tabular models; understanding attack surface and needed defenses is critical.
AI.method: A gradient-free direction estimation method operating in mixed discrete/continuous feature spaces, combined with an iterative boundary search under limited oracle access to craft perturbations that flip model decisions in a black-box, decision-based setting.
AI.result: The attack compromises a large portion of the test set across diverse models, with success rates above 90% and a small number of queries per instance, indicating a strong vulnerability of tabular models to adversarial perturbations.
AI.conclusion: Tabular models exhibit significant vulnerability to adversarial perturbations in black-box settings; there is an urgent need for robust defenses and evaluation methodologies in real-world decision-making systems.

title: A review of Recent Techniques for Person Re-Identification
summary:
Person re-identification (ReId), a crucial task in surveillance, involves
matching individuals across different camera views. The advent of Deep
Learning, especially supervised techniques like Convolutional Neural Networks
and Attention Mechanisms, has significantly enhanced person Re-ID. However, the
success of supervised approaches hinges on vast amounts of annotated data,
posing scalability challenges in data labeling and computational costs. To
address these limitations, recent research has shifted towards unsupervised
person re-identification. Leveraging abundant unlabeled data, unsupervised
methods aim to overcome the need for pairwise labelled data. Although
traditionally trailing behind supervised approaches, unsupervised techniques
have shown promising developments in recent years, signalling a narrowing
performance gap. Motivated by this evolving landscape, our survey pursues two
primary objectives. First, we review and categorize significant publications in
supervised person re-identification, providing an in-depth overview of the
current state-of-the-art and emphasizing little room for further improvement in
this domain. Second, we explore the latest advancements in unsupervised person
re-identification over the past three years, offering insights into emerging
trends and shedding light on the potential convergence of performance between
supervised and unsupervised paradigms. This dual-focus survey aims to
contribute to the evolving narrative of person re-identification, capturing
both the mature landscape of supervised techniques and the promising outcomes
in the realm of unsupervised learning.

AI.tldr: A survey contrasting supervised and unsupervised person re-identification (ReID), reviewing recent advances and highlighting the narrowing gap as unsupervised methods improve, with dual objectives: summarize supervised progress and analyze unsupervised developments over the last three years.
AI.motivation: address scalability challenges in labeling for supervised ReID and understand how unsupervised methods can leverage unlabeled data to close performance gaps.
AI.method: systematic literature review and categorization of supervised ReID publications; analysis of unsupervised ReID developments in the last three years; synthesis of trends and potential convergence.
AI.result: comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art in supervised ReID, identification of challenges and diminishing gains; insights into unsupervised progress and emerging trends toward performance parity; proposal of future research directions.
AI.conclusion: the field exhibits strong supervised performance with limited marginal gains, while unsupervised approaches are rapidly improving, suggesting a convergence path; the survey underscores the importance of scalable learning and future directions toward unified frameworks.

title: Teleoperator-Aware and Safety-Critical Adaptive Nonlinear MPC for Shared Autonomy in Obstacle Avoidance of Legged Robots
summary:
Ensuring safe and effective collaboration between humans and autonomous
legged robots is a fundamental challenge in shared autonomy, particularly for
teleoperated systems navigating cluttered environments. Conventional
shared-control approaches often rely on fixed blending strategies that fail to
capture the dynamics of legged locomotion and may compromise safety. This paper
presents a teleoperator-aware, safety-critical, adaptive nonlinear model
predictive control (ANMPC) framework for shared autonomy of quadrupedal robots
in obstacle-avoidance tasks. The framework employs a fixed arbitration weight
between human and robot actions but enhances this scheme by modeling the human
input with a noisily rational Boltzmann model, whose parameters are adapted
online using a projected gradient descent (PGD) law from observed joystick
commands. Safety is enforced through control barrier function (CBF) constraints
integrated into a computationally efficient NMPC, ensuring forward invariance
of safe sets despite uncertainty in human behavior. The control architecture is
hierarchical: a high-level CBF-based ANMPC (10 Hz) generates blended
human-robot velocity references, a mid-level dynamics-aware NMPC (60 Hz)
enforces reduced-order single rigid body (SRB) dynamics to track these
references, and a low-level nonlinear whole-body controller (500 Hz) imposes
the full-order dynamics via quadratic programming to track the mid-level
trajectories. Extensive numerical and hardware experiments, together with a
user study, on a Unitree Go2 quadrupedal robot validate the framework,
demonstrating real-time obstacle avoidance, online learning of human intent
parameters, and safe teleoperator collaboration.

AI.tldr: A teleoperator-aware, safety-critical adaptive nonlinear MPC framework for shared autonomy in quadrupedal robots, integrating online human intent learning via a noisily rational Boltzmann model, with CBF-based safety constraints in a hierarchical control stack and real-time obstacle avoidance validated on a Unitree Go2.
AI.motivation: Safe and effective human–robot collaboration for teleoperated legged locomotion in cluttered environments. Fixed arbitration in existing shared-control schemes inadequately captures legged dynamics and can compromise safety.
AI.method: A hierarchical control stack: (i) high-level 10 Hz CBF-based adaptive NMPC (ANMPC) that blends human and robot velocity references, (ii) mid-level 60 Hz dynamics-aware NMPC enforcing reduced-order SRB dynamics to track references, (iii) low-level 500 Hz whole-body controller (via QP) imposing full-order dynamics to track mid-level trajectories. Human input is modeled with a noisily rational Boltzmann model whose parameters are online-adapted via projected gradient descent from joystick data. Safety is ensured by integrating control barrier function (CBF) constraints into NMPC to maintain forward invariance of safe sets under human uncertainty.
AI.result: Extensive numerical simulations and hardware experiments, including a user study on a Unitree Go2, demonstrating real-time obstacle avoidance, online learning of human intent parameters, and safe teleoperator collaboration.
AI.conclusion: The framework achieves safe, real-time shared autonomy for teleoperated legged robots in cluttered environments, with online adaptation to human intent and robust safety guarantees; validated experimentally with real hardware.

title: Not only a helper, but also a teacher: Interactive LLM Cascade
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) vary widely in their capabilities, with larger
models often having better performance but higher cost: choosing an LLM model
often involves trading off performance and cost. The LLM Cascade is a paradigm
that defers difficult queries from weak/cheap to strong/expensive models. This
approach is nonadaptive: the deferral decision is trained offline. When
confronted with similar or repeated queries, the LLM Cascade may then
repeatedly consult the expensive model and incur higher cost. To improve the
cascading efficiency, we propose Inter-Cascade, an online and interactive LLM
Cascade that extends the role of strong model from a backup helper to a
long-term teacher. In our system, when a strong model resolves a difficult
query, it also distills its solution into a generalized, reusable
problem-solving strategy that boosts the weak model on subsequent queries.
Adding strategies to queries enables the weak model to dynamically improve its
performance over time, avoiding computationally and time-intensive fine-tuning.
Empirically, compared with standard LLM Cascade baselines across multiple
benchmarks, the Inter-Cascade significantly improves the accuracy of the weak
model (by up to 33.06 absolute percentage points) and the overall system (by up
to 5.53 absolute percentage points), while reducing the calls to strong models
(by up to 48.05% relative reduction) and saving the corresponding fees (by up
to 49.63% relative reduction). Inter-Cascade demonstrates the effective
in-context knowledge transfer between LLMs, and provides a general, scalable
framework applicable to both open-source and API-based LLMs.

AI.tldr: Inter-Cascade improves LLM cascade efficiency by online learning where a strong model distills problem-solving strategies to the weak model, reducing reliance on expensive models and improving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Traditional LLM cascades are offline and nonadaptive, deferring difficult queries to stronger models but potentially repeatedly invoking the expensive model for similar queries. There's a need for online, reusable knowledge transfer to the weak model to reduce cost and improve performance over time.
AI.method: An online, interactive cascade where a strong model not only solves difficult queries but also distills its solution into generalized, reusable problem-solving strategies that the weak model can apply on future queries. This in-context knowledge transfer avoids fine-tuning and applies across open-source and API-based LLMs, reducing strong-model calls while boosting weak-model accuracy.
AI.result: Compared with standard LLM Cascade baselines across multiple benchmarks, Inter-Cascade improves the weak model's accuracy by up to 33.06 percentage points and the overall system by up to 5.53 percentage points, while reducing strong-model calls by up to 48.05% and saving fees by up to 49.63%.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates effective in-context knowledge transfer between LLMs and provides a general, scalable framework for LLM cascades applicable to both open-source and API-based LLMs.

title: Adaptive Margin RLHF via Preference over Preferences
summary:
Margin-based optimization is fundamental to improving generalization and
robustness in classification tasks. In the context of reward model learning
from preferences within Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF),
existing methods typically rely on no margins, fixed margins, or margins that
are simplistic functions of preference ratings. However, such formulations
often fail to account for the varying strengths of different preferences, for
example some preferences are associated with larger margins between responses,
or they rely on noisy margin information derived from ratings. We argue that
modeling the strength of preferences can lead to better generalization and more
faithful alignment. Furthermore, many existing methods that use adaptive
margins assume access to accurate preference scores, which can be difficult for
humans to provide reliably. We propose an approach that leverages preferences
over preferences, that is annotations indicating which of two preferences
reflects a stronger distinction. We use this ordinal signal to infer adaptive
margins on a per-datapoint basis. We introduce an extension to Direct
Preference Optimization (DPO), DPO-PoP, that incorporates adaptive margins from
preference-over-preference supervision, enabling improved discriminative and
generative performance. Empirically, our method outperforms vanilla DPO, DPO
with fixed margins, and DPO with ground-truth margins on the UltraFeedback
dataset. Additionally, we show that there is a tradeoff between discriminative
and generative performance: improving test classification accuracy,
particularly by correctly labeling weaker preferences at the expense of
stronger ones, can lead to a decline in generative quality. To navigate this
tradeoff, we propose two sampling strategies to gather
preference-over-preference labels: one favoring discriminative performance and
one favoring generative performance.

AI.tldr: Introduce DPO-PoP, an adaptive-margin extension to Direct Preference Optimization that uses preference-over-preference signals to infer per-datapoint margins, boosting discriminative and generative performance on UltraFeedback; reveals a discriminative–generative tradeoff and offers two sampling strategies to collect PoP labels.
AI.motivation: Current RLHF margin formulations are static, rely on ratings, or ignore strength of preferences, leading to suboptimal generalization and misalignment. Preference strength is heterogeneous and noisy; a per-example adaptive margin informed by ordinal preference-over-preference signals can improve learning.
AI.method: Extend Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) to DPO-PoP by incorporating adaptive margins inferred from preference-over-preference supervision. Use ordinal PoP labels to infer per-example margins. Propose two sampling strategies: one prioritizing discriminative performance, the other prioritizing generative performance.
AI.result: DPO-PoP outperforms vanilla DPO, DPO with fixed margins, and DPO with ground-truth margins on UltraFeedback. Identifies a discriminative–generative tradeoff: improving classification accuracy on weaker preferences may reduce generative quality. Provides two PoP-based sampling strategies to navigate this tradeoff.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive margins learned from preference-over-preference supervision enhance alignment and generalization in RLHF, but balancing discriminative and generative objectives is crucial. The paper offers practical strategies to collect PoP signals to steer this balance.

title: Sequential Token Merging: Revisiting Hidden States
summary:
Vision Mambas (ViMs) achieve remarkable success with sub-quadratic
complexity, but their efficiency remains constrained by quadratic token scaling
with image resolution. While existing methods address token redundancy, they
overlook ViMs' intrinsic Limited Directional Sequential Dependence (LDSD) - a
critical information flow mechanism revealed in our analysis. We further
identify Mamba's selective scan enables gradual information aggregation in
hidden states. Based on these insights, we propose Sequential Token Merging
(STM), featuring: 1) Bidirectional nearest neighbor merging to preserve
sequential dependencies through symmetric spatial aggregation, and 2) Hidden
states protection to stabilize the hidden states around the class token. STM
strategically leverages Mamba's layer-wise loss convergence to convert temporal
forgetfulness into stability. Experiments demonstrate STM's superiority: 1.0%
accuracy drop for ViM-Ti at 20% token reduction, and only 1.4% degradation for
ViM-S at 40% reduction. Our method achieves state-of-the-art efficiency with
minimal complexity, while providing new insights into state-space model
dynamics. Codes will be released soon.

AI.tldr: Sequential Token Merging (STM) reduces token counts in Vision Mambas (ViMs) by bidirectional nearest-neighbor merging and hidden-state protection, preserving sequential dependencies and stabilizing the class token. It leverages LDSD/hidden-state dynamics to achieve strong efficiency with minimal accuracy loss.
AI.motivation: Vision Mambas offer sub-quadratic complexity but still suffer from quadratic token scaling with image resolution. There is a gap: token redundancy is addressed in part, but the intrinsic Limited Directional Sequential Dependence (LDSD) and selective scan allow gradual information aggregation in hidden states. The goal is to exploit these properties to reduce tokens without harming performance, improving efficiency and providing insights into state-space dynamics.
AI.method: Sequential Token Merging (STM) introduces: (1) Bidirectional nearest-neighbor merging to preserve sequential dependencies through symmetric spatial aggregation; (2) Hidden states protection to stabilize hidden states around the class token; STM leverages Mamba's layer-wise loss convergence to convert temporal forgetfulness into stability.
