AI.tldr: A novel cognitive-imagery benchmark shows state-of-the-art LLMs can solve imagery-dependent tasks using text-based reasoning, outperforming average humans; performance improves with more reasoning tokens, suggesting emergent cognitive capacity and raising questions about mental imagery representations.
AI.motivation: To probe whether large language models possess emergent cognitive capabilities beyond those learned from training data, by testing a task traditionally thought to require visual mental imagery, and to establish a benchmark that challenges non-imagistic reasoning in LLMs.
AI.method: Develop dozens of novel items from a classic mental imagery task. Provide text-only instructions to LLMs to perform specified transformations and report the final object. Establish a human baseline by testing 100 participants on the same task. Evaluate reasoning models at different levels of reasoning, varying the amount of reasoning tokens.
AI.result: Best LLMs performed significantly above average human performance. Higher reasoning-token allocation yielded stronger performance, indicating that more extensive internal deliberation benefits task success. The findings suggest LLMs can complete imagery-dependent tasks despite non-pictorial architectures.
AI.conclusion: The study reveals emergent cognitive capacities in LLMs for imagery-dependent tasks, offers a new challenging benchmark for model improvement, and rekindles debate on how visual imagery is represented, arguing that propositional or non-imagistic reasoning may suffice.

title: Compute-Optimal Quantization-Aware Training
summary:
Quantization-aware training (QAT) is a leading technique for improving the
accuracy of quantized neural networks. Previous work has shown that decomposing
training into a full-precision (FP) phase followed by a QAT phase yields
superior accuracy compared to QAT alone. However, the optimal allocation of
compute between the FP and QAT phases remains unclear. We conduct extensive
experiments with various compute budgets, QAT bit widths, and model sizes from
86.0M to 2.2B to investigate how different QAT durations impact final
performance. We demonstrate that, contrary to previous findings, the
loss-optimal ratio of QAT to FP training increases with the total amount of
compute. Moreover, the optimal fraction can be accurately predicted for a wide
range of model sizes and quantization widths using the
tokens-per-parameter-byte statistic. From experimental data, we derive a loss
scaling law that predicts both optimal QAT ratios and final model performance
across different QAT/FP compute allocation strategies and QAT bit widths. We
use the scaling law to make further predictions, which we verify
experimentally, including which QAT bit width is optimal under a given memory
constraint and how QAT accuracy with different bit widths compares to
full-precision model accuracy. Additionally, we propose a novel cooldown and
QAT fusion approach that performs learning rate decay jointly with
quantization-aware training, eliminating redundant full-precision model updates
and achieving significant compute savings. These findings provide practical
insights into efficient QAT planning and enable the training of higher-quality
quantized models with the same compute budget.

AI.tldr: Quantization-aware training (QAT) efficiency: learn how to allocate compute between full-precision and QAT, derive a predictive loss-scaling law and a tokens-per-parameter-byte statistic, and introduce a cooldown+QAT fusion to save compute while achieving higher-quality quantized models.
AI.motivation: Understand the optimal split of compute between full-precision (FP) training and QAT to maximize final accuracy of quantized neural networks under a fixed compute budget.
AI.method: Conduct extensive experiments across multiple compute budgets, QAT bit widths, and model sizes (86M to 2.2B parameters). Derive a loss-scaling law predicting optimal QAT ratios and final performance. Introduce the tokens-per-parameter-byte statistic to predict QAT planning across sizes/widths. Propose a cooldown and QAT fusion technique that learns rate decay jointly with QAT to save compute. Validate predictions experimentally.
AI.result: Findings show the loss-optimal QAT/FP ratio increases with total compute (contrary to some prior work). The scaling law can predict the optimal QAT ratio and final performance across allocation strategies and QAT widths. It informs which QAT bit width is optimal under memory constraints and how QAT accuracy with different widths compares to FP accuracy. The proposed cooldown+QAT fusion yields significant compute savings by eliminating redundant FP updates and integrating learning-rate decay with QAT.
AI.conclusion: Provides practical guidance for efficient QAT planning, enabling higher-quality quantized models under the same compute budget and offering a predictive framework for choosing QAT bit widths and allocation.

title: MILR: Improving Multimodal Image Generation via Test-Time Latent Reasoning
summary:
Reasoning-augmented machine learning systems have shown improved performance
in various domains, including image generation. However, existing
reasoning-based methods for image generation either restrict reasoning to a
single modality (image or text) or rely on high-quality reasoning data for
fine-tuning. To tackle these limitations, we propose MILR, a test-time method
that jointly reasons over image and text in a unified latent vector space.
Reasoning in MILR is performed by searching through vector representations of
discrete image and text tokens. Practically, this is implemented via the policy
gradient method, guided by an image quality critic. We instantiate MILR within
the unified multimodal understanding and generation (MUG) framework that
natively supports language reasoning before image synthesis and thus
facilitates cross-modal reasoning. The intermediate model outputs, which are to
be optimized, serve as the unified latent space, enabling MILR to operate
entirely at test time. We evaluate MILR on GenEval, T2I-CompBench, and WISE,
achieving state-of-the-art results on all benchmarks. Notably, on
knowledge-intensive WISE, MILR attains an overall score of 0.63, improving over
the baseline by 80%. Our further analysis indicates that joint reasoning in the
unified latent space is the key to its strong performance. Moreover, our
qualitative studies reveal MILR's non-trivial ability in temporal and cultural
reasoning, highlighting the efficacy of our reasoning method.

AI.tldr: MILR proposes a test-time, cross-modal reasoning method that searches a unified latent space for image and text tokens, guided by an image-quality critic, achieving state-of-the-art results without fine-tuning across multiple benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current reasoning-based image generation methods are constrained to a single modality (image or text) or require high-quality reasoning data for fine-tuning. There is a need for a test-time, cross-modal reasoning approach that can leverage both modalities in a unified latent space to improve synthesis, especially for knowledge-intensive tasks.
AI.method: MILR performs policy-gradient guided search over discrete image and text token vectors within a unified latent space. It is implemented within the MUG framework that enables language-before-image synthesis, uses intermediate model outputs as the latent space, and operates entirely at test time with an image quality critic guiding optimization.
AI.result: MILR achieves state-of-the-art on GenEval, T2I-CompBench, and WISE, with a WISE score of 0.63 (about 80% improvement over the baseline). The results indicate that joint reasoning in the unified latent space is crucial for performance, and qualitative analysis shows temporal and cultural reasoning capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Cross-modal, test-time reasoning in a unified latent space is effective for image generation, enabling robust, knowledge-intensive reasoning without finetuning. MILR’s approach highlights the power of unified representations and careful guidance (image quality critic) for cross-modal synthesis.

title: Robot Learning from Any Images
summary:
We introduce RoLA, a framework that transforms any in-the-wild image into an
interactive, physics-enabled robotic environment. Unlike previous methods, RoLA
operates directly on a single image without requiring additional hardware or
digital assets. Our framework democratizes robotic data generation by producing
massive visuomotor robotic demonstrations within minutes from a wide range of
image sources, including camera captures, robotic datasets, and Internet
images. At its core, our approach combines a novel method for single-view
physical scene recovery with an efficient visual blending strategy for
photorealistic data collection. We demonstrate RoLA's versatility across
applications like scalable robotic data generation and augmentation, robot
learning from Internet images, and single-image real-to-sim-to-real systems for
manipulators and humanoids. Video results are available at
https://sihengz02.github.io/RoLA .

AI.tldr: RoLA converts a single image into a photorealistic, interactive robotic environment, enabling rapid visuomotor data generation without extra hardware.
AI.motivation: Robotics data collection is bottlenecked by the need for large, labeled visuomotor datasets and specialized hardware; existing methods rely on multiple views or assets. RoLA aims to democratize data generation by leveraging abundant single images from diverse sources (camera captures, datasets, Internet) to create scalable, interactive environments.
AI.method: RoLA introduces a single-view physical scene recovery method plus an efficient visual blending technique to construct physics-enabled environments from a single image. This pipeline yields photorealistic data and rapid generation of robot demonstrations (minutes) without additional hardware or digital assets, applicable to manipulators and humanoids and across image sources.
AI.result: Demonstrates versatility in applications such as scalable robotic data generation and augmentation, learning from Internet images, and single-image real-to-sim-to-real pipelines. Video results are provided at the project page.
AI.conclusion: RoLA democratizes robotic data generation by enabling rapid creation of rich visuomotor demonstrations from a single image, reducing hardware and asset requirements while broadening applicability to various robots and data sources.

title: AttAnchor: Guiding Cross-Modal Token Alignment in VLMs with Attention Anchors
summary:
A fundamental reason for the dominance of attention over RNNs and LSTMs in
LLMs is its ability to capture long-range dependencies by modeling direct
interactions between all tokens, overcoming the sequential limitations of
recurrent architectures. Similarly, a key reason why today's vision language
models (VLMs) hallucinate and underperform pure language models is that they
rely on direct concatenation of image and text tokens with a modality-blinded
positional encoding, which conveniently adopts the pretrained LLM backbone but
forces unnecessary long-distance attention between semantically related tokens
across modalities. This underscores the urgent need for mechanisms that
efficiently enhance token locality and cross-modal alignment. In response, we
propose Attention Anchor, a parameter-free framework that efficiently groups
semantically similar tokens across modalities, improving cross-modal locality.
By inserting text tokens near relevant visual patches, we create semantic
signposts that reveal true content-based cross-modal attention scores, guiding
the model to focus on the correct image regions for tasks such as VQA, MMBench
and POPE. This improves answer accuracy and reduces hallucinations without
disrupting the prompt's semantic flow. AttAnchor achieves improvements across
13 out of 15 different metrics and benchmarks, including up to 32% gains on
reasoning tasks and up to 15% improvements on hallucination benchmarks.
AttAnchor enables TinyLLaVA 1B to outperform much larger models like LLaVA 7B
and QwenVL 3B on POPE with only 0.1% inference time overhead. To the best of
our knowledge, this work is among the first to investigate mixed-modal token
grouping, where text and image tokens are clustered jointly into shared groups
rather than being grouped within a single modality or merely aligned post-hoc
with additional alignment losses.

AI.tldr: Attention Anchor (AttAnchor) is a parameter-free, mixed-modal token grouping framework that enhances cross-modal locality by clustering semantically similar text and image tokens, inserting semantic signposts near relevant visual patches to guide cross-modal attention. It improves VLM tasks with reduced hallucinations, achieving gains on multiple benchmarks with minimal latency overhead; notably, TinyLLaVA 1B surpasses larger models on POPE with only 0.1% overhead.
AI.motivation: Address the limitations of cross-modal attention in vision-language models, where concatenating image and text tokens with modality-blind positional encodings leads to long-distance, semantically weak attention and hallucinations. There is a need for mechanisms that preserve prompt flow while improving local, semantically grounded cross-modal interactions.
AI.method: Propose Attention Anchor, a parameter-free framework that jointly groups text and image tokens into shared semantic clusters. It inserts text tokens near relevant visual patches to create semantic signposts, revealing content-based cross-modal attention scores and guiding the model to focus on correct image regions. The grouping is mixed-modal (text+image) rather than modality-isolated, and aims to improve locality without adding alignment losses or trainable parameters.
AI.result: AttAnchor yields improvements on 13 of 15 metrics/benchmarks, with up to 32% gains on reasoning tasks and about 15% improvements on hallucinatio n benchmarks. TinyLLaVA 1B outperforms LLaVA 7B and QwenVL 3B on POPE with only 0.1% inference-time overhead.
AI.conclusion: This work is among the first to investigate mixed-modal token grouping and demonstrates that parameter-free, cross-modal locality improvements can boost reasoning and reduce hallucinations while maintaining prompt coherence, suggesting a promising direction for efficient VLM improvements.

title: Understanding SOAP from the Perspective of Gradient Whitening
summary:
Shampoo with Adam in the Preconditioner's eigenbasis (SOAP) has recently
emerged as a promising optimization algorithm for neural network training,
achieving superior training efficiency over both Adam and Shampoo in language
modeling tasks. In this work, we analyze Adam, Shampoo, and SOAP from the
perspective of gradient whitening, interpreting their preconditioners as
approximations to the whitening matrix, which captures second-order curvature
information. We further establish a theoretical equivalence between idealized
versions of SOAP and Shampoo under the Kronecker product assumption. To
empirically evaluate these insights, we reproduce the language modeling
experiments using nanoGPT and grayscale image colorization. Our results show
that SOAP exhibits similar convergence rate as Shampoo, and no significant
advantage over both Adam and Shampoo in the final loss achieved, which aligns
with their equivalence in theory.

AI.tldr: SOAP's empirical gains arise from faster convergence rather than a lower final loss; theoretically, idealized SOAP and Shampoo are equivalent under a Kronecker-product assumption, linking their preconditioners to gradient whitening.
AI.motivation: Understand how Adam, Shampoo, and SOAP relate as gradient whitening preconditioners and whether SOAP offers a real advantage beyond convergence speed.
AI.method: Interpret preconditioners as approximations to a whitening matrix; prove equivalence between idealized SOAP and Shampoo under Kronecker-product structure; reproduce language-model (nanoGPT) and grayscale colorization experiments to compare convergence dynamics and final loss.
AI.result: SOAP achieves similar convergence rate to Shampoo, but does not surpass Adam or Shampoo in final loss; empirical findings align with the theoretical equivalence under the Kronecker assumption.
AI.conclusion: Under the Kronecker-product framework, SOAP and Shampoo are effectively equivalent in objective optimization; practical advantages of SOAP are limited to training dynamics rather than superior final performance.

title: UESA-Net: U-Shaped Embedded Multidirectional Shrinkage Attention Network for Ultrasound Nodule Segmentation
summary:
Background: Breast and thyroid cancers pose an increasing public-health
burden. Ultrasound imaging is a cost-effective, real-time modality for lesion
detection and segmentation, yet suffers from speckle noise, overlapping
structures, and weak global-local feature interactions. Existing networks
struggle to reconcile high-level semantics with low-level spatial details. We
aim to develop a segmentation framework that bridges the semantic gap between
global context and local detail in noisy ultrasound images.
  Methods: We propose UESA-Net, a U-shaped network with multidirectional
shrinkage attention. The encoder-decoder architecture captures long-range
dependencies and fine-grained structures of lesions. Within each encoding
block, attention modules operate along horizontal, vertical, and depth
directions to exploit spatial details, while a shrinkage (threshold) strategy
integrates prior knowledge and local features. The decoder mirrors the encoder
but applies a pairwise shrinkage mechanism, combining prior low-level physical
cues with corresponding encoder features to enhance context modeling.
  Results: On two public datasets - TN3K (3493 images) and BUSI (780 images) -
UESA-Net achieved state-of-the-art performance with intersection-over-union
(IoU) scores of 0.8487 and 0.6495, respectively.
  Conclusions: UESA-Net effectively aggregates multidirectional spatial
information and prior knowledge to improve robustness and accuracy in breast
and thyroid ultrasound segmentation, demonstrating superior performance to
existing methods on multiple benchmarks.

AI.tldr: UESA-Net is a U-Net variant for breast and thyroid ultrasound segmentation that uses multidirectional shrinkage attention to fuse global context with local details, achieving state-of-the-art IoU on TN3K and BUSI.
AI.motivation: Ultrasound suffers from speckle noise and weak global-local feature interactions; there is a semantic gap between global context and local detail; need architecture that reconciles high-level semantics with low-level spatial cues.
AI.method: A U-shaped encoder-decoder network with multidirectional shrinkage attention. Within each encoding block, attention modules operate along horizontal, vertical, and depth directions to capture spatial details; a shrinkage threshold strategy integrates prior knowledge with local features. The decoder uses a pairwise shrinkage mechanism to merge prior low-level cues with encoder features, enabling better context modeling.
AI.result: On TN3K (3493 images) IoU 0.8487; on BUSI (780 images) IoU 0.6495; reported as state-of-the-art performance.
AI.conclusion: UESA-Net aggregations of multidirectional spatial information and prior knowledge improve robustness and accuracy in breast and thyroid ultrasound segmentation, outperforming existing methods on benchmarks.

title: Safe Task Space Synchronization with Time-Delayed Information
summary:
In this paper, an adaptive controller is designed for the synchronization of
the trajectory of a robot with unknown kinematics and dynamics to that of the
current human trajectory in the task space using the delayed human trajectory
information. The communication time delay may be a result of various factors
that arise in human-robot collaboration tasks, such as sensor processing or
fusion to estimate trajectory/intent, network delays, or computational
limitations. The developed adaptive controller uses Barrier Lyapunov Function
(BLF) to constrain the Cartesian coordinates of the robot to ensure safety, an
ICL-based adaptive law to account for the unknown kinematics, and a
gradient-based adaptive law to estimate unknown dynamics. Barrier
Lyapunov-Krasovskii (LK) functionals are used for the stability analysis to
show that the synchronization and parameter estimation errors remain
semi-globally uniformly ultimately bounded (SGUUB). The simulation results
based on a human-robot synchronization scenario with time delay are provided to
demonstrate the effectiveness of the designed synchronization controller with
safety constraints.

AI.tldr: Adaptive controller synchronizes robot trajectory to a human's in the presence of unknown kinematics/dynamics and time-delayed information, enforcing safety with Barrier Lyapunov constraints and proving semi-global stability via Lyapunov–Krasovskii analysis, validated by simulations.
AI.motivation: Enable safe and robust human–robot collaboration where the robot's kinematics/dynamics are not fully known and communication delays exist, requiring guaranteed safety and stable synchronization to the human trajectory.
AI.method: Propose an adaptive controller using Barrier Lyapunov Function (BLF) to bound Cartesian position for safety, an ICL-based adaptive law to handle unknown kinematics, and a gradient-based adaptive law to estimate unknown dynamics. Stability is analyzed with Barrier Lyapunov–Krasovskii functionals to prove SGUUB of synchronization and parameter estimation errors.
AI.result: Simulation studies of a human–robot synchronization scenario with time delay demonstrate effective synchronization under safety constraints and bounded/semiglobal parameter estimation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed BLF-based adaptive controller with LK stability analysis achieves safe, delayed synchronization of a robot to a human trajectory under unknown kinematics/dynamics, highlighting its potential for safe HRI; future work may include experimental validation.

title: Exploring LLM-based Frameworks for Fault Diagnosis
summary:
Large Language Model (LLM)-based systems present new opportunities for
autonomous health monitoring in sensor-rich industrial environments. This study
explores the potential of LLMs to detect and classify faults directly from
sensor data, while producing inherently explainable outputs through natural
language reasoning. We systematically evaluate how LLM-system architecture
(single-LLM vs. multi-LLM), input representations (raw vs. descriptive
statistics), and context window size affect diagnostic performance. Our
findings show that LLM systems perform most effectively when provided with
summarized statistical inputs, and that systems with multiple LLMs using
specialized prompts offer improved sensitivity for fault classification
compared to single-LLM systems. While LLMs can produce detailed and
human-readable justifications for their decisions, we observe limitations in
their ability to adapt over time in continual learning settings, often
struggling to calibrate predictions during repeated fault cycles. These
insights point to both the promise and the current boundaries of LLM-based
systems as transparent, adaptive diagnostic tools in complex environments.

AI.tldr: LLM-based fault detection in sensor-rich industrial settings can achieve strong performance when fed summarized statistical inputs; employing multiple specialized LLMs improves fault classification sensitivity; while outputs can be explainable, continual learning and calibration across repeated fault cycles remain challenging.
AI.motivation: To enable autonomous, transparent fault diagnosis in harsh, sensor-rich industrial environments by leveraging LLMs to interpret data and generate natural-language explanations.
AI.method: Systematic evaluation across (a) LLM architecture (single vs. multi-LLM), (b) input representation (raw sensor data vs. descriptive statistics), and (c) context window size, assessing diagnostic performance and explainability.
AI.result: Best performance arises with summarized statistical inputs; multi-LLM systems with specialized prompts show increased sensitivity for fault classification compared to single-LLM systems; LLMs can provide detailed, human-readable justifications; limitations include limited adaptability and calibration in continual learning contexts across repeated fault cycles.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based diagnostic systems hold promise as transparent, adaptive tools in complex environments, but practical deployment must address current boundaries in continual learning and prediction calibration over time.

title: SINQ: Sinkhorn-Normalized Quantization for Calibration-Free Low-Precision LLM Weights
summary:
Post-training quantization has emerged as the most widely used strategy for
deploying large language models at low precision. Still, current methods show
perplexity degradation at bit-widths less than or equal to 4, partly because
representing outliers causes precision issues in parameters that share the same
scales as these outliers. This problem is especially pronounced for
calibration-free, uniform quantization methods. We introduce SINQ to augment
existing post-training quantizers with an additional second-axis scale factor
and a fast Sinkhorn-Knopp-style algorithm that finds scales to normalize
per-row and per-column variances, thereby minimizing a novel per-matrix proxy
target for quantization: the matrix imbalance. Our method has no interactions
between layers and can be trivially applied to new architectures to quantize
any linear layers. We evaluate our method on the Qwen3 model family and
DeepSeek-V2.5. SINQ improves WikiText2 and C4 perplexity significantly against
uncalibrated uniform quantization baselines and can be further enhanced by
combining it with calibration and non-uniform quantization levels. Code to
reproduce the results of this work and to easily quantize models using SINQ is
available at https://github.com/huawei-csl/SINQ.

AI.tldr: SINQ adds a second-axis scale and a Sinkhorn-Knopp–style normalization to post-training quantization, reducing matrix imbalance by aligning per-row/per-column variances; it improves perplexity over uncalibrated uniform PTQ on LLMs (Qwen3, DeepSeek-V2.5) and is easy to apply without inter-layer interactions; code is released.
AI.motivation: Calibration-free uniform PTQ suffers from perplexity degradation at low bit-widths due to outliers sharing scales with normal weights; there is a need for a scalable, layer-agnostic approach to stabilize quantization without per-layer calibration.
AI.method: Introduce a second-axis scale factor for weights. Use a fast Sinkhorn-Knopp–style algorithm to optimize scales to normalize per-row and per-column variances, minimizing a per-matrix proxy objective called matrix imbalance; no inter-layer coupling; applicable to quantizing any linear layers in new architectures.
AI.result: Significant perplexity improvements on WikiText2 and C4 against uncalibrated uniform PTQ baselines for Qwen3 family and DeepSeek-V2.5; gains can be further enhanced by combining with calibration and non-uniform quantization levels; code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: SINQ provides a simple, effective PTQ enhancement that targets matrix imbalance, is broadly applicable to linear layers, and can be combined with calibration or non-uniform quantization for additional gains.

title: PartCo: Part-Level Correspondence Priors Enhance Category Discovery
summary:
Generalized Category Discovery (GCD) aims to identify both known and novel
categories within unlabeled data by leveraging a set of labeled examples from
known categories. Existing GCD methods primarily depend on semantic labels and
global image representations, often overlooking the detailed part-level cues
that are crucial for distinguishing closely related categories. In this paper,
we introduce PartCo, short for Part-Level Correspondence Prior, a novel
framework that enhances category discovery by incorporating part-level visual
feature correspondences. By leveraging part-level relationships, PartCo
captures finer-grained semantic structures, enabling a more nuanced
understanding of category relationships. Importantly, PartCo seamlessly
integrates with existing GCD methods without requiring significant
modifications. Our extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets
demonstrate that PartCo significantly improves the performance of current GCD
approaches, achieving state-of-the-art results by bridging the gap between
semantic labels and part-level visual compositions, thereby setting new
benchmarks for GCD. Project page: https://visual-ai.github.io/partco

AI.tldr: PartCo introduces Part-Level Correspondence Priors to Generalized Category Discovery, leveraging part-level visual relationships to improve fine-grained categorization and lift current GCD methods without major changes.
AI.motivation: Current GCD methods rely on semantic labels and global image features, which miss fine-grained part-level cues needed to distinguish closely related categories.
AI.method: Propose PartCo to incorporate part-level correspondences as priors into existing GCD frameworks, enhancing finer-grained semantic structure while compatible with current methods without significant modification.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across multiple benchmarks show PartCo improves existing GCD approaches and achieves state-of-the-art results by aligning semantic labels with part-level visual compositions.
AI.conclusion: PartCo bridges semantic labels and part-level visual cues, providing a plug-in improvement for GCD that yields notable performance gains and sets new benchmarks.

title: UniPrototype: Humn-Robot Skill Learning with Uniform Prototypes
summary:
Data scarcity remains a fundamental challenge in robot learning. While human
demonstrations benefit from abundant motion capture data and vast internet
resources, robotic manipulation suffers from limited training examples. To
bridge this gap between human and robot manipulation capabilities, we propose
UniPrototype, a novel framework that enables effective knowledge transfer from
human to robot domains via shared motion primitives. ur approach makes three
key contributions: (1) We introduce a compositional prototype discovery
mechanism with soft assignments, enabling multiple primitives to co-activate
and thus capture blended and hierarchical skills; (2) We propose an adaptive
prototype selection strategy that automatically adjusts the number of
prototypes to match task complexity, ensuring scalable and efficient
representation; (3) We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through
extensive experiments in both simulation environments and real-world robotic
systems. Our results show that UniPrototype successfully transfers human
manipulation knowledge to robots, significantly improving learning efficiency
and task performance compared to existing approaches.The code and dataset will
be released upon acceptance at an anonymous repository.

AI.tldr: UniPrototype learns transferable human-to-robot manipulation via a flexible set of motion primitives, using soft, compositional prototypes and adaptive prototype counts to improve learning efficiency and task performance.
AI.motivation: Robot manipulation suffers from data scarcity; abundant human motion data and web resources exist. Bridging this gap enables scalable transfer of human manipulation skills to robots.
AI.method: Introduces a compositional prototype discovery with soft assignments allowing co-activation of multiple primitives; implements an adaptive prototype selection strategy to automatically adjust the number of prototypes to task complexity; validates through extensive simulations and real-world robotic experiments.
AI.result: The approach improves learning efficiency and task performance compared to existing methods, demonstrating successful transfer of human manipulation knowledge to robots.
AI.conclusion: UniPrototype provides a scalable, adaptable framework for cross-domain knowledge transfer via shared motion primitives; code and dataset will be released.

title: Transferring Vision-Language-Action Models to Industry Applications: Architectures, Performance, and Challenges
comment:
Accepted to IAI 2025 (International Conference on Industrial
  Artificial Intelligence), Shenyang, China, Aug 21 - 24, 2025. Preprint
  (before IEEE copyright transfer)
summary:
The application of artificial intelligence (AI) in industry is accelerating
the shift from traditional automation to intelligent systems with perception
and cognition. Vision language-action (VLA) models have been a key paradigm in
AI to unify perception, reasoning, and control. Has the performance of the VLA
models met the industrial requirements? In this paper, from the perspective of
industrial deployment, we compare the performance of existing state-of-the-art
VLA models in industrial scenarios and analyze the limitations of VLA models
for real-world industrial deployment from the perspectives of data collection
and model architecture. The results show that the VLA models retain their
ability to perform simple grasping tasks even in industrial settings after
fine-tuning. However, there is much room for performance improvement in complex
industrial environments, diverse object categories, and high precision placing
tasks. Our findings provide practical insight into the adaptability of VLA
models for industrial use and highlight the need for task-specific enhancements
to improve their robustness, generalization, and precision.

AI.tldr: VLA models show potential for simple grasping in industrial settings after fine-tuning but struggle with complex environments, diverse objects, and high-precision placing; deployment is limited by data collection and model architecture; task-specific enhancements are needed.
AI.motivation: Assess industrial readiness of Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models and identify gaps to guide practical deployment in real-world industry.
AI.method: Empirical comparison of state-of-the-art VLA models in industrial scenarios; analysis of limitations from data collection and architecture perspectives; evaluation of fine-tuning effects on grasping tasks.
AI.result: VLA models retain the ability for simple grasping after fine-tuning in industrial settings; performance gaps remain for complex environments, diverse object categories, and high-precision placing; significant room for improvement; practical deployment requires task-specific enhancements to improve robustness, generalization, and precision.
AI.conclusion: VLA models are adaptable to industrial use but are not yet robust enough for broad deployment; progress hinges on better data strategies, architectural adjustments, and task-specific modules to boost robustness, generalization, and precision.

title: Meta-Learning Fourier Neural Operators for Hessian Inversion and Enhanced Variational Data Assimilation
comment:
6 pages, 2 figures, Machine Learning and the Physical Sciences
  Workshop, (NeurIPS 2025)
summary:
Data assimilation (DA) is crucial for enhancing solutions to partial
differential equations (PDEs), such as those in numerical weather prediction,
by optimizing initial conditions using observational data. Variational DA
methods are widely used in oceanic and atmospheric forecasting, but become
computationally expensive, especially when Hessian information is involved. To
address this challenge, we propose a meta-learning framework that employs the
Fourier Neural Operator (FNO) to approximate the inverse Hessian operator
across a family of DA problems, thereby providing an effective initialization
for the conjugate gradient (CG) method. Numerical experiments on a linear
advection equation demonstrate that the resulting FNO-CG approach reduces the
average relative error by $62\%$ and the number of iterations by $17\%$
compared to the standard CG. These improvements are most pronounced in
ill-conditioned scenarios, highlighting the robustness and efficiency of FNO-CG
for challenging DA problems.

AI.tldr: Meta-learning with Fourier Neural Operator to approximate inverse Hessian in data assimilation, providing CG initialization; yields lower error and fewer iterations, especially in ill-conditioned problems.
AI.motivation: Variational data assimilation is powerful but computationally expensive due to Hessian operations; a fast, robust initialization can dramatically reduce CG iterations.
AI.method: Train/learn a Fourier Neural Operator to emulate the inverse Hessian operator across a family of data-assimilation problems, using it to warm-start CG in variational DA.
AI.result: In linear advection experiments, the FNO-CG method reduces average relative error by 62% and CG iterations by 17%.
AI.conclusion: FNO-CG offers robustness and efficiency for challenging, ill-conditioned DA problems, suggesting meta-learned Hessian approximations as a practical acceleration for variational DA.

title: DEFT: Decompositional Efficient Fine-Tuning for Text-to-Image Models
summary:
Efficient fine-tuning of pre-trained Text-to-Image (T2I) models involves
adjusting the model to suit a particular task or dataset while minimizing
computational resources and limiting the number of trainable parameters.
However, it often faces challenges in striking a trade-off between aligning
with the target distribution: learning a novel concept from a limited image for
personalization and retaining the instruction ability needed for unifying
multiple tasks, all while maintaining editability (aligning with a variety of
prompts or in-context generation). In this work, we introduce DEFT,
Decompositional Efficient Fine-Tuning, an efficient fine-tuning framework that
adapts a pre-trained weight matrix by decomposing its update into two
components with two trainable matrices: (1) a projection onto the complement of
a low-rank subspace spanned by a low-rank matrix, and (2) a low-rank update.
The single trainable low-rank matrix defines the subspace, while the other
trainable low-rank matrix enables flexible parameter adaptation within that
subspace. We conducted extensive experiments on the Dreambooth and Dreambench
Plus datasets for personalization, the InsDet dataset for object and scene
adaptation, and the VisualCloze dataset for a universal image generation
framework through visual in-context learning with both Stable Diffusion and a
unified model. Our results demonstrated state-of-the-art performance,
highlighting the emergent properties of efficient fine-tuning. Our code is
available on \href{https://github.com/MAXNORM8650/DEFT}{DEFTBase}.

AI.tldr: DEFT: Decompositional Efficient Fine-Tuning for text-to-image models updates via two low-rank components, enabling efficient personalization and universal generation with state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: To address the efficiency-personalization-generalization trade-off in fine-tuning pre-trained T2I models, balancing new concept learning from limited data with maintaining broad instruction ability and editability.
AI.method: Update decomposition: project updates onto the complement of a low-rank subspace (defined by one trainable low-rank matrix) and add a second trainable low-rank update within that subspace, enabling parameter-efficient adaptation.
AI.result: Empirically achieves state-of-the-art performance on Dreambooth/Dreambench Plus for personalization, InsDet for object/scene adaptation, and VisualCloze for visual in-context learning with Stable Diffusion and a unified model.
AI.conclusion: DEFT provides an effective, parameter-efficient fine-tuning framework for T2I models, delivering personalization, generalization to universal generation, and editability with strong empirical results; code available.

title: RAISE: A Robot-Assisted Selective Disassembly and Sorting System for End-of-Life Phones
summary:
End-of-Life (EoL) phones significantly exacerbate global e-waste challenges
due to their high production volumes and short lifecycles. Disassembly is among
the most critical processes in EoL phone recycling. However, it relies heavily
on human labor due to product variability. Consequently, the manual process is
both labor-intensive and time-consuming. In this paper, we propose a low-cost,
easily deployable automated and selective disassembly and sorting system for
EoL phones, consisting of three subsystems: an adaptive cutting system, a
vision-based robotic sorting system, and a battery removal system. The system
can process over 120 phones per hour with an average disassembly success rate
of 98.9%, efficiently delivering selected high-value components to downstream
processing. It provides a reliable and scalable automated solution to the
pressing challenge of EoL phone disassembly. Additionally, the automated system
can enhance disassembly economics, converting a previously unprofitable process
into one that yields a net profit per unit weight of EoL phones.

AI.tldr: Automated, low-cost disassembly and sorting system for End-of-Life (EoL) phones that uses three subsystems (adaptive cutting, vision-based sorting, battery removal) to achieve high throughput and high disassembly success, improving economics and scalability.
AI.motivation: End-of-Life phones are a major source of e-waste; disassembly is labor-intensive and variable, hindering scalability and profitability. An automated, selective, low-cost system could reduce labor, speed up processing, and recover high-value components.
AI.method: A three-subsystem pipeline: 1) adaptive cutting system for disassembly, 2) vision-based robotic sorting to select components, and 3) a battery removal system. The system is designed to be low-cost and easily deployable, capable of processing over 120 phones per hour with an average disassembly success rate of 98.9%, delivering selected components to downstream processing.
AI.result: Demonstrates a scalable automated solution for EoL phone disassembly with high throughput and high yield, producing a net profit per unit weight of EoL phones and enabling efficient recovery of high-value components.
AI.conclusion: The proposed trio of subsystems provides a reliable and scalable automated disassembly and sorting solution for EoL phones, addressing critical labor and profitability challenges in e-waste recycling.

title: SysMoBench: Evaluating AI on Formally Modeling Complex Real-World Systems
summary:
Formal models are essential to specifying large, complex computer systems and
verifying their correctness, but are notoriously expensive to write and
maintain. Recent advances in generative AI show promise in generating certain
forms of specifications. However, existing work mostly targets small code, not
complete systems. It is unclear whether AI can deal with realistic system
artifacts, as this requires abstracting their complex behavioral properties
into formal models. We present SysMoBench, a benchmark that evaluates AI's
ability to formally model large, complex systems. We focus on concurrent and
distributed systems, which are keystones of today's critical computing
infrastructures, encompassing operating systems and cloud infrastructure. We
use TLA+, the it de facto specification language for concurrent and distributed
systems, though the benchmark can be extended to other specification languages.
We address the primary challenge of evaluating AI-generated models by
automating metrics like syntactic and runtime correctness, conformance to
system code, and invariant correctness. SysMoBench currently includes nine
diverse system artifacts: the Raft implementation of Etcd and Redis, the
Spinlock and Mutex in Asterinas OS, etc.; more artifacts are being actively
added. SysMoBench enables us to understand the capabilities and limitations of
today's LLMs and agents, putting tools in this area on a firm footing and
opening up promising new research directions.

AI.tldr: SysMoBench is a benchmark to test AI's ability to formally model large, concurrent/distributed systems in TLA+, with automated metrics across nine artifacts, enabling evaluation of current AI capabilities and guiding future research.
AI.motivation: Formal models are essential for correct specification of large systems but expensive to write/maintain; AI could assist, but it is unclear if it can handle realistic system artifacts. A benchmark is needed to quantify AI's capabilities and guide progress.
AI.method: Target the TLA+ specification language and automate metrics such as syntactic/runtime correctness, conformance to system code, and invariant correctness. SysMoBench comprises diverse artifacts (e.g., Raft implementation of Etcd and Redis, Spinlock/Mutex in Asterinas OS) and is extensible to other languages.
AI.result: The work proposes and designs SysMoBench, along with its evaluation metrics and an initial set of artifacts. No empirical results are reported in the abstract; the contribution is the benchmark framework and its intended evaluation approach.
AI.conclusion: SysMoBench provides a foundation to assess current AI-generated formal models for large, complex systems, highlighting capabilities/limitations of today’s LLMs and guiding future research directions.

title: GDR-learners: Orthogonal Learning of Generative Models for Potential Outcomes
summary:
Various deep generative models have been proposed to estimate potential
outcomes distributions from observational data. However, none of them have the
favorable theoretical property of general Neyman-orthogonality and, associated
with it, quasi-oracle efficiency and double robustness. In this paper, we
introduce a general suite of generative Neyman-orthogonal (doubly-robust)
learners that estimate the conditional distributions of potential outcomes. Our
proposed GDR-learners are flexible and can be instantiated with many
state-of-the-art deep generative models. In particular, we develop GDR-learners
based on (a) conditional normalizing flows (which we call GDR-CNFs), (b)
conditional generative adversarial networks (GDR-CGANs), (c) conditional
variational autoencoders (GDR-CVAEs), and (d) conditional diffusion models
(GDR-CDMs). Unlike the existing methods, our GDR-learners possess the
properties of quasi-oracle efficiency and rate double robustness, and are thus
asymptotically optimal. In a series of (semi-)synthetic experiments, we
demonstrate that our GDR-learners are very effective and outperform the
existing methods in estimating the conditional distributions of potential
outcomes.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Generative Neyman-orthogonal (GDR) learners that flexibly estimate conditional distributions of potential outcomes using deep generative models, achieving quasi-oracle efficiency and double robustness.
AI.motivation: Existing deep generative models for potential-outcome distributions lack Neyman orthogonality and double robustness. There is a need for a flexible, theoretically sound framework that combines generative models with semiparametric efficiency properties to estimate conditional outcome distributions.
AI.method: Propose a general suite of GDR-learners that estimate conditional distributions of potential outcomes, instantiated with: (a) conditional normalizing flows (GDR-CNFs), (b) conditional GANs (GDR-CGANs), (c) conditional VAEs (GDR-CVAEs), and (d) conditional diffusion models (GDR-CDMs). These learners achieve Neyman orthogonality, quasi-oracle efficiency, and rate double robustness, enabling asymptotically optimal estimation.
AI.result: Semi- and fully-synthetic experiments show that GDR-learners outperform existing methods in estimating the conditional distributions of potential outcomes.
AI.conclusion: GDR-learners provide a flexible, theoretically grounded framework for estimating potential-outcome distributions that can be instantiated with various deep generative models, yielding improved empirical performance and strong asymptotic guarantees.

title: VideoScore2: Think before You Score in Generative Video Evaluation
summary:
Recent advances in text-to-video generation have produced increasingly
realistic and diverse content, yet evaluating such videos remains a fundamental
challenge due to their multi-faceted nature encompassing visual quality,
semantic alignment, and physical consistency. Existing evaluators and reward
models are limited to single opaque scores, lack interpretability, or provide
only coarse analysis, making them insufficient for capturing the comprehensive
nature of video quality assessment. We present VideoScore2, a
multi-dimensional, interpretable, and human-aligned framework that explicitly
evaluates visual quality, text-to-video alignment, and physical/common-sense
consistency while producing detailed chain-of-thought rationales. Our model is
trained on a large-scale dataset VideoFeedback2 containing 27,168
human-annotated videos with both scores and reasoning traces across three
dimensions, using a two-stage pipeline of supervised fine-tuning followed by
reinforcement learning with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to
enhance analytical robustness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
VideoScore2 achieves superior performance with 44.35 (+5.94) accuracy on our
in-domain benchmark VideoScore-Bench-v2 and 50.37 (+4.32) average performance
across four out-of-domain benchmarks (VideoGenReward-Bench, VideoPhy2, etc),
while providing interpretable assessments that bridge the gap between
evaluation and controllable generation through effective reward modeling for
Best-of-N sampling. Project Page: https://tiger-ai-lab.github.io/VideoScore2/

AI.tldr: VideoScore2 provides multi-dimensional, interpretable evaluation for video generation, scoring visual quality, text-to-video alignment, and physical/common-sense consistency with chain-of-thought rationales; trained on a large annotated dataset and enhanced by GRPO-based RL; achieves superior in-domain and out-of-domain performance and enables reward modeling for controllable generation.
AI.motivation: Current video evaluation largely yields a single opaque score and lacks interpretability across the visual, semantic, and physical aspects of videos. A multi-dimensional, human-aligned, interpretable framework is needed to better assess and guide text-to-video generation.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: supervised fine-tuning on a large dataset (VideoFeedback2 with 27,168 human-annotated videos providing scores and reasoning traces across three dimensions), followed by reinforcement learning using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to boost analytical robustness. Outputs include explicit scores and chain-of-thought rationales for three dimensions: visual quality, text-to-video alignment, and physical/common-sense consistency.
AI.result: VideoScore2 achieves 44.35 accuracy on the in-domain VideoScore-Bench-v2 (+5.94 over baselines) and 50.37 average performance across four out-of-domain benchmarks (e.g., VideoGenReward-Bench, VideoPhy2, etc.), demonstrating superior performance while delivering interpretable assessments that support reward modeling for Best-of-N sampling.
AI.conclusion: VideoScore2 bridges evaluation and controllable generation by providing interpretable, multi-dimensional assessments aligned with human judgment. It enables effective reward modeling for controlled video generation and is available via the project page.

title: In-Hand Manipulation of Articulated Tools with Dexterous Robot Hands with Sim-to-Real Transfer
summary:
Reinforcement learning (RL) and sim-to-real transfer have advanced robotic
manipulation of rigid objects. Yet, policies remain brittle when applied to
articulated mechanisms due to contact-rich dynamics and under-modeled joint
phenomena such as friction, stiction, backlash, and clearances. We address this
challenge through dexterous in-hand manipulation of articulated tools using a
robotic hand with reduced articulation and kinematic redundancy relative to the
human hand. Our controller augments a simulation-trained base policy with a
sensor-driven refinement learned from hardware demonstrations, conditioning on
proprioception and target articulation states while fusing whole-hand tactile
and force feedback with the policy's internal action intent via
cross-attention-based integration. This design enables online adaptation to
instance-specific articulation properties, stabilizes contact interactions,
regulates internal forces, and coordinates coupled-link motion under
perturbations. We validate our approach across a diversity of real-world
examples, including scissors, pliers, minimally invasive surgical tools, and
staplers. We achieve robust transfer from simulation to hardware, improved
disturbance resilience, and generalization to previously unseen articulated
tools, thereby reducing reliance on precise physical modeling in contact-rich
settings.

AI.tldr: A sim-trained base policy for articulated tools is augmented with a sensor-driven refinement that leverages proprioception, tactile/force feedback, and cross-attention to enable online adaptation and robust sim-to-real transfer to unseen articulated tools.
AI.motivation: Policy learning for articulated, contact-rich mechanisms is brittle due to unmodeled joint phenomena (friction, stiction, backlash, clearances) and complex interactions. The work aims to enable dexterous in-hand manipulation with reduced hand complexity and to improve sim-to-real transfer by incorporating real sensing.
AI.method: Train a base policy in simulation and augment it with a hardware-driven refinement module that conditions on proprioception and target articulation states. Fuse whole-hand tactile and force feedback with the policy's action intent using cross-attention-based integration to adapt online to articulation properties, stabilize contacts, regulate internal forces, and coordinate coupled-link motion under perturbations.
AI.result: Validated across diverse real-world tools (scissors, pliers, minimally invasive surgical tools, staplers). Showed robust sim-to-real transfer, improved disturbance resilience, and generalization to unseen articulated tools, reducing reliance on precise physical modeling in contact-rich settings.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates robust real-world manipulation of articulated tools by combining simulation-trained policies with sensor-driven refinement and cross-attention fusion, enabling online adaptation, stability in contact-rich dynamics, and broad generalization.

title: MathBode: Frequency-Domain Fingerprints of LLM Mathematical Reasoning
summary:
This paper presents MathBode, a dynamic diagnostic for mathematical reasoning
in large language models (LLMs). Instead of one-shot accuracy, MathBode treats
each parametric problem as a system: we drive a single parameter sinusoidally
and fit first-harmonic responses of model outputs and exact solutions. This
yields interpretable, frequency-resolved metrics -- gain (amplitude tracking)
and phase (lag) -- that form Bode-style fingerprints. Across five closed-form
families (linear solve, ratio/saturation, compound interest, 2x2 linear
systems, similar triangles), the diagnostic surfaces systematic low-pass
behavior and growing phase lag that accuracy alone obscures. We compare several
models against a symbolic baseline that calibrates the instrument ($G \approx
1$, $\phi \approx 0$). Results separate frontier from mid-tier models on
dynamics, providing a compact, reproducible protocol that complements standard
benchmarks with actionable measurements of reasoning fidelity and consistency.
We open-source the dataset and code to enable further research and adoption.

AI.tldr: MathBode introduces a dynamic, frequency-domain diagnostic for LLM mathematical reasoning that uses sinusoidal perturbations to extract gain and phase, yielding interpretable fingerprints that reveal reasoning dynamics beyond accuracy.
AI.motivation: Accuracy-only benchmarks miss the dynamic behavior of mathematical reasoning in LLMs. A reproducible, interpretable protocol is needed to measure reasoning fidelity and consistency.
AI.method: Treat each parametric problem as a system; perturb a single parameter sinusoidally and fit the first-harmonic responses of model outputs and exact solutions to obtain gain (amplitude tracking) and phase (lag). Evaluate across five closed-form families (linear solve, ratio/saturation, compound interest, 2x2 linear systems, similar triangles); compare models against a symbolic baseline to calibrate the instrument (G ≈ 1, φ ≈ 0); produce diagnostic surfaces.
AI.result: The diagnostic reveals systematic low-pass behavior and increasing phase lag not evident from accuracy alone, enabling separation of frontier from mid-tier models on dynamics; provides a compact, reproducible protocol for measuring reasoning fidelity and consistency; calibration against a symbolic baseline helps interpret outputs.
AI.conclusion: MathBode offers interpretable, Bode-style fingerprints of mathematical reasoning in LLMs, complementing standard benchmarks with actionable measurements; code and dataset are open-sourced to foster adoption and further research.

title: Doubly-Robust LLM-as-a-Judge: Externally Valid Estimation with Imperfect Personas
summary:
As Generative AI (GenAI) systems see growing adoption, a key concern involves
the external validity of evaluations, or the extent to which they generalize
from lab-based to real-world deployment conditions. Threats to the external
validity of GenAI evaluations arise when the source sample of human raters and
system outputs used to obtain a system quality estimate differs from the target
distribution at deployment time. In this work, we propose a doubly-robust
estimation framework designed to address this evaluation sampling bias. Key to
our approach is the use of "persona" ratings produced by prompting an LLM
evaluator (i.e., an LLM-as-a-judge) to behave as a human rater with specific
sociodemographic characteristics. Our doubly-robust framework combines these
informative yet imperfect persona ratings with human ratings obtained under
evaluation sampling bias to produce statistically valid system quality
estimates. In particular, we show that our approach yields valid system quality
estimates when either (i) a model trained to predict human ratings using
persona ratings and source data observed under sampling bias, or (ii) a
reweighting model that corrects for sampling bias is of sufficient quality. We
validate our framework theoretically and via a novel Persona Simulation
Framework (PSF) designed to systematically manipulate persona quality and the
degree of evaluation sampling bias present in source data. Our work provides a
principled foundation for combining imperfect persona ratings with human
ratings observed under sampling bias to obtain valid system quality estimates.

AI.tldr: Proposes a doubly-robust framework to fix evaluation sampling bias in GenAI by fusing persona-based LLM-evaluator ratings with biased human ratings; guarantees hold if either a predictive model using persona data or a bias-correcting reweighting model is high quality, with validation via a Persona Simulation Framework (PSF).
AI.motivation: As GenAI systems are deployed, evaluation results often fail to generalize from lab settings to real-world use due to sampling bias in raters and outputs. This work seeks a principled method to obtain valid system-quality estimates under such external validity threats.
AI.method: Develop a doubly-robust estimator that combines persona ratings (generated by prompting an LLM to mimic human raters with specific sociodemographic traits) with biased human ratings. The estimator remains valid if (i) a model predicting human ratings from persona-and-source data under bias is sufficiently accurate, or (ii) a reweighting model correcting for sampling bias is sufficiently accurate. A novel Persona Simulation Framework (PSF) is introduced to systematically vary persona quality and the degree of evaluation sampling bias.
AI.result: The framework provides valid system-quality estimates under the stated conditions, with theoretical guarantees and empirical validation through the PSF that demonstrates robustness to varying persona quality and sampling bias.
AI.conclusion: This work offers a principled foundation for integrating imperfect persona-based judgments with biased human ratings to obtain valid GenAI evaluation outcomes, advancing external validity in GenAI evaluations.

title: TRUST: Test-Time Refinement using Uncertainty-Guided SSM Traverses
summary:
State Space Models (SSMs) have emerged as efficient alternatives to Vision
Transformers (ViTs), with VMamba standing out as a pioneering architecture
designed for vision tasks. However, their generalization performance degrades
significantly under distribution shifts. To address this limitation, we propose
TRUST (Test-Time Refinement using Uncertainty-Guided SSM Traverses), a novel
test-time adaptation (TTA) method that leverages diverse traversal permutations
to generate multiple causal perspectives of the input image. Model predictions
serve as pseudo-labels to guide updates of the Mamba-specific parameters, and
the adapted weights are averaged to integrate the learned information across
traversal scans. Altogether, TRUST is the first approach that explicitly
leverages the unique architectural properties of SSMs for adaptation.
Experiments on seven benchmarks show that TRUST consistently improves
robustness and outperforms existing TTA methods.

AI.tldr: TRUST uses test-time refinement for Vision SSMs (VMamba) by generating multiple traversal permutations to obtain diverse causal views, updating Mamba-specific parameters with pseudo-labels, and averaging the adapted weights to improve robustness under distribution shifts.
AI.motivation: SSMs (e.g., VMamba) show degraded generalization under distribution shifts. Existing TTA methods may not exploit the unique architectural properties of SSMs for adaptation.
AI.method: At test time, TRUST creates diverse traversal scans (permutations) of the input image to produce multiple causal perspectives. Model predictions serve as pseudo-labels to refine Mamba-specific parameters. The adapted weights from each traversal are averaged to produce the final prediction, explicitly leveraging SSM architecture.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on seven benchmarks shows TRUST consistently improves robustness and outperforms existing TTA methods.
AI.conclusion: TRUST is the first approach to explicitly exploit SSM architectural properties for adaptation in vision tasks, yielding improved robustness under distribution shifts.

title: Open-Vocabulary Spatio-Temporal Scene Graph for Robot Perception and Teleoperation Planning
summary:
Teleoperation via natural-language reduces operator workload and enhances
safety in high-risk or remote settings. However, in dynamic remote scenes,
transmission latency during bidirectional communication creates gaps between
remote perceived states and operator intent, leading to command
misunderstanding and incorrect execution. To mitigate this, we introduce the
Spatio-Temporal Open-Vocabulary Scene Graph (ST-OVSG), a representation that
enriches open-vocabulary perception with temporal dynamics and lightweight
latency annotations. ST-OVSG leverages LVLMs to construct open-vocabulary 3D
object representations, and extends them into the temporal domain via Hungarian
assignment with our temporal matching cost, yielding a unified spatio-temporal
scene graph. A latency tag is embedded to enable LVLM planners to
retrospectively query past scene states, thereby resolving local-remote state
mismatches caused by transmission delays. To further reduce redundancy and
highlight task-relevant cues, we propose a task-oriented subgraph filtering
strategy that produces compact inputs for the planner. ST-OVSG generalizes to
novel categories and enhances planning robustness against transmission latency
without requiring fine-tuning. Experiments show that our method achieves 74
percent node accuracy on the Replica benchmark, outperforming ConceptGraph.
Notably, in the latency-robustness experiment, the LVLM planner assisted by
ST-OVSG achieved a planning success rate of 70.5 percent.

AI.tldr: We present ST-OVSG, a spatio-temporal open-vocabulary scene graph with latency tags to mitigate bidirectional latency in teleoperation. It uses LVLMs for open-vocabulary 3D objects, extends to time with temporal matching, and filters subgraphs for planners. It improves robustness to latency and generalizes without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Latency in remote teleoperation causes gaps between perceived states and operator intent, leading to misinterpretation and incorrect actions; need a representation that handles open-vocabulary categories, temporal dynamics, and latency compensation without heavy retraining.
AI.method: Construct ST-OVSG using LVLM-based open-vocabulary 3D objects; extend to temporal domain via Hungarian assignment with a temporal matching cost to form a unified spatio-temporal graph; embed latency tags enabling retrospective querying of past states; apply task-oriented subgraph filtering to produce compact planner inputs; allow LVLM planners to query past scenes to resolve state mismatches.
AI.result: Achieves 74% node accuracy on Replica benchmark, outperforming ConceptGraph; latency-robustness experiment shows planning success rate 70.5% when using ST-OVSG.
AI.conclusion: ST-OVSG generalizes to novel categories, improves planning robustness to transmission latency, and does not require fine-tuning, supporting safer and more reliable teleoperation in high-latency environments.

title: Coordination Requires Simplification: Thermodynamic Bounds on Multi-Objective Compromise in Natural and Artificial Intelligence
comment:
11 pages, 1 figure, 6 pages supplementary material, submitted to
  Physical Review E
summary:
Information-processing systems coordinating across multiple agents and
objectives face fundamental thermodynamic constraints. We show that solutions
with maximum utility to act as coordination focal points have much higher
selection pressure for being findable across agents rather than accuracy. We
derive that the information-theoretic minimum description length of
coordination protocols to precision $\varepsilon$ scales as $L(P)\geq NK\log_2
K+N^2d^2\log (1/\varepsilon)$ for $N$ agents with $d$ potentially conflicting
objectives and internal model complexity $K$. This scaling forces progressive
simplification, with coordination dynamics changing the environment itself and
shifting optimization across hierarchical levels. Moving from established focal
points requires re-coordination, creating persistent metastable states and
hysteresis until significant environmental shifts trigger phase transitions
through spontaneous symmetry breaking. We operationally define coordination
temperature to predict critical phenomena and estimate coordination work costs,
identifying measurable signatures across systems from neural networks to
restaurant bills to bureaucracies. Extending the topological version of Arrow's
theorem on the impossibility of consistent preference aggregation, we find it
recursively binds whenever preferences are combined. This potentially explains
the indefinite cycling in multi-objective gradient descent and alignment faking
in Large Language Models trained with reinforcement learning with human
feedback. We term this framework Thermodynamic Coordination Theory (TCT), which
demonstrates that coordination requires radical information loss.

AI.tldr: A Thermodynamic Coordination Theory (TCT) shows that coordinating multi-agent objectives imposes an information-loss–driven minimum description length that grows with N, K, d, and decreasing precision ε; this forces simplification, causes metastability and phase transitions, and offers a unifying explanation for challenges in ML alignment and multi-agent systems.
AI.motivation: To quantify fundamental thermodynamic constraints on coordination across agents with potentially conflicting objectives and to explain why coordination focal points are fragile, require information loss, and lead to dynamic, hierarchical organization across systems.
AI.method: Derives an information-theoretic lower bound on the description length L(P) ≥ NK log2 K + N^2 d^2 log(1/ε); introduces a coordination temperature; analyzes how coordination dynamics alter the environment, induce hierarchical optimization, metastable states, and phase transitions via spontaneous symmetry breaking; extends a topological Arrow’s theorem to bound aggregated preferences; suggests broad, cross-domain signatures and links to ML alignment and RLHF.
AI.result: The bound implies progressive simplification and that coordination costs grow with the number of agents, objectives, and complexity; coordination dynamics can reshape the environment, create persistent metastable states and hysteresis, and trigger phase transitions; practical signatures are expected across systems from neural networks to bureaucracies; Arrow’s theorem binds recursively as preferences are combined; potential explanations for gradient-descent cycling and alignment faking in RLHF.
AI.conclusion: Thermodynamic Coordination Theory reveals that achieving coordination inherently requires radical information loss, unifying diverse multi-agent phenomena under a thermodynamic lens and predicting when coordination will be costly, unstable, or undergo critical transitions across domains.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Discrete Diffusion Policies for Combinatorial Action Spaces
comment:
22 pages, 10 figures. Haitong Ma and Ofir Nabati contributed equally
  to this paper
summary:
Reinforcement learning (RL) struggles to scale to large, combinatorial action
spaces common in many real-world problems. This paper introduces a novel
framework for training discrete diffusion models as highly effective policies
in these complex settings. Our key innovation is an efficient online training
process that ensures stable and effective policy improvement. By leveraging
policy mirror descent (PMD) to define an ideal, regularized target policy
distribution, we frame the policy update as a distributional matching problem,
training the expressive diffusion model to replicate this stable target. This
decoupled approach stabilizes learning and significantly enhances training
performance. Our method achieves state-of-the-art results and superior sample
efficiency across a diverse set of challenging combinatorial benchmarks,
including DNA sequence generation, RL with macro-actions, and multi-agent
systems. Experiments demonstrate that our diffusion policies attain superior
performance compared to other baselines.

AI.tldr: Discrete diffusion policies trained via policy mirror descent (PMD) improve stability and sample efficiency in large combinatorial action spaces, achieving state-of-the-art results on diverse benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Reinforcement learning with large, combinatorial action spaces struggles with scalability and stable learning. The authors propose a diffusion-policy framework that leverages PMD to define a stable regularized target, enabling effective online training.
AI.method: Train a discrete diffusion model as the policy and perform a distributional matching update to a PMD-defined target distribution. The approach decouples learning of the target from policy optimization, improving stability and sample efficiency. Evaluated on benchmarks like DNA sequence generation, macro-actions RL, and multi-agent systems.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance and superior sample efficiency on diverse combinatorial tasks, with diffusion policies outperforming baselines.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion-based policies guided by policy mirror descent offer a stable, scalable approach to learning in combinatorial action spaces, delivering strong empirical gains across tasks.

title: MMPB: It's Time for Multi-Modal Personalization
summary:
Visual personalization is essential in user-facing AI systems such as smart
homes and healthcare, where aligning model behavior with user-centric concepts
is critical. However, recent large Vision-Language Models (VLMs), despite their
broad applicability, remain underexplored in their ability to adapt to
individual users. In this paper, we introduce MMPB, the first extensive
benchmark for evaluating VLMs on personalization. MMPB comprises 10k
image-query pairs and includes 111 personalizable concepts across four
categories: humans, animals, objects, and characters, with the human category
enriched with preference-grounded queries. We structure personalization into
three main task types, each highlighting a different key property of VLMs.
Using 23 widely used VLMs including both open- and closed-source models, we
evaluate personalization performance via a three-stage protocol: concept
injection, multi-turn dialogue, and personalized querying. Our findings
indicate that most VLMs (including some closed-source models) struggle with
personalization, particularly in maintaining consistency over dialogue,
handling user preferences, and adapting to visual cues. Our analysis reveals
that the challenges in VLM personalization (such as refusal behaviors and
long-context forgetting) highlight substantial room for improvement. By
identifying these limitations and offering a scalable benchmark, MMPB offers
valuable insights and a solid foundation for future research toward truly
personalized multi-modal AI. Project Page: aidaslab.github.io/MMPB

AI.tldr: MMPB introduces the first large-scale benchmark for personalizing vision-language models (VLMs) with 10k image-query pairs and 111 concepts across four categories, revealing that current models struggle with consistency, user preferences, and adapting to visual cues in a three-stage evaluation.
AI.motivation: To enable user-centric AI for multimodal systems, it is essential to evaluate how well VLMs can adapt to individual preferences and identities, which existing benchmarks overlook.
AI.method: Create MMPB: a 10k image-query dataset covering 111 personalizable concepts across humans, animals, objects, and characters (with preference-grounded queries for humans). Propose three task types to probe different VLM properties. Assess 23 VLMs (open and closed) using a three-stage protocol: concept injection, multi-turn dialogue, and personalized querying.
AI.result: Most VLMs struggle with personalization, especially maintaining dialogue consistency, honoring user preferences, and adapting to visual cues. Notable issues include refusal behaviors and long-context forgetting, indicating room for improvement. The benchmark is scalable and informative for future research in personalized multi-modal AI.
AI.conclusion: MMPB provides a scalable, widely applicable benchmark and a solid foundation for advancing truly personalized multi-modal AI, highlighting current gaps and guiding future development. Project Page: aidaslab.github.io/MMPB

title: Liaohe-CobotMagic-PnP: an Imitation Learning Dataset of Intelligent Robot for Industrial Applications
comment:
Accepted to IAI 2025 (International Conference on Industrial
  Artificial Intelligence), Shenyang, China, Aug 21 - 24, 2025. Preprint
  (before IEEE copyright transfer)
summary:
In Industry 4.0 applications, dynamic environmental interference induces
highly nonlinear and strongly coupled interactions between the environmental
state and robotic behavior. Effectively representing dynamic environmental
states through multimodal sensor data fusion remains a critical challenge in
current robotic datasets. To address this, an industrial-grade multimodal
interference dataset is presented, designed for robotic perception and control
under complex conditions. The dataset integrates multi-dimensional interference
features including size, color, and lighting variations, and employs
high-precision sensors to synchronously collect visual, torque, and joint-state
measurements. Scenarios with geometric similarity exceeding 85\% and
standardized lighting gradients are included to ensure real-world
representativeness. Microsecond-level time-synchronization and
vibration-resistant data acquisition protocols, implemented via the Robot
Operating System (ROS), guarantee temporal and operational fidelity.
Experimental results demonstrate that the dataset enhances model validation
robustness and improves robotic operational stability in dynamic,
interference-rich environments. The dataset is publicly available
at:https://modelscope.cn/datasets/Liaoh_LAB/Liaohe-CobotMagic-PnP.

AI.tldr: Proposes and releases an industrial-grade multimodal interference dataset for robotic perception and control under dynamic, interference-rich environments; features synchronous visual, torque, and joint-state data with diverse interference factors; demonstrates improved robustness; dataset publicly available.
AI.motivation: Industry 4.0 systems experience nonlinear, strongly coupled environmental interference that affects both perception and control. Current datasets struggle to capture and represent these dynamic states through multimodal fusion, hindering robust model validation and deployment.
AI.method: Design and collect a multimodal dataset with interference factors such as size, color, and lighting variations, using high-precision sensors to synchronously acquire visual, torque, and joint-state measurements. Data acquisition uses microsecond-level time synchronization and vibration-resistant protocols via ROS. Scenarios include geometric similarity >85% and standardized lighting gradients to ensure real-world representativeness.
AI.result: Experimental results indicate that models validated on or trained with the dataset show enhanced robustness and improved robotic operational stability in dynamic, interference-rich environments.
AI.conclusion: The dataset addresses a critical gap in multimodal perception and control under environmental interference, enabling more robust evaluation and development for Industry 4.0 robotics. The dataset is publicly available at the provided link.

title: AI-Enhanced Distributed Channel Access for Collision Avoidance in Future Wi-Fi 8
summary:
The exponential growth of wireless devices and stringent reliability
requirements of emerging applications demand fundamental improvements in
distributed channel access mechanisms for unlicensed bands. Current Wi-Fi
systems, which rely on binary exponential backoff (BEB), suffer from suboptimal
collision resolution in dense deployments and persistent fairness challenges
due to inherent randomness. This paper introduces a multi-agent reinforcement
learning framework that integrates artificial intelligence (AI) optimization
with legacy device coexistence. We first develop a dynamic backoff selection
mechanism that adapts to real-time channel conditions through access deferral
events while maintaining full compatibility with conventional CSMA/CA
operations. Second, we introduce a fairness quantification metric aligned with
enhanced distributed channel access (EDCA) principles to ensure equitable
medium access opportunities. Finally, we propose a centralized training
decentralized execution (CTDE) architecture incorporating neighborhood activity
patterns as observational inputs, optimized via constrained multi-agent
proximal policy optimization (MAPPO) to jointly minimize collisions and
guarantee fairness. Experimental results demonstrate that our solution
significantly reduces collision probability compared to conventional BEB while
preserving backward compatibility with commercial Wi-Fi devices. The proposed
fairness metric effectively eliminates starvation risks in heterogeneous
scenarios.
