AI.tldr: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (RL) framework to optimize dynamic backoff in unlicensed bands, reducing collisions and improving fairness while maintaining legacy Wi‑Fi compatibility.
AI.motivation: Binary exponential backoff (BEB) causes suboptimal collision handling in dense deployments and fairness issues across heterogeneous devices; new distributed access mechanisms are needed that coexist with legacy systems.
AI.method: Dynamic backoff selection tied to real-time channel conditions and access deferral with full CSMA/CA compatibility; a fairness metric aligned with EDCA; centralized training/decentralized execution (CTDE) using neighborhood activity as inputs, optimized via constrained MAPPO to minimize collisions and enforce fairness.
AI.result: Experiments show significantly lower collision probability versus BEB; backward compatibility with commercial Wi‑Fi devices is preserved; the fairness metric mitigates starvation in heterogeneous scenarios.
AI.conclusion: AI-guided, fairness-aware CSMA/CA with CTDE-MAPPO can enhance dense WLAN performance without disrupting legacy devices; the proposed framework offers practical coexistence benefits and a principled fairness guarantee.

title: Functional Critic Modeling for Provably Convergent Off-Policy Actor-Critic
summary:
Off-policy reinforcement learning (RL) with function approximation offers an
effective way to improve sample efficiency by reusing past experience. Within
this setting, the actor-critic (AC) framework has achieved strong empirical
success. However, both the critic and actor learning is challenging for the
off-policy AC methods: first of all, in addition to the classic "deadly triad"
instability of off-policy evaluation, it also suffers from a "moving target"
problem, where the policy being evaluated changes continually; secondly, actor
learning becomes less efficient due to the difficulty of estimating the exact
off-policy policy gradient. The first challenge essentially reduces the problem
to repeatedly performing off-policy evaluation for changing policies. For the
second challenge, the off-policy policy gradient theorem requires a complex and
often impractical algorithm to estimate an additional emphasis critic, which is
typically neglected in practice, thereby reducing to the on-policy policy
gradient as an approximation. In this work, we introduce a novel concept of
functional critic modeling, which leads to a new AC framework that addresses
both challenges for actor-critic learning under the deadly triad setting. We
provide a theoretical analysis in the linear function setting, establishing the
provable convergence of our framework, which, to the best of our knowledge, is
the first convergent off-policy target-based AC algorithm. From a practical
perspective, we further propose a carefully designed neural network
architecture for the functional critic modeling and demonstrate its
effectiveness through preliminary experiments on widely used RL tasks from the
DeepMind Control Benchmark.

AI.tldr: A new off-policy actor-critic framework using functional critic modeling to address deadly triad instability and moving-target policy changes, with theoretical convergence in linear settings and a neural-network realization showing preliminary DM Control results.
AI.motivation: To overcome instability and inefficiency in off-policy actor-critic methods caused by the deadly triad and the moving-target issue, and to provide a practical algorithm that remains convergent and data-efficient.
AI.method: Introduce functional critic modeling within an off-policy actor-critic framework, derive theory proving convergence in the linear function approximation setting, and design a neural network architecture for the functional critic with preliminary experiments on DeepMind Control benchmarks.
AI.result: The framework is shown to converge in the linear setting (provable convergence) and a practical neural network implementation demonstrates efficacy in initial experiments on DM Control tasks.
AI.conclusion: Functional critic modeling enables a convergent, off-policy target-based actor-critic algorithm, offering both theoretical guarantees and practical viability, with promising preliminary results requiring further empirical validation.

title: Seeing Isn't Believing: Context-Aware Adversarial Patch Synthesis via Conditional GAN
summary:
Adversarial patch attacks pose a severe threat to deep neural networks, yet
most existing approaches rely on unrealistic white-box assumptions, untargeted
objectives, or produce visually conspicuous patches that limit real-world
applicability. In this work, we introduce a novel framework for fully
controllable adversarial patch generation, where the attacker can freely choose
both the input image x and the target class y target, thereby dictating the
exact misclassification outcome. Our method combines a generative U-Net design
with Grad-CAM-guided patch placement, enabling semantic-aware localization that
maximizes attack effectiveness while preserving visual realism. Extensive
experiments across convolutional networks (DenseNet-121, ResNet-50) and vision
transformers (ViT-B/16, Swin-B/16, among others) demonstrate that our approach
achieves state-of-the-art performance across all settings, with attack success
rates (ASR) and target-class success (TCS) consistently exceeding 99%.
  Importantly, we show that our method not only outperforms prior white-box
attacks and untargeted baselines, but also surpasses existing non-realistic
approaches that produce detectable artifacts. By simultaneously ensuring
realism, targeted control, and black-box applicability-the three most
challenging dimensions of patch-based attacks-our framework establishes a new
benchmark for adversarial robustness research, bridging the gap between
theoretical attack strength and practical stealthiness.

AI.tldr: A fully controllable adversarial patch framework using a generative U-Net and Grad-CAM-guided patch placement to achieve semantic-aware, realistic patches that target a specific class. Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance across CNNs and ViTs, with attack success rate and target-class success exceeding 99%, while maintaining realism and black-box applicability.
AI.motivation: Current patch attacks rely on unrealistic white-box access, untargeted objectives, or visibly conspicuous patches, limiting real-world deployment. There is a need for realistic, targeted, and black-box compatible patch attacks that can be controlled by the attacker.
AI.method: A generative U-Net produces patches and a Grad-CAM-guided placement strategy to localize patches semantically. The attacker selects input x and target class y_target; the method optimizes patch content and placement to maximize the likelihood of the model predicting y_target while preserving visual realism. The approach emphasizes semantic-aware patch placement and supports black-box applicability.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on DenseNet-121, ResNet-50, ViT-B/16, Swin-B/16 (and others) show attack success rate and target-class success exceeding 99% across settings, outperforming prior white-box, untargeted baselines, and non-realistic, artifact-prone approaches.
AI.conclusion: The framework achieves realism, targeted control, and black-box applicability, establishing a new benchmark for adversarial patch attacks and bridging the gap between theoretical attack strength and practical stealthiness.

title: FTACT: Force Torque aware Action Chunking Transformer for Pick-and-Reorient Bottle Task
summary:
Manipulator robots are increasingly being deployed in retail environments,
yet contact rich edge cases still trigger costly human teleoperation. A
prominent example is upright lying beverage bottles, where purely visual cues
are often insufficient to resolve subtle contact events required for precise
manipulation. We present a multimodal Imitation Learning policy that augments
the Action Chunking Transformer with force and torque sensing, enabling
end-to-end learning over images, joint states, and forces and torques. Deployed
on Ghost, single-arm platform by Telexistence Inc, our approach improves
Pick-and-Reorient bottle task by detecting and exploiting contact transitions
during pressing and placement. Hardware experiments demonstrate greater task
success compared to baseline matching the observation space of ACT as an
ablation and experiments indicate that force and torque signals are beneficial
in the press and place phases where visual observability is limited, supporting
the use of interaction forces as a complementary modality for contact rich
skills. The results suggest a practical path to scaling retail manipulation by
combining modern imitation learning architectures with lightweight force and
torque sensing.

AI.tldr: A multimodal imitation-learning policy augments the Action Chunking Transformer (ACT) with force/torque sensing to improve contact-rich manipulation tasks (pick-and-reorient bottles) on Telexistence Ghost, outperforming ACT-only baselines, especially when visual cues are limited.
AI.motivation: Retail manipulation often involves subtle contact events that are not reliably detectable with vision alone. Edge cases like upright lying beverage bottles require understanding contact transitions to achieve precise manipulation. Incorporating force/torque sensing promises a practical, scalable path to improve success rates in real-world retail robots.
AI.method: Extend the Action Chunking Transformer with force and torque sensing to create a multimodal imitation-learning policy. Train end-to-end over images, joint states, and forces/torques. Deploy on Telexistence Ghost (single-arm) to perform Pick-and-Reorient bottle tasks. Compare against a baseline ACT with the same observation space (ablation) and evaluate the contribution of force/torque signals, especially during press and place phases when vision is limited.
AI.result: Hardware experiments show higher task success with the multimodal policy than the ACT-only baseline. Ablation suggests force/torque signals provide a meaningful improvement, particularly during press and place phases where visual cues are weak.
AI.conclusion: Integrating light force/torque sensing with modern imitation-learning architectures enables more reliable contact-rich manipulation in retail settings, offering a scalable path to broader deployment by leveraging multimodal signals for contact understanding.

title: Limit Analysis for Symbolic Multi-step Reasoning Tasks with Information Propagation Rules Based on Transformers
summary:
Transformers are able to perform reasoning tasks, however the intrinsic
mechanism remains widely open. In this paper we propose a set of information
propagation rules based on Transformers and utilize symbolic reasoning tasks to
theoretically analyze the limit reasoning steps. We show that the limit number
of reasoning steps is between $O(3^{L-1})$ and $O(2^{L-1})$ for a model with
$L$ attention layers in a single-pass.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes information propagation rules for Transformer-based models and derives theoretical bounds on single-pass reasoning depth, showing the limit number of steps scales between O(3^{L-1}) and O(2^{L-1}) for a model with L attention layers.
AI.motivation: To understand the intrinsic reasoning mechanisms of Transformers and establish theoretical limits on their reasoning depth using a formal framework.
AI.method: Introduce information propagation rules tailored to Transformer architectures and analyze symbolic reasoning tasks to theoretically bound the maximum number of reasoning steps achievable in a single forward pass.
AI.result: The limit number of reasoning steps in a single-pass Transformer with L attention layers is bounded between O(3^{L-1}) and O(2^{L-1}).
AI.conclusion: Provides a theoretical framework linking Transformer architecture (number of layers) to reasoning capacity in a single pass, outlining exponential bounds and highlighting the remaining gaps in understanding Transformer reasoning dynamics.

title: Shape-Informed Clustering of Multi-Dimensional Functional Data via Deep Functional Autoencoders
summary:
We introduce FAEclust, a novel functional autoencoder framework for cluster
analysis of multi-dimensional functional data, data that are random
realizations of vector-valued random functions. Our framework features a
universal-approximator encoder that captures complex nonlinear
interdependencies among component functions, and a universal-approximator
decoder capable of accurately reconstructing both Euclidean and manifold-valued
functional data. Stability and robustness are enhanced through innovative
regularization strategies applied to functional weights and biases.
Additionally, we incorporate a clustering loss into the network's training
objective, promoting the learning of latent representations that are conducive
to effective clustering. A key innovation is our shape-informed clustering
objective, ensuring that the clustering results are resistant to phase
variations in the functions. We establish the universal approximation property
of our non-linear decoder and validate the effectiveness of our model through
extensive experiments.

AI.tldr: FAEclust is a functional autoencoder framework for clustering multi-dimensional functional data, using a universal-approximator encoder/decoder, regularization, and a shape-informed clustering objective to achieve robust clustering with invariance to phase variation; the decoder is proven to have universal approximation capability; validated by extensive experiments.
AI.motivation: Clustering complex, multi-dimensional functional data is challenging due to nonlinear dependencies, phase (shape) variation, and the need to handle Euclidean and manifold-valued data. Existing methods struggle with nonlinearity, misalignment, and variability across components; a unified framework with strong representation power and clustering-aware training is desirable.
AI.method: Propose FAEclust with a universal-approximator encoder and decoder that can reconstruct both Euclidean and manifold-valued functional data. Apply regularization on functional weights and biases to improve stability. Incorporate a clustering loss into the training objective and introduce a shape-informed clustering objective to resist phase variations. Prove the universal approximation property of the non-linear decoder. Validate via extensive experiments demonstrating improved clustering performance.
AI.result: The model demonstrates effective learning of latent representations conducive to clustering, with robustness to phase variations and the ability to reconstruct both Euclidean and manifold-valued functional data; experimental results support the claimed universal approximation and clustering effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: FAEclust offers a general, theoretically grounded framework for clustering multi-dimensional functional data, combining strong representational power, regularization, and shape-informed clustering. It accommodates both Euclidean and manifold-valued data and is validated by extensive experiments, indicating promising applicability to real-world functional datasets.

title: Learning Temporal Saliency for Time Series Forecasting with Cross-Scale Attention
summary:
Explainability in time series forecasting is essential for improving model
transparency and supporting informed decision-making. In this work, we present
CrossScaleNet, an innovative architecture that combines a patch-based
cross-attention mechanism with multi-scale processing to achieve both high
performance and enhanced temporal explainability. By embedding attention
mechanisms into the training process, our model provides intrinsic
explainability for temporal saliency, making its decision-making process more
transparent. Traditional post-hoc methods for temporal saliency detection are
computationally expensive, particularly when compared to feature importance
detection. While ablation techniques may suffice for datasets with fewer
features, identifying temporal saliency poses greater challenges due to its
complexity. We validate CrossScaleNet on synthetic datasets with known saliency
ground truth and on established public benchmarks, demonstrating the robustness
of our method in identifying temporal saliency. Experiments on real-world
datasets for forecasting task show that our approach consistently outperforms
most transformer-based models, offering better explainability without
sacrificing predictive accuracy. Our evaluations demonstrate superior
performance in both temporal saliency detection and forecasting accuracy.
Moreover, we highlight that existing models claiming explainability often fail
to maintain strong performance on standard benchmarks. CrossScaleNet addresses
this gap, offering a balanced approach that captures temporal saliency
effectively while delivering state-of-the-art forecasting performance across
datasets of varying complexity.

AI.tldr: CrossScaleNet introduces a patch-based cross-attention, multi-scale time-series architecture with intrinsic temporal explainability, achieving strong forecasting performance and robust temporal saliency detection, outperforming many transformer baselines while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: Explainability in time series forecasting is crucial for transparency and decision-making. Post-hoc saliency methods are often expensive and unreliable; temporal saliency is particularly challenging and benefits from intrinsic, training-time explainability.
AI.method: A patch-based cross-attention architecture called CrossScaleNet that incorporates multi-scale processing. Attention mechanisms are embedded during training to provide intrinsic temporal saliency. The approach is evaluated on synthetic datasets with ground-truth saliency, public benchmarks, and real-world forecasting tasks, with comparisons to transformer-based models.
AI.result: The method shows robust temporal saliency detection and maintains or improves forecasting accuracy, outperforming most transformer-based models on benchmarks. It demonstrates strong explainability without sacrificing performance and highlights limitations of existing explainable models which often trade off accuracy.
AI.conclusion: CrossScaleNet offers a balanced solution that delivers effective temporal saliency detection and state-of-the-art forecasting performance across diverse datasets, addressing the gap where explainability methods sometimes incur performance costs.

title: EKF-Based Fusion of Wi-Fi/LiDAR/IMU for Indoor Localization and Navigation
comment:
8 pages, 7 figures, 3 tables, and submitted for presentation at a
  conference
summary:
Conventional Wi-Fi received signal strength indicator (RSSI) fingerprinting
cannot meet the growing demand for accurate indoor localization and navigation
due to its lower accuracy, while solutions based on light detection and ranging
(LiDAR) can provide better localization performance but is limited by their
higher deployment cost and complexity. To address these issues, we propose a
novel indoor localization and navigation framework integrating Wi-Fi RSSI
fingerprinting, LiDAR-based simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), and
inertial measurement unit (IMU) navigation based on an extended Kalman filter
(EKF). Specifically, coarse localization by deep neural network (DNN)-based
Wi-Fi RSSI fingerprinting is refined by IMU-based dynamic positioning using a
Gmapping-based SLAM to generate an occupancy grid map and output high-frequency
attitude estimates, which is followed by EKF prediction-update integrating
sensor information while effectively suppressing Wi-Fi-induced noise and IMU
drift errors. Multi-group real-world experiments conducted on the IR building
at Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University demonstrates that the proposed
multi-sensor fusion framework suppresses the instability caused by individual
approaches and thereby provides stable accuracy across all path configurations
with mean two-dimensional (2D) errors ranging from 0.2449 m to 0.3781 m. In
contrast, the mean 2D errors of Wi-Fi RSSI fingerprinting reach up to 1.3404 m
in areas with severe signal interference, and those of LiDAR/IMU localization
are between 0.6233 m and 2.8803 m due to cumulative drift.

AI.tldr: A multi-sensor fusion framework combining Wi-Fi RSSI fingerprinting, LiDAR-based SLAM, and IMU navigation via EKF yields robust indoor localization with sub-meter accuracy, outperforming Wi-Fi-only and LiDAR/IMU solutions.
AI.motivation: Wi-Fi RSSI fingerprinting alone lacks accuracy. LiDAR offers high accuracy but at higher cost and complexity. A fusion approach aims to leverage complementary strengths to achieve accurate, stable indoor localization in real-world settings.
AI.method: 1) Coarse localization via DNN-based Wi-Fi RSSI fingerprinting. 2) Refine with IMU-based dynamic positioning using Gmapping-based SLAM to build an occupancy grid and provide high-frequency attitude estimates. 3) EKF prediction-update to fuse sensors, suppress Wi-Fi-induced noise and IMU drift. 4) Real-world multi-group experiments in the IR building at Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University to validate performance.
AI.result: Mean 2D localization errors range from 0.2449 m to 0.3781 m across paths. Wi-Fi RSSI fingerprinting alone can reach up to 1.3404 m under strong interference; LiDAR/IMU localization drifts lead to 0.6233–2.8803 m errors. The proposed multi-sensor fusion framework provides stable, sub-meter accuracy across configurations by suppressing weaknesses of individual modalities.
AI.conclusion: The proposed multi-sensor fusion framework effectively mitigates modality-specific weaknesses, delivering robust indoor localization performance with sub-meter accuracy in real-world deployments, outperforming single-sensor approaches.

title: Understanding and Enhancing the Planning Capability of Language Models via Multi-Token Prediction
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have achieved impressive performance across
diverse tasks but continue to struggle with learning transitive relations, a
cornerstone for complex planning. To address this issue, we investigate the
Multi-Token Prediction (MTP) paradigm and its impact to transitive relation
learning. We theoretically analyze the MTP paradigm using a Transformer
architecture composed of a shared output head and a transfer layer. Our
analysis reveals that the transfer layer gradually learns the multi-step
adjacency information, which in turn enables the backbone model to capture
unobserved transitive reachability relations beyond those directly present in
the training data, albeit with some inevitable noise in adjacency estimation.
Building on this foundation, we propose two strategies to enhance the transfer
layer and overall learning quality: Next-Token Injection (NTI) and a
Transformer-based transfer layer. Our experiments on both synthetic graphs and
the Blocksworld planning benchmark validate our theoretical findings and
demonstrate that the improvements significantly enhance the model's
path-planning capability. These findings deepen our understanding of how
Transformers with MTP learn in complex planning tasks, and provide practical
strategies to overcome the transitivity bottleneck, paving the way toward
structurally aware and general-purpose planning models.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes Multi-Token Prediction (MTP) in Transformers to tackle learning transitive relations for planning. It shows a transfer layer can gradually learn multi-step adjacency, enabling reachability beyond training data with some noise, and proposes Next-Token Injection and a Transformer-based transfer layer, with experiments on synthetic graphs and Blocksworld to improve path planning.
AI.motivation: Transitive relations are crucial for complex planning but often poorly learned by LLMs. The paper investigates whether MTP and a dedicated transfer layer can internalize multi-step connectivity to enhance planning capabilities.
AI.method: The authors provide a theoretical analysis of a Transformer architecture with a shared output head and a transfer layer under the MTP regime. They show how the transfer layer captures multi-step adjacency information and propose two enhancements: Next-Token Injection (NTI) and a Transformer-based transfer layer. They validate their theory with experiments on synthetic graphs and the Blocksworld planning benchmark.
AI.result: The transfer layer progressively learns multi-step adjacency, enabling the backbone to infer transitive reachability beyond direct training data, albeit with some noise. The proposed NTI and a Transformer-based transfer layer improve the model's path-planning performance, as demonstrated on synthetic graphs and Blocksworld, supporting the theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: Transformers trained with MTP can learn transitive relations through a transfer layer, and targeted enhancements (NTI and a Transformer-based transfer layer) can alleviate the transitivity bottleneck, yielding more capable, structurally aware planning models.

title: OptiMind: Teaching LLMs to Think Like Optimization Experts
summary:
Mathematical programming -- the task of expressing operations and
decision-making problems in precise mathematical language -- is fundamental
across domains, yet remains a skill-intensive process requiring operations
research expertise. Recent advances in large language models for complex
reasoning have spurred interest in automating this task, translating natural
language into executable optimization models. Current approaches, however,
achieve limited accuracy, hindered by scarce and noisy training data without
leveraging domain knowledge. In this work, we systematically integrate
optimization expertise to improve formulation accuracy for mixed-integer linear
programming, a key family of mathematical programs. Our approach first cleans
training data through class-based error analysis to explicitly prevent common
mistakes within each optimization class. We then develop multi-turn inference
strategies that guide LLMs with class-specific error summaries and solver
feedback, enabling iterative refinement. Experiments across multiple base LLMs
demonstrate that combining cleaned data with domain-informed prompting and
feedback improves formulation accuracy by 14 percentage points on average,
enabling further progress toward robust LLM-assisted optimization formulation.

AI.tldr: Integrates optimization-domain knowledge into LLM-based MILP formulation via data cleaning and multi-turn, feedback-guided prompting, achieving about 14 percentage-point accuracy gains.
AI.motivation: Reduce errors when translating natural language into MILP by injecting domain knowledge and iterative refinement, addressing data scarcity and noisiness in training data.
AI.method: 1) Class-based error analysis to clean training data and prevent common mistakes per optimization class; 2) Class-specific error summaries guiding multi-turn inference; 3) Solver feedback for iterative refinement; 4) Evaluation across multiple base LLMs with domain-informed prompting.
AI.result: Average improvement of 14 percentage points in MILP formulation accuracy across several base LLMs.
AI.conclusion: Domain-informed prompting combined with iterative solver feedback advances robust, automated LLM-assisted optimization formulation and moves toward reliable NL-to-MIP modeling.

title: Multimodal Slice Interaction Network Enhanced by Transfer Learning for Precise Segmentation of Internal Gross Tumor Volume in Lung Cancer PET/CT Imaging
summary:
Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancerrelated deaths globally.
Accurate delineation of internal gross tumor volume (IGTV) in PET/CT imaging is
pivotal for optimal radiation therapy in mobile tumors such as lung cancer to
account for tumor motion, yet is hindered by the limited availability of
annotated IGTV datasets and attenuated PET signal intensity at tumor
boundaries. In this study, we present a transfer learningbased methodology
utilizing a multimodal interactive perception network with MAMBA, pre-trained
on extensive gross tumor volume (GTV) datasets and subsequently fine-tuned on a
private IGTV cohort. This cohort constitutes the PET/CT subset of the
Lung-cancer Unified Cross-modal Imaging Dataset (LUCID). To further address the
challenge of weak PET intensities in IGTV peripheral slices, we introduce a
slice interaction module (SIM) within a 2.5D segmentation framework to
effectively model inter-slice relationships. Our proposed module integrates
channel and spatial attention branches with depthwise convolutions, enabling
more robust learning of slice-to-slice dependencies and thereby improving
overall segmentation performance. A comprehensive experimental evaluation
demonstrates that our approach achieves a Dice of 0.609 on the private IGTV
dataset, substantially surpassing the conventional baseline score of 0.385.
This work highlights the potential of transfer learning, coupled with advanced
multimodal techniques and a SIM to enhance the reliability and clinical
relevance of IGTV segmentation for lung cancer radiation therapy planning.

AI.tldr: Transfer-learning with a multimodal interactive perception network and a slice interaction module (SIM) improves IGTV segmentation in PET/CT for lung cancer radiotherapy, achieving Dice 0.609 vs 0.385 baseline on a private IGTV dataset.
AI.motivation: IGTV delineation is crucial for motion-aware radiotherapy in lung cancer but hampered by scarce annotated IGTV data and weak PET signal at tumor boundaries.
AI.method: A transfer-learning pipeline: pre-train on extensive GTV datasets (MAMBA) and fine-tune on a private IGTV PET/CT cohort from LUCID. Introduce a slice interaction module (SIM) within a 2.5D segmentation framework, combining channel and spatial attention with depthwise convolutions to model inter-slice dependencies.
AI.result: Dice score of 0.609 on the private IGTV dataset, substantially higher than the conventional baseline 0.385.
AI.conclusion: Combining transfer learning with a SIM in a multimodal segmentation framework can enhance IGTV reliability and clinical relevance for lung cancer radiotherapy planning; suggests strong potential for data-scarce settings.

title: LAGEA: Language Guided Embodied Agents for Robotic Manipulation
summary:
Robotic manipulation benefits from foundation models that describe goals, but
today's agents still lack a principled way to learn from their own mistakes. We
ask whether natural language can serve as feedback, an error reasoning signal
that helps embodied agents diagnose what went wrong and correct course. We
introduce LAGEA (Language Guided Embodied Agents), a framework that turns
episodic, schema-constrained reflections from a vision language model (VLM)
into temporally grounded guidance for reinforcement learning. LAGEA summarizes
each attempt in concise language, localizes the decisive moments in the
trajectory, aligns feedback with visual state in a shared representation, and
converts goal progress and feedback agreement into bounded, step-wise shaping
rewardswhose influence is modulated by an adaptive, failure-aware coefficient.
This design yields dense signals early when exploration needs direction and
gracefully recedes as competence grows. On the Meta-World MT10 embodied
manipulation benchmark, LAGEA improves average success over the
state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods by 9.0% on random goals and 5.3% on fixed
goals, while converging faster. These results support our hypothesis: language,
when structured and grounded in time, is an effective mechanism for teaching
robots to self-reflect on mistakes and make better choices. Code will be
released soon.

AI.tldr: LAGEA uses time-grounded natural language feedback from a vision-language model to guide RL for robotic manipulation, producing dense shaping rewards that improve learning efficiency and success on Meta-World MT10.
AI.motivation: Agents currently lack principled methods to learn from their own mistakes; natural language can serve as an error-reasoning feedback signal to diagnose and correct behavior; aim to ground language in time and state to improve embodied agent learning.
AI.method: Proposes LAGEA framework that converts episodic, schema-constrained reflections from a vision-language model into temporally grounded guidance for reinforcement learning. It summarizes each attempt in language, localizes decisive moments, aligns feedback with a shared visual-language state, and translates progress and feedback agreement into bounded, step-wise rewards with an adaptive, failure-aware coefficient to modulate influence.
AI.result: On Meta-World MT10, LAGEA outperforms SOTA by 9.0% on random goals and 5.3% on fixed goals, with faster convergence, demonstrating effectiveness of language-grounded feedback in improving exploration and policy improvement.
AI.conclusion: Structured, time-grounded natural language can effectively teach robots to self-reflect and improve decision-making; the approach shows promise for scalable, language-guided embodied learning; code will be released.

title: AutoEP: LLMs-Driven Automation of Hyperparameter Evolution for Metaheuristic Algorithms
summary:
Dynamically configuring algorithm hyperparameters is a fundamental challenge
in computational intelligence. While learning-based methods offer automation,
they suffer from prohibitive sample complexity and poor generalization. We
introduce AutoEP, a novel framework that bypasses training entirely by
leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) as zero-shot reasoning engines for
algorithm control. AutoEP's core innovation lies in a tight synergy between two
components: (1) an online Exploratory Landscape Analysis (ELA) module that
provides real-time, quantitative feedback on the search dynamics, and (2) a
multi-LLM reasoning chain that interprets this feedback to generate adaptive
hyperparameter strategies. This approach grounds high-level reasoning in
empirical data, mitigating hallucination. Evaluated on three distinct
metaheuristics across diverse combinatorial optimization benchmarks, AutoEP
consistently outperforms state-of-the-art tuners, including neural evolution
and other LLM-based methods. Notably, our framework enables open-source models
like Qwen3-30B to match the performance of GPT-4, demonstrating a powerful and
accessible new paradigm for automated hyperparameter design. Our code is
available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/AutoEP-3E11

AI.tldr: AutoEP is a zero-shot, LLM-driven framework that autonomously tunes hyperparameters for metaheuristics in real-time by combining an online Exploratory Landscape Analysis (ELA) module with multi-LLM reasoning, achieving superior performance without training and enabling open-source models to match GPT-4.
AI.motivation: Hyperparameter tuning in computational intelligence is sample-inefficient when using learning-based methods and suffers from poor generalization. A training-free, data-grounded approach is needed to adapt hyperparameters in real time.
AI.method: AutoEP uses (1) an online ELA module that provides real-time feedback on search dynamics and (2) a multi-LLM reasoning chain that interprets this feedback to generate adaptive hyperparameter strategies in a zero-shot setting, mitigating hallucinations by grounding reasoning in empirical data. Evaluated on three metaheuristics and diverse combinatorial benchmarks.
AI.result: AutoEP consistently outperforms state-of-the-art tuners, including neural-evolution and other LLM-based methods. Open-source Qwen3-30B achieves GPT-4-level performance on these tasks. Code available at the provided URL.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates a powerful, accessible paradigm for automated hyperparameter design that reduces training requirements, scales across models, and broadens the practical use of LLMs for algorithm control.

title: MDP modeling for multi-stage stochastic programs
summary:
We study a class of multi-stage stochastic programs, which incorporate
modeling features from Markov decision processes (MDPs). This class includes
structured MDPs with continuous state and action spaces. We extend policy
graphs to include decision-dependent uncertainty for one-step transition
probabilities as well as a limited form of statistical learning. We focus on
the expressiveness of our modeling approach, illustrating ideas with a series
of examples of increasing complexity. As a solution method, we develop new
variants of stochastic dual dynamic programming, including approximations to
handle non-convexities.

AI.tldr: A flexible multi-stage stochastic-programming framework blending MDPs with continuous state/action spaces, featuring decision-dependent transition uncertainty and limited learning, solved via new SDDP variants capable of handling non-convexities.
AI.motivation: To model complex decision problems with dynamics that depend on decisions and with an element of learning about uncertainty, in a continuous, multi-stage setting.
AI.method: Extend policy graphs to allow decision-dependent one-step transitions and incorporate a limited form of statistical learning; develop new variants of stochastic dual dynamic programming with approximations to handle non-convexities; illustrate through increasingly complex examples.
AI.result: Demonstrates expressiveness of the modeling approach via a progression of examples; proposes SDDP-based solution variants that address non-convexities in this setting.
AI.conclusion: Enriches the MDP-informed multi-stage stochastic programming framework with decision-dependent uncertainty and learning, and offers scalable SDDP-based methods applicable to a broad class of problems, while leaving room for further refinement.

title: ControlEvents: Controllable Synthesis of Event Camera Datawith Foundational Prior from Image Diffusion Models
summary:
In recent years, event cameras have gained significant attention due to their
bio-inspired properties, such as high temporal resolution and high dynamic
range. However, obtaining large-scale labeled ground-truth data for event-based
vision tasks remains challenging and costly. In this paper, we present
ControlEvents, a diffusion-based generative model designed to synthesize
high-quality event data guided by diverse control signals such as class text
labels, 2D skeletons, and 3D body poses. Our key insight is to leverage the
diffusion prior from foundation models, such as Stable Diffusion, enabling
high-quality event data generation with minimal fine-tuning and limited labeled
data. Our method streamlines the data generation process and significantly
reduces the cost of producing labeled event datasets. We demonstrate the
effectiveness of our approach by synthesizing event data for visual
recognition, 2D skeleton estimation, and 3D body pose estimation. Our
experiments show that the synthesized labeled event data enhances model
performance in all tasks. Additionally, our approach can generate events based
on unseen text labels during training, illustrating the powerful text-based
generation capabilities inherited from foundation models.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based generative model, ControlEvents, synthesizes labeled event data using foundation-model priors guided by text and poses; reduces labeling cost and improves downstream tasks.
AI.motivation: Ground-truth labeled event data is scarce and expensive to obtain, hindering event-based vision research. A scalable data-generation approach is needed.
AI.method: ControlEvents uses diffusion-based generation guided by control signals (class text labels, 2D skeletons, 3D body poses) and leverages diffusion priors from foundation models (e.g., Stable Diffusion) to enable high-quality event data with minimal fine-tuning and limited labeled data.
AI.result: Synthesized event data improves performance on tasks such as visual recognition, 2D skeleton estimation, and 3D body pose estimation; the model can generate events for unseen text labels.
AI.conclusion: The approach reduces data-generation costs while enabling high-quality labeled event datasets and demonstrates strong text-based generation capabilities inherited from foundation models.

title: Physically-Feasible Reactive Synthesis for Terrain-Adaptive Locomotion
summary:
We present an integrated planning framework for quadrupedal locomotion over
dynamically changing, unforeseen terrains. Existing methods often depend on
heuristics for real-time foothold selection-limiting robustness and
adaptability-or rely on computationally intensive trajectory optimization
across complex terrains and long horizons. In contrast, our approach combines
reactive synthesis for generating correct-by-construction symbolic-level
controllers with mixed-integer convex programming (MICP) for dynamic and
physically feasible footstep planning during each symbolic transition. To
reduce the reliance on costly MICP solves and accommodate specifications that
may be violated due to physical infeasibility, we adopt a symbolic repair
mechanism that selectively generates only the required symbolic transitions.
During execution, real-time MICP replanning based on actual terrain data,
combined with runtime symbolic repair and delay-aware coordination, enables
seamless bridging between offline synthesis and online operation. Through
extensive simulation and hardware experiments, we validate the framework's
ability to identify missing locomotion skills and respond effectively in
safety-critical environments, including scattered stepping stones and rebar
scenarios.

AI.tldr: An integrated planning framework for quadrupedal locomotion on dynamic, unforeseen terrains that blends correct-by-construction symbolic synthesis with real-time MICP-based footstep planning, using symbolic repair and delay-aware replanning to reduce computation and increase robustness.
AI.motivation: Existing methods either rely on heuristics for foothold selection, limiting robustness, or depend on expensive trajectory optimization over long horizons. There is a need for real-time, robust, and adaptable locomotion planning that can handle unforeseen terrains while maintaining tractable computation.
AI.method: Combine reactive symbolic synthesis (correct-by-construction controllers) with mixed-integer convex programming (MICP) for per-transition footstep planning. Introduce symbolic repair to generate only necessary symbolic transitions, reducing MICP solves. During execution, perform real-time MICP replanning from actual terrain data, augmented with runtime symbolic repair and delay-aware coordination to bridge offline synthesis and online operation.
AI.result: Simulation and hardware experiments show the framework can identify missing locomotion skills, respond effectively in safety-critical scenarios (e.g., scattered stepping stones, rebar), and adapt to dynamic terrains while reducing reliance on costly optimization.
AI.conclusion: The approach offers a viable path to robust, real-time quadrupedal locomotion over unforeseen terrains by fusing symbolic synthesis with optimization, using repairs to manage infeasibility and replanning to bridge offline-online operation; it highlights potential for improved adaptability and skill discovery.

title: $p$-less Sampling: A Robust Hyperparameter-Free Approach for LLM Decoding
summary:
Obtaining high-quality outputs from Large Language Models (LLMs) often
depends upon the choice of a sampling-based decoding strategy to
probabilistically choose the next token at each generation step. While a
variety of such sampling methods have been proposed, their performance can be
sensitive to the selection of hyperparameters which may require different
settings depending upon the generation task and temperature configuration. In
this work, we introduce $p$-less sampling: an information-theoretic approach to
sampling which dynamically sets a truncation threshold at each decoding step
based on the entire token probability distribution. Unlike existing methods,
$p$-less sampling has no hyperparameters and consistently produces high-quality
outputs as temperature increases. We provide theoretical perspectives on
$p$-less sampling to ground our proposed method and conduct experiments to
empirically validate its effectiveness across a range of math, logical
reasoning, and creative writing tasks. Our results demonstrate how $p$-less
sampling consistently outperforms existing sampling approaches while exhibiting
much less degradation in text quality at higher temperature values. We further
show how $p$-less achieves greater inference-time efficiency than alternative
methods through lower average token sampling times and shorter generation
lengths, without sacrificing accuracy. Finally, we provide analyses to
highlight the benefits of $p$-less through qualitative examples, case studies,
and diversity assessments.

AI.tldr: A hyperparameter-free, information-theoretic decoding method called p-less sampling dynamically truncates the per-step token distribution to select the next token, yielding robust, high-quality outputs across tasks and temperatures with improved efficiency.
AI.motivation: Sampling-based decoding for LLMs relies on hyperparameters (e.g., temperature, top-p/top-k) that must be tuned for different tasks and configurations. There is a need for a universal, hyperparameter-free decoding strategy that maintains quality as temperature varies.
AI.method: p-less sampling introduces a dynamic truncation threshold at each decoding step based on the complete token probability distribution, without any hyperparameters. The approach is grounded in information theory, and the authors validate it theoretically and empirically across math, logical reasoning, and creative writing tasks, demonstrating higher efficiency via shorter sampling times and generation lengths.
AI.result: p-less sampling consistently outperforms existing sampling methods, showing less degradation in text quality at higher temperatures, and achieving greater inference-time efficiency without sacrificing accuracy. Qualitative analyses, case studies, and diversity assessments corroborate the improvements.
AI.conclusion: p-less sampling offers a robust, hyperparameter-free decoding strategy that improves output quality and efficiency across tasks and temperature regimes, suggesting it as a strong default alternative to traditional sampling methods.

title: T-TAMER: Provably Taming Trade-offs in ML Serving
comment:
Correspondence should be directed to yyangh@cs.washington.edu or
  haifengxu@uchicago.edu. This manuscript extends our earlier workshop version
  accepted at NeurIPS SPIGM 2025
summary:
As machine learning models continue to grow in size and complexity, efficient
serving faces increasingly broad trade-offs spanning accuracy, latency,
resource usage, and other objectives. Multi-model serving further complicates
these trade-offs; for example, in cascaded models, each early-exit decision
balances latency reduction against potential accuracy loss. Despite the
pervasiveness and importance of such trade-offs, current strategies remain
largely heuristic and case-specific, limiting both their theoretical guarantees
and general applicability.
  We present a general framework, T-Tamer, which formalizes this setting as a
multi-stage decision process, where the objective is to determine both when to
exit and which model to consult. Our main result shows that recall (i.e., the
ability to revisit earlier models) is both necessary and sufficient for
achieving provable performance guarantees. In particular, we prove that
strategies without recall cannot obtain any constant-factor approximation to
the optimal trade-off, whereas recall-based strategies provably attain the
optimal trade-off in polynomial time.
  We validate our analysis through experiments on synthetic datasets and
early-exit workloads for vision and NLP benchmarks. The results show that
recall-based strategies consistently yield efficient accuracy-latency
trade-offs. We hope this work provides a principled foundation for bridging
heuristic practice with theoretical guarantees in the design of early-exit and
cascaded models.

AI.tldr: A general multi-stage model serving framework (T-Tamer) that formalizes early-exit/cascaded models as a decision process and shows recall is necessary and sufficient for provable guarantees, enabling polynomial-time optimal trade-offs; validated on synthetic data and vision/NLP workloads.
AI.motivation: Efficient model serving requires principled guarantees on accuracy vs. latency/resource trade-offs, especially with cascaded models and early exits. Current strategies are heuristic with limited theoretical guarantees.
AI.method: Introduce T-Tamer framework as a multi-stage decision process to decide when to exit and which model to consult. Prove that recall (ability to revisit earlier models) is necessary and sufficient for provable performance guarantees. Show that non-recall strategies cannot achieve constant-factor approximations, while recall-based strategies can achieve the optimal trade-off in polynomial time. Validate with experiments on synthetic datasets and early-exit workloads for vision and NLP.
AI.result: Theoretically, recall is both necessary and sufficient for provable guarantees; non-recall strategies fail to achieve a constant-factor approximation, while recall-based strategies attain the optimal trade-off in polynomial time. Empirically, recall-based strategies yield efficient accuracy-latency trade-offs on synthetic data and vision/NLP benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: This work provides a principled foundation for designing early-exit and cascaded models with theoretical guarantees, bridging heuristic practice and theory, and highlighting recall as a central component for optimal trade-offs.

title: Learning KAN-based Implicit Neural Representations for Deformable Image Registration
summary:
Deformable image registration (DIR) is a cornerstone of medical image
analysis, enabling spatial alignment for tasks like comparative studies and
multi-modal fusion. While learning-based methods (e.g., CNNs, transformers)
offer fast inference, they often require large training datasets and struggle
to match the precision of classical iterative approaches on some organ types
and imaging modalities. Implicit neural representations (INRs) have emerged as
a promising alternative, parameterizing deformations as continuous mappings
from coordinates to displacement vectors. However, this comes at the cost of
requiring instance-specific optimization, making computational efficiency and
seed-dependent learning stability critical factors for these methods. In this
work, we propose KAN-IDIR and RandKAN-IDIR, the first integration of
Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) into deformable image registration with
implicit neural representations (INRs). Our proposed randomized basis sampling
strategy reduces the required number of basis functions in KAN while
maintaining registration quality, thereby significantly lowering computational
costs. We evaluated our approach on three diverse datasets (lung CT, brain MRI,
cardiac MRI) and compared it with competing instance-specific learning-based
approaches, dataset-trained deep learning models, and classical registration
approaches. KAN-IDIR and RandKAN-IDIR achieved the highest accuracy among
INR-based methods across all evaluated modalities and anatomies, with minimal
computational overhead and superior learning stability across multiple random
seeds. Additionally, we discovered that our RandKAN-IDIR model with randomized
basis sampling slightly outperforms the model with learnable basis function
indices, while eliminating its additional training-time complexity.

AI.tldr: Integrates Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks with implicit neural representations for deformable image registration, achieving high INR-based accuracy with smaller basis sets via randomized basis sampling; shows strong stability across seeds and datasets.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of learning-based DIR (data-hungry, modality-specific; INRs need instance optimization; classical methods are accurate but slow) by employing KANs to compactly and robustly represent deformations, and randomized basis sampling to further reduce computation.
AI.method: Extend INRs with KANs (KAN-IDIR) and RandKAN-IDIR. Use randomized basis sampling to reduce the number of basis functions. Evaluate on lung CT, brain MRI, cardiac MRI; compare to instance-learning, dataset-trained DL, and classical approaches; test seed stability.
AI.result: KAN-IDIR and RandKAN-IDIR achieve the highest accuracy among INR-based methods across presented modalities with minimal overhead and robust performance across seeds; RandKAN-IDIR with randomized basis sampling slightly outperforms baselines using learnable basis indices while avoiding extra training-time cost.
AI.conclusion: KAN-based INR DIR is a promising, efficient, and stable approach for multi-modal deformable registration, with RandKAN-IDIR offering improved robustness and reduced training complexity; applicable to diverse imaging domains.

title: CE-Nav: Flow-Guided Reinforcement Refinement for Cross-Embodiment Local Navigation
summary:
Generalizing local navigation policies across diverse robot morphologies is a
critical challenge. Progress is often hindered by the need for costly and
embodiment-specific data, the tight coupling of planning and control, and the
"disastrous averaging" problem where deterministic models fail to capture
multi-modal decisions (e.g., turning left or right). We introduce CE-Nav, a
novel two-stage (IL-then-RL) framework that systematically decouples universal
geometric reasoning from embodiment-specific dynamic adaptation. First, we
train an embodiment-agnostic General Expert offline using imitation learning.
This expert, a conditional normalizing flow model named VelFlow, learns the
full distribution of kinematically-sound actions from a large-scale dataset
generated by a classical planner, completely avoiding real robot data and
resolving the multi-modality issue. Second, for a new robot, we freeze the
expert and use it as a guiding prior to train a lightweight, Dynamics-Aware
Refiner via online reinforcement learning. This refiner rapidly learns to
compensate for the target robot's specific dynamics and controller
imperfections with minimal environmental interaction. Extensive experiments on
quadrupeds, bipeds, and quadrotors show that CE-Nav achieves state-of-the-art
performance while drastically reducing adaptation cost. Successful real-world
deployments further validate our approach as an efficient and scalable solution
for building generalizable navigation systems.

AI.tldr: CE-Nav introduces a two-stage IL-then-RL framework that generalizes local navigation across diverse robot morphologies by decoupling universal geometry from embodiment-specific dynamics. It uses an offline embodiment-agnostic expert VelFlow (a conditional normalizing flow) trained via imitation learning on planner data to capture multi-modal action distributions, followed by a lightweight Dynamics-Aware Refiner trained online with RL to adapt to target robot dynamics. This yields state-of-the-art navigation with drastically reduced adaptation cost and success in real-world deployments.
AI.motivation: Generalizing local navigation policies across diverse robot morphologies is hindered by the need for costly embodiment-specific data, tight planning–control coupling, and the impossibility of capturing multi-modal decisions with deterministic models. A method that separates universal geometric reasoning from embodiment-specific dynamics can reduce data needs and improve scalability.
AI.method: Stage 1 Offline General Expert: train VelFlow (conditional normalizing flow) via imitation learning on a large planner-generated dataset to model the distribution of kinematically-sound actions, avoiding real robot data and resolving multi-modality. Stage 2 Online Refinement: freeze the expert and train a lightweight Dynamics-Aware Refiner with online reinforcement learning on the target robot to adapt to its dynamics and controller imperfections with minimal environmental interaction.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation across quadrupeds, bipeds, and quadrotors demonstrates state-of-the-art performance and substantially reduced adaptation cost. Real-world deployments validate the method as an efficient and scalable solution for generalizable navigation.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling universal geometric reasoning from embodiment-specific dynamic adaptation enables scalable, data-efficient generalization of navigation policies across diverse robot morphologies. The two-stage IL-then-RL CE-Nav framework yields strong performance and practical deployment benefits.

title: Agentic AI Reasoning for Mobile Edge General Intelligence: Fundamentals, Approaches, and Directions
summary:
The rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) has enabled an
emergence of agentic artificial intelligence (AI) with powerful reasoning and
autonomous decision-making capabilities. This integration with edge computing
has led to the development of Mobile Edge General Intelligence (MEGI), which
brings real-time, privacy-preserving reasoning to the network edge. However,
deploying LLM-based agentic AI reasoning in MEGI environments poses significant
challenges due to the high computational demands of reasoning and the limited
resources of edge devices. To address these challenges, we propose a joint
optimization framework for efficient LLM reasoning deployment in MEGI. First,
we review methods that enhance LLM reasoning capabilities, such as
Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting, Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT), and Mixture of
Experts (MoE). Next, we present a distributed framework that addresses two
correlated aspects: reasoning enhancement through adaptive CoT prompting and
scalable deployment through distributed MoE architecture. The framework
dynamically activates expert networks and adjusts reasoning depth based on task
complexity and device capabilities. We further conduct experimental evaluations
in mobile edge environments. Experimental results demonstrate the framework's
effectiveness in balancing reasoning quality with resource efficiency,
validating the practical viability of deploying sophisticated LLM reasoning
capabilities in resource-constrained MEGI environments.

AI.tldr: A joint optimization framework enabling efficient LLM reasoning on MEGI by combining adaptive CoT prompting and distributed MoE, with dynamic reasoning depth, to balance quality and resource use in edge environments, validated experimentally.
AI.motivation: To enable real-time, privacy-preserving LLM-based agentic AI at mobile network edges, addressing the high computational demands and limited resources of edge devices.
AI.method: Review reasoning-enhancement methods (Chain-of-Thought prompting, SFT, Mixture of Experts) and present a distributed framework that adaptively activates expert networks and adjusts reasoning depth based on task complexity and device capabilities; uses distributed MoE to scale deployment in MEGI; includes experimental evaluation in mobile edge environments.
AI.result: The framework demonstrates a favorable balance between reasoning quality and resource efficiency in MEGI settings, showing practical viability for deploying advanced LLM reasoning on resource-constrained edge devices.
AI.conclusion: The proposed joint optimization framework enables efficient, real-time, and privacy-preserving LLM reasoning on MEGI, enabling broader deployment of sophisticated agentic AI at the network edge; suggests directions for improved adaptive prompting and scalable MoE deployment.

title: Analysis of Variational Autoencoders
summary:
Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs) have emerged as a promising approach for
interpreting neural network representations by learning sparse,
human-interpretable features from dense activations. We investigate whether
incorporating variational methods into SAE architectures can improve feature
organization and interpretability. We introduce the variational Sparse
Autoencoder (vSAE), which replaces deterministic ReLU gating with stochastic
sampling from learned Gaussian posteriors and incorporates KL divergence
regularization toward a standard normal prior. Our hypothesis is that this
probabilistic sampling creates dispersive pressure, causing features to
organize more coherently in the latent space while avoiding overlap. We
evaluate a Topk vSAE against a standard TopK SAE on Pythia-70M transformer
residual steam activations using comprehensive benchmarks including SAE Bench,
individual feature interpretability analysis, and global latent space
visualization through t-SNE. The vSAE underperforms standard SAE across core
evaluation metrics, though excels at feature independence and ablation metrics.
The KL divergence term creates excessive regularization pressure that
substantially reduces the fraction of living features, leading to observed
performance degradation. While vSAE features demonstrate improved robustness,
they exhibit many more dead features than baseline. Our findings suggest that
naive application of variational methods to SAEs does not improve feature
organization or interpretability.

AI.tldr: vSAE with stochastic Gaussian sampling and KL regularization does not improve feature organization or interpretability relative to a standard SAE; excessive regularization reduces alive features, though robustness improves.
AI.motivation: To enhance interpretability and organization of sparse autoencoders by introducing probabilistic latent representations and variational regularization.
AI.method: Replace deterministic ReLU gating with sampling from learned Gaussian posteriors; apply KL divergence toward a standard normal prior; compare TopK vSAE and TopK SAE on Pythia-70M transformer residual activations; evaluate with SAE Bench, feature interpretability analysis, and t-SNE latent-space visualization.
AI.result: vSAE underperforms on core evaluation metrics; KL term imposes strong regularization that drastically reduces the fraction of living features, leading to degraded performance; more dead features observed; robustness improves.
AI.conclusion: Naive application of variational methods to SAEs does not improve feature organization or interpretability.

title: Convolutional Set Transformer
summary:
We introduce the Convolutional Set Transformer (CST), a novel neural
architecture designed to process image sets of arbitrary cardinality that are
visually heterogeneous yet share high-level semantics - such as a common
category, scene, or concept. Existing set-input networks, e.g., Deep Sets and
Set Transformer, are limited to vector inputs and cannot directly handle 3D
image tensors. As a result, they must be cascaded with a feature extractor,
typically a CNN, which encodes images into embeddings before the set-input
network can model inter-image relationships. In contrast, CST operates directly
on 3D image tensors, performing feature extraction and contextual modeling
simultaneously, thereby enabling synergies between the two processes. This
design yields superior performance in tasks such as Set Classification and Set
Anomaly Detection and further provides native compatibility with CNN
explainability methods such as Grad-CAM, unlike competing approaches that
remain opaque. Finally, we show that CSTs can be pre-trained on large-scale
datasets and subsequently adapted to new domains and tasks through standard
Transfer Learning schemes. To support further research, we release CST-15, a
CST backbone pre-trained on ImageNet
(https://github.com/chinefed/convolutional-set-transformer).

AI.tldr: A Convolutional Set Transformer (CST) processes image sets directly as 3D tensors, integrating feature extraction and set-level reasoning to outperform vector-input approaches, enable explainability via Grad-CAM, and support transfer learning with pre-trained CST-15 on ImageNet.
AI.motivation: To handle image sets with arbitrary size and heterogeneous visuals that share high-level semantics without relying on sequential CNN+SET cascades; current methods operate on embeddings and lose end-to-end synergy and explainability.
AI.method: Introduce CST, a neural architecture that operates directly on 3D image tensors to perform simultaneous feature extraction and contextual modeling of image sets. CST handles arbitrary set cardinality, yields inter-image relationships, and is compatible with Grad-CAM. The approach supports pre-training on large datasets (CST-15 on ImageNet) and transfer learning.
AI.result: CST achieves superior performance on Set Classification and Set Anomaly Detection, offers native Grad-CAM compatibility for explainability, and demonstrates transfer learning capability via pre-training on ImageNet with CST-15 for adaptation to new domains/tasks.
AI.conclusion: CST enables end-to-end processing of image sets, improving performance and transparency over cascaded methods and enabling practical transfer learning through a pre-trained CST backbone.

title: Simulated Annealing for Multi-Robot Ergodic Information Acquisition Using Graph-Based Discretization
summary:
One of the goals of active information acquisition using multi-robot teams is
to keep the relative uncertainty in each region at the same level to maintain
identical acquisition quality (e.g., consistent target detection) in all the
regions. To achieve this goal, ergodic coverage can be used to assign the
number of samples according to the quality of observation, i.e., sampling noise
levels. However, the noise levels are unknown to the robots. Although this
noise can be estimated from samples, the estimates are unreliable at first and
can generate fluctuating values. The main contribution of this paper is to use
simulated annealing to generate the target sampling distribution, starting from
uniform and gradually shifting to an estimated optimal distribution, by varying
the coldness parameter of a Boltzmann distribution with the estimated sampling
entropy as energy. Simulation results show a substantial improvement of both
transient and asymptotic entropy compared to both uniform and direct-ergodic
searches. Finally, a demonstration is performed with a TurtleBot swarm system
to validate the physical applicability of the algorithm.

AI.tldr: Adaptive sampling for multi-robot ergodic coverage with unknown noise; uses simulated annealing to converge from uniform to an estimated optimal distribution using estimated entropy as energy; improves entropy and is validated on real robots.
AI.motivation: Maintain equal acquisition quality across regions in multi-robot sensing when noise levels are unknown and early estimates are unreliable; improve sampling distribution beyond uniform or direct-ergodic approaches.
AI.method: Apply simulated annealing to generate the target sampling distribution. Start from uniform, progressively shift toward an estimated optimal distribution by tuning the Boltzmann distribution's temperature (coldness). The energy is the estimated sampling entropy, which reflects observation quality uncertainties.
AI.result: Simulation results show substantial improvements in both transient and asymptotic entropy compared to uniform and direct-ergodic searches. A TurtleBot swarm demonstration validates the algorithm's physical applicability.
AI.conclusion: Annealing toward an estimated optimal distribution mitigates early unreliability of noise estimates and improves sampling efficiency in multi-robot ergodic coverage. The method is practically applicable to real robot teams and may generalize to other domains with uncertain observation noise.

title: Training Vision-Language Process Reward Models for Test-Time Scaling in Multimodal Reasoning: Key Insights and Lessons Learned
summary:
Process Reward Models (PRMs) provide step-level supervision that improves the
reliability of reasoning in large language models. While PRMs have been
extensively studied in text-based domains, their extension to Vision Language
Models (VLMs) remains limited. Existing Vision-Language PRMs (VL-PRMs) rely on
Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) for data construction, which can often produce
noisy supervision signals and limit generalization across tasks. In this work,
we aim to elucidate the design space of VL-PRMs by exploring diverse strategies
for dataset construction, training, and test-time scaling. First, we introduce
a hybrid data synthesis framework that combines MCTS with judgments from a
strong VLM, producing more accurate step-level labels. Second, we propose
perception-focused supervision, enabling our PRM to explicitly detect errors at
the visual grounding stage of reasoning. Third, we systematically evaluate
multiple test-time scaling strategies, showing that our PRMs can reliably guide
VLMs toward more accurate solutions. Our experiments covering five diverse
multimodal benchmarks (MMMU, PuzzleVQA, AlgoPuzzleVQA, MathVista, and
MathVision) reveal several key insights: (i) VL-PRMs when used as Outcome
Reward Models (ORMs) during test-time scaling (TTS) can outperform VL-PRM
guided process step selection, (ii) smaller VL-PRMs can match or even surpass
larger ones in detecting process errors, (iii) VL-PRMs uncover latent reasoning
abilities in stronger VLM backbones, (iv) perception-level supervision leads to
significant gains in test-time scaling, and (v) TTS performance of different
policies improve on advanced math reasoning datasets despite not training
VL-PRMs on such datasets. We hope our work will motivate further research and
support the advancement of VLMs.

AI.tldr: This work studies Vision-Language Process Reward Models (VL-PRMs), introducing a hybrid data-synthesis pipeline (MCTS + strong VLM judgments), perception-focused supervision for visual-grounding errors, and a range of test-time scaling (TTS) strategies. Across five multimodal benchmarks, ORM-based TTS often outperforms step-based policy selection; smaller VL-PRMs can match or exceed larger ones in error detection; VL-PRMs reveal latent reasoning in stronger backbones; perception supervision yields large gains; and TTS policies improve advanced math reasoning on unseen datasets without training VL-PRMs there.
AI.motivation: VL-PRMs promise step-level supervision for reliable reasoning in large language models, but extending them to Vision-Language Models faces noisy supervision from MCTS and limited cross-task generalization. This work aims to map the design space of VL-PRMs across data construction, supervision signals, and test-time strategies to improve VLM reasoning.
AI.method: 1) Propose a hybrid data-synthesis framework that combines Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) with judgments from a strong VLM to produce more accurate step-level labels. 2) Introduce perception-focused supervision to explicitly detect errors at the visual-grounding stage of reasoning. 3) Systematically evaluate multiple test-time scaling strategies to guide VLMs toward better solutions. 4) Empirically evaluate on five multimodal benchmarks (MMMU, PuzzleVQA, AlgoPuzzleVQA, MathVista, MathVision).
AI.result: Key empirical findings: (i) Using VL-PRMs as Outcome Reward Models (ORMs) during test-time scaling (TTS) can outperform VL-PRM guided process-step selection. (ii) Smaller VL-PRMs can match or surpass larger ones in detecting process errors. (iii) VL-PRMs reveal latent reasoning abilities in stronger VLM backbones. (iv) Perception-level supervision yields significant gains in TTS. (v) TTS policy performance improves on advanced math datasets even without training VL-PRMs on those datasets.
AI.conclusion: The study maps the VL-PRM design space, showing that hybrid data synthesis, perception-focused supervision, and ORM-based TTS can meaningfully improve VLM reasoning. The findings encourage further research and generalization of VL-PRMs across tasks and backbones.

title: Sample-efficient Multiclass Calibration under $\ell_{p}$ Error
summary:
Calibrating a multiclass predictor, that outputs a distribution over labels,
is particularly challenging due to the exponential number of possible
prediction values. In this work, we propose a new definition of calibration
error that interpolates between two established calibration error notions, one
with known exponential sample complexity and one with polynomial sample
complexity for calibrating a given predictor. Our algorithm can calibrate any
given predictor for the entire range of interpolation, except for one endpoint,
using only a polynomial number of samples. At the other endpoint, we achieve
nearly optimal dependence on the error parameter, improving upon previous work.
A key technical contribution is a novel application of adaptive data analysis
with high adaptivity but only logarithmic overhead in the sample complexity.

AI.tldr: Introduces a tunable calibration error for multiclass predictors that interpolates between two existing notions with different sample complexities, and presents an algorithm that calibrates across almost the entire interpolation range using polynomial samples, with near-optimal error dependence at one endpoint. A key technical tool is adaptive data analysis with high adaptivity and low sample overhead.
AI.motivation: Calibration of multiclass predictors is challenging due to the exponential number of possible prediction outputs. Existing calibration notions impose tradeoffs between sample complexity and the accuracy of calibration; the work seeks a unified, flexible measure that can be tuned to balance these resources.
AI.method: Define a new interpolation-based calibration error that bridges two traditional notions. Develop an algorithm that calibrates any given predictor over the full interpolation range except for one endpoint, using only polynomially many samples. At the opposite endpoint, achieve near-optimal dependence on the error parameter. Leverage adaptive data analysis with high adaptivity but only logarithmic sample overhead.
AI.result: The proposed calibration framework achieves polynomial sample complexity across most of the interpolation range, and near-optimal dependence on the error parameter at the endpoint. It advances previous work by improving sample efficiency and offering a flexible, unified calibration notion.
AI.conclusion: A tunable calibration error can unify and improve calibration efficiency for multiclass predictors. The approach highlights adaptive data analysis as a critical component to attain low sample complexity under high adaptivity, enabling practical calibration across a broad range of settings.

title: TY-RIST: Tactical YOLO Tricks for Real-time Infrared Small Target Detection
comment: Acctepted at the ICCV 2025 MIRA workshop, 11 pages, 7 figures
summary:
Infrared small target detection (IRSTD) is critical for defense and
surveillance but remains challenging due to (1) target loss from minimal
features, (2) false alarms in cluttered environments, (3) missed detections
from low saliency, and (4) high computational costs. To address these issues,
we propose TY-RIST, an optimized YOLOv12n architecture that integrates (1) a
stride-aware backbone with fine-grained receptive fields, (2) a high-resolution
detection head, (3) cascaded coordinate attention blocks, and (4) a branch
pruning strategy that reduces computational cost by about 25.5% while
marginally improving accuracy and enabling real-time inference. We also
incorporate the Normalized Gaussian Wasserstein Distance (NWD) to enhance
regression stability. Extensive experiments on four benchmarks and across 20
different models demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, improving mAP at 0.5
IoU by +7.9%, Precision by +3%, and Recall by +10.2%, while achieving up to 123
FPS on a single GPU. Cross-dataset validation on a fifth dataset further
confirms strong generalization capability. Additional results and resources are
available at https://www.github.com/moured/TY-RIST

AI.tldr: TY-RIST: an optimized YOLOv12n for infrared small target detection that combines a stride-aware backbone, high-resolution detection head, cascaded coordinate attention, and branch pruning with Normalized Gaussian Wasserstein Distance (NWD), delivering real-time performance and state-of-the-art accuracy across benchmarks with strong generalization.
AI.motivation: Infrared small target detection (IRSTD) is hampered by tiny targets with minimal features, high false alarms in clutter, missed detections due to low saliency, and high computational costs; a more efficient and accurate detector is needed for defense and surveillance.
AI.method: Introduce TY-RIST, an optimized YOLOv12n architecture featuring (1) a stride-aware backbone with fine-grained receptive fields, (2) a high-resolution detection head, (3) cascaded coordinate attention blocks, and (4) a branch pruning strategy reducing compute by ~25.5%. Also incorporate Normalized Gaussian Wasserstein Distance (NWD) for regression stability. Evaluate across four benchmarks and 20 models, with cross-dataset validation on a fifth dataset.
AI.result: Reported gains include mAP@0.5 up by 7.9 percentage points, Precision up by 3 percentage points, and Recall up by 10.2 percentage points. Achieved up to 123 FPS on a single GPU. Demonstrated strong generalization across four benchmarks and a cross-dataset validation on an additional dataset.
AI.conclusion: TY-RIST delivers state-of-the-art IRSTD performance with real-time inference and robust cross-dataset generalization, achieved via architectural innovations, targeted attention mechanisms, cost-reducing pruning, and a regression-stabilizing loss (NWD). The work includes publicly available resources.

title: GLUE: Global-Local Unified Encoding for Imitation Learning via Key-Patch Tracking
summary:
In recent years, visual representation learning has gained widespread
attention in robotic imitation learning. However, in complex
Out-of-Distribution(OOD) settings characterized by clutter and occlusion, the
attention of global visual representations can be diluted or interfered,
leading to degraded policy performance. The invariance of local representations
for task-relevant objects offers a solution. By efficiently utilizing these
local representations, training and testing data can be mapped to a more
similar feature space, thereby mitigating the covariate shift problem.
Accordingly, we propose GLUE, a global-local unified encoding framework for
imitation learning based on key-patch tracking. GLUE selects and tracks
key-patches as critical local representations by employing a text-guided
mechanism. It features a novel fusion framework where global patch features
query local patches to distill essential information, yielding fine-grained
local features with low heterogeneity relative to the global context. This
fused representation steers the robot's visual attention toward task-relevant
objects and preserves precise global context, which together align the training
and testing distributions into a similar and task-informative feature space,
ultimately enhancing the robustness of the imitation learning policy.
Experiments demonstrate that GLUE achieves strong performance across diverse
tasks in both simulation and real-world settings, outperforming the strongest
baseline by 17.6% in simulation, 36.3% in real-world environments, and 58.3% on
real-world generalization settings. The project website of GLUE is available at
https://GLUE666.github.io/.

AI.tldr: A global-local encoding (GLUE) framework for imitation learning that uses text-guided key-patch tracking to fuse local task-relevant patches with global features, improving robustness to clutter and occlusion by aligning training/testing distributions and outperforming strong baselines across simulation and real-world tasks.
