AI.motivation: Global visual representations suffer under Out-of-Distribution clutter and occlusion, diluting attention and harming policy performance. Local, task-relevant representations are more invariant and can reduce covariate shift between training and testing.
AI.method: GLUE selects and tracks key patches as local representations via a text-guided mechanism. It introduces a fusion framework where global patch features query local patches to distill essential information, producing fine-grained local features with low heterogeneity relative to global context. The fused global-local representation guides visual attention to task-relevant objects while preserving the global context.
AI.result: GLUE achieves strong performance gains over the strongest baseline: 17.6% in simulation, 36.3% in real-world environments, and 58.3% on real-world generalization tasks. Demonstrated across diverse tasks in both simulation and real-world settings; project website provided.
AI.conclusion: GLUE robustly improves imitation learning by aligning training and testing distributions in a task-informative feature space through a global-local fusion of patch representations, emphasizing local invariance for task-critical objects while maintaining global context.

title: GUI-PRA: Process Reward Agent for GUI Tasks
summary:
Graphical User Interface (GUI) Agents powered by Multimodal Large Language
Models (MLLMs) show significant potential for automating tasks. However, they
often struggle with long-horizon tasks, leading to frequent failures. Process
Reward Models (PRMs) are a promising solution, as they can guide these agents
with crucial process signals during inference. Nevertheless, their application
to the GUI domain presents unique challenges. When processing dense artificial
inputs with long history data, PRMs suffer from a "lost in the middle"
phenomenon, where the overwhelming historical context compromises the
evaluation of the current step. Furthermore, standard PRMs lacks GUI changing
awareness, providing static evaluations that are disconnected from the dynamic
consequences of actions, a critical mismatch with the inherently dynamic nature
of GUI tasks. In response to these challenges, we introduce GUI-PRA (Process
Reward Agent for GUI Tasks), a judge agent designed to better provide process
reward than standard PRM by intelligently processing historical context and
actively perceiving UI state changes. Specifically, to directly combat the
``lost in the middle'' phenomenon, we introduce a dynamic memory mechanism
consisting of two core components: a Relevance-based Retrieval Module to
actively fetch pertinent information from long histories and a Progressive
Summarization Module to dynamically condense growing interaction data, ensuring
the model focuses on relevant context. Moreover, to address the lack of UI
changing awareness, we introduce an Aadaptive UI Perception mechanism. This
mechanism enables the agent to reason about UI state changes and dynamically
select the most appropriate tool to gather grounded visual evidence, ensuring
its evaluation is always informed by the current UI context.

AI.tldr: GUI-PRA introduces a dynamic memory and UI-perception-based judge to guide GUI agents using Process Reward Models, addressing long-horizon and UI-dynamics challenges.
AI.motivation: PRMs struggle in GUI due to long history context ('lost in the middle') and lack of UI-change awareness; GUI tasks are dynamic and require grounded evaluation tied to current UI state.
AI.method: Proposes GUI-PRA with two modules: Relevance-based Retrieval to fetch pertinent history; Progressive Summarization to condense data; Adaptive UI Perception to observe UI changes and select appropriate grounding tools; integrates with MLLMs for process rewards in GUI tasks.
AI.result: Abstract presents architectural contribution and proposed method; no empirical results reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: GUI-PRA offers a pathway to more robust process reward signals in GUI tasks by focusing on relevant context and dynamic UI state, potentially improving long-horizon task performance for GUI agents.

title: Physically Plausible Multi-System Trajectory Generation and Symmetry Discovery
summary:
From metronomes to celestial bodies, mechanics underpins how the world
evolves in time and space. With consideration of this, a number of recent
neural network models leverage inductive biases from classical mechanics to
encourage model interpretability and ensure forecasted states are physical.
However, in general, these models are designed to capture the dynamics of a
single system with fixed physical parameters, from state-space measurements of
a known configuration space. In this paper we introduce Symplectic Phase Space
GAN (SPS-GAN) which can capture the dynamics of multiple systems, and
generalize to unseen physical parameters from. Moreover, SPS-GAN does not
require prior knowledge of the system configuration space. In fact, SPS-GAN can
discover the configuration space structure of the system from arbitrary
measurement types (e.g., state-space measurements, video frames). To achieve
physically plausible generation, we introduce a novel architecture which embeds
a Hamiltonian neural network recurrent module in a conditional GAN backbone. To
discover the structure of the configuration space, we optimize the conditional
time-series GAN objective with an additional physically motivated term to
encourages a sparse representation of the configuration space. We demonstrate
the utility of SPS-GAN for trajectory prediction, video generation and symmetry
discovery. Our approach captures multiple systems and achieves performance on
par with supervised models designed for single systems.

AI.tldr: SPS-GAN is a symplectic phase-space conditional GAN that jointly learns dynamics of multiple mechanical systems, discovers configuration-space structure from varied measurements, and generalizes to unseen parameters, matching single-system supervised models.
AI.motivation: Many physics-informed neural nets focus on a single system with fixed parameters and known configuration space. There is a need for models that generalize across multiple systems, infer the underlying configuration-space structure, and handle diverse measurement types (e.g., state-space, video).
AI.method: Embed a Hamiltonian neural network recurrent module inside a conditional GAN backbone (SPS-GAN). Add a physics-inspired term to the conditional time-series GAN objective to encourage a sparse representation of the configuration space, enabling discovery of configuration-space structure from arbitrary measurements.
AI.result: Demonstrates trajectory prediction, video generation, and symmetry discovery across multiple systems. Achieves performance on par with supervised models designed for single systems, indicating effective generalization.
AI.conclusion: SPS-GAN enables multi-system dynamics learning and configuration-space discovery from diverse measurements, with competitive performance and potential for broad physics-based generative tasks.

title: Learning Unified Representation of 3D Gaussian Splatting
summary:
A well-designed vectorized representation is crucial for the learning systems
natively based on 3D Gaussian Splatting. While 3DGS enables efficient and
explicit 3D reconstruction, its parameter-based representation remains hard to
learn as features, especially for neural-network-based models. Directly feeding
raw Gaussian parameters into learning frameworks fails to address the
non-unique and heterogeneous nature of the Gaussian parameterization, yielding
highly data-dependent models. This challenge motivates us to explore a more
principled approach to represent 3D Gaussian Splatting in neural networks that
preserves the underlying color and geometric structure while enforcing unique
mapping and channel homogeneity. In this paper, we propose an embedding
representation of 3DGS based on continuous submanifold fields that encapsulate
the intrinsic information of Gaussian primitives, thereby benefiting the
learning of 3DGS.

AI.tldr: Introduces an embedding-based representation for 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) using continuous submanifold fields to preserve color and geometry, enforce unique mapping, and improve learnability over raw Gaussian parameters.
AI.motivation: Raw Gaussian parameters are non-unique and heterogeneous, making learning difficult and data-dependent. A principled, structured, and homogeneous representation is needed to preserve intrinsic information for neural networks performing 3DGS reconstruction.
AI.method: Proposes an embedding representation of 3DGS based on continuous submanifold fields that encode the intrinsic information of Gaussian primitives, enabling unique mappings and channel-homogeneous features for neural networks while preserving color and geometric structure.
AI.result: Conceptual/architectural proposal with claimed benefits for learning 3DGS; the abstract does not report empirical results or experiments.
AI.conclusion: An embedding representation of 3D Gaussian Splatting via continuous submanifold fields to provide a principled, learnable representation that preserves color/geometry and ensures consistent mapping in neural-network models.

title: SAC-Loco: Safe and Adjustable Compliant Quadrupedal Locomotion
summary:
Quadruped robots are designed to achieve agile locomotion by mimicking legged
animals. However, existing control methods for quadrupeds often lack one of the
key capabilities observed in animals: adaptive and adjustable compliance in
response to external disturbances. Most locomotion controllers do not provide
tunable compliance and tend to fail under large perturbations. In this work, we
propose a switched policy framework for compliant and safe quadruped
locomotion. First, we train a force compliant policy with adjustable compliance
levels using a teacher student reinforcement learning framework, eliminating
the need for explicit force sensing. Next, we develop a safe policy based on
the capture point concept to stabilize the robot when the compliant policy
fails. Finally, we introduce a recoverability network that predicts the
likelihood of failure and switches between the compliant and safe policies.
Together, this framework enables quadruped robots to achieve both force
compliance and robust safety when subjected to severe external disturbances.

AI.tldr: A switched policy framework for quadrupeds enabling tunable force compliance and safety under disturbances via teacher-student RL, capture-point-based safety, and a recoverability predictor.
AI.motivation: Current quadruped controllers lack adjustable compliance and robust disturbance rejection, often failing under large perturbations and not leveraging compliant interaction with the environment. This work aims to provide tunable compliance without explicit force sensing and a safe fallback mechanism.
AI.method: 1) Train a force-compliant policy with adjustable compliance levels using teacher-student RL without explicit force sensing. 2) Develop a capture-point-based safe policy to stabilize the robot when the compliant policy fails. 3) Introduce a recoverability network to predict failure likelihood and switch between policies.
AI.result: Demonstrates that quadrupeds can achieve both force compliance and robust safety under severe external disturbances by switching between policies based on predicted recoverability.
AI.conclusion: A practical framework that combines adjustable compliance, safety, and automatic switching to enhance robustness of quadruped locomotion with minimal sensing requirements; ready for hardware validation and further work on scalability and energy efficiency.

title: Socio-Economic Model of AI Agents
summary:
Modern socio-economic systems are undergoing deep integration with artificial
intelligence technologies. This paper constructs a heterogeneous agent-based
modeling framework that incorporates both human workers and autonomous AI
agents, to study the impact of AI collaboration under resource constraints on
aggregate social output. We build five progressively extended models: Model 1
serves as the baseline of pure human collaboration; Model 2 introduces AI as
collaborators; Model 3 incorporates network effects among agents; Model 4
treats agents as independent producers; and Model 5 integrates both network
effects and independent agent production. Through theoretical derivation and
simulation analysis, we find that the introduction of AI agents can
significantly increase aggregate social output. When considering network
effects among agents, this increase exhibits nonlinear growth far exceeding the
simple sum of individual contributions. Under the same resource inputs,
treating agents as independent producers provides higher long-term growth
potential; introducing network effects further demonstrates strong
characteristics of increasing returns to scale.

AI.tldr: AI-human collaboration in a heterogeneous agent-based model increases aggregate output, with network effects yielding nonlinear gains and increasing returns; independent producers show stronger long-term growth potential.
AI.motivation: To understand how AI integration with human labor affects macro-scale productivity and growth under resource constraints, particularly when agent interactions and production modes vary.
AI.method: Develop five progressively extended agent-based models: (1) baseline human collaboration; (2) add AI collaborators; (3) include network effects among agents; (4) model agents as independent producers; (5) combine network effects with independent production. Use theoretical derivations and simulation analyses to compare outcomes.
AI.result: AI agents boost aggregate social output; network effects lead to nonlinear, super-additive increases beyond the sum of individual contributions; under equal resources, independent-producer modeling yields higher long-term growth, and network effects further amplify growth, showing increasing returns to scale.
AI.conclusion: Integrating AI with human agents can substantially raise productivity, with network structures and producer autonomy enhancing returns. Policy or design implications include leveraging AI collaboration and network effects to maximize growth, while considering resource constraints.

title: MoE-PHDS: One MoE checkpoint for flexible runtime sparsity
summary:
Sparse Mixtures of Experts (MoEs) are typically trained to operate at a fixed
sparsity level, e.g. $k$ in a top-$k$ gating function. This global sparsity
level determines an operating point on the accuracy/latency curve; currently,
meeting multiple efficiency targets means training and maintaining multiple
models. This practice complicates serving, increases training and maintenance
costs, and limits flexibility in meeting diverse latency, efficiency, and
energy requirements. We show that pretrained MoEs are more robust to runtime
sparsity shifts than commonly assumed, and introduce MoE-PHDS ({\bf P}ost {\bf
H}oc {\bf D}eclared {\bf S}parsity), a lightweight SFT method that turns a
single checkpoint into a global sparsity control surface. PHDS mixes training
across sparsity levels and anchors with a short curriculum at high sparsity,
requiring no architectural changes. The result is predictable accuracy/latency
tradeoffs from one model: practitioners can ``dial $k$'' at inference time
without swapping checkpoints, changing architecture, or relying on token-level
heuristics. Experiments on OLMoE-1B-7B-0125, Qwen1.5-MoE-A2.7B, and proprietary
models fit on multiple operating points show that PHDS matches or exceeds
well-specified oracle models, improves cross-sparsity agreement by up to 22\%
vs. well-specified oracle models, and enables simplified, flexible runtime MoE
deployment by making global sparsity a first-class serving primitive.

AI.tldr: A single pretrained MoE model can offer flexible, global sparsity control at inference through Post Hoc Declared Sparsity (PHDS), removing the need for multiple models or architectural changes.
AI.motivation: To address the inefficiency and maintenance burden of training and deploying multiple models for different sparsity/latency targets in sparse Mixtures of Experts (MoEs).
AI.method: Introduce PHDS, a lightweight post-training sparsity-declaration technique that converts one checkpoint into a global sparsity control surface. It trains across multiple sparsity levels with a short curriculum at high sparsity and requires no architectural changes.
AI.result: PHDS enables predictable accuracy/latency tradeoffs from a single model, matches or exceeds oracle models, and improves cross-sparsity agreement (up to 22%); it simplifies runtime MoE deployment by making global sparsity a primary serving primitive.
AI.conclusion: Global sparsity can be managed as a first-class serving primitive using post hoc sparsity declaration, enabling flexible, dialable inference without re-training or architectural changes.

title: Soft-Di[M]O: Improving One-Step Discrete Image Generation with Soft Embeddings
summary:
One-step generators distilled from Masked Diffusion Models (MDMs) compress
multiple sampling steps into a single forward pass, enabling efficient text and
image synthesis. However, they suffer two key limitations: they inherit
modeling bias from the teacher, and their discrete token outputs block gradient
flow, preventing post-distillation refinements such as adversarial training,
reward-based fine-tuning, and Test-Time Embedding Optimization (TTEO). In this
work, we introduce soft embeddings, a simple relaxation that replaces discrete
tokens with the expected embeddings under the generator's output distribution.
Soft embeddings preserve representation fidelity for one-step discrete
generator while providing a fully differentiable continuous surrogate that is
compatible with teacher backbones and tokenizer decoders. Integrating soft
embeddings into the Di[M]O distillation framework (denoted Soft-Di[M]O) makes
one-step generators end-to-end trainable and enables straightforward
application of GAN-based refinement, differentiable reward fine-tuning, and
TTEO. Empirically, across multiple MDM teachers (e.g., MaskBit, MaskGen),
Soft-Di[M]O achieves state-of-the-art one-step results: improved class-to-image
performance, a one-step FID of 1.56 on ImageNet-256 with GAN-based refinement,
along with higher GenEval and HPS scores on text-to-image with reward
fine-tuning, and further gains from TTEO.

AI.tldr: Soft embeddings enable differentiable, end-to-end distillation of one-step generators by replacing discrete tokens with their expected embeddings under the generator's distribution, overcoming gradient-blocking and teacher bias.
AI.motivation: To address modeling bias and non-differentiability in one-step diffusion-based distillation (Di[M]O) and to unlock post-distillation refinements such as adversarial training, reward-based fine-tuning, and Test-Time Embedding Optimization (TTEO).
AI.method: Introduce soft embeddings as a differentiable relaxation: compute the expected embeddings given the generator's output distribution and use them in place of discrete tokens. Integrate this into the Di[M]O framework to form Soft-Di[M]O, ensuring compatibility with teacher backbones and tokenizer decoders so end-to-end training and downstream refinements are possible.
AI.result: Soft-Di[M]O achieves state-of-the-art one-step results across multiple MDM teachers (e.g., MaskBit, MaskGen), including improved class-to-image performance, a one-step FID of 1.56 on ImageNet-256 with GAN-based refinement, and higher GenEval and HPS scores on text-to-image with reward fine-tuning; additional gains from Test-Time Embedding Optimization (TTEO).
AI.conclusion: Soft embeddings preserve token representations while providing a differentiable surrogate, enabling end-to-end training of one-step generators and facilitating GAN-based refinement, reward fine-tuning, and TTEO, leading to superior one-step performance.

title: Leave No Observation Behind: Real-time Correction for VLA Action Chunks
summary:
To improve efficiency and temporal coherence, Vision-Language-Action (VLA)
models often predict action chunks; however, this action chunking harms
reactivity under inference delay and long horizons. We introduce Asynchronous
Action Chunk Correction (A2C2), which is a lightweight real-time chunk
correction head that runs every control step and adds a time-aware correction
to any off-the-shelf VLA's action chunk. The module combines the latest
observation, the predicted action from VLA (base action), a positional feature
that encodes the index of the base action within the chunk, and some features
from the base policy, then outputs a per-step correction. This preserves the
base model's competence while restoring closed-loop responsiveness. The
approach requires no retraining of the base policy and is orthogonal to
asynchronous execution schemes such as Real Time Chunking (RTC). On the dynamic
Kinetix task suite (12 tasks) and LIBERO Spatial, our method yields consistent
success rate improvements across increasing delays and execution horizons (+23%
point and +7% point respectively, compared to RTC), and also improves
robustness for long horizons even with zero injected delay. Since the
correction head is small and fast, there is minimal overhead compared to the
inference of large VLA models. These results indicate that A2C2 is an
effective, plug-in mechanism for deploying high-capacity chunking policies in
real-time control.

AI.tldr: A real-time, lightweight A2C2 correction head improves reactivity of VLA action chunking without retraining, outperforming RTC on dynamic tasks.
AI.motivation: Action chunking in Vision-Language-Action models trades off reactivity for efficiency; a post-hoc, real-time correction is needed to maintain closed-loop responsiveness across inference delays and long horizons.
AI.method: Introduce A2C2: a per-step correction head that runs at every control step, using the latest observation, the base action from the VLA, a positional feature encoding the base action's index within the chunk, and features from the base policy to output a per-step correction. It requires no retraining and is orthogonal to asynchronous schemes like Real Time Chunking (RTC).
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on the dynamic Kinetix task suite (12 tasks) and LIBERO Spatial shows consistent success-rate improvements over RTC across increasing delays and horizons: +23 percentage points on Kinetix and +7 points on LIBERO. A2C2 also improves robustness for long horizons even with zero injected delay, with minimal overhead compared to full VLA inference.
AI.conclusion: A2C2 provides an effective, plug-in mechanism to deploy high-capacity chunking policies in real-time control without retraining.

title: Toward Effective Tool-Integrated Reasoning via Self-Evolved Preference Learning
summary:
Tool-Integrated Reasoning (TIR) enables large language models (LLMs) to
improve their internal reasoning ability by integrating external tools.
However, models employing TIR often display suboptimal behaviors, such as
insufficient or excessive tool usage and overthinking after tool calls. The
challenge of incentivizing LLMs to perform TIR efficiently and accurately,
while stabilizing the reasoning process, remains an open question. In this
paper, we start by exploring the impact of tool calls on model reasoning from
the perspective of information entropy. Our findings indicate that tool call
results lead to a distinct change in the information entropy of subsequent
reasoning, with the overall entropy of the reasoning chain varying based on the
number of tool calls. Building on these insights, we propose Tool-Light, a
framework designed to encourage LLMs to perform TIR efficiently and accurately.
Our framework includes dataset construction and multi-stage fine-tuning. For
dataset construction, we employ continuous self-evolved sampling using the
fine-tuned model, integrating both vanilla sampling and entropy-guided
sampling. Besides, we establish strict criteria for selecting positive-negative
pairs during sampling. The training process involves a two-stage approach,
comprising Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Self-Evolved Direct Preference
Optimization (DPO). Experimental results on 10 datasets demonstrate the
effectiveness of Tool-Light, significantly improving the model's efficiency in
executing TIR tasks.

AI.tldr: Tool-Light improves efficiency and accuracy of tool-integrated reasoning (TIR) in LLMs by entropy-aware data collection and a two-stage fine-tuning pipeline, guided by information-entropy changes from tool usage.
AI.motivation: To address suboptimal tool usage, excessive or insufficient tool calls, and unstable reasoning in TIR, by understanding how tool calls affect reasoning entropy and by training models to use tools more efficiently.
AI.method: First analyze how tool calls affect information entropy in the reasoning chain. Then develop Tool-Light with dataset construction via continuous self-evolved sampling that blends vanilla and entropy-guided sampling and enforces strict positive/negative pair criteria. Train in two stages: Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Self-Evolved Direct Preference Optimization (DPO). Evaluate on 10 datasets to assess efficiency and accuracy of TIR.
AI.result: Tool-Light demonstrated significant improvements in the efficiency of performing TIR tasks across 10 datasets, indicating more efficient and potentially more accurate use of tools during reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Entropy-aware, self-evolved sampling combined with a two-stage training regimen can stabilize and enhance tool-integrated reasoning in LLMs, reducing unnecessary tool usage while maintaining or improving performance.

title: On the Sheafification of Higher-Order Message Passing
summary:
Recent work in Topological Deep Learning (TDL) seeks to generalize graph
learning's preeminent $message \ passing$ paradigm to more complex relational
structures: simplicial complexes, cell complexes, hypergraphs, and combinations
thereof. Many approaches to such ${higher\text{-}order \ message \ passing}$
(HOMP) admit formulation in terms of nonlinear diffusion with the Hodge
(combinatorial) Laplacian, a graded operator which carries an inductive bias
that dimension-$k$ data features correlate with dimension-$k$ topological
features encoded in the (singular) cohomology of the underlying domain. For
$k=0$ this recovers the graph Laplacian and its well-studied homophily bias. In
higher gradings, however, the Hodge Laplacian's bias is more opaque and
potentially even degenerate. In this essay, we position sheaf theory as a
natural and principled formalism for modifying the Hodge Laplacian's
diffusion-mediated interface between local and global descriptors toward more
expressive message passing. The sheaf Laplacian's inductive bias correlates
dimension-$k$ data features with dimension-$k$ $sheaf$ cohomology, a data-aware
generalization of singular cohomology. We will contextualize and novelly extend
prior theory on sheaf diffusion in graph learning ($k=0$) in such a light --
and explore how it fails to generalize to $k>0$ -- before developing novel
theory and practice for the higher-order setting. Our exposition is accompanied
by a self-contained introduction shepherding sheaves from the abstract to the
applied.

AI.tldr: Sheaf-theoretic diffusion provides a principled, data-aware generalization of higher-order message passing beyond Hodge-Laplacian biases, linking k-dimensional features to sheaf cohomology and outlining a theory-practice framework for higher-order TD learning.
AI.motivation: Generalize graph-based message passing to higher-order relational structures (simplicial/cell complexes, hypergraphs) and address the opaque/degenerate inductive biases of the Hodge Laplacian in higher dimensions; introduce a data-aware cohomological prior via sheaves.
AI.method: Propose the sheaf Laplacian as the diffusion operator for higher-order TD learning, relate diffusion to dimension-k sheaf cohomology, critically assess prior k=0 theory and its failure to generalize to k>0, and develop new theory and practical guidelines for higher-order diffusion; provide a self-contained introduction from abstract to applied.
AI.result: Outlines a novel theoretical/practical framework for higher-order TD learning based on sheaf diffusion, clarifying limitations of naive generalizations of Hodge Laplacian and proposing a data-aware, cohomology-informed approach for k>0.
AI.conclusion: Sheaf theory offers a natural, principled framework to generalize HOMP to higher orders, with a self-contained introduction and planned development of theory and practice to address k>0 challenges.

title: FishAI 2.0: Marine Fish Image Classification with Multi-modal Few-shot Learning
summary:
Traditional marine biological image recognition faces challenges of
incomplete datasets and unsatisfactory model accuracy, particularly for
few-shot conditions of rare species where data scarcity significantly hampers
the performance. To address these issues, this study proposes an intelligent
marine fish recognition framework, FishAI 2.0, integrating multimodal few-shot
deep learning techniques with image generation for data augmentation. First, a
hierarchical marine fish benchmark dataset, which provides a comprehensive data
foundation for subsequent model training, is utilized to train the FishAI 2.0
model. To address the data scarcity of rare classes, the large language model
DeepSeek was employed to generate high-quality textual descriptions, which are
input into Stable Diffusion 2 for image augmentation through a hierarchical
diffusion strategy that extracts latent encoding to construct a multimodal
feature space. The enhanced visual-textual datasets were then fed into a
Contrastive Language-Image Pre-Training (CLIP) based model, enabling robust
few-shot image recognition. Experimental results demonstrate that FishAI 2.0
achieves a Top-1 accuracy of 91.67 percent and Top-5 accuracy of 97.97 percent
at the family level, outperforming baseline CLIP and ViT models with a
substantial margin for the minority classes with fewer than 10 training
samples. To better apply FishAI 2.0 to real-world scenarios, at the genus and
species level, FishAI 2.0 respectively achieves a Top-1 accuracy of 87.58
percent and 85.42 percent, demonstrating practical utility. In summary, FishAI
2.0 improves the efficiency and accuracy of marine fish identification and
provides a scalable technical solution for marine ecological monitoring and
conservation, highlighting its scientific value and practical applicability.

AI.tldr: FishAI 2.0 uses multimodal few-shot learning with LLM-generated text and diffusion-based image augmentation to boost marine fish recognition across taxonomic levels, achieving strong hierarchical performance.
AI.motivation: Overcome incomplete datasets and low accuracy in few-shot scenarios for rare marine fish species, enabling scalable ecological monitoring and conservation.
AI.method: Train on a hierarchical marine fish benchmark; generate high-quality textual descriptions with DeepSeek, augment images via Stable Diffusion 2 using a hierarchical diffusion strategy to obtain latent encodings for a multimodal feature space; employ a CLIP-based model for few-shot recognition.
AI.result: Top-1 accuracy 91.67% and Top-5 97.97% at the family level, outperforming baseline CLIP and ViT, with notable gains for minority classes (<10 training samples). At genus/species levels, Top-1 accuracies are 87.58% and 85.42%, respectively.
AI.conclusion: FishAI 2.0 enhances efficiency and accuracy of marine fish identification and offers a scalable solution for ecological monitoring and conservation.

title: Online Dynamic Goal Recognition in Gym Environments
summary:
Goal Recognition (GR) is the task of inferring an agent's intended goal from
partial observations of its behavior, typically in an online and one-shot
setting. Despite recent advances in model-free GR, particularly in applications
such as human-robot interaction, surveillance, and assistive systems, the field
remains fragmented due to inconsistencies in benchmarks, domains, and
evaluation protocols.
  To address this, we introduce gr-libs
(https://github.com/MatanShamir1/gr_libs) and gr-envs
(https://github.com/MatanShamir1/gr_envs), two complementary open-source
frameworks that support the development, evaluation, and comparison of GR
algorithms in Gym-compatible environments. gr-libs includes modular
implementations of MDP-based GR baselines, diagnostic tools, and evaluation
utilities. gr-envs provides a curated suite of environments adapted for dynamic
and goal-directed behavior, along with wrappers that ensure compatibility with
standard reinforcement learning toolkits. Together, these libraries offer a
standardized, extensible, and reproducible platform for advancing GR research.
Both packages are open-source and available on GitHub and PyPI.

AI.tldr: Introduces gr-libs and gr-envs, open-source frameworks to standardize and facilitate Goal Recognition (GR) research in Gym-compatible environments, enabling modular baselines, diagnostics, evaluation utilities, and curated dynamic/goal-directed environments.
AI.motivation: GR research is fragmented due to inconsistent benchmarks, domains, and evaluation protocols; there is a need for standardized, reproducible platforms to enable fair cross-method comparisons.
AI.method: Development of two complementary packages: gr-libs, which provides modular MDP-based GR baselines, diagnostic tools, and evaluation utilities; and gr-envs, which offers a curated suite of dynamic and goal-directed environments with wrappers for compatibility with standard RL toolkits; both are designed to integrate with Gym-compatible workflows and are open-source on GitHub and PyPI.
AI.result: A standardized, extensible, and reproducible platform for GR research, comprising ready-to-use libraries and environments that facilitate fair evaluation and comparison and support reproducible experiments.
AI.conclusion: Together, gr-libs and gr-envs provide a standardized, extensible platform to advance GR research in online, one-shot settings, promoting reproducibility and comparability across studies.

title: Learning How to Use Tools, Not Just When: Pattern-Aware Tool-Integrated Reasoning
summary:
Tool-integrated reasoning (TIR) has become a key approach for improving large
reasoning models (LRMs) on complex problems. Prior work has mainly studied when
to invoke tools, while overlooking how tools are applied. We identify two
common patterns: a calculator pattern that uses code for direct computation,
and an algorithmic pattern that encodes problems as programs. Misaligned
choices often cause failures even when reasoning is sound. We propose a
two-stage framework that first builds code competence from both patterns and
then aligns pattern selection with teacher preferences. Across challenging math
datasets, our pattern-aware method substantially improves both code usage and
accuracy, for instance raising Code@1 on MATH500 from 64.0% to 70.5% and on
AIME24 from 26.7% to 50.0%. These gains highlight the effectiveness of a
pattern-aware approach for tool-integrated reasoning.

AI.tldr: Two-stage pattern-aware framework for tool-integrated reasoning that addresses misaligned tool usage by focusing on calculator and algorithmic patterns; shows significant Code@1 gains on math datasets.
AI.motivation: Prior work on tool-integrated reasoning mostly examines when to invoke tools, while overlooking how tools are applied; misaligned tool usage can waste reasoning efforts and cause failures.
AI.method: Proposes a two-stage framework: (1) build code competence from two common tool-use patterns (calculator and algorithmic patterns); (2) align pattern selection with teacher preferences to improve tool usage and reasoning accuracy.
AI.result: Across challenging math datasets, pattern-aware method improves code usage and accuracy, e.g., Code@1 on MATH500 from 64.0% to 70.5% and on AIME24 from 26.7% to 50.0%.
AI.conclusion: A pattern-aware approach effectively enhances tool-integrated reasoning by ensuring tool-use patterns align with task demands and teacher preferences.

title: Tracing the Representation Geometry of Language Models from Pretraining to Post-training
summary:
Standard training metrics like loss fail to explain the emergence of complex
capabilities in large language models. We take a spectral approach to
investigate the geometry of learned representations across pretraining and
post-training, measuring effective rank (RankMe) and eigenspectrum decay
($\alpha$-ReQ). With OLMo (1B-7B) and Pythia (160M-12B) models, we uncover a
consistent non-monotonic sequence of three geometric phases during
autoregressive pretraining. The initial "warmup" phase exhibits rapid
representational collapse. This is followed by an "entropy-seeking" phase,
where the manifold's dimensionality expands substantially, coinciding with peak
n-gram memorization. Subsequently, a "compression-seeking" phase imposes
anisotropic consolidation, selectively preserving variance along dominant
eigendirections while contracting others, a transition marked with significant
improvement in downstream task performance. We show these phases can emerge
from a fundamental interplay of cross-entropy optimization under skewed token
frequencies and representational bottlenecks ($d \ll |V|$). Post-training
further transforms geometry: SFT and DPO drive "entropy-seeking" dynamics to
integrate specific instructional or preferential data, improving
in-distribution performance while degrading out-of-distribution robustness.
Conversely, RLVR induces "compression-seeking", enhancing reward alignment but
reducing generation diversity.

AI.tldr: Spectral geometry reveals three autoregressive pretraining phases (warmup, entropy-seeking, compression-seeking) in LLM representations, with post-training methods reshaping geometry to improve in-distribution performance but affecting robustness or diversity.
AI.motivation: Standard training loss does not explain emergent capabilities of large language models. A spectral, geometry-based view (RankMe and alpha-ReQ) can reveal how representations evolve during pretraining and after fine-tuning or RL-based alignment.
AI.method: Compute RankMe and alpha-ReQ on OLMo (1B–7B) and Pythia (160M–12B) across autoregressive pretraining to identify geometric phases. Analyze post-training updates (SFT, DPO, RLVR) to see how they shift the eigenspectrum and effective dimensionality.
AI.result: Identified a consistent non-monotonic sequence of three geometric phases during pretraining: warmup with rapid representational collapse, entropy-seeking with expanded manifold and peak memorization, and compression-seeking with anisotropic consolidation and downstream gains. Post-training, SFT/DPO push entropy-seeking to integrate instruction/data, boosting in-distribution performance but reducing out-of-distribution robustness; RLVR promotes compression-seeking, improving reward alignment but reducing generation diversity.
AI.conclusion: Geometric phases arise from the interaction of cross-entropy optimization under skewed token frequencies and representational bottlenecks (d ≪ |V|). Spectral metrics capture these dynamics and explain how post-training objectives re-shape representations, enabling task alignment at the cost of robustness or diversity.

title: Brain Tumor Classification from MRI Scans via Transfer Learning and Enhanced Feature Representation
summary:
Brain tumors are abnormal cell growths in the central nervous system (CNS),
and their timely detection is critical for improving patient outcomes. This
paper proposes an automatic and efficient deep-learning framework for brain
tumor detection from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. The framework
employs a pre-trained ResNet50 model for feature extraction, followed by Global
Average Pooling (GAP) and linear projection to obtain compact, high-level image
representations. These features are then processed by a novel Dense-Dropout
sequence, a core contribution of this work, which enhances non-linear feature
learning, reduces overfitting, and improves robustness through diverse feature
transformations. Another major contribution is the creation of the Mymensingh
Medical College Brain Tumor (MMCBT) dataset, designed to address the lack of
reliable brain tumor MRI resources. The dataset comprises MRI scans from 209
subjects (ages 9 to 65), including 3671 tumor and 13273 non-tumor images, all
clinically verified under expert supervision. To overcome class imbalance, the
tumor class was augmented, resulting in a balanced dataset well-suited for deep
learning research.

AI.tldr: A ResNet50-based feature extractor with Global Average Pooling and a novel Dense-Dropout module for brain tumor MRI detection, paired with the MMCBT dataset (balanced via augmentation) to improve learning, generalization, and robustness.
AI.motivation: Brain tumor detection in MRI is time-critical and current resources are scarce; class imbalance and overfitting hinder deep learning models. A reliable, efficient pipeline and a larger, balanced dataset are needed.
AI.method: Use pretrained ResNet50 for feature extraction, followed by Global Average Pooling and a linear projection to compact features. Apply a novel Dense-Dropout sequence to enhance non-linear feature learning, reduce overfitting, and boost robustness. Introduce the MMCBT dataset (209 subjects, ages 9–65) with 3671 tumor and 13273 non-tumor images; balance achieved by augmenting the tumor class.
AI.result: Dense-Dropout is reported to enhance non-linear feature learning, reduce overfitting, and improve robustness. The MMCBT dataset is balanced and clinically verified, making it suitable for deep learning research.
AI.conclusion: The framework, together with the MMCBT dataset, addresses data scarcity and class imbalance in brain-tumor MRI detection, with Dense-Dropout as a promising component for robust medical image learning.

title: Preventing Robotic Jailbreaking via Multimodal Domain Adaptation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) and Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are
increasingly deployed in robotic environments but remain vulnerable to
jailbreaking attacks that bypass safety mechanisms and drive unsafe or
physically harmful behaviors in the real world. Data-driven defenses such as
jailbreak classifiers show promise, yet they struggle to generalize in domains
where specialized datasets are scarce, limiting their effectiveness in robotics
and other safety-critical contexts. To address this gap, we introduce J-DAPT, a
lightweight framework for multimodal jailbreak detection through
attention-based fusion and domain adaptation. J-DAPT integrates textual and
visual embeddings to capture both semantic intent and environmental grounding,
while aligning general-purpose jailbreak datasets with domain-specific
reference data. Evaluations across autonomous driving, maritime robotics, and
quadruped navigation show that J-DAPT boosts detection accuracy to nearly 100%
with minimal overhead. These results demonstrate that J-DAPT provides a
practical defense for securing VLMs in robotic applications. Additional
materials are made available at: https://j-dapt.github.io.

AI.tldr: A multimodal jailbreak detector for robotics (J-DAPT) that fuses textual and visual embeddings and uses domain adaptation to generalize jailbreak detection to robotics with high accuracy and low overhead.
AI.motivation: Safety vulnerabilities in LLMs/VLMs in robotic settings; existing jailbreak detectors lack generalization in domains with scarce domain-specific data, hindering safe deployment.
AI.method: Attention-based fusion of text and image embeddings; domain adaptation aligning general jailbreak datasets with robotics-domain reference data.
AI.result: Significant improvement in jailbreak detection across autonomous driving, maritime robotics, and quadruped navigation; accuracy approaching 100% with minimal overhead.
AI.conclusion: J-DAPT offers a practical defense for securing VLMs in robotics and demonstrates effective multimodal, domain-adaptive jailbreak detection; materials available online.

title: Your Models Have Thought Enough: Training Large Reasoning Models to Stop Overthinking
summary:
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) have achieved impressive performance on
challenging tasks, yet their deep reasoning often incurs substantial
computational costs. To achieve efficient reasoning, existing reinforcement
learning methods still struggle to construct short reasoning path during the
rollout stage, limiting effective learning. Inspired by Evidence Accumulation
Models, we find that LRMs have accumulated sufficient information early in
reasoning, making further reasoning steps redundant. Based on this insight, we
propose Just-Enough Thinking (JET), which trains models to proactively
terminate unnecessary reasoning. JET performs trajectory truncation during
rollout to expose the model to short, distributionally consistent reasoning
paths. Besides, it uses a quality-controlled length reward to better encourage
concise reasoning while maintaining correctness. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that JET significantly improves reasoning efficiency without
sacrificing accuracy. Especially, DeepSeek-Distill-Qwen-1.5B achieves a 4.6%
accuracy gain while reducing output length by 46.3% on the Olympiad benchmark.
Our code is available in the GitHub.

AI.tldr: Just-Enough Thinking (JET) trains large reasoning models to terminate unnecessary reasoning early by truncating reasoning trajectories during rollout and using a quality-controlled length reward, achieving shorter and distributionally consistent reasoning paths without sacrificing accuracy; on Olympiad tasks, DeepSeek-Distill-Qwen-1.5B shows a 4.6% accuracy gain with 46.3% shorter outputs.
AI.motivation: Large Reasoning Models incur high computational costs due to deep reasoning. Existing reinforcement learning approaches struggle to learn short, efficient reasoning paths. Inspired by evidence accumulation models, there is a potential to terminate reasoning once sufficient information has been gathered.
AI.method: Introduce Just-Enough Thinking (JET): during rollout, perform trajectory truncation to produce short, distributionally consistent reasoning paths; train with a quality-controlled length reward to encourage concise yet correct reasoning.
AI.result: JET substantially improves reasoning efficiency without reducing accuracy. In experiments, DeepSeek-Distill-Qwen-1.5B achieves a 4.6% accuracy gain and a 46.3% reduction in output length on the Olympiad benchmark.
AI.conclusion: JET offers an effective approach to reducing computation in large reasoning models by enabling proactive early termination of reasoning while preserving performance; code is available on GitHub.

title: Understanding Catastrophic Interference On the Identifibility of Latent Representations
summary:
Catastrophic interference, also known as catastrophic forgetting, is a
fundamental challenge in machine learning, where a trained learning model
progressively loses performance on previously learned tasks when adapting to
new ones. In this paper, we aim to better understand and model the catastrophic
interference problem from a latent representation learning point of view, and
propose a novel theoretical framework that formulates catastrophic interference
as an identification problem. Our analysis demonstrates that the forgetting
phenomenon can be quantified by the distance between partial-task aware (PTA)
and all-task aware (ATA) setups. Building upon recent advances in
identifiability theory, we prove that this distance can be minimized through
identification of shared latent variables between these setups. When learning,
we propose our method \ourmeos with two-stage training strategy: First, we
employ maximum likelihood estimation to learn the latent representations from
both PTA and ATA configurations. Subsequently, we optimize the KL divergence to
identify and learn the shared latent variables. Through theoretical guarantee
and empirical validations, we establish that identifying and learning these
shared representations can effectively mitigate catastrophic interference in
machine learning systems. Our approach provides both theoretical guarantees and
practical performance improvements across both synthetic and benchmark
datasets.

AI.tldr: A latent-variable identifiability framework to mitigate catastrophic interference by identifying shared latent representations between partial-task aware and all-task aware setups.
AI.motivation: To understand catastrophic forgetting from a latent representation perspective and quantify forgetting as a distance between PTA and ATA, enabling mitigation via identifiability theory.
AI.method: Two-stage training: (1) maximum likelihood estimation to learn latent representations from PTA and ATA; (2) minimize KL divergence to identify and learn shared latent variables; theoretical guarantees derived.
AI.result: Shows that identifying and learning shared latent representations reduces interference; provides theoretical guarantees and empirical improvements on synthetic and benchmark data.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers principled guarantees and practical gains in mitigating catastrophic interference by aligning latent representations across task configurations.

title: Hemorica: A Comprehensive CT Scan Dataset for Automated Brain Hemorrhage Classification, Segmentation, and Detection
summary:
Timely diagnosis of Intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) on Computed Tomography (CT)
scans remains a clinical priority, yet the development of robust Artificial
Intelligence (AI) solutions is still hindered by fragmented public data. To
close this gap, we introduce Hemorica, a publicly available collection of 372
head CT examinations acquired between 2012 and 2024. Each scan has been
exhaustively annotated for five ICH subtypes-epidural (EPH), subdural (SDH),
subarachnoid (SAH), intraparenchymal (IPH), and intraventricular (IVH)-yielding
patient-wise and slice-wise classification labels, subtype-specific bounding
boxes, two-dimensional pixel masks and three-dimensional voxel masks. A
double-reading workflow, preceded by a pilot consensus phase and supported by
neurosurgeon adjudication, maintained low inter-rater variability.
Comprehensive statistical analysis confirms the clinical realism of the
dataset. To establish reference baselines, standard convolutional and
transformer architectures were fine-tuned for binary slice classification and
hemorrhage segmentation. With only minimal fine-tuning, lightweight models such
as MobileViT-XS achieved an F1 score of 87.8% in binary classification, whereas
a U-Net with a DenseNet161 encoder reached a Dice score of 85.5% for binary
lesion segmentation that validate both the quality of the annotations and the
sufficiency of the sample size. Hemorica therefore offers a unified,
fine-grained benchmark that supports multi-task and curriculum learning,
facilitates transfer to larger but weakly labelled cohorts, and facilitates the
process of designing an AI-based assistant for ICH detection and quantification
systems.

AI.tldr: Hemorica is a public, richly annotated head CT dataset (372 scans, 2012–2024) for intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) with five subtypes, enabling multi-task learning and robust baselines; demonstrates strong annotation quality and baseline performance for detection and segmentation.
AI.motivation: To overcome fragmented public datasets and enable robust AI for ICH by providing a comprehensive, well-annotated, clinically realistic CT dataset that supports multi-task learning, transfer to larger weakly labelled cohorts, and AI-assisted ICH detection/quantification.
AI.method: Assembled 372 head CT exams covering 2012–2024; exhaustively annotated for five ICH subtypes (EPH, SDH, SAH, IPH, IVH) with patient-wise and slice-wise labels, subtype-specific bounding boxes, 2D masks, and 3D voxel masks. Double-reading workflow with pilot consensus and neurosurgeon adjudication to ensure low inter-rater variability. Established baselines using standard CNNs/transformers on binary slice classification and hemorrhage segmentation; fine-tuned lightweight models (e.g., MobileViT-XS) and a U-Net with DenseNet161 encoder for segmentation.
AI.result: Baseline results show MobileViT-XS achieving an F1 score of 87.8% on binary slice classification after minimal fine-tuning; U‑Net with DenseNet161 encoder attaining a Dice score of 85.5% for binary lesion segmentation. The dataset annotations and evaluation demonstrate realism and adequate sample size for robust benchmarking and multi-task learning.
AI.conclusion: Hemorica offers a unified, fine-grained benchmark enabling multi-task learning and transfer to larger weakly labeled cohorts, and supports the development of AI-based assistants for ICH detection and quantification, backed by validated annotation quality.

title: A Novel Narrow Region Detector for Sampling-Based Planners' Efficiency: Match Based Passage Identifier
summary:
Autonomous technology, which has become widespread today, appears in many
different configurations such as mobile robots, manipulators, and drones. One
of the most important tasks of these vehicles during autonomous operations is
path planning. In the literature, path planners are generally divided into two
categories: probabilistic and deterministic methods. In the analysis of
probabilistic methods, the common problem of almost all methods is observed in
narrow passage environments. In this paper, a novel sampler is proposed that
deterministically identifies narrow passage environments using occupancy grid
maps and accordingly increases the amount of sampling in these regions. The
codes of the algorithm is provided as open source. To evaluate the performance
of the algorithm, benchmark studies are conducted in three distinct categories:
specific and random simulation environments, and a real-world environment. As a
result, it is observed that our algorithm provides higher performance in
planning time and number of milestones compared to the baseline samplers.

AI.tldr: A novel deterministic sampler improves sampling in narrow passages for path planning, using occupancy grids to bias sampling and achieve faster planning with more milestones.
AI.motivation: Probabilistic path planners struggle in narrow passage environments, leading to inefficiencies in planning time and convergence. A targeted sampling strategy aims to address this gap.
AI.method: Introduce a new sampler that deterministically identifies narrow passages via occupancy grid maps and biases sampling toward those regions; provide open-source implementation; evaluate in specific, random, and real-world scenarios.
AI.result: Compared to baseline samplers, the proposed method yields faster planning times and a higher number of milestones, indicating improved sampling efficiency in challenging environments.
AI.conclusion: The deterministic narrow-passage aware sampler enhances path-planning performance across simulated and real-world settings and is released as open-source for wider use.

title: From Conversation to Query Execution: Benchmarking User and Tool Interactions for EHR Database Agents
summary:
Despite the impressive performance of LLM-powered agents, their adoption for
Electronic Health Record (EHR) data access remains limited by the absence of
benchmarks that adequately capture real-world clinical data access flows. In
practice, two core challenges hinder deployment: query ambiguity from vague
user questions and value mismatch between user terminology and database
entries. To address this, we introduce EHR-ChatQA an interactive database
question answering benchmark that evaluates the end-to-end workflow of database
agents: clarifying user questions, using tools to resolve value mismatches, and
generating correct SQL to deliver accurate answers. To cover diverse patterns
of query ambiguity and value mismatch, EHR-ChatQA assesses agents in a
simulated environment with an LLM-based user across two interaction flows:
Incremental Query Refinement (IncreQA), where users add constraints to existing
queries, and Adaptive Query Refinement (AdaptQA), where users adjust their
search goals mid-conversation. Experiments with state-of-the-art LLMs (e.g.,
o4-mini and Gemini-2.5-Flash) over five i.i.d. trials show that while agents
achieve high Pass@5 of 90-95% (at least one of five trials) on IncreQA and
60-80% on AdaptQA, their Pass^5 (consistent success across all five trials) is
substantially lower by 35-60%. These results underscore the need to build
agents that are not only performant but also robust for the safety-critical EHR
domain. Finally, we provide diagnostic insights into common failure modes to
guide future agent development.

AI.tldr: Introduces EHR-ChatQA, a benchmark for end-to-end database agents in EHR data access, focusing on clarifying ambiguous questions and resolving value mismatches; evaluates two interaction flows (IncreQA and AdaptQA) with LLM-based users; finds high Pass@5 but much lower Pass^5, highlighting robustness and safety needs; offers diagnostic failure-mode insights.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of benchmarks that capture realistic clinical data access workflows for LLM-powered database agents, particularly addressing query ambiguity and terminology-to-database value gaps in EHRs.
AI.method: A simulated, interactive benchmark (EHR-ChatQA) with an LLM-based user across two flows: Incremental Query Refinement (IncreQA) and Adaptive Query Refinement (AdaptQA). Agents must clarify questions, resolve value mismatches with tools, and generate correct SQL. Evaluation spans five i.i.d. trials using state-of-the-art LLMs (e.g., o4-mini, Gemini-2.5-Flash).
AI.result: Agents attain Pass@5 of 90–95% on IncreQA and 60–80% on AdaptQA; Pass^5 is substantially lower by 35–60%, indicating robustness gaps across trials.
AI.conclusion: The work emphasizes that high performance is insufficient for safety-critical EHR deployments; there is a clear need for more robust, interpretable agents, and it provides diagnostic insights into common failure modes to guide future development.

title: DPFNAS: Differential Privacy-Enhanced Federated Neural Architecture Search for 6G Edge Intelligence
summary:
The Sixth-Generation (6G) network envisions pervasive artificial intelligence
(AI) as a core goal, enabled by edge intelligence through on-device data
utilization. To realize this vision, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a
key paradigm for collaborative training across edge devices. However, the
sensitivity and heterogeneity of edge data pose key challenges to FL: parameter
sharing risks data reconstruction, and a unified global model struggles to
adapt to diverse local distributions. In this paper, we propose a novel
federated learning framework that integrates personalized differential privacy
(DP) and adaptive model design. To protect training data, we leverage
sample-level representations for knowledge sharing and apply a personalized DP
strategy to resist reconstruction attacks. To ensure distribution-aware
adaptation under privacy constraints, we develop a privacy-aware neural
architecture search (NAS) algorithm that generates locally customized
architectures and hyperparameters. To the best of our knowledge, this is the
first personalized DP solution tailored for representation-based FL with
theoretical convergence guarantees. Our scheme achieves strong privacy
guarantees for training data while significantly outperforming state-of-the-art
methods in model performance. Experiments on benchmark datasets such as
CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 demonstrate that our scheme improves accuracy by 6.82\%
over the federated NAS method PerFedRLNAS, while reducing model size to 1/10
and communication cost to 1/20.

AI.tldr: A personalized DP federated learning framework that uses sample-level representations and a privacy-aware NAS to tailor architectures and hyperparameters per client under differential privacy, with convergence guarantees and superior accuracy and efficiency on CIFAR-10/100.
AI.motivation: Edge data in federated learning is sensitive and heterogeneous. A unified global model may underperform due to diverse local distributions, and sharing parameters risks data reconstruction. There's a need for personalized privacy-preserving FL that adapts models to local data while providing strong privacy guarantees.
AI.method: 1) Use sample-level representations for knowledge sharing instead of raw parameter sharing. 2) Apply a personalized differential privacy strategy to resist reconstruction attacks, providing client-specific privacy budgets. 3) Develop a privacy-aware neural architecture search (NAS) that yields locally customized architectures and hyperparameters under privacy constraints, enabling distribution-aware adaptation. 4) Provide theoretical convergence guarantees for the personalized DP FL framework.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 shows a 6.82% accuracy improvement over the Federated NAS method PerFedRLNAS. The proposed approach reduces model size to 1/10 and communication cost to 1/20, while maintaining strong privacy protections and outperforming state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: This work is, to the best of our knowledge, the first personalized DP solution tailored for representation-based FL with theoretical convergence guarantees. It achieves strong privacy for training data while delivering notable performance gains and efficiency improvements over existing FL approaches.

title: ARSS: Taming Decoder-only Autoregressive Visual Generation for View Synthesis From Single View
summary:
Despite their exceptional generative quality, diffusion models have limited
applicability to world modeling tasks, such as novel view generation from
sparse inputs. This limitation arises because diffusion models generate outputs
in a non-causal manner, often leading to distortions or inconsistencies across
views, and making it difficult to incrementally adapt accumulated knowledge to
new queries. In contrast, autoregressive (AR) models operate in a causal
fashion, generating each token based on all previously generated tokens. In
this work, we introduce \textbf{ARSS}, a novel framework that leverages a
GPT-style decoder-only AR model to generate novel views from a single image,
conditioned on a predefined camera trajectory. We employ a video tokenizer to
map continuous image sequences into discrete tokens and propose a camera
encoder that converts camera trajectories into 3D positional guidance. Then to
enhance generation quality while preserving the autoregressive structure, we
propose a autoregressive transformer module that randomly permutes the spatial
order of tokens while maintaining their temporal order. Extensive qualitative
and quantitative experiments on public datasets demonstrate that our method
performs comparably to, or better than, state-of-the-art view synthesis
approaches based on diffusion models. Our code will be released upon paper
acceptance.

AI.tldr: ARSS proposes a causal, autoregressive framework for novel view synthesis from a single image, conditioned on a camera trajectory. It uses a video tokenizer, a camera encoder, and an autoregressive transformer that permutes spatial token order to preserve AR structure. It achieves competitive or superior results to diffusion-based methods, with code to be released.
AI.motivation: Diffusion-based view synthesis struggles with causal consistency across views and incremental knowledge integration, limiting world-modeling tasks. Autoregressive models offer causal generation, suggesting a method better suited for creating consistent sequences (views) from sparse inputs.
AI.method: A GPT-style decoder-only autoregressive model generates novel views conditioned on a predefined camera trajectory. A video tokenizer maps image sequences to discrete tokens. A camera encoder converts camera trajectories into 3D positional guidance. An autoregressive transformer module randomly permutes spatial token order while preserving temporal order to maintain AR causality.
AI.result: Qualitative and quantitative experiments on public datasets show ARSS performs comparably to or better than state-of-the-art diffusion-model-based view synthesis approaches.
AI.conclusion: ARSS provides a causal alternative to diffusion for novel view synthesis from sparse inputs, achieving strong performance while maintaining autoregressive structure; code will be released upon acceptance.

title: Distributed Multi-Robot Multi-Target Simultaneous Search and Tracking in an Unknown Non-convex Environment
summary:
In unknown non-convex environments, such as indoor and underground spaces,
deploying a fleet of robots to explore the surroundings while simultaneously
searching for and tracking targets of interest to maintain high-precision data
collection represents a fundamental challenge that urgently requires resolution
in applications such as environmental monitoring and rescue operations. Current
research has made significant progress in addressing environmental exploration,
information search, and target tracking problems, but has yet to establish a
framework for simultaneously optimizing these tasks in complex environments. In
this paper, we propose a novel motion planning algorithm framework that
integrates three control strategies: a frontier-based exploration strategy, a
guaranteed coverage strategy based on Lloyd's algorithm, and a sensor-based
multi-target tracking strategy. By incorporating these three strategies, the
proposed algorithm balances coverage search and high-precision active tracking
during exploration. Our approach is validated through a series of MATLAB
simulations, demonstrating validity and superiority over standard approaches.

AI.tldr: A unified motion planning framework that combines frontier exploration, Lloyd-based guaranteed coverage, and sensor-driven multi-target tracking, validated by MATLAB simulations showing improved performance over standard methods in unknown, non-convex environments.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of simultaneously exploring unknown non-convex spaces, locating and tracking targets with high-precision data collection, which current work handles only individually; demanding a joint framework for exploration, search, and tracking for applications like environmental monitoring and rescue operations.
AI.method: Integrate three strategies: frontier-based exploration for discovery; Lloyd's algorithm-based guaranteed coverage to ensure complete area visitation; and sensor-based multi-target tracking to maintain high-precision tracking of multiple targets. The framework balances exploration and tracking, likely in a cooperative multi-robot setting, and is validated through MATLAB simulations.
AI.result: Demonstrates validity and superiority over standard approaches in MATLAB simulations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enables simultaneous optimization of exploration, search, and tracking in complex environments, improving data collection and offering a pathway toward real-world deployment and future extensions.

title: Democratizing AI scientists using ToolUniverse
summary:
AI scientists are emerging computational systems that serve as collaborative
partners in discovery. These systems remain difficult to build because they are
bespoke, tied to rigid workflows, and lack shared environments that unify
tools, data, and analyses into a common ecosystem. In omics, unified ecosystems
have transformed research by enabling interoperability, reuse, and
community-driven development; AI scientists require comparable infrastructure.
We present ToolUniverse, an ecosystem for building AI scientists from any
language or reasoning model, whether open or closed. TOOLUNIVERSE standardizes
how AI scientists identify and call tools, integrating more than 600 machine
learning models, datasets, APIs, and scientific packages for data analysis,
knowledge retrieval, and experimental design. It automatically refines tool
interfaces for correct use by AI scientists, creates new tools from natural
language descriptions, iteratively optimizes tool specifications, and composes
tools into agentic workflows. In a case study of hypercholesterolemia,
ToolUniverse was used to create an AI scientist to identify a potent analog of
a drug with favorable predicted properties. The open-source ToolUniverse is
available at https://aiscientist.tools.

AI.tldr: ToolUniverse provides an open ecosystem to build AI scientists by standardizing tool usage and integrating hundreds of tools, enabling automated tool refinement and workflow assembly, demonstrated by a hypercholesterolemia case study.
AI.motivation: AI scientists lack a shared, interoperable infrastructure; the paper draws on the success of omics ecosystems to argue for a unified environment that enables discovery, reproducibility, and reuse.
AI.method: Introduce ToolUniverse that standardizes tool discovery, calling, and interface refinement; supports any language or model; integrates 600+ models/datasets/APIs/packages; auto-refines interfaces; creates tools from NL descriptions; iteratively optimizes tool specs; composes tools into agentic workflows; demonstrates in hypercholesterolemia case study.
AI.result: Constructed an AI scientist within ToolUniverse that identified a potent drug analog with favorable predicted properties; ongoing open-source platform with community contributions.
AI.conclusion: ToolUniverse offers a scalable, interoperable ecosystem for AI scientists, enabling rapid construction and reuse of tools and workflows, aligning with improvements seen in omics ecosystems; released as open-source.

title: GuardNet: Graph-Attention Filtering for Jailbreak Defense in Large Language Models
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly susceptible to jailbreak
attacks, which are adversarial prompts that bypass alignment constraints and
induce unauthorized or harmful behaviors. These vulnerabilities undermine the
safety, reliability, and trustworthiness of LLM outputs, posing critical risks
in domains such as healthcare, finance, and legal compliance. In this paper, we
propose GuardNet, a hierarchical filtering framework that detects and filters
jailbreak prompts prior to inference. GuardNet constructs structured graphs
that combine sequential links, syntactic dependencies, and attention-derived
token relations to capture both linguistic structure and contextual patterns
indicative of jailbreak behavior. It then applies graph neural networks at two
levels: (i) a prompt-level filter that detects global adversarial prompts, and
(ii) a token-level filter that pinpoints fine-grained adversarial spans.
Extensive experiments across three datasets and multiple attack settings show
that GuardNet substantially outperforms prior defenses. It raises prompt-level
F$_1$ scores from 66.4\% to 99.8\% on LLM-Fuzzer, and from 67-79\% to over 94\%
on PLeak datasets. At the token level, GuardNet improves F$_1$ from 48-75\% to
74-91\%, with IoU gains up to +28\%. Despite its structural complexity,
GuardNet maintains acceptable latency and generalizes well in cross-domain
evaluations, making it a practical and robust defense against jailbreak threats
in real-world LLM deployments.

AI.tldr: GuardNet is a hierarchical graph-based defense that detects jailbreak prompts at both prompt and token levels, yielding large F1 gains and IoU improvements while maintaining latency and cross-domain robustness.
AI.motivation: Jailbreak attacks threaten LLM safety; current defenses struggle with both global prompts and fine-grained spans; a structure-aware, two-level approach is needed.
AI.method: Construct graphs fusing sequential links, syntactic dependencies, and attention-derived token relations; apply two-level graph neural networks: a prompt-level filter for global prompts and a token-level filter for adversarial spans.
AI.result: Significant performance gains across three datasets and multiple attacks: prompt-level F1 improved from 66.4% to 99.8% on LLM-Fuzzer and from 67–79% to >94% on PLeak; token-level F1 improved from 48–75% to 74–91%, IoU gains up to 28%; latency acceptable; good cross-domain generalization.
AI.conclusion: GuardNet offers a practical, robust defense against jailbreak threats in real-world LLM deployments by effectively detecting both global jailbreak prompts and fine-grained adversarial spans.

title: Disentangling Static and Dynamic Information for Reducing Static Bias in Action Recognition
comment:
in Proc. of ICCV2025 Workshop and Challenge on Disentangled
  Representation Learning for Controllable Generation (DRL4Real)
summary:
Action recognition models rely excessively on static cues rather than dynamic
human motion, which is known as static bias. This bias leads to poor
performance in real-world applications and zero-shot action recognition. In
this paper, we propose a method to reduce static bias by separating temporal
dynamic information from static scene information. Our approach uses a
statistical independence loss between biased and unbiased streams, combined
with a scene prediction loss. Our experiments demonstrate that this method
effectively reduces static bias and confirm the importance of scene prediction
loss.

AI.tldr: A method to reduce static bias in action recognition by separating temporal dynamics from static scene with an independence loss and a scene prediction loss, shown to be effective.
AI.motivation: Static cues dominate action recognition models, causing poor real-world and zero-shot performance; reducing static bias is necessary for robust recognition.
AI.method: Introduce two streams (unbiased temporal dynamics and biased static scene). Enforce statistical independence between streams with an independence loss and include a scene prediction loss to preserve scene information.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate reduced static bias and confirm the importance of the scene prediction loss.
AI.conclusion: Separating dynamic information from static scene using independence and scene prediction losses effectively mitigates static bias in action recognition; the scene prediction loss is crucial for performance.

title: GUARD: Toward a Compromise between Traditional Control and Learning for Safe Robot Systems
comment: Submitted as workshop paper to IEEE IROS 2025
summary:
This paper presents the framework \textbf{GUARD} (\textbf{G}uided robot
control via \textbf{U}ncertainty attribution and prob\textbf{A}bilistic kernel
optimization for \textbf{R}isk-aware \textbf{D}ecision making) that combines
traditional control with an uncertainty-aware perception technique using active
learning with real-time capability for safe robot collision avoidance. By doing
so, this manuscript addresses the central challenge in robotics of finding a
reasonable compromise between traditional methods and learning algorithms to
foster the development of safe, yet efficient and flexible applications. By
unifying a reactive model predictive countouring control (RMPCC) with an
Iterative Closest Point (ICP) algorithm that enables the attribution of
uncertainty sources online using active learning with real-time capability via
a probabilistic kernel optimization technique, \emph{GUARD} inherently handles
the existing ambiguity of the term \textit{safety} that exists in robotics
literature. Experimental studies indicate the high performance of \emph{GUARD},
thereby highlighting the relevance and need to broaden its applicability in
future.

AI.tldr: GUARD merges traditional control with uncertainty-aware perception using active learning and probabilistic kernels for real-time, risk-aware decision making in robotics. It fuses reactive MPC (RMPCC) with ICP to attribute uncertainty online, enabling safe collision avoidance.
AI.motivation: Bridge traditional model-based control and learning-based perception to achieve safe, efficient, and flexible robotic systems, addressing the ambiguous notion of safety in robotics.
AI.method: Integrates reactive model predictive contouring control (RMPCC) with Iterative Closest Point (ICP) to enable online attribution of uncertainty sources using active learning and probabilistic kernel optimization, delivering real-time risk-aware decisions.
AI.result: Experimental studies indicate high performance of GUARD in safe collision avoidance and real-time capability, supporting broader applicability.
AI.conclusion: GUARD provides a practical framework to balance safety, performance, and adaptability in robotics and invites future work to extend its safety notions and applicability.

title: Beyond Embeddings: Interpretable Feature Extraction for Binary Code Similarity
comment: 17 pages, 7 figures, submitted to USENIX Security '26
summary:
Binary code similarity detection is a core task in reverse engineering. It
supports malware analysis and vulnerability discovery by identifying
semantically similar code in different contexts. Modern methods have progressed
from manually engineered features to vector representations. Hand-crafted
statistics (e.g., operation ratios) are interpretable, but shallow and fail to
generalize. Embedding-based methods overcome this by learning robust
cross-setting representations, but these representations are opaque vectors
that prevent rapid verification. They also face a scalability-accuracy
trade-off, since high-dimensional nearest-neighbor search requires
approximations that reduce precision. Current approaches thus force a
compromise between interpretability, generalizability, and scalability.
  We bridge these gaps using a language model-based agent to conduct structured
reasoning analysis of assembly code and generate features such as input/output
types, side effects, notable constants, and algorithmic intent. Unlike
hand-crafted features, they are richer and adaptive. Unlike embeddings, they
are human-readable, maintainable, and directly searchable with inverted or
relational indexes. Without any matching training, our method respectively
achieves 42% and 62% for recall@1 in cross-architecture and cross-optimization
tasks, comparable to embedding methods with training (39% and 34%). Combined
with embeddings, it significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art,
demonstrating that accuracy, scalability, and interpretability can coexist.

AI.tldr: An LLM-based agent analyzes assembly to produce human-readable features for cross-architecture/code similarity, achieving competitive recall without training; when combined with embeddings, it surpasses SOTA.
AI.motivation: Need for interpretable, generalizable, scalable binary code similarity; hand-crafted features are limited; embeddings lack interpretability and require costly NN search; balance trade-offs.
AI.method: Use a language-model-based agent to perform structured reasoning on assembly code to extract features: input/output types, side effects, constants, algorithmic intent; these features are human-readable and indexable; no training data required for matching; can be combined with embeddings.
AI.result: Recall@1: 42% cross-architecture, 62% cross-optimization; embeddings alone achieve 39% and 34%; combined with embeddings, surpasses state-of-the-art.
AI.conclusion: Interpretability, generalizability, and scalability can coexist; the proposed feature-based approach complements embeddings and improves overall performance; highlights the potential of analysis-driven features for binary code similarity.

title: IsingFormer: Augmenting Parallel Tempering With Learned Proposals
