AI.tldr: DOoM is an open-source benchmark that evaluates Russian-language LMs on solving math and physics problems across difficulty levels, with initial results showing a correlation between token usage and performance and notable differences between math and physics tasks.
AI.motivation: To create a dedicated, open benchmark for Russian STEM problem solving to assess and compare language models, addressing gaps in multilingual benchmarks and enabling analysis of how factors like token budget affect reasoning.
AI.method: Dataset spans school-level to university Olympiad and entrance-exam style problems. The paper outlines dataset structure and evaluation methodology and reports initial experiments across several models, additionally analyzing how performance scales with token usage and comparing math vs physics tasks.
AI.result: Initial testing of various models reveals a correlation between the number of tokens used and performance, and identifies differences in model performance between mathematics and physics questions.
AI.conclusion: DOoM provides a reusable, open benchmark for evaluating Russian-language mathematical and physical reasoning in LMs, with a clear dataset structure, evaluation framework, and baseline results, paving the way for future improvements and broader analyses.

title: Unleashing Flow Policies with Distributional Critics
summary:
Flow-based policies have recently emerged as a powerful tool in offline and
offline-to-online reinforcement learning, capable of modeling the complex,
multimodal behaviors found in pre-collected datasets. However, the full
potential of these expressive actors is often bottlenecked by their critics,
which typically learn a single, scalar estimate of the expected return. To
address this limitation, we introduce the Distributional Flow Critic (DFC), a
novel critic architecture that learns the complete state-action return
distribution. Instead of regressing to a single value, DFC employs flow
matching to model the distribution of return as a continuous, flexible
transformation from a simple base distribution to the complex target
distribution of returns. By doing so, DFC provides the expressive flow-based
policy with a rich, distributional Bellman target, which offers a more stable
and informative learning signal. Extensive experiments across D4RL and OGBench
benchmarks demonstrate that our approach achieves strong performance,
especially on tasks requiring multimodal action distributions, and excels in
both offline and offline-to-online fine-tuning compared to existing methods.

AI.tldr: Proposes Distributional Flow Critic (DFC): a flow-based critic that models the full return distribution via flow matching, offering distributional Bellman targets and improved performance for multimodal actions in offline and offline-to-online RL (D4RL and OGBench).
AI.motivation: Traditional flow-based critics provide a single scalar estimate, which is insufficient to capture multimodal returns and can hinder learning from rich offline datasets. A distributional critic can provide richer, more informative targets and stabilize training.
AI.method: Introduce Distributional Flow Critic (DFC) that uses flow matching to learn the return distribution for state-action pairs. The critic models the distribution as a continuous transformation from a base distribution through a normalizing-flow-like mapping. This distributional critic provides a distributional Bellman target to the flow-based policy and is trained in offline and offline-to-online settings.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on D4RL and OGBench shows strong performance, especially on tasks requiring multimodal action distributions, with improvements in both offline learning and offline-to-online fine-tuning compared to existing baselines.
AI.conclusion: DFC demonstrates that learning the full return distribution with a flow-based critic yields richer targets and improved performance for flow-based policies in offline and offline-to-online RL, particularly for multimodal action scenarios.

title: MMeViT: Multi-Modal ensemble ViT for Post-Stroke Rehabilitation Action Recognition
summary:
Rehabilitation therapy for stroke patients faces a supply shortage despite
the increasing demand. To address this issue, remote monitoring systems that
reduce the burden on medical staff are emerging as a viable alternative. A key
component of these remote monitoring systems is Human Action Recognition (HAR)
technology, which classifies actions. However, existing HAR studies have
primarily focused on non-disable individuals, making them unsuitable for
recognizing the actions of stroke patients. HAR research for stroke has largely
concentrated on classifying relatively simple actions using machine learning
rather than deep learning. In this study, we designed a system to monitor the
actions of stroke patients, focusing on domiciliary upper limb Activities of
Daily Living (ADL). Our system utilizes IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) sensors
and an RGB-D camera, which are the most common modalities in HAR. We directly
collected a dataset through this system, investigated an appropriate preprocess
and proposed a deep learning model suitable for processing multimodal data. We
analyzed the collected dataset and found that the action data of stroke
patients is less clustering than that of non-disabled individuals.
Simultaneously, we found that the proposed model learns similar tendencies for
each label in data with features that are difficult to clustering. This study
suggests the possibility of expanding the deep learning model, which has
learned the action features of stroke patients, to not only simple action
recognition but also feedback such as assessment contributing to domiciliary
rehabilitation in future research. The code presented in this study is
available at https://github.com/ye-Kim/MMeViT.

AI.tldr: A multimodal deep-learning HAR system using IMU and RGB-D sensors monitors domiciliary upper-limb ADLs in stroke patients; a new dataset was collected; results reveal different clustering characteristics in patient data and the model shows label-consistent tendencies, with potential for rehab feedback.
AI.motivation: Address the shortage of rehabilitation resources for stroke patients and the inadequacy of existing HAR approaches (focused on non-disabled individuals and simple actions). Proposes a multimodal, deep-learning HAR solution tailored to stroke patients to enable remote monitoring and home-based rehabilitation.
AI.method: Collected a multimodal dataset using IMU sensors and an RGB-D camera. Designed a preprocessing pipeline and a multimodal deep-learning model (MMeViT) to process combined sensor data for action recognition. Analyzed clustering behavior and explored generalization across actions. Code available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.result: Found that stroke patient action data exhibit less clear clustering than non-disabled data. The proposed model learns label tendencies even in data with weak clustering, suggesting robustness to ambiguous features. Demonstrated feasibility for remote monitoring and identified potential for future feedback/assessment in domiciliary rehabilitation.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates the viability of multimodal deep-learning HAR for stroke patients in home settings and highlights opportunities to extend the model to provide rehabilitation feedback and assessment, pending broader action sets and clinical validation.

title: GES-UniGrasp: A Two-Stage Dexterous Grasping Strategy With Geometry-Based Expert Selection
summary:
Robust and human-like dexterous grasping of general objects is a critical
capability for advancing intelligent robotic manipulation in real-world
scenarios. However, existing reinforcement learning methods guided by grasp
priors often result in unnatural behaviors. In this work, we present
\textit{ContactGrasp}, a robotic dexterous pre-grasp and grasp dataset that
explicitly accounts for task-relevant wrist orientation and thumb-index
pinching coordination. The dataset covers 773 objects in 82 categories,
providing a rich foundation for training human-like grasp strategies. Building
upon this dataset, we perform geometry-based clustering to group objects by
shape, enabling a two-stage Geometry-based Expert Selection (GES) framework
that selects among specialized experts for grasping diverse object geometries,
thereby enhancing adaptability to diverse shapes and generalization across
categories. Our approach demonstrates natural grasp postures and achieves high
success rates of 99.4\% and 96.3\% on the train and test sets, respectively,
showcasing strong generalization and high-quality grasp execution.

AI.tldr: ContactGrasp provides a dexterous pre-grasp and grasp dataset and a two-stage geometry-based expert selection (GES) framework to achieve natural, human-like grasps across diverse objects, with high training/testing success rates.
AI.motivation: Reinforcement learning methods guided by grasp priors often yield unnatural grasp behaviors. There is a need for a dataset that encodes task-relevant wrist orientation and thumb-index coordination to enable natural, human-like grasping and strong generalization across object shapes and categories.
AI.method: Introduce the ContactGrasp dataset (773 objects in 82 categories) that explicitly encodes task-relevant wrist orientation and thumb-index pinching. Apply geometry-based clustering to group objects by shape and develop a two-stage Geometry-based Expert Selection (GES) framework that selects among specialized grasping experts for different object geometries, improving adaptability and generalization.
AI.result: The approach yields natural grasp postures and high success rates: 99.4% on the training set and 96.3% on the test set, indicating strong generalization and high-quality grasp execution.
AI.conclusion: The ContactGrasp dataset combined with the GES framework advances robust, generalizable, and human-like dexterous grasping for diverse objects, bridging data-driven learning and geometry-based specialization for real-world robotic manipulation.

title: Beyond the Strongest LLM: Multi-Turn Multi-Agent Orchestration vs. Single LLMs on Benchmarks
summary:
We study multi-turn multi-agent orchestration, where multiple large language
model (LLM) agents interact over multiple turns by iteratively proposing
answers or casting votes until reaching consensus. Using four LLMs (Gemini 2.5
Pro, GPT-5, Grok 4, and Claude Sonnet 4) on GPQA-Diamond, IFEval, and MuSR, we
conduct two experiments: (i) benchmarking orchestration against single-LLM
baselines; and (ii) ablations on GPQA-Diamond that vary whether agents see who
authored answers and whether they can observe ongoing votes. Orchestration
matches or exceeds the strongest single model and consistently outperforms the
others. Analysis of best-achievable orchestration performance shows potential
for further gains. The ablations show that revealing authorship increases
self-voting and ties, and that showing ongoing votes amplifies herding, which
speeds convergence but can sometimes yield premature consensus.

AI.tldr: Multi-turn LLM orchestration among several agents improves consensus performance over single-model baselines, with authorship visibility and ongoing vote visibility affecting dynamics.
AI.motivation: To evaluate how orchestrating multiple LLM agents over multiple turns compares to single-model baselines and to study how visibility of authorship and votes affects convergence.
AI.method: Empirically benchmark four LLM agents (Gemini 2.5 Pro, GPT-5, Grok 4, Claude Sonnet 4) on GPQA-Diamond, IFEval, MuSR with two experiments: orchestration vs baselines; ablations on GPQA-Diamond varying information visibility.
AI.result: Orchestration matches or exceeds strongest single model and outperforms others; best-achievable orchestration shows room for gains; revealing authorship increases self-voting and ties; showing ongoing votes amplifies herding and speeds convergence but risks premature consensus.
AI.conclusion: Multi-turn orchestration is a viable strategy to boost performance in multi-agent LLM settings, with dynamics influenced by information visibility; further improvements possible.

title: Demystifying Network Foundation Models
summary:
This work presents a systematic investigation into the latent knowledge
encoded within Network Foundation Models (NFMs) that focuses on hidden
representations analysis rather than pure downstream task performance.
Different from existing efforts, we analyze the models through a three-part
evaluation: Embedding Geometry Analysis to assess representation space
utilization, Metric Alignment Assessment to measure correspondence with
domain-expert features, and Causal Sensitivity Testing to evaluate robustness
to protocol perturbations. Using five diverse network datasets spanning
controlled and real-world environments, we evaluate four state-of-the-art NFMs,
revealing that they all exhibit significant anisotropy, inconsistent feature
sensitivity patterns, an inability to separate the high-level context, payload
dependency, and other properties. Our work identifies numerous limitations
across all models and demonstrates that addressing them can significantly
improve model performance (by up to +0.35 $F_1$ score without architectural
changes).

AI.tldr: Systematic latent-knowledge analysis of Network Foundation Models (NFMs) using three diagnostic axes—Embedding Geometry, Metric Alignment, and Causal Sensitivity—across five datasets and four NFMs. Findings show strong anisotropy, inconsistent feature sensitivity, and entanglement of high-level context with payload; addressing these limitations can boost F1 by up to 0.35 without architectural changes.
AI.motivation: Fill the gap between downstream task performance and what latent representations encode in NFMs. Provide diagnostic tools to understand representation geometry, domain-feature alignment, and robustness to protocol perturbations.
AI.method: Three-part evaluation: Embedding Geometry Analysis, Metric Alignment Assessment, and Causal Sensitivity Testing applied to five diverse datasets (controlled and real-world) and four state-of-the-art NFMs to probe representation space usage, feature-sensitivity consistency, and robustness to perturbations.
AI.result: All four NFMs show significant anisotropy and inconsistent feature-sensitivity patterns; they struggle to separate high-level context from payload and exhibit context-payload entanglement across datasets. Identifying these limitations yields potential performance gains (up to +0.35 F1) without changing architecture.
AI.conclusion: The study reveals pervasive latent-knowledge limitations in NFMs and demonstrates that targeted latent-analysis diagnostics can guide improvements in performance without architectural changes, highlighting the value of embedding-geometry, feature-alignment, and causal-robustness analyses.

title: Activation Matching for Explanation Generation
summary:
In this paper we introduce an activation-matching--based approach to generate
minimal, faithful explanations for the decision-making of a pretrained
classifier on any given image. Given an input image \(x\) and a frozen model
\(f\), we train a lightweight autoencoder to output a binary mask \(m\) such
that the explanation \(e = m \odot x\) preserves both the model's prediction
and the intermediate activations of \(x\). Our objective combines: (i)
multi-layer activation matching with KL divergence to align distributions and
cross-entropy to retain the top-1 label for both the image and the explanation;
(ii) mask priors -- L1 area for minimality, a binarization penalty for crisp
0/1 masks, and total variation for compactness; and (iii) abductive constraints
for faithfulness and necessity. Together, these objectives yield small,
human-interpretable masks that retain classifier behavior while discarding
irrelevant input regions, providing practical and faithful minimalist
explanations for the decision making of the underlying model.

AI.tldr: Activation-matching autoencoder to generate minimal, faithful explanations by masking input while preserving model predictions and activations.
AI.motivation: Need for explanations that are concise, faithful to the model’s decision process, and interpretable by humans; avoid revealing extraneous input regions.
AI.method: Train a lightweight autoencoder to output a binary mask m; explanation e = m ⊙ x. Optimize via multi-layer activation matching (KL divergence + cross-entropy to preserve top-1 label for image and explanation), mask priors (L1-area for minimality, binarization penalty, total variation for compactness), and abductive constraints for faithfulness and necessity.
AI.result: Produces small, human-interpretable masks that retain classifier behavior while discarding irrelevant input regions.
AI.conclusion: This approach yields faithful, minimalist explanations and demonstrates activation-aligned masking as a practical explanation method for pretrained classifiers.

title: Generalizable Coarse-to-Fine Robot Manipulation via Language-Aligned 3D Keypoints
summary:
Hierarchical coarse-to-fine policy, where a coarse branch predicts a region
of interest to guide a fine-grained action predictor, has demonstrated
significant potential in robotic 3D manipulation tasks by especially enhancing
sample efficiency and enabling more precise manipulation. However, even
augmented with pre-trained models, these hierarchical policies still suffer
from generalization issues. To enhance generalization to novel instructions and
environment variations, we propose Coarse-to-fine Language-Aligned manipulation
Policy (CLAP), a framework that integrates three key components: 1) task
decomposition, 2) VLM fine-tuning for 3D keypoint prediction, and 3) 3D-aware
representation. Through comprehensive experiments in simulation and on a real
robot, we demonstrate its superior generalization capability. Specifically, on
GemBench, a benchmark designed for evaluating generalization, our approach
achieves a 12\% higher average success rate than the SOTA method while using
only 1/5 of the training trajectories. In real-world experiments, our policy,
trained on only 10 demonstrations, successfully generalizes to novel
instructions and environments.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical coarse-to-fine policy with language-aligned VLM fine-tuning and 3D-aware representations (CLAP) improves generalization in robotic manipulation, achieving 12% higher success on GemBench with 1/5 data and 10-demo real-world generalization.
AI.motivation: Generalization gaps persist in hierarchical 3D manipulation policies even with pre-trained models; there is a need for methods that generalize to new instructions and varied environments.
AI.method: CLAP integrates: (1) task decomposition into coarse region and fine-grained action; (2) fine-tuning a vision-language model for 3D keypoint prediction; (3) 3D-aware representation to align language with actions.
AI.result: GemBench shows 12% higher average success rate than SOTA using only 1/5 training trajectories; real-world experiments show successful generalization to novel instructions and environments with only 10 demonstrations.
AI.conclusion: CLAP demonstrates superior generalization and sample efficiency, validating the proposed architecture for generalizing hierarchical policies in 3D manipulation.

title: Formalization Driven LLM Prompt Jailbreaking via Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities, yet
they also introduce novel security challenges. For instance, prompt
jailbreaking attacks involve adversaries crafting sophisticated prompts to
elicit responses from LLMs that deviate from human values. To uncover
vulnerabilities in LLM alignment methods, we propose the PASS framework
(\underline{P}rompt J\underline{a}ilbreaking via \underline{S}emantic and
\underline{S}tructural Formalization). Specifically, PASS employs reinforcement
learning to transform initial jailbreak prompts into formalized descriptions,
which enhances stealthiness and enables bypassing existing alignment defenses.
The jailbreak outputs are then structured into a GraphRAG system that, by
leveraging extracted relevant terms and formalized symbols as contextual input
alongside the original query, strengthens subsequent attacks and facilitates
more effective jailbreaks. We conducted extensive experiments on common
open-source models, demonstrating the effectiveness of our attack.

AI.tldr: PASS is a framework that weaponizes jailbreak prompts by first transforming them into formal semantic/structural descriptions via reinforcement learning, then embedding these descriptions into a GraphRAG context to produce more effective jailbreaks against LLM alignment defenses, with empirical success on common open-source models.
AI.motivation: To expose vulnerabilities in current LLM alignment methods by designing stealthy, potent jailbreaks and assess the limits of defenses against prompt jailbreaks.
AI.method: 1) Use reinforcement learning to convert initial jailbreak prompts into formalized semantic/structural descriptions. 2) Build a GraphRAG system that uses extracted terms and formal symbols as contextual input together with the original prompt to enhance attack effectiveness and bypass defenses.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on common open-source LLMs demonstrate the attack's effectiveness and ability to bypass existing alignment defenses.
AI.conclusion: PASS reveals persistent LLM alignment vulnerabilities and suggests the need for stronger, more robust defenses; the combination of semantic/structural formalization and GraphRAG context enables more stealthy and successful jailbreaks.

title: Sensitivity Analysis for Diffusion Models
summary:
Training a diffusion model approximates a map from a data distribution $\rho$
to the optimal score function $s_t$ for that distribution. Can we differentiate
this map? If we could, then we could predict how the score, and ultimately the
model's samples, would change under small perturbations to the training set
before committing to costly retraining. We give a closed-form procedure for
computing this map's directional derivatives, relying only on black-box access
to a pre-trained score model and its derivatives with respect to its inputs. We
extend this result to estimate the sensitivity of a diffusion model's samples
to additive perturbations of its target measure, with runtime comparable to
sampling from a diffusion model and computing log-likelihoods along the sample
path. Our method is robust to numerical and approximation error, and the
resulting sensitivities correlate with changes in an image diffusion model's
samples after retraining and fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: A closed-form method to differentiate the diffusion-score map with respect to training data, enabling fast sensitivity estimates of samples under small data perturbations without retraining.
AI.motivation: To predict how a diffusion model's score function and samples change when the training data (or target measure) is slightly perturbed, avoiding costly retraining.
AI.method: Derive directional derivatives of the map from data distribution to the optimal score using only black-box access to a pre-trained score model and its derivatives w.r.t. inputs; extend to additive perturbations of the target measure; runtime comparable to diffusion sampling and log-likelihood evaluation; robust to numerical/approximation errors.
AI.result: Provides a closed-form procedure for computing the map's directional derivatives; sensitivities correlate with sample changes after retraining/fine-tuning and have practical runtime.
AI.conclusion: Enables practical sensitivity analysis of diffusion models to training data changes, offering a tool to anticipate retraining effects without full retraining.

title: Mask What Matters: Controllable Text-Guided Masking for Self-Supervised Medical Image Analysis
summary:
The scarcity of annotated data in specialized domains such as medical imaging
presents significant challenges to training robust vision models. While
self-supervised masked image modeling (MIM) offers a promising solution,
existing approaches largely rely on random high-ratio masking, leading to
inefficiency and poor semantic alignment. Moreover, region-aware variants
typically depend on reconstruction heuristics or supervised signals, limiting
their adaptability across tasks and modalities. We propose Mask What Matters, a
controllable text-guided masking framework for self-supervised medical image
analysis. By leveraging vision-language models for prompt-based region
localization, our method flexibly applies differentiated masking to emphasize
diagnostically relevant regions while reducing redundancy in background areas.
This controllable design enables better semantic alignment, improved
representation learning, and stronger cross-task generalizability.
Comprehensive evaluation across multiple medical imaging modalities, including
brain MRI, chest CT, and lung X-ray, shows that Mask What Matters consistently
outperforms existing MIM methods (e.g., SparK), achieving gains of up to +3.1
percentage points in classification accuracy, +1.3 in box average precision
(BoxAP), and +1.1 in mask average precision (MaskAP) for detection. Notably, it
achieves these improvements with substantially lower overall masking ratios
(e.g., 40\% vs. 70\%). This work demonstrates that controllable, text-driven
masking can enable semantically aligned self-supervised learning, advancing the
development of robust vision models for medical image analysis.

AI.tldr: A controllable, text-guided masking framework (Mask What Matters) for self-supervised medical image analysis that uses vision-language prompts to localize regions and apply differentiated masking, achieving better semantic alignment with lower masking ratios and improved cross-modality performance.
AI.motivation: Medical imaging suffers from scarce annotated data. Random high-ratio masking in self-supervised masked image modeling (MIM) is inefficient and semantically misaligned. Region-aware methods often rely on heuristics or supervised signals, limiting transferability across tasks and modalities.
AI.method: Introduce Mask What Matters, a controllable, text-guided masking framework that uses vision-language models for prompt-based region localization to apply differentiated masking that emphasizes diagnostically relevant regions and reduces background redundancy, enabling semantically aligned self-supervised learning across modalities.
AI.result: The method consistently outperforms existing MIM approaches (e.g., SparK) across brain MRI, chest CT, and lung X-ray. Reported gains include +3.1 percentage points in classification accuracy, +1.3 in BoxAP, and +1.1 in MaskAP for detection, achieved with substantially lower masking ratios (e.g., 40% vs. 70%).
AI.conclusion: Controllable, text-driven masking facilitates semantically aligned self-supervised learning, improving representation learning and cross-task generalizability for medical image analysis.

title: Encoding Material Safety using Control Barrier Functions for Soft Actuator Control
summary:
Until recently, the concept of soft robot safety was an informal notion,
often attributed solely to the fact that soft robots are less likely to damage
their operating environment than rigid robots. As the field moves toward
feedback control for practical applications, it becomes increasingly important
to define what safety means and to characterize how soft robots can become
unsafe. The unifying theme of soft robotics is to achieve useful functionality
through deformation. Consequently, limitations in constitutive model accuracy
and risks of material failure are inherent to all soft robots and pose a key
challenge in designing provably safe controllers. This work introduces a formal
definition of material safety based on strain energy functions and provides a
controller that enforces it. We characterize safe and unsafe sets of an
incompressible hyperelastic material and demonstrate that safety can be
enforced using a high-order control barrier function (HOCBF) with quadratic
program-based feedback control. As a case study, we consider a pressurized
hyperelastic tube with inertial effects, first-order viscous effects, and
full-state feedback. Simulation results verify that the proposed methodology
can enforce the material safety specification.

AI.tldr: Defines material safety for soft robots via strain-energy-based safe/unsafe sets and enforces it with a high-order control barrier function (HOCBF) in a QP-based controller; validated through simulations on a pressurized hyperelastic tube.
AI.motivation: As soft robots scale to feedback control, there is a need for a formal safety definition and provable safety guarantees, given constitutive model inaccuracies and material failure risks.
AI.method: Formal safety sets derived from strain energy for incompressible hyperelastic materials; enforce safety with HOCBF integrated into a quadratic-program (QP) based feedback controller; case study with a pressurized hyperelastic tube including inertia, first-order viscosity, and full-state feedback.
AI.result: Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed HOCBF-based controller can enforce the material safety specification.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a principled, provable safety framework for soft-robot control under hyperelastic material models, using strain-energy safety sets and HOCBF-QP control; applicable to incompressible hyperelastic tubes and similar soft actuators.

title: A Hierarchical Structure-Enhanced Personalized Recommendation Model for Traditional Chinese Medicine Formulas Based on KG Diffusion Guidance
comment:
10 pages, 10 figures, Proceedings of the 34th ACM International
  Conference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM)
summary:
Artificial intelligence technology plays a crucial role in recommending
prescriptions for traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). Previous studies have
made significant progress by focusing on the symptom-herb relationship in
prescriptions. However, several limitations hinder model performance: (i)
Insufficient attention to patient-personalized information such as age, BMI,
and medical history, which hampers accurate identification of syndrome and
reduces efficacy. (ii) The typical long-tailed distribution of herb data
introduces training biases and affects generalization ability. (iii) The
oversight of the 'monarch, minister, assistant and envoy' compatibility among
herbs increases the risk of toxicity or side effects, opposing the 'treatment
based on syndrome differentiation' principle in clinical TCM. Therefore, we
propose a novel hierarchical structure-enhanced personalized recommendation
model for TCM formulas based on knowledge graph diffusion guidance, namely
TCM-HEDPR. Specifically, we pre-train symptom representations using
patient-personalized prompt sequences and apply prompt-oriented contrastive
learning for data augmentation. Furthermore, we employ a KG-guided homogeneous
graph diffusion method integrated with a self-attention mechanism to globally
capture the non-linear symptom-herb relationship. Lastly, we design a
heterogeneous graph hierarchical network to integrate herbal dispensing
relationships with implicit syndromes, guiding the prescription generation
process at a fine-grained level and mitigating the long-tailed herb data
distribution problem. Extensive experiments on two public datasets and one
clinical dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of TCM-HEDPR. In addition, we
incorporate insights from modern medicine and network pharmacology to evaluate
the recommended prescriptions comprehensively. It can provide a new paradigm
for the recommendation of modern TCM.

AI.tldr: A KG-diffusion-based, hierarchical, personalized recommender for traditional Chinese medicine formulas (TCM-HEDPR) that tackles personalization gaps, long-tailed herb distribution, and herb-compatibility to improve syndrome differentiation and safety; validated on multiple datasets with promising results.
AI.motivation: Current TCM prescription modeling focuses on symptom–herb mappings but neglects patient-specific factors (age, BMI, medical history), suffers from long-tailed herb data that biases learning, and overlooks the monarch–minister–assistant–envoy compatibility among herbs, risking toxicity and misalignment with syndrome differentiation. This motivates a personalized, safe, and generalizable approach guided by knowledge graphs.
AI.method: 1) Pre-train symptom representations via patient-personalized prompt sequences and use prompt-oriented contrastive learning for data augmentation. 2) Apply a KG-guided homogeneous graph diffusion with self-attention to capture non-linear symptom–herb relationships globally. 3) Build a heterogeneous graph hierarchical network to integrate herbal dispensing relationships with implicit syndromes, enabling fine-grained prescription generation and addressing long-tail data distribution.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on two public datasets and one clinical dataset show the method's effectiveness; the evaluation is complemented by insights from modern medicine and network pharmacology to assess prescriptions comprehensively.
AI.conclusion: TCM-HEDPR offers a new paradigm for modern TCM prescription recommendation, combining personalization, safety, and robust generalization through graph diffusion and hierarchical heterogeneous networks.

title: Causally-Enhanced Reinforcement Policy Optimization
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) trained with reinforcement objectives often
achieve superficially correct answers via shortcut strategies, pairing correct
outputs with spurious or unfaithful reasoning and degrading under small causal
perturbations. We introduce Causally-Enhanced Policy Optimization (CE-PO), a
drop-in reward-shaping framework that augments policy optimization with a
differentiable proxy for causal coherence along the generation pathway from
prompt (Z) to rationale (X) to answer (Y). CE-PO estimates model-internal
influence with Jacobian-based sensitivities, counterfactually hardens these
signals to suppress nuisance cues, and fuses the resulting coherence score with
task-accuracy feedback via a Minkowski (power-mean) combiner, exposing a single
tunable between accuracy and coherence trade-off. The unified reward integrates
with PPO/GRPO without architectural changes. Across reasoning benchmarks and
causal stress tests, CE-PO reduces reward hacking and unfaithful
chain-of-thought while improving robustness to correlation-causation flips and
light counterfactual edits, all at near-parity accuracy. Experimental results
across 4 datasets show that CE-PO improves accuracy over baselines by 5.49% on
average (up to 9.58%), while improving robustness to correlation-causation
flips and light counterfactual edits.

AI.tldr: CE-PO is a drop-in reward-shaping method that augments policy optimization with a differentiable causal coherence proxy along the Z->X->Y generation path; uses Jacobian-based sensitivities, counterfactually hardens signals, and fuses the resulting coherence score with task accuracy via a Minkowski combiner to trade off between accuracy and coherence; integrates with PPO/GRPO without architectural changes and improves robustness and reduces reward hacking, with near-parity accuracy and average accuracy gains (~5.49%, up to 9.58%) across 4 datasets.
AI.motivation: Pro: LLMs trained with reinforcement objectives can rely on shortcut strategies that yield superficially correct answers but are unfaithful in reasoning and fragile to small causal perturbations. Goal: enforce causal coherence along the reasoning chain (prompt Z -> rationale X -> answer Y) to improve faithfulness and robustness.
AI.method: Propose CE-PO: a differentiable proxy for causal coherence along the Z->X->Y path; estimates model-internal influence via Jacobian sensitivities; counterfactually hardens these signals to suppress nuisance cues; fuses coherence with task-accuracy feedback using a Minkowski (power-mean) combiner to yield a single tunable balance between accuracy and coherence; can be plugged into PPO or GRPO without changing architecture.
AI.result: Empirically reduces reward hacking and unfaithful chain-of-thought while improving robustness to correlation-causation flips and light counterfactual edits; achieves near-parity accuracy; across 4 datasets, average accuracy improvement of 5.49% (max 9.58%).
AI.conclusion: CE-PO provides a practical, tunable reward-shaping framework that enhances causal coherence and robustness of LLM reasoning without requiring architectural changes, achieving meaningful accuracy gains while mitigating shortcut-driven failures; effective across reasoning benchmarks and causal stress tests.

title: FMC-DETR: Frequency-Decoupled Multi-Domain Coordination for Aerial-View Object Detection
summary:
Aerial-view object detection is a critical technology for real-world
applications such as natural resource monitoring, traffic management, and
UAV-based search and rescue. Detecting tiny objects in high-resolution aerial
imagery presents a long-standing challenge due to their limited visual cues and
the difficulty of modeling global context in complex scenes. Existing methods
are often hampered by delayed contextual fusion and inadequate non-linear
modeling, failing to effectively use global information to refine shallow
features and thus encountering a performance bottleneck. To address these
challenges, we propose FMC-DETR, a novel framework with frequency-decoupled
fusion for aerial-view object detection. First, we introduce the Wavelet
Kolmogorov-Arnold Transformer (WeKat) backbone, which applies cascaded wavelet
transforms to enhance global low-frequency context perception in shallow
features while preserving fine-grained details, and employs Kolmogorov-Arnold
networks to achieve adaptive non-linear modeling of multi-scale dependencies.
Next, a lightweight Cross-stage Partial Fusion (CPF) module reduces redundancy
and improves multi-scale feature interaction. Finally, we introduce the
Multi-Domain Feature Coordination (MDFC) module, which unifies spatial,
frequency, and structural priors to to balance detail preservation and global
enhancement. Extensive experiments on benchmark aerial-view datasets
demonstrate that FMC-DETR achieves state-of-the-art performance with fewer
parameters. On the challenging VisDrone dataset, our model achieves
improvements of 6.5% AP and 8.2% AP50 over the baseline, highlighting its
effectiveness in tiny object detection. The code can be accessed at
https://github.com/bloomingvision/FMC-DETR.

AI.tldr: FMC-DETR uses frequency-decoupled fusion with WeKat, CPF, and MDFC to boost tiny aerial-object detection with fewer parameters, achieving state-of-the-art results on VisDrone.
AI.motivation: Tiny objects in high-resolution aerial imagery have limited visual cues and global context is hard to model; existing methods suffer from delayed fusion and weak non-linear multi-scale modeling, creating a performance bottleneck.
AI.method: Propose FMC-DETR: Wavelet Kolmogorov-Arnold Transformer (WeKat) backbone with cascaded wavelet transforms to enhance global low-frequency context while preserving detail, and Kolmogorov-Arnold networks for adaptive non-linear multi-scale modeling; Cross-stage Partial Fusion (CPF) to reduce redundancy and improve multi-scale feature interaction; Multi-Domain Feature Coordination (MDFC) to unify spatial, frequency, and structural priors.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on aerial-view benchmarks show state-of-the-art performance with fewer parameters; on VisDrone, gains of 6.5% AP and 8.2% AP50 over baseline, demonstrating effectiveness in tiny object detection.
AI.conclusion: The framework effectively leverages frequency-domain information and adaptive non-linear multi-scale modeling to improve tiny object detection in aerial imagery while maintaining parameter efficiency, suggesting strong potential for real-world UAV applications.

title: KiVi: Kinesthetic-Visuospatial Integration for Dynamic and Safe Egocentric Legged Locomotion
summary:
Vision-based locomotion has shown great promise in enabling legged robots to
perceive and adapt to complex environments. However, visual information is
inherently fragile, being vulnerable to occlusions, reflections, and lighting
changes, which often cause instability in locomotion. Inspired by animal
sensorimotor integration, we propose KiVi, a Kinesthetic-Visuospatial
integration framework, where kinesthetics encodes proprioceptive sensing of
body motion and visuospatial reasoning captures visual perception of
surrounding terrain. Specifically, KiVi separates these pathways, leveraging
proprioception as a stable backbone while selectively incorporating vision for
terrain awareness and obstacle avoidance. This modality-balanced, yet
integrative design, combined with memory-enhanced attention, allows the robot
to robustly interpret visual cues while maintaining fallback stability through
proprioception. Extensive experiments show that our method enables quadruped
robots to stably traverse diverse terrains and operate reliably in unstructured
outdoor environments, remaining robust to out-of-distribution (OOD) visual
noise and occlusion unseen during training, thereby highlighting its
effectiveness and applicability to real-world legged locomotion.

AI.tldr: KiVi: a proprioception-first, visuo-spatially aware locomotion framework that separates kinesthetic and visual pathways, using memory-enhanced attention to robustly traverse diverse terrains under occlusion and visual noise.
AI.motivation: Vision-based locomotion is fragile to occlusions, reflections, and lighting changes; inspired by animal sensorimotor integration to maintain stable motion using proprioception as backbone while leveraging vision for terrain-aware decisions.
AI.method: Separate kinesthetic and visuospatial pathways; proprioception serves as a stable backbone; selective visual input for terrain awareness and obstacle avoidance; modality-balanced fusion with memory-enhanced attention; evaluated on quadrupeds across diverse terrains and unstructured outdoor environments.
AI.result: Demonstrates stable traversal on diverse terrains; reliable operation in unstructured outdoor environments; robust to out-of-distribution visual noise and occlusion not seen during training.
AI.conclusion: Modality-balanced KiVi architecture with memory-enhanced attention improves robustness of vision-based legged locomotion and is applicable to real-world deployment.

title: Clean First, Align Later: Benchmarking Preference Data Cleaning for Reliable LLM Alignment
summary:
Human feedback plays a pivotal role in aligning large language models (LLMs)
with human preferences. However, such feedback is often noisy or inconsistent,
which can degrade the quality of reward models and hinder alignment. While
various automated data cleaning methods have been proposed to mitigate this
issue, a systematic evaluation of their effectiveness and generalizability
remains lacking. To bridge this gap, we introduce the first comprehensive
benchmark for evaluating 13 preference data cleaning methods in the context of
LLM alignment. PrefCleanBench offers a standardized protocol to assess cleaning
strategies in terms of alignment performance and generalizability across
diverse datasets, model architectures, and optimization algorithms. By unifying
disparate methods and rigorously comparing them, we uncover key factors that
determine the success of data cleaning in alignment tasks. This benchmark lays
the groundwork for principled and reproducible approaches to improving LLM
alignment through better data quality-highlighting the crucial but
underexplored role of data preprocessing in responsible AI development. We
release modular implementations of all methods to catalyze further research:
https://github.com/deeplearning-wisc/PrefCleanBench.

AI.tldr: First comprehensive benchmark (PrefCleanBench) for evaluating 13 automated preference data cleaning methods in LLM alignment, showing data cleaning quality critically influences alignment performance and generalization; provides a standardized protocol and modular implementations.
AI.motivation: Human feedback is essential for aligning LLMs but is often noisy/inconsistent, degrading reward models and alignment. A systematic, scalable evaluation of automated data cleaning methods is needed to understand their effectiveness and generalizability.
AI.method: Introduces PrefCleanBench, a standardized protocol to assess cleaning strategies across diverse datasets, model architectures, and optimization algorithms, evaluating 13 cleaning methods. Provides modular, released implementations to enable reproducibility and broad testing.
AI.result: Benchmarks reveal key factors that determine success of data cleaning in alignment tasks and show how effectiveness generalizes across datasets, architectures, and optimizers. The study highlights the importance of data preprocessing for robust LLM alignment and offers guidance for principled cleaning strategies.
AI.conclusion: Data preprocessing plays a crucial, underappreciated role in responsible AI development. PrefCleanBench establishes a foundation for reproducible evaluation and improvement of alignment pipelines through better data quality and cleaning methods, with released code to catalyze future research.

title: Towards Quantum-Ready Blockchain Fraud Detection via Ensemble Graph Neural Networks
summary:
Blockchain Business applications and cryptocurrencies such as enable secure,
decentralized value transfer, yet their pseudonymous nature creates
opportunities for illicit activity, challenging regulators and exchanges in
anti money laundering (AML) enforcement. Detecting fraudulent transactions in
blockchain networks requires models that can capture both structural and
temporal dependencies while remaining resilient to noise, imbalance, and
adversarial behavior. In this work, we propose an ensemble framework that
integrates Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN), Graph Attention Networks (GAT),
and Graph Isomorphism Networks (GIN) to enhance blockchain fraud detection.
Using the real-world Elliptic dataset, our tuned soft voting ensemble achieves
high recall of illicit transactions while maintaining a false positive rate
below 1%, beating individual GNN models and baseline methods. The modular
architecture incorporates quantum-ready design hooks, allowing seamless future
integration of quantum feature mappings and hybrid quantum classical graph
neural networks. This ensures scalability, robustness, and long-term
adaptability as quantum computing technologies mature. Our findings highlight
ensemble GNNs as a practical and forward-looking solution for real-time
cryptocurrency monitoring, providing both immediate AML utility and a pathway
toward quantum-enhanced financial security analytics.

AI.tldr: An ensemble of GCN, GAT, and GIN with soft voting improves blockchain fraud detection on the Elliptic dataset, achieving high recall with a false positive rate under 1%, outperforming individual GNNs and baselines, and featuring a modular, quantum-ready design for future quantum integration.
AI.motivation: Blockchain networks enable value transfer but rely on pseudonymous activity, making AML enforcement challenging. There is a need for models that capture both structural and temporal dependencies while remaining robust to noise, imbalance, and adversarial behavior.
AI.method: A tuned soft voting ensemble that combines Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN), Graph Attention Networks (GAT), and Graph Isomorphism Networks (GIN) to detect illicit transactions on the Elliptic real-world dataset; the architecture is modular with quantum-ready hooks to facilitate future quantum feature mappings and quantum-classical graph neural networks.
AI.result: The ensemble achieves high recall for illicit transactions while maintaining a false positive rate below 1%, beating individual GNNs and baseline methods.
AI.conclusion: Ensemble GNNs offer a practical, forward-looking solution for real-time cryptocurrency monitoring with immediate AML utility and a pathway toward quantum-enhanced financial security analytics; the approach emphasizes scalability, robustness, and adaptability.

title: Follow-Your-Preference: Towards Preference-Aligned Image Inpainting
summary:
This paper investigates image inpainting with preference alignment. Instead
of introducing a novel method, we go back to basics and revisit fundamental
problems in achieving such alignment. We leverage the prominent direct
preference optimization approach for alignment training and employ public
reward models to construct preference training datasets. Experiments are
conducted across nine reward models, two benchmarks, and two baseline models
with varying structures and generative algorithms. Our key findings are as
follows: (1) Most reward models deliver valid reward scores for constructing
preference data, even if some of them are not reliable evaluators. (2)
Preference data demonstrates robust trends in both candidate scaling and sample
scaling across models and benchmarks. (3) Observable biases in reward models,
particularly in brightness, composition, and color scheme, render them
susceptible to cause reward hacking. (4) A simple ensemble of these models
yields robust and generalizable results by mitigating such biases. Built upon
these observations, our alignment models significantly outperform prior models
across standard metrics, GPT-4 assessments, and human evaluations, without any
changes to model structures or the use of new datasets. We hope our work can
set a simple yet solid baseline, pushing this promising frontier. Our code is
open-sourced at: https://github.com/shenytzzz/Follow-Your-Preference.

AI.tldr: A baseline alignment study for image inpainting using direct preference optimization with public reward models; demonstrates robustness via ensemble of models, outperforming prior approaches without new data or architectural changes; code released.
AI.motivation: To address reliability and biases in reward-model–driven preference data and to establish a simple, robust baseline for alignment in image inpainting.
AI.method: Construct preference datasets from nine public reward models across two benchmarks and two baseline architectures; apply direct preference optimization for alignment; evaluate individual reward models, scaling trends, biases (brightness, composition, color), and ensemble performance; validate with standard metrics, GPT-4 assessments, and human evaluators.
AI.result: Most reward models produce valid reward scores for constructing preference data; preference data shows robust scaling trends; reward biases lead to reward hacking; ensemble of models mitigates biases and yields robust, generalizable results; alignment models outperform prior models without changing architectures or new datasets; code is open-sourced.
AI.conclusion: Provides a simple, solid baseline for preference alignment in image inpainting, highlighting the value of model ensemble to counteract reward-model biases and enabling strong performance without architectural or data changes.

title: HeLoM: Hierarchical Learning for Whole-Body Loco-Manipulation in Hexapod Robot
summary:
Robots in real-world environments are often required to move/manipulate
objects comparable in weight to their own bodies. Compared to grasping and
carrying, pushing provides a more straightforward and efficient non-prehensile
manipulation strategy, avoiding complex grasp design while leveraging direct
contact to regulate an object's pose. Achieving effective pushing, however,
demands both sufficient manipulation forces and the ability to maintain
stability, which is particularly challenging when dealing with heavy or
irregular objects. To address these challenges, we propose HeLoM, a
learning-based hierarchical whole-body manipulation framework for a hexapod
robot that exploits coordinated multi-limb control. Inspired by the cooperative
strategies of multi-legged insects, our framework leverages redundant contact
points and high degrees of freedom to enable dynamic redistribution of contact
forces. HeLoM's high-level planner plans pushing behaviors and target object
poses, while its low-level controller maintains locomotion stability and
generates dynamically consistent joint actions. Our policies trained in
simulation are directly deployed on real robots without additional fine-tuning.
This design allows the robot to maintain balance while exerting continuous and
controllable pushing forces through coordinated foreleg interaction and
supportive hind-leg propulsion. We validate the effectiveness of HeLoM through
both simulation and real-world experiments. Results show that our framework can
stably push boxes of varying sizes and unknown physical properties to
designated goal poses in the real world.

AI.tldr: Introduces HeLoM, a learning-based hierarchical framework for hexapod robots that enables stable, multi-limb pushing of heavy/unknown objects to target poses, with sim-to-real transfer and no fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: In real-world settings, pushing offers a simpler, non-prehensile way to manipulate objects too heavy or awkward to grasp. Exploiting multiple contact points and coordination among limbs improves stability and force distribution, inspired by multi-legged insects.
AI.method: A two-tier system: a high-level planner selects pushing behaviors and target object poses; a low-level controller maintains locomotion stability and generates coordinated joint actions. The robot uses redundant contacts to dynamically redistribute forces, with policies trained in simulation and deployed on real hardware without additional fine-tuning.
AI.result: Simulation and real-world experiments show stable pushing of boxes of varying sizes and unknown physical properties to designated goal poses, demonstrating effective sim-to-real transfer and controlled manipulation.
AI.conclusion: The framework demonstrates the viability of hierarchical, multi-limb pushing for robust real-world manipulation, enabling heavy/object-pose control without fine-tuning, and suggesting avenues for generalization to other robots and tasks.

title: BridgeDrive: Diffusion Bridge Policy for Closed-Loop Trajectory Planning in Autonomous Driving
summary:
Diffusion-based planners have shown great promise for autonomous driving due
to their ability to capture multi-modal driving behaviors. However, guiding
these models effectively in reactive, closed-loop environments remains a
significant challenge. Simple conditioning often fails to provide sufficient
guidance in complex and dynamic driving scenarios. Recent work attempts to use
typical expert driving behaviors (i.e., anchors) to guide diffusion models but
relies on a truncated schedule, which introduces theoretical inconsistencies
and can compromise performance. To address this, we introduce BridgeDrive, a
novel anchor-guided diffusion bridge policy for closed-loop trajectory
planning. Our approach provides a principled diffusion framework that
effectively translates anchors into fine-grained trajectory plans,
appropriately responding to varying traffic conditions. Our planner is
compatible with efficient ODE solvers, a critical factor for real-time
autonomous driving deployment. We achieve state-of-the-art performance on the
Bench2Drive benchmark, improving the success rate by 5% over prior arts.

AI.tldr: BridgeDrive introduces an anchor-guided diffusion bridge policy for closed-loop trajectory planning that overcomes truncation-based guidance and enables real-time deployment with ODE solvers, achieving state-of-the-art on Bench2Drive with a ~5% improvement in success rate over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Diffusion-based planners can capture multi-modal driving behaviors but struggle to provide effective guidance in reactive, closed-loop settings. Simple conditioning often falls short in dynamic traffic; anchor-based guidance with truncated schedules brings theoretical issues and performance compromises.
AI.method: A principled diffusion bridge framework that translates high-level anchors into fine-grained trajectory plans. It supports anchor-guided diffusion without truncation, integrates with efficient ODE solvers for real-time deployment, and adjusts to varying traffic conditions.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on the Bench2Drive benchmark, with a 5% improvement in success rate over prior arts.
AI.conclusion: BridgeDrive offers a theoretically sound and practically efficient anchor-guided diffusion approach for reactive autonomous driving, improving robustness and real-time planning under dynamic traffic conditions.

title: Effective Quantization of Muon Optimizer States
summary:
The Muon optimizer, based on matrix orthogonalization, has recently shown
faster convergence and up to 2x computational efficiency over AdamW in LLM
pretraining. Like AdamW, Muon is stateful, requiring storage of both model
weights and accumulated gradients. While 8-bit AdamW variants mitigate this
overhead using blockwise quantization, they are typically stable only under
dynamic quantization - which improves stability on linear quantization for
extreme values. In this paper, we introduce the 8-bit Muon optimizer using
blockwise quantization, supporting both linear and dynamic schemes. We
demonstrate that 8-bit Muon maintains stability under both, while delivering
$\sim$74\% reduction in memory footprint compared to full-precision Muon. In
extensive experiments, 8-bit Muon closely matches the performance of Muon while
outperforming AdamW and 8-bit AdamW in pre-training a 1.6B model on 4B FineWeb
tokens. It also shows competitive results when fine-tuning the Llama 3.2 3B
model on post-training data. We also provide a theoretical perspective to help
explain this robustness under quantization.

AI.tldr: 8-bit Muon with blockwise quantization achieves near-Muon performance with ~74% memory reduction vs full-precision Muon, and outperforms AdamW and 8-bit AdamW in large-scale pretraining (1.6B model on 4B tokens) and shows competitive results for Llama 3.2 3B fine-tuning, with demonstrated stability under both linear and dynamic quantization.
AI.motivation: Reduce memory overhead and improve quantization robustness for a stateful optimizer (Muon) used in large-language-model training, addressing the fragility of 8-bit AdamW under quantization and enabling efficient 8-bit training.
AI.method: Introduce 8-bit Muon using blockwise quantization that supports both linear and dynamic quantization schemes. Analyze stability under both schemes and provide a theoretical perspective. Empirically evaluate on pretraining a 1.6B model on 4B FineWeb tokens and fine-tuning a Llama 3.2 3B model on post-training data, comparing against Muon, AdamW, and 8-bit AdamW.
AI.result: 8-bit Muon achieves ~74% memory footprint reduction compared to full-precision Muon. It maintains stability under both linear and dynamic quantization while closely matching Muon’s performance and outperforming AdamW and 8-bit AdamW in pretraining a 1.6B model on 4B tokens. It also yields competitive results for fine-tuning the Llama 3.2 3B model. The paper provides a theoretical perspective explaining robustness under quantization.
AI.conclusion: 8-bit Muon with blockwise quantization delivers quantization-robust, memory-efficient optimization for LLM training and fine-tuning, preserving Muon’s advantages while substantially reducing memory overhead; the work also contributes a theoretical explanation for observed robustness under both quantization schemes.

title: Streamline pathology foundation model by cross-magnification distillation
summary:
Foundation models (FM) have transformed computational pathology but remain
computationally prohibitive for clinical deployment due to their massive
parameter counts and high-magnification processing requirements. Here, we
introduce XMAG, a lightweight FM developed through corss-magnification
distillation that transfers knowledge from state-of-the-art 20x magnification
teacher to an efficient 5x magnification student architecture. XMAG employs a
compact backbone and operates entirely at 5x, requiring 11.3 times fewer
patches per whole slide image (WSI) compared to existing approaches. Our Novel
distillation framework incorporates dual-level knowledge transfer, aligning
both global image representations and local spatial token mapping. We trained
XMAG on 3.49 million images curated from publicly available datasets and
evaluated performance across six clinically relevant histopathology analysis
tasks spanning multiple cancer types. XMAG achieved diagnostic accuracy within
1% of substantially larger foundation models while delivering 30-fold
processing acceleration, reaching 8.8 WSIs per minute processing speed. Our
cross-institutional validation confirmed robust generalization. Further, we
developed an end-to-end training strategy to further boost our model's
performance to approach the larger FMs' performance. These results establish
cross-magnification distillation as a viable approach for deploying FM
capabilities in resource-constrained clinical environments, potentially
enabling real-time pathology AI integration.

AI.tldr: XMAG is a lightweight 5x magnification foundation model for computational pathology trained via cross-magnification distillation from a 20x teacher, achieving near-state-of-the-art accuracy with significant speedups and robust generalization.
AI.motivation: Foundation models are too resource-intensive for clinical deployment in pathology; a lower-magnification, efficient model is needed that preserves diagnostic performance.
AI.method: Cross-magnification distillation from a 20x teacher to a 5x student, with dual-level knowledge transfer (global representations and local spatial token mapping); compact backbone; operates entirely at 5x; trained on 3.49 million public images; end-to-end training strategy to boost performance.
AI.result: Achieves diagnostic accuracy within 1% of larger foundation models; ~30x processing acceleration; 8.8 WSIs per minute; uses 11.3x fewer patches per WSI; robust cross-institution generalization; end-to-end training further improves performance toward large FMs.
AI.conclusion: Cross-magnification distillation enables deploying foundation-model capabilities in resource-constrained clinical environments and could enable real-time pathology AI integration.

title: Focusing on What Matters: Object-Agent-centric Tokenization for Vision Language Action models
comment:
Presented at 9th Conference on Robot Learning (CoRL 2025), Seoul,
  Korea
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models offer a pivotal approach to learning
robotic manipulation at scale by repurposing large pre-trained
Vision-Language-Models (VLM) to output robotic actions. However, adapting VLMs
for robotic domains comes with an unnecessarily high computational cost, which
we attribute to the tokenization scheme of visual inputs. In this work, we aim
to enable efficient VLA training by proposing Oat-VLA, an Object-Agent-centric
Tokenization for VLAs. Building on the insights of object-centric
representation learning, our method introduces an inductive bias towards scene
objects and the agent's own visual information. As a result, we find that
Oat-VLA can drastically reduce the number of visual tokens to just a few tokens
without sacrificing performance. We reveal that Oat-VLA converges at least
twice as fast as OpenVLA on the LIBERO suite, as well as outperform OpenVLA in
diverse real-world pick and place tasks.

AI.tldr: Oat-VLA uses object-agent-centric tokenization to drastically reduce visual tokens, enabling faster and scalable Vision-Language-Action training with maintained performance.
AI.motivation: Adapting Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to robotic VLA tasks incurs high computational cost, largely due to visual tokenization. An efficient, object-centric representation is needed.
AI.method: Introduce Oat-VLA, an object-agent-centric tokenization scheme that biases the model toward scene objects and the agent’s own visuals, reducing visual tokens to only a few. Builds on object-centric representation learning.
AI.result: Oat-VLA converges at least twice as fast as OpenVLA on the LIBERO suite and outperforms OpenVLA in diverse real-world pick-and-place tasks.
AI.conclusion: Efficient, scalable VLA training is achievable through a principled tokenization strategy that emphasizes objects and agent visuals, with strong empirical gains on benchmarks and real tasks.

title: PSG-Agent: Personality-Aware Safety Guardrail for LLM-based Agents
summary:
Effective guardrails are essential for safely deploying LLM-based agents in
critical applications. Despite recent advances, existing guardrails suffer from
two fundamental limitations: (i) they apply uniform guardrail policies to all
users, ignoring that the same agent behavior can harm some users while being
safe for others; (ii) they check each response in isolation, missing how risks
evolve and accumulate across multiple interactions. To solve these issues, we
propose PSG-Agent, a personalized and dynamic system for LLM-based agents.
First, PSG-Agent creates personalized guardrails by mining the interaction
history for stable traits and capturing real-time states from current queries,
generating user-specific risk thresholds and protection strategies. Second,
PSG-Agent implements continuous monitoring across the agent pipeline with
specialized guards, including Plan Monitor, Tool Firewall, Response Guard,
Memory Guardian, that track cross-turn risk accumulation and issue verifiable
verdicts. Finally, we validate PSG-Agent in multiple scenarios including
healthcare, finance, and daily life automation scenarios with diverse user
profiles. It significantly outperform existing agent guardrails including
LlamaGuard3 and AGrail, providing an executable and auditable path toward
personalized safety for LLM-based agents.

AI.tldr: PSG-Agent introduces a personalized, multi-guardrail framework for LLM agents that tracks user-specific risk across turns using history-informed traits and real-time states, plus continuous monitoring via specialized guards, to outperform existing guardrails in healthcare, finance, and daily life contexts.
AI.motivation: Current guardrails treat all users identically and evaluate risks per response, ignoring cross-turn risk evolution and user-specific sensitivity. This work targets personalized safety and termination of risky trajectories across an agent’s lifecycle.
AI.method: Develop PSG-Agent with two core components: (1) Personalized guardrails derived from mining user interaction history to identify stable traits and current query states, enabling user-specific risk thresholds and protection strategies; (2) Continuous monitoring across the agent pipeline using Plan Monitor, Tool Firewall, Response Guard, and Memory Guardian to track cross-turn risk accumulation and provide verifiable verdicts.
AI.result: Empirical validation across healthcare, finance, and daily-life automation with diverse user profiles shows PSG-Agent significantly outperforms existing guardrails (e.g., LlamaGuard3, AGrail) and offers an executable, auditable pathway toward personalized safety.
AI.conclusion: PSG-Agent advances personalized safety for LLM-based agents by integrating history-informed guardrails with cross-turn monitoring, enabling more nuanced and auditable safety guarantees than uniform, per-response systems.

title: RHYTHM: Reasoning with Hierarchical Temporal Tokenization for Human Mobility
comment: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 39 (NeurIPS) 2025
summary:
Predicting human mobility is inherently challenging due to complex long-range
dependencies and multi-scale periodic behaviors. To address this, we introduce
RHYTHM (Reasoning with Hierarchical Temporal Tokenization for Human Mobility),
a unified framework that leverages large language models (LLMs) as
general-purpose spatio-temporal predictors and trajectory reasoners.
Methodologically, RHYTHM employs temporal tokenization to partition each
trajectory into daily segments and encode them as discrete tokens with
hierarchical attention that captures both daily and weekly dependencies,
thereby significantly reducing the sequence length while preserving cyclical
information. Additionally, we enrich token representations by adding
pre-computed prompt embeddings for trajectory segments and prediction targets
via a frozen LLM, and feeding these combined embeddings back into the LLM
backbone to capture complex interdependencies. Computationally, RHYTHM freezes
the pretrained LLM's backbone to reduce attention complexity and memory cost.
We evaluate our model against state-of-the-art methods using three real-world
datasets. Notably, RHYTHM achieves a 2.4% improvement in overall accuracy, a
5.0% increase on weekends, and a 24.6% reduction in training time. Code is
publicly available at https://github.com/he-h/rhythm.

AI.tldr: RHYTHM uses hierarchical temporal tokenization and frozen LLMs to forecast human mobility efficiently, achieving accuracy gains with shorter sequences and reduced training time.
AI.motivation: Human mobility has long-range dependencies and multi-scale periodicity; existing methods struggle with scalability. LLMs offer general spatio-temporal reasoning; need a framework that leverages tokens and hierarchical attention while limiting compute.
AI.method: Temporal tokenization into daily segments; hierarchical attention to capture daily/weekly patterns; augment token embeddings with pre-computed prompt embeddings from a frozen LLM; feed combined embeddings back into LLM backbone; freeze backbone to reduce attention cost; evaluate on three real-world datasets; compare to SOTA; code released.
AI.result: 2.4% improvement in overall accuracy; 5.0% improvement on weekends; 24.6% reduction in training time.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates effectiveness of RHYTHM in modeling multi-scale temporal dependencies for mobility, offering accurate and efficient predictions with LLMs and tokenization.

title: CoPatch: Zero-Shot Referring Image Segmentation by Leveraging Untapped Spatial Knowledge in CLIP
summary:
Spatial grounding is crucial for referring image segmentation (RIS), where
the goal of the task is to localize an object described by language. Current
foundational vision-language models (VLMs), such as CLIP, excel at aligning
images and text but struggle with understanding spatial relationships. Within
the language stream, most existing methods often focus on the primary noun
phrase when extracting local text features, undermining contextual tokens.
Within the vision stream, CLIP generates similar features for images with
different spatial layouts, resulting in limited sensitivity to spatial
structure. To address these limitations, we propose \textsc{CoPatch}, a
zero-shot RIS framework that leverages internal model components to enhance
spatial representations in both text and image modalities. For language,
\textsc{CoPatch} constructs hybrid text features by incorporating context
tokens carrying spatial cues. For vision, it extracts patch-level image
features using our novel path discovered from intermediate layers, where
spatial structure is better preserved. These enhanced features are fused into a
clustered image-text similarity map, \texttt{CoMap}, enabling precise mask
selection. As a result, \textsc{CoPatch} significantly improves spatial
grounding in zero-shot RIS across RefCOCO, RefCOCO+, RefCOCOg, and PhraseCut (+
2--7 mIoU) without requiring any additional training. Our findings underscore
the importance of recovering and leveraging the untapped spatial knowledge
inherently embedded in VLMs, thereby paving the way for opportunities in
zero-shot RIS.

AI.tldr: CoPatch is a zero-shot RIS framework that enhances spatial reasoning in VLMs by enriching language with spatial context tokens and by extracting patch-level image features via a novel path in intermediate layers, fusing them into a CoMap for precise mask selection, achieving +2–7 mIoU without training.
AI.motivation: Foundational VLMs excel at image-text alignment but lack robust spatial understanding: language pipelines overlook contextual tokens; vision pipelines treat spatial layout similarly across images, reducing sensitivity to spatial structure. RIS requires precise localization based on language.
AI.method: Language: build hybrid text features by incorporating context tokens carrying spatial cues. Vision: identify a path through intermediate layers to extract patch-level features that preserve spatial structure; fuse enhanced text and image features into a clustered image-text similarity map (CoMap) for mask selection.
AI.result: Achieves significant gains in zero-shot RIS on RefCOCO, RefCOCO+, RefCOCOg, and PhraseCut, with improvements of about 2–7 mIoU without additional training.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that recovering and leveraging latent spatial knowledge in VLMs can substantially improve zero-shot RIS, suggesting new directions for exploiting internal components of VLMs.

title: Certifiably Optimal State Estimation and Robot Calibration Using Trace-Constrained SDP
summary:
Many nonconvex problems in robotics can be relaxed into convex formulations
via semidefinite programming (SDP), which offers the advantage of global
optimality. The practical quality of these solutions, however, critically
depends on achieving rank-1 matrices, a condition that typically requires
additional tightening. In this work, we focus on trace-constrained SDPs, where
the decision variables are positive semidefinite (PSD) matrices with fixed
trace values. These additional constraints not only capture important
structural properties but also facilitate first-order methods for recovering
rank-1 solutions. We introduce customized fixed-trace variables and constraints
to represent common robotic quantities such as rotations and translations,
which can be exactly recovered when the corresponding variables are rank-1. To
further improve practical performance, we develop a gradient-based refinement
procedure that projects relaxed SDP solutions toward rank-1, low-cost
candidates, which can then be certified for global optimality via the dual
problem. We demonstrate that many robotics tasks can be expressed within this
trace-constrained SDP framework, and showcase its effectiveness through
simulations in perspective-n-point (PnP) estimation, hand-eye calibration, and
dual-robot system calibration. To support broader use, we also introduce a
modular ``virtual robot'' abstraction that simplifies modeling across different
problem settings.

AI.tldr: Trace-constrained semidefinite programs (SDPs) for robotics: enforce structure via fixed-trace PSD variables to recover rank-1 solutions, with gradient refinement and dual-certification; demonstrates PnP, hand-eye, and dual-robot calibration plus a modular virtual-robot modeling framework.
AI.motivation: Nonconvex robotics problems are often relaxable to SDPs, but practical usefulness hinges on achieving rank-1 solutions. Trace constraints can encode essential structure and enable efficient first-order rank-1 recovery and certification.
AI.method: Develop fixed-trace variable representations for common robotic quantities (rotations, translations); impose trace constraints to enforce PSD matrix structure; introduce a gradient-based projection refinement to steer solutions toward rank-1 candidates; certify global optimality via the dual problem; propose a modular virtual-robot abstraction to ease modeling across problems.
AI.result: Demonstrate the approach on multiple robotics tasks (PnP estimation, hand-eye calibration, and dual-robot calibration) with simulations showing improved practical performance and the ability to recover rank-1 solutions; provide a framework that generalizes across problems through the virtual-robot abstraction.
AI.conclusion: Trace-constrained SDP with fixed-trace representations and a rank-1 refinement/projection toolkit yields practically effective, globally certifiable solutions for essential robotics problems, and the modular framework supports broad adoption across problem settings.

title: Reasoning Scaffolding: Distilling the Flow of Thought from LLMs
summary:
The prevailing approach to distilling reasoning from Large Language Models
(LLMs)-behavioral cloning from textual rationales-is fundamentally limited. It
teaches Small Language Models (SLMs) to mimic surface-level patterns rather
than the underlying algorithmic structure of thought, resulting in a critical
lack of logical robustness. We argue that instead of cloning text, distillation
should transfer this algorithmic structure directly. We introduce Reasoning
Scaffolding}, a framework that reframes reasoning as a structured generation
process. Our method first abstracts the teacher's thought process into a
sequence of discrete, interpretable semantic signals (e.g., Contrast, Addition)
that act as a scaffold. The student model is then trained via a multi-task
objective to both (1)predict the next semantic signal, anticipating the
reasoning flow, and (2)generate the corresponding step, conditioned on that
signal. This multi-task scheme acts as a powerful regularizer, compelling the
student to internalize the computational patterns of coherent reasoning. On a
suite of challenging reasoning benchmarks, our method significantly outperforms
state-of-the-art distillation in both accuracy and logical consistency,
providing a path towards creating smaller models that are genuine reasoners,
not just fluent mimics.

AI.tldr: Proposes Reasoning Scaffolding to replace text-based distillation; abstracts reasoning into discrete semantic signals and trains a multi-task student to predict signals and generate steps, improving accuracy and logical consistency over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Current distillation from LLMs via textual rationales tends to mimic surface patterns rather than underlying algorithmic reasoning; there is a need to transfer the actual computational structure of thought to smaller models to achieve genuine reasoning.
AI.method: Reasoning Scaffolding framework: convert teacher reasoning into a sequence of discrete, interpretable semantic signals (e.g., Contrast, Addition); train the student with a multi-task objective to (1) predict the next semantic signal and (2) generate the corresponding step conditioned on that signal, providing a strong regularizer for internalizing reasoning patterns.
AI.result: On challenging reasoning benchmarks, the approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art distillation in accuracy and logical consistency, suggesting smaller models can become genuine reasoners rather than fluent mimics.
AI.conclusion: Shifting distillation from text to an algorithmic scaffolding of reasoning enables smaller models to reason more robustly, offering a path toward genuinely reasoning machines rather than surface-level imitators.

title: Impute-MACFM: Imputation based on Mask-Aware Flow Matching
summary:
Tabular data are central to many applications, especially longitudinal data
in healthcare, where missing values are common, undermining model fidelity and
reliability. Prior imputation methods either impose restrictive assumptions or
struggle with complex cross-feature structure, while recent generative
approaches suffer from instability and costly inference. We propose
Impute-MACFM, a mask-aware conditional flow matching framework for tabular
