imputation that addresses missingness mechanisms, missing completely at random,
missing at random, and missing not at random. Its mask-aware objective builds
trajectories only on missing entries while constraining predicted velocity to
remain near zero on observed entries, using flexible nonlinear schedules.
Impute-MACFM combines: (i) stability penalties on observed positions, (ii)
consistency regularization enforcing local invariance, and (iii) time-decayed
noise injection for numeric features. Inference uses constraint-preserving
ordinary differential equation integration with per-step projection to fix
observed values, optionally aggregating multiple trajectories for robustness.
Across diverse benchmarks, Impute-MACFM achieves state-of-the-art results while
delivering more robust, efficient, and higher-quality imputation than competing
approaches, establishing flow matching as a promising direction for tabular
missing-data problems, including longitudinal data.

AI.tldr: Impute-MACFM introduces a mask-aware conditional flow matching framework for tabular imputation that handles missing data under MCAR/MAR/MNAR using trajectories focused on missing entries, stability constraints, consistency regularization, and time-decayed noise, solved via constraint-preserving ODE integration.
AI.motivation: Missing data in tabular, especially longitudinal healthcare data, is widespread and challenging. Existing methods either rely on restrictive assumptions or struggle with cross-feature structure or instability and costly inference in generative approaches. A flexible, stable, and efficient imputation method is needed.
AI.method: The method builds on mask-aware conditional flow matching (Impute-MACFM). It constructs trajectories only on missing entries while constraining predicted velocity to be near zero on observed entries. It uses three components: (i) stability penalties on observed positions, (ii) consistency regularization enforcing local invariance, and (iii) time-decayed noise injection for numeric features. Inference uses constraint-preserving ODE integration with per-step projection to fix observed values and can aggregate multiple trajectories for robustness.
AI.result: Empirically, Impute-MACFM achieves state-of-the-art imputation results across diverse benchmarks, delivering more robust, efficient, and higher-quality imputations than competing approaches.
AI.conclusion: Flow matching is a promising direction for tabular missing-data problems, including longitudinal data, offering robust imputation under multiple missingness mechanisms with improved stability and efficiency.

title: Deep Learning for Oral Health: Benchmarking ViT, DeiT, BEiT, ConvNeXt, and Swin Transformer
summary:
Objective: The aim of this study was to systematically evaluate and compare
the performance of five state-of-the-art transformer-based architectures -
Vision Transformer (ViT), Data-efficient Image Transformer (DeiT), ConvNeXt,
Swin Transformer, and Bidirectional Encoder Representation from Image
Transformers (BEiT) - for multi-class dental disease classification. The study
specifically focused on addressing real-world challenges such as data
imbalance, which is often overlooked in existing literature.
  Study Design: The Oral Diseases dataset was used to train and validate the
selected models. Performance metrics, including validation accuracy, precision,
recall, and F1-score, were measured, with special emphasis on how well each
architecture managed imbalanced classes.
  Results: ConvNeXt achieved the highest validation accuracy at 81.06, followed
by BEiT at 80.00 and Swin Transformer at 79.73, all demonstrating strong
F1-scores. ViT and DeiT achieved accuracies of 79.37 and 78.79, respectively,
but both struggled particularly with Caries-related classes.
  Conclusions: ConvNeXt, Swin Transformer, and BEiT showed reliable diagnostic
performance, making them promising candidates for clinical application in
dental imaging. These findings provide guidance for model selection in future
AI-driven oral disease diagnostic tools and highlight the importance of
addressing data imbalance in real-world scenarios

AI.tldr: ConvNeXt, Swin Transformer, and BEiT achieve the best performance for multi-class dental disease classification on the Oral Diseases dataset, with ConvNeXt at 81.06% validation accuracy. The study highlights data imbalance as a key factor affecting model performance, especially for Caries-related classes.
AI.motivation: To systematically compare state-of-the-art transformer-based architectures for dental image classification and address real-world data imbalance challenges that are often neglected in literature.
AI.method: Train and validate five architectures (ViT, DeiT, ConvNeXt, Swin Transformer, BEiT) on the Oral Diseases dataset; evaluate accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score with explicit attention to class imbalance.
AI.result: ConvNeXt: 81.06% validation accuracy; BEiT: 80.00%; Swin Transformer: 79.73%; ViT: 79.37%; DeiT: 78.79%. All three top models show strong F1-scores; ViT and DeiT underperform on Caries-related classes.
AI.conclusion: ConvNeXt, Swin Transformer, and BEiT are reliable options for clinical dental imaging applications; model choice should consider data imbalance handling for robust performance.

title: MDCPP: Multi-robot Dynamic Coverage Path Planning for Workload Adaptation
summary:
Multi-robot Coverage Path Planning (MCPP) addresses the problem of computing
paths for multiple robots to effectively cover a large area of interest.
Conventional approaches to MCPP typically assume that robots move at fixed
velocities, which is often unrealistic in real-world applications where robots
must adapt their speeds based on the specific coverage tasks assigned to
them.Consequently, conventional approaches often lead to imbalanced workload
distribution among robots and increased completion time for coverage tasks. To
address this, we introduce a novel Multi-robot Dynamic Coverage Path Planning
(MDCPP) algorithm for complete coverage in two-dimensional environments. MDCPP
dynamically estimates each robot's remaining workload by approximating the
target distribution with Gaussian mixture models, and assigns coverage regions
using a capacity-constrained Voronoi diagram. We further develop a distributed
implementation of MDCPP for range-constrained robotic networks. Simulation
results validate the efficacy of MDCPP, showing qualitative improvements and
superior performance compared to an existing sweeping algorithm, and a
quantifiable impact of communication range on coverage efficiency.

AI.tldr: Dynamic, workload-aware MDCPP for complete 2D coverage; uses Gaussian mixture workload estimation and capacity-constrained Voronoi region assignment; distributed version handles range constraints; simulations show improvements over a sweeping baseline and reveal range impact.
AI.motivation: Conventional MCPP assumes fixed robot speeds, causing imbalanced workloads and longer completion times in real-world tasks. A dynamic approach can tailor coverage effort to each robot, improving balance and efficiency.
AI.method: Model the remaining workload with Gaussian mixture models to capture target distribution; allocate coverage regions using a capacity-constrained Voronoi diagram; develop a distributed MDCPP for range-limited robotic networks.
AI.result: Simulation results indicate qualitative improvements and superior performance compared to an existing sweeping algorithm; a measurable impact of communication range on coverage efficiency is demonstrated.
AI.conclusion: MDCPP provides a dynamic, workload-aware framework for complete coverage in 2D environments, with effective distributed implementation; performance is sensitive to communication range and outperforms fixed-velocity sweeping baselines.

title: How LLMs Learn to Reason: A Complex Network Perspective
comment:
24 pages, 11 figures, 1 table, under review as a conference paper at
  ICLR 2026
summary:
Training large language models with Reinforcement Learning from Verifiable
Rewards (RLVR) exhibits a set of distinctive and puzzling behaviors that remain
poorly understood, including a two-stage learning curve, V-shaped
response-length trajectories, and a pronounced vulnerability to catastrophic
forgetting. In this work, we propose that these seemingly disparate phenomena
can be explained using a single unifying theory: the model's reasoning process
maps to the self-organization of a semantic complex network whose topology
remains persistently sparse, with the average degree pinned close to two. This
topology imposes a fundamental mechanism for forgetting and learning: it first
drives the system into a maximally frustrated state where ``skill islands''
form, slow-learning happens, and forgetting is induced; then it enters a sharp
growth phase where the new skills are ``bolted on'', driven by
phase-transition-like learning at the web's frontier. Equipped with the theory,
we propose \textit{Annealed-RLVR}, a principled algorithm that introduces an
SFT-based ``heating'' step at the point of maximal frustration to resolve the
competitive bottleneck and enhance the reasoning capability of the model.
Experiments on a 1.5B-parameter model demonstrate that the approach outperforms
standard RLVR on both in-distribution and out-of-distribution benchmarks. By
recasting RLVR from black-box optimization into a predictable process of
structural self-organization, our work provides a new physical intuition for
engineering the emergent reasoning capabilities of future AI systems.

AI.tldr: A unified theory explains RLVR behaviors as self-organizing sparse semantic networks; introduces Annealed-RLVR with SFT heating, yielding improved reasoning and performance on 1.5B models.
AI.motivation: To explain puzzling RLVR behaviors (two-stage learning, V-shaped trajectories, catastrophic forgetting) with a single theory of semantic network self-organization and persistent sparsity.
AI.method: Proposes a model mapping reasoning to a sparse semantic complex network with average degree ~2; identifies phases: maximal frustration with skill islands and slow learning, followed by a sharp growth phase via frontier-driven phase transitions; develops Annealed-RLVR that uses an SFT-based heating step at maximal frustration to overcome bottlenecks.
AI.result: Empirical evidence on a 1.5B-parameter model showing Annealed-RLVR outperforms standard RLVR on in-distribution and out-of-distribution benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Frames RLVR as a predictable process of structural self-organization, offering a physical intuition for engineering future AI emergent reasoning capabilities; suggests annealing as a general mechanism to enhance learning under competition and forgetting.

title: C$^2$GSPG: Confidence-calibrated Group Sequence Policy Gradient towards Self-aware Reasoning
summary:
Reinforcement Learning (RL) methods, exemplified by Group Relative Policy
Optimization (GRPO) and its variants, play a central role in developing
reasoning models. However, these methods often suffer from a critical
overconfidence issue, which prevents them from achieving self-aware reasoning
models. In this study, we propose a simple yet effective confidence-calibration
group sequence policy gradient method, called C$^2$GSPG, which simultaneously
enhances reasoning performance while suppressing overconfidence. In principle,
we propose a Group Sequence Policy Gradient (GSPG) framework for learning
reasoning models, which eliminates the token-level bias commonly appearing in
GRPO and its variants. In this framework, we define the model confidence for
each reasoning problem using the normalized sequence-level probability, and
then apply a cross-entropy regularizer to calibrate the model confidence to the
sequence's reward. We demonstrate that the confidence calibration regularizer
and GSPG are collaborative for binary rewards, as their objectives always share
the same gradient direction. For non-binary rewards, we apply nonlinear reward
normalization and adaptive regularizer clipping, mitigating the potential
conflict between the two objectives. Applying C$^2$GSPG to post-train large
language models in logical and mathematical reasoning tasks, we show its
superiority over state-of-the-art methods in both reasoning accuracy and
confidence calibration. The code of C$^2$GSPG is available at
https://github.com/HaotianLiu123/CCGSPG.

AI.tldr: Proposes C^2GSPG, a confidence-calibrated Group Sequence Policy Gradient to improve reasoning accuracy while reducing overconfidence in language models.
AI.motivation: RL-based reasoning methods (e.g., GRPO) suffer from critical overconfidence, hindering self-aware reasoning; a calibration mechanism is needed.
AI.method: Introduce the Group Sequence Policy Gradient (GSPG) framework and a confidence-calibration regularizer. Define sequence-level confidence from normalized probabilities, apply a cross-entropy regularizer to align confidence with the sequence reward; for binary rewards the gradients align, for non-binary rewards use nonlinear reward normalization and adaptive regularizer clipping. Apply to post-train LLMs on logical and mathematical reasoning tasks.
AI.result: C^2GSPG shows superior reasoning accuracy and confidence calibration compared to state-of-the-art methods on logical/mathematical tasks; code is released.
AI.conclusion: Confidence-calibrated GSPG mitigates token-level bias and overconfidence, enabling more self-aware reasoning in language models; effective across binary and non-binary reward settings with appropriate normalization and clipping.

title: HTMA-Net: Towards Multiplication-Avoiding Neural Networks via Hadamard Transform and In-Memory Computing
summary:
Reducing the cost of multiplications is critical for efficient deep neural
network deployment, especially in energy-constrained edge devices. In this
work, we introduce HTMA-Net, a novel framework that integrates the Hadamard
Transform (HT) with multiplication-avoiding (MA) SRAM-based in-memory computing
to reduce arithmetic complexity while maintaining accuracy. Unlike prior
methods that only target multiplications in convolutional layers or focus
solely on in-memory acceleration, HTMA-Net selectively replaces intermediate
convolutions with Hybrid Hadamard-based transform layers whose internal
convolutions are implemented via multiplication-avoiding in-memory operations.
We evaluate HTMA-Net on ResNet-18 using CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and Tiny ImageNet,
and provide a detailed comparison against regular, MF-only, and HT-only
variants. Results show that HTMA-Net eliminates up to 52\% of multiplications
compared to baseline ResNet-18, ResNet-20, and ResNet-50 models, while
achieving comparable accuracy in evaluation and significantly reducing
computational complexity and the number of parameters. Our results demonstrate
that combining structured Hadamard transform layers with SRAM-based in-memory
computing multiplication-avoiding operators is a promising path towards
efficient deep learning architectures.

AI.tldr: HTMA-Net combines Hadamard Transform layers with multiplication-avoiding SRAM-based in-memory computing to cut multiplications by up to 52% while preserving accuracy in ResNet-18 across CIFAR-10/100 and Tiny ImageNet.
AI.motivation: To reduce the arithmetic cost of deep neural networks, especially multiplications, for energy-constrained edge devices; existing approaches often target only parts of the network or in-memory acceleration in isolation, leaving room for further gains.
AI.method: Introduce HTMA-Net that uses Hybrid Hadamard-based transform layers with internal convolutions implemented via multiplication-avoiding in-memory operations; selectively replace intermediate convolutions with HT-based transform layers integrated with MA-SRAM computing.
AI.result: Achieves up to 52% reduction in multiplications compared to baseline ResNet variants (ResNet-18, ResNet-20, ResNet-50) with comparable accuracy; reduces computational complexity and number of parameters; evaluated on ResNet-18 with CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, Tiny ImageNet and compared against regular, MF-only, and HT-only variants.
AI.conclusion: Combining structured Hadamard transform layers with SRAM-based in-memory multiplication-avoiding operators is a promising direction for efficient deep learning architectures.

title: DA-MMP: Learning Coordinated and Accurate Throwing with Dynamics-Aware Motion Manifold Primitives
summary:
Dynamic manipulation is a key capability for advancing robot performance,
enabling skills such as tossing. While recent learning-based approaches have
pushed the field forward, most methods still rely on manually designed action
parameterizations, limiting their ability to produce the highly coordinated
motions required in complex tasks. Motion planning can generate feasible
trajectories, but the dynamics gap-stemming from control inaccuracies, contact
uncertainties, and aerodynamic effects-often causes large deviations between
planned and executed trajectories. In this work, we propose Dynamics-Aware
Motion Manifold Primitives (DA-MMP), a motion generation framework for
goal-conditioned dynamic manipulation, and instantiate it on a challenging
real-world ring-tossing task. Our approach extends motion manifold primitives
to variable-length trajectories through a compact parametrization and learns a
high-quality manifold from a large-scale dataset of planned motions. Building
on this manifold, a conditional flow matching model is trained in the latent
space with a small set of real-world trials, enabling the generation of
throwing trajectories that account for execution dynamics. Experiments show
that our method can generate coordinated and smooth motion trajectories for the
ring-tossing task. In real-world evaluations, it achieves high success rates
and even surpasses the performance of trained human experts. Moreover, it
generalizes to novel targets beyond the training range, indicating that it
successfully learns the underlying trajectory-dynamics mapping.

AI.tldr: DA-MMP learns a dynamics-aware latent manifold of variable-length motions and uses conditional flow matching to generate dynamic throwing trajectories from few real trials, demonstrated on ring tossing with high success and good generalization.
AI.motivation: Current dynamic manipulation methods struggle to bridge the gap between planned trajectories and real execution due to control errors, contact uncertainties, and aerodynamic effects. Existing methods relying on hand-designed action parameterizations limit coordination for complex tasks and fail to generalize to new targets.
AI.method: Extend motion manifold primitives to variable-length trajectories using a compact parameterization. Learn a large-scale manifold from planned motions. Train a conditional flow-matching model in the latent space with a small set of real-world trials. Use this model to generate goal-conditioned throwing trajectories that compensate for execution dynamics, demonstrated on a ring-tossing task.
AI.result: The approach generates coordinated, smooth throwing trajectories, achieves high real-world success rates, and even surpasses trained human experts. It generalizes to novel targets outside the training range, indicating it captures the underlying trajectory-dynamics mapping.
AI.conclusion: DA-MMP offers a dynamics-aware framework for goal-conditioned dynamic manipulation by learning a latent trajectory manifold and a dynamics-aware generative model, yielding robust, generalizable performance in real-world tasks like ring tossing.

title: Game-Oriented ASR Error Correction via RAG-Enhanced LLM
summary:
With the rise of multiplayer online games, real-time voice communication is
essential for team coordination. However, general ASR systems struggle with
gaming-specific challenges like short phrases, rapid speech, jargon, and noise,
leading to frequent errors. To address this, we propose the GO-AEC framework,
which integrates large language models, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG),
and a data augmentation strategy using LLMs and TTS. GO-AEC includes data
augmentation, N-best hypothesis-based correction, and a dynamic game knowledge
base. Experiments show GO-AEC reduces character error rate by 6.22% and
sentence error rate by 29.71%, significantly improving ASR accuracy in gaming
scenarios.

AI.tldr: A GO-AEC framework enhances gaming ASR by combining LLMs, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and LLM/TTS-based data augmentation, plus N-best correction and a dynamic game knowledge base, achieving notable reductions in CER and SER.
AI.motivation: Real-time voice in multiplayer games is crucial for coordination, but general ASR struggles with gaming-specific challenges (short phrases, fast speech, jargon, noise). A specialized solution is needed to improve recognition accuracy in gaming scenarios.
AI.method: GO-AEC integrates large language models, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and a data augmentation strategy using LLMs and text-to-speech (TTS). It comprises data augmentation, N-best hypothesis-based correction, and a dynamic game knowledge base to adapt to gaming vocabularies and contexts.
AI.result: Experiment results show the framework reduces character error rate by 6.22% and sentence error rate by 29.71%, indicating significant improvements in ASR accuracy for gaming speech.
AI.conclusion: GO-AEC significantly improves ASR accuracy in gaming scenarios, enabling better real-time communication and team coordination in multiplayer online games.

title: Trust Region Reward Optimization and Proximal Inverse Reward Optimization Algorithm
summary:
Inverse Reinforcement Learning (IRL) learns a reward function to explain
expert demonstrations. Modern IRL methods often use the adversarial (minimax)
formulation that alternates between reward and policy optimization, which often
lead to unstable training. Recent non-adversarial IRL approaches improve
stability by jointly learning reward and policy via energy-based formulations
but lack formal guarantees. This work bridges this gap. We first present a
unified view showing canonical non-adversarial methods explicitly or implicitly
maximize the likelihood of expert behavior, which is equivalent to minimizing
the expected return gap. This insight leads to our main contribution: Trust
Region Reward Optimization (TRRO), a framework that guarantees monotonic
improvement in this likelihood via a Minorization-Maximization process. We
instantiate TRRO into Proximal Inverse Reward Optimization (PIRO), a practical
and stable IRL algorithm. Theoretically, TRRO provides the IRL counterpart to
the stability guarantees of Trust Region Policy Optimization (TRPO) in forward
RL. Empirically, PIRO matches or surpasses state-of-the-art baselines in reward
recovery, policy imitation with high sample efficiency on MuJoCo and
Gym-Robotics benchmarks and a real-world animal behavior modeling task.

AI.tldr: Introduces TRRO, a stable IRL framework with monotonic improvement guarantees, instantiated as PIRO, achieving competitive reward recovery and policy imitation with high sample efficiency on standard benchmarks and real-world tasks.
AI.motivation: Adversarial IRL methods are prone to instability during training, while non-adversarial energy-based IRL lacks formal guarantees. A unified, stable, theoretically grounded approach is needed to reliably recover rewards and imitate expert behavior.
AI.method: Shows that canonical non-adversarial IRL methods implicitly/maximize the likelihood of expert behavior (equivalently minimizing the expected return gap). Builds Trust Region Reward Optimization (TRRO) using a Minorization-Maximization (MM) scheme to guarantee monotonic likelihood improvement. Instantiates this framework as Proximal Inverse Reward Optimization (PIRO), a practical algorithm.
AI.result: TRRO provides theoretical stability guarantees analogous to TRPO in forward RL. Empirically, PIRO matches or surpasses state-of-the-art baselines in reward recovery and policy imitation with high sample efficiency on MuJoCo and Gym-Robotics benchmarks and a real-world animal behavior modeling task.
AI.conclusion: The work delivers an IRL counterpart to TRPO, offering stable, principled reward learning with practical performance gains; PIRO stands as a robust, sample-efficient IRL algorithm for complex tasks.

title: Towards Comprehensive Interactive Change Understanding in Remote Sensing: A Large-scale Dataset and Dual-granularity Enhanced VLM
summary:
Remote sensing change understanding (RSCU) is essential for analyzing remote
sensing images and understanding how human activities affect the environment.
However, existing datasets lack deep understanding and interactions in the
diverse change captioning, counting, and localization tasks. To tackle these
gaps, we construct ChangeIMTI, a new large-scale interactive multi-task
instruction dataset that encompasses four complementary tasks including change
captioning, binary change classification, change counting, and change
localization. Building upon this new dataset, we further design a novel
vision-guided vision-language model (ChangeVG) with dual-granularity awareness
for bi-temporal remote sensing images (i.e., two remote sensing images of the
same area at different times). The introduced vision-guided module is a
dual-branch architecture that synergistically combines fine-grained spatial
feature extraction with high-level semantic summarization. These enriched
representations further serve as the auxiliary prompts to guide large
vision-language models (VLMs) (e.g., Qwen2.5-VL-7B) during instruction tuning,
thereby facilitating the hierarchical cross-modal learning. We extensively
conduct experiments across four tasks to demonstrate the superiority of our
approach. Remarkably, on the change captioning task, our method outperforms the
strongest method Semantic-CC by 1.39 points on the comprehensive S*m metric,
which integrates the semantic similarity and descriptive accuracy to provide an
overall evaluation of change caption. Moreover, we also perform a series of
ablation studies to examine the critical components of our method.

AI.tldr: A new interactive multi-task dataset ChangeIMTI and a vision-guided VLM ChangeVG improve change understanding in bi-temporal remote sensing, achieving state-of-the-art on change captioning (S*m) and strong results across four tasks with ablations backing components.
AI.motivation: Existing remote sensing change datasets lack deep understanding and cross-task interaction. There is a need for models that jointly handle captioning, counting, classification, and localization on bi-temporal RS images, guided by vision-language instructions.
AI.method: Construct ChangeIMTI with four tasks: change captioning, binary change classification, change counting, and change localization. Propose ChangeVG, a dual-branch vision-guided module that fuses fine-grained spatial features with high-level semantic summarization; use these enriched representations as auxiliary prompts to guide large VLMs during instruction tuning (e.g., Qwen2.5-VL-7B) for hierarchical cross-modal learning.
AI.result: Experiments across four tasks show the method’s superiority. On change captioning, it outperforms Semantic-CC by 1.39 points on the S*m metric. Ablation studies validate the importance of the proposed components.
AI.conclusion: The ChangeIMTI dataset and ChangeVG model advance RS change understanding by enabling multi-task instruction-tuning and effective cross-modal reasoning, with dual-granularity guidance proving beneficial for vision-language models.

title: LocoFormer: Generalist Locomotion via Long-context Adaptation
summary:
Modern locomotion controllers are manually tuned for specific embodiments. We
present LocoFormer, a generalist omni-bodied locomotion model that can control
previously unseen legged and wheeled robots, even without precise knowledge of
their kinematics. LocoFormer is able to adapt to changes in morphology and
dynamics at test time. We find that two key choices enable adaptation. First,
we train massive scale RL on procedurally generated robots with aggressive
domain randomization. Second, in contrast to previous policies that are myopic
with short context lengths, we extend context by orders of magnitude to span
episode boundaries. We deploy the same LocoFormer to varied robots and show
robust control even with large disturbances such as weight change and motor
failures. In extreme scenarios, we see emergent adaptation across episodes,
LocoFormer learns from falls in early episodes to improve control strategies in
later ones. We believe that this simple, yet general recipe can be used to
train foundation models for other robotic skills in the future. Videos at
generalist-locomotion.github.io.

AI.tldr: LocoFormer is a generalist locomotion model that can control unseen legged/wheeled robots by training with large-scale RL on procedurally generated morphologies and long-context histories, enabling adaptation to morphology and dynamics changes and robustness to disturbances.
AI.motivation: Traditional locomotion controllers are manually tuned for specific embodiments, limiting generalization to new robots or changed dynamics. A generalist, adaptable controller could operate across diverse morphologies without per-robot retuning, enabling scalable robotic skills.
AI.method: Train with massive-scale reinforcement learning on procedurally generated robots using aggressive domain randomization; employ long-context representations that span episode boundaries (non-myopic context); deploy the same model to varied robots without precise kinematic knowledge; test robustness to disturbances and failures.
AI.result: LocoFormer demonstrates robust control on unseen robots, adapting to morphology and dynamics at test time; withstands large disturbances like weight changes and motor failures; exhibits emergent cross-episode adaptation where early failures improve later performance.
AI.conclusion: A simple recipe—massive-scale RL with aggressive domain randomization and substantially extended context—can train foundation-model-like locomotion capabilities transferable across robots and potentially other robotic skills.

title: From Reasoning to Answer: Empirical, Attention-Based and Mechanistic Insights into Distilled DeepSeek R1 Models
summary:
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) generate explicit reasoning traces alongside
final answers, yet the extent to which these traces influence answer generation
remains unclear. In this work, we conduct a three-stage investigation into the
interplay between reasoning and answer generation in three distilled DeepSeek
R1 models. First, through empirical evaluation, we demonstrate that including
explicit reasoning consistently improves answer quality across diverse domains.
Second, attention analysis reveals that answer tokens attend substantially to
reasoning tokens, with certain mid-layer Reasoning-Focus Heads (RFHs) closely
tracking the reasoning trajectory, including self-reflective cues. Third, we
apply mechanistic interventions using activation patching to assess the
dependence of answer tokens on reasoning activations. Our results show that
perturbations to key reasoning tokens can reliably alter the final answers,
confirming a directional and functional flow of information from reasoning to
answer. These findings deepen our understanding of how LRMs leverage reasoning
tokens for answer generation, highlighting the functional role of intermediate
reasoning in shaping model outputs. Our data and code are publicly available at
\href{https://aka.ms/R2A-code}{this URL}.

AI.tldr: Explicit intermediate reasoning in large reasoning models causally shapes final answers; a three-stage study shows improved answer quality, attentive use of reasoning traces, and causal influence via activation interventions.
AI.motivation: To understand whether and how intermediate reasoning traces contribute to answer generation in LRMs, addressing whether reasoning tokens are functionally used rather than merely displayed.
AI.method: Three-stage approach: (1) empirical evaluation across diverse domains using distilled DeepSeek R1 models to compare answers with/without explicit reasoning; (2) analysis of attention patterns showing answer tokens attending to reasoning tokens and tracking Reasoning-Focus Heads (RFHs) that reflect the reasoning trajectory, including self-reflection cues; (3) mechanistic interventions via activation patching to perturb reasoning activations and observe effects on answers.
AI.result: Including explicit reasoning consistently improves answer quality; answer tokens show strong attention to reasoning tokens; RFHs track the reasoning path, including self-reflective signals; perturbing key reasoning tokens via activation patching reliably alters final answers, indicating a directional information flow from reasoning to answer.
AI.conclusion: Intermediate reasoning plays a functional role in shaping outputs of LRMs; the findings advance understanding of how reasoning traces influence answer generation; data and code are publicly available.

title: Beyond Heuristics: Globally Optimal Configuration of Implicit Neural Representations
summary:
Implicit Neural Representations (INRs) have emerged as a transformative
paradigm in signal processing and computer vision, excelling in tasks from
image reconstruction to 3D shape modeling. Yet their effectiveness is
fundamentally limited by the absence of principled strategies for optimal
configuration - spanning activation selection, initialization scales,
layer-wise adaptation, and their intricate interdependencies. These choices
dictate performance, stability, and generalization, but current practice relies
on ad-hoc heuristics, brute-force grid searches, or task-specific tuning, often
leading to inconsistent results across modalities. This work introduces
OptiINR, the first unified framework that formulates INR configuration as a
rigorous optimization problem. Leveraging Bayesian optimization, OptiINR
efficiently explores the joint space of discrete activation families - such as
sinusoidal (SIREN), wavelet-based (WIRE), and variable-periodic (FINER) - and
their associated continuous initialization parameters. This systematic approach
replaces fragmented manual tuning with a coherent, data-driven optimization
process. By delivering globally optimal configurations, OptiINR establishes a
principled foundation for INR design, consistently maximizing performance
across diverse signal processing applications.

AI.tldr: OptiINR formulates INR configuration as a Bayesian optimization problem over a discrete set of activation families (SIREN, WIRE, FINER) and their continuous initialization parameters to maximize performance across signal-processing tasks, providing a unified, data-driven tuning framework for INRs.
AI.motivation: INRs are powerful but their performance hinges on manual, ad-hoc choices for activations, initialization scales, and layer settings, causing instability and poor cross-task generalization. A principled, automated approach is lacking.
AI.method: Apply Bayesian optimization to jointly search discrete activation families and continuous initialization hyperparameters, across a joint space that captures interdependencies; compare performance across diverse tasks to identify globally optimal configurations.
AI.result: A unified optimization framework that yields globally optimal INR configurations, improving performance and consistency across modalities; demonstrates principled, data-driven design over ad-hoc tuning.
AI.conclusion: OptiINR provides a principled foundation for INR design, enabling robust, cross-task generalization; it can accommodate additional activations and hyperparameters and reduces manual tuning burden.

title: Stochastic Interpolants via Conditional Dependent Coupling
summary:
Existing image generation models face critical challenges regarding the
trade-off between computation and fidelity. Specifically, models relying on a
pretrained Variational Autoencoder (VAE) suffer from information loss, limited
detail, and the inability to support end-to-end training. In contrast, models
operating directly in the pixel space incur prohibitive computational cost.
Although cascade models can mitigate computational cost, stage-wise separation
prevents effective end-to-end optimization, hampers knowledge sharing, and
often results in inaccurate distribution learning within each stage. To address
these challenges, we introduce a unified multistage generative framework based
on our proposed Conditional Dependent Coupling strategy. It decomposes the
generative process into interpolant trajectories at multiple stages, ensuring
accurate distribution learning while enabling end-to-end optimization.
Importantly, the entire process is modeled as a single unified Diffusion
Transformer, eliminating the need for disjoint modules and also enabling
knowledge sharing. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves
both high fidelity and efficiency across multiple resolutions.

AI.tldr: Unified multistage diffusion framework using Conditional Dependent Coupling and a single Diffusion Transformer to enable end-to-end optimization across resolutions, achieving high fidelity and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Current image generation approaches face a trade-off between computation and fidelity. VAE-based methods suffer information loss and limited detail; pixel-space methods are computationally expensive; cascade/multi-stage models hinder end-to-end optimization and knowledge sharing.
AI.method: Introduce Conditional Dependent Coupling to decompose generation into interpolant trajectories across multiple stages, and model the entire process as a single unified Diffusion Transformer, eliminating disjoint modules and enabling end-to-end optimization and knowledge sharing.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate high fidelity and efficiency across multiple resolutions.
AI.conclusion: The framework addresses the computation–fidelity trade-off, enabling end-to-end training and unified modeling with strong performance across resolutions.

title: Sequence Pathfinder for Multi-Agent Pickup and Delivery in the Warehouse
summary:
Multi-Agent Pickup and Delivery (MAPD) is a challenging extension of
Multi-Agent Path Finding (MAPF), where agents are required to sequentially
complete tasks with fixed-location pickup and delivery demands. Although
learning-based methods have made progress in MAPD, they often perform poorly in
warehouse-like environments with narrow pathways and long corridors when
relying only on local observations for distributed decision-making.
Communication learning can alleviate the lack of global information but
introduce high computational complexity due to point-to-point communication. To
address this challenge, we formulate MAPF as a sequence modeling problem and
prove that path-finding policies under sequence modeling possess
order-invariant optimality, ensuring its effectiveness in MAPD. Building on
this, we propose the Sequential Pathfinder (SePar), which leverages the
Transformer paradigm to achieve implicit information exchange, reducing
decision-making complexity from exponential to linear while maintaining
efficiency and global awareness. Experiments demonstrate that SePar
consistently outperforms existing learning-based methods across various MAPF
tasks and their variants, and generalizes well to unseen environments.
Furthermore, we highlight the necessity of integrating imitation learning in
complex maps like warehouses.

AI.tldr: Reframes MAPF as a sequence modeling problem and introduces SePar, a Transformer-based planner that enables implicit communication, achieving linear rather than exponential decision complexity and outperforming prior learning-based MAPF methods with strong generalization; highlights imitation learning as important in warehouses.
AI.motivation: MAPD/MAPF tasks suffer from local observation limits and expensive, non-scalable communication; there is a need for globally aware, scalable coordination that remains efficient in narrow, warehouse-like environments.
AI.method: Proves order-invariant optimality for path-finding policies under sequence modeling and builds SePar using Transformer architecture to enable implicit information exchange, reducing decision-making complexity from exponential to linear while maintaining global awareness.
AI.result: Empirical results show SePar consistently outperforms existing learning-based methods across MAPF tasks and variants and generalizes to unseen environments; underlines the importance of incorporating imitation learning for complex maps like warehouses.
AI.conclusion: Sequence-modeling-based path finding is a viable and scalable approach for MAPF/MAPD; SePar provides a practical framework leveraging Transformers for global coordination with lower computational costs, and imitation learning enhances performance in challenging maps.

title: SafeSearch: Automated Red-Teaming for the Safety of LLM-Based Search Agents
summary:
Search agents connect LLMs to the Internet, enabling access to broader and
more up-to-date information. However, unreliable search results may also pose
safety threats to end users, establishing a new threat surface. In this work,
we conduct two in-the-wild experiments to demonstrate both the prevalence of
low-quality search results and their potential to misguide agent behaviors. To
counter this threat, we introduce an automated red-teaming framework that is
systematic, scalable, and cost-efficient, enabling lightweight and harmless
safety assessments of search agents. Building on this framework, we construct
the SafeSearch benchmark, which includes 300 test cases covering five
categories of risks (e.g., misinformation and indirect prompt injection). Using
this benchmark, we evaluate three representative search agent scaffolds,
covering search workflow, tool-calling, and deep research, across 7 proprietary
and 8 open-source backend LLMs. Our results reveal substantial vulnerabilities
of LLM-based search agents: when exposed to unreliable websites, the highest
ASR reached 90.5% for GPT-4.1-mini under a search workflow setting. Moreover,
our analysis highlights the limited effectiveness of common defense practices,
such as reminder prompting. This emphasizes the value of our framework in
promoting transparency for safer agent development. Our codebase and test cases
are publicly available: https://github.com/jianshuod/SafeSearch.

AI.tldr: SafeSearch introduces an automated red-teaming framework and a 300-case benchmark to assess and improve safety of LLM-powered search agents; results show high vulnerability to unreliable search results and limited defense effectiveness.
AI.motivation: Integrating LLMs with web search expands access to information but opens new safety threat surface from low-quality results; need scalable, transparent evaluation to guide safer agent development.
AI.method: Two in-the-wild experiments; develop automated red-teaming framework; construct SafeSearch benchmark with 300 test cases across five risk categories; evaluate three search scaffolds across 7 proprietary and 8 open-source LLM backends.
AI.result: Substantial vulnerabilities observed; highest ASR 90.5% (GPT-4.1-mini under a search workflow). Reminder prompting and common defenses underperform; SafeSearch enables transparent safety assessment; code and test cases released.
AI.conclusion: The framework and benchmark can promote safer agent development by exposing failure modes and guiding defense improvements; broad evaluation reveals limitations of current mitigation strategies; encourages ongoing safety testing.

title: TimeExpert: Boosting Long Time Series Forecasting with Temporal Mix of Experts
summary:
Transformer-based architectures dominate time series modeling by enabling
global attention over all timestamps, yet their rigid 'one-size-fits-all'
context aggregation fails to address two critical challenges in real-world
data: (1) inherent lag effects, where the relevance of historical timestamps to
a query varies dynamically; (2) anomalous segments, which introduce noisy
signals that degrade forecasting accuracy. To resolve these problems, we
propose the Temporal Mix of Experts (TMOE), a novel attention-level mechanism
that reimagines key-value (K-V) pairs as local experts (each specialized in a
distinct temporal context) and performs adaptive expert selection for each
query via localized filtering of irrelevant timestamps. Complementing this
local adaptation, a shared global expert preserves the Transformer's strength
in capturing long-range dependencies. We then replace the vanilla attention
mechanism in popular time-series Transformer frameworks (i.e., PatchTST and
Timer) with TMOE, without extra structural modifications, yielding our specific
version TimeExpert and general version TimeExpert-G. Extensive experiments on
seven real-world long-term forecasting benchmarks demonstrate that TimeExpert
and TimeExpert-G outperform state-of-the-art methods. Code is available at
https://github.com/xwmaxwma/TimeExpert.

AI.tldr: TimeExpert introduces Temporal Mix of Experts (TMOE), replacing vanilla attention with local K-V experts plus a global expert for time-series Transformers, achieving state-of-the-art long-term forecasting (TimeExpert and TimeExpert-G) on seven benchmarks; code released.
AI.motivation: To address two real-world issues in time-series data: (1) lag effects where historical relevance varies over time, and (2) anomalous segments that inject noisy signals. Global self-attention is rigid and can overlook dynamic relevance patterns and noise.
AI.method: Replace standard attention with Temporal Mix of Experts: local K-V pairs act as specialized experts in distinct temporal contexts; adaptive expert selection per query via filtering of relevant timestamps; a shared global expert captures long-range dependencies. Implemented by substituting vanilla attention in PatchTST and Timer to yield TimeExpert (specific) and TimeExpert-G (general).
AI.result: Comprehensive experiments on seven real-world long-term forecasting benchmarks show that TimeExpert and TimeExpert-G surpass state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: The proposed local-expert plus global-expert attention framework effectively handles lag dynamics and anomalous segments in time-series forecasting, delivering improved accuracy without extra architectural changes; code is publicly available.

title: Benchmarking DINOv3 for Multi-Task Stroke Analysis on Non-Contrast CT
summary:
Non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) is essential for rapid stroke
diagnosis but is limited by low image contrast and signal to noise ratio. We
address this challenge by leveraging DINOv3, a state-of-the-art self-supervised
vision transformer, to generate powerful feature representations for a
comprehensive set of stroke analysis tasks. Our evaluation encompasses infarct
and hemorrhage segmentation, anomaly classification (normal vs. stroke and
normal vs. infarct vs. hemorrhage), hemorrhage subtype classification (EDH,
SDH, SAH, IPH, IVH), and dichotomized ASPECTS classification (<=6 vs. >6) on
multiple public and private datasets. This study establishes strong benchmarks
for these tasks and demonstrates the potential of advanced self-supervised
models to improve automated stroke diagnosis from NCCT, providing a clear
analysis of both the advantages and current constraints of the approach. The
code is available at https://github.com/Zzz0251/DINOv3-stroke.

AI.tldr: A self-supervised DINOv3-based framework for NCCT stroke analysis achieving strong benchmarks across segmentation, classification, and ASPECTS tasks on multiple datasets; code released.
AI.motivation: NCCT-based stroke diagnosis suffers from low contrast and noise. Leveraging self-supervised DINOv3 aims to learn robust feature representations without heavy labeling, enabling multiple analytical tasks.
AI.method: Utilize DINOv3 vision transformer to extract features from NCCT and apply them to infarct/hemorrhage segmentation, anomaly classification (normal vs. stroke; normal vs. infarct vs. hemorrhage), hemorrhage subtype classification (EDH, SDH, SAH, IPH, IVH), and dichotomized ASPECTS (≤6 vs >6). Evaluated on multiple public and private datasets; benchmarks established; code available at the cited GitHub repository.
AI.result: The study establishes strong benchmarks across the targeted tasks, demonstrating the potential of advanced self-supervised models to improve automated stroke diagnosis from NCCT. It also provides a critical analysis of advantages and current limitations of the approach.
AI.conclusion: DINOv3-based self-supervised representations show promise for rapid, automated stroke assessment from NCCT. While encouraging, the approach has current constraints that warrant further investigation to facilitate clinical deployment; code is released for reproducibility.

title: High-Precision Climbing Robot Localization Using Planar Array UWB/GPS/IMU/Barometer Integration
summary:
To address the need for high-precision localization of climbing robots in
complex high-altitude environments, this paper proposes a multi-sensor fusion
system that overcomes the limitations of single-sensor approaches. Firstly, the
localization scenarios and the problem model are analyzed. An integrated
architecture of Attention Mechanism-based Fusion Algorithm (AMFA) incorporating
planar array Ultra-Wideband (UWB), GPS, Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), and
barometer is designed to handle challenges such as GPS occlusion and UWB
Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) problem. Then, End-to-end neural network inference
models for UWB and barometer are developed, along with a multimodal attention
mechanism for adaptive data fusion. An Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) is applied
to refine the trajectory, improving accuracy and robustness. Finally,
real-world experiments show that the method achieves 0.48 m localization
accuracy and lower MAX error of 1.50 m, outperforming baseline algorithms such
as GPS/INS-EKF and demonstrating stronger robustness.

AI.tldr: A multi-sensor fusion framework (AMFA) for high-precision localization of climbing robots in challenging high-altitude environments, combining UWB, GPS, IMU, and barometer with end-to-end networks and UKF; shows 0.48 m accuracy, MAX error 1.50 m, outperforming GPS/INS-EKF.
AI.motivation: Need for accurate, robust localization under GPS occlusion and UWB NLOS in high-altitude/climbing scenarios.
AI.method: Proposes Attention Mechanism-based Fusion Algorithm (AMFA) integrating planar array UWB, GPS, IMU, and barometer; develops end-to-end neural networks for UWB and barometer; uses a multimodal attention mechanism for adaptive fusion; refines trajectory with Unscented Kalman Filter.
AI.result: Real-world experiments show localization accuracy of 0.48 m and maximum error 1.50 m, outperforming GPS/INS-EKF and demonstrating robustness.
AI.conclusion: The AMFA-based multi-sensor fusion framework improves accuracy and robustness for high-precision localization in challenging environments and is suitable for climbing robot navigation; demonstrates potential for deployment in GPS-compromised scenarios.

title: Measuring Sparse Autoencoder Feature Sensitivity
comment: NeurIPS 2025 Workshop on Mechanistic Interpretability Camera Ready
summary:
Sparse Autoencoder (SAE) features have become essential tools for mechanistic
interpretability research. SAE features are typically characterized by
examining their activating examples, which are often "monosemantic" and align
with human interpretable concepts. However, these examples don't reveal feature
sensitivity: how reliably a feature activates on texts similar to its
activating examples. In this work, we develop a scalable method to evaluate
feature sensitivity. Our approach avoids the need to generate natural language
descriptions for features; instead we use language models to generate text with
the same semantic properties as a feature's activating examples. We then test
whether the feature activates on these generated texts. We demonstrate that
sensitivity measures a new facet of feature quality and find that many
interpretable features have poor sensitivity. Human evaluation confirms that
when features fail to activate on our generated text, that text genuinely
resembles the original activating examples. Lastly, we study feature
sensitivity at the SAE level and observe that average feature sensitivity
declines with increasing SAE width across 7 SAE variants. Our work establishes
feature sensitivity as a new dimension for evaluating both individual features
and SAE architectures.

AI.tldr: Proposes a scalable, language-model-based method to measure feature sensitivity in Sparse Autoencoder (SAE) features, revealing sensitivity as a distinct quality metric; many features show poor sensitivity, and SAE width deterioration lowers average sensitivity across 7 variants.
AI.motivation: Current analyses of SAE features rely on activating examples and qualitative interpretation, but do not quantify how reliably a feature activates on texts similar to its activating examples. The work introduces a scalable method to assess this sensitivity and to evaluate SAE architectures.
AI.method: For each SAE feature, use a language model to generate text with the same semantic properties as the feature's activating examples. Test whether the feature activates on these generated texts (without producing natural-language descriptions). Assess sensitivity at the feature level and across 7 SAE variants; include human evaluation confirming resemblance between generated texts and original examples.
AI.result: Feature sensitivity emerges as a distinct quality metric. Many interpretable features exhibit poor sensitivity. Human evaluation supports that non-activating generated texts resemble the original activating examples. Across 7 SAE variants, average feature sensitivity declines as SAE width increases.
AI.conclusion: Feature sensitivity should be considered a new dimension for evaluating both individual SAE features and SAE architectures, influencing how we interpret interpretability and guide SAE design.

title: Critique to Verify: Accurate and Honest Test-Time Scaling with RL-Trained Verifiers
summary:
Test-time scaling via solution sampling and aggregation has become a key
paradigm for improving the reasoning performance of Large Language Models
(LLMs). While reward model selection is commonly employed in this approach, it
often fails to identify minority-yet-correct answers, which limits its
effectiveness beyond that of simple majority voting. We argue that this
limitation stems from a lack of informative critique signals during verifier
training. To bridge this gap, we introduce Mirror-Critique, a framework that
trains a verifier with informative critiques. Our key insight is to leverage
the rich critique signal by contrasting model-generated solutions with
ground-truth solutions. We deploy a small instruction-tuned model to synthesize
high-quality critique data with rejection sampling that teaches the verifier
not only what is wrong, but also why. The synthetic data is used to cold-start
the LLMs in the RLVR process to further improve the verification ability. The
resulting Mirror-Verifier is deployed to evaluate candidate solutions by
generating multiple critiques per solution, aggregating them into a verify
score used for weighted voting or selective abstention. The experimental
results show that our Mirror-Verifier significantly outperforms majority voting
in terms of solution accuracy and also improves the solver's honesty to
recognize and abstain from answering beyond its capability boundaries.

AI.tldr: Mirror-Critique enhances verifier with informative critiques to improve RLVR solution verification, using ground-truth contrasts and synthetic critique data to outperform majority voting and enable abstention.
AI.motivation: Current reward-model based verification in test-time scaling often relies on majority voting and fails to identify minority-correct answers due to a lack of informative critique signals during verifier training. Richer critique signals are needed to improve evaluation of candidate solutions.
AI.method: Train a verifier with informative critiques by contrasting model-generated solutions with ground-truth solutions. Use a small instruction-tuned model to synthesize high-quality critique data via rejection sampling, teaching the verifier not only what is wrong, but why. Use the synthetic data to cold-start RLVR. Mirror-Verifier then generates multiple critiques per solution and aggregates them into a verify score for weighted voting or selective abstention.
AI.result: Mirror-Verifier significantly outperforms majority voting in solution accuracy and improves the solver's honesty, enabling abstention from answering beyond its capability boundaries.
AI.conclusion: Informative critique signals enable more reliable verification in RLVR; Mirror-Critique provides a practical approach to train verifiers with richer guidance, likely improving robustness and trust in LLM reasoning across tasks.

title: Earth-Agent: Unlocking the Full Landscape of Earth Observation with Agents
summary:
Earth observation (EO) is essential for understanding the evolving states of
the Earth system. Although recent MLLMs have advanced EO research, they still
lack the capability to tackle complex tasks that require multi-step reasoning
and the use of domain-specific tools. Agent-based methods offer a promising
direction, but current attempts remain in their infancy, confined to RGB
perception, shallow reasoning, and lacking systematic evaluation protocols. To
overcome these limitations, we introduce Earth-Agent, the first agentic
framework that unifies RGB and spectral EO data within an MCP-based tool
ecosystem, enabling cross-modal, multi-step, and quantitative spatiotemporal
reasoning beyond pretrained MLLMs. Earth-Agent supports complex scientific
tasks such as geophysical parameter retrieval and quantitative spatiotemporal
analysis by dynamically invoking expert tools and models across modalities. To
support comprehensive evaluation, we further propose Earth-Bench, a benchmark
of 248 expert-curated tasks with 13,729 images, spanning spectrum, products and
RGB modalities, and equipped with a dual-level evaluation protocol that
assesses both reasoning trajectories and final outcomes. We conduct
comprehensive experiments varying different LLM backbones, comparisons with
general agent frameworks, and comparisons with MLLMs on remote sensing
benchmarks, demonstrating both the effectiveness and potential of Earth-Agent.
Earth-Agent establishes a new paradigm for EO analysis, moving the field toward
scientifically grounded, next-generation applications of LLMs in Earth
observation. Our code and dataset will be publicly released.

AI.tldr: Earth-Agent unifies RGB and spectral EO data within an MCP-based tool ecosystem to enable cross-modal, multi-step, quantitative spatiotemporal reasoning; introduces Earth-Bench with 248 tasks and 13,729 images; demonstrates effectiveness and potential over baselines; code/dataset to be released.
AI.motivation: Current MLLMs struggle with complex, multi-step EO tasks and tool use; agent-based methods are underdeveloped (RGB-only, shallow reasoning) and lack systematic evaluation.
AI.method: Proposes Earth-Agent, the first agentic framework unifying RGB and spectral EO data in an MCP-based tool ecosystem to dynamically invoke expert tools/models across modalities for complex tasks (e.g., geophysical parameter retrieval, spatiotemporal analysis). Introduces Earth-Bench, a benchmark of 248 expert-curated tasks over 13,729 images spanning spectrum, products, and RGB modalities, with a dual-level evaluation protocol (reasoning trajectories and final outcomes). Conducts experiments varying LLM backbones and comparing against general agent frameworks and MLLMs on remote sensing benchmarks.
AI.result: Demonstrates effectiveness and potential of Earth-Agent; shows improved cross-modal reasoning and quantitative spatiotemporal analysis; robust evaluation across backbones and baselines; supports released code/dataset.
AI.conclusion: Earth-Agent establishes a new paradigm for EO analysis, enabling scientifically grounded, next-generation LLM-based Earth observation applications; code and dataset will be publicly released.

title: Fostering Robots: A Governance-First Conceptual Framework for Domestic, Curriculum-Based Trajectory Collection
summary:
We propose a conceptual, empirically testable framework for Robot Fostering,
-a curriculum-driven, governance-first approach to domestic robot deployments,
emphasizing long-term, curated interaction trajectories. We formalize
trajectory quality with quantifiable metrics and evaluation protocols aligned
with EU-grade governance standards, delineating a low-resource empirical
roadmap to enable rigorous validation through future pilot studies.

AI.tldr: A conceptual, empirically testable framework for Robot Fostering that integrates curriculum-driven deployment and governance-first practices, with quantifiable trajectory-quality metrics and EU-aligned evaluation protocols, plus a low-resource roadmap for future pilot validation.
AI.motivation: Addresses the need for responsible, long-term domestic robot deployments that are governed and testable, ensuring safe, ethical, and effective interaction trajectories aligned with policy standards.
AI.method: Formalizes trajectory quality via measurable metrics and evaluation protocols within a governance-first, curriculum-driven framework; specifies EU-grade governance alignment and outlines a low-resource empirical roadmap to enable rigorous validation through future pilot studies.
AI.result: Proposal of a framework and metrics, with a plan for empirical validation but no reported empirical results yet.
AI.conclusion: If adopted, the framework could enable rigorous, governance-compliant evaluation of domestic robot fostering and support scalable long-term deployment strategies.

title: MedLA: A Logic-Driven Multi-Agent Framework for Complex Medical Reasoning with Large Language Models
summary:
Answering complex medical questions requires not only domain expertise and
patient-specific information, but also structured and multi-perspective
reasoning. Existing multi-agent approaches often rely on fixed roles or shallow
interaction prompts, limiting their ability to detect and resolve fine-grained
logical inconsistencies. To address this, we propose \textsc{MedLA}, a
logic-driven multi-agent framework built on large language models. Each agent
organizes its reasoning process into an explicit logical tree based on
syllogistic triads (major premise, minor premise, and conclusion), enabling
transparent inference and premise-level alignment. Agents engage in a
multi-round, graph-guided discussion to compare and iteratively refine their
logic trees, achieving consensus through error correction and contradiction
resolution. We demonstrate that \textsc{MedLA} consistently outperforms both
static role-based systems and single-agent baselines on challenging benchmarks
such as MedDDx and standard medical QA tasks. Furthermore, \textsc{MedLA}
scales effectively across both open-source and commercial LLM backbones,
achieving state-of-the-art performance and offering a generalizable paradigm
for trustworthy medical reasoning.

AI.tldr: MedLA is a logic-driven multi-agent framework for medical reasoning that uses explicit syllogistic trees and graph-guided dialogue to detect and resolve inconsistencies, achieving stronger performance and scalability across LLM backbones.
AI.motivation: Current multi-agent medical reasoning systems rely on fixed roles or shallow prompts, which hinder detection of fine-grained logical contradictions and undermine trust in answers. There is a need for transparent, premise-level reasoning and robust consensus mechanisms.
AI.method: Each agent constructs a reasoning tree using syllogistic triads (major premise, minor premise, conclusion). Agents engage in multi-round, graph-guided discussions to compare and refine trees, perform error correction and contradiction resolution, and reach consensus. The framework is demonstrated across MedDDx and standard medical QA tasks and scales across open-source and commercial LLMs.
AI.result: MedLA outperforms static role-based systems and single-agent baselines on MedDDx and standard medical QA tasks. It scales across different LLM backbones and achieves state-of-the-art performance, enabling trustworthy medical reasoning.
AI.conclusion: MedLA provides a transparent, scalable paradigm for medical reasoning with premise-level alignment and contradiction resolution, generalizable across models and tasks.

title: CrystalGym: A New Benchmark for Materials Discovery Using Reinforcement Learning
summary:
In silico design and optimization of new materials primarily relies on
high-accuracy atomic simulators that perform density functional theory (DFT)
calculations. While recent works showcase the strong potential of machine
learning to accelerate the material design process, they mostly consist of
generative approaches that do not use direct DFT signals as feedback to improve
training and generation mainly due to DFT's high computational cost. To aid the
adoption of direct DFT signals in the materials design loop through online
reinforcement learning (RL), we propose CrystalGym, an open-source RL
environment for crystalline material discovery. Using CrystalGym, we benchmark
common value- and policy-based reinforcement learning algorithms for designing
various crystals conditioned on target properties. Concretely, we optimize for
challenging properties like the band gap, bulk modulus, and density, which are
directly calculated from DFT in the environment. While none of the algorithms
we benchmark solve all CrystalGym tasks, our extensive experiments and
ablations show different sample efficiencies and ease of convergence to
optimality for different algorithms and environment settings. Additionally, we
include a case study on the scope of fine-tuning large language models with
reinforcement learning for improving DFT-based rewards. Our goal is for
CrystalGym to serve as a test bed for reinforcement learning researchers and
material scientists to address these real-world design problems with practical
applications. We therefore introduce a novel class of challenges for
reinforcement learning methods dealing with time-consuming reward signals,
paving the way for future interdisciplinary research for machine learning
motivated by real-world applications.

AI.tldr: Proposes CrystalGym, an open-source RL environment for discovering crystalline materials using direct DFT-derived rewards, and benchmarks RL algorithms to handle expensive, time-consuming feedback in material design.
AI.motivation: Current ML in materials design relies heavily on costly DFT signals and mostly usesGenerative models without direct DFT feedback. There is a need for online reinforcement learning that can leverage direct DFT rewards to accelerate design.
AI.method: Introduce CrystalGym environment where properties such as band gap, bulk modulus, and density are computed via DFT as the reward signal. Benchmark multiple value- and policy-based RL algorithms on crystal design tasks conditioned on target properties. Include a case study on fine-tuning large language models with reinforcement learning to improve DFT-based rewards.
AI.result: Different RL algorithms show varying sample efficiency and convergence across tasks; no single method solves all CrystalGym tasks; ablations reveal the impact of environment settings on learning. The framework serves as a test bed for RL researchers and materials scientists to study time-consuming rewards.
AI.conclusion: CrystalGym provides a practical platform to study RL for real-world, DFT-driven materials design, highlighting challenges associated with expensive rewards and enabling interdisciplinary research at the intersection of ML and materials science.

title: WeatherCycle: Unpaired Multi-Weather Restoration via Color Space Decoupled Cycle Learning
summary:
Unsupervised image restoration under multi-weather conditions remains a
fundamental yet underexplored challenge. While existing methods often rely on
task-specific physical priors, their narrow focus limits scalability and
generalization to diverse real-world weather scenarios. In this work, we
propose \textbf{WeatherCycle}, a unified unpaired framework that reformulates
weather restoration as a bidirectional degradation-content translation cycle,
guided by degradation-aware curriculum regularization. At its core,
WeatherCycle employs a \textit{lumina-chroma decomposition} strategy to
decouple degradation from content without modeling complex weather, enabling
domain conversion between degraded and clean images. To model diverse and
complex degradations, we propose a \textit{Lumina Degradation Guidance Module}
(LDGM), which learns luminance degradation priors from a degraded image pool
and injects them into clean images via frequency-domain amplitude modulation,
enabling controllable and realistic degradation modeling. Additionally, we
incorporate a \textit{Difficulty-Aware Contrastive Regularization (DACR)}
module that identifies hard samples via a CLIP-based classifier and enforces
contrastive alignment between hard samples and restored features to enhance
semantic consistency and robustness. Extensive experiments across serve
multi-weather datasets, demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art
performance among unsupervised approaches, with strong generalization to
complex weather degradations.

AI.tldr: WeatherCycle offers a unified unsupervised restoration framework for multi-weather images via bidirectional degradation-content translation. It uses lumina-chroma decomposition to separate degradation from content, a Lumina Degradation Guidance Module to inject luminance priors through frequency-domain modulation, and a Difficulty-Aware Contrastive Regularization to enforce semantic consistency on hard samples. It achieves state-of-the-art results among unsupervised methods with strong generalization to complex degradations.
AI.motivation: Unsupervised image restoration under diverse weather is challenging; current methods rely on task-specific priors and struggle to generalize across varied real-world conditions. A unified framework that can model multiple degradations without paired data is highly desirable.
AI.method: 1) Reformulate restoration as a bidirectional degradation-content translation cycle. 2) Use lumina-chroma decomposition to decouple degradation from content without explicit weather modeling. 3) Introduce Lumina Degradation Guidance Module (LDGM) to learn luminance degradation priors from degraded image pools and inject them into clean images via frequency-domain amplitude modulation. 4) Incorporate Difficulty-Aware Contrastive Regularization (DACR) to identify hard samples (via a CLIP-based classifier) and enforce contrastive alignment between hard samples and restored features.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multi-weather datasets show WeatherCycle achieves state-of-the-art performance among unsupervised approaches and generalizes well to complex weather degradations.
AI.conclusion: WeatherCycle provides a scalable, unified unsupervised restoration framework that leverages decomposition, degradation guidance, and contrastive regularization to handle diverse weather degradations with strong performance and generalization.

title: Control Your Robot: A Unified System for Robot Control and Policy Deployment
summary:
Cross-platform robot control remains difficult because hardware interfaces,
data formats, and control paradigms vary widely, which fragments toolchains and
slows deployment. To address this, we present Control Your Robot, a modular,
general-purpose framework that unifies data collection and policy deployment
across diverse platforms. The system reduces fragmentation through a
standardized workflow with modular design, unified APIs, and a closed-loop
architecture. It supports flexible robot registration, dual-mode control with
teleoperation and trajectory playback, and seamless integration from multimodal
data acquisition to inference. Experiments on single-arm and dual-arm systems
show efficient, low-latency data collection and effective support for policy
learning with imitation learning and vision-language-action models. Policies
trained on data gathered by Control Your Robot match expert demonstrations
closely, indicating that the framework enables scalable and reproducible robot
learning across platforms.

AI.tldr: A modular, cross-platform robot-control framework that unifies data collection and policy deployment, enabling low-latency learning and reproducible results across different hardware.
AI.motivation: Hardware-interface fragmentation and divergent data formats impede scalable robot learning; a unified workflow and standardized APIs can streamline cross-platform deployment.
AI.method: Develop Control Your Robot with modular components, standardized APIs, and a closed-loop architecture. Features include flexible robot registration, dual-mode control (teleoperation and trajectory playback), and end-to-end data-to-inference pipelines that integrate multimodal data acquisition, imitation learning, and vision-language-action models.
AI.result: On single-arm and dual-arm setups, the framework enables efficient, low-latency data collection and supports policy learning. Policies trained on data collected via the framework closely match expert demonstrations.
AI.conclusion: The framework reduces fragmentation and enables scalable, reproducible robot learning across platforms through standardized workflows and cross-platform integration.

title: EAPO: Enhancing Policy Optimization with On-Demand Expert Assistance
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have recently advanced in reasoning when
optimized with reinforcement learning (RL) under verifiable rewards. Existing
methods primarily rely on outcome-based supervision to strengthen internal LLM
reasoning, often leading to inefficient exploration and sparse rewards. To
mitigate this issue, we propose Expert-Assisted Policy Optimization (EAPO), a
novel RL framework that enhances exploration by incorporating multi-turn
interactions with external experts during training. Unlike prior methods, where
policies reason in isolation, EAPO incentivizes the policy to adaptively
determine when and how to consult experts, yielding richer reward signals and
more reliable reasoning trajectories. External assistance ultimately
internalizes expert knowledge into the policy model, amplifying the model's
inherent reasoning capabilities. During evaluation, the policy model has been
well-optimized to solve questions independently, producing improved reasoning
paths and more accurate solutions. Experiments on mathematical reasoning
benchmarks, including AIME 2024, AIME 2025, and AIMO 2025, show that EAPO
consistently outperforms expert-assisted workflow, expert-distilled models, and
RL baselines, with an average gain of 5 points over self-exploratory models.

AI.tldr: EAPO introduces Expert-Assisted Policy Optimization to improve exploration and internalize expert knowledge in RL-powered LLM reasoning, achieving ~5-point gains on AIME/AIMO benchmarks over self-exploratory baselines.
AI.motivation: Tackle inefficient exploration and sparse rewards in outcome-based RL for LLM reasoning by leveraging adaptive, multi-turn consulting with external experts to enrich training signals and embed expert knowledge into the policy.
AI.method: Propose EAPO framework enabling adaptive expert consultation during training, integrating multi-turn expert interactions to guide policy decisions and reward shaping; expert guidance is internalized into the policy, improving autonomous reasoning in evaluation.
AI.result: EAPO outperforms expert-assisted workflows, expert-distilled models, and RL baselines on math reasoning benchmarks, with an average gain of about 5 points over self-exploratory models.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive expert consultation during RL training can enhance exploration and internalize expert reasoning, leading to more reliable reasoning trajectories and stronger performance on mathematical reasoning tasks.

title: Deep Learning-Based Detection of Cognitive Impairment from Passive Smartphone Sensing with Routine-Aware Augmentation and Demographic Personalization
comment:
Accepted at 2025 IEEE EMBS International Conference on Biomedical and
  Health Informatics (IEEE BHI 2025)
summary:
Early detection of cognitive impairment is critical for timely diagnosis and
intervention, yet infrequent clinical assessments often lack the sensitivity
and temporal resolution to capture subtle cognitive declines in older adults.
Passive smartphone sensing has emerged as a promising approach for naturalistic
and continuous cognitive monitoring. Building on this potential, we implemented
a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model to detect cognitive impairment from
sequences of daily behavioral features, derived from multimodal sensing data
collected in an ongoing one-year study of older adults. Our key contributions
are two techniques to enhance model generalizability across participants: (1)
routine-aware augmentation, which generates synthetic sequences by replacing
each day with behaviorally similar alternatives, and (2) demographic
personalization, which reweights training samples to emphasize those from
individuals demographically similar to the test participant. Evaluated on
6-month data from 36 older adults, these techniques jointly improved the Area
Under the Precision-Recall Curve (AUPRC) of the model trained on sensing and
demographic features from 0.637 to 0.766, highlighting the potential of
scalable monitoring of cognitive impairment in aging populations with passive
sensing.

AI.tldr: LSTM-based cognitive impairment detection from daily passive sensing improves cross-participant generalizability via routine-aware augmentation and demographic personalization, boosting AUPRC from 0.637 to 0.766 in 6-month data from 36 older adults.
AI.motivation: Early detection of cognitive decline is essential but hindered by sparse clinical assessments; passive smartphone sensing offers continuous, naturalistic monitoring, but cross-participant generalizability remains a key challenge.
AI.method: An LSTM model processes sequences of daily behavioral features derived from multimodal sensing. Two generalization techniques are proposed: (1) routine-aware augmentation to create synthetic sequences by replacing days with behaviorally similar alternatives, and (2) demographic personalization to reweight training samples toward individuals demographically similar to the test participant. Evaluation uses 6-month data from 36 older adults.
AI.result: With the two techniques, the model trained on sensing and demographic features achieved an AUPRC improvement from 0.637 (baseline) to 0.766, indicating improved detection performance.
AI.conclusion: Routine-aware augmentation and demographic personalization jointly enhance cross-participant generalizability of passive-sensing-based cognitive impairment detection, supporting scalable monitoring in aging populations.

title: Sparse2Dense: A Keypoint-driven Generative Framework for Human Video Compression and Vertex Prediction
summary:
For bandwidth-constrained multimedia applications, simultaneously achieving
ultra-low bitrate human video compression and accurate vertex prediction
