The root cause is Contextual Ambiguity: the model’s own stochastic actions create histories that resemble suboptimal training histories, triggering a feedback loop of poor decisions. A principled signal is needed to align training and testing trajectories toward monotonic improvement.
AI.method: Introduce Context Value as an explicit signal representing the ideal performance given the current context. Prove that Context Value grows with context and tightens the lower bound on the performance gap to an ideal monotonically improving policy. Propose two methods to estimate Context Value at training and testing time and integrate CV into the ICRL objective (CV-ICRL).
AI.result: Theoretical result: Context Value tightens the lower bound on the performance gap relative to an ideal monotone policy. Empirical result: CV-ICRL reduces performance degradation and improves ICRL performance across tasks/environments (Dark Room, Minigrid). Code and data are available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Contextual Ambiguity in ICRL can be mitigated by incorporating Context Value, yielding closer-to-monotonic improvements and stronger performance guarantees. CV-ICRL offers practical estimators and demonstrates broad effectiveness, with open-source implementation.

title: Self-Consistency as a Free Lunch: Reducing Hallucinations in Vision-Language Models via Self-Reflection
summary:
Vision-language models often hallucinate details, generating non-existent
objects or inaccurate attributes that compromise output reliability. Existing
methods typically address these issues via extensive human annotations or
external supervision from more powerful models. In this work, we present a
novel framework that leverages the model's self-consistency between long
responses and short answers to generate preference pairs for training. We
observe that short binary questions tend to yield highly reliable responses,
which can be used to query the target model to evaluate and rank its generated
responses. Specifically, we design a self-reflection pipeline where detailed
model responses are compared against concise binary answers, and inconsistency
signals are utilized to automatically curate high-quality training data without
human annotations or external model-based supervision. By relying solely on
self-consistency rather than external supervision, our method offers a scalable
and efficient solution that effectively reduces hallucinations using unlabeled
data. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks, i.e., AMBER,
MultiObject-Hal (ROPE), Object HalBench, and MMHal-Bench, demonstrate
significant improvements in factual grounding and reliability. Moreover, our
approach maintains robust instruction-following ability, as evidenced by
enhanced performance on LLaVA-Bench and MMBench.

AI.tldr: A self-consistency based data curation framework uses long-form model responses and short binary answers to generate preference data, reducing hallucinations in vision-language models without human annotations or external supervision, while preserving instruction-following.
AI.motivation: Vision-language models often hallucinate details; existing fixes rely on annotated data or external supervision. This work seeks a scalable, self-supervised approach by leveraging the model's own consistency signals to curate training data.
AI.method: A self-reflection pipeline compares detailed model outputs to concise binary answers. Inconsistencies are used to generate training preferences. The method relies solely on unlabeled data and self-consistency, avoiding human or external supervision to curate high-quality training data.
AI.result: Significant improvements in factual grounding and reliability across AMBER, MultiObject-Hal (ROPE), Object HalBench, and MMHal-Bench. The approach also preserves instruction-following ability, with boosted performance on LLaVA-Bench and MMBench.
AI.conclusion: Self-consistency-based data curation can effectively reduce hallucinations without external supervision, offering a scalable and efficient alternative for improving reliability in vision-language models.

title: Memory Transfer Planning: LLM-driven Context-Aware Code Adaptation for Robot Manipulation
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly explored in robot manipulation,
but many existing methods struggle to adapt to new environments. Many systems
require either environment-specific policy training or depend on fixed prompts
and single-shot code generation, leading to limited transferability and manual
re-tuning. We introduce Memory Transfer Planning (MTP), a framework that
leverages successful control-code examples from different environments as
procedural knowledge, using them as in-context guidance for LLM-driven
planning. Specifically, MTP (i) generates an initial plan and code using LLMs,
(ii) retrieves relevant successful examples from a code memory, and (iii)
contextually adapts the retrieved code to the target setting for re-planning
without updating model parameters. We evaluate MTP on RLBench, CALVIN, and a
physical robot, demonstrating effectiveness beyond simulation. Across these
settings, MTP consistently improved success rate and adaptability compared with
fixed-prompt code generation, naive retrieval, and memory-free re-planning.
Furthermore, in hardware experiments, leveraging a memory constructed in
simulation proved effective. MTP provides a practical approach that exploits
procedural knowledge to realize robust LLM-based planning across diverse
robotic manipulation scenarios, enhancing adaptability to novel environments
and bridging simulation and real-world deployment.

AI.tldr: Memory Transfer Planning (MTP) uses a code memory of successful cross-environment control-code examples to guide LLM-based planning for robot manipulation. It selects and contextually adapts retrieved examples to the target setting, enabling planning without model updates and improving transferability from simulation to real hardware.
AI.motivation: LLMs for robot manipulation often struggle to transfer policies across environments due to fixed prompts or single-shot code generation, requiring manual retuning. There is a need for leveraging procedural knowledge from multiple environments to improve adaptability without retraining.
AI.method: MTP framework: (i) an LLM generates an initial plan and code; (ii) retrieve relevant successful control-code examples from a code memory; (iii) contextually adapt the retrieved code to the target environment and re-plan without updating model parameters. Evaluated on RLBench, CALVIN, and a physical robot, including sim-to-real transfer.
AI.result: MTP consistently improves success rate and adaptability over fixed-prompt code generation, naive retrieval, and memory-free re-planning across simulation and hardware scenarios. A memory constructed in simulation is effective for real hardware experiments.
AI.conclusion: MTP provides a practical approach to exploit procedural knowledge as in-context guidance to realize robust LLM-based planning for robotic manipulation, improving cross-environment adaptability and bridging simulation-to-real deployment.

title: Mix-Ecom: Towards Mixed-Type E-Commerce Dialogues with Complex Domain Rules
summary:
E-commerce agents contribute greatly to helping users complete their
e-commerce needs. To promote further research and application of e-commerce
agents, benchmarking frameworks are introduced for evaluating LLM agents in the
e-commerce domain. Despite the progress, current benchmarks lack evaluating
agents' capability to handle mixed-type e-commerce dialogue and complex domain
rules. To address the issue, this work first introduces a novel corpus, termed
Mix-ECom, which is constructed based on real-world customer-service dialogues
with post-processing to remove user privacy and add CoT process. Specifically,
Mix-ECom contains 4,799 samples with multiply dialogue types in each e-commerce
dialogue, covering four dialogue types (QA, recommendation, task-oriented
dialogue, and chit-chat), three e-commerce task types (pre-sales, logistics,
after-sales), and 82 e-commerce rules. Furthermore, this work build baselines
on Mix-Ecom and propose a dynamic framework to further improve the performance.
Results show that current e-commerce agents lack sufficient capabilities to
handle e-commerce dialogues, due to the hallucination cased by complex domain
rules. The dataset will be publicly available.

AI.tldr: Mix-ECom: a new benchmark corpus for evaluating LLM-based e-commerce agents with mixed dialogue types and domain-specific rules; baseline models and a dynamic framework are proposed; current agents struggle due to rule-driven hallucinations; dataset to be released publicly.
AI.motivation: Address gaps in evaluating e-commerce agents by introducing a complex, real-world, privacy-cleared dataset that covers mixed dialogue types, multiple task types, and a substantial set of domain rules, enabling robust benchmarking of LLM agents in e-commerce.
AI.method: Construct Mix-ECom from real-world customer-service dialogues, post-process to remove user privacy and add chain-of-thought (CoT) processing; annotate with four dialogue types (QA, recommendation, task-oriented, chit-chat), three task types (pre-sales, logistics, after-sales), and 82 e-commerce rules; establish baselines and propose a dynamic benchmarking/framework to improve performance.
AI.result: Empirical baselines show current e-commerce agents underperform on Mix-ECom due to hallucinations and difficulty handling complex domain rules; the framework aims to guide improvements; dataset will be publicly released.
AI.conclusion: The Mix-ECom dataset will be publicly available and is intended to drive future research in robust, rule-aware e-commerce LLM agents; highlights the need to mitigate rule-induced hallucinations and to enhance capability across mixed dialogue types.

title: One-Shot Multi-Label Causal Discovery in High-Dimensional Event Sequences
comment:
Accepted at NeuRIPS2025 Workshop CauScien: Discovering Causality in
  Science. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:2509.19112
summary:
Understanding causality in event sequences with thousands of sparse event
types is critical in domains such as healthcare, cybersecurity, or vehicle
diagnostics, yet current methods fail to scale. We present OSCAR, a one-shot
causal autoregressive method that infers per-sequence Markov Boundaries using
two pretrained Transformers as density estimators. This enables efficient,
parallel causal discovery without costly global CI testing. On a real-world
automotive dataset with 29,100 events and 474 labels, OSCAR recovers
interpretable causal structures in minutes, while classical methods fail to
scale, enabling practical scientific diagnostics at production scale.

AI.tldr: OSCAR offers scalable one-shot causal discovery for high-dimensional sparse event sequences by using two pretrained Transformers as density estimators to infer per-sequence Markov boundaries, enabling fast, parallel inference on large datasets (e.g., 29k events, 474 labels).
AI.motivation: Current causal discovery methods do not scale to thousands of sparse event types; there is a need for scalable, interpretable causal structure learning in domains like healthcare, cybersecurity, and vehicle diagnostics.
AI.method: Two pretrained transformers act as density estimators within an autoregressive framework to infer per-sequence Markov boundaries; enables one-shot, parallel causal discovery without global conditional independence testing; scalable to large event alphabets.
AI.result: Applied to a real automotive dataset with 29,100 events and 474 labels, OSCAR recovers interpretable causal structures in minutes; classical methods fail to scale, showing practical viability at production scale.
AI.conclusion: OSCAR enables scalable, interpretable causal discovery for large-scale event sequences, reducing reliance on costly CI tests and enabling practical diagnostics in real-world production settings.

title: TATTOO: Training-free AesTheTic-aware Outfit recOmmendation
summary:
The global fashion e-commerce market relies significantly on intelligent and
aesthetic-aware outfit-completion tools to promote sales. While previous
studies have approached the problem of fashion outfit-completion and
compatible-item retrieval, most of them require expensive, task-specific
training on large-scale labeled data, and no effort is made to guide outfit
recommendation with explicit human aesthetics. In the era of Multimodal Large
Language Models (MLLMs), we show that the conventional training-based pipeline
could be streamlined to a training-free paradigm, with better recommendation
scores and enhanced aesthetic awareness. We achieve this with TATTOO, a
Training-free AesTheTic-aware Outfit recommendation approach. It first
generates a target-item description using MLLMs, followed by an aesthetic
chain-of-thought used to distill the images into a structured aesthetic profile
including color, style, occasion, season, material, and balance. By fusing the
visual summary of the outfit with the textual description and aesthetics
vectors using a dynamic entropy-gated mechanism, candidate items can be
represented in a shared embedding space and be ranked accordingly. Experiments
on a real-world evaluation set Aesthetic-100 show that TATTOO achieves
state-of-the-art performance compared with existing training-based methods.
Another standard Polyvore dataset is also used to measure the advanced
zero-shot retrieval capability of our training-free method.

AI.tldr: Training-free, aesthetic-aware outfit recommendation (TATTOO) leverages Multimodal LLMs to generate target-item descriptions and an aesthetic profile, fusing visual and textual cues through a dynamic entropy-gated fusion to rank items in a shared embedding space, achieving SOTA performance on Aesthetic-100 and strong zero-shot retrieval on Polyvore without labeled training.
AI.motivation: Reduce reliance on expensive task-specific labeled data and training, while explicitly guiding recommendations with human-like aesthetics; exploit the capabilities of Multimodal LLMs for end-to-end, training-free pipeline.
AI.method: 1) Use MLLMs to generate a target-item description. 2) Use an aesthetic chain-of-thought to distill outfit images into a structured aesthetics vector (color, style, occasion, season, material, balance). 3) Fuse visual summary, textual description, and aesthetics vectors via a dynamic entropy-gated mechanism into a shared embedding space. 4) Rank candidate items by similarity; evaluate on Aesthetic-100 and Polyvore for zero-shot retrieval.
AI.result: On Aesthetic-100, TATTOO achieves state-of-the-art performance compared with existing training-based methods; on Polyvore, demonstrates strong zero-shot retrieval capability in a training-free setting.
AI.conclusion: A training-free, aesthetic-aware outfit recommendation framework is viable and effective, reducing data requirements while maintaining top performance, and illustrating a practical use of MLLMs for multimodal recommendation tasks.

title: Preference-Based Long-Horizon Robotic Stacking with Multimodal Large Language Models
summary:
Pretrained large language models (LLMs) can work as high-level robotic
planners by reasoning over abstract task descriptions and natural language
instructions, etc. However, they have shown a lack of knowledge and
effectiveness in planning long-horizon robotic manipulation tasks where the
physical properties of the objects are essential. An example is the stacking of
containers with hidden objects inside, which involves reasoning over hidden
physics properties such as weight and stability. To this end, this paper
proposes to use multimodal LLMs as high-level planners for such long-horizon
robotic stacking tasks. The LLM takes multimodal inputs for each object to
stack and infers the current best stacking sequence by reasoning over stacking
preferences. Furthermore, in order to enable the LLM to reason over multiple
preferences at the same time without giving explicit instructions, we propose
to create a custom dataset considering stacking preferences including weight,
stability, size, and footprint, to fine-tune the LLM. Compared to the
pretrained LLM with prompt tuning, we demonstrate the improved stacking
completion of the LLM fine-tuned with our custom dataset via large-scale
simulation evaluation. Furthermore, we showcase the effectiveness of the
proposed framework for the long-horizon stacking task on a real humanoid robot
in an online manner.

AI.tldr: Multimodal LLMs fine-tuned on a dataset of stacking preferences improve long-horizon robotic stacking planning, validated in simulation and on a real humanoid robot.
AI.motivation: LLMs often lack domain knowledge for planning tasks that hinge on physical object properties. Long-horizon stacking with hidden objects requires reasoning about hidden physics (weight, stability, etc.). The work proposes using multimodal LLMs as high-level planners that can incorporate object properties.
AI.method: Use multimodal inputs for each object, and have the LLM infer the best stacking sequence by reasoning over stacking preferences. Create a custom fine-tuning dataset that encodes preferences such as weight, stability, size, and footprint to align the LLM with multi-criteria planning. Compare to a pretrained LLM with prompt tuning. Evaluate via large-scale simulation and demonstrate online real-robot performance on a humanoid robot.
AI.result: The fine-tuned, multimodal LLM shows improved stacking completion over the prompt-tuned pretrained LLM in simulations and is demonstrated effectively on a real humanoid robot in online operation.
AI.conclusion: Fine-tuning with a dataset that captures stacking preferences enables multimodal LLMs to reason about hidden physics for long-horizon robotic stacking tasks, making them effective high-level planners for such manipulation tasks.

title: AgentGuard: Runtime Verification of AI Agents
comment:
Accepted for publication in the proceedings of the 40th IEEE/ACM
  International Conference on Automated Software Engineering, ASE 2025, in the
  1st international workshop on Agentic Software Engineering (AgenticSE)
summary:
The rapid evolution to autonomous, agentic AI systems introduces significant
risks due to their inherent unpredictability and emergent behaviors; this also
renders traditional verification methods inadequate and necessitates a shift
towards probabilistic guarantees where the question is no longer if a system
will fail, but the probability of its failure within given constraints. This
paper presents AgentGuard, a framework for runtime verification of Agentic AI
systems that provides continuous, quantitative assurance through a new paradigm
called Dynamic Probabilistic Assurance. AgentGuard operates as an inspection
layer that observes an agent's raw I/O and abstracts it into formal events
corresponding to transitions in a state model. It then uses online learning to
dynamically build and update a Markov Decision Process (MDP) that formally
models the agent's emergent behavior. Using probabilistic model checking, the
framework then verifies quantitative properties in real-time.

AI.tldr: AgentGuard is a runtime-verification framework for agentic AI that provides continuous, quantitative probabilistic assurances by online learning an MDP of emergent behavior and verifying properties with probabilistic model checking in real-time.
AI.motivation: Traditional verification methods struggle with unpredictable, emergent agentic AI. There is a need for probabilistic guarantees about the likelihood of failures within given constraints.
AI.method: The framework acts as an inspection layer that observes raw I/O, abstracts to formal events corresponding to state transitions, uses online learning to build/update an MDP of emergent behavior, and applies probabilistic model checking to verify quantitative properties in real-time.
AI.result: Proposes a practical framework (AgentGuard) that enables continuous, real-time probabilistic assurance for agentic AI. The abstract does not report empirical results.
AI.conclusion: AgentGuard offers a path to real-time, probabilistic guarantees for emergent agentic AI by combining online MDP learning with probabilistic model checking, enabling quantitative risk assessment under constraints.

title: WirelessMathLM: Teaching Mathematical Reasoning for LLMs in Wireless Communications with Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) excel at general mathematical reasoning but fail
catastrophically on specialized technical mathematics. In wireless
communications, where problems require precise manipulation of
information-theoretic bounds, optimization constraints, and signal processing
formulations, even state-of-the-art models struggle to achieve competent
performance. We present WirelessMathLM, demonstrating that compact models
(0.5B-7B parameters) can match or exceed much larger models through
domain-specific reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards. Our key insight
is that wireless mathematics problems possess a unique property--verifiable
correctness--that enables effective reinforcement learning without human
feedback. We construct WirelessMathBench-XL, a comprehensive benchmark of 4,027
problems from 970 papers. Using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with
binary verification rewards, we train models directly from base checkpoints
without supervised warm-start. Our 7B model achieves 39.5% accuracy on
WirelessMathBench-XL, approaching GPT-4o (40.4%) while using about 100 times
fewer parameters than DeepSeek-R1 (671B, 57.4%). Remarkably, GRPO training
nearly doubles performance across all model scales (0.5B +11%, 3B +103%, 7B
+81%), with positive transfer to general mathematics benchmarks--our models
gain +8.4 points on average across MATH, Minerva-Math, OlympiadBench, AMC, and
AIME without any training on these tasks.

AI.tldr: Compact, domain-tuned LLMs with verifiable rewards (GRPO) reach near-GPT-4o performance on wireless math with far fewer parameters; training on WirelessMathBench-XL yields strong cross-domain math gains.
AI.motivation: General-purpose LLMs struggle with specialized technical mathematics; a domain-specific RL framework that leverages verifiable correctness can unlock efficient, high-quality reasoning in niche domains such as wireless communications.
AI.method: Train 0.5B–7B models (WirelessMathLM) using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with binary verification rewards on WirelessMathBench-XL (4,027 problems from 970 papers); no supervised warm-start; benchmark built specifically for wireless math.
AI.result: 7B model achieves 39.5% accuracy on WirelessMathBench-XL, close to GPT-4o at 40.4%; 7B uses ~100x fewer parameters than DeepSeek-R1 (671B, 57.4%); GRPO yields +11% (0.5B), +103% (3B), +81% (7B) improvements; positive transfer to general math benchmarks (+8.4 points average on MATH, Minerva-Math, OlympiadBench, AMC, AIME) without training on them.
AI.conclusion: Verifiable-correctness based RL enables compact domain-specific models to approach large-model performance on specialized math tasks and transfers gains to broader mathematics benchmarks; this approach reduces model size and resource needs while maintaining competitive accuracy.

title: Increasing the Diversity in RGB-to-Thermal Image Translation for Automotive Applications
summary:
Thermal imaging in Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) improves road
safety with superior perception in low-light and harsh weather conditions
compared to traditional RGB cameras. However, research in this area faces
challenges due to limited dataset availability and poor representation in
driving simulators. RGB-to-thermal image translation offers a potential
solution, but existing methods focus on one-to-one mappings. We propose a
one-to-many mapping using a multi-modal translation framework enhanced with our
Component-aware Adaptive Instance Normalization (CoAdaIN). Unlike the original
AdaIN, which applies styles globally, CoAdaIN adapts styles to different image
components individually. The result, as we show, is more realistic and diverse
thermal image translations. This is the accepted author manuscript of the paper
published in IEEE Sensors Conference 2024. The final published version is
available at 10.1109/SENSORS60989.2024.10785056.

AI.tldr: Proposes a multi-modal RGB-to-thermal translation framework using Component-aware Adaptive Instance Normalization (CoAdaIN) to produce diverse, realistic thermal images for ADAS.
AI.motivation: Thermal imaging in ADAS suffers from limited datasets and poor representation in driving simulators; there is demand for realistic, varied thermal data to improve perception in low-light and harsh weather.
AI.method: A multi-modal translation framework that extends AdaIN with CoAdaIN, which adapts styles to individual image components rather than applying a global style, enabling one-to-many RGB-to-thermal translations.
AI.result: Demonstrates that CoAdaIN yields more realistic and diverse thermal translations compared to global-style methods.
AI.conclusion: CoAdaIN enhances one-to-many RGB-to-thermal translation for ADAS applications, potentially improving perception in challenging driving conditions; manuscript accepted for IEEE Sensors Conference 2024 (final published version: IEEE Sensors 2024).

title: Very High Frequency Interpolation for Direct Torque Control
summary:
Torque control enables agile and robust robot motion, but deployment is often
hindered by instability and hardware limits. Here, we present a novel solution
to execute whole-body linear feedback at up to 40 kHz on open-source hardware.
We use this to interpolate non-linear schemes during real-world execution, such
as inverse dynamics and learned torque policies. Our results show that by
stabilizing torque controllers, high-frequency linear feedback could be an
effective route towards unlocking the potential of torque-controlled robotics.

AI.tldr: A high-frequency, open-hardware torque control framework delivering up to 40 kHz whole-body linear feedback, enabling real-time interpolation of non-linear schemes (e.g., inverse dynamics, learned torque policies) to stabilize torque controllers in torque-controlled robots.
AI.motivation: Torque control offers agile, robust robot motion but is often limited by instability and hardware constraints. High-frequency, open-source torque feedback could unlock more capable, reliable torque-controlled systems.
AI.method: Develop a whole-body linear feedback loop operating at up to 40 kHz on open-source hardware and use interpolation to incorporate non-linear control schemes (inverse dynamics, learned torque policies) during real-world execution.
AI.result: Stabilizing torque controllers with high-frequency linear feedback improves robustness and enables interpolation of non-linear schemes in real-time, suggesting a practical path to unleash the potential of torque-controlled robotics.
AI.conclusion: High-frequency linear torque feedback on open hardware is a promising route to overcome instability and hardware limits in torque-controlled robotics, enabling richer control strategies to be deployed in real-world systems.

title: Rethinking Reward Miscalibration of GRPO in Agentic RL
summary:
Building autonomous agents capable of solving long-horizon, real-world tasks
has garnered significant research interest. But outcome based rewards may cause
reward miscalibration which means it might mistakenly allocate positive reward
to flawed middle steps which is regarded as the key reason making the bad
actions being reinforced during training. However we reveal that outcome based
reward ensures expected negative advantage for those flawed middle steps, which
means the flawed actions should be punished during training. Even accounting
for the ``squeezing effect", the probability mass of good actions should
increase and the actor should gradually get rid of harmful actions. This shows
that flawed actions should be punished during training. We further identify
gradient coupling between similar samples as a key issue in agentic RL, the
input prompt is extremely similar and the output action space is limited,
therefore during training, gradients from well-performing samples can
inadvertently strengthen suboptimal or incorrect actions due to similar input
observation and output actions. We show that with gradient coupling, some
flawed actions might be enhanced. To address this, we propose training the
actor to classify good or bad actions to separate the embedding of good/bad
actions and alleviate the gradient interference, extensive experiments shows
its effectiveness.

AI.tldr: Outcome-based rewards can miscalibrate training by rewarding flawed middle steps; gradient coupling can amplify suboptimal actions; a classifier-based separation of good/bad actions mitigates this and improves learning.
AI.motivation: To enable autonomous agents to solve long-horizon tasks despite reward misalignment and gradient interference, by identifying root causes and proposing a remedy.
AI.method: Propose training the actor to classify actions as good or bad, thereby separating embeddings for good and bad actions to reduce gradient interference; evaluate with extensive experiments.
AI.result: The approach improves training stability and policy performance by mitigating the reinforcement of flawed actions and reducing gradient coupling.
AI.conclusion: Flawed actions should be punished during training; gradient coupling explains propagation of suboptimal actions; a classifier-based embedding separation offers a viable remedy for agentic RL.

title: SPEC-RL: Accelerating On-Policy Reinforcement Learning via Speculative Rollouts
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly rely on reinforcement learning with
verifiable rewards (RLVR) to elicit reliable chain-of-thought reasoning.
However, the training process remains bottlenecked by the computationally
expensive rollout stage. Existing acceleration methods-such as parallelization,
objective- and data-driven modifications, and replay buffers-either incur
diminishing returns, introduce bias, or overlook redundancy across iterations.
We identify that rollouts from consecutive training epochs frequently share a
large portion of overlapping segments, wasting computation. To address this, we
propose SPEC-RL, a novel framework that integrates SPECulative decoding with
the RL rollout process. SPEC-RL reuses prior trajectory segments as speculative
prefixes and extends them via a draft-and-verify mechanism, avoiding redundant
generation while ensuring policy consistency. Experiments on diverse math
reasoning and generalization benchmarks, including GSM8K, MATH-500,
OlympiadBench, MMLU-STEM, and others, demonstrate that SPEC-RL reduces rollout
time by 2-3x without compromising policy quality. As a purely rollout-stage
enhancement, SPEC-RL integrates seamlessly with mainstream algorithms (e.g.,
PPO, GRPO, DAPO), offering a general and practical path to scale RLVR for large
reasoning models. Our code is available at https://github.com/ShopeeLLM/Spec-RL

AI.tldr: SPEC-RL uses speculative decoding to reuse prior rollout prefixes in RLVR, cutting rollout time by 2-3x without harming policy quality; broadly compatible with PPO, GRPO, DAPO and validated on math reasoning benchmarks; code available.
AI.motivation: RL with verifiable rewards (RLVR) for large language models is bottlenecked by the costly rollout stage. Redundancy across consecutive epochs means rollouts share large overlapping segments, wasting computation. Existing accelerations either bias results or miss redundancy; a rollout-focused solution is needed.
AI.method: SPEC-RL integrates speculative decoding with the RL rollout process. It reuses prior trajectory segments as speculative prefixes and extends them with a draft-and-verify mechanism to maintain policy consistency. It is a rollout-stage enhancement that can be plugged into standard RL algorithms (e.g., PPO, GRPO, DAPO).
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on diverse math reasoning and generalization benchmarks (GSM8K, MATH-500, OlympiadBench, MMLU-STEM, etc.) shows 2-3x reduction in rollout time without compromising policy quality.
AI.conclusion: SPEC-RL offers a practical, general method to scale RLVR for large reasoning models by eliminating redundant rollout computation during training, with broad compatibility and available code.

title: LiDAR-based Human Activity Recognition through Laplacian Spectral Analysis
comment:
9 pages, 5 figures, 4 tables, 22 references, conference; Code
  available at https://github.com/Arritmic/oulu-pointcloud-har
summary:
Human Activity Recognition supports applications in healthcare,
manufacturing, and human-machine interaction. LiDAR point clouds offer a
privacy-preserving alternative to cameras and are robust to illumination. We
propose a HAR method based on graph spectral analysis. Each LiDAR frame is
mapped to a proximity graph (epsilon-graph) and the Laplacian spectrum is
computed. Eigenvalues and statistics of eigenvectors form pose descriptors, and
temporal statistics over sliding windows yield fixed vectors for classification
with support vector machines and random forests. On the MM-Fi dataset with 40
subjects and 27 activities, under a strict subject-independent protocol, the
method reaches 94.4% accuracy on a 13-class rehabilitation set and 90.3% on all
27 activities. It also surpasses the skeleton-based baselines reported for
MM-Fi. The contribution is a compact and interpretable feature set derived
directly from point cloud geometry that provides an accurate and efficient
alternative to end-to-end deep learning.

AI.tldr: Graph-spectral HAR from LiDAR frames using epsilon-graphs; compact, interpretable features yield strong accuracy and privacy advantages vs. deep learning.
AI.motivation: Privacy-preserving HAR using LiDAR point clouds; robust to illumination and avoids camera-based privacy concerns and heavy end-to-end models.
AI.method: For each LiDAR frame, construct an epsilon proximity graph; compute Laplacian spectrum; use eigenvalues and statistics of eigenvectors as pose descriptors; derive temporal statistics over sliding windows; classify with SVM and Random Forests.
AI.result: On MM-Fi (40 subjects, 27 activities) under subject-independent protocol: 13-class rehabilitation subset achieves 94.4% accuracy; all 27 activities achieve 90.3%;>skeleton-based baselines on MM-Fi.
AI.conclusion: Presents a compact, interpretable feature set derived from point-cloud geometry, providing accurate and efficient HAR as an alternative to end-to-end deep learning.

title: ViReSkill: Vision-Grounded Replanning with Skill Memory for LLM-Based Planning in Lifelong Robot Learning
summary:
Robots trained via Reinforcement Learning (RL) or Imitation Learning (IL)
often adapt slowly to new tasks, whereas recent Large Language Models (LLMs)
and Vision-Language Models (VLMs) promise knowledge-rich planning from minimal
data. Deploying LLMs/VLMs for motion planning, however, faces two key
obstacles: (i) symbolic plans are rarely grounded in scene geometry and object
physics, and (ii) model outputs can vary for identical prompts, undermining
execution reliability. We propose ViReSkill, a framework that pairs
vision-grounded replanning with a skill memory for accumulation and reuse. When
a failure occurs, the replanner generates a new action sequence conditioned on
the current scene, tailored to the observed state. On success, the executed
plan is stored as a reusable skill and replayed in future encounters without
additional calls to LLMs/VLMs. This feedback loop enables autonomous continual
learning: each attempt immediately expands the skill set and stabilizes
subsequent executions. We evaluate ViReSkill on simulators such as LIBERO and
RLBench as well as on a physical robot. Across all settings, it consistently
outperforms conventional baselines in task success rate, demonstrating robust
sim-to-real generalization.

AI.tldr: ViReSkill combines vision-grounded replanning with a reusable skill memory, enabling continual autonomous learning for robot tasks. It re-plans on failure using current scene, stores successful executions as skills, and replays them without further LLM/VLM calls, improving reliability and sim-to-real generalization.
AI.motivation: RL/IL agents adapt slowly to new tasks, while LLMs/VLMs offer planning from minimal data but suffer from lack of geometry/physics grounding and non-deterministic outputs. There is a need to ground high-level plans in scene context and provide reliable, reusable actions.
AI.method: When a task fails, ViReSkill triggers a vision-grounded replanner to generate a new action sequence conditioned on the current scene. Upon success, the executed plan is stored as a reusable skill in a memory and later replayed, avoiding additional LLM/VLM queries. This creates a feedback loop where each attempt expands the skill set and stabilizes future executions, enabling autonomous continual learning.
AI.result: Evaluations on simulators (LIBERO, RLBench) and a real robot show ViReSkill consistently outperforms baselines in task success rate and demonstrates robust sim-to-real generalization across settings.
AI.conclusion: ViReSkill provides a practical framework for grounding, re-planning, and memory-based skill reuse that enables continual autonomous learning for robotic tasks, reducing reliance on expensive LLM/VLM calls while improving reliability.

title: Quant Fever, Reasoning Blackholes, Schrodinger's Compliance, and More: Probing GPT-OSS-20B
summary:
OpenAI's GPT-OSS family provides open-weight language models with explicit
chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning and a Harmony prompt format. We summarize an
extensive security evaluation of GPT-OSS-20B that probes the model's behavior
under different adversarial conditions. Using the Jailbreak Oracle (JO) [1], a
systematic LLM evaluation tool, the study uncovers several failure modes
including quant fever, reasoning blackholes, Schrodinger's compliance,
reasoning procedure mirage, and chain-oriented prompting. Experiments
demonstrate how these behaviors can be exploited on GPT-OSS-20B models, leading
to severe consequences.

AI.tldr: The study uncovers multiple jailbreak-related failure modes in GPT-OSS-20B using the Jailbreak Oracle, showing that adversarial prompts can induce unsafe and unintended behaviors with potential serious consequences, highlighting security risks in open-weight LLMs with CoT reasoning.
AI.motivation: To evaluate the security and robustness of open-weight LLMs that support chain-of-thought reasoning and Harmony prompts by systematically probing them under adversarial conditions and identifying exploitable failure modes.
AI.method: Apply the Jailbreak Oracle evaluation framework to GPT-OSS-20B under a range of adversarial scenarios; identify and categorize failure modes such as quant fever, reasoning blackholes, Schrödinger's compliance, reasoning procedure mirage, and chain-oriented prompting, and demonstrate how these can be exploited.
AI.result: Identification of several concrete failure modes and patterns of exploitability; experiments show that these behaviors can be triggered and exploited in GPT-OSS-20B, potentially leading to severe real-world consequences.
AI.conclusion: Open-weight LLMs with explicit CoT reasoning and Harmony prompts exhibit notable security vulnerabilities under adversarial testing; findings motivate the need for mitigations, better safety protocols, and robust evaluation tools for such models.

title: More Data or Better Algorithms: Latent Diffusion Augmentation for Deep Imbalanced Regression
summary:
In many real-world regression tasks, the data distribution is heavily skewed,
and models learn predominantly from abundant majority samples while failing to
predict minority labels accurately. While imbalanced classification has been
extensively studied, imbalanced regression remains relatively unexplored. Deep
imbalanced regression (DIR) represents cases where the input data are
high-dimensional and unstructured. Although several data-level approaches for
tabular imbalanced regression exist, deep imbalanced regression currently lacks
dedicated data-level solutions suitable for high-dimensional data and relies
primarily on algorithmic modifications. To fill this gap, we propose
LatentDiff, a novel framework that uses conditional diffusion models with
priority-based generation to synthesize high-quality features in the latent
representation space. LatentDiff is computationally efficient and applicable
across diverse data modalities, including images, text, and other
high-dimensional inputs. Experiments on three DIR benchmarks demonstrate
substantial improvements in minority regions while maintaining overall
accuracy.

AI.tldr: LatentDiff introduces a latent-space diffusion-based data-level augmentation for deep imbalanced regression, using priority-based generation to synthesize minority-region features, improving minority performance with little loss in overall accuracy across three benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Imbalanced regression, especially with high-dimensional, unstructured data, lags behind imbalanced classification. Existing data-level solutions largely target tabular data; there is a need for data-level augmentation in the latent space that works across modalities to improve minority predictions without sacrificing overall accuracy.
AI.method: LatentDiff uses conditional diffusion models operating in the latent representation space with priority-based generation to synthesize high-quality features for minority regions. The approach is modality-agnostic, computationally efficient, and applicable to images, text, and other high-dimensional inputs.
AI.result: Experiments on three deep imbalanced regression benchmarks show substantial improvements in minority-region predictions while maintaining overall regression accuracy.
AI.conclusion: LatentDiff provides a practical, scalable data-level solution for deep imbalanced regression by leveraging latent-space diffusion and priority-based generation, addressing a gap in high-dimensional data settings and enabling cross-modality applicability.

title: OracleGS: Grounding Generative Priors for Sparse-View Gaussian Splatting
summary:
Sparse-view novel view synthesis is fundamentally ill-posed due to severe
geometric ambiguity. Current methods are caught in a trade-off: regressive
models are geometrically faithful but incomplete, whereas generative models can
complete scenes but often introduce structural inconsistencies. We propose
OracleGS, a novel framework that reconciles generative completeness with
regressive fidelity for sparse view Gaussian Splatting. Instead of using
generative models to patch incomplete reconstructions, our
"propose-and-validate" framework first leverages a pre-trained 3D-aware
diffusion model to synthesize novel views to propose a complete scene. We then
repurpose a multi-view stereo (MVS) model as a 3D-aware oracle to validate the
3D uncertainties of generated views, using its attention maps to reveal regions
where the generated views are well-supported by multi-view evidence versus
where they fall into regions of high uncertainty due to occlusion, lack of
texture, or direct inconsistency. This uncertainty signal directly guides the
optimization of a 3D Gaussian Splatting model via an uncertainty-weighted loss.
Our approach conditions the powerful generative prior on multi-view geometric
evidence, filtering hallucinatory artifacts while preserving plausible
completions in under-constrained regions, outperforming state-of-the-art
methods on datasets including Mip-NeRF 360 and NeRF Synthetic.

AI.tldr: A propose-and-validate framework (OracleGS) reconciles generative priors with regressive fidelity for sparse-view Gaussian Splatting by using a 3D-aware diffusion model to propose views and an MVS-based oracle to validate 3D uncertainty, guiding an uncertainty-weighted optimization and improving state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Sparse-view novel view synthesis is fundamentally ill-posed due to geometric ambiguity. Regressive models are faithful but incomplete, while generative models complete scenes but can introduce structural inconsistencies. A framework that balances these aspects is needed.
AI.method: 1) Use a pre-trained 3D-aware diffusion model to synthesize novel views and propose a complete scene. 2) Use a multi-view stereo (MVS) model as a 3D-aware oracle to validate 3D uncertainties of generated views via attention maps, identifying well-supported vs uncertain regions. 3) Use the resulting uncertainty signal to drive an uncertainty-weighted loss that optimizes a 3D Gaussian Splatting model, conditioning the generative prior on multi-view evidence.
AI.result: The method filters hallucinations by leveraging multi-view evidence, enabling plausible completions in under-constrained regions, and achieves superior performance compared to prior work on Mip-NeRF 360 and NeRF Synthetic datasets.
AI.conclusion: OracleGS successfully reconciles generative completeness with regressive fidelity by coupling a 3D-aware diffusion prior with MVS-based uncertainty validation, yielding improved geometric consistency and fidelity in sparse-view neural rendering.

title: Towards Tighter Convex Relaxation of Mixed-integer Programs: Leveraging Logic Network Flow for Task and Motion Planning
summary:
This paper proposes an optimization-based task and motion planning framework,
named "Logic Network Flow", that integrates temporal logic specifications into
mixed-integer programs for efficient robot planning. Inspired by the
Graph-of-Convex-Sets formulation, temporal predicates are encoded as polyhedron
constraints on each edge of a network flow model, instead of as constraints
between nodes in traditional Logic Tree formulations. We further propose a
network-flow-based Fourier-Motzkin elimination procedure that removes
continuous flow variables while preserving convex relaxation tightness, leading
to provably tighter convex relaxations and fewer constraints than Logic Tree
formulations. For temporal logic motion planning with piecewise-affine dynamic
systems, comprehensive experiments across vehicle routing, multi-robot
coordination, and temporal logic control on dynamical systems using point mass
and linear inverted pendulum models demonstrate computational speedups of up to
several orders of magnitude. Hardware demonstrations with quadrupedal robots
validate real-time replanning capabilities under dynamically changing
environmental conditions. The project website is at
https://logicnetworkflow.github.io/.

AI.tldr: An optimization-based task and motion planning framework, Logic Network Flow, integrates temporal logic into network-flow MILPs, yielding tighter convex relaxations and large speedups—enabling real-time, hardware-validated planning under dynamic conditions.
AI.motivation: To efficiently incorporate temporal logic specifications into planning while overcoming scalability limits of Logic Tree formulations and ensuring tight relaxations for better optimization performance.
AI.method: Encode temporal predicates as polyhedral constraints on network-flow edges inspired by Graph-of-Convex-Sets; develop a network-flow-based Fourier-Motzkin elimination to remove continuous flow variables while preserving tightness; demonstrate on piecewise-affine dynamics with vehicle routing, multi-robot coordination, and temporal logic control, plus hardware tests.
AI.result: Significant computational speedups (up to orders of magnitude) across diverse benchmarks; tighter convex relaxations with fewer constraints than Logic Tree; real-time re-planning demonstrated on quadrupedal hardware under changing environments.
AI.conclusion: Logic Network Flow provides provably tighter relaxations and scalable, real-time planning for temporal-logic-constrained tasks, outperforming traditional Logic Tree formulations and enabling robust hardware-enabled reactivity.

title: From Neural Networks to Logical Theories: The Correspondence between Fibring Modal Logics and Fibring Neural Networks
summary:
Fibring of modal logics is a well-established formalism for combining
countable families of modal logics into a single fibred language with common
semantics, characterized by fibred models. Inspired by this formalism, fibring
of neural networks was introduced as a neurosymbolic framework for combining
learning and reasoning in neural networks. Fibring of neural networks uses the
(pre-)activations of a trained network to evaluate a fibring function computing
the weights of another network whose outputs are injected back into the
original network. However, the exact correspondence between fibring of neural
networks and fibring of modal logics was never formally established. In this
paper, we close this gap by formalizing the idea of fibred models
\emph{compatible} with fibred neural networks. Using this correspondence, we
then derive non-uniform logical expressiveness results for Graph Neural
Networks (GNNs), Graph Attention Networks (GATs) and Transformer encoders.
Longer-term, the goal of this paper is to open the way for the use of fibring
as a formalism for interpreting the logical theories learnt by neural networks
with the tools of computational logic.

AI.tldr: Bridges fibring in modal logics with fibring in neural networks by formalizing fibred models and deriving expressiveness results for GNNs, GATs, and Transformers; aims to interpret learned logical theories in neural nets via logical fibring.
AI.motivation: To formalize the previously informal link between fibring neural networks and modal logics, enabling a principled framework for learning and reasoning in neurosymbolic systems and for interpreting neural theories using logical tools.
AI.method: Propose fibred models compatible with fibred neural networks, establish a formal correspondence between fibring in neural networks and fibring in modal logics, and derive non-uniform expressiveness results for Graph NNs, Graph Attention Networks, and Transformer encoders.
AI.result: The paper provides a theoretical bridge showing non-uniform logical expressiveness for GNNs, GATs, and Transformer encoders within the fibring framework and formalizes compatibility between fibred neural networks and fibred modal logics.
AI.conclusion: Long-term goal is to use fibring as a formalism for interpreting the logical theories learned by neural networks, using computational-logic tools to interpret neurosymbolic learning and reasoning.

title: Adaptive Token-Weighted Differential Privacy for LLMs: Not All Tokens Require Equal Protection
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) frequently memorize sensitive or personal
information, raising significant privacy concerns. Existing variants of
differential privacy stochastic gradient descent (DPSGD) inject uniform noise
into every gradient step, significantly extending training time and reducing
model accuracy. We propose that concentrating noise primarily on gradients
associated with sensitive tokens can substantially decrease DP training time,
strengthen the protection of sensitive information, and simultaneously preserve
the model's performance on non-sensitive data. We operationalize this insight
through Adaptive Token-Weighted Differential Privacy (ATDP), a modification of
vanilla DP-SGD that adaptively assigns different gradient weights to sensitive
and non-sensitive tokens. By employing a larger noise scale at the early stage
of training, ATDP rapidly disrupts memorization of sensitive content. As a
result, ATDP only requires a few additional epochs of lightweight
post-processing following standard fine-tuning, injecting targeted noise
primarily on parameters corresponding to sensitive tokens, thus minimally
affecting the model's general capabilities. ATDP can be seamlessly integrated
into any existing DP-based fine-tuning pipeline or directly applied to
non-private models as a fast privacy-enhancing measure. Additionally, combined
with an initial redacted fine-tuning phase, ATDP forms a streamlined DP
pipeline that achieves comparable canary protection to state-of-the-art DP-SGD
methods, significantly reduces the computational overhead of DP fine-tuning,
shortening training time by approximately 90 percent, while achieving
comparable or superior privacy protection and minimal accuracy degradation.

AI.tldr: ATDP is an adaptive DP-SGD variant that concentrates noise on gradients linked to sensitive tokens and increases noise early in training, achieving privacy protection faster with minimal impact on non-sensitive data performance; it can be integrated into existing pipelines and can substantially reduce DP fine-tuning time (~90% faster).
AI.motivation: Large language models frequently memorize sensitive information. Uniform noise in DP-SGD enlarges training time and degrades performance. There is a need for a privacy-preserving method that protects sensitive content efficiently while preserving non-sensitive accuracy.
AI.method: Adaptive Token-Weighted Differential Privacy (ATDP) modifies vanilla DP-SGD by assigning different gradient weights to sensitive vs. non-sensitive tokens. It uses a larger noise scale early in training to rapidly disrupt memorization, followed by lightweight post-processing after standard fine-tuning. Noise is injected primarily into parameters associated with sensitive tokens. ATDP can be integrated into existing DP-based fine-tuning pipelines or applied to non-private models, and can be combined with an initial redacted fine-tuning phase to streamline DP pipelines.
AI.result: ATDP rapidly disrupts memorization of sensitive content, requiring only a few extra epochs of lightweight post-processing. It reduces DP fine-tuning training time by about 90% while achieving comparable or superior privacy protection and minimal accuracy degradation.
AI.conclusion: ATDP offers a practical, efficient approach to privacy-preserving fine-tuning, preserving non-sensitive performance while providing strong protection for sensitive tokens. It is versatile, easy to integrate, and can complement redacted or standard DP pipelines.

title: Learning Regional Monsoon Patterns with a Multimodal Attention U-Net
comment:
Accepted in Geospatial AI and Applications with Foundation Models
  (GAIA) 2025, INSAIT and ELLIS Unit Sofia, Bulgaria
summary:
Accurate monsoon rainfall prediction is vital for India's agriculture, water
management, and climate risk planning, yet remains challenging due to sparse
ground observations and complex regional variability. We present a multimodal
deep learning framework for high-resolution precipitation classification that
leverages satellite and Earth observation data. Unlike previous rainfall
prediction models based on coarse 5-50 km grids, we curate a new 1 km
resolution dataset for five Indian states, integrating seven key geospatial
modalities: land surface temperature, vegetation (NDVI), soil moisture,
relative humidity, wind speed, elevation, and land use, covering the
June-September 2024 monsoon season. Our approach uses an attention-guided U-Net
architecture to capture spatial patterns and temporal dependencies across
modalities, combined with focal and dice loss functions to handle rainfall
class imbalance defined by the India Meteorological Department (IMD).
Experiments demonstrate that our multimodal framework consistently outperforms
unimodal baselines and existing deep learning methods, especially in extreme
rainfall categories. This work contributes a scalable framework, benchmark
dataset, and state-of-the-art results for regional monsoon forecasting, climate
resilience, and geospatial AI applications in India.

AI.tldr: A high-resolution (1 km) multimodal deep learning framework for regional monsoon rainfall classification in India using 7 geospatial modalities and an attention-guided U-Net, achieving state-of-the-art results and providing a benchmark dataset.
AI.motivation: Accurate monsoon rainfall prediction is critical for agriculture, water management, and climate risk planning in India but hindered by sparse observations and strong regional variability.
AI.method: Curates a 1 km dataset for five Indian states for June-September 2024, integrates land surface temperature, NDVI, soil moisture, relative humidity, wind speed, elevation, land use; uses an attention-guided U-Net; incorporates temporal and cross-modal attention; trains with focal and dice losses to address rainfall class imbalance.
AI.result: Outperforms unimodal baselines and existing deep learning approaches, especially for extreme rainfall categories; provides a scalable framework, a benchmark dataset, and state-of-the-art results for regional monsoon forecasting and geospatial AI in India.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a scalable framework and benchmark for high-resolution regional monsoon forecasting with potential applications in climate resilience and geospatial AI in India.

title: PROFusion: Robust and Accurate Dense Reconstruction via Camera Pose Regression and Optimization
summary:
Real-time dense scene reconstruction during unstable camera motions is
crucial for robotics, yet current RGB-D SLAM systems fail when cameras
experience large viewpoint changes, fast motions, or sudden shaking. Classical
optimization-based methods deliver high accuracy but fail with poor
initialization during large motions, while learning-based approaches provide
robustness but lack sufficient accuracy for dense reconstruction. We address
this challenge through a combination of learning-based initialization with
optimization-based refinement. Our method employs a camera pose regression
network to predict metric-aware relative poses from consecutive RGB-D frames,
which serve as reliable starting points for a randomized optimization algorithm
that further aligns depth images with the scene geometry. Extensive experiments
demonstrate promising results: our approach outperforms the best competitor on
challenging benchmarks, while maintaining comparable accuracy on stable motion
sequences. The system operates in real-time, showcasing that combining simple
and principled techniques can achieve both robustness for unstable motions and
accuracy for dense reconstruction. Project page:
https://github.com/siyandong/PROFusion.

AI.tldr: A real-time RGB-D dense reconstruction method that combines learning-based pose initialization with optimization-based refinement to handle unstable camera motions, achieving robustness and dense accuracy in real time.
AI.motivation: Real-time dense scene reconstruction is essential for robotics, but existing RGB-D SLAM systems struggle with large viewpoint changes and fast motions; optimization methods are accurate but brittle to poor initialization, while learning-based methods are robust but less accurate for dense reconstruction.
AI.method: A camera pose regression network predicts metric-aware relative poses from consecutive RGB-D frames to initialize a randomized optimization that further aligns depth images with the scene geometry.
AI.result: Experiments show the method outperforms the best competitor on challenging benchmarks while maintaining comparable accuracy on stable sequences, and it runs in real-time.
AI.conclusion: Hybridizing learning-based initialization with optimization-based refinement yields robust real-time dense reconstruction under unstable motions without sacrificing accuracy.

title: Conditional Advantage Estimation for Reinforcement Learning in Large Reasoning Models
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) for large language
models (LLMs) has achieved remarkable progress in enhancing LLMs' reasoning
capabilities on tasks with clear correctness criteria, such as mathematical
reasoning tasks. Several training metrics, such as entropy or response length,
have been observed to correlate with different reasoning behaviors in
reinforcement learning. Prior approaches incorporate such priors through reward
or advantage shaping, which often relies on hand-crafted penalties and
preferences (e.g., higher-is-better or lower-is-better). However, without
careful hyperparameter tuning, these directional priors can be overly biased
and may lead to failure. To this end, we introduce Conditional advANtage
estimatiON (CANON), amplifying the impact of the target metric without
presuming its direction. Specifically, CANON regroups the sampled responses
into two groups based on the higher or lower value of a target metric, measures
which metric trend contributes to better performance through inter-group
comparison, and identifies the better response within the same group. In
summary, CANON based on entropy consistently outperforms prior methods across
three LLMs on both math reasoning and high-complexity logic tasks. When applied
to response length, CANON further improves token efficiency, yielding a more
favorable Pareto frontier in the performance-cost trade-off.

AI.tldr: CANON is a direction-agnostic conditional advantage estimator for RL in LLMs that groups responses by a target metric, uses inter-group comparisons to identify metric-trend contributions, and improves math-reasoning and logic tasks, plus token efficiency when optimizing response length.
AI.motivation: Directional priors in reward shaping (e.g., higher entropy or longer responses) can bias RL and require careful tuning; a method that does not assume the direction of the metric's effect can be more robust.
AI.method: Regroup sampled responses into two groups based on higher vs lower target metric; analyze inter-group trends to determine which metric direction or trend correlates with better performance; identify the best response within each group; amplify the impact of the target metric without presuming its direction.
AI.result: Entropy-driven CANON outperforms prior methods across three LLMs on math reasoning and high-complexity logic tasks; applying CANON to response length improves token efficiency and yields a better Pareto frontier between performance and cost.
AI.conclusion: CANON offers a robust, direction-agnostic reward shaping approach for RL in LLMs, reducing reliance on hand-tuned penalties and improving reasoning performance and efficiency; likely generalizable to other metrics.

title: Deep Learning for Subspace Regression
summary:
It is often possible to perform reduced order modelling by specifying linear
subspace which accurately captures the dynamics of the system. This approach
becomes especially appealing when linear subspace explicitly depends on
parameters of the problem. A practical way to apply such a scheme is to compute
subspaces for a selected set of parameters in the computationally demanding
offline stage and in the online stage approximate subspace for unknown
parameters by interpolation. For realistic problems the space of parameters is
high dimensional, which renders classical interpolation strategies infeasible
or unreliable. We propose to relax the interpolation problem to regression,
introduce several loss functions suitable for subspace data, and use a neural
network as an approximation to high-dimensional target function. To further
simplify a learning problem we introduce redundancy: in place of predicting
subspace of a given dimension we predict larger subspace. We show theoretically
that this strategy decreases the complexity of the mapping for elliptic
eigenproblems with constant coefficients and makes the mapping smoother for
general smooth function on the Grassmann manifold. Empirical results also show
that accuracy significantly improves when larger-than-needed subspaces are
predicted. With the set of numerical illustrations we demonstrate that subspace
regression can be useful for a range of tasks including parametric
eigenproblems, deflation techniques, relaxation methods, optimal control and
solution of parametric partial differential equations.

AI.tldr: A neural-network-based regression approach to learn parametric subspaces for reduced-order models, using oversized subspaces to ease learning, with theoretical and empirical gains across parametric eigenproblems and PDE-related tasks.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional parameter spaces make interpolation of parameter-dependent subspaces impractical; need efficient offline/online ROM that adapts to parameters.
AI.method: Formulate subspace selection as regression on Grassmann manifold; use neural network to map parameters to subspace; predict larger-than-needed subspaces; develop suitable loss functions for subspace data; analyze theoretical properties; offline training with sampled parameters; apply to various tasks.
AI.result: The approach reduces mapping complexity (theory for elliptic eigenproblems) and smoothness (Grassmann). Empirically, predicting larger subspaces improves accuracy; demonstrates usefulness for parametric eigenproblems, deflation, relaxation, optimal control, and parametric PDEs.
AI.conclusion: Subspace regression is a viable, versatile tool for parametric reduced-order modeling, enabling improved online performance and broad applicability.

title: SynDoc: A Hybrid Discriminative-Generative Framework for Enhancing Synthetic Domain-Adaptive Document Key Information Extraction
summary:
Domain-specific Visually Rich Document Understanding (VRDU) presents
significant challenges due to the complexity and sensitivity of documents in
fields such as medicine, finance, and material science. Existing Large
(Multimodal) Language Models (LLMs/MLLMs) achieve promising results but face
limitations such as hallucinations, inadequate domain adaptation, and reliance
on extensive fine-tuning datasets. This paper introduces SynDoc, a novel
framework that combines discriminative and generative models to address these
challenges. SynDoc employs a robust synthetic data generation workflow, using
structural information extraction and domain-specific query generation to
produce high-quality annotations. Through adaptive instruction tuning, SynDoc
improves the discriminative model's ability to extract domain-specific
knowledge. At the same time, a recursive inferencing mechanism iteratively
refines the output of both models for stable and accurate predictions. This
framework demonstrates scalable, efficient, and precise document understanding
and bridges the gap between domain-specific adaptation and general world
knowledge for document key information extraction tasks.

AI.tldr: SynDoc proposes a hybrid discriminative-generative framework for domain-specific VRDU, leveraging synthetic data, adaptive instruction tuning, and recursive inference to improve robust, scalable key information extraction in regulated domains.
AI.motivation: Current LLMs (LLMs/MLLMs) suffer from hallucinations, limited domain adaptation, and costly fine-tuning when applied to visually rich documents in medicine, finance, and materials science.
AI.method: A hybrid framework combining discriminative and generative models with a synthetic data generation workflow (structural information extraction and domain-specific query generation), adaptive instruction tuning for the discriminative model, and a recursive inferencing mechanism that iteratively refines outputs from both models.
AI.result: Demonstrates scalable, efficient, and precise document understanding in domain-specific VRDU, bridging domain-specific adaptation with general world knowledge for document key information extraction tasks.
AI.conclusion: SynDoc offers a scalable, practical approach to domain-specific VRDU by integrating synthetic data, adaptive instruction tuning, and recursive inference to improve extraction accuracy and efficiency.

title: SafeFlowMatcher: Safe and Fast Planning using Flow Matching with Control Barrier Functions
summary:
Generative planners based on flow matching (FM) can produce high-quality
paths in one or a few ODE steps, but their sampling dynamics offer no formal
safety guarantees and can yield incomplete paths near constraints. We present
SafeFlowMatcher, a planning framework that couples FM with control barrier
functions (CBFs) to achieve both real-time efficiency and certified safety.
SafeFlowMatcher uses a two-phase prediction-correction (PC) integrator: (i) a
prediction phase integrates the learned FM once (or a few steps) to obtain a
candidate path without intervention; (ii) a correction phase refines this path
with a vanishing time-scaled vector field and a CBF-based quadratic program
that minimally perturbs the vector field. We prove a barrier certificate for
the resulting flow system, establishing forward invariance of a robust safe set
and finite-time convergence to the safe set. By enforcing safety only on the
executed path (rather than on all intermediate latent paths), SafeFlowMatcher
avoids distributional drift and mitigates local trap problems. Across maze
navigation and locomotion benchmarks, SafeFlowMatcher attains faster, smoother,
and safer paths than diffusion- and FM-based baselines. Extensive ablations
corroborate the contributions of the PC integrator and the barrier certificate.

AI.tldr: SafeFlowMatcher couples flow-matching planning with control barrier functions to ensure safety in real-time path planning, using a two-phase prediction-correction integrator to generate safe, smooth paths faster than baselines.
AI.motivation: FM-based generative planners are fast but lack formal safety guarantees and can produce incomplete paths near constraints; there is a need for certifiable safety in planning and execution.
AI.method: A two-phase prediction-correction (PC) integrator: (i) prediction phase runs the learned flow matcher once or a few steps to obtain a candidate path without intervention; (ii) correction phase refines this path with a vanishing-time-scaled vector field and a CBF-based quadratic program that minimally perturbs the vector field. A barrier certificate proves forward invariance of a robust safe set and finite-time convergence. Safety is enforced only on the executed path to avoid distributional drift and local traps. Evaluations on maze navigation and locomotion benchmarks show faster, smoother, and safer paths compared with diffusion- and FM-based baselines; ablations corroborate the PC integrator and barrier certificate contributions.
AI.result: The approach yields faster, smoother, and safer paths than baselines, with formal safety guarantees (forward invariance and finite-time convergence) and reduced distributional drift; it scales to maze and locomotion tasks and benefits from the PC and barrier components as shown by ablations.
AI.conclusion: SafeFlowMatcher provides certifiably safe, efficient flow-based planning by integrating control barrier functions into flow matching with a two-phase PC integrator, addressing safety and distributional-drift issues and improving planning performance over diffusion- and FM-based methods.

title: Automatic selection of primary studies in systematic reviews with evolutionary rule-based classification
summary:
Searching, filtering and analysing scientific literature are time-consuming
tasks when performing a systematic literature review. With the rise of
artificial intelligence, some steps in the review process are progressively
being automated. In particular, machine learning for automatic paper selection
can greatly reduce the effort required to identify relevant literature in
scientific databases. We propose an evolutionary machine learning approach,
called \ourmodel, to automatically determine whether a paper retrieved from a
literature search process is relevant. \ourmodel builds an interpretable
rule-based classifier using grammar-guided genetic programming. The use of a
grammar to define the syntax and the structure of the rules allows \ourmodel to
easily combine the usual textual information with other bibliometric data not
considered by state-of-the-art methods. Our experiments demonstrate that it is
possible to generate accurate classifiers without impairing interpretability
and using configurable information sources not supported so far.

AI.tldr: An interpretable, grammar-guided evolutionary ML method (OurModel) for automatic paper relevance classification in literature reviews, combining textual and bibliometric features to achieve accurate results without sacrificing interpretability.
AI.motivation: Systematic literature reviews are time-consuming; automating paper selection with ML can greatly reduce effort, and grammar-guided genetic programming enables integrating diverse features into interpretable rules.
AI.method: Proposes OurModel, an evolutionary ML approach using grammar-guided genetic programming to evolve rule-based classifiers. A grammar defines the syntax and structure of rules to combine textual information with bibliometric data, producing interpretable models.
AI.result: Experiments show that accurate classifiers can be generated without compromising interpretability, and the method supports configurable information sources beyond those used by prior state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: Grammar-guided evolutionary ML can effectively automate paper screening in literature reviews, delivering interpretable, accurate classifiers that leverage a wider set of information sources.

title: NanoFlux: Adversarial Dual-LLM Evaluation and Distillation For Multi-Domain Reasoning
summary:
We present NanoFlux, a novel adversarial framework for generating targeted
training data to improve LLM reasoning, where adversarially-generated datasets
containing fewer than 200 examples outperform conventional fine-tuning
approaches. The framework employs a competitive dynamic between models
alternating as Attacker and Defender, supervised by a tool-augmented Judge,
synthesizing multi-step questions with explanatory annotations that target
specific reasoning capabilities. Fine-tuning a 4B-parameter model on
NanoFlux-generated data yields performance gains across diverse domains
compared to full-benchmark fine-tuning: +5.9% on mathematical reasoning
(GSMHard), +3.6% on scientific reasoning (GenomeBench), and +16.6% on medical
reasoning (MultiMedQA), while reducing computational requirements by 3-14x.
Ablation studies reveal a non-monotonic relationship between dataset
characteristics and model performance, uncovering domain-specific optimal
points for question complexity and reasoning quality. NanoFlux automates
training data generation through embedding-based novelty filtering,
tool-augmented evaluation, and multi-hop reasoning, suggesting that future
model improvements may lie in the intelligent synthesis of small, precisely
targeted training datasets.

AI.tldr: NanoFlux uses a competitive Attacker/Defender loop with a tool-augmented Judge to auto-generate targeted, multi-hop Q&A data (≤200 examples) that improves LLM reasoning with less data and compute.
AI.motivation: Data-efficient improvement of LLM reasoning by generating small, precisely targeted training data to enhance specific reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: Adversarial framework with Attacker/Defender dynamics, a tool-augmented Judge, embedding-based novelty filtering, and multi-hop explanations; fine-tune a 4B model on NanoFlux data.
AI.result: Outperforms full-benchmark fine-tuning on GSMHard (+5.9%), GenomeBench (+3.6%), and MultiMedQA (+16.6%), using <200 examples and achieving 3–14x computational savings.
AI.conclusion: Targeted small datasets can yield strong domain-specific gains; there is a non-monotonic relationship between dataset properties and performance; future work lies in smart data synthesis and tooling.

title: Vid-Freeze: Protecting Images from Malicious Image-to-Video Generation via Temporal Freezing
comment: Under Review at ICASSP 26 4 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables
summary:
The rapid progress of image-to-video (I2V) generation models has introduced
significant risks, enabling video synthesis from static images and facilitating
deceptive or malicious content creation. While prior defenses such as I2VGuard
attempt to immunize images, effective and principled protection to block motion
remains underexplored. In this work, we introduce Vid-Freeze - a novel
attention-suppressing adversarial attack that adds carefully crafted
adversarial perturbations to images. Our method explicitly targets the
attention mechanism of I2V models, completely disrupting motion synthesis while
preserving semantic fidelity of the input image. The resulting immunized images
generate stand-still or near-static videos, effectively blocking malicious
content creation. Our experiments demonstrate the impressive protection
provided by the proposed approach, highlighting the importance of attention
attacks as a promising direction for robust and proactive defenses against
misuse of I2V generation models.

AI.tldr: Vid-Freeze is an attention-suppressing adversarial attack that perturbs images to disrupt motion synthesis in image-to-video models, producing stand-still videos while preserving image semantics.
AI.motivation: To address the risk of image-to-video models enabling deceptive or malicious video content, and to extend defenses beyond image immunization to block motion.
AI.method: Craft adversarial perturbations that suppress the model's attention mechanism, thereby preventing motion synthesis while retaining semantic fidelity of the input image.
AI.result: Immunized images yield stand-still or near-static videos; experiments show strong protection against motion synthesis and highlight attention-targeted attacks as a promising defensive direction.
AI.conclusion: Attention-focused adversarial defenses can effectively block motion generation in I2V systems, representing a proactive protection strategy against misuse.

title: Contextual Neural Moving Horizon Estimation for Robust Quadrotor Control in Varying Conditions
comment:
9 pages, 7 Figures, Kasra Torshizi and Chak Lam Shek contributed
  equally
summary:
Adaptive controllers on quadrotors typically rely on estimation of
disturbances to ensure robust trajectory tracking. Estimating disturbances
across diverse environmental contexts is challenging due to the inherent
variability and uncertainty in the real world. Such estimators require
extensive fine-tuning for a specific scenario, which makes them inflexible and
brittle to changing conditions. Machine-learning approaches, such as training a
neural network to tune the estimator's parameters, are promising. However,
collecting data across all possible environmental contexts is impossible. It is
also inefficient as the same estimator parameters could work for "nearby"
contexts. In this paper, we present a sequential decision making strategy that
decides which environmental contexts, using Bayesian Optimization with a
Gaussian Process, to collect data from in order to ensure robust performance
across a wide range of contexts. Our method, Contextual NeuroMHE, eliminates
the need for exhaustive training across all environments while maintaining
robust performance under different conditions. By enabling the neural network
to adapt its parameters dynamically, our method improves both efficiency and
generalization. Experimental results in various real-world settings demonstrate
that our approach outperforms the prior work by 20.3\% in terms of maximum
absolute position error and can capture the variations in the environment with
a few carefully chosen contexts.
