AI.tldr: Introduces Contextual NeuroMHE, a sequential decision-making framework using Bayesian Optimization with Gaussian Processes to select informative environmental contexts for training a neural estimator of disturbances in quadrotor control, improving robustness and data efficiency with a 20.3% reduction in maximum absolute position error.
AI.motivation: Disturbance estimation for quadrotor control is highly sensitive to environmental context. Traditional estimators require extensive, brittle tuning per scenario. ML-based tuning risks infeasible data collection across all contexts; there is a need for an approach that efficiently selects informative contexts to train a robust, generalizable estimator.
AI.method: A sequential decision-making strategy using Bayesian Optimization with a Gaussian Process to decide which environmental contexts to sample for data collection. The collected data tunes a neural network that adapts estimator parameters in a Contextual NeuroMHE framework, enabling dynamic adaptation without exhaustive multi-context training.
AI.result: Experimental results in real-world settings show a 20.3% improvement in maximum absolute position error over prior work and demonstrate that a small set of carefully chosen contexts can capture relevant environmental variations.
AI.conclusion: Contextual NeuroMHE improves efficiency and generalization by enabling dynamic parameter adaptation across contexts, reducing data collection burden while maintaining robust performance; the approach has potential applicability to disturbance estimation in robotics and beyond.

title: TusoAI: Agentic Optimization for Scientific Methods
summary:
Scientific discovery is often slowed by the manual development of
computational tools needed to analyze complex experimental data. Building such
tools is costly and time-consuming because scientists must iteratively review
literature, test modeling and scientific assumptions against empirical data,
and implement these insights into efficient software. Large language models
(LLMs) have demonstrated strong capabilities in synthesizing literature,
reasoning with empirical data, and generating domain-specific code, offering
new opportunities to accelerate computational method development. Existing
LLM-based systems either focus on performing scientific analyses using existing
computational methods or on developing computational methods or models for
general machine learning without effectively integrating the often unstructured
knowledge specific to scientific domains. Here, we introduce TusoAI , an
agentic AI system that takes a scientific task description with an evaluation
function and autonomously develops and optimizes computational methods for the
application. TusoAI integrates domain knowledge into a knowledge tree
representation and performs iterative, domain-specific optimization and model
diagnosis, improving performance over a pool of candidate solutions. We
conducted comprehensive benchmark evaluations demonstrating that TusoAI
outperforms state-of-the-art expert methods, MLE agents, and scientific AI
agents across diverse tasks, such as single-cell RNA-seq data denoising and
satellite-based earth monitoring. Applying TusoAI to two key open problems in
genetics improved existing computational methods and uncovered novel biology,
including 9 new associations between autoimmune diseases and T cell subtypes
and 7 previously unreported links between disease variants linked to their
target genes. Our code is publicly available at
https://github.com/Alistair-Turcan/TusoAI.

AI.tldr: TusoAI is an agentic AI system that autonomously develops and optimizes computational methods for scientific tasks using a knowledge-tree representation, outperforming baselines and enabling new biological findings, with open-source code.
AI.motivation: To accelerate scientific tool development by integrating domain knowledge with large language models, reducing manual literature review and programming effort, and improving reproducibility.
AI.method: TusoAI uses a knowledge-tree representation to embed domain knowledge, and performs iterative, domain-specific optimization and model diagnosis. It benchmarks its performance against expert methods, MLE agents, and scientific AI agents on tasks such as single-cell RNA-seq denoising and satellite-based earth monitoring, guided by a task-specific evaluation function.
AI.result: TusoAI outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across diverse tasks; applied to two open genetics problems, it uncovers novel biology, including 9 new associations between autoimmune diseases and T cell subtypes and 7 previously unreported links between disease variants and target genes; code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates that agentic AI can accelerate computational method development in science, improve performance, and yield novel biological insights, supported by open-source tooling.

title: ABConformer: Physics-inspired Sliding Attention for Antibody-Antigen Interface Prediction
summary:
Accurate prediction of antibody-antigen (Ab-Ag) interfaces is critical for
vaccine design, immunodiagnostics, and therapeutic antibody development.
However, achieving reliable predictions from sequences alone remains a
challenge. In this paper, we present ABCONFORMER, a model based on the
Conformer backbone that captures both local and global features of a
biosequence. To accurately capture Ab-Ag interactions, we introduced the
physics-inspired sliding attention, enabling residue-level contact recovery
without relying on three-dimensional structural data. ABConformer can
accurately predict paratopes and epitopes given the antibody and antigen
sequence, and predict pan-epitopes on the antigen without antibody information.
In comparison experiments, ABCONFORMER achieves state-of-the-art performance on
a recent SARS-CoV-2 Ab-Ag dataset, and surpasses widely used sequence-based
methods for antibody-agnostic epitope prediction. Ablation studies further
quantify the contribution of each component, demonstrating that, compared to
conventional cross-attention, sliding attention significantly enhances the
precision of epitope prediction. To facilitate reproducibility, we will release
the code under an open-source license upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: ABCONFORMER uses a Conformer-based backbone with physics-inspired sliding attention to predict antibody–antigen interfaces from sequence alone, achieving state-of-the-art results on a SARS-CoV-2 dataset and enabling paratope/epitope as well as pan-epitope predictions without structural data; ablation shows the sliding attention improves precision; code will be released.
AI.motivation: Predicting Ab–Ag interfaces from sequence alone is challenging yet crucial for vaccine design, diagnostics, and therapeutics because reliable 3D structures are costly or unavailable. The work aims to move beyond structure dependence by capturing local/global sequence features and residue-level contacts.
AI.method: Introduce ABCONFORMER with a Conformer backbone to capture local and global sequence features. Implement physics-inspired sliding attention to recover residue-level contacts without 3D structures. Predict paratopes and epitopes from antibody and antigen sequences, and pan-epitopes on the antigen without antibody information. Ablation studies compare sliding attention to conventional cross-attention to quantify contribution.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on a recent SARS-CoV-2 Ab–Ag dataset; outperforms common sequence-based methods for antibody-agnostic epitope prediction. Ablation confirms the contribution of sliding attention to improved epitope prediction precision.
AI.conclusion: Code will be released under an open-source license upon acceptance, facilitating reproducibility and enabling broader use in sequence-based Ab–Ag interface prediction and related applications.

title: Seeing Through the Blur: Unlocking Defocus Maps for Deepfake Detection
summary:
The rapid advancement of generative AI has enabled the mass production of
photorealistic synthetic images, blurring the boundary between authentic and
fabricated visual content. This challenge is particularly evident in deepfake
scenarios involving facial manipulation, but also extends to broader
AI-generated content (AIGC) cases involving fully synthesized scenes. As such
content becomes increasingly difficult to distinguish from reality, the
integrity of visual media is under threat. To address this issue, we propose a
physically interpretable deepfake detection framework and demonstrate that
defocus blur can serve as an effective forensic signal. Defocus blur is a
depth-dependent optical phenomenon that naturally occurs in camera-captured
images due to lens focus and scene geometry. In contrast, synthetic images
often lack realistic depth-of-field (DoF) characteristics. To capture these
discrepancies, we construct a defocus blur map and use it as a discriminative
feature for detecting manipulated content. Unlike RGB textures or
frequency-domain signals, defocus blur arises universally from optical imaging
principles and encodes physical scene structure. This makes it a robust and
generalizable forensic cue. Our approach is supported by three in-depth feature
analyses, and experimental results confirm that defocus blur provides a
reliable and interpretable cue for identifying synthetic images. We aim for our
defocus-based detection pipeline and interpretability tools to contribute
meaningfully to ongoing research in media forensics. The implementation is
publicly available at:
https://github.com/irissun9602/Defocus-Deepfake-Detection

AI.tldr: A physics-based defocus blur map is proposed as a robust, interpretable cue for detecting synthetic/deepfake images, supported by three feature analyses and experimental validation; the implementation is publicly available.
AI.motivation: As AI-generated content becomes increasingly realistic, there is a need for interpretable, generalizable forensic signals. Defocus blur encodes depth-of-field inconsistencies that are hard to fake accurately in synthetic images.
AI.method: Compute a defocus blur map from images to capture depth-dependent DoF characteristics and use it as a discriminative feature for deepfake detection. The approach is complemented by three in-depth feature analyses to support interpretability and relies on a detection pipeline with accompanying interpretability tools.
AI.result: Defocus blur provides a reliable and interpretable cue for distinguishing synthetic images from real ones; experimental results demonstrate robustness and generalizability across AI-generated content.
AI.conclusion: The proposed defocus-based framework contributes to media forensics by offering a physically grounded, interpretable detector for synthetic imagery, with code publicly available at the referenced repository.

title: Learning to Sample: Reinforcement Learning-Guided Sampling for Autonomous Vehicle Motion Planning
comment: 8 pages, submitted to the IEEE ICRA 2026, Vienna, Austria
summary:
Sampling-based motion planning is a well-established approach in autonomous
driving, valued for its modularity and analytical tractability. In complex
urban scenarios, however, uniform or heuristic sampling often produces many
infeasible or irrelevant trajectories. We address this limitation with a hybrid
framework that learns where to sample while keeping trajectory generation and
evaluation fully analytical and verifiable. A reinforcement learning (RL) agent
guides the sampling process toward regions of the action space likely to yield
feasible trajectories, while evaluation and final selection remains governed by
deterministic feasibility checks and cost functions. We couple the RL sampler
with a world model (WM) based on a decodable deep set encoder, enabling both
variable numbers of traffic participants and reconstructable latent
representations. The approach is evaluated in the CommonRoad simulation
environment, showing up to 99% fewer required samples and a runtime reduction
of up to 84% while maintaining planning quality in terms of success and
collision-free rates. These improvements lead to faster, more reliable
decision-making for autonomous vehicles in urban environments, achieving safer
and more responsive navigation under real-world constraints. Code and trained
artifacts are publicly available at:
https://github.com/TUM-AVS/Learning-to-Sample

AI.tldr: A hybrid RL-guided sampling framework for sampling-based motion planning in urban driving that reduces samples and computation while preserving analytical feasibility checks; integrates a world model with a decodable deep set encoder; validated in CommonRoad; open-sourced.
AI.motivation: Uniform or heuristic sampling in complex urban scenarios often yields many infeasible or irrelevant trajectories. The work aims to make planning faster and more reliable by guiding sampling while keeping analytical verification.
AI.method: An RL agent guides the sampling process toward regions of the action space more likely to yield feasible trajectories, while final evaluation remains governed by deterministic feasibility checks and cost functions. Paired with a world model based on a decodable deep set encoder to handle varying numbers of traffic participants and reconstruct latent representations.
AI.result: In the CommonRoad environment, the approach achieves up to 99% fewer samples and up to 84% runtime reduction, while maintaining planning quality in terms of success and collision-free rates.
AI.conclusion: The hybrid RL-guided sampling framework enables faster, more reliable decision-making for autonomous vehicles in urban environments under real-world constraints; code and trained artifacts are publicly available.

title: LLM/Agent-as-Data-Analyst: A Survey
summary:
Large language model (LLM) and agent techniques for data analysis (a.k.a
LLM/Agent-as-Data-Analyst) have demonstrated substantial impact in both
academica and industry. In comparison with traditional rule or small-model
based approaches, (agentic) LLMs enable complex data understanding, natural
language interfaces, semantic analysis functions, and autonomous pipeline
orchestration. The technical evolution further distills five key design goals
for intelligent data analysis agents, namely semantic-aware design,
modality-hybrid integration, autonomous pipelines, tool-augmented workflows,
and support for open-world tasks. From a modality perspective, we review
LLM-based techniques for (i) structured data (e.g., table question answering
for relational data and NL2GQL for graph data), (ii) semi-structured data
(e.g., markup languages understanding and semi-structured table modeling),
(iii) unstructured data (e.g., chart understanding, document understanding,
programming languages vulnerable detection), and (iv) heterogeneous data (e.g.,
data retrieval and modality alignment for data lakes). Finally, we outline the
remaining challenges and propose several insights and practical directions for
advancing LLM/Agent-powered data analysis.

AI.tldr: A survey of LLM/Agent-powered data analysis (LLM/Agent-as-Data-Analyst) that identifies five design goals, maps data modalities to techniques, and offers challenges and practical directions for future work.
AI.motivation: To surpass traditional rule-based and small-model approaches by enabling semantic understanding, natural-language interfaces, autonomous pipelines, and tool-augmented workflows for data analysis, across diverse data types and open-world tasks.
AI.method: A comprehensive review that (i) articulates five design goals—semantic-aware design, modality-hybrid integration, autonomous pipelines, tool-augmented workflows, open-world task support—and (ii) surveys techniques across data modalities (structured, semi-structured, unstructured, heterogeneous) to enable data analysis using LLMs and agents.
AI.result: Provides a taxonomy and synthesis of methods, identifies remaining challenges (e.g., multimodal integration, reliable tool use, open-world reasoning), and outlines practical directions for advancing LLM/Agent-powered data analysis (no empirical results reported).
AI.conclusion: LLM/Agent-powered data analysis is promising but requires progress on design goals and cross-modal capabilities; overcoming open-world task challenges will be crucial for widespread adoption.

title: CREPE: Controlling Diffusion with Replica Exchange
summary:
Inference-time control of diffusion models aims to steer model outputs to
satisfy new constraints without retraining. Previous approaches have mostly
relied on heuristic guidance or have been coupled with Sequential Monte Carlo
(SMC) for bias correction. In this paper, we propose a flexible alternative
based on replica exchange, an algorithm designed initially for sampling
problems. We refer to this method as the CREPE (Controlling with REPlica
Exchange). Unlike SMC, CREPE: (1) generates particles sequentially, (2)
maintains high diversity in the generated samples after a burn-in period, and
(3) enables online refinement or early termination. We demonstrate its
versatility across various tasks, including temperature annealing,
reward-tilting, model composition and classifier-free guidance debiasing, with
competitive performance compared to prior SMC methods.

AI.tldr: A replica-exchange-based method (CREPE) for inference-time control of diffusion models that samples sequentially, preserves sample diversity after burn-in, and supports online refinement, achieving competitive results with SMC across tasks like temperature annealing, reward tilting, model composition, and debiasing classifier-free guidance.
AI.motivation: To steer diffusion-model outputs without retraining and without relying solely on heuristic guidance or SMC bias correction, while preserving sample diversity and enabling online refinement during generation.
AI.method: Adaptation of replica-exchange sampling for inference-time control of diffusion models (CREPE). Particles are generated sequentially, maintaining diversity even after burn-in, with support for online termination and refinement. Applied to temperature annealing, reward tilting, model composition, and classifier-free guidance debiasing.
AI.result: Demonstrates versatility and competitive performance relative to prior SMC methods across multiple control tasks, showing that CREPE can replace or supplement SMC in inference-time steering of diffusion models.
AI.conclusion: CREPE provides a flexible alternative to SMC for inference-time control of diffusion models, offering sequential particle generation, sustained diversity after burn-in, and online refinement/termination with broad applicability across control tasks.

title: Seeing the Unseen in Low-light Spike Streams
summary:
Spike camera, a type of neuromorphic sensor with high-temporal resolution,
shows great promise for high-speed visual tasks. Unlike traditional cameras,
spike camera continuously accumulates photons and fires asynchronous spike
streams. Due to unique data modality, spike streams require reconstruction
methods to become perceptible to the human eye.
  However, lots of methods struggle to handle spike streams in low-light
high-speed scenarios due to severe noise and sparse information. In this work,
we propose Diff-SPK, the first diffusion-based reconstruction method for spike
camera. Diff-SPK effectively leverages generative priors to supplement texture
information in low-light conditions. Specifically, it first employs an
\textbf{E}nhanced \textbf{T}exture \textbf{f}rom Inter-spike \textbf{I}nterval
(ETFI) to aggregate sparse information from low-light spike streams. Then, ETFI
serves as a conditioning input for ControlNet to generate the high-speed
scenes. To improve the quality of results, we introduce an ETFI-based feature
fusion module during the generation process.
  Moreover, we establish the first bona fide benchmark for the low-light spike
stream reconstruction task. It significantly surpasses existing reconstruction
datasets in scale and provides quantitative illumination information. The
performance on real low-light spike streams demonstrates the superiority of
Diff-SPK.

AI.tldr: Diff-SPK uses a diffusion model conditioned on ETFI to reconstruct low-light spike camera data, addressing noise and sparsity; it introduces a new benchmark for evaluation.
AI.motivation: Spike cameras produce asynchronous spike streams with high temporal resolution, but in low-light/high-speed conditions the data is noisy and sparse, making reconstruction difficult. Existing methods struggle without strong priors; there is a need for generative-prior-based reconstruction and a reliable benchmark.
AI.method: Introduce ETFI (Enhanced Texture From Inter-spike Interval) to aggregate sparse information from low-light spike streams. Use ETFI as conditioning input for ControlNet to generate high-speed scenes via a diffusion model. Add an ETFI-based feature fusion module to improve generation quality. Establish the first bona fide benchmark for low-light spike stream reconstruction.
AI.result: Empirical results show Diff-SPK surpasses existing reconstruction datasets in scale and provides quantitative illumination information. Demonstrates superior performance on real low-light spike streams.
AI.conclusion: Diff-SPK provides an effective diffusion-based reconstruction framework for low-light spike streams by leveraging ETFI conditioning and feature fusion, and introduces a valuable benchmark for evaluation.

title: SONAR: Semantic-Object Navigation with Aggregated Reasoning through a Cross-Modal Inference Paradigm
summary:
Understanding human instructions and accomplishing Vision-Language Navigation
tasks in unknown environments is essential for robots. However, existing
modular approaches heavily rely on the quality of training data and often
exhibit poor generalization. Vision-Language Model based methods, while
demonstrating strong generalization capabilities, tend to perform
unsatisfactorily when semantic cues are weak. To address these issues, this
paper proposes SONAR, an aggregated reasoning approach through a cross modal
paradigm. The proposed method integrates a semantic map based target prediction
module with a Vision-Language Model based value map module, enabling more
robust navigation in unknown environments with varying levels of semantic cues,
and effectively balancing generalization ability with scene adaptability. In
terms of target localization, we propose a strategy that integrates multi-scale
semantic maps with confidence maps, aiming to mitigate false detections of
target objects. We conducted an evaluation of the SONAR within the Gazebo
simulator, leveraging the most challenging Matterport 3D (MP3D) dataset as the
experimental benchmark. Experimental results demonstrate that SONAR achieves a
success rate of 38.4% and an SPL of 17.7%.

AI.tldr: SONAR proposes an aggregated cross-modal framework forVision-Language Navigation, combining semantic-map based target prediction with a Vision-Language Model value map to improve navigation in unseen environments with varying semantic cues; evaluated in Gazebo on the MP3D benchmark, showing moderate gains.
AI.motivation: Modular VLN methods struggle to generalize beyond training data, while Vision-Language Models generalize poorly when semantic cues are weak. A cross-modal approach seeks to balance strong generalization with scene adaptability.
AI.method: Introduce SONAR, a cross-modal aggregated reasoning framework. It integrates a semantic-map based target prediction module with a Vision-Language Model based value map module. Target localization uses multi-scale semantic maps combined with confidence maps to reduce false positives. The system operates in unknown environments and leverages MP3D data in Gazebo for evaluation.
AI.result: In experiments on Gazebo using the MP3D benchmark, SONAR achieves a success rate of 38.4% and an SPL of 17.7%.
AI.conclusion: The cross-modal aggregation of semantic-map predictions and Vision-Language value maps enhances robustness to varying semantic cues and improves generalization-adaptability balance in VLN. While results are promising, performance remains task-dependent and could be further improved with refined target localization and more diverse evaluation scenarios.

title: Future-Proofing Programmers: Optimal Knowledge Tracing for AI-Assisted Personalized Education
comment:
The paper is accepted to IEEE Signal Processing Magazine, Special
  Issue on Artificial Intelligence for Education
summary:
Learning to learn is becoming a science, driven by the convergence of
knowledge tracing, signal processing, and generative AI to model student
learning states and optimize education. We propose CoTutor, an AI-driven model
that enhances Bayesian Knowledge Tracing with signal processing techniques to
improve student progress modeling and deliver adaptive feedback and strategies.
Deployed as an AI copilot, CoTutor combines generative AI with adaptive
learning technology. In university trials, it has demonstrated measurable
improvements in learning outcomes while outperforming conventional educational
tools. Our results highlight its potential for AI-driven personalization,
scalability, and future opportunities for advancing privacy and ethical
considerations in educational technology. Inspired by Richard Hamming's vision
of computer-aided 'learning to learn,' CoTutor applies convex optimization and
signal processing to automate and scale up learning analytics, while reserving
pedagogical judgment for humans, ensuring AI facilitates the process of
knowledge tracing while enabling learners to uncover new insights.

AI.tldr: CoTutor is an AI-driven system that augments Bayesian Knowledge Tracing with signal processing to deliver adaptive learning and shows improved outcomes in trials, highlighting scalability, personalization, and ethical considerations.
AI.motivation: To integrate knowledge tracing, signal processing, and generative AI to model student learning states at scale while preserving human pedagogical oversight and addressing privacy/ethics.
AI.method: Integrates Bayesian Knowledge Tracing with signal processing techniques; uses convex optimization; AI copilot architecture combining generative AI with adaptive learning tech; university trials to evaluate outcomes.
AI.result: Demonstrates measurable learning gains and outperforms conventional educational tools in university trials; evidence for personalization and scalability.
AI.conclusion: AI facilitates learning analytics while keeping human judgment central; points to privacy/ethics considerations and future opportunities in AI-driven education.

authors: Cornelis J. H. van der Velde
title: Transfer Learning and Machine Learning for Training Five Year Survival Prognostic Models in Early Breast Cancer
summary:
Prognostic information is essential for decision-making in breast cancer
management. Recently trials have predominantly focused on genomic
prognostication tools, even though clinicopathological prognostication is less
costly and more widely accessible. Machine learning (ML), transfer learning and
ensemble integration offer opportunities to build robust prognostication
frameworks. We evaluate this potential to improve survival prognostication in
breast cancer by comparing de-novo ML, transfer learning from a pre-trained
prognostic tool and ensemble integration. Data from the MA.27 trial was used
for model training, with external validation on the TEAM trial and a SEER
cohort. Transfer learning was applied by fine-tuning the pre-trained prognostic
tool PREDICT v3, de-novo ML included Random Survival Forests and Extreme
Gradient Boosting, and ensemble integration was realized through a weighted sum
of model predictions. Transfer learning, de-novo RSF, and ensemble integration
improved calibration in MA.27 over the pre-trained model (ICI reduced from
0.042 in PREDICT v3 to <=0.007) while discrimination remained comparable (AUC
increased from 0.738 in PREDICT v3 to 0.744-0.799). Invalid PREDICT v3
predictions were observed in 23.8-25.8% of MA.27 individuals due to missing
information. In contrast, ML models and ensemble integration could predict
survival regardless of missing information. Across all models, patient age,
nodal status, pathological grading and tumor size had the highest SHAP values,
indicating their importance for survival prognostication. External validation
in SEER, but not in TEAM, confirmed the benefits of transfer learning, RSF and
ensemble integration. This study demonstrates that transfer learning, de-novo
RSF, and ensemble integration can improve prognostication in situations where
relevant information for PREDICT v3 is lacking or where a dataset shift is
likely.

AI.tldr: Transfer learning, de-novo Random Survival Forests (RSF), and ensemble integration can improve calibration and maintain discrimination for breast cancer survival prognostication, especially when using PREDICT v3-derived data is incomplete or when distribution shifts occur.
AI.motivation: Clinicopathological prognostication is cheaper and more accessible than genomic tools. ML, transfer learning, and ensembles offer opportunities to improve prognostication robustness and usability across settings.
AI.method: Train on MA.27 trial data; validate externally on TEAM and SEER. Apply transfer learning by fine-tuning a pre-trained prognostic tool (PREDICT v3). Develop de-novo RSF and XGBoost-based prognostic models. Create an ensemble via weighted sum of predictions. Assess calibration (ICI) and discrimination (AUC); analyze SHAP for feature importance to identify key prognostic factors.
AI.result: Transfer learning, de-novo RSF, and ensemble integration improved calibration (ICI from 0.042 to ≤0.007) with discrimination preserved or improved (AUC 0.738→0.744–0.799). PREDICT v3 had 23.8–25.8% invalid predictions due to missing data; ML approaches could predict survival regardless of missing information. SHAP highlighted age, nodal status, tumor grade, and tumor size as top contributors. External validation supported benefits in SEER (not TEAM).
AI.conclusion: Transfer learning and ML ensembles can enhance breast cancer prognostication when pre-trained model data are incomplete or when dataset shift is likely, with external validation showing context-dependent benefits.

title: Balanced Diffusion-Guided Fusion for Multimodal Remote Sensing Classification
summary:
Deep learning-based techniques for the analysis of multimodal remote sensing
data have become popular due to their ability to effectively integrate
complementary spatial, spectral, and structural information from different
sensors. Recently, denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) have
attracted attention in the remote sensing community due to their powerful
ability to capture robust and complex spatial-spectral distributions. However,
pre-training multimodal DDPMs may result in modality imbalance, and effectively
leveraging diffusion features to guide complementary diversity feature
extraction remains an open question. To address these issues, this paper
proposes a balanced diffusion-guided fusion (BDGF) framework that leverages
multimodal diffusion features to guide a multi-branch network for land-cover
classification. Specifically, we propose an adaptive modality masking strategy
to encourage the DDPMs to obtain a modality-balanced rather than spectral
image-dominated data distribution. Subsequently, these diffusion features
hierarchically guide feature extraction among CNN, Mamba, and transformer
networks by integrating feature fusion, group channel attention, and
cross-attention mechanisms. Finally, a mutual learning strategy is developed to
enhance inter-branch collaboration by aligning the probability entropy and
feature similarity of individual subnetworks. Extensive experiments on four
multimodal remote sensing datasets demonstrate that the proposed method
achieves superior classification performance. The code is available at
https://github.com/HaoLiu-XDU/BDGF.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-guided fusion framework (BDGF) balances modalities in multimodal remote sensing, using diffusion features to guide a multi-branch network (CNN, Mamba, Transformer) with attention and mutual learning, achieving state-of-the-art land-cover classification on four datasets; code available.
AI.motivation: Pre-training multimodal diffusion models can cause modality imbalance and underutilization of complementary information. There is a need to leverage diffusion-derived features to enable diverse, complementary feature extraction across modalities in land-cover classification.
AI.method: Introduce adaptive modality masking to balance diffusion outputs; use diffusion features to hierarchically guide feature extraction across CNN, Mamba, and Transformer branches via feature fusion, group channel attention, and cross-attention; employ a mutual learning strategy to align probability entropy and feature similarity across subnetworks.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on four multimodal remote sensing datasets show that BDGF achieves superior classification performance compared to baselines, validating the effectiveness of modality balancing and diffusion-guided fusion.
AI.conclusion: BDGF effectively mitigates modality imbalance in multimodal diffusion models and leverages diffusion-derived features to guide diverse feature extraction, leading to improved land-cover classification in multimodal remote sensing.

title: AdaNav: Adaptive Reasoning with Uncertainty for Vision-Language Navigation
summary:
Vision Language Navigation (VLN) requires agents to follow natural language
instructions by grounding them in sequential visual observations over long
horizons. Explicit reasoning could enhance temporal consistency and perception
action alignment, but reasoning at fixed steps often leads to suboptimal
performance and unnecessary computation. To address this, we propose AdaNav, an
uncertainty-based adaptive reasoning framework for VLN. At its core is the
Uncertainty Adaptive Reasoning Block (UAR), a lightweight plugin that
dynamically triggers reasoning. We introduce Action Entropy as a policy prior
for UAR and progressively refine it through a Heuristics to RL training method,
enabling agents to learn difficulty aware reasoning policies under the strict
data limitations of embodied tasks. Results show that with only 6K training
samples, AdaNav achieves substantial gains over closed source models trained on
million scale data, improving success rate by 20% on R2R val-unseen, 11.7% on
RxR-CE, and 11.4% in real world scenes. The code is available at
https://github.com/xinding-sys/AdaNav.

AI.tldr: AdaNav introduces a light Uncertainty Adaptive Reasoning Block (UAR) that triggers reasoning only when needed via Action Entropy, enabling data-efficient Vision-Language Navigation and yielding notable gains across benchmarks with limited training data.
AI.motivation: VLN demands long-horizon grounding and coherent perception-action alignment, but fixed-step or excessive reasoning wastes computation and can harm performance, especially under strict data constraints. An uncertainty-aware, adaptive reasoning approach is needed.
AI.method: Propose Uncertainty Adaptive Reasoning Block (UAR) as a lightweight plugin. Use Action Entropy as a policy prior for UAR and employ a Heuristics-to-RL training regime to progressively refine the reasoning policy, enabling difficulty-aware reasoning with limited embodied-task data.
AI.result: With only 6K training samples, AdaNav substantially surpasses million-data closed-source models, achieving +20% SR on R2R val-unseen, +11.7% on RxR-CE, and +11.4% in real-world scenes. Code is available at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, uncertainty-driven reasoning can improve VLN performance efficiently, reducing unnecessary computation and enabling strong generalization under data scarcity; UAR serves as an effective, lightweight plugin for dynamic reasoning in embodied AI tasks.

title: Do Repetitions Matter? Strengthening Reliability in LLM Evaluations
summary:
LLM leaderboards often rely on single stochastic runs, but how many
repetitions are required for reliable conclusions remains unclear. We
re-evaluate eight state-of-the-art models on the AI4Math Benchmark with three
independent runs per setting. Using mixed-effects logistic regression,
domain-level marginal means, rank-instability analysis, and run-to-run
reliability, we assessed the value of additional repetitions. Our findings
shows that Single-run leaderboards are brittle: 10/12 slices (83\%) invert at
least one pairwise rank relative to the three-run majority, despite a zero
sign-flip rate for pairwise significance and moderate overall interclass
correlation. Averaging runs yields modest SE shrinkage ($\sim$5\% from one to
three) but large ranking gains; two runs remove $\sim$83\% of single-run
inversions. We provide cost-aware guidance for practitioners: treat evaluation
as an experiment, report uncertainty, and use $\geq 2$ repetitions under
stochastic decoding. These practices improve robustness while remaining
feasible for small teams and help align model comparisons with real-world
reliability.

AI.tldr: Single-run leaderboards are brittle; multiple independent repetitions (≥2, ideally 3) reduce rank inversions and improve reliability.
AI.motivation: To quantify how many repetitions are needed for robust model comparisons on LLM leaderboards and to assess the stability of rankings under stochastic decoding.
AI.method: Re-evaluate eight state-of-the-art models on the AI4Math Benchmark with three independent runs per setting; apply mixed-effects logistic regression, domain-level marginal means, rank-instability analysis, and run-to-run reliability analyses.
AI.result: Single-run leaderboards invert 83% of slices relative to the three-run majority; zero sign-flip rate for pairwise significance; modest SE shrinkage (~5% from one to three) with averaging but large ranking gains; two runs remove ~83% of single-run inversions.
AI.conclusion: Treat evaluation as an experiment, report uncertainty, and use ≥2 repetitions under stochastic decoding; these practices improve robustness and are feasible for small teams, aligning model comparisons with real-world reliability.

title: Continuous-Time Reinforcement Learning for Asset-Liability Management
comment:
Accepted at the 6th ACM International Conference on AI in Finance
  (ICAIF 2025), 8 pages, 2 figures
summary:
This paper proposes a novel approach for Asset-Liability Management (ALM) by
employing continuous-time Reinforcement Learning (RL) with a linear-quadratic
(LQ) formulation that incorporates both interim and terminal objectives. We
develop a model-free, policy gradient-based soft actor-critic algorithm
tailored to ALM for dynamically synchronizing assets and liabilities. To ensure
an effective balance between exploration and exploitation with minimal tuning,
we introduce adaptive exploration for the actor and scheduled exploration for
the critic. Our empirical study evaluates this approach against two enhanced
traditional financial strategies, a model-based continuous-time RL method, and
three state-of-the-art RL algorithms. Evaluated across 200 randomized market
scenarios, our method achieves higher average rewards than all alternative
strategies, with rapid initial gains and sustained superior performance. The
outperformance stems not from complex neural networks or improved parameter
estimation, but from directly learning the optimal ALM strategy without
learning the environment.

AI.tldr: A model-free continuous-time RL approach for Asset-Liability Management using a linear-quadratic formulation and a tailored Soft Actor-Critic, with adaptive actor exploration and scheduled critic exploration, achieving superior performance across 200 randomized market scenarios.
AI.motivation: Asset-Liability Management requires dynamic synchronization of assets and liabilities; traditional methods often rely on model-based risk estimates or complex optimization. A model-free framework that directly learns the optimal ALM policy can potentially improve performance and robustness.
AI.method: Develop a policy-gradient based soft actor-critic algorithm tailored to ALM within a continuous-time, linear-quadratic setting. Introduce adaptive exploration for the actor and scheduled exploration for the critic to balance exploration/exploitation with minimal tuning. Evaluate against enhanced traditional strategies, a model-based continuous-time RL method, and three state-of-the-art RL algorithms across 200 randomized market scenarios.
AI.result: The proposed method achieves higher average rewards than all baselines, with rapid initial gains and sustained superior performance across the 200 scenarios. The outperforming mechanism stems from directly learning the optimal ALM policy rather than learning the environment or relying on complex model estimation.
AI.conclusion: Directly learning the optimal ALM strategy via a model-free, continuous-time RL with LQ structure yields superior performance and robustness, without requiring sophisticated environment modeling or large neural architectures.

title: Seeing Symbols, Missing Cultures: Probing Vision-Language Models' Reasoning on Fire Imagery and Cultural Meaning
comment:
8 pages, 5 figures, 4 tables. Submitted to WiNLP 2025 Workshop at
  COLING 2025
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) often appear culturally competent but rely on
superficial pattern matching rather than genuine cultural understanding. We
introduce a diagnostic framework to probe VLM reasoning on fire-themed cultural
imagery through both classification and explanation analysis. Testing multiple
models on Western festivals, non-Western traditions, and emergency scenes
reveals systematic biases: models correctly identify prominent Western
festivals but struggle with underrepresented cultural events, frequently
offering vague labels or dangerously misclassifying emergencies as
celebrations. These failures expose the risks of symbolic shortcuts and
highlight the need for cultural evaluation beyond accuracy metrics to ensure
interpretable and fair multimodal systems.

AI.tldr: A diagnostic framework reveals cultural biases in Vision-Language Models (VLMs): models rely on superficial pattern matching rather than genuine cultural understanding. Western festivals are recognized well, while underrepresented cultures are often mislabeled or given vague labels, and emergencies can be misclassified as celebrations. This underscores risks of symbolic shortcuts and calls for cultural evaluation beyond accuracy to ensure interpretable, fair multimodal systems.
AI.motivation: VLMs often claim cultural competence but may lean on superficial cues. This study aims to systematically probe VLM reasoning on fire-themed cultural imagery to uncover biases, ensure safer deployment, and push toward evaluations that capture true cultural understanding rather than pattern shortcuts.
AI.method: Develop a diagnostic framework combining classification and explanation analysis. Test multiple VLMs on image sets including Western festivals, non-Western traditions, and emergency scenes. Assess accuracy, label quality, and the faithfulness/usefulness of explanations, focusing on systematic biases and risk of misclassification.
AI.result: Models show systematic biases: strong performance on prominent Western festivals but struggles with underrepresented cultural events, yielding vague labels or misclassifying emergencies as celebrations. Findings reveal reliance on symbolic shortcuts rather than genuine cultural understanding, highlighting risks in evaluation that focus only on accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Emphasizes the need for cultural evaluation beyond standard accuracy metrics to ensure interpretable, fair multimodal systems. Calls for diverse, culturally representative data, robust evaluation of reasoning, and safeguards against dangerous misclassifications.

title: DynaMIC: Dynamic Multimodal In-Context Learning Enabled Embodied Robot Counterfactual Resistance Ability
summary:
The emergence of large pre-trained models based on natural language has
breathed new life into robotics development. Extensive research has integrated
large models with robots, utilizing the powerful semantic understanding and
generation capabilities of large models to facilitate robot control through
natural language instructions gradually. However, we found that robots that
strictly adhere to human instructions, especially those containing misleading
information, may encounter errors during task execution, potentially leading to
safety hazards. This resembles the concept of counterfactuals in natural
language processing (NLP), which has not yet attracted much attention in
robotic research. In an effort to highlight this issue for future studies, this
paper introduced directive counterfactuals (DCFs) arising from misleading human
directives. We present DynaMIC, a framework for generating robot task flows to
identify DCFs and relay feedback to humans proactively. This capability can
help robots be sensitive to potential DCFs within a task, thus enhancing the
reliability of the execution process. We conducted semantic-level experiments
and ablation studies, showcasing the effectiveness of this framework.

AI.tldr: This paper highlights directive counterfactuals in robot instruction-following, introducing DCFs and a DynaMIC framework to generate task flows that detect misleading directives and proactively provide feedback to humans; semantic-level experiments and ablations show improved reliability.
AI.motivation: To address safety risks when robots strictly follow human instructions that may be misleading. The work connects counterfactual ideas from NLP to robotics, aiming to improve robustness and reliability by detecting and communicating potential misleading directives.
AI.method: Define directive counterfactuals (DCFs) and present DynaMIC, a framework that generates robot task flows to identify DCFs and relay feedback to humans. The approach is evaluated via semantic-level experiments and ablation studies to validate effectiveness.
AI.result: Semantic-level experiments and ablation studies demonstrate that DynaMIC effectively identifies potential DCFs and improves the reliability of task execution by guiding feedback mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: Directive counterfactuals are a pertinent safety concern in robot instruction following. DynaMIC provides a proactive framework to detect and communicate misleading directives, enhancing execution reliability and suggesting avenues for future research.

title: Fathom-DeepResearch: Unlocking Long Horizon Information Retrieval and Synthesis for SLMs
summary:
Tool-integrated reasoning has emerged as a key focus for enabling agentic
applications. Among these, DeepResearch Agents have gained significant
attention for their strong performance on complex, open-ended
information-seeking tasks. We introduce Fathom-DeepResearch, an agentic system
composed of two specialized models. The first is Fathom-Search-4B, a DeepSearch
model trained from Qwen3-4B and optimized for evidence-based investigation
through live web search and targeted webpage querying. Its training combines
three advances: (i) DUETQA, a 5K-sample dataset generated via multi-agent
self-play that enforces strict web-search dependence and heterogeneous source
grounding; (ii) RAPO, a zero-overhead extension of GRPO that stabilizes
multi-turn Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards through curriculum
pruning, reward-aware advantage scaling, and per-prompt replay buffers; and
(iii) a steerable step-level reward that classifies each tool call by cognitive
behavior and marginal utility, enabling explicit control over search trajectory
breadth, depth, and horizon. These improvements enable reliable extension of
tool-calling beyond 20 calls when warranted. The second is
Fathom-Synthesizer-4B, trained from Qwen3-4B, which converts multi-turn
DeepSearch traces into structured, citation-dense DeepResearch Reports for
comprehensive synthesis. Evaluated on DeepSearch benchmarks (SimpleQA, FRAMES,
WebWalker, Seal0, MuSiQue) and DeepResearch-Bench, the system achieves
state-of-the-art performance in the open-weights category while demonstrating
strong generalization to diverse reasoning tasks including HLE, AIME-25,
GPQA-Diamond, and MedQA.

AI.tldr: A dual-model agentic system, Fathom-DeepResearch, combining Fathom-Search-4B and Fathom-Synthesizer-4B to enable robust, tool-assisted reasoning with structured, citation-dense outputs; achieves state-of-the-art performance and strong generalization.
AI.motivation: To enable reliable, evidence-based, tool-integrated reasoning for open-ended information-seeking tasks by grounding searches, controlling tool use, and producing traceable synthesis.
AI.method: Two specialized models: (1) Fathom-Search-4B, trained from Qwen3-4B, leverages live web search and targeted querying. Its training uses DUETQA (5K-sample, multi-agent self-play) for strict web-grounding, RAPO (reward-aware, curriculum-pruned, zero-overhead extension of GRPO) for stable multi-turn RL with verifiable rewards, and a steerable, step-level reward that classifies each tool call by cognitive behavior and marginal utility to control search breadth/depth/horizon. This enables extending tool-calling beyond 20 calls. (2) Fathom-Synthesizer-4B, trained from Qwen3-4B, converts multi-turn search traces into structured, citation-dense DeepResearch Reports. Evaluation on DeepSearch benchmarks (SimpleQA, FRAMES, WebWalker, Seal0, MuSiQue) and DeepResearch-Bench shows state-of-the-art open-weights performance and strong generalization to HLE, AIME-25, GPQA-Diamond, and MedQA.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance in the open-weights category on DeepSearch benchmarks with robust generalization across diverse reasoning tasks (HLE, AIME-25, GPQA-Diamond, MedQA).
AI.conclusion: The Fathom-DeepResearch system demonstrates effective tool-integrated reasoning with controllable search trajectories and high-quality, citation-rich synthesis, achieving leading performance and generalization while enabling extended tool use when warranted.

title: A Neural ODE Approach to Aircraft Flight Dynamics Modelling
summary:
Accurate aircraft trajectory prediction is critical for air traffic
management, airline operations, and environmental assessment. This paper
introduces NODE-FDM, a Neural Ordinary Differential Equations-based Flight
Dynamics Model trained on Quick Access Recorder (QAR) data. By combining
analytical kinematic relations with data-driven components, NODE-FDM achieves a
more accurate reproduction of recorded trajectories than state-of-the-art
models such as a BADA-based trajectory generation methodology (BADA4
performance model combined with trajectory control routines), particularly in
the descent phase of the flight. The analysis demonstrates marked improvements
across altitude, speed, and mass dynamics. Despite current limitations,
including limited physical constraints and the limited availability of QAR
data, the results demonstrate the potential of physics-informed neural ordinary
differential equations as a high-fidelity, data-driven approach to aircraft
performance modelling. Future work will extend the framework to incorporate a
full modelling of the lateral dynamics of the aircraft.

AI.tldr: NODE-FDM is a physics-informed Neural Ordinary Differential Equations–based flight dynamics model trained on QAR data that fuses analytical kinematics with data-driven components to reproduce trajectories more accurately than BADA-based methods, notably in descent. Future work includes adding lateral dynamics.
AI.motivation: Accurate trajectory prediction is critical for air traffic management, airline operations, and environmental assessment. Existing models (e.g., BADA-based approaches) have limitations, especially in the descent phase and in capturing altitude, speed, and mass dynamics. A physics-informed neural ODE offers a data-driven yet physically grounded alternative.
AI.method: Propose NODE-FDM, a Neural Ordinary Differential Equations–based flight dynamics model trained on Quick Access Recorder (QAR) data. The model combines analytical kinematic relations with data-driven components to create a hybrid, physics-informed representation of aircraft dynamics.
AI.result: The approach yields more accurate reproduction of recorded trajectories than state-of-the-art models like BADA4, with notable improvements in altitude, speed, and mass dynamics, especially during descent. However, limitations include restricted physical constraints and limited availability of QAR data.
AI.conclusion: Physics-informed neural ODEs show promise as high-fidelity, data-driven aircraft performance models. Future work will extend the framework to model full lateral dynamics.

title: C3-OWD: A Curriculum Cross-modal Contrastive Learning Framework for Open-World Detection
summary:
Object detection has advanced significantly in the closed-set setting, but
real-world deployment remains limited by two challenges: poor generalization to
unseen categories and insufficient robustness under adverse conditions. Prior
research has explored these issues separately: visible-infrared detection
improves robustness but lacks generalization, while open-world detection
leverages vision-language alignment strategy for category diversity but
struggles under extreme environments. This trade-off leaves robustness and
diversity difficult to achieve simultaneously. To mitigate these issues, we
propose \textbf{C3-OWD}, a curriculum cross-modal contrastive learning
framework that unifies both strengths. Stage~1 enhances robustness by
pretraining with RGBT data, while Stage~2 improves generalization via
vision-language alignment. To prevent catastrophic forgetting between two
stages, we introduce an Exponential Moving Average (EMA) mechanism that
theoretically guarantees preservation of pre-stage performance with bounded
parameter lag and function consistency. Experiments on FLIR, OV-COCO, and
OV-LVIS demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach: C3-OWD achieves $80.1$
AP$^{50}$ on FLIR, $48.6$ AP$^{50}_{\text{Novel}}$ on OV-COCO, and $35.7$
mAP$_r$ on OV-LVIS, establishing competitive performance across both robustness
and diversity evaluations. Code available at:
https://github.com/justin-herry/C3-OWD.git.

AI.tldr: C3-OWD unifies robustness and open-world diversity via a two-stage curriculum cross-modal contrastive learning, with EMA to prevent forgetting; achieves strong results on FLIR, OV-COCO, OV-LVIS.
AI.motivation: There is a trade-off between robustness under adverse conditions and generalization to unseen/open-set categories in object detection; existing methods excel in one but not both.
AI.method: Two-stage curriculum: Stage1 pretraining with RGB-T data to boost robustness; Stage2 vision-language alignment to improve generalization across unseen categories; EMA mechanism to bound parameter lag and preserve pre-stage performance, aiming to prevent catastrophic forgetting.
AI.result: Empirical results on FLIR, OV-COCO, OV-LVIS show competitive performance across robustness and open-world evaluation; code released.
AI.conclusion: C3-OWD demonstrates that combining modality-driven robustness and cross-modal generalization with controlled forgetting yields balanced performance; EMA theory provides a bound on forgetting.

title: PhysiAgent: An Embodied Agent Framework in Physical World
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have achieved notable success but often
struggle with limited generalizations. To address this, integrating generalized
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) as assistants to VLAs has emerged as a popular
solution. However, current approaches often combine these models in rigid,
sequential structures: using VLMs primarily for high-level scene understanding
and task planning, and VLAs merely as executors of lower-level actions, leading
to ineffective collaboration and poor grounding challenges. In this paper, we
propose an embodied agent framework, PhysiAgent, tailored to operate
effectively in physical environments. By incorporating monitor, memory,
self-reflection mechanisms, and lightweight off-the-shelf toolboxes, PhysiAgent
offers an autonomous scaffolding framework to prompt VLMs to organize different
components based on real-time proficiency feedback from VLAs to maximally
exploit VLAs' capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate significant
improvements in task-solving performance on complex real-world robotic tasks,
showcasing effective self-regulation of VLMs, coherent tool collaboration, and
adaptive evolution of the framework during execution. PhysiAgent makes
practical and pioneering efforts to integrate VLMs and VLAs, effectively
grounding embodied agent frameworks in real-world settings.

AI.tldr: PhysiAgent introduces an embodied scaffolding framework that orchestrates Vision-Language Models (VLMs) and Vision-Language-Action agents (VLAs) via monitor, memory, and self-reflection, plus lightweight tools, to dynamically organize components and leverage real-time proficiency feedback for better grounding and performance in real-world robotics.
AI.motivation: Current VLA–VLM integration relies on rigid, sequential roles (VLMs for high-level understanding and planning, VLAs for low-level execution), which hampers generalization and grounding in real-world tasks. There is a need for a dynamic, self-regulating framework that can adaptively marshal VLMs' capabilities in embodied settings.
AI.method: Introduce PhysiAgent, an embodied agent framework with monitor, memory, self-reflection mechanisms, and lightweight off-the-shelf toolboxes. It provides autonomous scaffolding that prompts VLMs to organize components based on real-time proficiency feedback from VLAs, enabling coherent tool collaboration and adaptive evolution during execution.
AI.result: Demonstrates significant improvements on complex real-world robotic tasks, showing effective self-regulation of VLMs, coherent tool collaboration, and adaptive framework evolution during execution.
AI.conclusion: PhysiAgent offers a practical, pioneering step toward grounding and integrating VLMs with VLAs in embodied agents for real-world settings, improving collaboration and task performance through adaptive coordination.

title: Transparent, Evaluable, and Accessible Data Agents: A Proof-of-Concept Framework
summary:
This article presents a modular, component-based architecture for developing
and evaluating AI agents that bridge the gap between natural language
interfaces and complex enterprise data warehouses. The system directly
addresses core challenges in data accessibility by enabling non-technical users
to interact with complex data warehouses through a conversational interface,
translating ambiguous user intent into precise, executable database queries to
overcome semantic gaps. A cornerstone of the design is its commitment to
transparent decision-making, achieved through a multi-layered reasoning
framework that explains the "why" behind every decision, allowing for full
interpretability by tracing conclusions through specific, activated business
rules and data points. The architecture integrates a robust quality assurance
mechanism via an automated evaluation framework that serves multiple functions:
it enables performance benchmarking by objectively measuring agent performance
against golden standards, and it ensures system reliability by automating the
detection of performance regressions during updates. The agent's analytical
depth is enhanced by a statistical context module, which quantifies deviations
from normative behavior, ensuring all conclusions are supported by quantitative
evidence including concrete data, percentages, and statistical comparisons. We
demonstrate the efficacy of this integrated agent-development-with-evaluation
framework through a case study on an insurance claims processing system. The
agent, built on a modular architecture, leverages the BigQuery ecosystem to
perform secure data retrieval, apply domain-specific business rules, and
generate human-auditable justifications. The results confirm that this approach
creates a robust, evaluable, and trustworthy system for deploying LLM-powered
agents in data-sensitive, high-stakes domains.

AI.tldr: A modular, explainable framework for building and evaluating LLM-powered agents that query enterprise data warehouses via natural language, with multi-layered reasoning, automated evaluation, and quantitative support; demonstrated in insurance claims with BigQuery integration.
AI.motivation: Bridge the semantic gap between natural language interfaces and complex data warehouses, enabling non-technical users to access data. Improve interpretability, auditability, and reliability in high-stakes environments through transparent decision-making and automated evaluation.
AI.method: A component-based architecture that supports conversational NL interfaces translating user intents into executable database queries. Incorporates a multi-layered reasoning framework for explainability, automated evaluation for benchmarking and regression detection, a statistical context module to quantify deviations, and BigQuery-based secure data retrieval with domain-specific business rules and human-auditable justifications.
AI.result: Empirical demonstration in an insurance claims case study showing robust, evaluable, and trustworthy operation. The evaluation framework provides objective performance benchmarks against golden standards and automated detection of regressions, with quantitative evidence supporting conclusions.
AI.conclusion: The integrated agent-development-with-evaluation framework is effective for deploying LLM-powered agents in data-sensitive, high-stakes domains. It enhances transparency, trust, and reliability, and is scalable to enterprise data warehouses (e.g., BigQuery) for secure data access and auditable decision-making.

title: ASTGI: Adaptive Spatio-Temporal Graph Interactions for Irregular Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
summary:
Irregular multivariate time series (IMTS) are prevalent in critical domains
like healthcare and finance, where accurate forecasting is vital for proactive
decision-making. However, the asynchronous sampling and irregular intervals
inherent to IMTS pose two core challenges for existing methods: (1) how to
accurately represent the raw information of irregular time series without
introducing data distortion, and (2) how to effectively capture the complex
dynamic dependencies between observation points. To address these challenges,
we propose the Adaptive Spatio-Temporal Graph Interaction (ASTGI) framework.
Specifically, the framework first employs a Spatio-Temporal Point
Representation module to encode each discrete observation as a point within a
learnable spatio-temporal embedding space. Second, a Neighborhood-Adaptive
Graph Construction module adaptively builds a causal graph for each point in
the embedding space via nearest neighbor search. Subsequently, a
Spatio-Temporal Dynamic Propagation module iteratively updates information on
these adaptive causal graphs by generating messages and computing interaction
weights based on the relative spatio-temporal positions between points.
Finally, a Query Point-based Prediction module generates the final forecast by
aggregating neighborhood information for a new query point and performing
regression. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate
that ASTGI outperforms various state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: ASTGI is a framework for irregular multivariate time series forecasting that uses a learnable spatio-temporal embedding, adaptive nearest-neighbor causal graphs, dynamic message propagation, and query-point prediction to achieve state-of-the-art performance.
AI.motivation: Irregular sampling and asynchronous intervals in IMTS hinder effective representation and dependency modeling; existing methods struggle with data distortion and complex dependencies.
AI.method: 1) Spatio-Temporal Point Representation to embed observations; 2) Neighborhood-Adaptive Graph Construction via nearest neighbors to form adaptive causal graphs; 3) Spatio-Temporal Dynamic Propagation to update messages and interaction weights; 4) Query Point-based Prediction to forecast by aggregating neighborhood info for new query point and regression.
AI.result: Empirical results on multiple benchmarks show ASTGI outperforms various SOTA methods.
AI.conclusion: ASTGI effectively handles irregular multivariate time series forecasting with adaptive graphs and spatio-temporal propagation, improving accuracy.

title: Spatial-Spectral Binarized Neural Network for Panchromatic and Multi-spectral Images Fusion
summary:
Remote sensing pansharpening aims to reconstruct spatial-spectral properties
during the fusion of panchromatic (PAN) images and low-resolution
multi-spectral (LR-MS) images, finally generating the high-resolution
multi-spectral (HR-MS) images. Although deep learning-based models have
achieved excellent performance, they often come with high computational
complexity, which hinder their applications on resource-limited devices. In
this paper, we explore the feasibility of applying the binary neural network
(BNN) to pan-sharpening. Nevertheless, there are two main issues with
binarizing pan-sharpening models: (i) the binarization will cause serious
spectral distortion due to the inconsistent spectral distribution of the
PAN/LR-MS images; (ii) the common binary convolution kernel is difficult to
adapt to the multi-scale and anisotropic spatial features of remote sensing
objects, resulting in serious degradation of contours. To address the above
issues, we design the customized spatial-spectral binarized convolution
(S2B-Conv), which is composed of the Spectral-Redistribution Mechanism (SRM)
and Gabor Spatial Feature Amplifier (GSFA). Specifically, SRM employs an affine
transformation, generating its scaling and bias parameters through a dynamic
learning process. GSFA, which randomly selects different frequencies and angles
within a preset range, enables to better handle multi-scale and-directional
spatial features. A series of S2B-Conv form a brand-new binary network for
pan-sharpening, dubbed as S2BNet. Extensive quantitative and qualitative
experiments have shown our high-efficiency binarized pan-sharpening method can
attain a promising performance.

AI.tldr: A specialized binary network, S2BNet, for pan-sharpening uses Spectral-Redistribution Mechanism (SRM) and Gabor Spatial Feature Amplifier (GSFA) to mitigate spectral distortion and capture multi-scale spatial features, achieving high efficiency with competitive performance.
AI.motivation: Reduce computational complexity of deep pan-sharpening on resource-constrained devices. Binarization often causes spectral distortion and poor handling of multi-scale/anisotropic spatial features; the paper aims to address these issues.
AI.method: Introduce S2B-Conv consisting of SRM, which uses an affine transformation with dynamically learned scale and bias, and GSFA, which randomly selects frequencies and angles within a preset range. Stack multiple S2B-Conv to form the S2BNet for pan-sharpening.
AI.result: Extensive quantitative and qualitative experiments show high-efficiency binarized pan-sharpening with promising performance.
AI.conclusion: S2BNet demonstrates feasibility of binarized pan-sharpening for remote sensing pan-sharpening, addressing spectral distortion and contour degradation, with potential for deployment on resource-limited devices; future work may explore further improvements and generalization.

title: Game Theory to Study Cooperation in Human-Robot Mixed Groups: Exploring the Potential of the Public Good Game
comment:
Work presented at the workshop BAILAR in conjunction with IEEE RO-MAN
  2023. Peer reviewed
summary:
In this study, we explore the potential of Game Theory as a means to
investigate cooperation and trust in human-robot mixed groups. Particularly, we
introduce the Public Good Game (PGG), a model highlighting the tension between
individual self-interest and collective well-being. In this work, we present a
modified version of the PGG, where three human participants engage in the game
with the humanoid robot iCub to assess whether various robot game strategies
(e.g., always cooperate, always free ride, and tit-for-tat) can influence the
participants' inclination to cooperate. We test our setup during a pilot study
with nineteen participants. A preliminary analysis indicates that participants
prefer not to invest their money in the common pool, despite they perceive the
robot as generous. By conducting this research, we seek to gain valuable
insights into the role that robots can play in promoting trust and cohesion
during human-robot interactions within group contexts. The results of this
study may hold considerable potential for developing social robots capable of
fostering trust and cooperation within mixed human-robot groups.

AI.tldr: A pilot study tests a modified Public Good Game with iCub to see if robot strategies affect human cooperation; initial results show participants hesitate to contribute despite perceiving the robot as generous, highlighting challenges in robot-enabled trust within mixed groups.
AI.motivation: To evaluate whether game-theoretic frameworks can illuminate cooperation and trust dynamics in human-robot mixed groups and to explore if robot game strategies can steer cooperative behavior.
AI.method: A modified Public Good Game involving three human participants collaborating with the humanoid robot iCub; robot strategies tested include always cooperate, always free ride, and tit-for-tat; pilot study conducted with nineteen participants.
AI.result: Preliminary analysis indicates participants prefer not to invest in the common pool even when the robot is perceived as generous, suggesting limited immediate impact of robot strategy on cooperation; results point to the potential value of robots in promoting trust and cohesion in mixed human-robot groups.
AI.conclusion: The study aims to glean insights on how robots can foster trust and cooperation in group contexts; while participants showed reluctance to contribute, the work points to the promise of social robots in facilitating trust and cohesion, with implications for design of robot-mediated group interactions.

title: Reasoning or Retrieval? A Study of Answer Attribution on Large Reasoning Models
summary:
Large reasoning models (LRMs) exhibit unprecedented capabilities in solving
complex problems through Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning. However, recent
studies reveal that their final answers often contradict their own reasoning
traces. We hypothesize that this inconsistency stems from two competing
mechanisms for generating answers: CoT reasoning and memory retrieval. To test
this hypothesis, we conduct controlled experiments that challenge LRMs with
misleading cues during reasoning and/or corrupted answers during retrieval. Our
results across models and datasets confirm that both mechanisms operate
simultaneously, with their relative dominance influenced by multiple factors:
problem domains, model scales, and fine-tuning approaches (e.g., reinforcement
learning vs. distillation). The findings reveal a critical limitation in
current reasoning fine-tuning paradigms: models can exploit the retrieval
mechanism as a shortcut, effectively "hacking" the reward signal and
undermining genuine reasoning development. To address this challenge, we
introduce FARL, a novel fine-tuning framework that integrates memory unlearning
with reinforcement learning. By carefully suppressing retrieval shortcuts
during the fine-tuning process, FARL promotes reasoning-dominant behavior and
enhances generalizable reasoning capabilities.

AI.tldr: LRMs' final answers can conflict with their own reasoning traces due to competing CoT and memory retrieval; a new fine-tuning method FARL suppresses retrieval shortcuts to emphasize reasoning.
AI.motivation: to diagnose the source of inconsistency and improve robustness of LRM reasoning under noisy cues.
AI.method: perform controlled experiments with misleading cues during reasoning and corrupted retrieval; assess across models, domains, and fine-tuning methods; introduce FARL combining memory unlearning with reinforcement learning.
AI.result: both CoT reasoning and retrieval influence answers; their dominance varies with domain, model scale, and fine-tuning; retrieval shortcuts can hijack reward signals, undermining genuine reasoning.
AI.conclusion: FARL can suppress retrieval shortcuts and foster reasoning-dominant behavior, enhancing generalizable reasoning capabilities.

title: Two-Scale Latent Dynamics for Recurrent-Depth Transformers
summary:
Recurrent-depth transformers scale test-time compute by iterating latent
computations before emitting tokens. We study the geometry of these iterates
and argue for a simple, \emph{two-scale} operational picture: (i) within a
looped block, updates act as \emph{small-scale refinements}; (ii) across
consecutive blocks, states undergo a \emph{larger-scale drift}. Across
checkpoints, our measurements show that loop steps become \emph{smaller} and
increasingly \emph{orthogonal} to one another, indicating better local modeling
of fine structure rather than merely pushing in a single direction. These
dynamics motivate an early-exit mechanism based on the model's second-order
difference in step-size, which we show is superior in terms of performance,
stability and time-efficiency, when compared to the KL-divergence exit strategy
of Geiping et al. and its naive first-order counterpart.

AI.tldr: Two-scale dynamics in recurrent-depth transformers: small-scale refinements inside looped blocks and larger-scale drift across blocks. Loop updates shrink and become more orthogonal over time, suggesting improved local modeling of fine structure. Proposes an early-exit based on the second-order difference in step-size, which outperforms KL-divergence exit and first-order methods in performance, stability, and time-efficiency.
AI.motivation: To understand the geometry of iterates in recurrent-depth transformers to inform efficient, stable late-stage inference and to develop principled exit criteria.
AI.method: Empirical analysis of latent iterates across looped blocks and checkpoints; measure step-size and directional changes (orthogonality) of updates; compare exit strategies—second-order difference-based exit vs KL-divergence exit (Geiping et al.) and naive first-order exits.
AI.result: Validation of a two-scale operational picture: within-block updates act as small refinements while across-block states drift at a larger scale; loop steps diminish in magnitude and become increasingly orthogonal over checkpoints. The second-order difference in step-size yields superior performance, stability, and time efficiency compared to KL-divergence exit and first-order exits.
AI.conclusion: The study supports a two-scale view of recurrent-depth transformers and introduces a second-order step-size-based early exit that improves efficiency and stability over prior exit strategies.

title: Decoupling Reasoning and Perception: An LLM-LMM Framework for Faithful Visual Reasoning
summary:
Significant advancements in the reasoning capabilities of Large Language
Models (LLMs) are now driven by test-time scaling laws, particularly those
leveraging extended Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning. Inspired by these
breakthroughs, researchers have extended these paradigms to Large Multimodal
Models (LMMs). However, a critical limitation emerges: as their reasoning
chains extend, LMMs increasingly rely on textual logic, progressively losing
grounding in the underlying visual information. This leads to reasoning paths
that diverge from the image content, culminating in erroneous conclusions. To
address this, we introduce a strikingly simple yet effective training-free
visual-reasoning pipeline. The core concept is to decouple the reasoning and
perception processes. A powerful LLM orchestrates the high-level reasoning,
strategically interrogating a LMM to extract specific visual information
required for its logical chain. The LMM, in turn, functions exclusively as a
visual question-answering engine, supplying the necessary perceptual details on
demand. This lightweight, plug-and-play approach requires no additional
training or architectural changes. Comprehensive evaluations validate that our
framework effectively governs the visual reasoning process, leading to a
significant reduction in visually-unfounded reasoning steps and a substantial
improvement in reasoning fidelity.

AI.tldr: A training-free visual-reasoning pipeline that decouples reasoning from perception in LMMs, using an LLM to direct targeted visual queries to a LMM VQA engine.
AI.motivation: To address the problem that extended multimodal reasoning chains in LMMs drift from visual grounding, causing visually unfounded conclusions, by keeping perception and reasoning separate in a simple plug-and-play setup without retraining.
AI.method: An LLM performs high-level reasoning and governs the process by strategically querying a LMM to obtain only the visual information needed for its logical chain. The LMM acts solely as a visual question-answering engine, supplying perceptual details on demand. The system requires no additional training or architectural changes.
AI.result: Comprehensive evaluations show a significant reduction in visually unfounded reasoning steps and a substantial improvement in reasoning fidelity compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: The proposed training-free visual-reasoning pipeline effectively governs visual reasoning, offering a simple, plug-and-play solution that preserves grounding to visual content and improves reasoning quality.

title: Unlocking the Potential of Soft Actor-Critic for Imitation Learning
summary:
Learning-based methods have enabled robots to acquire bio-inspired movements
with increasing levels of naturalness and adaptability. Among these, Imitation
Learning (IL) has proven effective in transferring complex motion patterns from
animals to robotic systems. However, current state-of-the-art frameworks
predominantly rely on Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), an on-policy
algorithm that prioritizes stability over sample efficiency and policy
generalization. This paper proposes a novel IL framework that combines
Adversarial Motion Priors (AMP) with the off-policy Soft Actor-Critic (SAC)
algorithm to overcome these limitations. This integration leverages
replay-driven learning and entropy-regularized exploration, enabling
naturalistic behavior and task execution, improving data efficiency and
robustness. We evaluate the proposed approach (AMP+SAC) on quadruped gaits
involving multiple reference motions and diverse terrains. Experimental results
demonstrate that the proposed framework not only maintains stable task
execution but also achieves higher imitation rewards compared to the widely
used AMP+PPO method. These findings highlight the potential of an off-policy IL
formulation for advancing motion generation in robotics.

AI.tldr: An off-policy imitation learning framework AMP+SAC that combines Adversarial Motion Priors with Soft Actor-Critic to improve data efficiency and imitation quality over AMP+PPO in quadruped locomotion.
AI.motivation: Current state-of-the-art IL often relies on PPO, which is on-policy and trades off sample efficiency and generalization. There is a need for more data-efficient, robust, and generalizable motion imitation in robotics.
