AI.method: Proposes AMP+SAC: integrate Adversarial Motion Priors with the off-policy SAC, leveraging replay-driven learning and entropy-regularized exploration; evaluate on quadruped gaits across multiple reference motions and terrains.
AI.result: AMP+SAC achieves stable task execution and higher imitation rewards than AMP+PPO, demonstrating improved data efficiency and robustness in diverse terrains.
AI.conclusion: Off-policy IL with AMP+SAC is a promising direction for robotic motion generation, potentially enabling more natural and adaptable behaviors; future work could explore broader tasks, transferability, and stability considerations in off-policy IL.

title: Robust Preference Optimization: Aligning Language Models with Noisy Preference Feedback
summary:
Standard human preference-based alignment methods, such as Reinforcement
Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF), are a cornerstone technology for aligning
Large Language Models (LLMs) with human values. However, these methods are all
underpinned by a critical, yet flawed assumption: human preferences are
homogeneous (representing a single, unified preference) and the collected data
is noiseless (free from error). In reality, neither is true since human
preference is pluralistic and annotators can make mistakes. This creates a
discrepancy between the recorded data and the ground-truth preferences, which
can misguide the model and degrade its performance. To address this challenge,
we introduce Robust Preference Optimization (RPO). RPO employs an
Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm to infer the posterior probability of
each label's correctness, which is used to adaptively re-weigh each data point
in the training loss to mitigate noise. We further generalize this approach by
establishing a theoretical link between arbitrary preference losses and their
corresponding probabilistic models. This generalization enables the systematic
transformation of existing alignment algorithms into their robust counterparts,
elevating RPO from a specific algorithm to a meta-framework for robust
preference alignment. Theoretically, we prove that under the condition of a
perfectly calibrated model, RPO is guaranteed to converge to the true noise
level of the dataset. Our experiments demonstrate RPO's effectiveness as a
meta-framework, consistently enhancing four state-of-the-art alignment
algorithms (DPO, IPO, SimPO, and CPO). When applied to Mistral and Llama 3
models, the RPO-enhanced methods achieve substantial win rate gains on
AlpacaEval 2 and Arena-Hard, with improvements of up to 7.0% and 5.4%,
respectively.

AI.tldr: Robust Preference Optimization (RPO) introduces an EM-based framework to handle noisy/multi-valued human preferences and generalizes to convert existing alignment losses into robust versions; proven to converge to true noise under a calibrated model; improves four state-of-the-art algorithms and yields gains on AlpacaEval 2 and Arena-Hard.
AI.motivation: Human preferences are pluralistic and annotators can err; standard RLHF assumes homogeneous/noiseless data, which is unrealistic and can misguide models. There is a need for a robust framework that accounts for label noise and varying preferences.
AI.method: An Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm is used to infer posterior probabilities of the correctness of each label, enabling adaptive re-weighting of data points in the training loss. The work also establishes a theoretical link between general preference losses and probabilistic models, turning existing alignment methods into robust counterparts. This yields a meta-framework for robust preference alignment and applies to methods like DPO, IPO, SimPO, and CPO.
AI.result: Empirically, RPO enhances performance of four alignment algorithms across models Mistral and Llama 3, with win-rate gains on AlpacaEval 2 (up to 7.0%) and Arena-Hard (up to 5.4%). Theoretically, under perfect calibration, RPO converges to the true dataset noise level.
AI.conclusion: RPO provides a general, theoretically grounded framework for robust preference alignment that mitigates label noise and annotator disagreement. It can improve existing alignment methods and offers convergence guarantees under calibration, making it a versatile tool for making LLM alignment more reliable.

title: MELCOT: A Hybrid Learning Architecture with Marginal Preservation for Matrix-Valued Regression
summary:
Regression is essential across many domains but remains challenging in
high-dimensional settings, where existing methods often lose spatial structure
or demand heavy storage. In this work, we address the problem of matrix-valued
regression, where each sample is naturally represented as a matrix. We propose
MELCOT, a hybrid model that integrates a classical machine learning-based
Marginal Estimation (ME) block with a deep learning-based Learnable-Cost
Optimal Transport (LCOT) block. The ME block estimates data marginals to
preserve spatial information, while the LCOT block learns complex global
features. This design enables MELCOT to inherit the strengths of both classical
and deep learning methods. Extensive experiments across diverse datasets and
domains demonstrate that MELCOT consistently outperforms all baselines while
remaining highly efficient.

AI.tldr: MELCOT is a hybrid matrix-valued regression model that combines Marginal Estimation to preserve spatial structure with a Learnable-Cost Optimal Transport block to capture global features, achieving superior efficiency and accuracy across tasks.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional regression with matrix-valued data where preserving spatial structure is important and computational efficiency is challenging.
AI.method: Hybrid MELCOT: ME block estimates data marginals to preserve spatial information; LCOT block learns global features; integrates classical and deep-learning components.
AI.result: Across diverse datasets, MELCOT outperforms all baselines and remains highly efficient.
AI.conclusion: Combining classical estimators with deep learning-based optimal transport yields robust performance; potential generalization to various matrix-valued regression tasks.

title: DDP: Dual-Decoupled Prompting for Multi-Label Class-Incremental Learning
summary:
Prompt-based methods have shown strong effectiveness in single-label
class-incremental learning, but their direct extension to multi-label
class-incremental learning (MLCIL) performs poorly due to two intrinsic
challenges: semantic confusion from co-occurring categories and
true-negative-false-positive confusion caused by partial labeling. We propose
Dual-Decoupled Prompting (DDP), a replay-free and parameter-efficient framework
that explicitly addresses both issues. DDP assigns class-specific
positive-negative prompts to disentangle semantics and introduces Progressive
Confidence Decoupling (PCD), a curriculum-inspired decoupling strategy that
suppresses false positives. Past prompts are frozen as knowledge anchors, and
interlayer prompting enhances efficiency. On MS-COCO and PASCAL VOC, DDP
consistently outperforms prior methods and is the first replay-free MLCIL
approach to exceed 80% mAP and 70% F1 under the standard MS-COCO B40-C10
benchmark.

AI.tldr: Dual-Decoupled Prompting (DDP) is a replay-free, parameter-efficient prompt-based framework for multi-label class-incremental learning that tackles semantic confusion via class-specific positive/negative prompts and reduces false positives with Progressive Confidence Decoupling; it freezes past prompts and uses interlayer prompting, achieving state-of-the-art results (>80% mAP, >70% F1) on MS-COCO B40-C10 and strong results on PASCAL VOC.
AI.motivation: Prompts in multi-label class-incremental learning (MLCIL) suffer from two core issues: semantic confusion due to co-occurring categories and true-negative-false-positive confusion from partial labeling. A replay-free, parameter-efficient approach that disentangles semantics and suppresses false positives is needed.
AI.method: Dual-Decoupled Prompting (DDP) assigns class-specific positive and negative prompts to disentangle semantics between labels. Progressive Confidence Decoupling (PCD) is a curriculum-inspired decoupling strategy that suppresses false positives. Past prompts are frozen as knowledge anchors, and interlayer prompting enhances efficiency.
AI.result: DDP consistently outperforms prior methods on MS-COCO and PASCAL VOC, and is the first replay-free MLCIL method to exceed 80% mAP and 70% F1 under the standard MS-COCO B40-C10 benchmark.
AI.conclusion: DDP provides an effective, replay-free and parameter-efficient solution for MLCIL by decoupling semantics and confidence. Frozen prompts serve as knowledge anchors while interlayer prompting improves efficiency, with strong empirical validation on two widely-used datasets.

title: Prompting Robot Teams with Natural Language
summary:
This paper presents a framework towards prompting multi-robot teams with
high-level tasks using natural language expressions. Our objective is to use
the reasoning capabilities demonstrated by recent language models in
understanding and decomposing human expressions of intent, and repurpose these
for multi-robot collaboration and decision-making. The key challenge is that an
individual's behavior in a collective can be hard to specify and interpret, and
must continuously adapt to actions from others. This necessitates a framework
that possesses the representational capacity required by the logic and
semantics of a task, and yet supports decentralized and interactive real-time
operation. We solve this dilemma by recognizing that a task can be represented
as a deterministic finite automaton (DFA), and that recurrent neural networks
(RNNs) can encode numerous automata. This allows us to distill the logic and
sequential decompositions of sub-tasks obtained from a language model into an
RNN, and align its internal states with the semantics of a given task. By
training a graph neural network (GNN) control policy that is conditioned on the
hidden states of the RNN and the language embeddings, our method enables robots
to execute task-relevant actions in a decentralized manner. We present
evaluations of this single light-weight interpretable model on various
simulated and real-world multi-robot tasks that require sequential and
collaborative behavior by the team -- sites.google.com/view/prompting-teams.

AI.tldr: A lightweight, interpretable framework that uses language-driven task decomposition encoded into an RNN-based DFA and a GNN controller for decentralized multi-robot coordination, validated on simulated and real-world tasks.
AI.motivation: To enable flexible, interpretable, and real-time coordination of robot teams via high-level natural language prompts, addressing the challenge that individual robot behavior in a group is hard to specify and must adapt to others.
AI.method: Represent the task as a deterministic finite automaton (DFA). Use an RNN to encode many automata; distill logic and sub-task decompositions from a language model into the RNN, aligning its hidden states with task semantics. Train a graph neural network (GNN) control policy conditioned on the RNN hidden states and language embeddings to produce decentralized, task-relevant actions.
AI.result: Evaluation on various simulated and real-world multi-robot tasks requiring sequential and collaborative team behavior, using a single lightweight interpretable model; link provided for additional details.
AI.conclusion: A NL-promptable framework that bridges language models and decentralized robotic control via DFA-RNN encoding and GNN policy, enabling scalable, interpretable multi-robot coordination.

title: Humanline: Online Alignment as Perceptual Loss
summary:
Online alignment (e.g., GRPO) is generally more performant than offline
alignment (e.g., DPO) -- but why? Drawing on prospect theory from behavioral
economics, we propose a human-centric explanation. We prove that online
on-policy sampling better approximates the human-perceived distribution of what
the model can produce, and PPO/GRPO-style clipping -- originally introduced to
just stabilize training -- recovers a perceptual bias in how humans perceive
probability. In this sense, PPO/GRPO act as perceptual losses already. Our
theory further suggests that the online/offline dichotomy is itself incidental
to maximizing human utility, since we can achieve the same effect by
selectively training on any data in a manner that mimics human perception,
rather than restricting ourselves to online on-policy data. Doing so would
allow us to post-train more quickly, cheaply, and flexibly without sacrificing
performance. To this end, we propose a design pattern that explicitly
incorporates perceptual distortions of probability into objectives like
DPO/KTO/GRPO, creating humanline variants of them. Surprisingly, we find that
these humanline variants, even when trained with offline off-policy data, can
match the performance of their online counterparts on both verifiable and
unverifiable tasks.

AI.tldr: Online on-policy alignment (GRPO/PPO) outperforms offline alignment (DPO) due to alignment with human perception. The authors provide a prospect-theory-based explanation, viewing clipping as a perceptual loss and showing that offline data can be made to mimic online success by incorporating perceptual distortions; this allows effective offline/post-training variants (“humanline”) that match online performance on various tasks.
AI.motivation: Explain why online vs offline alignment differences exist from a human-centric, perceptual perspective and to explore whether perceptual distortions can bridge the gap, enabling efficient offline/post-training without sacrificing utility.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis grounded in prospect theory. Shows online sampling better approximates the human-perceived model distribution; interprets PPO/GRPO clipping as perceptual losses; proposes a design pattern to inject perceptual distortions into objectives (creating humanline variants); empirically demonstrates offline, perceptual-mimicking variants can match online performance on verifiable/unverifiable tasks.
AI.result: Online methods typically outperform offline baselines. However, by incorporating perceptual distortions into training objectives (humanline design), offline/off-policy data can achieve parity with online methods, matching performance on both verifiable and unverifiable tasks.
AI.conclusion: The online/offline dichotomy may be incidental to maximizing human utility. Perceptual-aware training enables effective offline post-training, offering faster, cheaper, and more flexible deployment without sacrificing performance; a concrete pattern for building perceptual losses into alignment objectives is proposed.

title: LLM Interpretability with Identifiable Temporal-Instantaneous Representation
summary:
Despite Large Language Models' remarkable capabilities, understanding their
internal representations remains challenging. Mechanistic interpretability
tools such as sparse autoencoders (SAEs) were developed to extract
interpretable features from LLMs but lack temporal dependency modeling,
instantaneous relation representation, and more importantly theoretical
guarantees, undermining both the theoretical foundations and the practical
confidence necessary for subsequent analyses. While causal representation
learning (CRL) offers theoretically grounded approaches for uncovering latent
concepts, existing methods cannot scale to LLMs' rich conceptual space due to
inefficient computation. To bridge the gap, we introduce an identifiable
temporal causal representation learning framework specifically designed for
LLMs' high-dimensional concept space, capturing both time-delayed and
instantaneous causal relations. Our approach provides theoretical guarantees
and demonstrates efficacy on synthetic datasets scaled to match real-world
complexity. By extending SAE techniques with our temporal causal framework, we
successfully discover meaningful concept relationships in LLM activations. Our
findings show that modeling both temporal and instantaneous conceptual
relationships advances the interpretability of LLMs.

AI.tldr: Introduces an identifiable temporal causal representation learning framework for LLMs to capture both time-delayed and instantaneous causal relations, bridging sparse autoencoders and causal representation learning with theoretical guarantees and scalable validation on synthetic data.
AI.motivation: Current mechanistic interpretability with SAEs lacks temporal modeling and guarantees; CRL methods are theoretically appealing but do not scale to LLM-level complexity; there is a need for a scalable, identifiable framework that models both delayed and instantaneous causal relations to improve interpretability.
AI.method: Proposes an identifiable temporal causal representation learning framework tailored for high-dimensional LLM concept spaces, capable of modeling both time-delayed and instantaneous causal relationships; extends SAE techniques by integrating temporal causal structure; provides theoretical identifiability guarantees; validated on synthetic datasets scaled to real-world complexity.
AI.result: The framework yields theoretical guarantees and demonstrates efficacy on synthetic datasets scaled for real-world complexity; discovers meaningful concept relationships in LLM activations, showing gains in interpretability by capturing both temporal and instantaneous relations.
AI.conclusion: Modeling temporal and instantaneous conceptual relationships enhances LLM interpretability; the approach bridges SAEs and CRL, offering theoretical guarantees and practical scalability for analyzing LLM activations.

title: LRPO: Enhancing Blind Face Restoration through Online Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Blind Face Restoration (BFR) encounters inherent challenges in exploring its
large solution space, leading to common artifacts like missing details and
identity ambiguity in the restored images. To tackle these challenges, we
propose a Likelihood-Regularized Policy Optimization (LRPO) framework, the
first to apply online reinforcement learning (RL) to the BFR task. LRPO
leverages rewards from sampled candidates to refine the policy network,
increasing the likelihood of high-quality outputs while improving restoration
performance on low-quality inputs. However, directly applying RL to BFR creates
incompatibility issues, producing restoration results that deviate
significantly from the ground truth. To balance perceptual quality and
fidelity, we propose three key strategies: 1) a composite reward function
tailored for face restoration assessment, 2) ground-truth guided likelihood
regularization, and 3) noise-level advantage assignment. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our proposed LRPO significantly improves the face restoration
quality over baseline methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance.

AI.tldr: LRPO introduces online reinforcement learning to blind face restoration (BFR) to improve restoration quality, balancing perceptual quality and fidelity with three strategies, achieving state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Blind Face Restoration struggles with a large solution space, leading to artifacts, missing details, and identity ambiguity. While reinforcement learning can leverage rewards, naive RL may diverge from ground truth. This motivates designing an online RL framework with regularization and task-tailored rewards to improve fidelity and perceptual quality.
AI.method: Propose Likelihood-Regularized Policy Optimization (LRPO), the first online RL approach for BFR. LRPO updates a policy network using rewards from sampled restoration candidates to increase the likelihood of high-quality outputs. To address fidelity vs perceptual quality, three strategies are employed: (1) a composite reward function tailored for face restoration assessment, (2) ground-truth guided likelihood regularization, and (3) noise-level advantage assignment.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that LRPO significantly improves face restoration quality over baseline methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance on BFR tasks.
AI.conclusion: LRPO successfully reconciles perceptual quality with fidelity in blind face restoration through online RL and targeted regularization, delivering strong empirical gains and SOTA performance.

title: U-DiT Policy: U-shaped Diffusion Transformers for Robotic Manipulation
summary:
Diffusion-based methods have been acknowledged as a powerful paradigm for
end-to-end visuomotor control in robotics. Most existing approaches adopt a
Diffusion Policy in U-Net architecture (DP-U), which, while effective, suffers
from limited global context modeling and over-smoothing artifacts. To address
these issues, we propose U-DiT Policy, a novel U-shaped Diffusion Transformer
framework. U-DiT preserves the multi-scale feature fusion advantages of U-Net
while integrating the global context modeling capability of Transformers,
thereby enhancing representational power and policy expressiveness. We evaluate
U-DiT extensively across both simulation and real-world robotic manipulation
tasks. In simulation, U-DiT achieves an average performance gain of 10\% over
baseline methods and surpasses Transformer-based diffusion policies (DP-T) that
use AdaLN blocks by 6\% under comparable parameter budgets. On real-world
robotic tasks, U-DiT demonstrates superior generalization and robustness,
achieving an average improvement of 22.5\% over DP-U. In addition, robustness
and generalization experiments under distractor and lighting variations further
highlight the advantages of U-DiT. These results highlight the effectiveness
and practical potential of U-DiT Policy as a new foundation for diffusion-based
robotic manipulation.

AI.tldr: Introduces U-DiT Policy, a U-shaped diffusion transformer that fuses U-Net multi-scale features with Transformer global context to enhance diffusion-based visuomotor control.
AI.motivation: DP-U diffusion policies suffer from limited global context modeling and over-smoothing, restricting policy expressiveness and robustness in manipulation tasks.
AI.method: Propose U-DiT Policy: a U-shaped Diffusion Transformer that preserves multi-scale feature fusion of U-Net while integrating Transformers to model global context; evaluated on simulation and real-world robotic manipulation with robustness to distractors and lighting variations.
AI.result: In simulation, U-DiT gains ~10% over baselines and beats DP-T with AdaLN by ~6% at similar parameter budgets. In real-world tasks, it improves performance by ~22.5% over DP-U, with better generalization and robustness under distractor and lighting variations.
AI.conclusion: U-DiT Policy is an effective and practical foundation for diffusion-based robotic manipulation, offering improved expressiveness and robustness by combining U-Net-like multiscale fusion with Transformer-based global context.

title: ELHPlan: Efficient Long-Horizon Task Planning for Multi-Agent Collaboration
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) enable intelligent multi-robot collaboration but
face fundamental trade-offs: declarative methods lack adaptability in dynamic
environments, while iterative methods incur prohibitive computational costs
that scale poorly with team size and task complexity. In this paper, we propose
ELHPlan, a novel framework that introduces Action Chains--sequences of actions
explicitly bound to sub-goal intentions--as the fundamental planning primitive.
ELHPlan operates via a cyclical process: 1) constructing intention-bound action
sequences, 2) proactively validating for conflicts and feasibility, 3) refining
issues through targeted mechanisms, and 4) executing validated actions. This
design balances adaptability and efficiency by providing sufficient planning
horizons while avoiding expensive full re-planning. We further propose
comprehensive efficiency metrics, including token consumption and planning
time, to more holistically evaluate multi-agent collaboration. Our experiments
on benchmark TDW-MAT and C-WAH demonstrate that ELHPlan achieves comparable
task success rates while consuming only 24% of the tokens required by
state-of-the-art methods. Our research establishes a new
efficiency-effectiveness frontier for LLM-based multi-agent planning systems.

AI.tldr: ELHPlan introduces Action Chains as planning primitives for LLM-based multi-agent planning, achieving comparable task success with substantially lower token usage (24% of state-of-the-art).
AI.motivation: Declarative planning methods lack adaptability in dynamic environments, while iterative planning incurs prohibitive computational costs that scale poorly with team size and task complexity. There is a need for a framework that offers planning horizons with controlled re-planning overhead.
AI.method: Introduce Action Chains—sequences of actions bound to sub-goal intentions—as the fundamental planning primitive. Operates in a cyclical process: (1) construct intention-bound action sequences, (2) proactively validate conflicts/feasibility, (3) refine issues via targeted mechanisms, (4) execute validated actions. Proposes efficiency metrics (token consumption, planning time) to evaluate multi-agent collaboration.
AI.result: ELHPlan achieves comparable task success rates to state-of-the-art methods while consuming only 24% of the tokens.
AI.conclusion: Establishes a new efficiency–effectiveness frontier for LLM-based multi-agent planning systems.

title: Robust Fine-Tuning from Non-Robust Pretrained Models: Mitigating Suboptimal Transfer With Adversarial Scheduling
summary:
Fine-tuning pretrained models is a standard and effective workflow in modern
machine learning. However, robust fine-tuning (RFT), which aims to
simultaneously achieve adaptation to a downstream task and robustness to
adversarial examples, remains challenging. Despite the abundance of non-robust
pretrained models in open-source repositories, their potential for RFT is less
understood. We address this knowledge gap by systematically examining RFT from
such non-robust models. Our experiments reveal that fine-tuning non-robust
models with a robust objective, even under small perturbations, can lead to
poor performance, a phenomenon that we dub \emph{suboptimal transfer}. In
challenging scenarios (eg, difficult tasks, high perturbation), the resulting
performance can be so low that it may be considered a transfer failure. We find
that fine-tuning using a robust objective impedes task adaptation at the
beginning of training and eventually prevents optimal transfer. However, we
propose a novel heuristic, \emph{Epsilon-Scheduling}, a schedule over
perturbation strength used during training that promotes optimal transfer.
Additionally, we introduce \emph{expected robustness}, a metric that captures
performance across a range of perturbations, providing a more comprehensive
evaluation of the accuracy-robustness trade-off for diverse models at test
time. Extensive experiments on a wide range of configurations (six pretrained
models and five datasets) show that \emph{Epsilon-Scheduling} successfully
prevents \emph{suboptimal transfer} and consistently improves expected
robustness.

AI.tldr: Non-robust pretrained models, when fine-tuned with robust objectives, can suffer suboptimal transfer; introduces Epsilon-Scheduling and expected robustness to improve robustness-adaptation trade-offs across multiple models and datasets.
AI.motivation: There is limited understanding of robust fine-tuning (RFT) with non-robust pretrained models. Robust objectives can hinder initial task adaptation, potentially causing transfer failures. A strategy and an evaluation metric are needed to assess and improve RFT performance.
AI.method: Systematic experiments on six pretrained models and five datasets to study RFT on non-robust models. Proposes Epsilon-Scheduling, a perturbation-strength schedule during training, and defines expected robustness as an aggregated metric across perturbations.
AI.result: Fine-tuning non-robust models with a robust objective can impede early adaptation and lead to suboptimal transfer; in difficult scenarios, transfer may fail. Epsilon-Scheduling prevents suboptimal transfer and consistently improves expected robustness across configurations.
AI.conclusion: Epsilon-Scheduling is an effective heuristic to promote optimal transfer in robust fine-tuning of non-robust models, and expected robustness provides a more comprehensive evaluation of the accuracy-robustness trade-off.

title: DentVLM: A Multimodal Vision-Language Model for Comprehensive Dental Diagnosis and Enhanced Clinical Practice
summary:
Diagnosing and managing oral diseases necessitate advanced visual
interpretation across diverse imaging modalities and integrated information
synthesis. While current AI models excel at isolated tasks, they often fall
short in addressing the complex, multimodal requirements of comprehensive
clinical dental practice. Here we introduce DentVLM, a multimodal
vision-language model engineered for expert-level oral disease diagnosis.
DentVLM was developed using a comprehensive, large-scale, bilingual dataset of
110,447 images and 2.46 million visual question-answering (VQA) pairs. The
model is capable of interpreting seven 2D oral imaging modalities across 36
diagnostic tasks, significantly outperforming leading proprietary and
open-source models by 19.6% higher accuracy for oral diseases and 27.9% for
malocclusions. In a clinical study involving 25 dentists, evaluating 1,946
patients and encompassing 3,105 QA pairs, DentVLM surpassed the diagnostic
performance of 13 junior dentists on 21 of 36 tasks and exceeded that of 12
senior dentists on 12 of 36 tasks. When integrated into a collaborative
workflow, DentVLM elevated junior dentists' performance to senior levels and
reduced diagnostic time for all practitioners by 15-22%. Furthermore, DentVLM
exhibited promising performance across three practical utility scenarios,
including home-based dental health management, hospital-based intelligent
diagnosis and multi-agent collaborative interaction. These findings establish
DentVLM as a robust clinical decision support tool, poised to enhance primary
dental care, mitigate provider-patient imbalances, and democratize access to
specialized medical expertise within the field of dentistry.

AI.tldr: DentVLM is a large multimodal vision-language model for dental diagnosis that integrates seven 2D imaging modalities across 36 tasks, outperforming existing models and improving clinician performance and efficiency in a clinical study.
AI.motivation: There is a need for integrated multimodal AI in dentistry to support comprehensive clinical decision-making. Current models handle isolated tasks and often cannot match expert-level practice, contributing to access gaps and inefficiencies in primary dental care.
AI.method: Developed DentVLM using a large bilingual dataset (110,447 images and 2.46 million visual question-answering pairs). It interprets seven 2D imaging modalities across 36 diagnostic tasks. Evaluated against leading models; included a clinical study with 25 dentists evaluating 1,946 patients and 3,105 QA pairs. Demonstrated integration into collaborative workflows and evaluated utility scenarios (home management, hospital diagnosis, multi-agent collaboration).
AI.result: DentVLM outperformed leading proprietary and open-source models by 19.6% in oral-disease accuracy and 27.9% in malocclusion accuracy. In a clinical study, it surpassed 13 junior dentists on 21 of 36 tasks and exceeded 12 senior dentists on 12 of 36 tasks. When integrated into workflows, junior dentists reached senior-level performance and overall diagnostic time decreased by 15–22%. It also showed promising performance in home-based, hospital-based, and multi-agent collaboration scenarios.
AI.conclusion: DentVLM demonstrates strong potential as a robust clinical decision-support tool to enhance primary dental care, reduce provider–patient disparities, and broaden access to dental expertise across diverse settings.

title: PoseDiff: A Unified Diffusion Model Bridging Robot Pose Estimation and Video-to-Action Control
summary:
We present PoseDiff, a conditional diffusion model that unifies robot state
estimation and control within a single framework. At its core, PoseDiff maps
raw visual observations into structured robot states-such as 3D keypoints or
joint angles-from a single RGB image, eliminating the need for multi-stage
pipelines or auxiliary modalities. Building upon this foundation, PoseDiff
extends naturally to video-to-action inverse dynamics: by conditioning on
sparse video keyframes generated by world models, it produces smooth and
continuous long-horizon action sequences through an overlap-averaging strategy.
This unified design enables scalable and efficient integration of perception
and control. On the DREAM dataset, PoseDiff achieves state-of-the-art accuracy
and real-time performance for pose estimation. On Libero-Object manipulation
tasks, it substantially improves success rates over existing inverse dynamics
modules, even under strict offline settings. Together, these results show that
PoseDiff provides a scalable, accurate, and efficient bridge between
perception, planning, and control in embodied AI. The video visualization
results can be found on the project page:
https://haozhuo-zhang.github.io/PoseDiff-project-page/.

AI.tldr: PoseDiff is a diffusion-based framework that converts raw RGB observations into structured robot states (e.g., 3D keypoints or joint angles) in a single step and extends to video-to-action inverse dynamics for long-horizon control using sparse keyframes and overlap-averaging, achieving state-of-the-art pose estimation on DREAM and improved inverse dynamics on Libero tasks within a unified perception–planning–control pipeline.
AI.motivation: The abstract targets unifying perception, planning, and control to simplify pipelines, enable real-time performance, and improve robustness in embodied AI by removing multi-stage dependencies and providing a single framework for both state estimation from vision and action generation.
AI.method: PoseDiff uses a conditional diffusion model to map RGB inputs to structured robot states. For video-to-action, it conditions on sparse video keyframes generated by world models and employs an overlap-averaging strategy to produce smooth, long-horizon action sequences.
AI.result: On the DREAM dataset, PoseDiff achieves state-of-the-art accuracy and real-time performance for pose estimation. On Libero-Object manipulation tasks, it substantially improves success rates over existing inverse dynamics modules, even in offline settings.
AI.conclusion: PoseDiff offers a scalable, accurate, and efficient bridge between perception, planning, and control in embodied AI, enabling unified handling of perception and control within a single model, with publicly available visualization on the project page.

title: Learning to Ponder: Adaptive Reasoning in Latent Space
summary:
Test-time compute has emerged as a key paradigm for enhancing LLM reasoning,
yet prevailing approaches like Best-of-N and majority voting apply uniform
depth across inputs, wasting computation on simple queries while potentially
under-thinking complex ones. We present FR-Ponder, a single-graph,
backbone-training-free framework that allocates instance-adaptive reasoning
compute via latent steering. A less than 1M-param controller observes hidden
states and decides to halt or apply a small ponder step by adding a
pre-computed steering vector to frozen representations. Our method extracts the
latent steering vector associated with deeper reasoning outputs and direct IO
from LLM and re-applies it through a tunable scaling factor, allowing the model
to adapt its reasoning depth to the complexity of each input. To balance
performance and computational cost, we employ Group Relative Policy
Optimization (GRPO) as a reward signal to adaptively regulate reasoning depth,
achieving task accuracy while mitigating overreasoning. Through curriculum
learning and careful reward engineering, FR-Ponder learns calibrated compute
allocation correlated with problem difficulty. On GSM8K and MATH500, FR-Ponder
improves the compute-accuracy frontier, delivering lower FLOPs with better
matched accuracy and comparing favorably to early-exit baselines, without
modifying backbone weights. Analyses visualize interpretable steering
directions and show learned compute allocation correlates with problem
difficulty.

AI.tldr: FR-Ponder is a backbone-training-free framework that adaptively allocates reasoning depth at test time via a tiny controller and latent steering, improving compute-accuracy tradeoffs on GSM8K and MATH500 without changing the LLM backbone.
AI.motivation: To cure the inefficiency of uniform-depth approaches (e.g., Best-of-N, majority voting) by enabling instance-specific compute allocation based on problem difficulty.
AI.method: A <1M-param controller sits on the frozen backbone, observes hidden states, and decides to halt or apply a small ponder step by adding a pre-computed steering vector to the frozen representations, scaled by a tunable factor. It extracts latent steering vectors linked to deeper reasoning outputs and re-applies them with a scaling factor. Training uses Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with curriculum to regulate compute; no backbone weights are updated; analyses show interpretable steering directions and compute allocation correlating with difficulty.
AI.result: On GSM8K and MATH500, FR-Ponder delivers a better compute-accuracy frontier, achieving lower FLOPs with better-matched accuracy and outperforming early-exit baselines; analyses reveal interpretable steering directions and that computed depth correlates with problem difficulty.
AI.conclusion: FR-Ponder enables calibrated, instance-adaptive reasoning compute without backbone finetuning, yielding efficient and interpretable compute allocation aligned with input difficulty.

title: Entering the Era of Discrete Diffusion Models: A Benchmark for Schrödinger Bridges and Entropic Optimal Transport
summary:
The Entropic Optimal Transport (EOT) problem and its dynamic counterpart, the
Schr\"odinger bridge (SB) problem, play an important role in modern machine
learning, linking generative modeling with optimal transport theory. While
recent advances in discrete diffusion and flow models have sparked growing
interest in applying SB methods to discrete domains, there is still no reliable
way to evaluate how well these methods actually solve the underlying problem.
We address this challenge by introducing a benchmark for SB on discrete spaces.
Our construction yields pairs of probability distributions with analytically
known SB solutions, enabling rigorous evaluation. As a byproduct of building
this benchmark, we obtain two new SB algorithms, DLightSB and DLightSB-M, and
additionally extend prior related work to construct the $\alpha$-CSBM
algorithm. We demonstrate the utility of our benchmark by evaluating both
existing and new solvers in high-dimensional discrete settings. This work
provides the first step toward proper evaluation of SB methods on discrete
spaces, paving the way for more reproducible future studies.

AI.tldr: A benchmark for evaluating Schrödinger bridge methods on discrete spaces is introduced, featuring analytically solvable SB instances and two new algorithms (DLightSB, DLightSB-M) plus an extension (alpha-CSBM). It enables rigorous, high-dimensional evaluation and aims to standardize reproducibility in SB research on discrete domains.
AI.motivation: There is currently no reliable benchmark to assess how well Schrödinger bridge methods solve the entropic optimal transport problem on discrete spaces, hindering fair comparisons and reproducibility.
AI.method: Construct SB benchmark pairs with analytically known SB solutions; develop new algorithms DLightSB and DLightSB-M; extend prior work to alpha-CSBM; validate by evaluating existing and new solvers in high-dimensional discrete settings.
AI.result: The benchmark enables rigorous evaluation of SB methods on discrete spaces and demonstrates the utility of the proposed solvers; it also introduces the two new algorithms and the alpha-CSBM extension.
AI.conclusion: This work provides the first step toward proper evaluation of SB methods on discrete spaces, paving the way for more reproducible future studies and broader adoption of SB approaches in discrete domains.

title: Dynamic-TreeRPO: Breaking the Independent Trajectory Bottleneck with Structured Sampling
summary:
The integration of Reinforcement Learning (RL) into flow matching models for
text-to-image (T2I) generation has driven substantial advances in generation
quality. However, these gains often come at the cost of exhaustive exploration
and inefficient sampling strategies due to slight variation in the sampling
group. Building on this insight, we propose Dynamic-TreeRPO, which implements
the sliding-window sampling strategy as a tree-structured search with dynamic
noise intensities along depth. We perform GRPO-guided optimization and
constrained Stochastic Differential Equation (SDE) sampling within this tree
structure. By sharing prefix paths of the tree, our design effectively
amortizes the computational overhead of trajectory search. With well-designed
noise intensities for each tree layer, Dynamic-TreeRPO can enhance the
variation of exploration without any extra computational cost. Furthermore, we
seamlessly integrate Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and RL paradigm within
Dynamic-TreeRPO to construct our proposed LayerTuning-RL, reformulating the
loss function of SFT as a dynamically weighted Progress Reward Model (PRM)
rather than a separate pretraining method. By associating this weighted PRM
with dynamic-adaptive clipping bounds, the disruption of exploration process in
Dynamic-TreeRPO is avoided. Benefiting from the tree-structured sampling and
the LayerTuning-RL paradigm, our model dynamically explores a diverse search
space along effective directions. Compared to existing baselines, our approach
demonstrates significant superiority in terms of semantic consistency, visual
fidelity, and human preference alignment on established benchmarks, including
HPS-v2.1, PickScore, and ImageReward. In particular, our model outperforms SoTA
by $4.9\%$, $5.91\%$, and $8.66\%$ on those benchmarks, respectively, while
improving the training efficiency by nearly $50\%$.

AI.tldr: A tree-structured RL sampling framework (Dynamic-TreeRPO) with dynamic noise and LayerTuning-RL improves T2I generation quality and efficiency by amortizing search costs and reformulating SFT as a weighted PRM.
AI.motivation: Address the inefficiency and excessive exploration in RL-enhanced flow-matching models for text-to-image generation, aiming to boost diversity and quality without extra compute.
AI.method: Introduce Dynamic-TreeRPO: a tree-structured sliding-window sampling with depth-varying noise; GRPO-guided optimization and constrained SDE sampling within the tree; share prefix paths to amortize trajectory search; integrate SFT with RL via LayerTuning-RL, modeling SFT loss as a dynamically weighted Progress Reward Model (PRM) and coupling with dynamic clipping bounds.
AI.result: Outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on HPS-v2.1, PickScore, and ImageReward by 4.9%, 5.91%, and 8.66% respectively, while achieving ~50% training efficiency gains and improved semantic fidelity and human preference alignment.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic-TreeRPO with LayerTuning-RL demonstrates that structured exploration and adaptive RL/SFT coupling can yield superior T2I generation quality and efficiency, highlighting the value of shared trajectory prefixes and dynamic noise strategies for robust search.

title: CEDex: Cross-Embodiment Dexterous Grasp Generation at Scale from Human-like Contact Representations
summary:
Cross-embodiment dexterous grasp synthesis refers to adaptively generating
and optimizing grasps for various robotic hands with different morphologies.
This capability is crucial for achieving versatile robotic manipulation in
diverse environments and requires substantial amounts of reliable and diverse
grasp data for effective model training and robust generalization. However,
existing approaches either rely on physics-based optimization that lacks
human-like kinematic understanding or require extensive manual data collection
processes that are limited to anthropomorphic structures. In this paper, we
propose CEDex, a novel cross-embodiment dexterous grasp synthesis method at
scale that bridges human grasping kinematics and robot kinematics by aligning
robot kinematic models with generated human-like contact representations. Given
an object's point cloud and an arbitrary robotic hand model, CEDex first
generates human-like contact representations using a Conditional Variational
Auto-encoder pretrained on human contact data. It then performs kinematic human
contact alignment through topological merging to consolidate multiple human
hand parts into unified robot components, followed by a signed distance
field-based grasp optimization with physics-aware constraints. Using CEDex, we
construct the largest cross-embodiment grasp dataset to date, comprising 500K
objects across four gripper types with 20M total grasps. Extensive experiments
show that CEDex outperforms state-of-the-art approaches and our dataset
benefits cross-embodiment grasp learning with high-quality diverse grasps.

AI.tldr: CEDex is a cross-embodiment dexterous grasp synthesis pipeline that aligns human grasp kinematics with arbitrary robot hands via a CVAE-generated human-like contact representation, topological alignment, and signed distance field optimization, enabling scalable, large-scale cross-embodiment grasp data (500k objects, 20M grasps across four gripper types) and improved performance.
AI.motivation: There is a need for versatile grasp data across diverse hand morphologies to enable robust manipulation, but existing methods are either physics-driven without kinematic human-like understanding or require extensive manual data collection limited to anthropomorphic shapes.
AI.method: 1) Use a CVAE pretrained on human contact data to generate human-like contact representations conditioned on the object. 2) Perform kinematic human contact alignment via topological merging to fuse multiple human hand parts into unified robot components. 3) Apply a signed distance field (SDF) based grasp optimization with physics-aware constraints to refine grasps. 4) Build a large cross-embodiment grasp dataset by applying the above to many objects and gripper types.
AI.result: CEDex outperforms state-of-the-art grasp methods on cross-embodiment tasks, and the resulting dataset supports high-quality, diverse grasps that enhance cross-embodiment learning.
AI.conclusion: The approach bridges human grasping kinematics and robot kinematics in a scalable, data-driven framework, enabling large-scale cross-embodiment dexterous grasp synthesis and contributing a comprehensive dataset to train generalizable grasp models across diverse hands.

title: Model Merging Scaling Laws in Large Language Models
summary:
We study empirical scaling laws for language model merging measured by
cross-entropy. Despite its wide practical use, merging lacks a quantitative
rule that predicts returns as we add experts or scale the model size. We
identify a compact power law that links model size and expert number: the
size-dependent floor decreases with model capacity, while the merging tail
exhibits clear diminishing returns in the number of experts. The law holds
in-domain and cross-domain, tightly fits measured curves across diverse
architectures and methods (Average, TA, TIES, DARE), and explains two robust
regularities: most gains arrive early, and variability shrinks as more experts
are included. Building on this, we present a simple theory that explains why
gains fall roughly as 1/k and links the floor and tail to properties of the
base model and the diversity across domains. This law enables predictive
planning: estimate how many experts are needed to reach a target loss, decide
when to stop adding experts, and trade off scaling the base model versus adding
experts under a fixed budget--turning merging from heuristic practice into a
computationally efficient, planable alternative to multitask training. This
suggests a scaling principle for distributed generative AI: predictable gains
can be achieved by composing specialists, offering a complementary path toward
AGI-level systems.

AI.tldr: A compact, cross-domain scaling law links model size and the number of experts in language-model merging, showing a size-dependent floor that falls with base capacity and a diminishing-tail with respect to experts, enabling predictive planning and budget trade-offs.
AI.motivation: Provide a quantitative rule for returns when merging experts or scaling model size, addressing the lack of predictive guidance in mixture-of-experts merging.
AI.method: Empirical analysis across architectures and methods (Average, TA, TIES, DARE) in-domain and cross-domain. The authors identify a size-dependent floor and a diminishing tail that follows a power law, and they propose a simple theory explaining why gains scale roughly as 1/k and linking floor and tail to base-model properties and domain diversity.
AI.result: The proposed law fits measured curves across diverse settings, showing most gains early and decreasing variability as more experts are added. Gains scale roughly as 1/k and the floor decreases with base capacity; the tail exhibits diminishing returns with the number of experts. The law supports predictive planning for the number of experts needed to reach a target loss and for when to stop adding experts; it also suggests a scalable principle for distributed generative AI by composing specialists.
AI.conclusion: The study offers a scalable, predictive framework for language-model merging, enabling efficient budgeting between scaling the base model and adding experts, and presenting a path toward AGI-level systems through distributed specialization.

title: Landing with the Score: Riemannian Optimization through Denoising
summary:
Under the data manifold hypothesis, high-dimensional data are concentrated
near a low-dimensional manifold. We study the problem of Riemannian
optimization over such manifolds when they are given only implicitly through
the data distribution, and the standard manifold operations required by
classical algorithms are unavailable. This formulation captures a broad class
of data-driven design problems that are central to modern generative AI. Our
key idea is to introduce a link function that connects the data distribution to
the geometric operations needed for optimization. We show that this function
enables the recovery of essential manifold operations, such as retraction and
Riemannian gradient computation. Moreover, we establish a direct connection
between our construction and the score function in diffusion models of the data
distribution. This connection allows us to leverage well-studied
parameterizations, efficient training procedures, and even pretrained score
networks from the diffusion model literature to perform optimization. Building
on this foundation, we propose two efficient inference-time algorithms --
Denoising Landing Flow (DLF) and Denoising Riemannian Gradient Descent (DRGD)
-- and provide theoretical guarantees for both feasibility (approximate
manifold adherence) and optimality (small Riemannian gradient norm). Finally,
we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on finite-horizon reference
tracking tasks in data-driven control, highlighting its potential for practical
generative and design applications.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-score guided framework for implicit Riemannian optimization on data manifolds, introducing two inference-time algorithms (DLF and DRGD) with theoretical guarantees, demonstrated on data-driven control tasks.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional data lie on low-dimensional manifolds, but classical manifold operations require explicit geometry. The data-manifold hypothesis and modern generative AI motivate optimizing directly over implicitly defined manifolds using distributional information (e.g., diffusion scores).
AI.method: Introduce a link function connecting the data distribution to required geometric operations (retraction and Riemannian gradient). Leverage the score function from diffusion models and pretrained score networks. Propose two algorithms for inference-time optimization: Denoising Landing Flow (DLF) and Denoising Riemannian Gradient Descent (DRGD). Provide theoretical guarantees for feasibility (approximate manifold adherence) and optimality (small Riemannian gradient norm).
AI.result: Derives conditions under which the manifold operations can be recovered via the link function and score information; proves feasibility and optimality guarantees for DLF and DRGD; demonstrates effectiveness on finite-horizon reference tracking tasks in data-driven control.
AI.conclusion: The approach enables efficient, data-driven optimization on implicitly defined manifolds by leveraging diffusion-score information, connecting generative modeling with practical optimization, and showcasing potential for generative and design applications in AI-driven tasks.

title: Test-time Uncertainty Estimation for Medical Image Registration via Transformation Equivariance
summary:
Accurate image registration is essential for downstream applications, yet
current deep registration networks provide limited indications of whether and
when their predictions are reliable. Existing uncertainty estimation
strategies, such as Bayesian methods, ensembles, or MC dropout, require
architectural changes or retraining, limiting their applicability to pretrained
registration networks. Instead, we propose a test-time uncertainty estimation
framework that is compatible with any pretrained networks. Our framework is
grounded in the transformation equivariance property of registration, which
states that the true mapping between two images should remain consistent under
spatial perturbations of the input. By analyzing the variance of network
predictions under such perturbations, we derive a theoretical decomposition of
perturbation-based uncertainty in registration. This decomposition separates
into two terms: (i) an intrinsic spread, reflecting epistemic noise, and (ii) a
bias jitter, capturing how systematic error drifts under perturbations. Across
four anatomical structures (brain, cardiac, abdominal, and lung) and multiple
registration models (uniGradICON, SynthMorph), the uncertainty maps correlate
consistently with registration errors and highlight regions requiring caution.
Our framework turns any pretrained registration network into a risk-aware tool
at test time, placing medical image registration one step closer to safe
deployment in clinical and large-scale research settings.

AI.tldr: A test-time uncertainty framework for pretrained medical image registration networks based on transformation equivariance, decomposing perturbation-based uncertainty into intrinsic spread (epistemic noise) and bias jitter; validated across four anatomical structures and two models, enabling risk-aware registration.
AI.motivation: Current uncertainty methods for registration (Bayesian methods, ensembles, MC dropout) require architectural changes or retraining, limiting applicability to pretrained networks. There is a need for a universal, test-time uncertainty estimate compatible with any pretrained registration model to enable safer deployment.
AI.method: Leverage the transformation equivariance property of image registration. Apply spatial perturbations to inputs, analyze the variance of network predictions under perturbations, and derive a theoretical decomposition of perturbation-based uncertainty into two terms: intrinsic spread (epistemic noise) and bias jitter (systematic drift under perturbations).
AI.result: Uncertainty maps produced by the framework correlate with registration errors across four anatomical structures (brain, cardiac, abdominal, lung) and multiple models (uniGradICON, SynthMorph). The method consistently highlights regions requiring caution, effectively turning any pretrained registration network into a risk-aware tool at test time.
AI.conclusion: The proposed test-time uncertainty framework enables safe deployment of pretrained registration networks by providing reliable, model-agnostic uncertainty estimates at inference time.

title: Stabilizing Humanoid Robot Trajectory Generation via Physics-Informed Learning and Control-Informed Steering
comment:
This paper has been accepted for publication at the IEEE/RSJ
  International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS), Hangzhou,
  China, 2025
summary:
Recent trends in humanoid robot control have successfully employed imitation
learning to enable the learned generation of smooth, human-like trajectories
from human data. While these approaches make more realistic motions possible,
they are limited by the amount of available motion data, and do not incorporate
prior knowledge about the physical laws governing the system and its
interactions with the environment. Thus they may violate such laws, leading to
divergent trajectories and sliding contacts which limit real-world stability.
We address such limitations via a two-pronged learning strategy which leverages
the known physics of the system and fundamental control principles. First, we
encode physics priors during supervised imitation learning to promote
trajectory feasibility. Second, we minimize drift at inference time by applying
a proportional-integral controller directly to the generated output state. We
validate our method on various locomotion behaviors for the ergoCub humanoid
robot, where a physics-informed loss encourages zero contact foot velocity. Our
experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach is compatible with multiple
controllers on a real robot and significantly improves the accuracy and
physical constraint conformity of generated trajectories.

AI.tldr: Physics-informed imitation learning with a PI correction improves feasibility and stability of humanoid trajectories; validated on ergoCub, showing better physical constraint adherence and compatibility with multiple controllers.
AI.motivation: Imitation-learning-based humanoid control can overfit to data and violate physical laws, causing unstable trajectories and contact slipping; limited data hampers realism and safety in real-world deployment.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (1) incorporate physics priors through a physics-informed loss during supervised imitation learning to promote feasible trajectories; (2) apply a proportional-integral controller to the generated output state at inference to reduce drift and enforce constraints (e.g., zero foot velocity at contact). Validation on ergoCub humanoid with a physics-aware loss and PI correction; demonstrates compatibility with multiple controllers and improved constraint conformity.
AI.result: Improved trajectory accuracy and adherence to physical constraints, reduced contact-velocity violations, and stable real-world performance across different controllers on a real humanoid robot (ergoCub).
AI.conclusion: Integrating physics priors during learning and a PI-based correction at inference yields more feasible, stable, and physically consistent humanoid motions, addressing data scarcity and physics-violation issues in imitation learning.

title: SpecExit: Accelerating Large Reasoning Model via Speculative Exit
summary:
Despite their strong performance on reasoning tasks, large reasoning models
(LRMs) often suffer from overthinking, producing unnecessarily long outputs and
incurring high end-to-end latency, a significant limitation to their real-world
deployment. To address overthinking, early-exit mechanisms have been proposed
to terminate reasoning before typical completion, showing that this approach
can effectively shorten generation length with minimal impact on accuracy.
However, their reliance on probing mechanisms introduces a detection overhead
that limits their end-to-end latency gains and compromises their
generalizability across diverse problems. Inspired by the use of hidden states
in speculative decoding, we propose SpecExit, a novel framework that predicts
both future tokens and an early-exit signal directly from a lightweight draft
model without probing overhead. Our method offers significant improvements,
reducing average generation length by 66\% and achieving a 2.5x speedup in
end-to-end latency compared to the speculative decoding baseline, without
compromising accuracy. Our method leverages the inherent signals from hidden
states to provide effective early-exit signals, suggesting broader use of
hidden states for efficient reasoning. Our code is available at
https://github.com/Tencent/AngelSlim.

AI.tldr: SpecExit reduces generation length and latency by predicting exit signals and future tokens from a lightweight draft model, avoiding probing overhead.
AI.motivation: LRMs suffer from overthinking (long outputs, high latency). Early-exit methods with probing overhead limit latency gains and generalizability. The approach aims to exploit hidden states to enable efficient early-exits without probing overhead.
AI.method: Train/use a lightweight draft model to predict both future tokens and an early-exit signal directly from hidden states, eliminating probing overhead and leveraging speculative decoding concepts.
AI.result: Average generation length shortened by 66%, end-to-end latency reduced by 2.5x compared to the speculative decoding baseline, while maintaining accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Hidden-state signals can effectively support early exits and efficient reasoning, suggesting broader use of hidden states for reducing computation in large reasoning models.

title: Emergence of Superposition: Unveiling the Training Dynamics of Chain of Continuous Thought
summary:
Previous work shows that the chain of continuous thought (continuous CoT)
improves the reasoning capability of large language models (LLMs) by enabling
implicit parallel thinking, and a subsequent work provided theoretical insight
by showing that a two-layer transformer equipped with continuous CoT can
efficiently solve directed graph reachability by maintaining a superposition of
multiple reasoning traces in the continuous thought. However, it remains
unclear how the superposition mechanism is naturally learned from
gradient-based training methods. To fill this gap, we theoretically analyze the
training dynamics of a simplified two-layer transformer on the directed graph
reachability problem to unveil how the superposition mechanism emerges during
training in two training stages -- (i) a thought-generation stage that
autoregressively expands the continuous thought, and (ii) a prediction stage
that converts the thought into the final answer. Our analysis reveals that
during training using continuous thought, the index-matching logit, an
important quantity which reflects the strength of the model's local search
ability, will first increase and then remain bounded under mild assumptions.
The bounded index-matching logit effectively balances exploration and
exploitation during the reasoning process: the model will exploit local problem
structures to identify plausible search traces, and assign comparable weights
to multiple such traces to explore when it is uncertain about which solution is
correct, which results in superposition. Our experimental results tracking the
growth of logits further validate our theory.

AI.tldr: A two-layer transformer with continuous chain-of-thought (CoT) develops a superposition of reasoning traces during training. The training dynamics show the index-matching logit grows and becomes bounded, enabling a balance between local search and exploration of multiple traces, which yields superposition. Experimental tracking of logits corroborates the theory.
AI.motivation: To understand how the mechanism for superposing multiple reasoning traces in continuous CoT emerges from gradient-based training, particularly for directed graph reachability.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of the training dynamics of a simplified two-layer transformer on directed graph reachability. The analysis identifies two training stages: (i) a thought-generation stage that autoregressively expands the continuous thought, and (ii) a prediction stage that converts the thought into the final answer. It focuses on the behavior of the index-matching logit and how it evolves under training.
AI.result: Under mild assumptions, the index-matching logit increases initially and then remains bounded. This boundedness creates a balance between exploiting local problem structure and exploring multiple plausible traces, enabling the model to assign comparable weights to several traces and thereby realize a superposition of reasoning paths. Experimental results tracking logits support the theoretical claims.
AI.conclusion: Continuous thought training yields a bounded index-matching logit that fosters exploration–exploitation balance and superposition of reasoning traces in a two-layer transformer for directed graph reachability; theory aligns with empirical observations.

title: GRAPE: Let GPRO Supervise Query Rewriting by Ranking for Retrieval
summary:
The CLIP model has become a cornerstone of large-scale retrieval systems by
aligning text and image data in a unified embedding space. Despite its
simplicity and efficiency, CLIP struggles when applied to tasks whose input
distributions diverge from its training corpus, such as queries with
multilingual, long-form, or multimodal differences. To avoid costly retraining,
existing methods mainly adopt query-rewriting strategies with large language
models (LLMs), aiming to mitigate distribution gaps at the query level.
However, due to the lack of supervision signals, LLMs fail to generate the
optimal one that fits the training distribution. We address this challenge with
GRAPE (Grouped Ranking-Aware Policy Optimization Enhancement), a plug-and-play
enhancement approach that incorporates ranking signals into retrieval-guided
query rewriting with LLMs. Intuitively, GRAPE proposes to leverage GRPO to
bridge distributional differences -- including length, multilingual, and
modality shifts -- by transforming queries into forms better aligned with the
retriever's training distribution. However, our preliminary experiment finds
that naively finetuning LLM with similarity scores can lead to score inflation,
where nearly all candidates are assigned unexpectedly high scores regardless of
their true relevance. To address score inflation, we propose a corpus-relative
ranking-based reward, which explicitly aligns optimization with ranking metrics
while suppressing spurious score inflation. Extensive experiments demonstrate
that GRAPE consistently improves retrieval performance under distributional
shifts -- including multilingual differences (Flickr30k-CN, CVLUE, XM3600),
length differences (Wikipedia), and multimodal differences (CIRR) -- achieving
an average improvement of 4.9\% in Recall\@10. The code is available at
https://github.com/Chinese0123456/GRAPE.git

AI.tldr: GRAPE is a plug-and-play enhancement that uses grouped ranking-aware policy optimization to guide LLM-based query rewriting for CLIP-like retrievers, aligning queries with the retriever’s training distribution and avoiding score inflation. It improves retrieval under distribution shifts ( multilingual, long-form, multimodal ) by about 4.9% in Recall@10 across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: CLIP-style retrievers struggle when query/input distributions differ from the training corpus. LLM-based query rewriting lacks supervision signals to match the retriever distribution, and naive fine-tuning can inflate scores. A ranking-aware optimization with supervision signals is needed to bridge distributional gaps without distorting scoring.
AI.method: Introduce GRAPE (Grouped Ranking-Aware Policy Optimization Enhancement), a plug-and-play approach that uses ranking signals to guide LLM-based query rewriting. It leverages a corpus-relative ranking-based reward to align optimization with ranking metrics and suppress score inflation. GRAPE employs GRPO to transform queries into forms better aligned with the retriever’s training distribution across length, multilingual, and modality shifts.
AI.result: GRAPE consistently improves retrieval under distributional shifts, achieving an average Recall@10 improvement of 4.9% across multilingual (Flickr30k-CN, CVLUE, XM3600), length (Wikipedia), and multimodal (CIRR) benchmarks. Code is released at the provided GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: GRAPE provides a practical, effective enhancement for CLIP-like retrieval systems facing distribution shifts by rewriting queries with ranking-aware supervision, mitigating score inflation, and delivering reliable gains without retraining the retriever.

title: LLM-Handover:Exploiting LLMs for Task-Oriented Robot-Human Handovers
comment: Accepted to IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters (RA-L)
summary:
Effective human-robot collaboration depends on task-oriented handovers, where
robots present objects in ways that support the partners intended use. However,
many existing approaches neglect the humans post-handover action, relying on
assumptions that limit generalizability. To address this gap, we propose
LLM-Handover, a novel framework that integrates large language model
(LLM)-based reasoning with part segmentation to enable context-aware grasp
selection and execution. Given an RGB-D image and a task description, our
system infers relevant object parts and selects grasps that optimize
post-handover usability. To support evaluation, we introduce a new dataset of
60 household objects spanning 12 categories, each annotated with detailed part
labels. We first demonstrate that our approach improves the performance of the
used state-of-the-art part segmentation method, in the context of robot-human
handovers. Next, we show that LLM-Handover achieves higher grasp success rates
and adapts better to post-handover task constraints. During hardware
experiments, we achieve a success rate of 83% in a zero-shot setting over
conventional and unconventional post-handover tasks. Finally, our user study
underlines that our method enables more intuitive, context-aware handovers,
with participants preferring it in 86% of cases.

AI.tldr: A framework (LLM-Handover) that uses LLM-driven reasoning with part segmentation to choose context-aware grasps for post-handover usability, validated on a new dataset; shows 83% zero-shot success and 86% user preference.
AI.motivation: Current handover approaches often ignore the user’s post-handover actions, limiting real-world effectiveness and generalizability. This work targets context-aware grasp selection to improve post-handover usability, supported by a new annotated dataset and user feedback.
AI.method: The system takes an RGB-D image and a task description, infers relevant object parts via segmentation, and uses LLM-based reasoning to select grasps that optimize post-handover use. It introduces a dataset of 60 household objects across 12 categories with detailed part labels, and validates the approach through (i) segmentation improvement, (ii) higher grasp success and adaptability in post-handover tasks, (iii) hardware experiments achieving 83% zero-shot success, and (iv) a user study with 86% participant preference.
AI.result: The approach improves state-of-the-art part segmentation within the handover context, yields higher grasp success rates, and better adapts to post-handover task constraints. Hardware tests report 83% zero-shot success; users prefer the method in 86% of cases.
AI.conclusion: LLM-Handover demonstrates that integrating language-based reasoning with part-aware perception can produce context-aware, intuitive handovers and generalizes across post-handover scenarios, supported by a new 60-object dataset.

title: Interactive Program Synthesis for Modeling Collaborative Physical Activities from Narrated Demonstrations
summary:
Teaching systems physical tasks is a long standing goal in HCI, yet most
prior work has focused on non collaborative physical activities. Collaborative
tasks introduce added complexity, requiring systems to infer users assumptions
about their teammates intent, which is an inherently ambiguous and dynamic
process. This necessitates representations that are interpretable and
correctable, enabling users to inspect and refine system behavior. We address
this challenge by framing collaborative task learning as a program synthesis
problem. Our system represents behavior as editable programs and uses narrated
demonstrations, i.e. paired physical actions and natural language, as a unified
modality for teaching, inspecting, and correcting system logic without
requiring users to see or write code. The same modality is used for the system
to communicate its learning to users. In a within subjects study, 20 users
taught multiplayer soccer tactics to our system. 70 percent (14/20) of
participants successfully refined learned programs to match their intent and 90
percent (18/20) found it easy to correct the programs. The study surfaced
unique challenges in representing learning as programs and in enabling users to
teach collaborative physical activities. We discuss these issues and outline
mitigation strategies.

AI.tldr: A program-synthesis approach enables learning collaborative physical tasks from narrated demonstrations; editable programs let users inspect, refine, and correct system behavior without coding; a small user study shows substantial success and ease of correction, though challenges remain.
AI.motivation: To handle the ambiguity and dynamism of team-based physical tasks by offering interpretable, editable representations that users can inspect and correct, improving collaboration between humans and systems.
AI.method: Represent system behavior as editable programs; teach via narrated demonstrations (paired actions + natural language) as a unified teaching channel for learning, inspection, and correction; conduct a within-subjects study with 20 participants teaching multiplayer soccer tactics.
AI.result: 70% of participants refined the learned programs to match their intent; 90% found it easy to correct the programs; revealed challenges specific to program-as-model representation and teaching collaboration.
AI.conclusion: Framing collaborative physical task learning as program synthesis with narrated demonstrations is promising for interpretability and corrigibility, but requires addressing domain-specific representation and teaching challenges; the paper discusses mitigation strategies.

title: Splines-Based Feature Importance in Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks: A Framework for Supervised Tabular Data Dimensionality Reduction
summary:
High-dimensional datasets require effective feature selection to improve
predictive performance, interpretability, and robustness. We propose and
evaluate feature selection methods for tabular datasets based on
Kolmogorov-Arnold networks (KANs), which parameterize feature transformations
through splines, enabling direct access to interpretable importance measures.
We introduce four KAN-based selectors ($\textit{KAN-L1}$, $\textit{KAN-L2}$,
$\textit{KAN-SI}$, $\textit{KAN-KO}$) and compare them against classical
baselines (LASSO, Random Forest, Mutual Information, SVM-RFE) across multiple
classification and regression tabular dataset benchmarks. Average (over three
retention levels: 20\%, 40\%, and 60\%) F1 scores and $R^2$ score results
reveal that KAN-based selectors, particularly $\textit{KAN-L2}$,
$\textit{KAN-L1}$, $\textit{KAN-SI}$, and $\textit{KAN-KO}$, are competitive
with and sometimes superior to classical baselines in structured and synthetic
datasets. However, $\textit{KAN-L1}$ is often too aggressive in regression,
removing useful features, while $\textit{KAN-L2}$ underperforms in
classification, where simple coefficient shrinkage misses complex feature
interactions. $\textit{KAN-L2}$ and $\textit{KAN-SI}$ provide robust
performance on noisy regression datasets and heterogeneous datasets, aligning
closely with ensemble predictors. In classification tasks, KAN selectors such
as $\textit{KAN-L1}$, $\textit{KAN-KO}$, and $\textit{KAN-SI}$ sometimes
surpass the other selectors by eliminating redundancy, particularly in
high-dimensional multi-class data. Overall, our findings demonstrate that
KAN-based feature selection provides a powerful and interpretable alternative
to traditional methods, capable of uncovering nonlinear and multivariate
feature relevance beyond sparsity or impurity-based measures.

AI.tldr: KAN-based feature selectors use spline-parameterized Kolmogorov-Arnold networks to learn interpretable feature importances for tabular data, achieving competitive or superior results to classical baselines and capturing nonlinear multivariate interactions.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional tabular datasets require effective feature selection to improve predictive performance, interpretability, and robustness. Many traditional methods rely on sparsity or simple correlations and may miss nonlinear/multivariate interactions. KANs provide a framework to learn feature transformations with interpretable importance measures.
AI.method: Propose four KAN-based selectors (KAN-L1, KAN-L2, KAN-SI, KAN-KO) and compare them against standard baselines (LASSO, Random Forest, Mutual Information, SVM-RFE) on classification and regression tabular benchmarks. Evaluate across three retention levels (20%, 40%, 60%) using average F1 (classification) and R^2 (regression). Analyze performance in terms of accuracy, robustness to noise, redundancy removal, and interpretability of feature importance.
AI.result: KAN-based selectors are competitive with or superior to classical baselines on structured and synthetic datasets. KAN-L2, KAN-L1, KAN-SI, and KAN-KO show strong performance, with KAN-L1 often too aggressive in regression (removing useful features) and KAN-L2 underperforming in classification due to simple coefficient shrinkage missing complex interactions. KAN-L2 and KAN-SI are robust on noisy regression and heterogeneous data; in classification, KAN-L1, KAN-KO, and KAN-SI may outperform by removing redundancy in high-dimensional multi-class data. Overall, KAN-based feature selection offers interpretable, nonlinearity-aware feature relevance beyond sparsity or impurity-based methods.
AI.conclusion: KAN-based feature selection provides a powerful and interpretable alternative to traditional methods for tabular data, capable of uncovering nonlinear and multivariate feature relevance beyond sparsity or impurity-based measures; performance depends on the task and selection strategy, with certain KAN selectors excelling in specific settings.

title: CasPoinTr: Point Cloud Completion with Cascaded Networks and Knowledge Distillation
summary:
Point clouds collected from real-world environments are often incomplete due
to factors such as limited sensor resolution, single viewpoints, occlusions,
and noise. These challenges make point cloud completion essential for various
applications. A key difficulty in this task is predicting the overall shape and
reconstructing missing regions from highly incomplete point clouds. To address
this, we introduce CasPoinTr, a novel point cloud completion framework using
cascaded networks and knowledge distillation. CasPoinTr decomposes the
completion task into two synergistic stages: Shape Reconstruction, which
