generates auxiliary information, and Fused Completion, which leverages this
information alongside knowledge distillation to generate the final output.
Through knowledge distillation, a teacher model trained on denser point clouds
transfers incomplete-complete associative knowledge to the student model,
enhancing its ability to estimate the overall shape and predict missing
regions. Together, the cascaded networks and knowledge distillation enhance the
model's ability to capture global shape context while refining local details,
effectively bridging the gap between incomplete inputs and complete targets.
Experiments on ShapeNet-55 under different difficulty settings demonstrate that
CasPoinTr outperforms existing methods in shape recovery and detail
preservation, highlighting the effectiveness of our cascaded structure and
distillation strategy.

AI.tldr: CasPoinTr introduces a cascaded point cloud completion framework with knowledge distillation, achieving improved global shape recovery and detail preservation, outperforming baselines on ShapeNet-55.
AI.motivation: Incomplete real-world point clouds due to limited sensor resolution, viewpoints, occlusions, and noise necessitate effective completion methods that recover global shape and missing regions.
AI.method: A two-stage cascaded network: Shape Reconstruction generates auxiliary information; Fused Completion leverages this information plus knowledge distillation from a teacher model trained on denser point clouds to produce the final completed point cloud, enhancing global context and local detail.
AI.result: CasPoinTr demonstrates superior shape recovery and detail preservation over existing methods on ShapeNet-55 across different difficulty settings.
AI.conclusion: Cascaded architecture combined with distillation effectively bridges incomplete inputs and complete targets by improving global shape estimation and refining local details.

title: APREBot: Active Perception System for Reflexive Evasion Robot
summary:
Reliable onboard perception is critical for quadruped robots navigating
dynamic environments, where obstacles can emerge from any direction under
strict reaction-time constraints. Single-sensor systems face inherent
limitations: LiDAR provides omnidirectional coverage but lacks rich texture
information, while cameras capture high-resolution detail but suffer from
restricted field of view. We introduce APREBot (Active Perception System for
Reflexive Evasion Robot), a novel framework that integrates reflexive evasion
with active hierarchical perception. APREBot strategically combines LiDAR-based
omnidirectional scanning with camera-based active focusing, achieving
comprehensive environmental awareness essential for agile obstacle avoidance in
quadruped robots. We validate APREBot through extensive sim-to-real experiments
on a quadruped platform, evaluating diverse obstacle types, trajectories, and
approach directions. Our results demonstrate substantial improvements over
state-of-the-art baselines in both safety metrics and operational efficiency,
highlighting APREBot's potential for dependable autonomy in safety-critical
scenarios. Videos are available at https://sites.google.com/view/aprebot/

AI.tldr: An active perception framework (APREBot) combines LiDAR omnidirectional scanning with camera-based active focusing to enable reflexive evasion in quadruped robots, yielding improvements over baselines in sim-to-real tests.
AI.motivation: Reliable onboard perception is critical for quadrupeds navigating dynamic environments. Single-sensor systems face tradeoffs: LiDAR offers omnidirectional coverage but limited texture, while cameras provide texture but narrow field of view. Under fast reaction-time constraints, robust environmental awareness is essential for safe obstacle avoidance.
AI.method: APREBot integrates reflexive evasion with active hierarchical perception by fusing LiDAR-based omnidirectional scanning with camera-based active focusing. The framework employs an active perception strategy to adapt sensing resources, expanding reliable perception for agile obstacle avoidance in quadrupeds. Validation uses sim-to-real experiments on a quadruped platform across diverse obstacles, trajectories, and approach directions.
AI.result: Extensive sim-to-real experiments show APREBot achieves substantial improvements over state-of-the-art baselines in safety metrics and operational efficiency, demonstrating more reliable environmental awareness and faster, safer evasive maneuvers.
AI.conclusion: APREBot demonstrates strong potential for dependable autonomy in safety-critical quadruped navigation. Further work may explore real-world deployment challenges, robustness to varied conditions, and scalability of the active perception strategy. Videos are available at the project site.

title: Rethinking and Benchmarking Large Language Models for Graph Reasoning
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) for Graph Reasoning have been extensively
studied over the past two years, involving enabling LLMs to understand graph
structures and reason on graphs to solve various graph problems, with graph
algorithm problems being the most prevalent. Recent studies underscore the
potential of LLMs in handling graph reasoning tasks, but their performance is
underwhelming. In this work, we point out issues with existing methods and
benchmarks, and rethink the direction that LLMs for graph reasoning should
strive toward. We find that base models, e.g., GPT-4o-mini, are largely
underestimated due to improper reasoning focus. Base models with reasoning
focus redirected from replicating graph algorithms to designing them can easily
solve most graph reasoning tasks in existing benchmarks. To truly evaluate the
graph reasoning capabilities of LLMs, we construct a more challenging
GraphAlgorithm benchmark, comprising 239 different graph problems and 3,041
test instances collected from 4 competition platforms. Finally, we introduce a
simple and strong baseline Simple-Reasoning-Then-Coding (Simple-RTC)-which
guides LLMs to design graph algorithms first and then code to address graph
reasoning tasks. Simple-RTC achieves near-perfect accuracy on existing
benchmarks and significantly outperforms GPT-4o-mini and all prior methods on
the GraphAlgorithm benchmark. This strong baseline encourages further
advancements in LLMs for Graph Reasoning in the future.

AI.tldr: The paper critiques current LLM-based graph reasoning benchmarks, introduces a tougher GraphAlgorithm benchmark, and presents Simple-Reasoning-Then-Coding (Simple-RTC) as a strong baseline that first designs graph algorithms and then implements them, achieving near-perfect scores on existing benchmarks and strong gains on GraphAlgorithm.
AI.motivation: Current LLM approaches to graph reasoning underperform due to misaligned focus (replicating graph algorithms) and weak benchmarks. There is a need to reevaluate evaluation benchmarks and guidance for model design to truly test reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: Create a more challenging GraphAlgorithm benchmark with 239 graph problems and 3,041 test instances from 4 platforms. Propose Simple-RTC: guide LLMs to design graph algorithms first and then code to implement them. Evaluate on both existing benchmarks and GraphAlgorithm.
AI.result: Simple-RTC achieves near-perfect accuracy on existing benchmarks and significantly outperforms GPT-4o-mini and prior methods on GraphAlgorithm.
AI.conclusion: The Simple-RTC baseline sets a strong standard for LLMs in graph reasoning and suggests future research should center on reasoning-forward design and robust benchmarks rather than solely empirical improvements on weak baselines.

title: Graph Your Own Prompt
comment:
Accepted at the 39th Conference on Neural Information Processing
  Systems (NeurIPS 2025)
summary:
We propose Graph Consistency Regularization (GCR), a novel framework that
injects relational graph structures, derived from model predictions, into the
learning process to promote class-aware, semantically meaningful feature
representations. Functioning as a form of self-prompting, GCR enables the model
to refine its internal structure using its own outputs. While deep networks
learn rich representations, these often capture noisy inter-class similarities
that contradict the model's predicted semantics. GCR addresses this issue by
introducing parameter-free Graph Consistency Layers (GCLs) at arbitrary depths.
Each GCL builds a batch-level feature similarity graph and aligns it with a
global, class-aware masked prediction graph, derived by modulating softmax
prediction similarities with intra-class indicators. This alignment enforces
that feature-level relationships reflect class-consistent prediction behavior,
acting as a semantic regularizer throughout the network. Unlike prior work, GCR
introduces a multi-layer, cross-space graph alignment mechanism with adaptive
weighting, where layer importance is learned from graph discrepancy magnitudes.
This allows the model to prioritize semantically reliable layers and suppress
noisy ones, enhancing feature quality without modifying the architecture or
training procedure. GCR is model-agnostic, lightweight, and improves semantic
structure across various networks and datasets. Experiments show that GCR
promotes cleaner feature structure, stronger intra-class cohesion, and improved
generalization, offering a new perspective on learning from prediction
structure. [Project website](https://darcyddx.github.io/gcr/)
[Code](https://github.com/Darcyddx/graph-prompt)

AI.tldr: Graph Consistency Regularization (GCR) injects relational graphs derived from model predictions into training via parameter-free Graph Consistency Layers to align feature similarity with class-aware prediction structure, improving semantic feature quality without changing architecture.
AI.motivation: Deep networks often learn rich representations that include noisy inter-class similarities conflicting with predicted semantics. A semantic regularizer that enforces consistency between feature relationships and class-level predictions can improve the quality and usefulness of learned features.
AI.method: Introduce parameter-free Graph Consistency Layers (GCLs) at arbitrary depths. Each GCL constructs a batch-level feature similarity graph and aligns it with a global, class-aware masked prediction graph (derived by modulating softmax similarities with intra-class indicators). Employ a multi-layer, cross-space graph alignment with adaptive weighting, where layer importance is learned from graph discrepancy magnitudes. The approach is model-agnostic, lightweight, and requires no architectural or training procedure changes.
AI.result: Empirically, GCR yields cleaner feature structures, stronger intra-class cohesion, and improved generalization across various networks and datasets.
AI.conclusion: GCR offers a new perspective on learning from prediction structure by using self-prompted, graph-based semantic regularization to refine representations without modifying network architecture.

title: UniPose: Unified Cross-modality Pose Prior Propagation towards RGB-D data for Weakly Supervised 3D Human Pose Estimation
summary:
In this paper, we present UniPose, a unified cross-modality pose prior
propagation method for weakly supervised 3D human pose estimation (HPE) using
unannotated single-view RGB-D sequences (RGB, depth, and point cloud data).
UniPose transfers 2D HPE annotations from large-scale RGB datasets (e.g., MS
COCO) to the 3D domain via self-supervised learning on easily acquired RGB-D
sequences, eliminating the need for labor-intensive 3D keypoint annotations.
This approach bridges the gap between 2D and 3D domains without suffering from
issues related to multi-view camera calibration or synthetic-to-real data
shifts. During training, UniPose leverages off-the-shelf 2D pose estimations as
weak supervision for point cloud networks, incorporating spatial-temporal
constraints like body symmetry and joint motion. The 2D-to-3D back-projection
loss and cross-modality interaction further enhance this process. By treating
the point cloud network's 3D HPE results as pseudo ground truth, our
anchor-to-joint prediction method performs 3D lifting on RGB and depth
networks, making it more robust against inaccuracies in 2D HPE results compared
to state-of-the-art methods. Experiments on CMU Panoptic and ITOP datasets show
that UniPose achieves comparable performance to fully supervised methods.
Incorporating large-scale unlabeled data (e.g., NTU RGB+D 60) enhances its
performance under challenging conditions, demonstrating its potential for
practical applications. Our proposed 3D lifting method also achieves
state-of-the-art results.

AI.tldr: UniPose is a weakly supervised 3D human pose estimation framework that uses unannotated RGB-D sequences to transfer 2D pose priors to 3D, via self-supervision and cross-modality learning, achieving competitive results with fully supervised methods and improved with large-scale unlabeled data.
AI.motivation: 3D HPE typically requires labor-intensive 3D keypoint annotations and multi-view calibration. This work aims to leverage abundant 2D pose data and readily available RGB-D sequences to bridge 2D and 3D domains without heavy labeling, calibration, or synthetic-to-real gaps.
AI.method: Train on unannotated single-view RGB-D data. Use off-the-shelf 2D pose estimators as weak supervision for a point-cloud network. Enforce spatial-temporal constraints (body symmetry, joint motion), apply 2D-to-3D back-projection loss and cross-modality interactions. Use the point-cloud network's 3D HPE as pseudo ground truth to perform anchor-to-joint 3D lifting on RGB and depth networks. Leverage RGB, depth, and point cloud data and augment with large unlabeled datasets.
AI.result: On CMU Panoptic and ITOP, UniPose achieves performance comparable to fully supervised methods. Incorporating large-scale unlabeled data (e.g., NTU RGB+D 60) further improves robustness, and the proposed 3D lifting method yields state-of-the-art results.
AI.conclusion: UniPose demonstrates effective weakly supervised 3D HPE by propagating 2D pose priors across modalities, reducing labeling/calibration requirements while maintaining competitive or superior performance, especially when leveraging additional unlabeled data.

title: SSR-ZSON: Zero-Shot Object Navigation via Spatial-Semantic Relations within a Hierarchical Exploration Framework
summary:
Zero-shot object navigation in unknown environments presents significant
challenges, mainly due to two key limitations: insufficient semantic guidance
leads to inefficient exploration, while limited spatial memory resulting from
environmental structure causes entrapment in local regions. To address these
issues, we propose SSR-ZSON, a spatial-semantic relative zero-shot object
navigation method based on the TARE hierarchical exploration framework,
integrating a viewpoint generation strategy balancing spatial coverage and
semantic density with an LLM-based global guidance mechanism. The performance
improvement of the proposed method is due to two key innovations. First, the
viewpoint generation strategy prioritizes areas of high semantic density within
traversable sub-regions to maximize spatial coverage and minimize invalid
exploration. Second, coupled with an LLM-based global guidance mechanism, it
assesses semantic associations to direct navigation toward high-value spaces,
preventing local entrapment and ensuring efficient exploration. Deployed on
hybrid Habitat-Gazebo simulations and physical platforms, SSR-ZSON achieves
real-time operation and superior performance. On Matterport3D and
Habitat-Matterport3D datasets, it improves the Success Rate(SR) by 18.5\% and
11.2\%, and the Success weighted by Path Length(SPL) by 0.181 and 0.140,
respectively, over state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: SSR-ZSON introduces a spatial-semantic relative zero-shot navigation framework that combines a viewpoint generation strategy with an LLM-guided global navigation cue within a TARE hierarchical exploration to improve exploration efficiency and avoid local entrapment in unknown environments; it yields substantial SR and SPL gains on Matterport3D datasets and runs in real-time on simulations and hardware.
AI.motivation: The abstract identifies two core limitations in zero-shot navigation: (1) inadequate semantic guidance leads to inefficient exploration, and (2) limited spatial memory due to environmental structure causes entrapment in local regions. Addressing these issues requires better semantic-aware planning and global-guided exploration.
AI.method: SSR-ZSON integrates a viewpoint generation strategy that targets high semantic density within traversable sub-regions to maximize spatial coverage while reducing invalid exploration, and an LLM-based global guidance mechanism to evaluate semantic associations and steer navigation toward high-value spaces. It operates within the TARE hierarchical exploration framework and is deployed in hybrid Habitat-Gazebo simulations and on physical platforms.
AI.result: Empirical results show significant improvements: on Matterport3D and Habitat-Matterport3D, SR improves by 18.5% and 11.2%, and SPL improves by 0.181 and 0.140, respectively, compared to state-of-the-art methods. Real-time operation is demonstrated across simulations and physical setups.
AI.conclusion: By combining semantic-density-aware viewpoint planning with an LLM-informed global guidance strategy within a hierarchical exploration framework, SSR-ZSON effectively mitigates inefficient exploration and local entrapment in unknown environments, achieving strong zero-shot navigation performance and real-time applicability across datasets, simulators, and hardware.

title: Risk-Sensitive RL for Alleviating Exploration Dilemmas in Large Language Models
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has proven effective
for enhancing Large Language Models (LLMs) on complex reasoning tasks. However,
existing methods suffer from an exploration dilemma: the sharply peaked initial
policies of pre-trained LLMs confine standard RL algorithms to a narrow set of
solutions, boosting single-solution accuracy (pass@1) but suppressing solution
diversity and multi-solution performance (pass@k). As a result, RLVR often
distills existing capabilities rather than discovering new reasoning
strategies. To overcome this, we introduce a Risk-Sensitive Reinforcement
Learning framework. Our approach employs a risk-seeking objective that
interpolates between mean and maximum rewards, leading to a novel algorithm,
Risk-Sensitive GRPO (RS-GRPO), which drives deeper exploration by amplifying
learning from challenging prompts. Remarkably, RS-GRPO is simple to implement,
requiring only minor code modifications. On six mathematical reasoning
benchmarks and with five different LLMs, RS-GRPO consistently improves pass@k
performance while maintaining or enhancing pass@1 accuracy.

AI.tldr: A risk-sensitive RL approach (RS-GRPO) improves pass@k in LLM-based reasoning by using a risk-seeking objective that blends mean and max rewards, enabling deeper exploration beyond the sharp initial policies of pre-trained LLMs. Demonstrated across six mathematical benchmarks and five LLMs, with maintained or improved pass@1.
AI.motivation: RL-based reward shaping for LLMs (RLVR) often suffers from an exploration dilemma: highly peaked initial policies limit exploration to a narrow set of solutions, boosting single-solution accuracy (pass@1) but harming solution diversity and multi-solution performance (pass@k). There is a need to discover new reasoning strategies rather than merely distilling existing capabilities.
AI.method: Introduce a Risk-Sensitive Reinforcement Learning framework using a risk-seeking objective that interpolates between mean and maximum rewards. Develop the RS-GRPO algorithm, a simple-to-implement extension requiring only minor code changes, designed to amplify learning from challenging prompts and encourage exploration beyond the initial policy peak.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows RS-GRPO consistently improves pass@k across six mathematical reasoning benchmarks and five LLMs, while maintaining or enhancing pass@1 accuracy.
AI.conclusion: RS-GRPO provides deeper exploration and greater solution diversity in RL-based LLM training, addressing the exploration dilemma of RLVR with minimal implementation burden and potential applicability to other reasoning tasks beyond mathematics.

title: Planner Aware Path Learning in Diffusion Language Models Training
summary:
Diffusion language models have emerged as a powerful alternative to
autoregressive models, enabling fast inference through flexible and parallel
generation paths. This flexibility is enabled by new sampling strategies, or
planners, that iteratively choose where to denoise along the sequence rather
than sampling uniformly at random. However, by modifying reverse paths,
planners introduce a mismatch between the uniformly random denoising paths used
during training and the planning-based paths used at inference. In this work,
we systematically investigate this mismatch and theoretically show that the
standard discrete diffusion training evidence lower bound (ELBO) does not
accurately describe a denoiser under non-uniform planning. To bridge this gap,
we derive a new Planned Evidence Lower Bound (P-ELBO) that directly
incorporates planner-based reverse dynamics into the training objective.
Building on this, we propose Planner Aware Path Learning (PAPL), a simple and
effective modification of the standard masked discrete diffusion loss that
aligns training and inference under planned denoisers. Empirically, PAPL
delivers consistent improvements across domains, including a 40% relative gain
in protein sequence modeling, up to a 4x improvement in MAUVE for text
generation, and a 23% relative gain in HumanEval pass@10 for code generation.

AI.tldr: Aligns training with planner-based inference by deriving P-ELBO and Planner Aware Path Learning (PAPL), improving diffusion-language-model performance across protein, text, and code domains.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models trained with uniform random denoising paths mismatch the planner-based reverse dynamics used at inference; this mismatch harms performance.
AI.method: Derive Planned ELBO (P-ELBO) that incorporates planner-based reverse dynamics into the training objective; propose Planner Aware Path Learning (PAPL), a modification of the standard masked discrete diffusion loss to align training with planned denoising paths.
AI.result: Empirical improvements across domains: ~40% relative gain in protein sequence modeling; up to 4x improvement in MAUVE for text generation; ~23% relative gain in HumanEval pass@10 for code generation.
AI.conclusion: Accounting for planner-based reverse dynamics in training reduces mismatches between training and inference, yielding consistent, cross-domain gains with PAPL.

title: Generative Modeling of Shape-Dependent Self-Contact Human Poses
summary:
One can hardly model self-contact of human poses without considering
underlying body shapes. For example, the pose of rubbing a belly for a person
with a low BMI leads to penetration of the hand into the belly for a person
with a high BMI. Despite its relevance, existing self-contact datasets lack the
variety of self-contact poses and precise body shapes, limiting conclusive
analysis between self-contact poses and shapes. To address this, we begin by
introducing the first extensive self-contact dataset with precise body shape
registration, Goliath-SC, consisting of 383K self-contact poses across 130
subjects. Using this dataset, we propose generative modeling of self-contact
prior conditioned by body shape parameters, based on a body-part-wise latent
diffusion with self-attention. We further incorporate this prior into
single-view human pose estimation while refining estimated poses to be in
contact. Our experiments suggest that shape conditioning is vital to the
successful modeling of self-contact pose distribution, hence improving
single-view pose estimation in self-contact.

AI.tldr: Introduces Goliath-SC, the first extensive self-contact dataset with precise body shapes (383K poses from 130 subjects), and a shape-conditioned self-contact prior built with a body-part–wise latent diffusion model with self-attention, which is integrated into single-view pose estimation to enforce contact.
AI.motivation: Modeling self-contact requires accurate body geometry; existing datasets lack pose diversity and precise body shapes, hindering analysis of the relationship between self-contact poses and body shapes.
AI.method: Construct Goliath-SC with 383K self-contact poses across 130 subjects and precise shape registration; develop a generative self-contact prior conditioned on body shape parameters using a body-part–wise latent diffusion model with self-attention; integrate this prior into a single-view pose estimation pipeline and refine poses to satisfy contact constraints.
AI.result: Experiments show that conditioning on body shape is essential for modeling the self-contact pose distribution and improves the performance of single-view pose estimation in self-contact scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Shape-aware priors are crucial for accurate self-contact modeling; the dataset enables robust analysis of pose–shape interactions, and diffusion-based, shape-conditioned priors effectively support pose estimation under self-contact.

title: IA-VLA: Input Augmentation for Vision-Language-Action models in settings with semantically complex tasks
summary:
Vision-language-action models (VLAs) have become an increasingly popular
approach for addressing robot manipulation problems in recent years. However,
such models need to output actions at a rate suitable for robot control, which
limits the size of the language model they can be based on, and consequently,
their language understanding capabilities. Manipulation tasks may require
complex language instructions, such as identifying target objects by their
relative positions, to specify human intention. Therefore, we introduce IA-VLA,
a framework that utilizes the extensive language understanding of a large
vision language model as a pre-processing stage to generate improved context to
augment the input of a VLA. We evaluate the framework on a set of semantically
complex tasks which have been underexplored in VLA literature, namely tasks
involving visual duplicates, i.e., visually indistinguishable objects. A
dataset of three types of scenes with duplicate objects is used to compare a
baseline VLA against two augmented variants. The experiments show that the VLA
benefits from the augmentation scheme, especially when faced with language
instructions that require the VLA to extrapolate from concepts it has seen in
the demonstrations. For the code, dataset, and videos, see
https://sites.google.com/view/ia-vla.

AI.tldr: IA-VLA uses a large vision-language model as a pre-processing step to augment the input to a vision-language-action model, improving manipulation performance on visually indistinguishable objects and complex language instructions.
AI.motivation: Vision-language-action models are constrained by real-time control needs and limited language understanding from small LMs. There is a need to handle complex instructions (e.g., relative object positions) and visual duplicates without sacrificing speed.
AI.method: Introduce IA-VLA, a framework that leverages a large vision-language model as a pre-processing stage to generate richer context, which augments the input to a VLA. Evaluation on semantically complex tasks involving visual duplicates across three scene types, comparing a baseline VLA and two augmented variants on a dataset with code, data, and videos provided.
AI.result: Augmentation improves VLA performance, especially for instructions that require extrapolation from concepts seen in demonstrations, indicating the benefit of using LLM-derived context to guide action generation.
AI.conclusion: Integrating LLM-based preprocessing with VLA improves robustness to language complexity and visual ambiguity, suggesting a promising direction for building more capable manipulation systems that can handle nuanced instructions and duplicate objects.

title: PAME-AI: Patient Messaging Creation and Optimization using Agentic AI
summary:
Messaging patients is a critical part of healthcare communication, helping to
improve things like medication adherence and healthy behaviors. However,
traditional mobile message design has significant limitations due to its
inability to explore the high-dimensional design space. We develop PAME-AI, a
novel approach for Patient Messaging Creation and Optimization using Agentic
AI. Built on the Data-Information-Knowledge-Wisdom (DIKW) hierarchy, PAME-AI
offers a structured framework to move from raw data to actionable insights for
high-performance messaging design. PAME-AI is composed of a system of
specialized computational agents that progressively transform raw experimental
data into actionable message design strategies. We demonstrate our approach's
effectiveness through a two-stage experiment, comprising of 444,691 patient
encounters in Stage 1 and 74,908 in Stage 2. The best-performing generated
message achieved 68.76% engagement compared to the 61.27% baseline,
representing a 12.2\% relative improvement in click-through rates. This agentic
architecture enables parallel processing, hypothesis validation, and continuous
learning, making it particularly suitable for large-scale healthcare
communication optimization.

AI.tldr: An agent-based, DIKW-driven framework (PAME-AI) for creating and optimizing patient messages; in two large-stage experiments, the best message achieved 68.76% engagement versus a 61.27% baseline, a 12.2% relative improvement in click-through rate.
AI.motivation: Traditional mobile message design struggles with exploring a high-dimensional design space, limiting scalable optimization of health messaging. A structured, scalable approach is needed to improve engagement and, potentially, health-related behaviors.
AI.method: DIKW-based architecture with specialized AI agents that iteratively transform raw experimental data into actionable message design strategies. Two-stage experiments with large samples (Stage 1: 444,691 encounters; Stage 2: 74,908). Parallel processing, hypothesis validation, and continuous learning enable high-throughput optimization of messages.
AI.result: Best-generated message achieved 68.76% engagement, up from 61.27% baseline; 12.2% relative improvement in click-through rates. Demonstrates scalability and effectiveness of agentic design for messaging.
AI.conclusion: Agentic AI within a DIKW framework offers a scalable path for optimizing healthcare messaging at large scale; effective in improving engagement, with potential for ongoing learning and refinement. Further work needed to assess impact on health outcomes and generalizability across settings.

title: Mind the Links: Cross-Layer Attention for Link Prediction in Multiplex Networks
summary:
Multiplex graphs capture diverse relations among shared nodes. Most
predictors either collapse layers or treat them independently. This loses
crucial inter-layer dependencies and struggles with scalability. To overcome
this, we frame multiplex link prediction as multi-view edge classification. For
each node pair, we construct a sequence of per-layer edge views and apply
cross-layer self-attention to fuse evidence for the target layer. We present
two models as instances of this framework: Trans-SLE, a lightweight transformer
over static embeddings, and Trans-GAT, which combines layer-specific GAT
encoders with transformer fusion. To ensure scalability and fairness, we
introduce a Union--Set candidate pool and two leakage-free protocols:
cross-layer and inductive subgraph generalization. Experiments on six public
multiplex datasets show consistent macro-F_1 gains over strong baselines (MELL,
HOPLP-MUL, RMNE). Our approach is simple, scalable, and compatible with both
precomputed embeddings and GNN encoders.

AI.tldr: Cross-layer transformer framework for multiplex link prediction with two instantiations, Trans-SLE and Trans-GAT, emphasizing inter-layer dependencies, scalability, and leakage-free evaluation; achieves macro-F1 gains on six datasets.
AI.motivation: Multiplex graphs encode multiple relation types among shared nodes. Traditional approaches either collapse layers or treat them independently, which loses cross-layer dependencies and raises scalability concerns. A scalable, fair, multi-view approach is needed for reliable multiplex link prediction.
AI.method: For each node pair, build a sequence of per-layer edge views and apply cross-layer self-attention to fuse evidence for the target layer. Two instantiations: Trans-SLE (lightweight transformer over static embeddings) and Trans-GAT (layer-specific GAT encoders with transformer fusion). Introduces a Union–Set candidate pool and leakage-free protocols (cross-layer and inductive subgraph generalization) to ensure scalability and fair evaluation. Compatible with both precomputed embeddings and GNN encoders.
AI.result: Experiments on six public multiplex datasets show consistent macro-F1 gains over strong baselines (MELL, HOPLP-MUL, RMNE).
AI.conclusion: The approach is simple, scalable, and capable of leveraging inter-layer dependencies for multiplex link prediction, with broad compatibility for embeddings and GNNs and fair leakage-free evaluation protocols.

title: WorldSplat: Gaussian-Centric Feed-Forward 4D Scene Generation for Autonomous Driving
summary:
Recent advances in driving-scene generation and reconstruction have
demonstrated significant potential for enhancing autonomous driving systems by
producing scalable and controllable training data. Existing generation methods
primarily focus on synthesizing diverse and high-fidelity driving videos;
however, due to limited 3D consistency and sparse viewpoint coverage, they
struggle to support convenient and high-quality novel-view synthesis (NVS).
Conversely, recent 3D/4D reconstruction approaches have significantly improved
NVS for real-world driving scenes, yet inherently lack generative capabilities.
To overcome this dilemma between scene generation and reconstruction, we
propose \textbf{WorldSplat}, a novel feed-forward framework for 4D
driving-scene generation. Our approach effectively generates consistent
multi-track videos through two key steps: ((i)) We introduce a 4D-aware latent
diffusion model integrating multi-modal information to produce pixel-aligned 4D
Gaussians in a feed-forward manner. ((ii)) Subsequently, we refine the novel
view videos rendered from these Gaussians using a enhanced video diffusion
model. Extensive experiments conducted on benchmark datasets demonstrate that
\textbf{WorldSplat} effectively generates high-fidelity, temporally and
spatially consistent multi-track novel view driving videos.

AI.tldr: A 4D driving-scene generation framework, WorldSplat, combines a 4D-aware latent diffusion model to generate pixel-aligned 4D Gaussians and a video diffusion refinement to produce temporally and spatially consistent multi-view driving videos, bridging generative and reconstructive capabilities.
AI.motivation: Current driving-scene pipelines struggle to provide both high-quality, novel-view synthesis (NVS) and temporally consistent 4D representations. Generative methods lack robust 3D consistency and reconstruction-based methods lack generation capabilities, hindering scalable, controllable data for autonomous driving.
AI.method: WorldSplat introduces a two-stage feed-forward approach: (i) a 4D-aware latent diffusion model that fuses multi-modal information to produce pixel-aligned 4D Gaussians for the scene; (ii) an enhanced video diffusion model that refines the novel-view videos rendered from these Gaussians, yielding temporally and spatially coherent multi-track driving videos.
AI.result: Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that WorldSplat generates high-fidelity, temporally and spatially consistent multi-track novel-view driving videos, showing effective NVS and scalable data generation.
AI.conclusion: WorldSplat effectively bridges generative and reconstructive capabilities for driving scenes, providing a scalable, high-quality 4D driving-video synthesis framework with strong 3D consistency and novel-view synthesis.

title: Fidelity-Aware Data Composition for Robust Robot Generalization
summary:
Generalist robot policies trained on large-scale, visually homogeneous
datasets can be susceptible to shortcut learning, which impairs their
out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization. While generative data augmentation is
a common approach to introduce diversity, it presents a subtle challenge: data
composition. Naively mixing real and synthetic data can corrupt the learning
signal, as this process often prioritizes visual diversity at the expense of
information fidelity. This paper suggests that robust generalization depends on
principled, fidelity-aware data composition. We introduce Coherent Information
Fidelity Tuning (CIFT), a framework that treats data composition as an
optimization problem. CIFT uses a practical proxy for Information Fidelity
based on the feature-space geometry of a dataset. This enables the
identification of a phase transition, termed the Decoherence Point, where
training stability degrades. The framework includes a generative engine,
Multi-View Video Augmentation (MVAug), to synthesize a causally disentangled
data spectrum for this tuning process. Applying CIFT to policy architectures
such as $\pi_0$ and Diffusion Policy improves OOD success rates by over 54\%.
These results indicate that fidelity-aware composition, beyond data synthesis
alone, is an important component for developing robust, general-purpose robots.

AI.tldr: CIFT introduces fidelity-aware data composition for robust OOD generalization in robotics, using a feature-space Information Fidelity proxy and Multi-View Video Augmentation, identifying a Decoherence Point to guide training; yields >54% OOD gains on policies like pi_0 and Diffusion Policy.
AI.motivation: Generalist robot policies trained on visually homogeneous data risk shortcut learning; naive mixing of real and synthetic data can degrade learning by prioritizing visual diversity over information fidelity.
AI.method: Formulate data composition as an optimization using a practical Information Fidelity proxy derived from dataset feature-space geometry; employ Multi-View Video Augmentation to synthesize a causally disentangled data spectrum; detect a training-stability phase transition (Decoherence Point) to guide tuning; apply to policies such as pi_0 and Diffusion Policy.
AI.result: Significant improvement in out-of-distribution success rates, with gains exceeding 54% when using CIFT.
AI.conclusion: Fidelity-aware data composition is essential for robust general-purpose robots and complements data synthesis by ensuring information fidelity during augmentation.

title: AdvChain: Adversarial Chain-of-Thought Tuning for Robust Safety Alignment of Large Reasoning Models
summary:
Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in
complex problem-solving through Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning. However, the
multi-step nature of CoT introduces new safety challenges that extend beyond
conventional language model alignment. We identify a failure mode in current
safety CoT tuning methods: the \textit{snowball effect}, where minor reasoning
deviations progressively amplify throughout the thought process, leading to
either harmful compliance or excessive refusal. This effect stems from models
being trained to imitate perfect reasoning scripts without learning to
self-correct. To address this limitation, we propose AdvChain, an alignment
paradigm that teaches models dynamic self-correction through adversarial CoT
tuning. Our method involves constructing a dataset containing
Temptation-Correction and Hesitation-Correction samples, where models learn to
recover from harmful reasoning drifts and unnecessary cautions. Extensive
experiments show that AdvChain significantly enhances robustness against
jailbreak attacks and CoT hijacking while substantially reducing over-refusal
on benign prompts, achieving a superior safety-utility balance without
compromising reasoning capabilities. Our work establishes a new direction for
building more robust and reliable reasoning models.

AI.tldr: AdvChain introduces adversarial CoT tuning to teach Large Reasoning Models dynamic self-correction, mitigating the snowball effect in chain-of-thought and improving safety with minimal impact on reasoning performance.
AI.motivation: Safety challenges in multi-step reasoning (CoT) extend beyond standard alignment. The snowball effect causes minor deviations to amplify, leading to harmful compliance or excessive refusals. Current safety CoT tuning trains on ideal reasoning, failing to teach self-correction.
AI.method: Construct an adversarial CoT dataset featuring Temptation-Correction and Hesitation-Correction samples. Train models to recover from harmful reasoning drifts and unnecessary cautions, enabling dynamic self-correction during reasoning (AdvChain).
AI.result: AdvChain enhances robustness against jailbreaks and CoT hijacking, reduces over-refusal on benign prompts, and achieves a better safety-utility balance without hurting reasoning capabilities.
AI.conclusion: AdvChain opens a new path for robust, reliable reasoning in LRMs by embedding self-correction through adversarial CoT tuning, potentially applicable to broader safety and reliability challenges.

title: PATCH: Learnable Tile-level Hybrid Sparsity for LLMs
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) deliver impressive performance but incur
prohibitive memory and compute costs at deployment. Model pruning is an
effective way to reduce these overheads, yet existing approaches face
challenges: unstructured sparsity, where nonzeros can appear anywhere,
preserves accuracy but yields irregular access patterns that prevent GPU
acceleration, while semi-structured 2:4 sparsity is hardware-friendly but
enforces a rigid 50% pattern that degrades model quality. To bridge this gap,
we introduce PATCH, a hybrid sparsity framework that enables a continuous
sparsity ratio between 0% and 50%. PATCH partitions weight matrices into tiles,
assigning each tile to be either dense or 2:4 sparse via a learnable mask
selection mechanism. This design provides fine-grained control over
accuracy-acceleration tradeoffs and supports non-uniform sparsity across
layers, leading to superior overall quality. Across models from 0.5B to 8B
parameters, PATCH consistently narrows the gap to dense accuracy while
delivering practical speedups. For instance, on LLaMA-2 7B with an A6000 GPU,
PATCH achieves 1.18x-1.38x end-to-end speedup over dense baselines while
improving accuracy by 0.37%-2.96% compared to the state-of-the-art 2:4 pruning
method, MaskLLM.

AI.tldr: PATCH enables a hybrid, tile-based sparsity framework that supports a continuous sparsity ratio from 0% to 50% by selectively marking tiles as either dense or 2:4 sparse. This yields hardware-friendly acceleration with non-uniform sparsity across layers and improved accuracy over prior 2:4 pruning.
AI.motivation: To reduce memory and compute costs of large language models while preserving accuracy. Unstructured sparsity hurts GPU acceleration due to irregular access patterns, and rigid 2:4 sparsity degrades quality. A flexible, tile-level hybrid sparsity seeks a better accuracy-acceleration balance.
AI.method: Partition weight matrices into tiles and apply a learnable mask to choose per-tile dense or 2:4 sparse representation. Allows a continuous sparsity ratio (0-50%) and non-uniform sparsity across layers for fine-grained control and hardware-friendly acceleration.
AI.result: Across models from 0.5B to 8B parameters, PATCH narrows the gap to dense accuracy while providing practical speedups. On LLaMA-2 7B with an A6000 GPU, PATCH achieves 1.18x-1.38x end-to-end speedup and improves accuracy by 0.37%-2.96% over the state-of-the-art 2:4 pruning method, MaskLLM.
AI.conclusion: PATCH offers a flexible, hardware-friendly hybrid sparsity solution that bridges the gap between unstructured and structured (2:4) pruning, enabling fine-grained accuracy-acceleration tradeoffs and non-uniform sparsity across layers with consistent gains.

title: Enhanced Fracture Diagnosis Based on Critical Regional and Scale Aware in YOLO
summary:
Fracture detection plays a critical role in medical imaging analysis,
traditional fracture diagnosis relies on visual assessment by experienced
physicians, however the speed and accuracy of this approach are constrained by
the expertise. With the rapid advancements in artificial intelligence, deep
learning models based on the YOLO framework have been widely employed for
fracture detection, demonstrating significant potential in improving diagnostic
efficiency and accuracy. This study proposes an improved YOLO-based model,
termed Fracture-YOLO, which integrates novel Critical-Region-Selector Attention
(CRSelector) and Scale-Aware (ScA) heads to further enhance detection
performance. Specifically, the CRSelector module utilizes global texture
information to focus on critical features of fracture regions. Meanwhile, the
ScA module dynamically adjusts the weights of features at different scales,
enhancing the model's capacity to identify fracture targets at multiple scales.
Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to the baseline model,
Fracture-YOLO achieves a significant improvement in detection precision, with
mAP50 and mAP50-95 increasing by 4 and 3, surpassing the baseline model and
achieving state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance.

AI.tldr: An improved YOLO-based fracture detector, Fracture-YOLO, with CRSelector and ScA heads, achieves state-of-the-art performance, showing +4 mAP50 and +3 mAP50-95 over a baseline.
AI.motivation: Medical fracture assessment relies on expert visual inspection; while YOLO-based detectors have improved speed and accuracy, performance can be further enhanced by leveraging global texture cues and multi-scale feature weighting to handle variable fracture appearances.
AI.method: Introduce Fracture-YOLO by integrating CRSelector (global texture-guided attention on fracture regions) and ScA (scale-aware feature weighting) into a YOLO framework, and evaluate against a baseline on fracture datasets using standard AP/mAP metrics.
AI.result: Fracture-YOLO achieves significant gains over the baseline, with mAP50 and mAP50-95 increasing by 4 and 3 points, surpassing the baseline and achieving state-of-the-art performance.
AI.conclusion: CRSelector and ScA effectively enhance fracture detection, improving accuracy and robustness across scales; this approach shows potential for faster, more reliable clinical fracture diagnosis.

title: Towards Modular and Accessible AUV Systems
comment:
6 pages, accepted by 2024 IEEE/OES Autonomous Underwater Vehicles
  Symposium (AUV)
summary:
This paper reports the development of a new open-access modular framework,
called Marine Vehicle Packages (MVP), for Autonomous Underwater Vehicles. The
framework consists of both software and hardware designs allowing easy
construction of AUV for research with increased customizability and sufficient
payload capacity. This paper will present the scalable hardware system design
and the modular software design architecture. New features, such as articulated
thruster integration and high-level Graphic User Interface will be discussed.
Both simulation and field experiments results are shown to highlight the
performance and compatibility of the MVP.

AI.tldr: Open-access MVP for AUVs enabling scalable hardware and modular software with articulated thrusters and GUI; validated by simulations and field tests.
AI.motivation: to create an accessible, customizable, and expandable AUV platform that accelerates research development and broadens payload options.
AI.method: developed a scalable hardware system and modular software architecture; integrated articulated thrusters; built a high-level GUI; evaluated via simulations and field experiments.
AI.result: new features implemented; demonstration of performance and compatibility with MVP in both simulated and real-world tests.
AI.conclusion: MVP offers a flexible, scalable framework for AUV design, facilitating research through open access designs and modular components.

title: G-reasoner: Foundation Models for Unified Reasoning over Graph-structured Knowledge
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) excel at complex reasoning but remain limited by
static and incomplete parametric knowledge. Retrieval-augmented generation
(RAG) mitigates this by incorporating external knowledge, yet existing RAGs
struggle with knowledge-intensive tasks due to fragmented information and weak
modeling of knowledge structure. Graphs offer a natural way to model
relationships within knowledge, but LLMs are inherently unstructured and cannot
effectively reason over graph-structured data. Recent graph-enhanced RAG
(GraphRAG) attempts to bridge this gap by constructing tailored graphs and
enabling LLMs to reason on them. However, these methods often depend on ad-hoc
graph designs, heuristic search, or costly agent pipelines, which hinder
scalability and generalization. To address these challenges, we present
G-reasoner, a unified framework that integrates graph and language foundation
models for reasoning over diverse graph-structured knowledge. Central to our
approach is QuadGraph, a standardized four-layer abstraction that unifies
heterogeneous knowledge sources into a common graph representation. Building on
this, we introduce a 34M-parameter graph foundation model (GFM) that jointly
captures graph topology and textual semantics, and is integrated with LLMs to
enhance reasoning in downstream applications. To ensure scalability and
efficiency, mixed-precision training and distributed message-passing are
implemented to scale GFM with more GPUs. Extensive experiments on six
benchmarks show that G-reasoner consistently outperforms state-of-the-art
baselines, significantly enhances LLM reasoning, and achieves strong efficiency
and cross-graph generalization.

AI.tldr: G-reasoner presents a unified graph-and-language foundation to reason over diverse graph-structured knowledge by introducing QuadGraph and a 34M-parameter graph foundation model (GFM) that integrates with LLMs; demonstrates scalability and superior performance across six benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LLMs have static, incomplete knowledge; existing RAG and graph-augmented methods struggle with knowledge fragmentation, poor graph reasoning, scalability; need a unified, scalable framework to jointly model graph topology and textual semantics to improve reasoning.
AI.method: Introduce QuadGraph four-layer abstraction to unify heterogeneous knowledge sources into a common graph; develop a 34M-parameter GFM that encodes topology and textual semantics; integrate GFM with LLMs for improved reasoning; implement mixed-precision training and distributed message-passing to scale; evaluate on six benchmarks.
AI.result: G-reasoner consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, improves LLM reasoning, and offers strong efficiency and cross-graph generalization.
AI.conclusion: A unified QuadGraph + GFM framework enables scalable, effective reasoning over graph-structured knowledge when combined with LLMs, with broad generalization across graphs and practical efficiency gains.

title: URS: A Unified Neural Routing Solver for Cross-Problem Zero-Shot Generalization
summary:
Multi-task neural routing solvers have emerged as a promising paradigm for
their ability to solve multiple vehicle routing problems (VRPs) using a single
model. However, existing neural solvers typically rely on predefined problem
constraints or require per-problem fine-tuning, which substantially limits
their zero-shot generalization ability to unseen VRP variants. To address this
critical bottleneck, we propose URS, a unified neural routing solver capable of
zero-shot generalization across a wide range of unseen VRPs using a single
model without any fine-tuning. The key component of URS is the unified data
representation (UDR), which replaces problem enumeration with data unification,
thereby broadening the problem coverage and reducing reliance on domain
expertise. In addition, we propose a Mixed Bias Module (MBM) to efficiently
learn the geometric and relational biases inherent in various problems. On top
of the proposed UDR, we further develop a parameter generator that adaptively
adjusts the decoder and bias weights of MBM to enhance zero-shot
generalization. Moreover, we propose an LLM-driven constraint satisfaction
mechanism, which translates raw problem descriptions into executable stepwise
masking functions to ensure solution feasibility. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that URS can consistently produce high-quality solutions for more
than 100 distinct VRP variants without any fine-tuning, which includes more
than 90 unseen variants. To the best of our knowledge, URS is the first neural
solver capable of handling over 100 VRP variants with a single model.

AI.tldr: URS is a single-model neural solver that achieves zero-shot generalization across 100+ VRP variants using unified data representation, a mixed bias module, a parameter generator, and LLM-driven constraint satisfaction, without any fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: To overcome zero-shot generalization limitations of existing neural VRP solvers that rely on fixed constraints or per-problem fine-tuning, hindering applicability to unseen VRP variants.
AI.method: Proposes URS: Unified Data Representation (UDR) to unify problem inputs; Mixed Bias Module (MBM) to learn geometric/relational biases; a parameter generator to adapt decoder weights and MBM biases for new variants; an LLM-driven constraint satisfaction system translating problem descriptions into executable masking steps.
AI.result: Empirical results show URS delivers high-quality solutions for over 100 VRP variants with no fine-tuning, including more than 90 unseen variants, making it the first neural VRP solver to cover such breadth with a single model.
AI.conclusion: URS broadens zero-shot generalization in neural VRP solvers through data unification, bias-aware architecture, adaptive parameter generation, and LLM-guided feasibility, reducing reliance on domain expertise and enabling versatile, scalable VRP solving.

title: FracDetNet: Advanced Fracture Detection via Dual-Focus Attention and Multi-scale Calibration in Medical X-ray Imaging
summary:
In this paper, an advanced fracture detection framework, FracDetNet, is
proposed to address challenges in medical imaging, as accurate fracture
detection is essential for enhancing diagnostic efficiency in clinical
practice. Despite recent advancements, existing methods still struggle with
detecting subtle and morphologically diverse fractures due to variable imaging
angles and suboptimal image quality. To overcome these limitations, FracDetNet
integrates Dual-Focus Attention (DFA) and Multi-scale Calibration (MC).
Specifically, the DFA module effectively captures detailed local features and
comprehensive global context through combined global and local attention
mechanisms. Additionally, the MC adaptively refines feature representations to
enhance detection performance. Experimental evaluations on the publicly
available GRAZPEDWRI-DX dataset demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, with
FracDetNet achieving a mAP$_{50-95}$ of 40.0\%, reflecting a \textbf{7.5\%}
improvement over the baseline model. Furthermore, the mAP$_{50}$ reaches
63.9\%, representing an increase of \textbf{4.2\%}, with fracture-specific
detection accuracy also enhanced by \textbf{2.9\%}.

AI.tldr: FracDetNet proposes Dual-Focus Attention (DFA) and Multi-scale Calibration (MC) to improve fracture detection in medical imaging, achieving state-of-the-art results on GRAZPEDWRI-DX with notable mAP gains.
AI.motivation: Fracture detection is challenging due to subtle and morphologically diverse fractures, variability in imaging angles, and suboptimal image quality, which hinder clinical diagnostic efficiency.
AI.method: Introduce Dual-Focus Attention (DFA) to capture both local details and global context through combined global and local attention, and incorporate Multi-scale Calibration (MC) to adaptively refine feature representations for better detection. Evaluated on the GRAZPEDWRI-DX dataset with standard object-detection metrics.
AI.result: FracDetNet achieves a mAP50-95 of 40.0%, a 7.5 percentage point improvement over the baseline. mAP50 reaches 63.9%, up by 4.2 percentage points, with fracture-specific detection accuracy improved by 2.9%.
AI.conclusion: The proposed DFA and MC modules enable robust fracture detection, achieving state-of-the-art performance on a public dataset and improving both overall and fracture-specific detection metrics.

title: Finding an Initial Probe Pose in Teleoperated Robotic Echocardiography via 2D LiDAR-Based 3D Reconstruction
comment: This work has been submitted to the IEEE for possible publication
summary:
Echocardiography is a key imaging modality for cardiac assessment but remains
highly operator-dependent, and access to trained sonographers is limited in
underserved settings. Teleoperated robotic echocardiography has been proposed
as a solution; however, clinical studies report longer examination times than
manual procedures, increasing diagnostic delays and operator workload.
Automating non-expert tasks, such as automatically moving the probe to an ideal
starting pose, offers a pathway to reduce this burden. Prior vision- and
depth-based approaches to estimate an initial probe pose are sensitive to
lighting, texture, and anatomical variability. We propose a robot-mounted 2D
LiDAR-based approach that reconstructs the chest surface in 3D and estimates
the initial probe pose automatically. To the best of our knowledge, this is the
first demonstration of robot-mounted 2D LiDAR used for 3D reconstruction of a
human body surface. Through plane-based extrinsic calibration, the
transformation between the LiDAR and robot base frames was estimated with an
overall root mean square (RMS) residual of 1.8 mm and rotational uncertainty
below 0.2{\deg}. The chest front surface, reconstructed from two linear LiDAR
sweeps, was aligned with non-rigid templates to identify an initial probe pose.
A mannequin-based study assessing reconstruction accuracy showed mean surface
errors of 2.78 +/- 0.21 mm. Human trials (N=5) evaluating the proposed approach
found probe initial points typically 20-30 mm from the clinically defined
initial point, while the variation across repeated trials on the same subject
was less than 4 mm.

AI.tldr: Robot-mounted 2D LiDAR reconstructs the chest surface in 3D to auto-estimate an initial echocardiography probe pose, achieving sub-millimeter to millimeter calibration accuracy and encouraging initial-pose accuracy in early trials.
AI.motivation: Automate non-expert tasks in teleoperated echocardiography to reduce operator workload and exam time, addressing limitations of vision/depth methods sensitive to lighting, texture, and anatomy.
AI.method: Mount a 2D LiDAR on the robot to perform two linear sweeps, reconstruct the chest surface in 3D; use plane-based extrinsic calibration to relate LiDAR and robot base frames (RMS 1.8 mm, rotation <0.2 deg); align reconstructed chest surface with non-rigid templates to identify an initial probe pose; evaluate with mannequin and human trials.
AI.result: Calibration RMS 1.8 mm with rotation <0.2 deg; mannequin surface error 2.78 ± 0.21 mm; human trials (N=5) initial probe points 20–30 mm from the clinical starting point; inter-trial repeatability <4 mm.
AI.conclusion: First demonstration of robot-mounted 2D LiDAR for 3D reconstruction of a human body surface; automated initial pose estimation is feasible and may reduce operator burden and exam time in teleoperated echocardiography, showing promising accuracy in initial tests.

title: SCI-Verifier: Scientific Verifier with Thinking
comment:
This paper focuses on LLM-as-a-Judge, and the project is currently in
  progress
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) are increasingly applied to scientific
reasoning, the complexity of answer formats and the diversity of equivalent
expressions make answer verification a critical yet challenging task. Existing
verification studies in scientific domains suffer from two major limitations:
(a) the absence of systematic evaluation standards and insufficient
disciplinary coverage, which hinders their comprehensive assessment; and (b)
heavy reliance on cumbersome rule design or prompt engineering, which reduces
their effectiveness in complex reasoning scenarios or limits their
cross-disciplinary generalization. To address these challenges, we propose
solutions at both the data and model levels. On the data side, we construct
SCI-VerifyBench, a cross-disciplinary benchmark covering mathematics, physics,
biology, chemistry, and general scientific QA. The benchmark is built from real
LLM responses and enhanced with domain-specific equivalence transformations
that generate challenging and realistic data. Model-based and expert
annotations ensure both quality and diversity, enabling rigorous evaluation of
verification ability. On the model side, we emphasize the importance of
reasoning for verification and introduce SCI-Verifier, a unified
reasoning-augmented verifier for scientific domains. Through post-training,
SCI-Verifier demonstrates strong logical reasoning and equivalence judgment
capabilities while maintaining concise and stable outputs. Together,
SCI-VerifyBench and SCI-Verifier provide a principled framework for scientific
verification, offering both systematic evaluation and practical pathways to
enhance the reliability and applicability of LLMs in scientific domains.

AI.tldr: Introduces SCI-VerifyBench and SCI-Verifier to enhance verification of LLMs in scientific reasoning via a cross-disciplinary benchmark and a reasoning-augmented verifier.
AI.motivation: Current verification studies in scientific domains lack systematic evaluation standards, narrow disciplinary coverage, and reliance on heavy rule/prompt engineering, hindering reliability and cross-domain generalization.
AI.method: Data side: build SCI-VerifyBench across mathematics, physics, biology, chemistry, and general scientific QA using real LLM responses, domain-specific equivalence transformations, and expert annotations. Model side: develop SCI-Verifier, a unified reasoning-augmented verifier, trained post-hoc to improve logical reasoning and equivalence judgment while delivering concise outputs.
AI.result: SCI-Verifier exhibits strong logical reasoning and equivalence judgments; SCI-VerifyBench enables rigorous, cross-disciplinary evaluation; together they offer a principled framework for evaluating and improving scientific verification in LLMs.
AI.conclusion: SCI-VerifyBench and SCI-Verifier jointly provide a principled framework for systematic evaluation and practical improvement of LLM reliability in scientific domains.

title: LOTFormer: Doubly-Stochastic Linear Attention via Low-Rank Optimal Transport
summary:
Transformers have proven highly effective across a wide range of modalities.
However, the quadratic complexity of the standard softmax attention mechanism
poses a fundamental barrier to scaling them to long context windows. A large
body of work addresses this with linear attention, which reformulates attention
as a kernel function and approximates it with finite feature maps to achieve
linear-time computation. Orthogonal to computational scaling, most attention
mechanisms -- both quadratic and linear -- produce row-normalized maps that can
over-focus on a few tokens, degrading robustness and information flow.
Enforcing doubly-stochastic attention alleviates this by balancing token
participation across rows and columns, but existing doubly-stochastic attention
mechanisms typically introduce substantial overhead, undermining scalability.
We propose LOTFormer, a principled attention mechanism that is simultaneously
linear-time and doubly-stochastic. Our approach exploits the connection between
attention maps and transportation plans between query and key measures. The
central idea is to constrain the transport plan to be low-rank by conditioning
it on a learnable pivot measure with small support. Concretely, we solve two
entropic optimal transport problems (queries $\to$ pivot and pivot $\to$ keys)
and compose them into a conditional (glued) coupling. This yields an attention
matrix that is provably doubly-stochastic, has rank at most $r \ll n$, and
applies to values in $O(nr)$ time without forming the full $n \times n$ map.
The pivot locations and masses are learned end-to-end. Empirically, LOTFormer
achieves state-of-the-art results on the Long Range Arena benchmark, surpassing
prior linear and transport-based attention methods in both accuracy and
efficiency.

AI.tldr: LOTFormer provides a linear-time, doubly-stochastic attention by reframing attention as entropic optimal transport with a learnable pivot, achieving O(nr) complexity and improved performance on long-range tasks.
AI.motivation: Quadratic softmax attention is expensive and can over-emphasize a few tokens; most attention maps are row-normalized and lack robust token participation across both rows and columns. There is a need for scalable, robust attention that also balances participation.
AI.method: Formulate attention as two entropic OT problems: queries→pivot and pivot→keys; compose them into a conditional (glued) coupling. Constrain the transport plan to be low-rank by conditioning on a learnable pivot measure with small support. Learn pivot locations and masses end-to-end. Compute attention in O(nr) time without forming the full n×n map; rank is at most r<<n.
AI.result: Empirically achieves state-of-the-art results on the Long Range Arena benchmark, surpassing prior linear and transport-based attention methods in both accuracy and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: LOTFormer delivers a principled, scalable attention mechanism that is doubly-stochastic and low-rank, enabling robust and efficient long-context modeling without incurring full quadratic cost.

title: SPIKE-RL: Video-LLMs meet Bayesian Surprise
summary:
Real-world videos often show routine activities punctuated by memorable,
surprising events. However, most Video-LLMs process videos by sampling frames
uniformly, likely missing critical moments that define a video's narrative. We
introduce SPIKE, an inference-time framework that quantifies Bayesian Surprise
as the belief update triggered by new visual evidence in the video stream,
identifying moments where new visual evidence conflicts with prior beliefs.
SPIKE effectively localizes surprise in videos, strongly correlated with humans
on positive (FunQA) and negative (Oops!) surprise benchmarks. Since the beliefs
of zero-shot Video-LLMs are often suboptimal, we develop SPIKE-RL, which
leverages GRPO to optimize belief hypotheses based on a reward signal from the
video caption. SPIKE and SPIKE-RL guide query-agnostic surprise-weighted frame
sampling, which allocates more frames to interesting moments in the video. With
this strategy, we achieve consistent performance gains on five downstream
benchmarks over uniform sampling. By enabling Video-LLMs to track beliefs and
register surprise, our work paves the way for more robust models that can
revise their understanding in response to new information.

AI.tldr: SPIKE introduces a Bayesian-surprise-based frame-sampling framework for Video-LLMs, plus SPIKE-RL to optimize belief hypotheses; both guide surprise-weighted frame selection to capture critical moments.
AI.motivation: Uniform frame sampling in Video-LLMs often misses pivotal moments that shape a video's narrative. By quantifying Bayesian Surprise, the approach aims to detect moments where new visual evidence challenges prior beliefs, enabling more informative sampling and robust video understanding.
AI.method: Define Bayesian Surprise as the belief update triggered by new visual evidence in a video stream; identify moments where new evidence conflicts with prior beliefs (SPIKE). Extend with SPIKE-RL (using GRPO) to optimize belief hypotheses based on a reward signal from the video caption. Use surprise-weighted frame sampling that allocates more frames to surprising moments, query-agnostic.
AI.result: SPIKE localizes surprise in videos and correlates strongly with human surprise on FunQA (positive) and Oops! (negative) benchmarks. SPIKE-RL improves belief hypotheses via GRPO and, together with surprise-weighted sampling, yields consistent gains across five downstream benchmarks compared to uniform sampling.
AI.conclusion: Tracking beliefs and registering surprise enables Video-LLMs to revise understanding in light of new evidence, leading to more robust video understanding and improved downstream performance.

title: JuggleRL: Mastering Ball Juggling with a Quadrotor via Deep Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Aerial robots interacting with objects must perform precise, contact-rich
maneuvers under uncertainty. In this paper, we study the problem of aerial ball
juggling using a quadrotor equipped with a racket, a task that demands accurate
timing, stable control, and continuous adaptation. We propose JuggleRL, the
first reinforcement learning-based system for aerial juggling. It learns
closed-loop policies in large-scale simulation using systematic calibration of
quadrotor and ball dynamics to reduce the sim-to-real gap. The training
incorporates reward shaping to encourage racket-centered hits and sustained
juggling, as well as domain randomization over ball position and coefficient of
restitution to enhance robustness and transferability. The learned policy
outputs mid-level commands executed by a low-level controller and is deployed
zero-shot on real hardware, where an enhanced perception module with a
lightweight communication protocol reduces delays in high-frequency state
estimation and ensures real-time control. Experiments show that JuggleRL
achieves an average of $311$ hits over $10$ consecutive trials in the real
world, with a maximum of $462$ hits observed, far exceeding a model-based
baseline that reaches at most $14$ hits with an average of $3.1$. Moreover, the
policy generalizes to unseen conditions, successfully juggling a lighter $5$ g
ball with an average of $145.9$ hits. This work demonstrates that reinforcement
learning can empower aerial robots with robust and stable control in dynamic
interaction tasks.

AI.tldr: JuggleRL is a reinforcement learning-based system enabling a quadrotor with a racket to juggle balls, achieving high real-world performance and robustness through large-scale simulation, calibrated dynamics, reward shaping, and domain randomization, with zero-shot transfer to hardware.
AI.motivation: Aerial robots performing contact-rich interactions face uncertainty and a significant sim-to-real gap. Juggling a ball is a challenging benchmark that requires precise timing, stable control, and adaptation, motivating learning-based approaches over purely model-based controllers.
AI.method: Train closed-loop policies in large-scale simulation with calibrated quadrotor and ball dynamics; use reward shaping to favor racket-centered hits and sustained juggling; apply domain randomization over ball position and restitution to improve robustness; policy outputs mid-level commands for a low-level controller; deploy zero-shot on hardware with an enhanced perception module and low-latency communication; validate on real hardware.
AI.result: RL policy achieves an average of 311 hits over 10 consecutive trials (max 462 hits); a model-based baseline reaches at most 14 hits (avg 3.1). The policy generalizes to unseen, lighter 5 g balls, averaging 145.9 hits.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcement learning can empower aerial robots to perform robust, stable, dynamic interaction tasks like juggling, with effective sim-to-real transfer when dynamics are carefully calibrated and robustness is built in through reward design and domain randomization.

title: Experience Paper: Adopting Activity Recognition in On-demand Food Delivery Business
summary:
This paper presents the first nationwide deployment of human activity
recognition (HAR) technology in the on-demand food delivery industry. We
successfully adapted the state-of-the-art LIMU-BERT foundation model to the
delivery platform. Spanning three phases over two years, the deployment
progresses from a feasibility study in Yangzhou City to nationwide adoption
involving 500,000 couriers across 367 cities in China. The adoption enables a
series of downstream applications, and large-scale tests demonstrate its
significant operational and economic benefits, showcasing the transformative
potential of HAR technology in real-world applications. Additionally, we share
lessons learned from this deployment and open-source our LIMU-BERT pretrained
with millions of hours of sensor data.

AI.tldr: First nationwide HAR deployment in on-demand food delivery using LIMU-BERT; 500k couriers across 367 cities; demonstrates operational and economic benefits; open-sources LIMU-BERT.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between laboratory HAR models and real-world industrial deployment; assess scalability, economic impact, and deployment challenges; enable large-scale adoption in logistics.
AI.method: Three-phase rollout over two years: feasibility study in Yangzhou; platform-adapted LIMU-BERT; large-scale tests; training on millions of hours of sensor data; 500k couriers across 367 cities; open-source release.
AI.result: Successful nationwide adoption with downstream HAR-enabled applications; significant operational and economic benefits demonstrated in large-scale tests; lessons learned from deployment.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates HAR's transformative potential in real-world logistics; presents the first nationwide deployment; provides deployment lessons and opens LIMU-BERT for broader use.

title: Better Hessians Matter: Studying the Impact of Curvature Approximations in Influence Functions
summary:
Influence functions offer a principled way to trace model predictions back to
training data, but their use in deep learning is hampered by the need to invert
a large, ill-conditioned Hessian matrix. Approximations such as Generalised
Gauss-Newton (GGN) and Kronecker-Factored Approximate Curvature (K-FAC) have
been proposed to make influence computation tractable, yet it remains unclear
how the departure from exactness impacts data attribution performance.
Critically, given the restricted regime in which influence functions are
derived, it is not necessarily clear better Hessian approximations should even
lead to better data attribution performance. In this paper, we investigate the
effect of Hessian approximation quality on influence-function attributions in a
controlled classification setting. Our experiments show that better Hessian
approximations consistently yield better influence score quality, offering
justification for recent research efforts towards that end. We further
decompose the approximation steps for recent Hessian approximation methods and
evaluate each step's influence on attribution accuracy. Notably, the mismatch
between K-FAC eigenvalues and GGN/EK-FAC eigenvalues accounts for the majority
of the error and influence loss. These findings highlight which approximations
are most critical, guiding future efforts to balance computational tractability
and attribution accuracy.

AI.tldr: In influence-function data attribution for deep nets, higher-fidelity Hessian approximations consistently yield more accurate attribution scores. Among approximations, a mismatch between K-FAC eigenvalues and GGN/EK-FAC eigenvalues explains the majority of errors, guiding which steps to prioritize.
AI.motivation: Influence functions aim to trace a model's predictions back to training data, but their practical use in deep learning is hampered by the need to invert large, ill-conditioned Hessians. While approximations like GGN and K-FAC exist to make computations tractable, it is unclear how the quality of these approximations affects attribution performance.
AI.method: The authors conduct controlled classification experiments comparing various Hessian-approximation methods (e.g., GGN, EK-FAC, K-FAC). They decompose each approximation into constituent steps and evaluate each step's impact on attribution accuracy, including an analysis of eigenvalue spectra to identify the source of errors.
AI.result: Better Hessian approximations yield consistently higher-quality influence scores. Decomposing the methods reveals that the dominant error arises from the mismatch between K-FAC eigenvalues and the true/Hessian-like eigenvalues (GGN/EK-FAC), with other approximation steps contributing less to attribution loss.
AI.conclusion: Prioritize improving Hessian eigenstructure alignment with the true curvature when designing tractable influence-function computations; focus on steps that affect eigenvalue alignment to balance computational tractability with attribution accuracy.

title: FM-SIREN & FM-FINER: Nyquist-Informed Frequency Multiplier for Implicit Neural Representation with Periodic Activation
summary:
Existing periodic activation-based implicit neural representation (INR)
networks, such as SIREN and FINER, suffer from hidden feature redundancy, where
neurons within a layer capture overlapping frequency components due to the use
of a fixed frequency multiplier. This redundancy limits the expressive capacity
of multilayer perceptrons (MLPs). Drawing inspiration from classical signal
processing methods such as the Discrete Sine Transform (DST), we propose
FM-SIREN and FM-FINER, which assign Nyquist-informed, neuron-specific frequency
multipliers to periodic activations. Unlike existing approaches, our design
introduces frequency diversity without requiring hyperparameter tuning or
additional network depth. This simple yet principled modification reduces the
redundancy of features by nearly 50% and consistently improves signal
reconstruction across diverse INR tasks, including fitting 1D audio, 2D image
and 3D shape, and synthesis of neural radiance fields (NeRF), outperforming
their baseline counterparts while maintaining efficiency.

AI.tldr: Neuron-specific, Nyquist-informed frequency multipliers for periodic activations in SIREN/FINER reduce feature redundancy and improve INR reconstruction without extra depth.
AI.motivation: Current periodic INRs suffer from hidden feature redundancy due to fixed frequency multipliers, limiting MLP expressiveness.
AI.method: Introduce FM-SIREN and FM-FINER by assigning neuron-specific frequency multipliers inspired by Discrete Sine Transform, achieving frequency diversity without extra hyperparameters or depth.
AI.result: Reduces feature redundancy by about 50% and improves signal reconstruction across 1D audio, 2D images, 3D shapes, and NeRFs, while maintaining efficiency.
AI.conclusion: A simple, principled modification that enhances INR expressiveness across tasks without increasing model complexity.

title: DRCP: Diffusion on Reinforced Cooperative Perception for Perceiving Beyond Limits
summary:
Cooperative perception enabled by Vehicle-to-Everything communication has
shown great promise in enhancing situational awareness for autonomous vehicles
and other mobile robotic platforms. Despite recent advances in perception
