backbones and multi-agent fusion, real-world deployments remain challenged by
hard detection cases, exemplified by partial detections and noise accumulation
which limit downstream detection accuracy. This work presents Diffusion on
Reinforced Cooperative Perception (DRCP), a real-time deployable framework
designed to address aforementioned issues in dynamic driving environments. DRCP
integrates two key components: (1) Precise-Pyramid-Cross-Modality-Cross-Agent,
a cross-modal cooperative perception module that leverages
camera-intrinsic-aware angular partitioning for attention-based fusion and
adaptive convolution to better exploit external features; and (2)
Mask-Diffusion-Mask-Aggregation, a novel lightweight diffusion-based refinement
module that encourages robustness against feature perturbations and aligns
bird's-eye-view features closer to the task-optimal manifold. The proposed
system achieves real-time performance on mobile platforms while significantly
improving robustness under challenging conditions. Code will be released in
late 2025.

AI.tldr: DRCP is a real-time cooperative perception framework that combines cross-modal fusion with diffusion-based refinement to improve robustness against partial detections and noise in dynamic driving, deployable on mobile platforms.
AI.motivation: Cooperative perception faces hard detection cases from partial detections and cumulative noise, limiting downstream accuracy. There is a need for a real-time, robust framework that can function on mobile platforms in dynamic environments.
AI.method: Two main components: (1) Precise-Pyramid-Cross-Modality-Cross-Agent for cross-modal fusion using camera-intrinsic-aware angular partitioning and adaptive convolution to better exploit external camera features; (2) Mask-Diffusion-Mask-Aggregation, a lightweight diffusion-based refinement module that enhances robustness to perturbations and aligns BEV features toward a task-optimal manifold.
AI.result: Real-time performance on mobile platforms with significantly improved robustness under challenging conditions, despite noise and partial detections. Code will be released in late 2025.
AI.conclusion: DRCP provides a real-time, robust solution for cooperative perception by fusing multi-modal information with diffusion-based refinement, enabling more reliable perception in dynamic driving environments.

title: MedMMV: A Controllable Multimodal Multi-Agent Framework for Reliable and Verifiable Clinical Reasoning
summary:
Recent progress in multimodal large language models (MLLMs) has demonstrated
promising performance on medical benchmarks and in preliminary trials as
clinical assistants. Yet, our pilot audit of diagnostic cases uncovers a
critical failure mode: instability in early evidence interpretation precedes
hallucination, creating branching reasoning trajectories that cascade into
globally inconsistent conclusions. This highlights the need for clinical
reasoning agents that constrain stochasticity and hallucination while producing
auditable decision flows. We introduce MedMMV, a controllable multimodal
multi-agent framework for reliable and verifiable clinical reasoning. MedMMV
stabilizes reasoning through diversified short rollouts, grounds intermediate
steps in a structured evidence graph under the supervision of a Hallucination
Detector, and aggregates candidate paths with a Combined Uncertainty scorer. On
six medical benchmarks, MedMMV improves accuracy by up to 12.7% and, more
critically, demonstrates superior reliability. Blind physician evaluations
confirm that MedMMV substantially increases reasoning truthfulness without
sacrificing informational content. By controlling instability through a
verifiable, multi-agent process, our framework provides a robust path toward
deploying trustworthy AI systems in high-stakes domains like clinical decision
support.

AI.tldr: MedMMV introduces a controllable, multi-agent framework for clinical reasoning in multimodal LLMs, stabilizing reasoning, reducing hallucinations via evidence graphs and detectors, and achieving improved accuracy and reliability on medical benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current MLLMs exhibit instability in early evidence interpretation that leads to hallucinations and globally inconsistent conclusions in clinical reasoning; there is a need for auditable, low-stochasticity reasoning processes in high-stakes medical AI.
AI.method: A four-part approach: (1) diversified short rollouts to stabilize reasoning, (2) an evidence graph to ground intermediate steps, supervised by a Hallucination Detector, (3) a Combined Uncertainty scorer to aggregate candidate reasoning paths, and (4) a controllable, multi-agent framework that orchestrates these components.
AI.result: On six medical benchmarks, MedMMV yields up to 12.7% accuracy improvement and demonstrates superior reliability; blind physician evaluations show substantially increased reasoning truthfulness without sacrificing informational content.
AI.conclusion: A verifiable, multi-agent process that controls instability and hallucination provides a robust path toward deploying trustworthy AI in high-stakes clinical decision support.

title: Factor Decorrelation Enhanced Data Removal from Deep Predictive Models
summary:
The imperative of user privacy protection and regulatory compliance
necessitates sensitive data removal in model training, yet this process often
induces distributional shifts that undermine model performance-particularly in
out-of-distribution (OOD) scenarios. We propose a novel data removal approach
that enhances deep predictive models through factor decorrelation and loss
perturbation. Our approach introduces: (1) a discriminative-preserving factor
decorrelation module employing dynamic adaptive weight adjustment and iterative
representation updating to reduce feature redundancy and minimize inter-feature
correlations. (2) a smoothed data removal mechanism with loss perturbation that
creates information-theoretic safeguards against data leakage during removal
operations. Extensive experiments on five benchmark datasets show that our
approach outperforms other baselines and consistently achieves high predictive
accuracy and robustness even under significant distribution shifts. The results
highlight its superior efficiency and adaptability in both in-distribution and
out-of-distribution scenarios.

AI.tldr: A privacy-aware data-removal method for training deep models that decorrelates factors and perturbs loss to maintain performance under distribution shifts, including OOD scenarios.
AI.motivation: Privacy regulations and data protection require removing sensitive data, which can induce distributional shifts and degrade performance, especially out-of-distribution (OOD) performance.
AI.method: Two components: (1) discriminative-preserving factor decorrelation module with dynamic adaptive weight adjustment and iterative representation updating to reduce feature redundancy and inter-feature correlations; (2) smoothed data removal with loss perturbation to create information-theoretic safeguards against data leakage during removal operations.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on five benchmark datasets shows the proposed method outperforms baselines, delivering high predictive accuracy and robustness under both in-distribution and out-of-distribution shifts, with claimed efficiency and adaptability.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides effective privacy-preserving data removal that preserves discriminative power, mitigates distribution shift, and maintains robustness, with practical potential for deployment under regulatory data-removal requirements.

title: FoR-SALE: Frame of Reference-guided Spatial Adjustment in LLM-based Diffusion Editing
summary:
Frame of Reference (FoR) is a fundamental concept in spatial reasoning that
humans utilize to comprehend and describe space. With the rapid progress in
Multimodal Language models, the moment has come to integrate this
long-overlooked dimension into these models. In particular, in text-to-image
(T2I) generation, even state-of-the-art models exhibit a significant
performance gap when spatial descriptions are provided from perspectives other
than the camera. To address this limitation, we propose Frame of
Reference-guided Spatial Adjustment in LLM-based Diffusion Editing (FoR-SALE),
an extension of the Self-correcting LLM-controlled Diffusion (SLD) framework
for T2I. For-Sale evaluates the alignment between a given text and an initially
generated image, and refines the image based on the Frame of Reference
specified in the spatial expressions. It employs vision modules to extract the
spatial configuration of the image, while simultaneously mapping the spatial
expression to a corresponding camera perspective. This unified perspective
enables direct evaluation of alignment between language and vision. When
misalignment is detected, the required editing operations are generated and
applied. FoR-SALE applies novel latent-space operations to adjust the facing
direction and depth of the generated images. We evaluate FoR-SALE on two
benchmarks specifically designed to assess spatial understanding with FoR. Our
framework improves the performance of state-of-the-art T2I models by up to 5.3%
using only a single round of correction.

AI.tldr: FoR-SALE extends the SLD framework to incorporate Frame of Reference for spatial editing in text-to-image generation. It aligns language with vision via a unified perspective and achieves single-round corrections that improve T2I performance by up to 5.3% on two FoR-focused benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current multimodal T2I models struggle with spatial descriptions from non-camera viewpoints. Frame of Reference is a missing but essential dimension for accurate spatial understanding. The work aims to close the gap by enabling unified perception and editing based on FoR.
AI.method: Extend Self-correcting LLM-controlled Diffusion (SLD) into FoR-SALE. Use vision modules to extract image spatial configuration and map spatial expressions to a camera perspective. Evaluate alignment between language and vision and generate required edits when misalignment is detected. Apply novel latent-space operations to adjust facing direction and depth. Validate on two FoR-design benchmarks.
AI.result: Demonstrates up to 5.3% improvement over state-of-the-art T2I models with a single round of correction on two FoR-oriented benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: FoR-SALE effectively integrates Frame of Reference into diffusion-based T2I editing, enabling efficient, one-shot alignment of spatial language and vision and improving generation quality in non-camera viewpoints.

title: Real-time Recognition of Human Interactions from a Single RGB-D Camera for Socially-Aware Robot Navigation
summary:
{Recognizing human interactions is essential for social robots as it enables
them to navigate safely and naturally in shared environments. Conventional
robotic systems however often focus on obstacle avoidance, neglecting social
cues necessary for seamless human-robot interaction. To address this gap, we
propose a framework to recognize human group interactions for socially aware
navigation. Our method utilizes color and depth frames from a monocular RGB-D
camera to estimate 3D human keypoints and positions. Principal component
analysis (PCA) is then used to determine dominant interaction directions. The
shoelace formula is finally applied to compute interest points and engagement
areas. Extensive experiments have been conducted to evaluate the validity of
the proposed method. The results show that our method is capable of recognizing
group interactions across different scenarios with varying numbers of
individuals. It also achieves high-speed performance, processing each frame in
approximately 4 ms on a single-board computer used in robotic systems. The
method is implemented as a ROS 2 package making it simple to integrate into
existing navigation systems. Source code is available at
https://github.com/thanhlong103/social-interaction-detector

AI.tldr: A real-time framework for recognizing human group interactions to enable socially aware navigation for robots, using monocular RGB-D to estimate 3D keypoints, PCA to find dominant interaction directions, and the shoelace formula to identify engagement areas, implemented as a ROS 2 package with ~4 ms per frame performance.
AI.motivation: Robots operating in shared human environments need to understand social cues and group interactions, not just obstacle avoidance, to navigate safely and naturally.
AI.method: From color and depth frames of a monocular RGB-D camera, estimate 3D human keypoints and positions. Apply PCA to determine dominant interaction directions. Use the shoelace formula to compute interest points and engagement areas. Implemented as a ROS 2 package for easy integration; runs at about 4 ms per frame on a single-board computer.
AI.result: The method can recognize group interactions across scenarios with varying numbers of individuals and delivers high-speed performance suitable for robotic systems; validated experimentally across different settings.
AI.conclusion: Provides a practical, real-time framework for socially aware navigation by recognizing group interactions, with open-source ROS 2 integration and source code available at the provided GitHub link.

title: humancompatible.detect: a Python Toolkit for Detecting Bias in AI Models
summary:
There is a strong recent emphasis on trustworthy AI. In particular,
international regulations, such as the AI Act, demand that AI practitioners
measure data quality on the input and estimate bias on the output of high-risk
AI systems. However, there are many challenges involved, including scalability
(MMD) and computability (Wasserstein-1) issues of traditional methods for
estimating distances on measure spaces. Here, we present
humancompatible.detect, a toolkit for bias detection that addresses these
challenges. It incorporates two newly developed methods to detect and evaluate
bias: maximum subgroup discrepancy (MSD) and subsampled $\ell_\infty$
distances. It has an easy-to-use API documented with multiple examples.
humancompatible.detect is licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0.

AI.tldr: A new bias-detection toolkit, humancompatible.detect, introduces maximum subgroup discrepancy (MSD) and subsampled l_infinity distances to address data-quality and bias estimation at scale, with an easy API and Apache 2.0 license.
AI.motivation: Regulatory emphasis on trustworthy AI (e.g., AI Act) requires measuring input data quality and estimating output bias for high-risk AI systems. Traditional distance measures (MMD, Wasserstein-1) are challenged by scalability and computability.
AI.method: Introduce two new bias-detection methods: maximum subgroup discrepancy (MSD) and subsampled ℓ∞ distances, packaged as the humancompatible.detect toolkit with an easy-to-use API and examples.
AI.result: Presentation of a practical toolkit and the two novel bias-detection methods; documentation and examples are provided; released under Apache License 2.0.
AI.conclusion: The work contributes a practical, scalable bias-detection toolkit addressing regulatory needs, enabling accessible bias measurement in high-risk AI systems.

title: PHASE: Physics-Integrated, Heterogeneity-Aware Surrogates for Scientific Simulations
summary:
Large-scale numerical simulations underpin modern scientific discovery but
remain constrained by prohibitive computational costs. AI surrogates offer
acceleration, yet adoption in mission-critical settings is limited by concerns
over physical plausibility, trustworthiness, and the fusion of heterogeneous
data. We introduce PHASE, a modular deep-learning framework for
physics-integrated, heterogeneity-aware surrogates in scientific simulations.
PHASE combines data-type-aware encoders for heterogeneous inputs with
multi-level physics-based constraints that promote consistency from local
dynamics to global system behavior. We validate PHASE on the biogeochemical
(BGC) spin-up workflow of the U.S. Department of Energy's Energy Exascale Earth
System Model (E3SM) Land Model (ELM), presenting-to our knowledge-the first
scientifically validated AI-accelerated solution for this task. Using only the
first 20 simulation years, PHASE infers a near-equilibrium state that otherwise
requires more than 1,200 years of integration, yielding an effective reduction
in required integration length by at least 60x. The framework is enabled by a
pipeline for fusing heterogeneous scientific data and demonstrates strong
generalization to higher spatial resolutions with minimal fine-tuning. These
results indicate that PHASE captures governing physical regularities rather
than surface correlations, enabling practical, physically consistent
acceleration of land-surface modeling and other complex scientific workflows.

AI.tldr: PHASE is a modular physics-informed ML framework that accelerates scientific simulations by enforcing multi-level physical constraints and heterogeneity-aware encoders, achieving ~60x reduction in required integration time for E3SM Land Model biogeochemical spin-up.
AI.motivation: Large-scale numerical simulations are computationally expensive and AI surrogates struggle with physical plausibility, trust, and integrating heterogeneous data. A trustworthy, data-fusion capable surrogate is needed for mission-critical scientific workflows.
AI.method: PHASE uses data-type-aware encoders for heterogeneous inputs and multi-level physics-based constraints to enforce consistency from local dynamics to global behavior; includes a data-fusion pipeline enabling heterogeneous data integration and generalizes to higher spatial resolutions with minimal fine-tuning.
AI.result: Applied to the BGC spin-up workflow of E3SM Land Model; with only the first 20 simulation years, PHASE infers a near-equilibrium state that would otherwise require >1,200 years of integration, achieving at least a 60x reduction in integration length; demonstrates scientifically validated AI acceleration and strong generalization.
AI.conclusion: PHASE captures governing physical regularities rather than surface correlations, enabling physically consistent acceleration of land-surface modeling and other complex scientific workflows.

title: 3DPCNet: Pose Canonicalization for Robust Viewpoint-Invariant 3D Kinematic Analysis from Monocular RGB cameras
comment:
8 pages, 6 figures, 1 table, 21 references, conference, Code
  available at: https://github.com/tharindu326/3DPCNet
summary:
Monocular 3D pose estimators produce camera-centered skeletons, creating
view-dependent kinematic signals that complicate comparative analysis in
applications such as health and sports science. We present 3DPCNet, a compact,
estimator-agnostic module that operates directly on 3D joint coordinates to
rectify any input pose into a consistent, body-centered canonical frame. Its
hybrid encoder fuses local skeletal features from a graph convolutional network
with global context from a transformer via a gated cross-attention mechanism.
From this representation, the model predicts a continuous 6D rotation that is
mapped to an $SO(3)$ matrix to align the pose. We train the model in a
self-supervised manner on the MM-Fi dataset using synthetically rotated poses,
guided by a composite loss ensuring both accurate rotation and pose
reconstruction. On the MM-Fi benchmark, 3DPCNet reduces the mean rotation error
from over 20$^{\circ}$ to 3.4$^{\circ}$ and the Mean Per Joint Position Error
from ~64 mm to 47 mm compared to a geometric baseline. Qualitative evaluations
on the TotalCapture dataset further demonstrate that our method produces
acceleration signals from video that show strong visual correspondence to
ground-truth IMU sensor data, confirming that our module removes viewpoint
variability to enable physically plausible motion analysis.

AI.tldr: 3DPCNet is a compact, estimator-agnostic module that canonicalizes monocular 3D poses into a body-centered frame by predicting a 6D rotation mapped to SO(3), using a hybrid GCN+Transformer with gated cross-attention; trained self-supervised on MM-Fi with synthetic rotations, it dramatically improves rotation accuracy and MPJPE and aligns acceleration signals with IMU data, enabling consistent motion analysis.
AI.motivation: Monocular 3D pose outputs are camera-centered and view-dependent, hindering cross-study comparability and downstream physiologic analysis. A body-centered canonical frame improves consistency, enables fairer comparisons, and better cross-modal validation with IMUs.
AI.method: A hybrid encoder that fuses local skeletal features from a graph convolutional network with global context from a transformer via gated cross-attention. The model predicts a continuous 6D rotation, mapped to an SO(3) matrix, to align the pose. Training is self-supervised on the MM-Fi dataset using synthetically rotated poses with a composite loss for rotation accuracy and pose reconstruction.
AI.result: On MM-Fi, mean rotation error drops from over 20 degrees to 3.4 degrees and MPJPE from ~64 mm to 47 mm compared to a geometric baseline. Qualitative results on TotalCapture show acceleration signals from video align well with ground-truth IMU data, indicating successful removal of viewpoint variability.
AI.conclusion: 3DPCNet provides a compact, estimator-agnostic module that enforces a body-centered canonical pose representation, enabling more consistent, physically plausible motion analysis and better cross-modal alignment with IMU data.

title: From Code to Action: Hierarchical Learning of Diffusion-VLM Policies
comment: 19 pages including references, 6 figures. Accepted to CoRL LEAP 2025
summary:
Imitation learning for robotic manipulation often suffers from limited
generalization and data scarcity, especially in complex, long-horizon tasks. In
this work, we introduce a hierarchical framework that leverages code-generating
vision-language models (VLMs) in combination with low-level diffusion policies
to effectively imitate and generalize robotic behavior. Our key insight is to
treat open-source robotic APIs not only as execution interfaces but also as
sources of structured supervision: the associated subtask functions - when
exposed - can serve as modular, semantically meaningful labels. We train a VLM
to decompose task descriptions into executable subroutines, which are then
grounded through a diffusion policy trained to imitate the corresponding robot
behavior. To handle the non-Markovian nature of both code execution and certain
real-world tasks, such as object swapping, our architecture incorporates a
memory mechanism that maintains subtask context across time. We find that this
design enables interpretable policy decomposition, improves generalization when
compared to flat policies and enables separate evaluation of high-level
planning and low-level control.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical imitation-learning framework uses code-generating vision-language models (VLMs) and low-level diffusion policies, with API-based subtask supervision and memory, to improve generalization and interpretability in long-horizon robotic manipulation.
AI.motivation: Imitation learning for robotic manipulation suffers from limited generalization and data scarcity, especially for complex, long-horizon tasks, necessitating structured supervision and scalable planning–control separation.
AI.method: A two-level system where a code-generating VLM decomposes task descriptions into executable subtasks (subroutines) grounded by a diffusion policy that imitates robot behavior. Open-source robotic APIs provide modular, semantically meaningful labels via subtask functions. A memory mechanism preserves subtask context across time to address non-Markovian aspects like object swapping.
AI.result: The approach enables interpretable policy decomposition, improves generalization over flat policies, and allows separate evaluation of high-level planning and low-level control.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging API-derived subtask supervision and memory-enabled hierarchical diffusion policies yields better generalization and interpretability in imitation learning for robotic manipulation, with modular, inspectable planning–execution separation.

title: Fin-Ally: Pioneering the Development of an Advanced, Commonsense-Embedded Conversational AI for Money Matters
summary:
The exponential technological breakthrough of the FinTech industry has
significantly enhanced user engagement through sophisticated advisory chatbots.
However, large-scale fine-tuning of LLMs can occasionally yield unprofessional
or flippant remarks, such as ``With that money, you're going to change the
world,'' which, though factually correct, can be contextually inappropriate and
erode user trust. The scarcity of domain-specific datasets has led previous
studies to focus on isolated components, such as reasoning-aware frameworks or
the enhancement of human-like response generation. To address this research
gap, we present Fin-Solution 2.O, an advanced solution that 1) introduces the
multi-turn financial conversational dataset, Fin-Vault, and 2) incorporates a
unified model, Fin-Ally, which integrates commonsense reasoning, politeness,
and human-like conversational dynamics. Fin-Ally is powered by
COMET-BART-embedded commonsense context and optimized with a Direct Preference
Optimization (DPO) mechanism to generate human-aligned responses. The novel
Fin-Vault dataset, consisting of 1,417 annotated multi-turn dialogues, enables
Fin-Ally to extend beyond basic account management to provide personalized
budgeting, real-time expense tracking, and automated financial planning. Our
comprehensive results demonstrate that incorporating commonsense context
enables language models to generate more refined, textually precise, and
professionally grounded financial guidance, positioning this approach as a
next-generation AI solution for the FinTech sector. Dataset and codes are
available at: https://github.com/sarmistha-D/Fin-Ally

AI.tldr: Fin-Solution 2.0 introduces Fin-Vault dataset and Fin-Ally model to produce professional, commonsense-augmented, multi-turn financial guidance, optimized via DPO, addressing unprofessional model remarks in FinTech chatbots.
AI.motivation: Address unprofessional or context-inappropriate responses from large-scale fine-tuning in fintech chatbots; scarcity of domain-specific dialogue data; need for personalized financial guidance and human-like interactions.
AI.method: Create Fin-Vault 1,417 annotated multi-turn dialogues; develop Fin-Ally integrating COMET-BART-level commonsense context, politeness, human-like conversational dynamics; apply Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) to align responses; dataset and code release.
AI.result: Improved generation of refined, textually precise, professionally grounded financial guidance; demonstration of advantages of commonsense context; more human-aligned responses; dataset and code available.
AI.conclusion: Fin-Ally is presented as a next-generation AI solution for the FinTech sector with promising potential, though the moderate dataset size and need for broader evaluation highlight areas for future work, including generalization, safety, and privacy considerations.

title: Data-Efficient Training by Evolved Sampling
summary:
Data selection is designed to accelerate learning with preserved performance.
To achieve this, a fundamental thought is to identify informative data samples
with significant contributions to the training. In this work, we propose
\textbf{Evolved Sampling} (\textbf{ES}), a simple yet effective framework for
\emph{dynamic} sampling along the training process. This method conducts \em
batch \em level data selection based on the dynamics of losses and augmented
\emph{loss differences}, which enables flexible \emph{frequency tuning}, and
hence significantly reduces the back propagation time with maintained model
performance. Due to its conciseness, ES is also readily extensible to
incorporate \em set \em level data selection (to form ES with pruning,
\textbf{ESWP}) for further accelerations. As a plug-and-play framework, ES(WP)
consistently achieves lossless training accelerations across various
pre-training and post-training tasks, saving up to nearly 45\% wall-clock time.
Our results motivate further investigations on the data efficiency aspect of
modern large-scale machine learning.

AI.tldr: Evolved Sampling (ES) is a dynamic data-sampling framework that selects informative batches based on loss dynamics and loss differences to accelerate training with minimal or no loss in performance; extended to ESWP for set-level pruning, achieving up to ~45% wall-clock time savings across tasks.
AI.motivation: To reduce training time while preserving model performance by focusing on informative data through dynamic batch-level sampling, addressing data efficiency in large-scale ML.
AI.method: Dynamic batch-level data selection guided by the dynamics of training losses and augmented loss differences, with flexible frequency tuning. ES can be extended to set-level data selection (ESWP) with pruning. It is a plug-and-play framework for lossless training accelerations.
AI.result: Consistently achieves lossless training accelerations across various pre-training and post-training tasks, saving up to nearly 45% of wall-clock time.
AI.conclusion: ES presents a concise, extensible approach to data-efficient learning, motivating further research into dynamic data selection for large-scale ML.

title: No Concept Left Behind: Test-Time Optimization for Compositional Text-to-Image Generation
summary:
Despite recent advances in text-to-image (T2I) models, they often fail to
faithfully render all elements of complex prompts, frequently omitting or
misrepresenting specific objects and attributes. Test-time optimization has
emerged as a promising approach to address this limitation by refining
generation without the need for retraining. In this paper, we propose a
fine-grained test-time optimization framework that enhances compositional
faithfulness in T2I generation. Unlike most of prior approaches that rely
solely on a global image/text similarity score, our method decomposes the input
prompt into semantic concepts and evaluates alignment at both the global and
concept levels. A fine-grained variant of CLIP is used to compute concept-level
correspondence, producing detailed feedback on missing or inaccurate concepts.
This feedback is fed into an iterative prompt refinement loop, enabling the
large language model to propose improved prompts. Experiments on DrawBench and
CompBench prompts demonstrate that our method significantly improves concept
coverage and human-judged faithfulness over both standard test-time
optimization and the base T2I model. Code is available at:
https://github.com/AmirMansurian/NoConceptLeftBehind

AI.tldr: A fine-grained test-time optimization framework for text-to-image generation that decomposes prompts into semantic concepts and uses a concept-level CLIP to improve compositional faithfulness, guided by an iterative prompt refinement loop with an LLM.
AI.motivation: Current T2I models often misrender complex prompts. Global similarity scores in test-time optimization fail to ensure faithful rendering of individual objects/attributes; a compositional, concept-aware approach can improve faithfulness.
AI.method: Decompose the input prompt into semantic concepts; use a fine-grained CLIP variant to measure concept-level alignment; provide detailed feedback on missing/incorrect concepts; feed feedback into an iterative prompt refinement loop where an LLM proposes improved prompts; evaluate on DrawBench and CompBench with human judgments.
AI.result: The approach significantly improves concept coverage and human-judged faithfulness compared with standard test-time optimization and the base T2I model.
AI.conclusion: Fine-grained, concept-level feedback enables better compositional faithfulness in T2I generation, demonstrating the value of integrating concept-aware evaluation with iterative prompt refinement; code is released for reproducibility.

title: CineWild: Balancing Art and Robotics for Ethical Wildlife Documentary Filmmaking
summary:
Drones, or unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), have become powerful tools across
domains-from industry to the arts. In documentary filmmaking, they offer
dynamic, otherwise unreachable perspectives, transforming how stories are told.
Wildlife documentaries especially benefit, yet drones also raise ethical
concerns: the risk of disturbing the animals they aim to capture. This paper
introduces CineWild, an autonomous UAV framework that combines robotics,
cinematography, and ethics. Built on model predictive control, CineWild
dynamically adjusts flight paths and camera settings to balance cinematic
quality with animal welfare. Key features include adaptive zoom for filming
from acoustic and visual safe distances, path-planning that avoids an animal's
field of view, and smooth, low-noise maneuvers. CineWild exemplifies
interdisciplinary innovation-bridging engineering, visual storytelling, and
environmental ethics. We validate the system through simulation studies and
will release the code upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: CineWild autonomously balances cinematic quality and animal welfare in wildlife filming by using model predictive control to adapt drone flight and camera settings, with adaptive zoom, field-of-view-aware path planning, and smooth, quiet maneuvers; validated in simulation with code to be released.
AI.motivation: Wildlife filmmaking faces a trade-off between capturing cinematic shots and minimizing disturbance to animals; there is a need for an interdisciplinary framework combining robotics, cinematography, and ethics.
AI.method: A model predictive control (MPC) based framework that dynamically adjusts flight paths and camera parameters; adaptive zoom based on acoustic and visual safe distances; path planning that avoids the animal’s field of view; emphasizes smooth, low-noise maneuvers; evaluated via simulations; code release planned upon acceptance.
AI.result: Simulation studies show the approach can balance cinematography quality with animal welfare; no field tests reported; code will be released after acceptance.
AI.conclusion: CineWild demonstrates an interdisciplinary approach bridging engineering, storytelling, and environmental ethics, offering a path toward safer, higher-quality wildlife drone cinematography.

title: From Static to Dynamic: Adaptive Monte Carlo Search for Mathematical Process Supervision
summary:
The quality of process data plays a key role in training a Process Reward
Model (PRM), which can enhance the complex mathematical reasoning capability of
large language models. Existing methods estimate the quality of reasoning steps
based on a fixed-budget sampling strategy and navigate a vast search space to
perform path expansion during the automated data generation process, resulting
in their inefficiency and inflexibility. To address these issues, we propose
Adaptive Monte Carlo Search (AMCS), a framework that transforms data generation
from fixed, static to adaptive, dynamic search at the level of node value
estimation and path expansion. On one hand, AMCS adaptively refines estimation
by allocating more samples to uncertain reasoning steps while using fewer
samples for those that are easier to estimate. On the other hand, it enhances
the path expansion through a Monte Carlo algorithm with a temporally adaptive
policy that begins with broad exploration and gradually shifts toward
exploiting the most promising directions. With AMCS, we construct a large-scale
dataset MathSearch-200K of about 200K process supervision examples for training
PRMs. To verify the effectiveness of our method, we conduct extensive
experiments on four mathematical reasoning benchmarks. Experimental results
show that Qwen2.5-Math-7B-PRM-AMCS achieves up to 76.2% accuracy on MATH500
with GLM-4-9B, outperforming all baseline PRMs. Notably, a 7B model supervised
by Qwen2.5-Math-7B-PRM-AMCS surpasses a 72B model with weaker supervision.
Moreover, Qwen2.5-Math-7B-PRM-AMCS maintains consistent advantages on
out-of-distribution problems, demonstrating strong generalization capability.
Our code is available at https://github.com/reml-group/AMCS.

AI.tldr: Adaptive Monte Carlo Search (AMCS) for data generation in Process Reward Models (PRMs) improves efficiency and generalization by adaptive sampling and temporal exploration-exploitation in path expansion; results on math reasoning benchmarks with a 200K dataset (MathSearch-200K).
AI.motivation: Existing PRM data generation relies on fixed-budget sampling, which is inefficient and inflexible in exploring the reasoning space. There is a need for adaptive, dynamic search to improve data quality and training efficacy for LLMs on mathematical reasoning.
AI.method: Introduce Adaptive Monte Carlo Search (AMCS) that adaptively refines node-value estimation by allocating more samples to uncertain steps and fewer to easier ones, and uses a temporally adaptive policy for path expansion from exploration to exploitation. Construct MathSearch-200K dataset and train PRMs; evaluate on four math reasoning benchmarks.
AI.result: AMCS-based models achieve strong performance, e.g., Qwen2.5-Math-7B-PRM-AMCS reaches up to 76.2% accuracy on MATH500 with GLM-4-9B, outperforming baselines. A 7B model supervised by AMCS-based PRM surpasses a 72B model with weaker supervision. Robust gains on out-of-distribution problems.
AI.conclusion: AMCS effectively enhances data generation quality and PRM training, improving accuracy and generalization in mathematical reasoning tasks; code is publicly available.

title: Generative Evolutionary Meta-Solver (GEMS): Scalable Surrogate-Free Multi-Agent Learning
summary:
Scalable multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) remains a central
challenge for AI. Existing population-based methods, like Policy-Space Response
Oracles, PSRO, require storing explicit policy populations and constructing
full payoff matrices, incurring quadratic computation and linear memory costs.
We present Generative Evolutionary Meta-Solver (GEMS), a surrogate-free
framework that replaces explicit populations with a compact set of latent
anchors and a single amortized generator. Instead of exhaustively constructing
the payoff matrix, GEMS relies on unbiased Monte Carlo rollouts,
multiplicative-weights meta-dynamics, and a model-free empirical-Bernstein UCB
oracle to adaptively expand the policy set. Best responses are trained within
the generator using an advantage-based trust-region objective, eliminating the
need to store and train separate actors. We evaluated GEMS in a variety of
Two-player and Multi-Player games such as the Deceptive Messages Game, Kuhn
Poker and Multi-Particle environment. We find that GEMS is up to ~6x faster,
has 1.3x less memory usage than PSRO, while also reaps higher rewards
simultaneously. These results demonstrate that GEMS retains the game theoretic
guarantees of PSRO, while overcoming its fundamental inefficiencies, hence
enabling scalable multi-agent learning in multiple domains.

AI.tldr: GEMS is a surrogate-free, scalable MARL framework that replaces explicit policy populations with latent anchors and a single amortized generator, enabling faster, more memory-efficient learning with higher rewards than PSRO while preserving game-theoretic guarantees.
AI.motivation: PSRO and similar population-based MARL methods require storing explicit policy populations and constructing payoff matrices, leading to quadratic computation and linear memory costs. This hinders scalability. There is a need for a memory-efficient, scalable alternative that retains theoretical guarantees.
AI.method: GEMS replaces explicit populations with a compact set of latent anchors and one amortized generator. It avoids building payoff matrices by using unbiased Monte Carlo rollouts, multiplicative-weights meta-dynamics, and a model-free empirical-Bernstein UCB oracle to adaptively expand the policy set. Best responses are trained inside the generator using an advantage-based trust-region objective, so there is no separate actor training or population storage.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation across two-player and multi-player games (Deceptive Messages Game, Kuhn Poker, Multi-Particle environment) shows GEMS is up to ~6x faster and uses ~1.3x less memory than PSRO, while achieving higher rewards.
AI.conclusion: GEMS retains the game-theoretic guarantees of PSRO while overcoming its inefficiencies, enabling scalable multi-agent learning across multiple domains.

title: Robust Multi-Modal Face Anti-Spoofing with Domain Adaptation: Tackling Missing Modalities, Noisy Pseudo-Labels, and Model Degradation
summary:
Recent multi-modal face anti-spoofing (FAS) methods have investigated the
potential of leveraging multiple modalities to distinguish live and spoof
faces. However, pre-adapted multi-modal FAS models often fail to detect unseen
attacks from new target domains. Although a more realistic domain adaptation
(DA) scenario has been proposed for single-modal FAS to learn specific spoof
attacks during inference, DA remains unexplored in multi-modal FAS methods. In
this paper, we propose a novel framework, MFAS-DANet, to address three major
challenges in multi-modal FAS under the DA scenario: missing modalities, noisy
pseudo labels, and model degradation. First, to tackle the issue of missing
modalities, we propose extracting complementary features from other modalities
to substitute missing modality features or enhance existing ones. Next, to
reduce the impact of noisy pseudo labels during model adaptation, we propose
deriving reliable pseudo labels by leveraging prediction uncertainty across
different modalities. Finally, to prevent model degradation, we design an
adaptive mechanism that decreases the loss weight during unstable adaptations
and increasing it during stable ones. Extensive experiments demonstrate the
effectiveness and state-of-the-art performance of our proposed MFAS-DANet.

AI.tldr: MFAS-DANet is a domain-adaptive, multi-modal face anti-spoofing framework that handles missing modalities, noisy pseudo labels, and model degradation by substituting features from available modalities, using cross-modal uncertainty for pseudo-labels, and adapting loss weights during training; it achieves state-of-the-art results under DA.
AI.motivation: Multi-modal FAS often relies on complete modality inputs and fails to adapt to unseen attacks in new target domains. While domain adaptation has been explored for single-modal FAS, it remains underexplored for multi-modal FAS, and practical DA must handle missing modalities, label noise, and unstable adaptation.
AI.method: MFAS-DANet introduces: (1) missing modality compensation by extracting complementary features from other modalities to substitute or enrich missing ones; (2) robust pseudo-labels using prediction uncertainty across modalities to reduce label noise during adaptation; (3) an adaptive loss-weighting mechanism that decreases loss during unstable adaptation and increases it during stable phases to prevent model degradation, all within a DA framework for multi-modal FAS.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate the framework’s effectiveness, achieving state-of-the-art performance for multi-modal FAS under domain adaptation settings.
AI.conclusion: MFAS-DANet effectively addresses three core challenges in multi-modal FAS under DA—missing modalities, noisy pseudo labels, and model degradation—leading to superior performance and robust cross-domain spoof detection.

title: Trajectory Prediction via Bayesian Intention Inference under Unknown Goals and Kinematics
summary:
This work introduces an adaptive Bayesian algorithm for real-time trajectory
prediction via intention inference, where a target's intentions and motion
characteristics are unknown and subject to change. The method concurrently
estimates two critical variables: the target's current intention, modeled as a
Markovian latent state, and an intention parameter that describes the target's
adherence to a shortest-path policy. By integrating this joint update
technique, the algorithm maintains robustness against abrupt intention shifts
and unknown motion dynamics. A sampling-based trajectory prediction mechanism
then exploits these adaptive estimates to generate probabilistic forecasts with
quantified uncertainty. We validate the framework through numerical
experiments: Ablation studies of two cases, and a 500-trial Monte Carlo
analysis; Hardware demonstrations on quadrotor and quadrupedal platforms.
Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly
outperforms non-adaptive and partially adaptive methods. The method operates in
real time around 270 Hz without requiring training or detailed prior knowledge
of target behavior, showcasing its applicability in various robotic systems.

AI.tldr: Adaptive Bayesian real-time trajectory prediction via joint intention inference (Markovian latent state) and intention-parameter estimation; robust to abrupt changes; 270 Hz real-time; validated on simulations and hardware; outperforms non-adaptive baselines.
AI.motivation: Real-time belief over target intentions and motion dynamics that can change unpredictably, without extensive prior training; need probabilistic forecasts with quantified uncertainty for autonomous agents.
AI.method: Concurrent online estimation of latent intention state and adherence parameter; Bayesian filtering with a sampling-based trajectory predictor; use a Markovian latent state for intention; update in real time to handle abrupt shifts; generate probabilistic forecasts with uncertainty.
AI.result: Ablation studies on two cases; 500-trial Monte Carlo analysis; hardware demonstrations on quadrotor and quadrupedal platforms; significantly outperforms non-adaptive and partially adaptive methods; operates at ~270 Hz in real time without training or detailed prior knowledge.
AI.conclusion: An adaptive joint estimation framework yields robust, real-time, intention-aware trajectory prediction with quantified uncertainty, applicable across diverse robotic systems without extensive prior data.

title: Plan before Solving: Problem-Aware Strategy Routing for Mathematical Reasoning with LLMs
summary:
Existing methods usually leverage a fixed strategy, such as natural language
reasoning, code-augmented reasoning, tool-integrated reasoning, or
ensemble-based reasoning, to guide Large Language Models (LLMs) to perform
mathematical reasoning. Our analysis reveals that the single strategy cannot
adapt to problem-specific requirements and thus overlooks the trade-off between
effectiveness and efficiency. To address these issues, we propose Planning and
Routing through Instance-Specific Modeling (PRISM), a novel framework that
decouples mathematical reasoning into two stages: strategy planning and
targeted execution. Specifically, we first curate a multi-strategy preference
dataset, which we call MathStrat, capturing correctness, process quality, and
computational efficiency for each problem--strategy pair. Then, we train a
lightweight Strategy Adapter based on the dataset to obtain confidence
distributions over the mentioned four reasoning strategies. At inference time,
an adaptive routing policy dynamically tailors the reasoning approach based on
predictor confidence. It directs the model to use single-strategy execution for
high-confidence predictions, dual-strategy verification for competitive
scenarios, or comprehensive multi-strategy exploration for uncertain cases.
Extensive experiments across five mathematical reasoning benchmarks demonstrate
that PRISM consistently outperforms individual strategies and ensemble
baselines, achieving improvements ranging from 0.9% to 7.6% across different
base models. The adaptive routing approach shows particularly strong benefits
for mathematical reasoning tasks across diverse model architectures. Our code
is released at https://github.com/reml-group/PRISM.

AI.tldr: PRISM decouples mathematical reasoning into instance-specific planning and targeted execution, using a MathStrat dataset and a Strategy Adapter to route LLMs across single, dual, or multi-strategy reasoning, improving performance and efficiency across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Single fixed reasoning strategies cannot adapt to problem-specific requirements, leading to suboptimal trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency. An adaptive, instance-level planning approach is needed to select appropriate strategies per problem.
AI.method: Introduce PRISM framework with two stages: strategy planning and targeted execution. Create MathStrat dataset capturing correctness, process quality, and computational cost for each problem-strategy pair. Train a lightweight Strategy Adapter to estimate confidence over four strategies. At inference, use an adaptive routing policy to choose: (i) single-strategy for high-confidence predictions, (ii) dual-strategy verification for competitive cases, or (iii) multi-strategy exploration for uncertain cases.
AI.result: PRISM consistently outperforms single strategies and ensemble baselines, with improvements ranging from 0.9% to 7.6% across five mathematical reasoning benchmarks and various base models. The adaptive routing approach shows strong benefits across model architectures.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling reasoning into strategy planning and adaptive execution enables dynamic, problem-specific selection among reasoning strategies, yielding improvements in accuracy and efficiency. The approach is validated across multiple benchmarks and model types, and the authors release their code.

title: Solve Smart, Not Often: Policy Learning for Costly MILP Re-solving
summary:
A common challenge in real-time operations is deciding whether to re-solve an
optimization problem or continue using an existing solution. While modern data
platforms may collect information at high frequencies, many real-time
operations require repeatedly solving computationally intensive optimization
problems formulated as Mixed-Integer Linear Programs (MILPs). Determining when
to re-solve is, therefore, an economically important question. This problem
poses several challenges: 1) How to characterize solution optimality and
solving cost; 2) How to detect environmental changes and select beneficial
samples for solving the MILP; 3) Given the large time horizon and non-MDP
structure, vanilla reinforcement learning (RL) methods are not directly
applicable and tend to suffer from value function explosion. Existing
literature largely focuses on heuristics, low-data settings, and smooth
objectives, with little focus on common NP-hard MILPs. We propose a framework
called Proximal Policy Optimization with Change Point Detection (POC), which
systematically offers a solution for balancing performance and cost when
deciding appropriate re-solving times. Theoretically, we establish the
relationship between the number of re-solves and the re-solving cost. To test
our framework, we assemble eight synthetic and real-world datasets, and show
that POC consistently outperforms existing baselines by 2%-17%. As a side
benefit, our work fills the gap in the literature by introducing real-time MILP
benchmarks and evaluation criteria.

AI.tldr: A framework named POC (Proximal Policy Optimization with Change Point Detection) guides when to re-solve MILPs in real-time operations. It uses PPO plus change-point detection to balance solution quality and re-solving cost, addressing non-MDP, high-horizon settings; shows 2-17% improvement over baselines on eight datasets and introduces real-time MILP benchmarks.
AI.motivation: In real-time operations, deciding whether to re-solve computationally expensive MILPs is economically critical. High-frequency data collection clashes with costly optimization; challenges include characterizing optimality and cost, detecting environmental changes, sample selection, and the non-MDP, long-horizon nature unsuitable for vanilla RL; current literature relies on heuristics and smooth objectives.
AI.method: Propose POC: a framework that integrates change-point detection with Proximal Policy Optimization to decide re-solve times. Theoretical linkage between number of re-solves and re-solving cost. Empirically validated on eight synthetic/real datasets; includes new real-time MILP benchmarks and evaluation criteria.
AI.result: POC consistently outperforms baselines by 2-17% across eight datasets; demonstrates practical utility and contributes benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: POC provides a principled approach to balancing performance and cost in re-solving real-time MILPs, addressing a gap in literature and enabling real-time MILP benchmarking; potential for broader applicability in NP-hard optimization settings.

title: RestoRect: Degraded Image Restoration via Latent Rectified Flow & Feature Distillation
summary:
Current approaches for restoration of degraded images face a critical
trade-off: high-performance models are too slow for practical use, while fast
models produce poor results. Knowledge distillation transfers teacher knowledge
to students, but existing static feature matching methods cannot capture how
modern transformer architectures dynamically generate features. We propose
'RestoRect', a novel Latent Rectified Flow Feature Distillation method for
restoring degraded images. We apply rectified flow to reformulate feature
distillation as a generative process where students learn to synthesize
teacher-quality features through learnable trajectories in latent space. Our
framework combines Retinex theory for physics-based decomposition with
learnable anisotropic diffusion constraints, and trigonometric color space
polarization. We introduce a Feature Layer Extraction loss for robust knowledge
transfer between different network architectures through cross-normalized
transformer feature alignment with percentile-based outlier detection.
RestoRect achieves better training stability, and faster convergence and
inference while preserving restoration quality. We demonstrate superior results
across 15 image restoration datasets, covering 4 tasks, on 8 metrics.

AI.tldr: A fast, knowledge-distillation-based image restoration method (RestoRect) that uses latent rectified flow to simulate teacher features for lightweight students, combining Retinex-based physics with diffusion and color polarization; introduces a cross-architecture feature transfer via a Feature Layer Extraction loss; claims improved stability, speed, and restoration quality across 15 datasets and 4 tasks.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between high-quality restoration and practical speed by enabling lightweight models to emulate transformer-based teacher features. Static feature matching fails to capture dynamic, context-dependent features produced by modern transformers.
AI.method: RestoRect reformulates distillation as a generative process over latent-space trajectories using latent rectified flow. It fuses Retinex-based physics decomposition, learnable anisotropic diffusion constraints, and trigonometric color space polarization. A Feature Layer Extraction loss enables cross-architecture, percentile-based outlier-robust alignment of transformer features.
AI.result: Empirically, the method yields better training stability, faster convergence and inference while maintaining or improving restoration quality across 15 image restoration datasets, covering 4 tasks and evaluated on 8 metrics.
AI.conclusion: RestoRect offers a practical distillation framework that captures dynamic transformer feature generation via latent trajectories, enabling fast yet high-quality restoration and generalizing across tasks and architectures. Potentially extendable to other vision domains where teacher-student dynamics are critical.

title: World-Env: Leveraging World Model as a Virtual Environment for VLA Post-Training
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models trained via imitation learning suffer
from significant performance degradation in data-scarce scenarios due to their
reliance on large-scale demonstration datasets. Although reinforcement learning
(RL)-based post-training has proven effective in addressing data scarcity, its
application to VLA models is hindered by the non-resettable nature of
real-world environments. This limitation is particularly critical in high-risk
domains such as industrial automation, where interactions often induce state
changes that are costly or infeasible to revert. Furthermore, existing VLA
approaches lack a reliable mechanism for detecting task completion, leading to
redundant actions that reduce overall task success rates. To address these
challenges, we propose World-Env, an RL-based post-training framework that
replaces physical interaction with a low-cost, world model-based virtual
simulator. World-Env consists of two key components: (1) a video-based world
simulator that generates temporally consistent future visual observations, and
(2) a vision-language model (VLM)-guided instant reflector that provides
continuous reward signals and predicts action termination. This simulated
environment enables VLA models to safely explore and generalize beyond their
initial imitation learning distribution. Our method achieves notable
performance gains with as few as five expert demonstrations per task.
Experiments on complex robotic manipulation tasks demonstrate that World-Env
effectively overcomes the data inefficiency, safety constraints, and
inefficient execution of conventional VLA models that rely on real-world
interaction, offering a practical and scalable solution for post-training in
resource-constrained settings.

AI.tldr: RL-based post-training for Vision-Language-Action (VLA) via a video-based world model simulator with a VLM-guided reflector, enabling data-efficient learning in non-resettable, high-risk tasks.
AI.motivation: Imitation-learning VLA models perform poorly with limited demonstrations; RL post-training helps data efficiency but real-world non-resettable environments hinder exploration and safety; need reliable task completion signaling.
AI.method: Two components: (1) a video-based world simulator that produces temporally consistent future visuals, (2) a vision-language model (VLM)-guided instant reflector that provides continuous rewards and predicts action termination, enabling safe, virtual interaction instead of physical samples.
AI.result: The approach achieves notable performance gains with as few as five expert demonstrations per task and demonstrates improved data efficiency, safety, and execution efficiency over conventional real-world VLA methods.
AI.conclusion: World-Env enables safe, scalable post-training for VLA in data-scarce, high-risk settings by leveraging a virtual world model and VLM-guided signals to support exploration and reliable task termination.

title: Towards Safe Reasoning in Large Reasoning Models via Corrective Intervention
summary:
Although Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) have progressed in solving complex
problems, their chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning often contains harmful content
that can persist even when the final responses appear safe. We show that this
issue still remains in existing methods which overlook the unique significance
of safe reasoning, undermining their trustworthiness and posing potential risks
in applications if unsafe reasoning is accessible for and exploited by
malicious users. We therefore shift our focus to aligning the safety of
reasoning itself in this paper and explore process supervision as the solution.
However, simply rewarding safe reasoning proves inadequate due to low rollout
diversity and limited training signals. To tackle this challenge, we first
delve into the characteristics of safe reasoning and uncover several critical
insights that 1) safe reasoning is often consolidated by a few critical steps
of safety triggers; 2) compliance cues strongly correlate with unsafe
continuations; and 3) corrective interventions reliably steer unsafe
trajectories towards safer traces. Motivated by these, we propose Intervened
Preference Optimization (IPO), an alignment method that enforces safe reasoning
by substituting compliance steps with safety triggers and constructing pairs
for preference learning with strong signals. Experiments on jailbreak and
adversarial safety benchmarks demonstrate that IPO remarkably improves overall
safety regarding both reasoning and responses, outperforming SFT-based and
RL-based baselines with a relative reduction of over 30% in harmfulness, while
preserving excellent performance across diverse reasoning tasks. The results
highlight the importance of explicit alignment for reasoning and provide a
practical path to safer LRMs.

AI.tldr: IPO aligns the safety of reasoning in Large Reasoning Models, reducing harmful content by >30% while maintaining task performance.
AI.motivation: Current methods ignore the safety of the reasoning process; harmful CoT can persist and be exploited; need to ensure safe reasoning to improve trust and safety.
AI.method: Propose Intervened Preference Optimization (IPO): leverage insights that safe reasoning is driven by a few triggers; substitute compliance steps with safety triggers; construct preference-learning data pairs with strong safety signals; use process supervision to steer unsafe trajectories toward safe traces.
AI.result: Benchmarks on jailbreak/adversarial safety show IPO achieves >30% relative reduction in harmfulness compared with SFT/RL baselines; preserves performance across diverse reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly aligning the reasoning process is crucial; IPO offers a practical pathway to safer LLMs by focusing on safety triggers and strong-signal preference learning.

title: Drift-Adapter: A Practical Approach to Near Zero-Downtime Embedding Model Upgrades in Vector Databases
summary:
Upgrading embedding models in production vector databases typically requires
re-encoding the entire corpus and rebuilding the Approximate Nearest Neighbor
(ANN) index, leading to significant operational disruption and computational
cost. This paper presents Drift-Adapter, a lightweight, learnable
transformation layer designed to bridge embedding spaces between model
versions. By mapping new queries into the legacy embedding space, Drift-Adapter
enables the continued use of the existing ANN index, effectively deferring full
re-computation. We systematically evaluate three adapter parameterizations:
Orthogonal Procrustes, Low-Rank Affine, and a compact Residual MLP, trained on
a small sample of paired old and new embeddings. Experiments on MTEB text
corpora and a CLIP image model upgrade (1M items) show that Drift-Adapter
recovers 95-99% of the retrieval recall (Recall@10, MRR) of a full
re-embedding, adding less than 10 microseconds of query latency. Compared to
operational strategies like full re-indexing or dual-index serving,
Drift-Adapter reduces recompute costs by over 100 times and facilitates
upgrades with near-zero operational interruption. We analyze robustness to
varied model drift, training data size, scalability to billion-item systems,
and the impact of design choices like diagonal scaling, demonstrating
Drift-Adapter's viability as a pragmatic solution for agile model deployment.

AI.tldr: Drift-Adapter is a lightweight, learnable transform that maps new embeddings into the old space to avoid full re-embedding/reindexing after model upgrades, preserving ~95–99% of retrieval quality with minimal latency and substantial recompute savings.
AI.motivation: To minimize operational disruption and computational cost when upgrading embedding models in production vector databases by sidestepping full corpus re-encoding and ANN index rebuilds.
AI.method: Systematic evaluation of three adapter variants—Orthogonal Procrustes, Low-Rank Affine, and compact Residual MLP—trained on paired old/new embeddings; experiments on MTEB text corpora and a 1M-item CLIP image upgrade to assess recall, latency, robustness, and scalability.
AI.result: Drift-Adapter recovers 95–99% of full re-embedding recall (Recall@10, MRR), with <10 microseconds additional per-query latency; recompute costs reduced by >100x versus full re-indexing or dual-index approaches; robust to drift and scalable to large item sets.
AI.conclusion: A pragmatic, near-zero-interruption upgrade mechanism that integrates with existing ANN indices; suitable for agile deployments and scalable to billion-item systems, with design choices (e.g., diagonal scaling) affecting performance.

title: Orientation-anchored Hyper-Gaussian for 4D Reconstruction from Casual Videos
summary:
We present Orientation-anchored Gaussian Splatting (OriGS), a novel framework
for high-quality 4D reconstruction from casually captured monocular videos.
While recent advances extend 3D Gaussian Splatting to dynamic scenes via
various motion anchors, such as graph nodes or spline control points, they
often rely on low-rank assumptions and fall short in modeling complex,
region-specific deformations inherent to unconstrained dynamics. OriGS
addresses this by introducing a hyperdimensional representation grounded in
scene orientation. We first estimate a Global Orientation Field that propagates
principal forward directions across space and time, serving as stable
structural guidance for dynamic modeling. Built upon this, we propose
Orientation-aware Hyper-Gaussian, a unified formulation that embeds time,
space, geometry, and orientation into a coherent probabilistic state. This
enables inferring region-specific deformation through principled conditioned
slicing, adaptively capturing diverse local dynamics in alignment with global
motion intent. Experiments demonstrate the superior reconstruction fidelity of
OriGS over mainstream methods in challenging real-world dynamic scenes.

AI.tldr: OriGS introduces orientation-anchored Gaussian Splatting for high-quality 4D reconstruction from monocular videos, featuring a Global Orientation Field and Orientation-aware Hyper-Gaussian to model time-space-geometry-orientation, enabling region-specific deformations and achieving superior fidelity over mainstream methods in challenging dynamic scenes.
AI.motivation: Existing dynamic 3D Gaussian Splatting methods rely on simple, low-rank motion anchors (e.g., graph nodes or spline control points) and struggle to capture complex, region-specific deformations in unconstrained dynamic scenes. A global orientation-guided, high-dimensional representation is needed to accurately model both global motion intent and local dynamics.
AI.method: 1) Estimate a Global Orientation Field that propagates principal forward directions across space-time to provide stable structural guidance. 2) Propose Orientation-aware Hyper-Gaussian, a unified formulation that embeds time, space, geometry, and orientation into a probabilistic state. 3) Enable principled conditioned slicing to infer region-specific deformation aligned with the global motion, extending Gaussian Splatting to 4D dynamic scenes.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate superior reconstruction fidelity of OriGS over mainstream methods on challenging real-world dynamic scenes.
AI.conclusion: OriGS delivers a stable, orientation-guided, hyper-dimensional representation for 4D reconstruction from casually captured monocular videos, enabling accurate modeling of complex dynamics and improved reconstruction quality.

title: MSG: Multi-Stream Generative Policies for Sample-Efficient Robotic Manipulation
summary:
Generative robot policies such as Flow Matching offer flexible, multi-modal
policy learning but are sample-inefficient. Although object-centric policies
improve sample efficiency, it does not resolve this limitation. In this work,
we propose Multi-Stream Generative Policy (MSG), an inference-time composition
framework that trains multiple object-centric policies and combines them at
inference to improve generalization and sample efficiency. MSG is
model-agnostic and inference-only, hence widely applicable to various
generative policies and training paradigms. We perform extensive experiments
both in simulation and on a real robot, demonstrating that our approach learns
high-quality generative policies from as few as five demonstrations, resulting
in a 95% reduction in demonstrations, and improves policy performance by 89
percent compared to single-stream approaches. Furthermore, we present
comprehensive ablation studies on various composition strategies and provide
practical recommendations for deployment. Finally, MSG enables zero-shot object
instance transfer. We make our code publicly available at
https://msg.cs.uni-freiburg.de.

AI.tldr: MSG introduces inference-time composition of multiple object-centric policies to improve sample efficiency and generalization for generative robot policies, achieving strong gains from as few as five demonstrations and enabling zero-shot transfer; code released.
AI.motivation: Flow Matching and other generative policies are flexible but do not scale in sample efficiency. Object-centric policies help but still face limitations. A way to combine multiple policies at inference could enhance generalization and reduce data requirements.
AI.method: Train multiple object-centric policies (multi-stream) and compose them at inference to produce a final policy. Model-agnostic and inference-only. Analyze various composition strategies via ablations. Validate on simulation and real robot; demonstrate zero-shot transfer.
AI.result: Demonstrates high-quality generative policies from as few as five demonstrations, 95% reduction in demonstrations, 89% improvement over single-stream approaches. Comprehensive ablations and deployment recommendations. Real-world transfers and zero-shot object transfer shown. Code publicly released.
AI.conclusion: MSG is widely applicable across generative policies and training paradigms, improving sample efficiency and generalization, and enabling zero-shot transfer; practical guidelines provided for deployment.

title: A Systematic Review of Digital Twin-Driven Predictive Maintenance in Industrial Engineering: Taxonomy, Architectural Elements, and Future Research Directions
summary:
With the increasing complexity of industrial systems, there is a pressing
need for predictive maintenance to avoid costly downtime and disastrous
outcomes that could be life-threatening in certain domains. With the growing
popularity of the Internet of Things, Artificial Intelligence, machine
learning, and real-time big data analytics, there is a unique opportunity for
efficient predictive maintenance to forecast equipment failures for real-time
intervention and optimize maintenance actions, as traditional reactive and
preventive maintenance practices are often inadequate to meet the requirements
for the industry to provide quality-of-services of operations. Central to this
evolution is digital twin technology, an adaptive virtual replica that
continuously monitors and integrates sensor data to simulate and improve asset
performance. Despite remarkable progress in digital twin implementations, such
as considering DT in predictive maintenance for industrial engineering. This
paper aims to address this void. We perform a retrospective analysis of the
temporal evolution of the digital twin in predictive maintenance for industrial
engineering to capture the applications, middleware, and technological
requirements that led to the development of the digital twin from its inception
to the AI-enabled digital twin and its self-learning models. We provide a
layered architecture of the digital twin technology, as well as a taxonomy of
the technology-enabled industrial engineering applications systems, middleware,
and the used Artificial Intelligence algorithms. We provide insights into these
systems for the realization of a trustworthy and efficient smart digital-twin
industrial engineering ecosystem. We discuss future research directions in
digital twin for predictive maintenance in industrial engineering.

AI.tldr: A retrospective study on the evolution of digital twin (DT) in predictive maintenance for industrial engineering, delivering a layered DT architecture, a taxonomy of tech-enabled applications/middleware/AI algorithms, and insights toward a trustworthy, efficient smart DT ecosystem, with future research directions.
AI.motivation: Rising complexity of industrial systems and the need for predictive maintenance to prevent downtime and safety-critical failures; IoT, AI, and real-time analytics enable real-time interventions; DT is a central enabling technology, but gaps remain in understanding its evolution, architecture, and AI-enabled self-learning capabilities.
AI.method: Retrospective temporal analysis of the DT evolution in predictive maintenance for industrial engineering; development of a layered DT architecture; creation of a taxonomy covering applications, middleware, and AI algorithms; synthesis of insights and discussion of future research directions.
AI.result: Proposes a layered DT architecture and a taxonomy for technology-enabled industrial engineering applications, systems, middleware, and AI algorithms; provides insights aimed at realizing a trustworthy and efficient smart DT ecosystem; identifies future research directions for DT in predictive maintenance.
AI.conclusion: Future research should advance trustworthy, efficient, AI-enabled DTs for predictive maintenance in industrial engineering, addressing architectural, middleware, and algorithmic aspects and bridging gaps toward self-learning capabilities.

title: Memory-Efficient Fine-Tuning via Low-Rank Activation Compression
summary:
The parameter-efficient fine-tuning paradigm has garnered significant
attention with the advancement of foundation models. Although numerous methods
have been proposed to reduce the number of trainable parameters, their
substantial memory overhead remains a critical bottleneck that hinders
practical deployment. In this paper, we observe that model activations
constitute a major source of memory consumption, especially under large batch
sizes and long context lengths; however, the rank of the activations remains
consistently low. Motivated by this insight, we propose a memory-efficient
fine-tuning approach Low-Rank Activation Compression (LoRAct). Unlike prior
work, LoRAct provides a more flexible and versatile compressing strategy that
can be applied online during the forward pass without the need for any
calibration data. Moreover, LoRAct incorporates a novel sampling-based
orthogonal decomposition algorithm specifically designed for low-rank matrices,
offering improved computational efficiency and a tighter error bound compared
to the widely used RSVD. Experiments on both vision and language tasks
demonstrate the effectiveness of LoRAct. Notably, LoRAct further reduces
activation memory by approximately 80% in comparison with the widely adopted
LoRA method, while maintaining competitive performance. The source code is
available at https://github.com/shijxcs/meft.

AI.tldr: LoRAct proposes memory-efficient fine-tuning via online low-rank activation compression, reducing activation memory by ~80% over LoRA with competitive performance, and without calibration data.
AI.motivation: Activation memory is a major bottleneck in parameter-efficient fine-tuning, especially with large batch sizes and long contexts; activations exhibit low rank, suggesting a low-rank compression strategy.
AI.method: Introduce Low-Rank Activation Compression (LoRAct) that compresses activations online during the forward pass without calibration data, and a sampling-based orthogonal decomposition algorithm for low-rank matrices offering faster computation and tighter error bounds than RSVD.
AI.result: Experiments on vision and language tasks show significant activation-memory reduction (~80% vs LoRA) while maintaining competitive performance.
AI.conclusion: LoRAct provides a flexible, online, calibration-free low-rank activation compression approach that substantially reduces activation memory without sacrificing performance; source code is available.

title: Multi-modal Data Spectrum: Multi-modal Datasets are Multi-dimensional
summary:
Understanding the interplay between intra-modality dependencies (the
contribution of an individual modality to a target task) and inter-modality
dependencies (the relationships between modalities and the target task) is
fundamental to advancing multi-modal learning. However, the nature of and
interaction between these dependencies within current benchmark evaluations
remains poorly characterized. In this work, we present a large-scale empirical
study to quantify these dependencies across 23 visual question-answering
benchmarks using multi-modal large language models (MLLMs) covering domains
such as general and expert knowledge reasoning, optical character recognition,
and document understanding. Our findings show that the reliance on vision,
question (text), and their interaction varies significantly, both across and
within benchmarks. We discover that numerous benchmarks intended to mitigate
text-only biases have inadvertently amplified image-only dependencies. This
characterization persists across model sizes, as larger models often use these
intra-modality dependencies to achieve high performance that mask an underlying
lack of multi-modal reasoning. We provide a quantitative characterization of
multi-modal datasets, enabling a principled approach to multi-modal benchmark
design and evaluation.

AI.tldr: A large-scale empirical study quantifies intra- and inter-modality dependencies in 23 VQA benchmarks using multi-modal LLMs, revealing varying reliance on vision, text, and their interaction, with some benchmarks amplifying image-only biases; the work provides a quantitative framework to guide principled multi-modal benchmark design.
AI.motivation: To understand how intra-modality (within a modality) and inter-modality (between modalities and the task) dependencies shape multi-modal learning and benchmark evaluation, addressing gaps in characterizing these dependencies in current benchmarks.
AI.method: Performing a large-scale empirical study across 23 VQA benchmarks using multi-modal large language models to measure reliance on vision, question text, and their interaction; analyzing variation across benchmarks and model sizes.
AI.result: Dependencies vary across benchmarks and tasks; several benchmarks intended to mitigate text-only bias instead amplify image-only dependence; larger models tend to rely on intra-modal cues to achieve high performance, masking weaker multi-modal reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Offers a quantitative characterization of multi-modal datasets to enable principled benchmark design and evaluation, guiding future dataset construction to better assess true multi-modal reasoning.

title: Annotation-Free One-Shot Imitation Learning for Multi-Step Manipulation Tasks
summary:
Recent advances in one-shot imitation learning have enabled robots to acquire
new manipulation skills from a single human demonstration. While existing
methods achieve strong performance on single-step tasks, they remain limited in
their ability to handle long-horizon, multi-step tasks without additional model
training or manual annotation. We propose a method that can be applied to this
setting provided a single demonstration without additional model training or
manual annotation. We evaluated our method on multi-step and single-step
manipulation tasks where our method achieves an average success rate of 82.5%
and 90%, respectively. Our method matches and exceeds the performance of the
baselines in both these cases. We also compare the performance and
