computational efficiency of alternative pre-trained feature extractors within
our framework.

AI.tldr: A one-shot imitation learning framework that can learn long-horizon manipulation from a single demonstration without extra training or annotation, achieving 82.5% multi-step and 90% single-step success, outperforming baselines; also evaluates different pre-trained feature extractors.
AI.motivation: To enable robust long-horizon robotic manipulation from minimal data by removing the need for additional training or manual annotations, addressing limitations of existing one-shot methods in multi-step tasks.
AI.method: A one-shot imitation learning approach that uses only a single demonstration and requires no further model training or manual annotation. The framework also compares different pre-trained feature extractors within its pipeline to assess impact on performance and efficiency.
AI.result: On multi-step and single-step manipulation tasks, the method achieves average success rates of 82.5% and 90%, respectively, and matches or surpasses baselines. It also provides comparative analysis of pre-trained feature extractors with respect to performance and computational efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach effectively handles both multi-step and single-step tasks under a single demonstration with no extra training, yielding competitive accuracy and practicality; feature extractor choice influences performance and efficiency.

title: ContextPRM: Leveraging Contextual Coherence for multi-domain Test-Time Scaling
summary:
Process reward models (PRMs) have demonstrated significant efficacy in
enhancing the mathematical reasoning capabilities of large language models
(LLMs) by leveraging test-time scaling (TTS). However, while most PRMs exhibit
substantial gains in mathematical domains, the scarcity of domain-specific
training data and knowledge-based learning patterns limits their generalization
ability when faced with other domains. To address this limitation, we shift the
learning objective from verifying domain-specific knowledge to modeling
domain-agnostic logical flow. Centering on contextual coherence between
chain-of-thought (CoT) steps, our approach is realized through a novel data
annotation and training framework, which enhances the model's generalization
capabilities across diverse domains. For instance, our resulting model,
ContextPRM, achieves a notable 6.5% average accuracy improvement over the
majority voting baseline via weighted majority voting across nine
non-mathematical domains in MMLU-Pro, including law, history, and philosophy,
significantly surpassing the 2.2% improvement from VersaPRM and 0.5% gains from
other mathematics-focused PRMs, demonstrating consistent performance across
both mathematical and non-mathematical domains.

AI.tldr: ContextPRM improves cross-domain generalization of process reward models by emphasizing domain-agnostic logical flow, achieving 6.5% average accuracy gains over majority voting in MMLU-Pro across nine non-mathematical domains, and outperforming VersaPRM and other math-focused PRMs.
AI.motivation: PRMs currently excel in math but struggle to generalize to other domains due to domain-specific training data and knowledge-based learning patterns; there is a need to shift learning objectives toward domain-agnostic logical flow and contextual coherence in chain-of-thought (CoT).
AI.method: Introduce a novel data annotation and training framework that centers on contextual coherence between CoT steps; apply weighted majority voting across nine non-mathematical domains in MMLU-Pro; compare cross-domain performance with math-focused PRMs like VersaPRM.
AI.result: ContextPRM yields a 6.5% average accuracy improvement over the majority voting baseline in nine non-mathematical domains of MMLU-Pro; it significantly outperforms VersaPRM by 2.2% and other math-focused PRMs by 0.5%, indicating robust cross-domain performance.
AI.conclusion: Modeling domain-agnostic logical flow via CoT coherence can substantially improve cross-domain generalization of PRMs, enabling consistent performance across mathematical and non-mathematical domains.

title: Statistical Learning Guarantees for Group-Invariant Barron Functions
summary:
We investigate the generalization error of group-invariant neural networks
within the Barron framework. Our analysis shows that incorporating
group-invariant structures introduces a group-dependent factor
$\delta_{G,\Gamma,\sigma} \le 1$ into the approximation rate. When this factor
is small, group invariance yields substantial improvements in approximation
accuracy. On the estimation side, we establish that the Rademacher complexity
of the group-invariant class is no larger than that of the non-invariant
counterpart, implying that the estimation error remains unaffected by the
incorporation of symmetry. Consequently, the generalization error can improve
significantly when learning functions with inherent group symmetries. We
further provide illustrative examples demonstrating both favorable cases, where
$\delta_{G,\Gamma,\sigma}\approx |G|^{-1}$, and unfavorable ones, where
$\delta_{G,\Gamma,\sigma}\approx 1$. Overall, our results offer a rigorous
theoretical foundation showing that encoding group-invariant structures in
neural networks leads to clear statistical advantages for symmetric target
functions.

AI.tldr: Group invariance in neural networks can improve generalization in the Barron framework via a group-dependent factor delta <= 1 in the approximation rate; when delta is small (e.g., ~|G|^{-1}), invariance yields substantial gains, while estimation error remains unaffected by symmetry.
AI.motivation: To rigorously quantify how incorporating group symmetries into neural networks affects approximation and estimation errors within the Barron framework, and to identify regimes where symmetry yields statistical advantages.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis within the Barron framework deriving a group-dependent delta factor in the approximation rate; proving the Rademacher complexity of the invariant class is no larger than that of the non-invariant class; and presenting illustrative examples for delta ~ |G|^{-1} and delta ~ 1.
AI.result: Key results: (1) Approximation error scales with delta, so small delta yields substantial improvements; (2) Estimation error is unaffected by symmetry since Rademacher complexity does not increase; (3) Generalization can improve when target functions possess group symmetries; (4) Examples show both favorable and unfavorable regimes depending on delta.
AI.conclusion: Encoding group-invariant structures in neural networks provides a rigorous theoretical basis for statistical advantages in symmetric settings, with gains determined by the group-dependent delta; practical gains depend on the symmetry strength of the target function.

title: Enhancing Polyp Segmentation via Encoder Attention and Dynamic Kernel Update
summary:
Polyp segmentation is a critical step in colorectal cancer detection, yet it
remains challenging due to the diverse shapes, sizes, and low contrast
boundaries of polyps in medical imaging. In this work, we propose a novel
framework that improves segmentation accuracy and efficiency by integrating a
Dynamic Kernel (DK) mechanism with a global Encoder Attention module. The DK
mechanism, initialized by a global context vector from the EA module,
iteratively refines segmentation predictions across decoding stages, enabling
the model to focus on and accurately delineate complex polyp boundaries. The EA
module enhances the network's ability to capture critical lesion features by
aggregating multi scale information from all encoder layers. In addition, we
employ Unified Channel Adaptation (UCA) in the decoder to standardize feature
dimensions across stages, ensuring consistent and computationally efficient
information fusion. Our approach extends the lesion-aware kernel framework by
introducing a more flexible, attention driven kernel initialization and a
unified decoder design. Extensive experiments on the KvasirSEG and CVC ClinicDB
benchmark datasets demonstrate that our model outperforms several state of the
art segmentation methods, achieving superior Dice and Intersection over Union
scores. Moreover, UCA simplifies the decoder structure, reducing computational
cost without compromising accuracy. Overall, the proposed method provides a
robust and adaptable solution for polyp segmentation, with promising
applications in clinical and automated diagnostic systems.

AI.tldr: Dynamic Kernel with Encoder Attention and Unified Channel Adaptation improves polyp segmentation efficiency and accuracy, achieving state-of-the-art Dice/IoU on KvasirSEG and ClinicDB.
AI.motivation: Polyp segmentation is challenging due to diverse polyp shapes, sizes, and low-contrast boundaries; there is a need for architectures that integrate global context, flexible kernel refinement, and efficient decoding.
AI.method: Introduce a Dynamic Kernel (DK) mechanism initialized by a global context from an Encoder Attention (EA) module; the EA aggregates multi-scale features from all encoder layers; unify channel adaptation (UCA) in the decoder to standardize feature dimensions across stages; extend the lesion-aware kernel framework with flexible, attention-driven kernel initialization and a unified decoder design.
AI.result: The method outperforms several state-of-the-art segmentation methods on KvasirSEG and CVC ClinicDB, achieving superior Dice and IoU scores; UCA reduces computational cost while maintaining accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework offers a robust, adaptable solution for polyp segmentation with potential clinical and automated diagnostic applications.

title: Path Diffuser: Diffusion Model for Data-Driven Traffic Simulator
summary:
Simulating diverse and realistic traffic scenarios is critical for developing
and testing autonomous planning. Traditional rule-based planners lack diversity
and realism, while learning-based simulators often replay, forecast, or edit
scenarios using historical agent trajectories. However, they struggle to
generate new scenarios, limiting scalability and diversity due to their
reliance on fully annotated logs and historical data. Thus, a key challenge for
a learning-based simulator's performance is that it requires agents' past
trajectories and pose information in addition to map data, which might not be
available for all agents on the road.Without which, generated scenarios often
produce unrealistic trajectories that deviate from drivable areas, particularly
under out-of-distribution (OOD) map scenes (e.g., curved roads). To address
this, we propose Path Diffuser (PD): a two-stage, diffusion model for
generating agent pose initializations and their corresponding trajectories
conditioned on the map, free of any historical context of agents' trajectories.
Furthermore, PD incorporates a motion primitive-based prior, leveraging Frenet
frame candidate trajectories to enhance diversity while ensuring road-compliant
trajectory generation. We also explore various design choices for modeling
complex multi-agent interactions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our
method through extensive experiments on the Argoverse2 Dataset and additionally
evaluate the generalizability of the approach on OOD map variants. Notably,
Path Diffuser outperforms the baseline methods by 1.92x on distribution
metrics, 1.14x on common-sense metrics, and 1.62x on road compliance from
adversarial benchmarks.

AI.tldr: Path Diffuser (PD) is a two-stage diffusion model that generates agent poses and trajectories conditioned on a map without relying on historical trajectories, using a Frenet-frame motion-primitives prior to boost diversity and road compliance; validated on Argoverse2 and OOD maps, it outperforms baselines on distribution, common-sense, and road-compliance metrics.
AI.motivation: Learning-based traffic simulators struggle to generate novel, diverse scenarios because they rely on fully annotated logs, historical agent trajectories, and pose information. This limits scalability, realism, and generalization, especially for out-of-distribution (OOD) map scenes. A method that can generate plausible agent trajectories from maps alone would enable scalable, diverse scenario generation for autonomous planning.
AI.method: A two-stage diffusion framework (Path Diffuser): first, generate agent pose initializations, then their trajectories, conditioned only on map data and without historical agent context. It incorporates a motion-primitives prior based on Frenet-frame candidate trajectories to enhance diversity while ensuring road-compatibility. The approach also explores design choices for modeling multi-agent interactions and is evaluated on the Argoverse2 dataset, with additional tests on OOD map variants.
AI.result: PD outperforms baselines by 1.92x on distribution metrics, 1.14x on common-sense metrics, and 1.62x on road-compliance metrics from adversarial benchmarks. It demonstrates strong effectiveness on Argoverse2 and generalizes to OOD map variants, indicating improved diversity, realism, and safety of generated scenarios without historical trajectory data.
AI.conclusion: Path Diffuser provides a scalable, data-efficient, and realistic simulator for autonomous planning by generating diverse, road-compliant agent trajectories from maps alone. Its diffusion-based two-stage design, aided by a Frenet-based motion-primitives prior, improves diversity and generalization to unseen maps, addressing a key limitation of prior learning-based simulators.

title: Overcoming Over-Fitting in Constraint Acquisition via Query-Driven Interactive Refinement
comment:
Preprint. Uses the International Journal on Artificial Intelligence
  Tools (World Scientific) template. Includes figures, tables, and algorithms.
  Submitted to IJAIT
summary:
Manual modeling in Constraint Programming is a substantial bottleneck, which
Constraint Acquisition (CA) aims to automate. However, passive CA methods are
prone to over-fitting, often learning models that include spurious global
constraints when trained on limited data, while purely active methods can be
query-intensive. We introduce a hybrid CA framework specifically designed to
address the challenge of over-fitting in CA. Our approach integrates passive
learning for initial candidate generation, a query-driven interactive
refinement phase that utilizes probabilistic confidence scores (initialized by
machine learning priors) to systematically identify over-fitted constraints,
and a specialized subset exploration mechanism to recover valid substructures
from rejected candidates. A final active learning phase ensures model
completeness. Extensive experiments on diverse benchmarks demonstrate that our
interactive refinement phase is crucial for achieving high target model
coverage and overall model accuracy from limited examples, doing so with
manageable query complexity. This framework represents a substantial
advancement towards robust and practical constraint acquisition in data-limited
scenarios.

AI.tldr: A hybrid Constraint Acquisition framework that combines passive learning, interactive refinement with probabilistic confidence scores (seeded by ML priors), subset exploration to recover valid substructures, and final active learning to combat over-fitting and reduce query load, achieving high model coverage under data-limited conditions.
AI.motivation: Manual modeling in Constraint Programming is labor-intensive, and existing CA approaches struggle: passive methods over-fit with scarce data, while pure active methods are query-heavy. A robust, data-efficient CA framework is needed to produce accurate models without excessive querying.
AI.method: 1) Passive learning to generate initial candidate constraints. 2) Query-driven interactive refinement using probabilistic confidence scores (from ML priors) to identify over-fitted constraints. 3) Specialized subset exploration to recover valid substructures from rejected candidates. 4) Final active learning phase to ensure model completeness.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on diverse benchmarks show the interactive refinement phase is crucial for achieving high target model coverage and accuracy with limited examples, while keeping query complexity manageable.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hybrid CA framework advances robust, practical constraint acquisition for data-limited scenarios by effectively mitigating over-fitting and balancing learning efficiency with query cost.

title: Temporal Generalization: A Reality Check
summary:
Machine learning (ML) models often struggle to maintain performance under
distribution shifts, leading to inaccurate predictions on unseen future data.
In this work, we investigate whether and under what conditions models can
achieve such a generalization when relying solely on past data. We explore two
primary approaches: convex combinations of past model parameters
(\emph{parameter interpolation}) and explicit extrapolation beyond the convex
hull of past parameters (\emph{parameter extrapolation}). We benchmark several
methods within these categories on a diverse set of temporal tasks, including
language modeling, news summarization, news tag prediction, academic paper
categorization, satellite image-based land use classification over time, and
historical yearbook photo gender prediction. Our empirical findings show that
none of the evaluated methods consistently outperforms the simple baseline of
using the latest available model parameters in all scenarios. In the absence of
access to future data or robust assumptions about the underlying
data-generating process, these results underscore the inherent difficulties of
generalizing and extrapolating to future data and warrant caution when
evaluating claims of such generalization.

AI.tldr: Investigates interpolation and extrapolation in parameter space for generalization under distribution shifts; finds no method consistently beating using the latest parameters; emphasizes limitations and need for future data or assumptions.
AI.motivation: To determine whether models can generalize to future data using only past observations when distributions shift, and under what conditions extrapolation in parameter space might help.
AI.method: Benchmarks of parameter interpolation (convex combinations of past model parameters) and parameter extrapolation (extrapolating beyond the convex hull of past parameters) across diverse temporal tasks: language modeling, news summarization, news tag prediction, academic paper categorization, satellite land-use classification over time, and historical yearbook photo gender prediction.
AI.result: Across tasks, none of the methods consistently outperformed the simple baseline of using the most recent model parameters.
AI.conclusion: Without access to future data or robust assumptions about the data-generating process, generalization and extrapolation to future data are inherently challenging; findings urge caution in claiming generalization under distribution shifts.

title: Evaluating point-light biological motion in multimodal large language models
summary:
Humans can extract rich semantic information from minimal visual cues, as
demonstrated by point-light displays (PLDs), which consist of sparse sets of
dots localized to key joints of the human body. This ability emerges early in
development and is largely attributed to human embodied experience. Since PLDs
isolate body motion as the sole source of meaning, they represent key stimuli
for testing the constraints of action understanding in these systems. Here we
introduce ActPLD, the first benchmark to evaluate action processing in MLLMs
from human PLDs. Tested models include state-of-the-art proprietary and
open-source systems on single-actor and socially interacting PLDs. Our results
reveal consistently low performance across models, introducing fundamental gaps
in action and spatiotemporal understanding.

AI.tldr: ActPLD introduces a benchmark to test action understanding in multimodal large language models using human point-light displays; current models show low performance, revealing gaps in action and spatiotemporal reasoning.
AI.motivation: Point-light displays reveal minimal visual cues necessary for action understanding; evaluating ML models on such cues probes embodied and temporal reasoning abilities; existing models underperform, highlighting fundamental limitations.
AI.method: Create ActPLD benchmark with single-actor and social interaction PLDs; evaluate state-of-the-art proprietary and open-source MLLMs on these tasks.
AI.result: Models exhibit consistently low performance across tasks; significant gaps in action recognition and spatiotemporal understanding.
AI.conclusion: Need to improve how models represent and reason about sparse motion cues; this benchmark exposes key deficiencies and guides future work in embodied, temporal action understanding.

title: AIRoA MoMa Dataset: A Large-Scale Hierarchical Dataset for Mobile Manipulation
summary:
As robots transition from controlled settings to unstructured human
environments, building generalist agents that can reliably follow natural
language instructions remains a central challenge. Progress in robust mobile
manipulation requires large-scale multimodal datasets that capture contact-rich
and long-horizon tasks, yet existing resources lack synchronized force-torque
sensing, hierarchical annotations, and explicit failure cases. We address this
gap with the AIRoA MoMa Dataset, a large-scale real-world multimodal dataset
for mobile manipulation. It includes synchronized RGB images, joint states,
six-axis wrist force-torque signals, and internal robot states, together with a
novel two-layer annotation schema of sub-goals and primitive actions for
hierarchical learning and error analysis. The initial dataset comprises 25,469
episodes (approx. 94 hours) collected with the Human Support Robot (HSR) and is
fully standardized in the LeRobot v2.1 format. By uniquely integrating mobile
manipulation, contact-rich interaction, and long-horizon structure, AIRoA MoMa
provides a critical benchmark for advancing the next generation of
Vision-Language-Action models. The first version of our dataset is now
available at https://huggingface.co/datasets/airoa-org/airoa-moma .

AI.tldr: AIRoA MoMa is a large-scale real-world multimodal dataset for mobile manipulation that combines synchronized RGB images, joint states, six-axis wrist force-torque signals, and internal robot states with a two-layer annotation schema (sub-goals and primitive actions) for hierarchical learning and error analysis. The initial release comprises 25,469 episodes (~94 hours) collected with the Human Support Robot, standardized in LeRobot v2.1, and publicly available on HuggingFace. It aims to benchmark Vision-Language-Action models in contact-rich, long-horizon manipulation tasks in unstructured environments.
AI.motivation: Robust mobile manipulation in unstructured human environments is limited by the lack of large-scale multimodal datasets that capture contact-rich, long-horizon tasks, synchronized sensing (including force-torque), hierarchical annotations, and explicit failure cases, hindering progress toward generalist language-grounded agents.
AI.method: Data collection of real-world mobile manipulation using HSR, capturing synchronized modalities (RGB, joint states, six-axis wrist wrench, internal robot states) and providing a two-layer annotation schema: sub-goals (high-level task segments) and primitive actions (low-level movements) to enable hierarchical learning and error analysis; standardization of data format (LeRobot v2.1).
AI.result: A first version with 25,469 episodes (~94 hours), real-world multimodal data, and hierarchical annotations is released; dataset is standardized and publicly accessible, offering a benchmark for vision-language-action research in long-horizon, contact-rich manipulation.
AI.conclusion: The AIRoA MoMa dataset fills a critical gap by enabling robust evaluation and training of language-guided mobile manipulation systems in realistic settings, supporting long-horizon planning, error analysis, and hierarchical learning for next-generation vision-language-action models.

title: Neuroplasticity-inspired dynamic ANNs for multi-task demand forecasting
summary:
This paper introduces a novel approach to Dynamic Artificial Neural Networks
(D-ANNs) for multi-task demand forecasting called Neuroplastic Multi-Task
Network (NMT-Net). Unlike conventional methods focusing on inference-time
dynamics or computational efficiency, our proposed method enables structural
adaptability of the computational graph during training, inspired by
neuroplasticity as seen in biological systems. Each new task triggers a dynamic
network adaptation, including similarity-based task identification and
selective training of candidate ANN heads, which are then assessed and
integrated into the model based on their performance. We evaluated our
framework using three real-world multi-task demand forecasting datasets from
Kaggle. We demonstrated its superior performance and consistency, achieving
lower RMSE and standard deviation compared to traditional baselines and
state-of-the-art multi-task learning methods. NMT-Net offers a scalable,
adaptable solution for multi-task and continual learning in time series
prediction. The complete code for NMT-Net is available from our GitHub
repository.

AI.tldr: A neuroplastic-inspired dynamic multi-task network (NMT-Net) that grows/adapts its architecture during training for multi-task demand forecasting, achieving superior RMSE and consistency on Kaggle datasets, with code released on GitHub.
AI.motivation: Conventional multi-task learning and inference-time dynamic models fix architecture during training, limiting adaptability for new tasks. The paper aims to enable structural plasticity to improve performance and continual learning in time-series forecasting.
AI.method: Introduce NMT-Net that triggers network adaptation when a new task arrives, uses similarity-based task identification, trains selective candidate ANN heads, evaluates them, and integrates the best-performing components into the main model.
AI.result: On three real-world Kaggle demand forecasting datasets, NMT-Net achieves lower RMSE and lower standard deviation than baselines and state-of-the-art MTL methods, showing superior performance and consistency.
AI.conclusion: NMT-Net offers a scalable, adaptable solution for multi-task and continual learning in time-series prediction; provides code on GitHub; implies potential for broader adoption in time-series forecasting and dynamic networks.

title: Revisiting Multivariate Time Series Forecasting with Missing Values
summary:
Missing values are common in real-world time series, and multivariate time
series forecasting with missing values (MTSF-M) has become a crucial area of
research for ensuring reliable predictions. To address the challenge of missing
data, current approaches have developed an imputation-then-prediction framework
that uses imputation modules to fill in missing values, followed by forecasting
on the imputed data. However, this framework overlooks a critical issue: there
is no ground truth for the missing values, making the imputation process
susceptible to errors that can degrade prediction accuracy. In this paper, we
conduct a systematic empirical study and reveal that imputation without direct
supervision can corrupt the underlying data distribution and actively degrade
prediction accuracy. To address this, we propose a paradigm shift that moves
away from imputation and directly predicts from the partially observed time
series. We introduce Consistency-Regularized Information Bottleneck (CRIB), a
novel framework built on the Information Bottleneck principle. CRIB combines a
unified-variate attention mechanism with a consistency regularization scheme to
learn robust representations that filter out noise introduced by missing values
while preserving essential predictive signals. Comprehensive experiments on
four real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of CRIB, which predicts
accurately even under high missing rates. Our code is available in
https://github.com/Muyiiiii/CRIB.

AI.tldr: Proposes CRIB to forecast directly from incomplete multivariate time series, avoiding imputation, with strong performance under high missingness.
AI.motivation: Imputation-based forecasting assumes missing values can be accurately filled, but there is no ground-truth for missing data; imputation can distort data distributions and degrade predictive accuracy, necessitating methods that operate on partially observed data.
AI.method: Introduce Consistency-Regularized Information Bottleneck (CRIB) built on the Information Bottleneck principle. It uses a unified-variate attention mechanism and a consistency regularization scheme to learn robust representations from partially observed sequences that suppress noise from missing values while preserving predictive signals.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on four real-world datasets demonstrate CRIB’s effectiveness, achieving accurate predictions even with high missing rates; the authors release their code on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: Shifts the paradigm from imputation-then-prediction to direct prediction on partial data; CRIB provides a robust mechanism for MTSF-M and illustrates the viability of information-bottleneck-based approaches for handling missing data.

title: Imaging-Based Mortality Prediction in Patients with Systemic Sclerosis
comment: 11 pages, 4 figures, 1 table, accepted in MICCAI PRIME 2025
summary:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality
in systemic sclerosis (SSc). Chest computed tomography (CT) is the primary
imaging modality for diagnosing and monitoring lung complications in SSc
patients. However, its role in disease progression and mortality prediction has
not yet been fully clarified. This study introduces a novel, large-scale
longitudinal chest CT analysis framework that utilizes radiomics and deep
learning to predict mortality associated with lung complications of SSc. We
collected and analyzed 2,125 CT scans from SSc patients enrolled in the
Northwestern Scleroderma Registry, conducting mortality analyses at one, three,
and five years using advanced imaging analysis techniques. Death labels were
assigned based on recorded deaths over the one-, three-, and five-year
intervals, confirmed by expert physicians. In our dataset, 181, 326, and 428 of
the 2,125 CT scans were from patients who died within one, three, and five
years, respectively. Using ResNet-18, DenseNet-121, and Swin Transformer we use
pre-trained models, and fine-tuned on 2,125 images of SSc patients. Models
achieved an AUC of 0.769, 0.801, 0.709 for predicting mortality within one-,
three-, and five-years, respectively. Our findings highlight the potential of
both radiomics and deep learning computational methods to improve early
detection and risk assessment of SSc-related interstitial lung disease, marking
a significant advancement in the literature.

AI.tldr: Large-scale longitudinal study using radiomics and deep learning on 2,125 chest CTs from systemic sclerosis patients to predict mortality related to lung complications at 1, 3, and 5 years, achieving AUCs up to ~0.80.
AI.motivation: Systemic sclerosis-associated ILD carries high mortality; accurate early risk stratification via CT-based imaging biomarkers could guide surveillance and treatment decisions.
AI.method: Retrospective analysis of 2,125 CT scans from the Northwestern Scleroderma Registry. Mortality labels defined for 1-, 3-, and 5-year intervals. Applied radiomics features and deep learning models (ResNet-18, DenseNet-121, Swin Transformer), pretrained and fine-tuned on the dataset; evaluated performance with AUC.
AI.result: AUCs reported as 0.769 (1-year), 0.801 (3-year), 0.709 (5-year) for mortality prediction. Three architectures were evaluated on the same dataset.
AI.conclusion: Radiomics and DL on chest CT show promise for early mortality risk stratification in SSc-ILD; supports imaging-based prognostication and warrants further validation and external testing to enable clinical adoption.

title: AgriCruiser: An Open Source Agriculture Robot for Over-the-row Navigation
summary:
We present the AgriCruiser, an open-source over-the-row agricultural robot
developed for low-cost deployment and rapid adaptation across diverse crops and
row layouts. The chassis provides an adjustable track width of 1.42 m to 1.57
m, along with a ground clearance of 0.94 m. The AgriCruiser achieves compact
pivot turns with radii of 0.71 m to 0.79 m, enabling efficient headland
maneuvers. The platform is designed for the integration of the other
subsystems, and in this study, a precision spraying system was implemented to
assess its effectiveness in weed management. In twelve flax plots, a single
robotic spray pass reduced total weed populations (pigweed and Venice mallow)
by 24- to 42-fold compared to manual weeding in four flax plots, while also
causing less crop damage. Mobility experiments conducted on concrete, asphalt,
gravel, grass, and both wet and dry soil confirmed reliable traversal
consistent with torque sizing. The complete chassis can be constructed from
commodity T-slot extrusion with minimal machining, resulting in a bill of
materials costing approximately $5,000 - $6,000, which enables replication and
customization. The mentioned results demonstrate that low-cost, reconfigurable
over-the-row robots can achieve effective weed management with reduced crop
damage and labor requirements, while providing a versatile foundation for
phenotyping, sensing, and other agriculture applications. Design files and
implementation details are released to accelerate research and adoption of
modular agricultural robotics.

AI.tldr: A low-cost, open-source over-the-row robot (AgriCruiser) with adjustable track width, compact turning, and a precision sprayer. Demonstrated strong weed suppression in flax plots with minimal crop damage; buildable from commodity parts for ~$5–6k; design files released to enable replication.
AI.motivation: Address high labor costs and crop damage in row-crop weed management by providing a low-cost, modular, and adaptable robotic platform suitable for rapid deployment across diverse crops and layouts.
AI.method: A reconfigurable chassis with adjustable track width (1.42–1.57 m) and ground clearance (0.94 m) enabling compact pivot turns (0.71–0.79 m). Implemented a precision spraying system and evaluated weed control in twelve flax plots against manual weeding. Mobility tested on concrete, asphalt, gravel, grass, and wet/dry soils. BOM cost ~ $5–6k from commodity parts. Open-source design files released for replication and customization.
AI.result: In twelve flax plots, a single robotic spray pass reduced total weed populations (pigweed and Venice mallow) by 24– to 42-fold compared with manual weeding and caused less crop damage. Traversal was reliable across multiple surfaces, and the chassis supports easy integration of subsystems, phenotyping, sensing, etc., enabling replication at low cost.
AI.conclusion: Low-cost, reconfigurable over-the-row robots can achieve effective weed management with reduced crop damage and labor, while serving as a versatile platform for broader agricultural sensing and phenotyping tasks. Release of design files facilitates research adoption and customization.

title: Experience-guided reflective co-evolution of prompts and heuristics for automatic algorithm design
summary:
Combinatorial optimization problems are traditionally tackled with
handcrafted heuristic algorithms, which demand extensive domain expertise and
significant implementation effort. Recent progress has highlighted the
potential of automatic heuristics design powered by large language models
(LLMs), enabling the automatic generation and refinement of heuristics. These
approaches typically maintain a population of heuristics and employ LLMs as
mutation operators to evolve them across generations. While effective, such
methods often risk stagnating in local optima. To address this issue, we
propose the Experience-Guided Reflective Co-Evolution of Prompt and Heuristics
(EvoPH) for automatic algorithm design, a novel framework that integrates the
island migration model with the elites selection algorithm to simulate diverse
heuristics populations. In EvoPH, prompts are co-evolved with heuristic
algorithms, guided by performance feedback. We evaluate our framework on two
problems, i.e., Traveling Salesman Problem and Bin Packing Problem.
Experimental results demonstrate that EvoPH achieves the lowest relative error
against optimal solutions across both datasets, advancing the field of
automatic algorithm design with LLMs.

AI.tldr: EvoPH co-evolves prompts and heuristics with an island-migration, elitist-selection framework to diversify automatic heuristic design via LLMs, achieving lowest relative error on TSP and Bin Packing compared to optimal solutions.
AI.motivation: Automatic design of heuristics with LLMs can reduce manual engineering, but current methods risk stagnation in local optima. A mechanism to maintain diversity and leverage feedback is needed.
AI.method: Introduce EvoPH: Experience-Guided Reflective Co-Evolution of Prompt and Heuristics. It uses an island migration model with elites selection to maintain multiple diverse heuristic populations. Prompts are co-evolved with heuristics and guided by performance feedback (reflective loop). Applied to Traveling Salesman Problem and Bin Packing Problem, using LLMs as mutation operators and prompt design adjustments.
AI.result: EvoPH achieves the lowest relative error against optimal solutions on both TSP and Bin Packing datasets, outperforming baselines and demonstrating effectiveness of co-evolving prompts with heuristics for automatic algorithm design.
AI.conclusion: Co-evolution of prompts and heuristics via an island-migration, elite-selection framework effectively mitigates stagnation and improves automatic algorithm design with LLMs for combinatorial optimization.

title: Beyond Outliers: A Study of Optimizers Under Quantization
summary:
As new optimizers gain traction and model quantization becomes standard for
efficient deployment, a key question arises: how does the choice of optimizer
affect model performance in the presence of quantization? Despite progress in
both areas, systematic evidence on optimizer-quantization interactions remains
limited. To fill this gap, we study the impact of optimizer choice on model
robustness under quantization, considering both post-training quantization
(PTQ), and quantization-aware training (QAT). We first train full-precision
models, ranging from 50M to 1.5B parameters, with six optimizers, to explore
the hyperparameter landscape, and establish well-tuned baselines. We then apply
PTQ to evaluate how model performance degrades when trained with different
optimizers. We find that outlier-related metrics, such as the max-to-mean ratio
(MMR) and Kurtosis, fail to predict the PTQ performance across different
optimizers. We show analytically that this is due to the MMR capturing only
isolated layer errors, while ignoring how quantization errors accumulate and
propagate through the network. To study the QAT degradation, we train quantized
models from scratch and compare them to our original-precision baselines. We
find that optimizers performing well in the original pretraining setup may not
remain optimal under QAT, and that models trained with Shampoo show the lowest
accuracy degradation. Finally, we derive scaling laws for quantization-aware
training under different optimizers, showing that Shampoo achieves the highest
parameter efficiency of all tested optimizers.

AI.tldr: Systematic study of how optimizer choice affects model robustness under post-training quantization (PTQ) and quantization-aware training (QAT) across large models; standard outlier metrics (MMR, Kurtosis) fail to predict PTQ degradation; Shampoo offers the best robustness under QAT and highest parameter efficiency; optimizer choice matters for quantization outcomes.
AI.motivation: As optimizers update and quantization becomes standard for efficient deployment, there is a need for systematic evidence on optimizer–quantization interactions to guide training and deployment strategies.
AI.method: Train FP models (50M–1.5B params) using six optimizers to map hyperparameter landscapes; apply PTQ to assess degradation across optimizers; analytically explain why MMR fails; train quantized models from scratch (QAT) and compare to FP baselines; derive scaling laws for QAT under different optimizers; identify Shampoo as least degraded and most parameter-efficient.
AI.result: MMR and Kurtosis do not reliably predict PTQ performance across optimizers due to ignoring error propagation through the network; QAT degradation depends on optimizer, with some optimizers (Shampoo) showing the least accuracy loss and best scaling/parameter efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Optimizer choice materially affects quantization robustness; PTQ and QAT evaluations should consider optimizer selection; Shampoo is particularly favorable for QAT in terms of degradation and efficiency; standard outlier metrics are insufficient predictors of PTQ outcomes.

title: Calibrated and Resource-Aware Super-Resolution for Reliable Driver Behavior Analysis
summary:
Driver monitoring systems require not just high accuracy but reliable,
well-calibrated confidence scores for safety-critical deployment. While direct
low-resolution training yields high overall accuracy, it produces poorly
calibrated predictions that can be dangerous in safety-critical scenarios. We
propose a resource-aware adaptive super-resolution framework that optimizes for
model calibration and high precision-recall on critical events. Our approach
achieves state-of-the-art performance on safety-centric metrics: best
calibration (ECE of 5.8\% vs 6.2\% for LR-trained baselines), highest AUPR for
drowsiness detection (0.78 vs 0.74), and superior precision-recall for phone
use detection (0.74 vs 0.71). A lightweight artifact detector (0.3M parameters,
5.2ms overhead) provides additional safety by filtering SR-induced
hallucinations. While LR-trained video models serve as strong general-purpose
baselines, our adaptive framework represents the state-of-the-art solution for
safety-critical applications where reliability is paramount.

AI.tldr: A resource-aware adaptive super-resolution framework improves confidence calibration and safety-critical detection in driver monitoring, outperforming low-resolution baselines on calibration and critical-event metrics, with a lightweight artifact detector to curb hallucinations.
AI.motivation: Safety-critical driver monitoring demands reliable, well-calibrated confidence estimates; direct low-resolution training yields high accuracy but poor calibration, risking unsafe decisions.
AI.method: Develop a resource-aware adaptive super-resolution framework that enhances calibration and critical-event precision-recall, plus a lightweight artifact detector (0.3M params, ~5.2 ms) to filter SR-induced hallucinations.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art safety-centric metrics: ECE 5.8% (vs 6.2% LR baseline), AUPR for drowsiness 0.78 (vs 0.74), and precision-recall for phone use 0.74 (vs 0.71), with a fast, compact artifact detector.
AI.conclusion: LR-trained video models remain strong baselines, but the proposed adaptive SR framework advances reliability for safety-critical applications where calibrated confidence is essential.

title: Crop Spirals: Re-thinking the field layout for future robotic agriculture
comment: Submitted to Computers and Electronics in Agriculture
summary:
Conventional linear crop layouts, optimised for tractors, hinder robotic
navigation with tight turns, long travel distances, and perceptual aliasing. We
propose a robot-centric square spiral layout with a central tramline, enabling
simpler motion and more efficient coverage. To exploit this geometry, we
develop a navigation stack combining DH-ResNet18 waypoint regression,
pixel-to-odometry mapping, A* planning, and model predictive control (MPC). In
simulations, the spiral layout yields up to 28% shorter paths and about 25%
faster execution for waypoint-based tasks across 500 waypoints than linear
layouts, while full-field coverage performance is comparable to an optimised
linear U-turn strategy. Multi-robot studies demonstrate efficient coordination
on the spirals rule-constrained graph, with a greedy allocator achieving 33-37%
lower batch completion times than a Hungarian assignment under our setup. These
results highlight the potential of redesigning field geometry to better suit
autonomous agriculture.

AI.tldr: Robot-centric square spiral field layout improves autonomous farming navigation and coordination, outperforming linear layouts in key metrics.
AI.motivation: Tractor-optimized, conventional linear layouts hinder robotic navigation due to tight turns, long travel distances, and perceptual aliasing.
AI.method: Introduce a robot-centric square spiral layout with a central tramline. Develop a navigation stack: DH-ResNet18 waypoint regression, pixel-to-odometry mapping, A* planning, and model predictive control (MPC). Evaluate in simulation across 500 waypoints; extend to multi-robot coordination on the spirals rule-constrained graph with a greedy allocator.
AI.result: Spiral layout yields up to 28% shorter paths and ~25% faster execution for waypoint-based tasks, across 500 waypoints; full-field coverage comparable to optimized linear U-turn strategy. In multi-robot tests, greedy allocation achieves 33-37% lower batch completion times than Hungarian assignment.
AI.conclusion: Redesigning field geometry to suit autonomous agriculture can substantially improve navigation efficiency, motion simplicity, and coordination among multiple robots.

title: Training Agents Inside of Scalable World Models
summary:
World models learn general knowledge from videos and simulate experience for
training behaviors in imagination, offering a path towards intelligent agents.
However, previous world models have been unable to accurately predict object
interactions in complex environments. We introduce Dreamer 4, a scalable agent
that learns to solve control tasks by reinforcement learning inside of a fast
and accurate world model. In the complex video game Minecraft, the world model
accurately predicts object interactions and game mechanics, outperforming
previous world models by a large margin. The world model achieves real-time
interactive inference on a single GPU through a shortcut forcing objective and
an efficient transformer architecture. Moreover, the world model learns general
action conditioning from only a small amount of data, allowing it to extract
the majority of its knowledge from diverse unlabeled videos. We propose the
challenge of obtaining diamonds in Minecraft from only offline data, aligning
with practical applications such as robotics where learning from environment
interaction can be unsafe and slow. This task requires choosing sequences of
over 20,000 mouse and keyboard actions from raw pixels. By learning behaviors
in imagination, Dreamer 4 is the first agent to obtain diamonds in Minecraft
purely from offline data, without environment interaction. Our work provides a
scalable recipe for imagination training, marking a step towards intelligent
agents.

AI.tldr: Dreamer 4 trains a fast, scalable world model to perform offline-imagination reinforcement learning in Minecraft, achieving real-time inference on a single GPU and obtaining diamonds purely from offline data.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of prior world models in predicting complex object interactions, enable data-efficient learning from unlabeled videos, and pursue safe, rapid learning for robotics and intelligent agents.
AI.method: Develop a scalable, transformer-based world model with a shortcut forcing objective that enables real-time interactive inference; train to predict object interactions and game mechanics; learn general action conditioning from limited data; perform reinforcement learning inside imagination and evaluate on Minecraft, including an offline-data challenge.
AI.result: The world model accurately predicts object interactions and game mechanics, outperforming previous models by a large margin; real-time inference on a single GPU; learns general action conditioning from small data; Dreamer 4 is the first agent to obtain diamonds in Minecraft purely from offline data without environment interaction.
AI.conclusion: This work provides a scalable recipe for imagination training, advancing world-model-based reinforcement learning and moving toward intelligent agents capable of learning from offline data and safe exploration, with potential impact on robotics and other data-scarce domains.

title: Disentanglement of Variations with Multimodal Generative Modeling
summary:
Multimodal data are prevalent across various domains, and learning robust
representations of such data is paramount to enhancing generation quality and
downstream task performance. To handle heterogeneity and interconnections among
different modalities, recent multimodal generative models extract shared and
private (modality-specific) information with two separate variables. Despite
attempts to enforce disentanglement between these two variables, these methods
struggle with challenging datasets where the likelihood model is insufficient.
In this paper, we propose Information-disentangled Multimodal VAE (IDMVAE) to
explicitly address this issue, with rigorous mutual information-based
regularizations, including cross-view mutual information maximization for
extracting shared variables, and a cycle-consistency style loss for redundancy
removal using generative augmentations. We further introduce diffusion models
to improve the capacity of latent priors. These newly proposed components are
complementary to each other. Compared to existing approaches, IDMVAE shows a
clean separation between shared and private information, demonstrating superior
generation quality and semantic coherence on challenging datasets.

AI.tldr: IDMVAE introduces an information-disentangled multimodal VAE that uses cross-view mutual information to extract shared factors, a cycle-consistency style loss with generative augmentations to remove redundancy, and diffusion priors to strengthen latent modeling, yielding clearer shared/private separation and improved generation and semantic coherence on hard datasets.
AI.motivation: Multimodal data are heterogeneous and highly interconnected; disentangling shared (cross-modal) information from private (modality-specific) information is challenging, especially when the likelihood model is insufficient for robust disentanglement.
AI.method: Propose IDMVAE with explicit shared and private latent spaces. Apply cross-view mutual information maximization to capture shared variables. Use a cycle-consistency style loss with generative augmentations to reduce redundancy in private factors. Incorporate diffusion models to enhance the capacity of latent priors. The components are complementary.
AI.result: Experiments show a clean separation between shared and private information, with superior generation quality and semantic coherence on challenging datasets compared to existing methods.
AI.conclusion: IDMVAE provides a robust framework for information-disentangled multimodal modeling. The combination of MI-based regularizations and diffusion priors improves disentanglement and downstream performance, with broad applicability to multimodal generation tasks.

title: OVSeg3R: Learn Open-vocabulary Instance Segmentation from 2D via 3D Reconstruction
summary:
In this paper, we propose a training scheme called OVSeg3R to learn
open-vocabulary 3D instance segmentation from well-studied 2D perception models
with the aid of 3D reconstruction. OVSeg3R directly adopts reconstructed scenes
from 2D videos as input, avoiding costly manual adjustment while aligning input
with real-world applications. By exploiting the 2D to 3D correspondences
provided by 3D reconstruction models, OVSeg3R projects each view's 2D instance
mask predictions, obtained from an open-vocabulary 2D model, onto 3D to
generate annotations for the view's corresponding sub-scene. To avoid
incorrectly introduced false positives as supervision due to partial
annotations from 2D to 3D, we propose a View-wise Instance Partition algorithm,
which partitions predictions to their respective views for supervision,
stabilizing the training process. Furthermore, since 3D reconstruction models
tend to over-smooth geometric details, clustering reconstructed points into
representative super-points based solely on geometry, as commonly done in
mainstream 3D segmentation methods, may overlook geometrically non-salient
objects. We therefore introduce 2D Instance Boundary-aware Superpoint, which
leverages 2D masks to constrain the superpoint clustering, preventing
superpoints from violating instance boundaries. With these designs, OVSeg3R not
only extends a state-of-the-art closed-vocabulary 3D instance segmentation
model to open-vocabulary, but also substantially narrows the performance gap
between tail and head classes, ultimately leading to an overall improvement of
+2.3 mAP on the ScanNet200 benchmark. Furthermore, under the standard
open-vocabulary setting, OVSeg3R surpasses previous methods by about +7.1 mAP
on the novel classes, further validating its effectiveness.

AI.tldr: OVSeg3R enables open-vocabulary 3D instance segmentation by leveraging 2D open-vocabulary models and 3D reconstructions, introducing View-wise Instance Partition and 2D Boundary-aware Superpoints to generate supervision and preserve instance boundaries, achieving notable gains on ScanNet200 and novel classes.
AI.motivation: To extend 3D instance segmentation to open vocabulary while reducing annotation costs and handling partial supervision and geometric smoothing, leveraging cross-modal 2D-3D information.
AI.method: Utilizes reconstructed scenes from 2D videos; projects 2D instance masks into 3D via reconstruction correspondences to create per-view supervision; introduces View-wise Instance Partition to align predictions to views; creates 2D Instance Boundary-aware Superpoints by constraining geometry-based clustering with 2D masks.
AI.result: Outperforms previous methods by ~+7.1 mAP on novel classes and +2.3 mAP overall on ScanNet200; extends state-of-the-art closed-vocabulary 3D model to open-vocabulary.
AI.conclusion: OVSeg3R effectively bridges 2D open-vocabulary perception and 3D segmentation, narrowing tail-head gap and enabling robust open-vocabulary 3D instance segmentation with reduced annotation effort.

title: Curriculum Imitation Learning of Distributed Multi-Robot Policies
comment: Accepted and presented at the Eight Iberian Robotics Conference, 2025
summary:
Learning control policies for multi-robot systems (MRS) remains a major
challenge due to long-term coordination and the difficulty of obtaining
realistic training data. In this work, we address both limitations within an
imitation learning framework. First, we shift the typical role of Curriculum
Learning in MRS, from scalability with the number of robots, to focus on
improving long-term coordination. We propose a curriculum strategy that
gradually increases the length of expert trajectories during training,
stabilizing learning and enhancing the accuracy of long-term behaviors. Second,
we introduce a method to approximate the egocentric perception of each robot
using only third-person global state demonstrations. Our approach transforms
idealized trajectories into locally available observations by filtering
neighbors, converting reference frames, and simulating onboard sensor
variability. Both contributions are integrated into a physics-informed
technique to produce scalable, distributed policies from observations. We
conduct experiments across two tasks with varying team sizes and noise levels.
Results show that our curriculum improves long-term accuracy, while our
perceptual estimation method yields policies that are robust to realistic
uncertainty. Together, these strategies enable the learning of robust,
distributed controllers from global demonstrations, even in the absence of
expert actions or onboard measurements.

AI.tldr: Imitation learning for multi-robot control uses a curriculum that lengthens expert trajectories to improve long-term coordination and a perceptual proxy that converts global demonstrations into local observations, enabling scalable, robust distributed policies without onboard measurements.
AI.motivation: Long-term coordination in multi-robot systems (MRS) is hard to learn and realistic training data are scarce. The work aims to improve long-horizon behavior and perception so policies can be learned from global demonstrations without expert actions or onboard sensors.
AI.method: Two main contributions: (1) curriculum strategy that gradually increases the length of expert trajectories during training to stabilize learning and enhance long-term accuracy; (2) a method to approximate egocentric perception from third-person global state demonstrations by filtering neighbors, transforming reference frames, and simulating onboard sensor variability; integrated in a physics-informed framework to produce scalable, distributed policies from observations.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation on two tasks with varying team sizes and noise shows that the curriculum improves long-term accuracy and the perceptual estimation method yields policies robust to realistic uncertainty, enabling learning of distributed controllers from global demonstrations even without expert actions or onboard measurements.
AI.conclusion: The combination of curriculum-based long-horizon training and perceptual proxying from global demonstrations enables robust, scalable MRS policies that operate in a distributed fashion without onboard measurements or expert actions.

title: BPMN Assistant: An LLM-Based Approach to Business Process Modeling
summary:
This paper presents BPMN Assistant, a tool that leverages Large Language
Models (LLMs) for natural language-based creation and editing of BPMN diagrams.
A specialized JSON-based representation is introduced as a structured
alternative to the direct handling of XML to enhance the accuracy of process
modifications. Process generation quality is evaluated using Graph Edit
Distance (GED) and Relative Graph Edit Distance (RGED), while editing
performance is evaluated with a binary success metric. Results show that JSON
and XML achieve similar similarity scores in generation, but JSON offers
greater reliability, faster processing, and significantly higher editing
success rates. We discuss key trade-offs, limitations, and future improvements.
The implementation is available at https://github.com/jtlicardo/bpmn-assistant.

AI.tldr: BPMN Assistant uses LLMs with a JSON-based diagram representation to improve natural language-based creation and editing of BPMN diagrams, achieving similar generation quality to XML but superior editing reliability and speed.
AI.motivation: Address fragility and inefficiency of XML-based BPMN editing with LLMs by adopting a structured, JSON representation to improve modification accuracy, processing speed, and editing success.
AI.method: Introduce BPMN Assistant, employing LLMs for NL-based BPMN creation/editing and a specialized JSON-based representation as an alternative to direct XML handling. Evaluate generation quality via Graph Edit Distance (GED) and Relative Graph Edit Distance (RGED); evaluate editing with a binary success metric; compare JSON vs XML in generation and editing performance.
AI.result: Generation quality: JSON and XML yield similar similarity scores. Editing performance: JSON offers greater reliability, faster processing, and significantly higher editing success rates.
AI.conclusion: JSON-based representation is advantageous for LLM-driven BPMN editing, with trade-offs and limitations discussed and future work proposed. Implementation is available at the provided GitHub URL.

title: Fusing Sequence Motifs and Pan-Genomic Features: Antimicrobial Resistance Prediction using an Explainable Lightweight 1D CNN-XGBoost Ensemble
comment:
Submitted to SCA/HPCAsia 2026. This preprint version has been
  prepared for open-access distribution and may differ in formatting from the
  official proceedings. Also available on bioRxiv for visibility to the life
  sciences community
summary:
Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) is a rapidly escalating global health crisis.
While genomic sequencing enables rapid prediction of resistance phenotypes,
current computational methods have limitations. Standard machine learning
models treat the genome as an unordered collection of features, ignoring the
sequential context of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs). State-of-the-art
sequence models like Transformers are often too data-hungry and computationally
expensive for the moderately-sized datasets that are typical in this domain. To
address these challenges, we propose AMR-EnsembleNet, an ensemble framework
that synergistically combines sequence-based and feature-based learning. We
developed a lightweight, custom 1D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to
efficiently learn predictive sequence motifs from high-dimensional SNP data.
This sequence-aware model was ensembled with an XGBoost model, a powerful
gradient boosting system adept at capturing complex, non-local feature
interactions. We trained and evaluated our framework on a benchmark dataset of
809 E. coli strains, predicting resistance across four antibiotics with varying
class imbalance. Our 1D CNN-XGBoost ensemble consistently achieved top-tier
performance across all the antibiotics, reaching a Matthews Correlation
Coefficient (MCC) of 0.926 for Ciprofloxacin (CIP) and the highest Macro
F1-score of 0.691 for the challenging Gentamicin (GEN) AMR prediction. We also
show that our model consistently focuses on SNPs within well-known AMR genes
like fusA and parC, confirming it learns the correct genetic signals for
resistance. Our work demonstrates that fusing a sequence-aware 1D CNN with a
feature-based XGBoost model creates a powerful ensemble, overcoming the
limitations of using either an order-agnostic or a standalone sequence model.

AI.tldr: A lightweight AMR-EnsembleNet uses a 1D CNN to learn SNP sequence motifs and fuses it with XGBoost, achieving strong AMR prediction on 809 E. coli strains across four antibiotics, with high MCC and Macro F1 and focus on known AMR genes.
AI.motivation: AMR is a rising global health crisis. Genomic sequencing enables rapid resistance prediction, but standard ML treats genomes as unordered features; Transformers are data- and compute-heavy for moderate datasets. There is a need for efficient models that leverage SNP sequential context and non-local interactions.
AI.method: Propose AMR-EnsembleNet: a lightweight 1D CNN to extract predictive sequence motifs from high-dimensional SNP data, ensembled with an XGBoost model. Trained on 809 E. coli strains across four antibiotics with class imbalance. Evaluation uses MCC and Macro F1; analysis shows SNP focus in known AMR genes (e.g., fusA, parC).
AI.result: The 1D CNN–XGBoost ensemble achieved top-tier performance across all antibiotics, e.g., MCC 0.926 for Ciprofloxacin (CIP) and Macro F1 0.691 for Gentamicin (GEN). The model consistently highlights SNPs within well-known AMR genes, indicating it learns relevant genetic signals.
AI.conclusion: Ensembling a sequence-aware CNN with a feature-based XGBoost model effectively overcomes the limitations of order-agnostic or standalone sequence models, offering a performant and interpretable approach for AMR prediction on moderately-sized datasets.

title: From Fields to Splats: A Cross-Domain Survey of Real-Time Neural Scene Representations
summary:
Neural scene representations such as Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) and 3D
Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) have transformed how 3D environments are modeled,
rendered, and interpreted. NeRF introduced view-consistent photorealism via
volumetric rendering; 3DGS has rapidly emerged as an explicit, efficient
alternative that supports high-quality rendering, faster optimization, and
integration into hybrid pipelines for enhanced photorealism and task-driven
scene understanding. This survey examines how 3DGS is being adopted across
SLAM, telepresence and teleoperation, robotic manipulation, and 3D content
generation. Despite their differences, these domains share common goals:
photorealistic rendering, meaningful 3D structure, and accurate downstream
tasks. We organize the review around unified research questions that explain
why 3DGS is increasingly displacing NeRF-based approaches: What technical
advantages drive its adoption? How does it adapt to different input modalities
and domain-specific constraints? What limitations remain? By systematically
comparing domain-specific pipelines, we show that 3DGS balances photorealism,
geometric fidelity, and computational efficiency. The survey offers a roadmap
for leveraging neural rendering not only for image synthesis but also for
perception, interaction, and content creation across real and virtual
environments.

AI.tldr: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) is increasingly preferred over NeRF in real-world pipelines due to better efficiency, fidelity, and integration, with a survey mapping advantages, modalities, limitations, and a roadmap for adoption across domains.
AI.motivation: There is a need for scalable, photorealistic, and versatile 3D representations that work across diverse tasks (SLAM, telepresence, robotics, content creation). 3DGS offers explicit, efficient rendering and easier integration into hybrid systems, addressing limitations of NeRF-based methods.
AI.method: Systematic survey organized around unified research questions. It compares domain-specific pipelines, analyzes input modalities and domain constraints, and evaluates tradeoffs among photorealism, geometric fidelity, and computation. It culminates in a roadmap and identification of limitations and future directions.
AI.result: 3DGS provides a favorable balance of photorealism, geometric fidelity, and computational efficiency, enabling rapid optimization and integration into a range of perception and rendering pipelines. The review demonstrates adoption across SLAM, teleoperation, robotics, and 3D content generation.
AI.conclusion: 3DGS is a promising direction for neural rendering in real and virtual environments. The survey offers guidance for leveraging neural rendering beyond image synthesis toward perception, interaction, and content creation, while outlining remaining challenges and opportunities.

title: Safe Planning in Unknown Environments using Conformalized Semantic Maps
summary:
This paper addresses semantic planning problems in unknown environments under
perceptual uncertainty. The environment contains multiple unknown semantically
labeled regions or objects, and the robot must reach desired locations while
maintaining class-dependent distances from them. We aim to compute robot paths
that complete such semantic reach-avoid tasks with user-defined probability
despite uncertain perception. Existing planning algorithms either ignore
perceptual uncertainty - thus lacking correctness guarantees - or assume known
sensor models and noise characteristics. In contrast, we present the first
planner for semantic reach-avoid tasks that achieves user-specified mission
completion rates without requiring any knowledge of sensor models or noise.
This is enabled by quantifying uncertainty in semantic maps - constructed
on-the-fly from perceptual measurements - using conformal prediction in a
model- and distribution-free manner. We validate our approach and the
theoretical mission completion rates through extensive experiments, showing
that it consistently outperforms baselines in mission success rates.

AI.tldr: A model-free, conformal-prediction-based planner for semantic reach-avoid under perceptual uncertainty, achieving user-specified mission completion rates without assuming sensor models.
AI.motivation: Semantic planning in unknown environments with perceptual uncertainty requires guarantees on success rates. Existing methods either ignore uncertainty or rely on known sensor models, hindering reliability and generality.
AI.method: Construct semantic maps on-the-fly from perceptual measurements and quantify their uncertainty using conformal prediction in a model- and distribution-free way. Use these uncertainty quantifications to synthesize a planner that guarantees user-specified mission completion probabilities without needing sensor-model knowledge.
AI.result: The approach provides theoretical mission completion rate guarantees and is validated by extensive experiments, where it consistently outperforms baselines in mission success rates.
AI.conclusion: This work delivers the first planner for semantic reach-avoid under perceptual uncertainty with user-specified success guarantees, without requiring sensor-model information, and demonstrates robust performance across tests.

title: LTL$_f$ Learning Meets Boolean Set Cover
summary:
Learning formulas in Linear Temporal Logic (LTLf) from finite traces is a
fundamental research problem which has found applications in artificial
intelligence, software engineering, programming languages, formal methods,
control of cyber-physical systems, and robotics. We implement a new CPU tool
called Bolt improving over the state of the art by learning formulas more than
100x faster over 70% of the benchmarks, with smaller or equal formulas in 98%
of the cases. Our key insight is to leverage a problem called Boolean Set Cover
as a subroutine to combine existing formulas using Boolean connectives. Thanks
to the Boolean Set Cover component, our approach offers a novel trade-off
between efficiency and formula size.

AI.tldr: Introduces Bolt for fast learning of LTLf formulas from finite traces, using Boolean Set Cover to compose formulas. Claims up to 100x faster learning on 70% of benchmarks with smaller or equal formulas in 98% of cases.
AI.motivation: Automate extraction of LTLf specifications from finite traces and improve scalability across AI, software engineering, programming languages, formal methods, cyber-physical systems, and robotics.
AI.method: Leverages Boolean Set Cover as a subroutine to combine existing formulas via Boolean connectives, enabling a trade-off between learning efficiency and formula size.
AI.result: Bolt achieves more than 100x faster learning than the state of the art on over 70% of benchmarks, with smaller or equivalent formula sizes in 98% of cases.
AI.conclusion: Using a Boolean Set Cover component yields a favorable efficiency–size trade-off, making Bolt a practical advancement for LTLf formula learning from finite traces.

title: Improving constraint-based discovery with robust propagation and reliable LLM priors
summary:
Learning causal structure from observational data is central to scientific
modeling and decision-making. Constraint-based methods aim to recover
conditional independence (CI) relations in a causal directed acyclic graph
(DAG). Classical approaches such as PC and subsequent methods orient
v-structures first and then propagate edge directions from these seeds,
assuming perfect CI tests and exhaustive search of separating subsets --
assumptions often violated in practice, leading to cascading errors in the
final graph. Recent work has explored using large language models (LLMs) as
experts, prompting sets of nodes for edge directions, and could augment edge
orientation when assumptions are not met. However, such methods implicitly
assume perfect experts, which is unrealistic for hallucination-prone LLMs. We
propose MosaCD, a causal discovery method that propagates edges from a
high-confidence set of seeds derived from both CI tests and LLM annotations. To
filter hallucinations, we introduce shuffled queries that exploit LLMs'
positional bias, retaining only high-confidence seeds. We then apply a novel
confidence-down propagation strategy that orients the most reliable edges
first, and can be integrated with any skeleton-based discovery method. Across
multiple real-world graphs, MosaCD achieves higher accuracy in final graph
construction than existing constraint-based methods, largely due to the
improved reliability of initial seeds and robust propagation strategies.

AI.tldr: MosaCD uses high-confidence seeds from CI tests and LLM annotations, filters LLM hallucinations via shuffled queries, and propagates edge directions with a confidence-down strategy, improving accuracy over traditional constraint-based methods and compatible with skeleton-based discovery.
AI.motivation: CI-based causal discovery assumes perfect CI tests and exhaustive search; real data breach assumptions leading to cascading errors. LLMs offer supplementary guidance but are prone to hallucinations; need robust seed selection and propagation.
AI.method: Combine seeds from CI tests and LLMs; apply shuffled queries to resist positional bias and filter hallucinations; apply confidence-down propagation to orient edges from the most reliable seeds; integrate with any skeleton-based method.
AI.result: On multiple real-world graphs, MosaCD achieves higher final-graph accuracy than existing constraint-based methods due to improved seed reliability and robust propagation.
AI.conclusion: MosaCD provides a robust, plug-in approach for causal discovery from observational data by leveraging mixed evidence sources and a principled seed propagation strategy, adaptable to various skeleton-based algorithms.

title: Pancreas Part Segmentation under Federated Learning Paradigm
summary:
We present the first federated learning (FL) approach for pancreas part(head,
body and tail) segmentation in MRI, addressing a critical clinical challenge as
a significant innovation. Pancreatic diseases exhibit marked regional
heterogeneity cancers predominantly occur in the head region while chronic
pancreatitis causes tissue loss in the tail, making accurate segmentation of
the organ into head, body, and tail regions essential for precise diagnosis and
treatment planning. This segmentation task remains exceptionally challenging in
MRI due to variable morphology, poor soft-tissue contrast, and anatomical
variations across patients. Our novel contribution tackles two fundamental
challenges: first, the technical complexity of pancreas part delineation in
MRI, and second the data scarcity problem that has hindered prior approaches.
We introduce a privacy-preserving FL framework that enables collaborative model
training across seven medical institutions without direct data sharing,
leveraging a diverse dataset of 711 T1W and 726 T2W MRI scans. Our key
innovations include: (1) a systematic evaluation of three state-of-the-art
segmentation architectures (U-Net, Attention U-Net,Swin UNETR) paired with two
FL algorithms (FedAvg, FedProx), revealing Attention U-Net with FedAvg as
optimal for pancreatic heterogeneity, which was never been done before; (2) a
novel anatomically-informed loss function prioritizing region-specific texture
contrasts in MRI. Comprehensive evaluation demonstrates that our approach
achieves clinically viable performance despite training on distributed,
heterogeneous datasets.

AI.tldr: Federated learning for pancreas part segmentation (head/body/tail) in MRI across seven institutions using 711 T1W and 726 T2W scans. Attention U-Net with FedAvg yields best results; introduces anatomically-informed loss; achieves clinically viable performance while preserving privacy.
AI.motivation: Pancreas segmentation into head, body, and tail is clinically important due to regional disease patterns and morphological variability in MRI. Limited data and privacy constraints hinder centralized training, motivating a privacy-preserving FL approach across multiple institutions.
AI.method: Systematic evaluation of three segmentation architectures (U-Net, Attention U-Net, Swin UNETR) with two FL algorithms (FedAvg, FedProx) on distributed, heterogeneous MRI data. Development of an anatomically-informed loss prioritizing region-specific MRI texture contrasts. Data from seven institutions (711 T1W, 726 T2W scans) used for training and evaluation.
AI.result: Attention U-Net with FedAvg identified as optimal for handling pancreatic heterogeneity in FL setting. The anatomically-informed loss improved region-specific segmentation performance. The approach achieved clinically viable segmentation performance despite distributed data and privacy constraints.
AI.conclusion: First FL framework for pancreas part segmentation in MRI, demonstrating feasibility of privacy-preserving multi-institution collaboration for organ-part segmentation and introducing a loss that leverages anatomical priors to enhance MRI texture-based segmentation.

title: From Static to Dynamic: a Survey of Topology-Aware Perception in Autonomous Driving
summary:
The key to achieving autonomous driving lies in topology-aware perception,
the structured understanding of the driving environment with an emphasis on
lane topology and road semantics. This survey systematically reviews four core
research directions under this theme: vectorized map construction, topological
structure modeling, prior knowledge fusion, and language model-based
perception. Across these directions, we observe a unifying trend: a paradigm
shift from static, pre-built maps to dynamic, sensor-driven perception.
Specifically, traditional static maps have provided semantic context for
autonomous systems. However, they are costly to construct, difficult to update
in real time, and lack generalization across regions, limiting their
scalability. In contrast, dynamic representations leverage on-board sensor data
for real-time map construction and topology reasoning. Each of the four
research directions contributes to this shift through compact spatial modeling,
semantic relational reasoning, robust domain knowledge integration, and
multimodal scene understanding powered by pre-trained language models.
Together, they pave the way for more adaptive, scalable, and explainable
autonomous driving systems.

AI.tldr: A survey of topology-aware perception in autonomous driving identifies four directions—vectorized map construction, topological structure modeling, prior knowledge fusion, and language-model–based perception—and highlights a shift from static maps to dynamic, sensor-driven representations that enable compact spatial modeling, relational reasoning, knowledge integration, and multimodal understanding for scalable, explainable systems.
AI.motivation: Static maps provide semantic context but are costly to build, hard to update in real time, and poorly generalize across regions. There is a need for dynamic, sensor-driven perception that can adapt in real time and scale to diverse environments.
AI.method: Systematic review of four research directions: (1) vectorized map construction, (2) topological structure modeling, (3) prior knowledge fusion, and (4) language model–based perception, analyzing how each contributes to dynamic, topology-aware understanding and identifying common trends and requirements.
AI.result: The survey reveals a unifying trend toward dynamic representations driven by onboard sensors, enabling real-time map construction and topology reasoning.
