AI.motivation: Current equivariant transformers are limited to low-order features and local contexts, incurring high compute when scaling to global attention. There is a need for scalable, expressive models that can handle high-order geometric information in physical, chemical, and vision tasks.
AI.method: Propose Clebsch-Gordan Convolution on SO(3) irreps to realize global attention within an equivariant framework. Achieves O(N log N) input token complexity and leverages sparsity of the Clebsch-Gordan matrix to scale to high-order features. Optional token permutation equivariance is provided via weight sharing or data augmentation.
AI.result: Empirical benchmarks across n-body simulation, QM9, ModelNet point cloud classification, and a robotic grasping dataset show clear gains in GPU memory footprint, speed, and accuracy compared to existing equivariant transformers.
AI.conclusion: The CK-Transformer delivers scalable, expressive, high-order equivariant modeling with efficient global attention, and practical performance improvements across diverse domains; permutation equivariance can be incorporated without sacrificing efficiency.

title: Pushing LLMs to Their Logical Reasoning Bound: The Role of Data Reasoning Intensity
summary:
Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) highlight the importance of
training data structure and quality in shaping reasoning behavior. However,
most existing approaches focus on transforming data formats while neglecting
the internal reasoning complexity of training samples, leaving the reasoning
potential of data under-explored and underutilized. In this work, we posit that
LLM logical reasoning performance is jointly constrained by the potential of
the training data and the cognitive capacity of the model. To make this
relationship measurable, we introduce Data Reasoning Intensity (DRI), a novel
metric that quantifies the latent logical reasoning complexity of samples by
decomposing and aggregating their logical structures. This allows us to analyze
how well current LLMs utilize logical reasoning signals and identify
performance gaps relative to data potential. Based on this insight, we
introduce a re-cognizing optimization strategy that systematically enhances the
logical reasoning intensity of training data.Rather than increasing data
volume, our method re-optimizes existing samples to better align with the LLM's
logical reasoning boundary. Extensive experiments show that our approach
significantly improves performance and generalization over data-centric
strategies. We further validate our method under a reinforcement learning
framework. Our results indicate that prioritizing reasoning complexity in data
rather than sheer scale or superficial form is essential to realizing LLMs'
full cognitive potential.

AI.tldr: Introduces Data Reasoning Intensity (DRI) to quantify latent reasoning in training data and a re-cognizing optimization to boost LLM reasoning capacity by data rather than scale, improving performance and generalization, also validated under RL.
AI.motivation: LLMs' reasoning performance is shaped by both training data potential and model cognitive capacity. Existing data-centric work mainly focuses on data formats and scale, neglecting implicit logical reasoning content in samples. This work proposes a measurable latent reasoning metric (DRI) and a data-centric optimization to unlock the data's reasoning potential.
AI.method: Define DRI to decompose and quantify the latent logical reasoning complexity of samples by parsing their logical structures and aggregating these signals. Use DRI to analyze how well current LLMs utilize reasoning signals and identify gaps. Propose a re-cognizing optimization strategy that re-optimizes existing samples to better align with the LLM's logical reasoning boundary without increasing data volume. Validate under standard training and reinforcement learning settings.
AI.result: Empirical results show significant performance and generalization gains over traditional data-centric strategies. The approach outperforms volume-based or superficial-format improvements. Reinforcement learning experiments further validate that prioritizing reasoning complexity in data enhances cognitive potential of LLMs.
AI.conclusion: Prioritizing reasoning complexity in data, rather than merely increasing data size or altering formats, is essential to realizing the full cognitive potential of LLMs. The data's latent logical structure and its alignment with model capacity are critical factors for robust reasoning and generalization.

title: PreScope: Unleashing the Power of Prefetching for Resource-Constrained MoE Inference
summary:
Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models face memory and PCIe latency bottlenecks when
deployed on commodity hardware. Offloading expert weights to CPU memory results
in PCIe transfer latency that exceeds GPU computation by several folds. We
present PreScope, a prediction-driven expert scheduling system that addresses
three key challenges: inaccurate activation prediction, PCIe bandwidth
competition, and cross-device scheduling complexity. Our solution includes: 1)
Learnable Layer-Aware Predictor (LLaPor) that captures layer-specific expert
activation patterns; 2) Prefetch-Aware Cross-Layer Scheduling (PreSched) that
generates globally optimal plans balancing prefetching costs and loading
overhead; 3) Asynchronous I/O Optimizer (AsyncIO) that decouples I/O from
computation, eliminating waiting bubbles. PreScope achieves 141% higher
throughput and 74.6% lower latency than state-of-the-art solutions.

AI.tldr: A prediction-driven, three-part scheduling system (PreScope) mitigates MoE offload bottlenecks by learning activation patterns, planning prefetch/loading across layers, and decoupling I/O from compute, achieving substantial throughput and latency gains.
AI.motivation: MoE deployment on commodity hardware suffers memory and PCIe bottlenecks when offloading expert weights to CPU memory; accurate activation prediction, bandwidth-aware scheduling, and asynchronous I/O are needed to minimize transfer overheads.
AI.method: 1) Learnable Layer-Aware Predictor (LLaPor) models layer-specific expert activation patterns; 2) Prefetch-Aware Cross-Layer Scheduling (PreSched) computes globally optimal prefetch/loading plans balancing costs; 3) Async I/O Optimizer (AsyncIO) decouples I/O from computation to remove waiting bubbles.
AI.result: PreScope reports 141% higher throughput and 74.6% lower latency than state-of-the-art solutions on MoE deployments with CPU offload.
AI.conclusion: A modular, prediction-driven approach can effectively address memory and PCIe transfer bottlenecks in MoE on commodity hardware, enabling faster and more efficient inference; effectiveness depends on prediction accuracy and orchestration across components.

title: VMDiff: Visual Mixing Diffusion for Limitless Cross-Object Synthesis
summary:
Creating novel images by fusing visual cues from multiple sources is a
fundamental yet underexplored problem in image-to-image generation, with broad
applications in artistic creation, virtual reality and visual media. Existing
methods often face two key challenges: coexistent generation, where multiple
objects are simply juxtaposed without true integration, and bias generation,
where one object dominates the output due to semantic imbalance. To address
these issues, we propose Visual Mixing Diffusion (VMDiff), a simple yet
effective diffusion-based framework that synthesizes a single, coherent object
by integrating two input images at both noise and latent levels. Our approach
comprises: (1) a hybrid sampling process that combines guided denoising,
inversion, and spherical interpolation with adjustable parameters to achieve
structure-aware fusion, mitigating coexistent generation; and (2) an efficient
adaptive adjustment module, which introduces a novel similarity-based score to
automatically and adaptively search for optimal parameters, countering semantic
bias. Experiments on a curated benchmark of 780 concept pairs demonstrate that
our method outperforms strong baselines in visual quality, semantic
consistency, and human-rated creativity.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based image fusion method (VMDiff) that merges two inputs into one coherent object, using hybrid denoising/inversion/spherical interpolation and adaptive similarity-based parameter search to reduce coexistent artifacts and semantic bias.
AI.motivation: Coexistent generation (objects merely juxtaposed) and bias generation (one object dominates) hinder multi-source image-to-image synthesis; there is a need for structure-aware fusion.
AI.method: Hybrid sampling combining guided denoising, inversion, and spherical interpolation; an adaptive adjustment module with a similarity-based score to automatically optimize parameters.
AI.result: On a curated benchmark of 780 concept pairs, VMDiff outperforms strong baselines in visual quality, semantic consistency, and human-rated creativity.
AI.conclusion: VMDiff provides a simple yet effective diffusion-based framework for coherent single-object fusion from two inputs, addressing coexistent and bias issues; shows promise for artistic creation and related visual media.

title: PhysicsMinions: Winning Gold Medals in the Latest Physics Olympiads with a Coevolutionary Multimodal Multi-Agent System
summary:
Physics is central to understanding and shaping the real world, and the
ability to solve physics problems is a key indicator of real-world physical
intelligence. Physics Olympiads, renowned as the crown of competitive physics,
provide a rigorous testbed requiring complex reasoning and deep multimodal
understanding, yet they remain largely underexplored in AI research. Existing
approaches are predominantly single-model based, and open-source MLLMs rarely
reach gold-medal-level performance. To address this gap, we propose
PhysicsMinions, a coevolutionary multi-agent system for Physics Olympiad. Its
architecture features three synergistic studios: a Visual Studio to interpret
diagrams, a Logic Studio to formulate solutions, and a Review Studio to perform
dual-stage verification. The system coevolves through an iterative refinement
loop where feedback from the Review Studio continuously guides the Logic
Studio, enabling the system to self-correct and converge towards the ground
truth. Evaluated on the HiPhO benchmark spanning 7 latest physics Olympiads,
PhysicsMinions delivers three major breakthroughs: (i) Strong generalization:
it consistently improves both open-source and closed-source models of different
sizes, delivering clear benefits over their single-model baselines; (ii)
Historic breakthroughs: it elevates open-source models from only 1-2 to 6 gold
medals across 7 Olympiads, achieving the first-ever open-source gold medal in
the latest International Physics Olympiad (IPhO) under the average-score
metric; and (iii) Scaling to human expert: it further advances the open-source
Pass@32 score to 26.8/30 points on the latest IPhO, ranking 4th of 406
contestants and far surpassing the top single-model score of 22.7 (ranked
22nd). Generally, PhysicsMinions offers a generalizable framework for
Olympiad-level problem solving, with the potential to extend across
disciplines.

AI.tldr: A coevolutionary multi-agent system (PhysicsMinions) tackles Physics Olympiad problems via three synergistic studios (Visual, Logic, Review) to achieve strong generalization, historic open-source breakthroughs, and near-human expert performance on the HiPhO benchmark.
AI.motivation: Physics Olympiads require advanced multimodal reasoning and precise solution verification; current AI approaches are mostly single-model and underperform at gold-medal level, especially for open-source models.
AI.method: PhysicsMinions deploys three interdependent studios: Visual Studio for diagram interpretation, Logic Studio for solution derivation, and Review Studio for dual-stage verification. It uses a coevolutionary loop where feedback from the Review Studio guides the Logic Studio iteratively toward the ground truth, enabling self-correction and convergence.
AI.result: On the HiPhO benchmark across 7 recent Olympiads, PhysicsMinions achieves: (i) strong generalization—consistent improvements for both open-source and closed-source models across sizes; (ii) historic breakthroughs—open-source medals rise from 1–2 to 6 gold medals across 7 Olympiads, including the first open-source gold in the latest IPhO (average-score metric); (iii) scaling to human experts—Pass@32 reaches 26.8/30 (rank 4th of 406 contestants, top-4) while the top single-model score is 22.7 (rank 22nd).
AI.conclusion: PhysicsMinions provides a generalizable, multi-agent framework for high-level problem solving at Olympiad scale, with potential applicability beyond physics to other disciplines.

title: Virtual Nodes based Heterogeneous Graph Convolutional Neural Network for Efficient Long-Range Information Aggregation
summary:
Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks (HGNNs) have exhibited powerful
performance in heterogeneous graph learning by aggregating information from
various types of nodes and edges. However, existing heterogeneous graph models
often struggle to capture long-range information or necessitate stacking
numerous layers to learn such dependencies, resulting in high computational
complexity and encountering over-smoothing issues. In this paper, we propose a
Virtual Nodes based Heterogeneous Graph Convolutional Network (VN-HGCN), which
leverages virtual nodes to facilitate enhanced information flow within the
graph. Virtual nodes are auxiliary nodes interconnected with all nodes of a
specific type in the graph, facilitating efficient aggregation of long-range
information across different types of nodes and edges. By incorporating virtual
nodes into the graph structure, VN-HGCN achieves effective information
aggregation with only $4$ layers. Additionally, we demonstrate that VN-HGCN can
serve as a versatile framework that can be seamlessly applied to other HGNN
models, showcasing its generalizability. Empirical evaluations validate the
effectiveness of VN-HGCN, and extensive experiments conducted on three
real-world heterogeneous graph datasets demonstrate the superiority of our
model over several state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: Proposes VN-HGCN, a virtual-nodes framework for HGNNs enabling long-range information flow with only 4 layers, outperforming baselines across three real-world datasets and generalizable to other HGNNs.
AI.motivation: Heterogeneous graphs struggle to capture long-range dependencies and often require deep stacks, leading to high computation costs and over-smoothing; there is a need for efficient long-range information aggregation across types.
AI.method: Introduce virtual nodes connected to all nodes of each type, forming VN-HGCN. Integrate virtual nodes into the graph to facilitate information flow, enabling effective aggregation with shallow depth (4 layers). Framework is generalizable to other HGNN models.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations on three real-world heterogeneous graph datasets show superiority over several state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: VN-HGCN provides effective long-range information propagation, reduces necessary depth, and generalizes to other HGNNs, offering a versatile approach for heterogeneous graph learning.

title: FlowLUT: Efficient Image Enhancement via Differentiable LUTs and Iterative Flow Matching
summary:
Deep learning-based image enhancement methods face a fundamental trade-off
between computational efficiency and representational capacity. For example,
although a conventional three-dimensional Look-Up Table (3D LUT) can process a
degraded image in real time, it lacks representational flexibility and depends
solely on a fixed prior. To address this problem, we introduce FlowLUT, a novel
end-to-end model that integrates the efficiency of LUTs, multiple priors, and
the parameter-independent characteristic of flow-matched reconstructed images.
Specifically, firstly, the input image is transformed in color space by a
collection of differentiable 3D LUTs (containing a large number of 3D LUTs with
different priors). Subsequently, a lightweight content-aware dynamically
predicts fusion weights, enabling scene-adaptive color correction with
$\mathcal{O}(1)$ complexity. Next, a lightweight fusion prediction network runs
on multiple 3D LUTs, with $\mathcal{O}(1)$ complexity for scene-adaptive color
correction.Furthermore, to address the inherent representation limitations of
LUTs, we design an innovative iterative flow matching method to restore local
structural details and eliminate artifacts. Finally, the entire model is
jointly optimized under a composite loss function enforcing perceptual and
structural fidelity. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the
effectiveness of our method on three benchmarks.

AI.tldr: FlowLUT combines differentiable 3D LUTs with a light fusion mechanism and iterative flow-matching to achieve real-time, scene-adaptive color correction with improved detail.
AI.motivation: To overcome the trade-off between efficiency and representational capacity in image enhancement: fixed 3D LUTs are fast but rigid; this work aims to retain LUT efficiency while increasing flexibility and detail.
AI.method: An ensemble of differentiable 3D LUTs transform the color space; a lightweight, content-aware network predicts fusion weights for O(1) fusion across LUTs; a lightweight fusion network performs scene-adaptive fusion across multiple LUTs; an iterative flow-matching module restores local structure and mitigates artifacts; end-to-end optimization with a composite perceptual/structural loss.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on three benchmarks demonstrate effectiveness of FlowLUT, validating improved efficiency and quality due to LUT fusion and flow-based refinement.
AI.conclusion: FlowLUT provides an end-to-end framework that combines the efficiency of LUTs with flexible, flow-based refinement to achieve real-time, scene-adaptive color correction with enhanced detail.

title: FreeAction: Training-Free Techniques for Enhanced Fidelity of Trajectory-to-Video Generation
comment: 8 pages, 4 figures, accepted to CoRL 2025 LSRW workshop
summary:
Generating realistic robot videos from explicit action trajectories is a
critical step toward building effective world models and robotics foundation
models. We introduce two training-free, inference-time techniques that fully
exploit explicit action parameters in diffusion-based robot video generation.
Instead of treating action vectors as passive conditioning signals, our methods
actively incorporate them to guide both the classifier-free guidance process
and the initialization of Gaussian latents. First, action-scaled
classifier-free guidance dynamically modulates guidance strength in proportion
to action magnitude, enhancing controllability over motion intensity. Second,
action-scaled noise truncation adjusts the distribution of initially sampled
noise to better align with the desired motion dynamics. Experiments on real
robot manipulation datasets demonstrate that these techniques significantly
improve action coherence and visual quality across diverse robot environments.

AI.tldr: Two training-free inference-time techniques—action-scaled classifier-free guidance and action-scaled noise truncation—leverage explicit action trajectories to improve controllability and realism in diffusion-based robot video generation without retraining.
AI.motivation: To build better world models and robotics foundation models by generating faithful, controllable robot videos; existing methods treat actions as passive conditioning signals, and retraining for better control is costly. Training-free inference-time methods offer rapid, flexible improvements.
AI.method: During inference, explicitly incorporate action vectors by (1) scaling classifier-free guidance strength in proportion to action magnitude to control motion intensity, and (2) adjusting the initial noise distribution through action-scaled noise truncation to align with motion dynamics. Both techniques require no training and directly use the action parameters to guide generation.
AI.result: On real robot manipulation datasets, the proposed techniques significantly improve action coherence and visual quality across diverse robot environments.
AI.conclusion: Inference-time, training-free action-aware strategies can substantially enhance controllability and realism in diffusion-based robot video generation, aiding the development of robust world models and robotics foundation models without additional training.

title: The Emergence of Social Science of Large Language Models
summary:
The social science of large language models (LLMs) examines how these systems
evoke mind attributions, interact with one another, and transform human
activity and institutions. We conducted a systematic review of 270 studies,
combining text embeddings, unsupervised clustering and topic modeling to build
a computational taxonomy. Three domains emerge organically across the reviewed
literature. LLM as Social Minds examines whether and when models display
behaviors that elicit attributions of cognition, morality and bias, while
addressing challenges such as test leakage and surface cues. LLM Societies
examines multi-agent settings where interaction protocols, architectures and
mechanism design shape coordination, norms, institutions and collective
epistemic processes. LLM-Human Interactions examines how LLMs reshape tasks,
learning, trust, work and governance, and how risks arise at the human-AI
interface. This taxonomy provides a reproducible map of a fragmented field,
clarifies evidentiary standards across levels of analysis, and highlights
opportunities for cumulative progress in the social science of artificial
intelligence.

AI.tldr: A systematic review of 270 studies yields a three-domain computational taxonomy of the social science of LLMs, offering a reproducible map to organize evidence and guide future research.
AI.motivation: To address fragmentation in the social science of AI and clarify how LLMs evoke mind attributions, mediate multi-agent interactions, and reshape human activity and institutions, while standardizing evidentiary practices.
AI.method: Systematic review of 270 studies, employing text embeddings, unsupervised clustering, and topic modeling to build a computational taxonomy.
AI.result: Three domains emerge: LLM as Social Minds; LLM Societies; LLM-Human Interactions. The taxonomy provides a reproducible map, clarifies evidentiary standards across analysis levels, and highlights opportunities for cumulative progress; it also engages with challenges like test leakage and surface cues.
AI.conclusion: The taxonomy advances synthesis in a fragmented field, enabling more cohesive progress in the social science of AI by standardizing evidentiary expectations and guiding future research across domains.

title: Pure Node Selection for Imbalanced Graph Node Classification
summary:
The problem of class imbalance refers to an uneven distribution of quantity
among classes in a dataset, where some classes are significantly
underrepresented compared to others. Class imbalance is also prevalent in
graph-structured data. Graph neural networks (GNNs) are typically based on the
assumption of class balance, often overlooking the issue of class imbalance. In
our investigation, we identified a problem, which we term the Randomness
Anomalous Connectivity Problem (RACP), where certain off-the-shelf models are
affected by random seeds, leading to a significant performance degradation. To
eliminate the influence of random factors in algorithms, we proposed PNS (Pure
Node Sampling) to address the RACP in the node synthesis stage. Unlike existing
approaches that design specialized algorithms to handle either quantity
imbalance or topological imbalance, PNS is a novel plug-and-play module that
operates directly during node synthesis to mitigate RACP. Moreover, PNS also
alleviates performance degradation caused by abnormal distribution of node
neighbors. We conduct a series of experiments to identify what factors are
influenced by random seeds. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness
and stability of our method, which not only eliminates the effect of
unfavorable random seeds but also outperforms the baseline across various
benchmark datasets with different GNN backbones. Data and code are available at
https://github.com/flzeng1/PNS.

AI.tldr: Introduces Pure Node Sampling (PNS) to combat Randomness Anomalous Connectivity Problem in GNNs under class imbalance; a plug-and-play node-synthesis module that improves stability and performance across backbones and datasets.
AI.motivation: Class imbalance exists in graphs and GNNs often assume balance; randomness from seeds leads to performance degradation (Randomness Anomalous Connectivity Problem, RACP); there is a need to eliminate seed-induced variance during node synthesis.
AI.method: Proposes PNS, a plug-and-play module that operates during node synthesis to mitigate RACP and abnormal neighbor distributions; does not require designing specialized imbalance remedies and is compatible with multiple GNN backbones.
AI.result: Experiments show PNS reduces sensitivity to random seeds and outperforms baselines across benchmark datasets and backbones; data and code are available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: PNS provides stable, effective mitigation of randomness-driven performance degradation in graph learning under class imbalance and generalizes across datasets and GNN backbones.

title: InteractMove: Text-Controlled Human-Object Interaction Generation in 3D Scenes with Movable Objects
summary:
We propose a novel task of text-controlled human object interaction
generation in 3D scenes with movable objects. Existing human-scene interaction
datasets suffer from insufficient interaction categories and typically only
consider interactions with static objects (do not change object positions), and
the collection of such datasets with movable objects is difficult and costly.
To address this problem, we construct the InteractMove dataset for Movable
Human-Object Interaction in 3D Scenes by aligning existing human object
interaction data with scene contexts, featuring three key characteristics: 1)
scenes containing multiple movable objects with text-controlled interaction
specifications (including same-category distractors requiring spatial and 3D
scene context understanding), 2) diverse object types and sizes with varied
interaction patterns (one-hand, two-hand, etc.), and 3) physically plausible
object manipulation trajectories. With the introduction of various movable
objects, this task becomes more challenging, as the model needs to identify
objects to be interacted with accurately, learn to interact with objects of
different sizes and categories, and avoid collisions between movable objects
and the scene. To tackle such challenges, we propose a novel pipeline solution.
We first use 3D visual grounding models to identify the interaction object.
Then, we propose a hand-object joint affordance learning to predict contact
regions for different hand joints and object parts, enabling accurate grasping
and manipulation of diverse objects. Finally, we optimize interactions with
local-scene modeling and collision avoidance constraints, ensuring physically
plausible motions and avoiding collisions between objects and the scene.
Comprehensive experiments demonstrate our method's superiority in generating
physically plausible, text-compliant interactions compared to existing
approaches.

AI.tldr: Introduces the InteractMove dataset for movable human–object interaction in 3D scenes and a pipeline to identify interaction objects, predict hand–object contact regions, and ensure physically plausible, collision-free motions via local-scene modeling and constraints.
AI.motivation: Existing human–scene interaction datasets largely focus on static objects, with limited interaction categories. Collecting data with movable objects is challenging and costly, hindering text-controlled interactions in dynamic scenes. A dataset and method addressing movable objects, diverse sizes/types, and plausible trajectories is needed.
AI.method: 1) Build InteractMove by aligning existing human–object interaction data with scene contexts. 2) Use 3D visual grounding to identify the interaction object. 3) Propose hand–object joint affordance learning to predict contact regions for different hand joints and object parts to enable accurate grasping/manipulation across diverse objects. 4) Optimize interactions with local-scene modeling and collision-avoidance constraints to produce physically plausible motions.
AI.result: Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the method generates physically plausible, text-compliant interactions and outperforms existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a dataset and a pipeline for movable-human–object interaction in 3D scenes, enabling richer, text-controlled manipulation across multiple movable objects and setting a foundation for future research in dynamic scene interaction.

title: RealUnify: Do Unified Models Truly Benefit from Unification? A Comprehensive Benchmark
summary:
The integration of visual understanding and generation into unified
multimodal models represents a significant stride toward general-purpose AI.
However, a fundamental question remains unanswered by existing benchmarks: does
this architectural unification actually enable synergetic interaction between
the constituent capabilities? Existing evaluation paradigms, which primarily
assess understanding and generation in isolation, are insufficient for
determining whether a unified model can leverage its understanding to enhance
its generation, or use generative simulation to facilitate deeper
comprehension. To address this critical gap, we introduce RealUnify, a
benchmark specifically designed to evaluate bidirectional capability synergy.
RealUnify comprises 1,000 meticulously human-annotated instances spanning 10
categories and 32 subtasks. It is structured around two core axes: 1)
Understanding Enhances Generation, which requires reasoning (e.g., commonsense,
logic) to guide image generation, and 2) Generation Enhances Understanding,
which necessitates mental simulation or reconstruction (e.g., of transformed or
disordered visual inputs) to solve reasoning tasks. A key contribution is our
dual-evaluation protocol, which combines direct end-to-end assessment with a
diagnostic stepwise evaluation that decomposes tasks into distinct
understanding and generation phases. This protocol allows us to precisely
discern whether performance bottlenecks stem from deficiencies in core
abilities or from a failure to integrate them. Through large-scale evaluations
of 12 leading unified models and 6 specialized baselines, we find that current
unified models still struggle to achieve effective synergy, indicating that
architectural unification alone is insufficient. These results highlight the
need for new training strategies and inductive biases to fully unlock the
potential of unified modeling.

AI.tldr: RealUnify benchmarks bidirectional synergy between understanding and generation in unified multimodal models, using two axes of evaluation and a dual end-to-end plus diagnostic protocol; results show current unified models lack sufficient synergy.
AI.motivation: To address the gap that existing benchmarks evaluate understanding and generation in isolation and do not reveal whether architectural unification enables true synergy between capabilities.
AI.method: RealUnify comprises 1,000 human-annotated instances across 10 categories and 32 subtasks, organized into two axes: 1) Understanding Enhances Generation (reasoning to guide image generation) and 2) Generation Enhances Understanding (mental simulation to solve reasoning tasks). It employs a dual-evaluation protocol: end-to-end assessment plus stepwise diagnostic evaluation that decomposes tasks into separate understanding and generation phases. The study evaluates 12 unified models and 6 specialized baselines.
AI.result: Current unified models struggle to achieve effective synergy; architectural unification alone is insufficient. The findings indicate the need for new training strategies and inductive biases to fully unlock unified modeling potential.
AI.conclusion: Architectural unification alone does not guarantee synergistic capabilities; to realize true bidirectional synergy between understanding and generation, new training approaches and inductive biases are required.

title: Calibration Meets Reality: Making Machine Learning Predictions Trustworthy
summary:
Post-hoc calibration methods are widely used to improve the reliability of
probabilistic predictions from machine learning models. Despite their
prevalence, a comprehensive theoretical understanding of these methods remains
elusive, particularly regarding their performance across different datasets and
model architectures. Input features play a crucial role in shaping model
predictions and, consequently, their calibration. However, the interplay
between feature quality and calibration performance has not been thoroughly
investigated. In this work, we present a rigorous theoretical analysis of
post-hoc calibration methods, focusing on Platt scaling and isotonic
regression. We derive convergence guarantees, computational complexity bounds,
and finite-sample performance metrics for these methods. Furthermore, we
explore the impact of feature informativeness on calibration performance
through controlled synthetic experiments. Our empirical evaluation spans a
diverse set of real-world datasets and model architectures, demonstrating
consistent improvements in calibration metrics across various scenarios. By
examining calibration performance under varying feature conditions utilizing
only informative features versus complete feature spaces including noise
dimensions, we provide fundamental insights into the robustness and reliability
of different calibration approaches. Our findings offer practical guidelines
for selecting appropriate calibration methods based on dataset characteristics
and computational constraints, bridging the gap between theoretical
understanding and practical implementation in uncertainty quantification. Code
and experimental data are available at:
https://github.com/Ajwebdevs/calibration-analysis-experiments.

AI.tldr: A theoretical and empirical study of post-hoc calibration methods (Platt scaling and isotonic regression) with guarantees and complexity bounds, plus experiments on feature informativeness to guide practice.
AI.motivation: Post-hoc calibration is widely used but lacks deep theoretical understanding, especially how feature quality affects calibration performance; understanding this relationship can inform method choice and resource allocation.
AI.method: Provide convergence guarantees, computational complexity bounds, and finite-sample metrics for Platt scaling and isotonic regression; conduct controlled synthetic experiments varying feature informativeness (informative vs. noisy features); perform broad empirical evaluations across real-world datasets and model architectures; compare performance under different feature spaces.
AI.result: Derived convergence guarantees, complexity bounds, and finite-sample performance metrics for the two methods; empirical results show consistent calibration improvements across scenarios; feature informativeness significantly influences calibration robustness; code and data are provided.
AI.conclusion: Offers practical guidelines for selecting calibration methods based on dataset characteristics and computational constraints; highlights the role of feature quality in calibration performance and bridges theory with practical UQ implementation.

title: BioVessel-Net and RetinaMix: Unsupervised Retinal Vessel Segmentation from OCTA Images
summary:
Structural changes in retinal blood vessels are critical biomarkers for the
onset and progression of glaucoma and other ocular diseases. However, current
vessel segmentation approaches largely rely on supervised learning and
extensive manual annotations, which are costly, error-prone, and difficult to
obtain in optical coherence tomography angiography. Here we present
BioVessel-Net, an unsupervised generative framework that integrates vessel
biostatistics with adversarial refinement and a radius-guided segmentation
strategy. Unlike pixel-based methods, BioVessel-Net directly models vascular
structures with biostatistical coherence, achieving accurate and explainable
vessel extraction without labeled data or high-performance computing. To
support training and evaluation, we introduce RetinaMix, a new benchmark
dataset of 2D and 3D OCTA images with high-resolution vessel details from
diverse populations. Experimental results demonstrate that BioVessel-Net
achieves near-perfect segmentation accuracy across RetinaMix and existing
datasets, substantially outperforming state-of-the-art supervised and
semi-supervised methods. Together, BioVessel-Net and RetinaMix provide a
label-free, computationally efficient, and clinically interpretable solution
for retinal vessel analysis, with broad potential for glaucoma monitoring,
blood flow modeling, and progression prediction. Code and dataset are
available: https://github.com/VikiXie/SatMar8.

AI.tldr: BioVessel-Net is an unsupervised, radius-guided, biostatistics-consistent framework for retinal vessel segmentation, paired with RetinaMix dataset, achieving near-perfect accuracy without labels and outperforming supervised methods; code/dataset released.
AI.motivation: Current retinal vessel segmentation relies on annotated data and supervised learning, which is costly and hard to obtain in OCTA; there is a need for label-free, interpretable, efficient methods for glaucoma and ocular disease monitoring.
AI.method: An unsupervised generative framework that models vascular structures via biostatistics, uses adversarial refinement, and incorporates a radius-guided segmentation strategy. It operates without labeled data and is evaluated on RetinaMix, a new 2D/3D OCTA dataset with diverse populations, emphasizing explainability over pixel-wise segmentation.
AI.result: BioVessel-Net achieves near-perfect segmentation accuracy on RetinaMix and existing datasets, significantly surpassing state-of-the-art supervised and semi-supervised methods. It is label-free, computationally efficient, and clinically interpretable; code and data are released at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: BioVessel-Net and RetinaMix provide a label-free, efficient, and clinically interpretable solution for retinal vessel analysis with potential applications in glaucoma monitoring, blood flow modeling, and progression prediction.

title: SCOPE: Semantic Conditioning for Sim2Real Category-Level Object Pose Estimation in Robotics
summary:
Object manipulation requires accurate object pose estimation. In open
environments, robots encounter unknown objects, which requires semantic
understanding in order to generalize both to known categories and beyond. To
resolve this challenge, we present SCOPE, a diffusion-based category-level
object pose estimation model that eliminates the need for discrete category
labels by leveraging DINOv2 features as continuous semantic priors. By
combining these DINOv2 features with photorealistic training data and a noise
model for point normals, we reduce the Sim2Real gap in category-level object
pose estimation. Furthermore, injecting the continuous semantic priors via
cross-attention enables SCOPE to learn canonicalized object coordinate systems
across object instances beyond the distribution of known categories. SCOPE
outperforms the current state of the art in synthetically trained
category-level object pose estimation, achieving a relative improvement of
31.9\% on the 5$^\circ$5cm metric. Additional experiments on two instance-level
datasets demonstrate generalization beyond known object categories, enabling
grasping of unseen objects from unknown categories with a success rate of up to
100\%. Code available: https://github.com/hoenigpeter/scope.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-based category-level object pose estimation (SCOPE) uses continuous semantic priors from DINOv2 to generalize to unknown objects, achieving SOTA results and enabling unseen-object grasping.
AI.motivation: Robots in open environments must estimate poses for unknown objects; discrete category labels prevent robust generalization across known and unknown categories.
AI.method: A diffusion-based model that injects continuous semantic priors from DINOv2 via cross-attention, combined with photorealistic training data and a noise model for point normals, to learn canonicalized object coordinate systems across instances beyond known categories.
AI.result: Outperforms current state of the art in synthetic category-level pose estimation with a 31.9% relative improvement on the 5°5cm metric; two instance-level datasets show generalization to unseen categories with grasping success up to 100%.
AI.conclusion: Continuous semantic priors enable generalization beyond labeled categories; code is released for reproducibility.

title: Neural network embeddings recover value dimensions from psychometric survey items on par with human data
summary:
This study introduces "Survey and Questionnaire Item Embeddings
Differentials" (SQuID), a novel methodological approach that enables neural
network embeddings to effectively recover latent dimensions from psychometric
survey items. We demonstrate that embeddings derived from large language
models, when processed with SQuID, can recover the structure of human values
obtained from human rater judgments on the Revised Portrait Value Questionnaire
(PVQ-RR). Our experimental validation compares multiple embedding models across
a number of evaluation metrics. Unlike previous approaches, SQuID successfully
addresses the challenge of obtaining negative correlations between dimensions
without requiring domain-specific fine-tuning. Quantitative analysis reveals
that our embedding-based approach explains 55% of variance in
dimension-dimension similarities compared to human data. Multidimensional
scaling configurations from both types of data show fair factor congruence
coefficients and largely follow the underlying theory. These results
demonstrate that semantic embeddings can effectively replicate psychometric
structures previously established through extensive human surveys. The approach
offers substantial advantages in cost, scalability and flexibility while
maintaining comparable quality to traditional methods. Our findings have
significant implications for psychometrics and social science research,
providing a complementary methodology that could expand the scope of human
behavior and experience represented in measurement tools.

AI.tldr: SQuID uses neural embeddings to recover latent psychometric dimensions from survey items, showing that large-language-model embeddings can replicate PVQ-RR structure without fine-tuning, with competitive validity and scalability.
AI.motivation: Address the need for scalable, cost-effective psychometric measurement by deriving latent dimensions from item embeddings, and overcome the challenge of negative correlations and domain-specific fine-tuning.
AI.method: Process neural embeddings of survey items through the SQuID framework, compare multiple embedding models, and evaluate against human rater judgments on PVQ-RR using variance explained in dimension-dimension similarities and multidimensional scaling/factor congruence analyses.
AI.result: Embedding-based approach explains 55% of variance in dimension–dimension similarities relative to human data; MD Scaling configurations show fair factor congruence and align with theory, indicating embeddings can replicate established psychometric structures.
AI.conclusion: Semantic embeddings via SQuID offer a cost-effective, scalable complement to traditional psychometrics that can reproduce core latent structures without extensive domain-specific tuning.

title: Beyond Greedy Exits: Improved Early Exit Decisions for Risk Control and Reliability
summary:
Early-Exit Deep Neural Networks enable adaptive inference by allowing
prediction at intermediary layers, significantly reducing computational costs
and latency. Most of the early exit strategies greedily exit a sample at an
intermediary layer if the confidence in class prediction exceeds a predefined
threshold that is set using a static validation set. This is problematic as the
model might be overconfident in a wrong class. Also, they are not robust to
distribution shifts encountered in deployment, which can undermine model
trustworthiness and accuracy. To address these challenges, we propose UAT that
adapts the threshold for exit decisions using a Multi-Armed Bandit framework,
enabling online, unsupervised adjustment of exit decisions. UAT makes decisions
based on a new reward function that assesses predictive certainty and its
reliability to balance computational efficiency and prediction quality while
penalizing unnecessary late exits. We provide guarantees on risk achieved by
UAT and validate its performance on diverse tasks spanning vision-language
understanding, text generation, and classification. Our framework demonstrates
consistent improvements in speedup (1.70-2.10x) with a minimal performance drop
(<2%) as compared to full model performance. Our source code is available at
https://github.com/Div290/UAT.

AI.tldr: Proposes UAT, an online, unsupervised threshold adaptation for early-exit DNNs via a Multi-Armed Bandit framework, achieving 1.7–2.1x speedups with ≤2% accuracy loss and robustness to distribution shifts.
AI.motivation: Early-exit DNNs use static confidence thresholds, which can cause overconfident wrong exits and are brittle to distribution shifts encountered during deployment; there is a need for online, unsupervised adaptation of exit decisions.
AI.method: Frame exit decisions as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem and introduce a reward function that balances predictive certainty and reliability, penalizes late exits, and provides theoretical risk guarantees; perform online adaptation of thresholds without supervision; validate across diverse tasks: vision-language understanding, text generation, and classification.
AI.result: UAT achieves consistent speedups in the range of 1.70–2.10x with minimal performance drop (<2%) compared to full-model performance; demonstrates robustness to distribution shifts across tasks; source code available at provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: UAT offers a general, online adaptive mechanism for early-exit decisions in DNNs, improving computational efficiency while maintaining accuracy and robustness, with theoretical guarantees and cross-domain validation.

title: DiffInk: Glyph- and Style-Aware Latent Diffusion Transformer for Text to Online Handwriting Generation
summary:
Deep generative models have advanced text-to-online handwriting generation
(TOHG), which aims to synthesize realistic pen trajectories conditioned on
textual input and style references. However, most existing methods still
primarily focus on character- or word-level generation, resulting in
inefficiency and a lack of holistic structural modeling when applied to full
text lines. To address these issues, we propose DiffInk, the first latent
diffusion Transformer framework for full-line handwriting generation. We first
introduce InkVAE, a novel sequential variational autoencoder enhanced with two
complementary latent-space regularization losses: (1) an OCR-based loss
enforcing glyph-level accuracy, and (2) a style-classification loss preserving
writing style. This dual regularization yields a semantically structured latent
space where character content and writer styles are effectively disentangled.
We then introduce InkDiT, a novel latent diffusion Transformer that integrates
target text and reference styles to generate coherent pen trajectories.
Experimental results demonstrate that DiffInk outperforms existing
state-of-the-art methods in both glyph accuracy and style fidelity, while
significantly improving generation efficiency. Code will be made publicly
available.

AI.tldr: DiffInk is the first latent diffusion Transformer framework for full-line handwriting generation, combining InkVAE with dual latent-space regularization (OCR-based glyph accuracy and style-classification) and InkDiT latent diffusion to generate coherent pen trajectories conditioned on text and style. It achieves better glyph accuracy, style fidelity, and efficiency than prior methods; code will be released.
AI.motivation: To enable efficient, holistic full-line handwriting generation by addressing inefficiencies and lack of structural modeling in character/word-level methods, and to disentangle content (glyphs) from writer style in a structured latent space.
AI.method: InkVAE: a sequential variational autoencoder with two regularization losses—OCR-based glyph accuracy and style-classification—to structure latent space and disentangle content and style. InkDiT: a latent diffusion Transformer that conditions on target text and reference styles to produce coherent pen trajectories for full lines.
AI.result: DiffInk outperforms state-of-the-art methods in glyph accuracy and style fidelity and offers significantly improved generation efficiency for full-line handwriting generation.
AI.conclusion: DiffInk provides a novel, efficient, and semantically structured approach for full-line handwriting generation, enabling better content-style disentanglement and coherent line-level synthesis; code will be publicly released.

title: Discrete Variational Autoencoding via Policy Search
summary:
Discrete latent bottlenecks in variational autoencoders (VAEs) offer high bit
efficiency and can be modeled with autoregressive discrete distributions,
enabling parameter-efficient multimodal search with transformers. However,
discrete random variables do not allow for exact differentiable
parameterization; therefore, discrete VAEs typically rely on approximations,
such as Gumbel-Softmax reparameterization or straight-through gradient
estimates, or employ high-variance gradient-free methods such as REINFORCE that
have had limited success on high-dimensional tasks such as image
reconstruction. Inspired by popular techniques in policy search, we propose a
training framework for discrete VAEs that leverages the natural gradient of a
non-parametric encoder to update the parametric encoder without requiring
reparameterization. Our method, combined with automatic step size adaptation
and a transformer-based encoder, scales to challenging datasets such as
ImageNet and outperforms both approximate reparameterization methods and
quantization-based discrete autoencoders in reconstructing high-dimensional
data from compact latent spaces, achieving a 20% improvement on FID Score for
ImageNet 256.

AI.tldr: A training framework for discrete VAEs that uses the natural gradient of a non-parametric encoder to update a parametric encoder without reparameterization, aided by automatic step-size adaptation and a transformer-based encoder, enabling scalable high-dimensional reconstructions and outperforming prior discrete-autoencoder methods on ImageNet 256 (≈20% FID improvement).
AI.motivation: Discrete latent bottlenecks are efficient and can be captured with autoregressive discrete distributions, but exact differentiability is blocked by discrete variables. Standard remedies (Gumbel-Softmax, straight-through, or REINFORCE) struggle on high-dimensional tasks like image reconstruction. A differentiable, scalable approach is needed to train discrete VAEs without reparameterization.
AI.method: Train a parametric encoder using the natural gradient of a non-parametric encoder, avoiding reparameterization. Incorporate automatic step-size adaptation and a transformer-based encoder to handle high-dimensional data and scalability. The framework draws inspiration from policy-search techniques.
AI.result: The method scales to challenging datasets such as ImageNet and outperforms both approximate reparameterization methods and quantization-based discrete autoencoders in reconstructing high-dimensional data from compact latent spaces, achieving a 20% improvement on FID Score for ImageNet 256.
AI.conclusion: A non-parametric-to-parametric natural-gradient training framework for discrete VAEs is effective at scaling to ImageNet and achieving superior reconstruction quality with discrete latent bottlenecks, addressing differentiability and optimization challenges inherent to discrete representations.

title: Meta-Learning Theory-Informed Inductive Biases using Deep Kernel Gaussian Processes
summary:
Normative and task-driven theories offer powerful top-down explanations for
biological systems, yet the goals of quantitatively arbitrating between
competing theories, and utilizing them as inductive biases to improve
data-driven fits of real biological datasets are prohibitively laborious, and
often impossible. To this end, we introduce a Bayesian meta-learning framework
designed to automatically convert raw functional predictions from normative
theories into tractable probabilistic models. We employ adaptive deep kernel
Gaussian processes, meta-learning a kernel on synthetic data generated from a
normative theory. This Theory-Informed Kernel specifies a probabilistic model
representing the theory predictions -- usable for both fitting data and
rigorously validating the theory. As a demonstration, we apply our framework to
the early visual system, using efficient coding as our normative theory. We
show improved response prediction accuracy in ex vivo recordings of mouse
retinal ganglion cells stimulated by natural scenes compared to conventional
data-driven baselines, while providing well-calibrated uncertainty estimates
and interpretable representations. Using exact Bayesian model selection, we
also show that our informed kernel can accurately infer the degree of
theory-match from data, confirming faithful encapsulation of theory structure.
This work provides a more general, scalable, and automated approach for
integrating theoretical knowledge into data-driven scientific inquiry in
neuroscience and beyond.

AI.tldr: A Bayesian meta-learning framework converts normative theory predictions into probabilistic models using adaptive deep kernel Gaussian processes, enabling automatic theory-data integration and model selection in neuroscience.
AI.motivation: To address the laborious and often impractical task of quantitatively arbitraing between competing normative theories and using them as inductive biases to improve data-driven fits in biology. The work aims to provide an automated, scalable framework that safely injects theory structure into data analysis and validation.
AI.method: Meta-learn a kernel on synthetic data generated by a normative theory using adaptive deep kernel Gaussian processes. Build a Theory-Informed Kernel that encapsulates the theory's predictions and uncertainties. Apply to early visual system with efficient coding as normative theory, fitting to ex vivo mouse retinal ganglion cell data and using exact Bayesian model selection to assess theory-match.
AI.result: The framework yields improved response prediction accuracy over conventional data-driven baselines, with well-calibrated uncertainty estimates and interpretable representations. Exact Bayesian model selection indicates the kernel accurately infers the degree of theory-match from data, confirming faithful encapsulation of theory structure.
AI.conclusion: A general, scalable, and automated approach for integrating theoretical knowledge into data-driven scientific inquiry in neuroscience and beyond, enabling better predictions, uncertainty quantification, and principled theory validation.

title: Why Alignment Must Precede Distillation: A Minimal Working Explanation
summary:
For efficiency, preference alignment is often performed on compact,
knowledge-distilled (KD) models. We argue this common practice introduces a
significant limitation by overlooking a key property of the alignment's
reference model: its distributional recall. We show that the standard KD ->
Align workflow diminishes the model's capacity to align rare yet desirable
behaviors, even under strong preference signals. We instead demonstrate that
reversing the pipeline (i.e., Align -> KD) is essential: alignment must first
be performed on a high-recall reference before distillation. Our contributions
are threefold. First, we provide a minimal working explanation of how the
reference model constrains preference alignment objectives at a fundamental
level. Second, we validate this theory in a controllable Mixture-of-Gaussians
experiment, where low-recall anchoring consistently results in suboptimal model
performance. Finally, we demonstrate that the same phenomenon holds in LLM
alignment with the SmolLM2 family: models aligned after KD fail to effectively
align target behaviors, resulting in substantially lower reward and target
precision. In contrast, our proposed Align -> KD pipeline robustly aligns these
behaviors, yielding models with superior target-oriented metrics and lower
variance. Together, these results establish reference-model recall as a
first-order design choice in alignment, offering a clear principle: alignment
must precede distillation.

AI.tldr: Argues for Align -> KD over KD -> Align in LLM alignment, stressing the reference model's distributional recall. Shows KD->Align harms retrieval of rare but desirable behaviors; demonstrates Align->KD yields higher reward/precision and lower variance in Mixture-of-Gaussians and SmolLM2 alignment; advocates alignment before distillation as a first-order design choice.
AI.motivation: Current practice distills the alignment signal from a high-recall reference, but the role of the reference's recall in steering alignment objectives is underexplored. The work aims to reveal a fundamental limitation and to advocate a pipeline that preserves recall before distillation.
AI.method: Provide a minimal theoretical explanation of how a reference model constrains alignment objectives; validate via a controllable Mixture-of-Gaussians experiment; empirically compare Align->KD versus KD->Align on SmolLM2-based LLM alignment, using reward and target precision metrics.
AI.result: Across both synthetic and real-model experiments, Align->KD yields superior target-oriented performance with higher rewards, better precision, and lower variance; KD->Align struggles to align rare desirable behaviors even with strong preference signals.
AI.conclusion: Distributional recall of the reference model is a first-order design choice in alignment. Alignment should precede distillation (Align->KD) to robustly attain target behaviors across tasks and models.

title: RIV: Recursive Introspection Mask Diffusion Vision Language Model
summary:
Mask Diffusion-based Vision Language Models (MDVLMs) have achieved remarkable
progress in multimodal understanding tasks. However, these models are unable to
correct errors in generated tokens, meaning they lack self-correction
capability. In this paper, we propose Recursive Introspection Mask Diffusion
Vision Language Model (RIV), which equips the model with self-correction
ability through two novel mechanisms. The first is Introspection Training,
where an Introspection Model is introduced to identify errors within generated
sequences. Introspection Training enables the model to detect not only
grammatical and spelling mistakes, but more importantly, logical errors. The
second is Recursive Inference. Beginning with the standard unmasking step, the
learned Introspection Model helps to identify errors in the output sequence and
remask them. This alternating
($\text{unmask}\rightarrow\text{introspection}\rightarrow\text{remask}$)
process is repeated recursively until reliable results are obtained.
Experimental results on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed RIV
achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming most existing MDVLMs.

AI.tldr: RIV introduces self-correction in Mask Diffusion Vision-Language Models via introspection training and recursive inference, achieving state-of-the-art results on multimodal benchmarks.
AI.motivation: MDVLMs currently cannot self-correct generated tokens, leading to uncorrected errors (including logical mistakes). A self-correcting mechanism is needed for more reliable multimodal generation.
AI.method: Two components: (1) Introspection Training: train an Introspection Model to detect errors in generated sequences, including grammatical, spelling, and notably logical inconsistencies. (2) Recursive Inference: after an unmask step, use the introspection model to identify errors, remask them, and repeat the unmask/introspection/remask loop until outputs stabilize.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on multiple benchmarks shows RIV achieves state-of-the-art performance, surpassing most existing MDVLMs.
AI.conclusion: Introducing self-correction via introspection and recursion enhances reliability and performance of MDVLMs, with potential implications for broader sequence generation tasks.

title: Evaluation of Polarimetric Fusion for Semantic Segmentation in Aquatic Environments
summary:
Accurate segmentation of floating debris on water is often compromised by
surface glare and changing outdoor illumination. Polarimetric imaging offers a
single-sensor route to mitigate water-surface glare that disrupts semantic
segmentation of floating objects. We benchmark state-of-the-art fusion networks
on PoTATO, a public dataset of polarimetric images of plastic bottles in inland
waterways, and compare their performance with single-image baselines using
traditional models. Our results indicate that polarimetric cues help recover
low-contrast objects and suppress reflection-induced false positives, raising
mean IoU and lowering contour error relative to RGB inputs. These sharper masks
come at a cost: the additional channels enlarge the models increasing the
computational load and introducing the risk of new false positives. By
providing a reproducible, diagnostic benchmark and publicly available code, we
hope to help researchers choose if polarized cameras are suitable for their
applications and to accelerate related research.

AI.tldr: Polarimetric imaging improves segmentation of floating debris, boosting mean IoU and reducing contour errors vs RGB, but increases model size and risk of new false positives; a reproducible PoTATO benchmark is provided to guide researchers in using polarized cameras.
AI.motivation: Water surfaces suffer from glare and changing illumination, degrading semantic segmentation. Polarimetric cues offer a single-sensor approach to mitigate glare, but there is a need for standardized benchmarks comparing fusion networks and baselines.
AI.method: Benchmark state-of-the-art fusion networks on PoTATO, a public polarimetric dataset of plastic bottles in inland waterways, and compare their performance with single-image baselines using traditional models; evaluate improvements in IoU and contour accuracy; provide reproducible benchmark and publicly available code.
AI.result: Polarimetric cues help recover low-contrast objects and suppress reflection-induced false positives, increasing mean IoU and lowering contour error relative to RGB inputs; the added polarization channels enlarge models, increasing computational load and risk of new false positives.
AI.conclusion: Polarimetric cameras are a promising approach for robust floating-object segmentation; the provided benchmark and code enable researchers to assess applicability and accelerate related research.

title: MASLegalBench: Benchmarking Multi-Agent Systems in Deductive Legal Reasoning
summary:
Multi-agent systems (MAS), leveraging the remarkable capabilities of Large
Language Models (LLMs), show great potential in addressing complex tasks. In
this context, integrating MAS with legal tasks is a crucial step. While
previous studies have developed legal benchmarks for LLM agents, none are
specifically designed to consider the unique advantages of MAS, such as task
decomposition, agent specialization, and flexible training. In fact, the lack
of evaluation methods limits the potential of MAS in the legal domain. To
address this gap, we propose MASLegalBench, a legal benchmark tailored for MAS
and designed with a deductive reasoning approach. Our benchmark uses GDPR as
the application scenario, encompassing extensive background knowledge and
covering complex reasoning processes that effectively reflect the intricacies
of real-world legal situations. Furthermore, we manually design various
role-based MAS and conduct extensive experiments using different
state-of-the-art LLMs. Our results highlight the strengths, limitations, and
potential areas for improvement of existing models and MAS architectures.

AI.tldr: MASLegalBench is a GDPR-based benchmark for evaluating multi-agent LLM systems in legal tasks, highlighting how MAS advantages like task decomposition, agent specialization, and flexible training can be leveraged, using role-based agents and deductive reasoning across multiple LLMs, with insights on model strengths and gaps.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of evaluation tools tailored to multi-agent systems (MAS) in the legal domain. Existing legal benchmarks focus on single-agent LLMs and do not adequately assess MAS-specific benefits such as task decomposition, specialization, and flexible training. A dedicated MAS-specific benchmark is needed to guide development and reveal strengths, limitations, and improvement opportunities for MAS architectures in real-world legal reasoning.
AI.method: The authors design MASLegalBench, a GDPR-based legal benchmark with extensive background knowledge and complex deductive reasoning tasks. They create various role-based MAS configurations and conduct extensive experiments using state-of-the-art LLMs to evaluate how MAS approaches perform on legal reasoning, knowledge integration, and task coordination.
AI.result: Empirical results highlight the strengths and limitations of current models and MAS architectures in handling legal tasks. The evaluation demonstrates where MAS-based approaches excel (e.g., in decomposition and specialization) and where improvements are needed (e.g., training, coordination, and long-horizon reasoning).
AI.conclusion: MASLegalBench provides a focused evaluation framework to study MAS in the legal domain, revealing promising directions and remaining challenges. It reflects the value of MAS for legal tasks while guiding future work on benchmark design, evaluation metrics, and agent coordination strategies.

title: Multi-Scale Spatial-Temporal Hypergraph Network with Lead-Lag Structures for Stock Time Series Forecasting
summary:
Time series forecasting occurs in a range of financial applications providing
essential decision-making support to investors, regulatory institutions, and
analysts. Unlike multivariate time series from other domains, stock time series
exhibit industry correlation. Exploiting this kind of correlation can improve
forecasting accuracy. However, existing methods based on hypergraphs can only
capture industry correlation relatively superficially. These methods face two
key limitations: they do not fully consider inter-industry lead-lag
interactions, and they do not model multi-scale information within and among
industries. This study proposes the Hermes framework for stock time series
forecasting that aims to improve the exploitation of industry correlation by
eliminating these limitations. The framework integrates moving aggregation and
multi-scale fusion modules in a hypergraph network. Specifically, to more
flexibly capture the lead-lag relationships among industries, Hermes proposes a
hyperedge-based moving aggregation module. This module incorporates a sliding
window and utilizes dynamic temporal aggregation operations to consider
lead-lag dependencies among industries. Additionally, to effectively model
multi-scale information, Hermes employs cross-scale, edge-to-edge message
passing to integrate information from different scales while maintaining the
consistency of each scale. Experimental results on multiple real-world stock
datasets show that Hermes outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in both
efficiency and accuracy.

AI.tldr: Hermes extends hypergraph-based stock forecasting with a moving aggregation and cross-scale edge-to-edge message passing to better capture lead-lag inter-industry relationships and multi-scale information, achieving better efficiency and accuracy.
AI.motivation: Stock time series exhibit industry correlations; existing hypergraph methods inadequately model lead-lag interactions and multi-scale information, limiting forecasting performance.
AI.method: Introduce a hyperedge-based moving aggregation module using sliding windows to capture lead-lag dependencies, and cross-scale, edge-to-edge message passing to fuse information across scales while preserving scale-wise consistency.
AI.result: Empirical results on real-world stock datasets show Hermes outperforms state-of-the-art methods in accuracy and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Hermes is a promising framework for leveraging inter-industry correlations in stock forecasting, addressing key limitations of prior hypergraph approaches.

title: Efficient Domain-Adaptive Multi-Task Dense Prediction with Vision Foundation Models
summary:
Multi-task dense prediction, which aims to jointly solve tasks like semantic
segmentation and depth estimation, is crucial for robotics applications but
suffers from domain shift when deploying models in new environments. While
unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) addresses this challenge for single tasks,
existing multi-task UDA methods primarily rely on adversarial learning
approaches that are less effective than recent self-training techniques. In
this paper, we introduce FAMDA, a simple yet effective UDA framework that
bridges this gap by leveraging Vision Foundation Models (VFMs) as powerful
teachers. Our approach integrates Segmentation and Depth foundation models into
a self-training paradigm to generate high-quality pseudo-labels for the target
domain, effectively distilling their robust generalization capabilities into a
single, efficient student network. Extensive experiments show that FAMDA
achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance on standard synthetic-to-real UDA
multi-task learning (MTL) benchmarks and a challenging new day-to-night
adaptation task. Our framework enables the training of highly efficient models;
a lightweight variant achieves SOTA accuracy while being more than 10$\times$
smaller than foundation models, highlighting FAMDA's suitability for creating
domain-adaptive and efficient models for resource-constrained robotics
applications.

AI.tldr: FAMDA uses Vision Foundation Models as teachers in a self-training UDA framework for multi-task dense prediction (semantic segmentation and depth) to produce high-quality pseudo-labels in the target domain, distilling robust generalization into a lightweight student network.
AI.motivation: Domain shift in multi-task dense prediction for robotics is a problem; existing UDA methods rely on adversarial learning and underperform compared to self-training. Leveraging powerful VFMs as teachers could provide robust pseudo-labels for better generalization.
AI.method: Integrate segmentation and depth foundation models as teachers within a self-training loop. Generate pseudo-labels for the target domain via these teachers, then train a single student network to distill their capabilities. Also present a lightweight variant.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on synthetic-to-real UDA multi-task learning benchmarks and a day-to-night adaptation task. A lightweight variant attains SOTA accuracy while being more than 10× smaller than foundation models, showing strong efficiency for resource-constrained robotics.
AI.conclusion: FAMDA bridges the gap between multi-task UDA and self-training by using VFMs as teachers to produce high-quality pseudo-labels, enabling efficient, domain-adaptive models suitable for robotics applications.

title: ThermalGen: Style-Disentangled Flow-Based Generative Models for RGB-to-Thermal Image Translation
comment:
23 pages including the checklist and appendix. Accepted at NeurIPS
  2025
summary:
Paired RGB-thermal data is crucial for visual-thermal sensor fusion and
cross-modality tasks, including important applications such as multi-modal
image alignment and retrieval. However, the scarcity of synchronized and
calibrated RGB-thermal image pairs presents a major obstacle to progress in
these areas. To overcome this challenge, RGB-to-Thermal (RGB-T) image
translation has emerged as a promising solution, enabling the synthesis of
thermal images from abundant RGB datasets for training purposes. In this study,
we propose ThermalGen, an adaptive flow-based generative model for RGB-T image
translation, incorporating an RGB image conditioning architecture and a
style-disentangled mechanism. To support large-scale training, we curated eight
public satellite-aerial, aerial, and ground RGB-T paired datasets, and
introduced three new large-scale satellite-aerial RGB-T datasets--DJI-day,
Bosonplus-day, and Bosonplus-night--captured across diverse times, sensor
types, and geographic regions. Extensive evaluations across multiple RGB-T
benchmarks demonstrate that ThermalGen achieves comparable or superior
translation performance compared to existing GAN-based and diffusion-based
methods. To our knowledge, ThermalGen is the first RGB-T image translation
model capable of synthesizing thermal images that reflect significant
variations in viewpoints, sensor characteristics, and environmental conditions.
Project page: http://xjh19971.github.io/ThermalGen

AI.tldr: ThermalGen is an adaptive flow-based RGB-to-Thermal image translation model with RGB conditioning and style disentanglement, trained on eight large RGB-T datasets (including three new satellite-aerial collections), achieving competitive or superior translation quality to GAN and diffusion methods and capable of handling large viewpoint and sensor variations.
AI.motivation: Overcoming the lack of synchronized RGB-thermal pairs for visual-thermal fusion and cross-modality tasks, by synthesizing thermal images from abundant RGB data to enable training and evaluation.
AI.method: An adaptive flow-based generator conditioned on RGB inputs with a style-disentangled mechanism. The authors curated eight RGB-T paired datasets and introduced three large-scale satellite-aerial RGB-T datasets (DJI-day, Bosonplus-day, Bosonplus-night). They evaluate against GAN-based and diffusion-based methods across multiple benchmarks.
AI.result: ThermalGen achieves comparable or superior translation performance to existing GAN-based and diffusion-based methods across RGB-T benchmarks. It is reportedly the first RGB-T translation model capable of synthesizing thermal images with significant variations in viewpoints, sensor characteristics, and environmental conditions.
AI.conclusion: ThermalGen advances RGB-T image translation by combining adaptive flow-based generation, RGB conditioning, and style disentanglement, enabled by large-scale, diverse RGB-T datasets; this broadens the applicability of RGB-to-thermal translation for cross-modality tasks and real-world scenarios.

title: When Autonomous Vehicle Meets V2X Cooperative Perception: How Far Are We?
comment:
The paper has been accepted by the 40th IEEE/ACM International
  Conference on Automated Software Engineering, ASE 2025
summary:
With the tremendous advancement of deep learning and communication
technology, Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) cooperative perception has the
potential to address limitations in sensing distant objects and occlusion for a
single-agent perception system. V2X cooperative perception systems are software
systems characterized by diverse sensor types and cooperative agents, varying
fusion schemes, and operation under different communication conditions.
Therefore, their complex composition gives rise to numerous operational
challenges. Furthermore, when cooperative perception systems produce erroneous
predictions, the types of errors and their underlying causes remain
insufficiently explored. To bridge this gap, we take an initial step by
conducting an empirical study of V2X cooperative perception. To systematically
evaluate the impact of cooperative perception on the ego vehicle's perception
performance, we identify and analyze six prevalent error patterns in
cooperative perception systems. We further conduct a systematic evaluation of
the critical components of these systems through our large-scale study and
identify the following key findings: (1) The LiDAR-based cooperation
configuration exhibits the highest perception performance; (2)
Vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) and vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication
exhibit distinct cooperative perception performance under different fusion
schemes; (3) Increased cooperative perception errors may result in a higher
frequency of driving violations; (4) Cooperative perception systems are not
robust against communication interference when running online. Our results
reveal potential risks and vulnerabilities in critical components of
cooperative perception systems. We hope that our findings can better promote
the design and repair of cooperative perception systems.

AI.tldr: Empirical study of V2X cooperative perception identifying six error patterns and key vulnerabilities; LiDAR-based fusion performs best; V2I vs V2V depend on fusion scheme; more cooperative errors can increase driving violations; online systems are sensitive to interference.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of understanding of error types and their causes in V2X cooperative perception and quantify their impact on ego-perception and driving safety.
AI.method: Large-scale empirical study analyzing six prevalent error patterns in V2X cooperative perception, evaluating critical components across different fusion schemes and communication conditions, to assess impact on ego perception and driving behavior.
AI.result: LiDAR-based cooperation configuration yields the highest perception performance. V2I and V2V have distinct performance profiles under different fusion schemes. More cooperative errors may lead to higher driving-violation frequency. Cooperative perception systems are not robust to communication interference when running online.
AI.conclusion: Highlights risks and vulnerabilities in key components of cooperative perception systems and provides guidance for their design, evaluation, and repair.

title: Graph Neural Networks with Diversity-aware Neighbor Selection and Dynamic Multi-scale Fusion for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
summary:
Recently, numerous deep models have been proposed to enhance the performance
of multivariate time series (MTS) forecasting. Among them, Graph Neural
Networks (GNNs)-based methods have shown great potential due to their
capability to explicitly model inter-variable dependencies. However, these
methods often overlook the diversity of information among neighbors, which may
lead to redundant information aggregation. In addition, their final prediction
typically relies solely on the representation from a single temporal scale. To
tackle these issues, we propose a Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with
Diversity-aware Neighbor Selection and Dynamic Multi-scale Fusion (DIMIGNN).
DIMIGNN introduces a Diversity-aware Neighbor Selection Mechanism (DNSM) to
