ensure that each variable shares high informational similarity with its
neighbors while maintaining diversity among neighbors themselves. Furthermore,
a Dynamic Multi-Scale Fusion Module (DMFM) is introduced to dynamically adjust
the contributions of prediction results from different temporal scales to the
final forecasting result. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets
demonstrate that DIMIGNN consistently outperforms prior methods.

AI.tldr: DIMIGNN introduces diversity-aware neighbor selection and dynamic multi-scale fusion to improve multivariate time series forecasting, addressing neighbor redundancy and single-scale aggregation, and shows consistent improvements over prior methods.
AI.motivation: GNN-based MTS models often aggregate from neighbors with limited diversity, leading to redundant information, and rely on a single temporal scale for prediction. There is a need to exploit diverse neighbor information and multiple temporal scales.
AI.method: Proposes a Diversity-aware Neighbor Selection Mechanism (DNSM) to ensure high similarity with neighbors while preserving diversity among them, and a Dynamic Multi-Scale Fusion Module (DMFM) to adaptively fuse predictions from multiple temporal scales. Integrated into a GNN framework and trained end-to-end on real-world datasets.
AI.result: DIMIGNN consistently outperforms prior methods on real-world datasets.
AI.conclusion: DNSM and DMFM effectively address neighbor diversity and multi-scale fusion limitations, yielding improved forecasting performance in MTS tasks.

title: MotionVerse: A Unified Multimodal Framework for Motion Comprehension, Generation and Editing
summary:
This paper proposes MotionVerse, a unified framework that harnesses the
capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) to comprehend, generate, and edit
human motion in both single-person and multi-person scenarios. To efficiently
represent motion data, we employ a motion tokenizer with residual quantization,
which converts continuous motion sequences into multi-stream discrete tokens.
Furthermore, we introduce a \textit{Delay Parallel} Modeling strategy, which
temporally staggers the encoding of residual token streams. This design enables
LLMs to effectively capture inter-stream dependencies while maintaining
computational efficiency comparable to single-stream modeling. Moreover, to
alleviate modality interference between motion and language, we design a
\textit{dual-tower architecture} with modality-specific parameters, ensuring
stable integration of motion information for both comprehension and generation
tasks. Comprehensive ablation studies demonstrate the effectiveness of each
component in MotionVerse, and extensive experiments showcase its superior
performance across a wide range of motion-relevant tasks.

AI.tldr: MotionVerse is a unified LLM-based framework that converts motion into discrete tokens via residual quantization, uses delay-parallel encoding and a dual-tower architecture to enable efficient, multi-person motion understanding and generation with strong empirical results.
AI.motivation: To extend the capabilities of LLMs to comprehensively understand, generate, and edit human motion, addressing efficient motion representation, inter-stream dependencies, and modality interference between motion and language.
AI.method: Introduce a motion tokenizer with residual quantization to map continuous motion into multi-stream discrete tokens; apply Delay Parallel Modeling to temporally stagger residual token streams for inter-stream dependency capture with single-stream efficiency; implement a dual-tower architecture with modality-specific parameters to stabilize fusion of motion and language; validate via ablations and extensive experiments.
AI.result: Ablation studies confirm the usefulness of each component; MotionVerse achieves superior performance across diverse motion-related tasks while maintaining computational efficiency close to single-stream modeling; demonstrates effective inter-stream dependency capture and robust single/multi-person handling.
AI.conclusion: MotionVerse provides a unified, scalable approach for LLM-enabled motion understanding and generation in single- and multi-person scenarios, with modular components that deliver performance gains and stable multimodal integration.

title: KIRETT -- A wearable device to support rescue operations using artificial intelligence to improve first aid
comment:
Conference Paper for 2022 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference
  (ISC2), KIRETT Project, University of Siegen, Germany
summary:
This short paper presents first steps in the scientific part of the KIRETT
project, which aims to improve first aid during rescue operations using a
wearable device. The wearable is used for computer-aided situation recognition
by means of artificial intelligence. It provides contextual recommendations for
actions and operations to rescue personnel and is intended to minimize damage
to patients due to incorrect treatment, as well as increase the probability of
survival. The paper describes a first overview of research approaches within
the project.

AI.tldr: A short paper introducing the KIRETT project and its wearable AI-assisted system for situation recognition to aid first aid during rescue operations; provides an initial overview of research approaches within the project.
AI.motivation: To improve effectiveness of on-scene first aid, reduce harm from incorrect treatment, and increase patient survival by providing context-aware recommendations to rescuers through a wearable device.
AI.method: Describes a wearable device enabling computer-aided situation recognition via artificial intelligence and generating contextual action recommendations; presents an initial overview of the research approaches integrated in the KIRETT project (no experimental results reported).
AI.result: No empirical results are reported; the paper provides a high-level overview of the project and the first research directions.
AI.conclusion: The KIRETT project aims to enhance rescue operations with wearable AI-assisted decision support; this short paper establishes the foundational research directions and outlines how the technology could improve patient outcomes.

title: Towards a Comprehensive Scaling Law of Mixture-of-Experts
summary:
Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models have become the consensus approach for
enabling parameter-efficient scaling and cost-effective deployment in large
language models. However, existing scaling laws for dense models are
inapplicable to MoE models, which stems from three critical challenges: the
multiplicity of influencing factors, their intricate coupling relationships and
the non-monotonic nature of their performance impacts. They collectively
necessitate a fine-grained investigation into MoE-specific scaling laws. In
this work, we perform a systematic decomposition of MoE settings, identifying
five key factors that influence model performance from both size and structural
perspectives (data size ($D$), total model size ($N$), activated model size
($N_a$), number of active experts ($G$) and the ratio of shared experts ($S$)).
Specifically, we design $446$ controlled experiments to characterize their
marginal effects, ultimately constructing a comprehensive and precise joint MoE
scaling law that considers all essential factors. Furthermore, we derive the
theoretically optimal and practically efficiency-aware optimal configurations
for $G$, $S$ and $N_a/N$ with detailed analyses. Our results demonstrate that
the optimal settings for $G$ and $S$ are independent of both the model
architecture and data size. With the scaling of $N$, the optimal activation
parameter ratio of $N_a/N$ becomes sparser. Our proposed MoE scaling law could
function as an accurate and insightful guidance to facilitate future MoE model
design and training.

AI.tldr: A systematic MoE-specific scaling law via 446 experiments uncovering how data size D, total model size N, activated size Na, active experts G, and shared-expert ratio S interact; derives optimal configurations and independence results, guiding efficient MoE design.
AI.motivation: Dense-model scaling laws do not transfer to MoE models due to multiple influencing factors, their coupling, and non-monotonic effects; there is a need for a fine-grained MoE-specific scaling framework.
AI.method: Decompose MoE settings into five factors (D, N, Na, G, S); conduct 446 controlled experiments to characterize marginal effects; construct a joint MoE scaling law; derive theoretically optimal and practically efficiency-aware configurations for G, S, and Na/N; analyze independence and sparsity patterns.
AI.result: A comprehensive MoE scaling law is obtained that accounts for all five factors; optimal G and S are independent of model architecture and data size; as N grows, the optimal Na/N ratio becomes sparser; provides guidance for MoE design and training.
AI.conclusion: The proposed MoE scaling law offers accurate, actionable guidance for future MoE model design and training, enabling more efficient scaling and deployment.

title: LightFair: Towards an Efficient Alternative for Fair T2I Diffusion via Debiasing Pre-trained Text Encoders
summary:
This paper explores a novel lightweight approach LightFair to achieve fair
text-to-image diffusion models (T2I DMs) by addressing the adverse effects of
the text encoder. Most existing methods either couple different parts of the
diffusion model for full-parameter training or rely on auxiliary networks for
correction. They incur heavy training or sampling burden and unsatisfactory
performance. Since T2I DMs consist of multiple components, with the text
encoder being the most fine-tunable and front-end module, this paper focuses on
mitigating bias by fine-tuning text embeddings. To validate feasibility, we
observe that the text encoder's neutral embedding output shows substantial
skewness across image embeddings of various attributes in the CLIP space. More
importantly, the noise prediction network further amplifies this imbalance. To
finetune the text embedding, we propose a collaborative distance-constrained
debiasing strategy that balances embedding distances to improve fairness
without auxiliary references. However, mitigating bias can compromise the
original generation quality. To address this, we introduce a two-stage
text-guided sampling strategy to limit when the debiased text encoder
intervenes. Extensive experiments demonstrate that LightFair is effective and
efficient. Notably, on Stable Diffusion v1.5, our method achieves SOTA
debiasing at just $1/4$ of the training burden, with virtually no increase in
sampling burden. The code is available at https://github.com/boyuh/LightFair.

AI.tldr: LightFair debiases text-to-image diffusion models by fine-tuning the text encoder with a collaborative distance-constrained strategy and a two-stage sampling method, delivering SOTA debiasing with 1/4 training burden and minimal sampling overhead.
AI.motivation: Mitigate bias originating from the text encoder that skews CLIP-space embeddings and is amplified by the noise predictor, without heavy retraining.
AI.method: Collaborative distance-constrained debiasing to adjust text embeddings; two-stage text-guided sampling to restrict intervention; evaluation on Stable Diffusion v1.5; no auxiliary references.
AI.result: Achieves SOTA debiasing at 1/4 training burden; virtually no increase in sampling burden; code released.
AI.conclusion: Efficiently improves fairness in T2I DMs by targeting the text encoder, balancing parameter efficiency and generation quality.

title: Fast Feature Field ($\text{F}^3$): A Predictive Representation of Events
summary:
This paper develops a mathematical argument and algorithms for building
representations of data from event-based cameras, that we call Fast Feature
Field ($\text{F}^3$). We learn this representation by predicting future events
from past events and show that it preserves scene structure and motion
information. $\text{F}^3$ exploits the sparsity of event data and is robust to
noise and variations in event rates. It can be computed efficiently using ideas
from multi-resolution hash encoding and deep sets - achieving 120 Hz at HD and
440 Hz at VGA resolutions. $\text{F}^3$ represents events within a contiguous
spatiotemporal volume as a multi-channel image, enabling a range of downstream
tasks. We obtain state-of-the-art performance on optical flow estimation,
semantic segmentation, and monocular metric depth estimation, on data from
three robotic platforms (a car, a quadruped robot and a flying platform),
across different lighting conditions (daytime, nighttime), environments
(indoors, outdoors, urban, as well as off-road) and dynamic vision sensors
(resolutions and event rates). Our implementations can predict these tasks at
25-75 Hz at HD resolution.

AI.tldr: A fast, sparse spatiotemporal representation for event cameras (F^3) learned by predicting future events, enabling state-of-the-art optical flow, semantic segmentation, and monocular depth estimation across varied platforms.
AI.motivation: Event cameras produce highly sparse, high-rate data that are difficult to process with traditional frames-based methods. There is a need for a robust, efficient representation that preserves scene structure and motion and is resilient to noise and varying event rates for real-time downstream tasks.
AI.method: Learn F^3 by predicting future events from past events to shape the representation. It uses multi-resolution hash encoding and deep sets to construct a contiguous spatiotemporal volume represented as a multi-channel image, exploiting sparsity for efficiency. The approach runs at 25–75 Hz at HD, with capable rates (120 Hz at HD and 440 Hz at VGA) for construction, and is validated on tasks including optical flow, semantic segmentation, and monocular depth estimation across diverse platforms and conditions.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on optical flow, semantic segmentation, and monocular metric depth estimation across three robotic platforms (car, quadruped, flying platform) under varied lighting, environments, and sensor configurations; maintains robustness to motion and noise, and supports real-time inference.
AI.conclusion: F^3 provides a scalable, robust, and efficient representation for event data by coupling predictive learning with multi-resolution hashing and deep set techniques, enabling high-rate inference and broad applicability to multiple vision tasks across platforms.

title: Agentic Exploration of Physics Models
summary:
The process of scientific discovery relies on an interplay of observations,
analysis, and hypothesis generation. Machine learning is increasingly being
adopted to address individual aspects of this process. However, it remains an
open challenge to fully automate the open-ended, heuristic, iterative loop
required to discover the laws of an unknown system by exploring it through
experiments and analysis, without tailoring the approach to the specifics of a
given task. Here, we introduce SciExplorer, an agent that leverages large
language model tool-use capabilities to enable free-form exploration of systems
without any domain-specific blueprints, and apply it to the exploration of
physical systems that are initially unknown to the agent. We test SciExplorer
on a broad set of models spanning mechanical dynamical systems, wave evolution,
and quantum many-body physics. Despite using a minimal set of tools, primarily
based on code execution, we observe impressive performance on tasks such as
recovering equations of motion from observed dynamics and inferring
Hamiltonians from expectation values. The demonstrated effectiveness of this
setup opens the door towards similar scientific exploration in other domains,
without the need for finetuning or task-specific instructions.

AI.tldr: An LLM-driven agent (SciExplorer) uses tool-use to autonomously explore unknown physical systems and infer underlying laws (e.g., equations of motion, Hamiltonians) with minimal tooling; demonstrates domain-agnostic scientific exploration without task-specific tuning.
AI.motivation: To automate the open-ended loop of discovery—observations, analysis, hypothesis generation—in a domain-agnostic way, without task-specific blueprints or fine-tuning.
AI.method: Introduce SciExplorer, an agent leveraging large language model tool-use to perform free-form exploration with a minimal toolset (primarily code execution) on unknown physical systems (mechanics, waves, quantum many-body).
AI.result: Recovered equations of motion from dynamics; inferred Hamiltonians from expectation values; performed across diverse model classes; shows strong performance with minimal tooling.
AI.conclusion: This demonstrates the feasibility of domain-agnostic, self-guided scientific exploration and suggests potential extension to other domains without finetuning; could generalize to broader AI-assisted discovery.

title: Decentralized Dynamic Cooperation of Personalized Models for Federated Continual Learning
summary:
Federated continual learning (FCL) has garnered increasing attention for its
ability to support distributed computation in environments with evolving data
distributions. However, the emergence of new tasks introduces both temporal and
cross-client shifts, making catastrophic forgetting a critical challenge. Most
existing works aggregate knowledge from clients into a global model, which may
not enhance client performance since irrelevant knowledge could introduce
interference, especially in heterogeneous scenarios. Additionally, directly
applying decentralized approaches to FCL suffers from ineffective group
formation caused by task changes. To address these challenges, we propose a
decentralized dynamic cooperation framework for FCL, where clients establish
dynamic cooperative learning coalitions to balance the acquisition of new
knowledge and the retention of prior learning, thereby obtaining personalized
models. To maximize model performance, each client engages in selective
cooperation, dynamically allying with others who offer meaningful performance
gains. This results in non-overlapping, variable coalitions at each stage of
the task. Moreover, we use coalitional affinity game to simulate coalition
relationships between clients. By assessing both client gradient coherence and
model similarity, we quantify the client benefits derived from cooperation. We
also propose a merge-blocking algorithm and a dynamic cooperative evolution
algorithm to achieve cooperative and dynamic equilibrium. Comprehensive
experiments demonstrate the superiority of our method compared to various
baselines. Code is available at: https://github.com/ydn3229/DCFCL.

AI.tldr: We present a decentralized dynamic cooperation framework for federated continual learning that forms adaptive, non-overlapping coalitions, guided by a coalitional affinity game, to personalize models and mitigate forgetting, with a merge-blocking and dynamic evolution algorithm; experiments show superior performance over baselines.
AI.motivation: To address catastrophic forgetting and non-stationary data distributions in federated continual learning, especially under heterogeneity, where global aggregation or static decentralization can hurt client performance.
AI.method: Introduce dynamic, task-stage coalitions enabling selective cooperation among clients; non-overlapping coalitions form and evolve per task stage; use a coalitional affinity game to model relationships; quantify cooperation benefits via client gradient coherence and model similarity; propose a merge-blocking algorithm and a dynamic cooperative evolution algorithm to reach cooperative dynamic equilibrium.
AI.result: Comprehensive experiments demonstrate superiority over various baselines; code is released.
AI.conclusion: The framework enables personalized, effective decentralized FCL by balancing acquisition of new knowledge with retention of prior learning through dynamic cooperation.

title: EfficientMIL: Efficient Linear-Complexity MIL Method for WSI Classification
summary:
Whole slide images (WSIs) classification represents a fundamental challenge
in computational pathology, where multiple instance learning (MIL) has emerged
as the dominant paradigm. Current state-of-the-art (SOTA) MIL methods rely on
attention mechanisms, achieving good performance but requiring substantial
computational resources due to quadratic complexity when processing hundreds of
thousands of patches. To address this computational bottleneck, we introduce
EfficientMIL, a novel linear-complexity MIL approach for WSIs classification
with the patches selection module Adaptive Patch Selector (APS) that we
designed, replacing the quadratic-complexity self-attention mechanisms in
Transformer-based MIL methods with efficient sequence models including
RNN-based GRU, LSTM, and State Space Model (SSM) Mamba. EfficientMIL achieves
significant computational efficiency improvements while outperforming other MIL
methods across multiple histopathology datasets. On TCGA-Lung dataset,
EfficientMIL-Mamba achieved AUC of 0.976 and accuracy of 0.933, while on
CAMELYON16 dataset, EfficientMIL-GRU achieved AUC of 0.990 and accuracy of
0.975, surpassing previous state-of-the-art methods. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that APS is also more effective for patches selection than
conventional selection strategies.

AI.tldr: EfficientMIL introduces a linear-complexity MIL for WSIs with Adaptive Patch Selector, replacing self-attention with lightweight sequence models, achieving state-of-the-art results with improved efficiency.
AI.motivation: Current MIL in computational pathology relies on attention with quadratic complexity, making large WSIs computationally expensive. A scalable approach is needed.
AI.method: Replace quadratic attention with linear-sequence models (GRU, LSTM, SSM Mamba) in a MIL framework, guided by an Adaptive Patch Selector to pick informative patches.
AI.result: Significant computational efficiency gains and superior performance on TCGA-Lung (EfficientMIL-Mamba: AUC 0.976, acc 0.933) and CAMELYON16 (EfficientMIL-GRU: AUC 0.990, acc 0.975) surpassing prior methods; APS enhances patch selection.
AI.conclusion: EfficientMIL demonstrates that linear-complexity MIL with effective patch selection can outperform existing attention-based MIL methods in WSIs classification and substantially reduce resource usage.

title: CLPO: Curriculum Learning meets Policy Optimization for LLM Reasoning
summary:
Recently, online Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has
become a key paradigm for enhancing the reasoning capabilities of Large
Language Models (LLMs). However, existing methods typically treat all training
samples uniformly, overlooking the vast differences in problem difficulty
relative to the model's current capabilities. This uniform training strategy
leads to inefficient exploration of problems the model has already mastered,
while concurrently lacking effective guidance on problems that are challenging
its abilities the most, limiting both learning efficiency and upper-bound
performance. To address this, we propose CLPO (Curriculum-guided Learning for
Policy Optimization), a novel algorithm that creates a dynamic pedagogical
feedback loop within the policy optimization process. The core of CLPO
leverages the model's own rollout performance to conduct real-time difficulty
assessment, thereby constructing an Online Curriculum. This curriculum then
guides an Adaptive Problem Restructuring mechanism, where the model acts as its
own teacher: it diversifies medium-difficulty problems to promote
generalization and simplifies challenging problems to make them more
attainable. Our approach transforms the static training procedure into a
dynamic process that co-evolves with the model's capabilities. Experiments show
that CLPO achieves state-of-the-art performance across eight challenging
mathematical and general reasoning benchmarks, with an average pass@1
improvement of 6.96% over other methods, demonstrating its potential for more
efficiently training more capable reasoning models.

AI.tldr: CLPO introduces a curriculum-guided approach to policy optimization in online RL with verifiable rewards (RLVR) for LLM reasoning. It uses the model’s own rollout performance to build an Online Curriculum and an Adaptive Problem Restructuring loop, enabling the model to self-teach by diversifying medium-difficulty problems and simplifying hard ones. This dynamic co-evolution yields strong performance gains.
AI.motivation: Existing RLVR training treats all samples uniformly, causing inefficient exploration of mastered problems and insufficient guidance on tasks that are too difficult for the current model, limiting learning efficiency and upper-bound performance.
AI.method: CLPO constructs an Online Curriculum from real-time difficulty assessments based on the model's rollout performance, then applies Adaptive Problem Restructuring where the model acts as its own teacher to diversify medium-difficulty problems to promote generalization and simplify challenging problems to make them attainable.
AI.result: CLPO achieves state-of-the-art performance across eight challenging mathematical and general reasoning benchmarks, with an average pass@1 improvement of 6.96% over competing methods.
AI.conclusion: By co-evolving the curriculum with the model’s capabilities, CLPO improves learning efficiency and upper-bound reasoning performance, demonstrating potential for training more capable reasoning models.

title: Hedonic Neurons: A Mechanistic Mapping of Latent Coalitions in Transformer MLPs
summary:
Fine-tuned Large Language Models (LLMs) encode rich task-specific features,
but the form of these representations, especially within MLP layers, remains
unclear. Empirical inspection of LoRA updates shows that new features
concentrate in mid-layer MLPs, yet the scale of these layers obscures
meaningful structure. Prior probing suggests that statistical priors may
strengthen, split, or vanish across depth, motivating the need to study how
neurons work together rather than in isolation.
  We introduce a mechanistic interpretability framework based on coalitional
game theory, where neurons mimic agents in a hedonic game whose preferences
capture their synergistic contributions to layer-local computations. Using
top-responsive utilities and the PAC-Top-Cover algorithm, we extract stable
coalitions of neurons: groups whose joint ablation has non-additive effects. We
then track their transitions across layers as persistence, splitting, merging,
or disappearance.
  Applied to LLaMA, Mistral, and Pythia rerankers fine-tuned on scalar IR
tasks, our method finds coalitions with consistently higher synergy than
clustering baselines. By revealing how neurons cooperate to encode features,
hedonic coalitions uncover higher-order structure beyond disentanglement and
yield computational units that are functionally important, interpretable, and
predictive across domains.

AI.tldr: Mech interpretability of fine-tuned LLMs via hedonic coalitional game theory; extract stable neuron coalitions with non-additive synergy across layers, showing higher synergy than clustering and yielding interpretable, predictive units across LLaMA, Mistral, and Pythia rerankers.
AI.motivation: Unclear form of task-specific representations in mid-layer MLPs; prior probing suggests priors may strengthen/split/vanish with depth; need to study neuron cooperation rather than isolation to understand feature encoding.
AI.method: Model neurons as agents in a hedonic game with preferences capturing synergistic contributions to layer-local computations. Use top-responsive utilities and PAC-Top-Cover to extract stable coalitions (groups whose ablation effects are non-additive). Track coalition dynamics across layers as persistence, splitting, merging, or disappearance.
AI.result: Coalitions exhibit consistently higher synergy than clustering baselines. They reveal higher-order cooperative structure beyond disentanglement and yield functionally important, interpretable, and predictive units across domains on LLaMA, Mistral, and Pythia rerankers trained on scalar IR tasks.
AI.conclusion: Hedonic coalitions provide a principled, interpretable unit of computation in fine-tuned LLMs by capturing cooperative neuron interactions, enabling robust understanding of how features are encoded and propagated across layers.

title: Scaling Synthetic Task Generation for Agents via Exploration
summary:
Post-Training Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to build interactive
agents holds promise across domains such as computer-use, web navigation, and
robotics. A key challenge in scaling such post-training is lack of high-quality
downstream agentic task datasets with tasks that are diverse, feasible, and
verifiable. Existing approaches for task generation rely heavily on human
annotation or prompting MLLM with limited downstream environment information,
which is either costly or poorly scalable as it yield tasks with limited
coverage. To remedy this, we present AutoPlay, a scalable pipeline for task
generation that explicitly explores interactive environments to discover
possible interactions and current state information to synthesize
environment-grounded tasks. AutoPlay operates in two stages: (i) an exploration
phase, where an MLLM explorer agent systematically uncovers novel environment
states and functionalities, and (ii) a task generation phase, where a task
generator leverages exploration trajectories and a set of task guideline
prompts as context to synthesize diverse, executable, and verifiable tasks. We
show AutoPlay generates 20k tasks across 20 Android applications and 10k tasks
across 13 applications Ubuntu applications to train mobile-use and computer-use
agents. AutoPlay generated tasks enable large-scale task demonstration
synthesis without human annotation by employing an MLLM task executor and
verifier. This data enables training MLLM-based UI agents that improve success
rates up to $20.0\%$ on mobile-use and $10.9\%$ on computer-use scenarios. In
addition, AutoPlay generated tasks combined with MLLM verifier-based rewards
enable scaling reinforcement learning training of UI agents, leading to an
additional $5.7\%$ gain. coverage. These results establish AutoPlay as a
scalable approach for post-training capable MLLM agents reducing reliance on
human annotation.

AI.tldr: AutoPlay is a scalable two-stage pipeline that explores interactive environments to generate thousands of environment-grounded, executable tasks for post-training Multimodal LLMs, reducing annotation needs and boosting UI agent performance and RL training.
AI.motivation: There is a shortage of high-quality, diverse, down-stream agentic task datasets for post-training MLLMs. Current task-generation methods rely on costly human annotation or limited environment information, limiting coverage and scalability.
AI.method: A two-stage pipeline: (i) exploration by an MLLM explorer to uncover new environment states and functionalities; (ii) task generation where a generator uses exploration trajectories and task-guideline prompts to synthesize diverse, executable, and verifiable tasks grounded in environment data. Tasks are validated by an MLLM task executor and verifier, enabling demonstrations and RL rewards without human annotation.
AI.result: AutoPlay produced about 20k tasks across 20 Android apps and 10k tasks across 13 Ubuntu applications, enabling training of mobile-use and computer-use agents. Task demonstrations and verifier-based rewards improved success rates by up to 20.0% (mobile) and 10.9% (computer), with an additional 5.7% gain from RL training using verifier-based rewards.
AI.conclusion: AutoPlay offers a scalable solution for post-training capable MLLMs, reducing reliance on human annotation by automatically generating environment-grounded tasks and supporting improved agent performance and scalable RL training.

title: FedDAPL: Toward Client-Private Generalization in Federated Learning
summary:
Federated Learning (FL) trains models locally at each research center or
clinic and aggregates only model updates, making it a natural fit for medical
imaging, where strict privacy laws forbid raw data sharing. A major obstacle is
scanner-induced domain shift: non-biological variations in hardware or
acquisition protocols can cause models to fail on external sites. Most
harmonization methods correct this shift by directly comparing data across
sites, conflicting with FL's privacy constraints. Domain Generalization (DG)
offers a privacy-friendly alternative - learning site-invariant representations
without sharing raw data - but standard DG pipelines still assume centralized
access to multi-site data, again violating FL's guarantees. This paper meets
these difficulties with a straightforward integration of a Domain-Adversarial
Neural Network (DANN) within the FL process. After demonstrating that a naive
federated DANN fails to converge, we propose a proximal regularization method
that stabilizes adversarial training among clients. Experiments on T1-weighted
3-D brain MRIs from the OpenBHB dataset, performing brain-age prediction on
participants aged 6-64 y (mean 22+/-6 y; 45 percent male) in training and 6-79
y (mean 19+/-13 y; 55 percent male) in validation, show that training on 15
sites and testing on 19 unseen sites yields superior cross-site generalization
over FedAvg and ERM while preserving data privacy.

AI.tldr: Federated Domain-Adversarial Training with proximal regularization improves cross-site generalization for medical imaging under privacy constraints, outperforming FedAvg and ERM while preserving data privacy.
AI.motivation: Privacy-preserving domain generalization in medical imaging FL is needed due to scanner-induced domain shifts and data-sharing restrictions; existing DG approaches assume centralized data, which FL forbids.
AI.method: Integrates a Domain-Adversarial Neural Network (DANN) into federated learning and adds proximal regularization to stabilize adversarial training across clients; evaluated on 3D T1-weighted brain MRIs from OpenBHB with cross-site setup (15 training sites, 19 unseen test sites).
AI.result: The federated DANN with proximal stabilization achieves superior cross-site generalization compared to FedAvg and ERM on unseen sites while maintaining data privacy.
AI.conclusion: A privacy-friendly DG approach for FL in medical imaging is feasible: federated DANN with proximal regularization yields better generalization across sites without sharing raw data.

title: Griffin: Generative Reference and Layout Guided Image Composition
summary:
Text-to-image models have achieved a level of realism that enables the
generation of highly convincing images. However, text-based control can be a
limiting factor when more explicit guidance is needed. Defining both the
content and its precise placement within an image is crucial for achieving
finer control. In this work, we address the challenge of multi-image layout
control, where the desired content is specified through images rather than
text, and the model is guided on where to place each element. Our approach is
training-free, requires a single image per reference, and provides explicit and
simple control for object and part-level composition. We demonstrate its
effectiveness across various image composition tasks.

AI.tldr: Training-free multi-image layout control for text-to-image models using a single reference image to guide object and part placement.
AI.motivation: Text-only prompts can be insufficient for explicit content and precise placement; there is a need for content-and-layout control that doesn’t require retraining or many examples.
AI.method: A training-free approach that uses a single reference image to specify content and its placement, enabling explicit object- and part-level composition during generation.
AI.result: The method demonstrates effectiveness across a range of image composition tasks.
AI.conclusion: Offers a simple, training-free solution for multi-image layout control that enables fine-grained composition in text-to-image generation.

title: Cogito, Ergo Ludo: An Agent that Learns to Play by Reasoning and Planning
summary:
The pursuit of artificial agents that can learn to master complex
environments has led to remarkable successes, yet prevailing deep reinforcement
learning methods often rely on immense experience, encoding their knowledge
opaquely within neural network weights. We propose a different paradigm, one in
which an agent learns to play by reasoning and planning. We introduce Cogito,
ergo ludo (CEL), a novel agent architecture that leverages a Large Language
Model (LLM) to build an explicit, language-based understanding of its
environment's mechanics and its own strategy. Starting from a tabula rasa state
with no prior knowledge (except action set), CEL operates on a cycle of
interaction and reflection. After each episode, the agent analyzes its complete
trajectory to perform two concurrent learning processes: Rule Induction, where
it refines its explicit model of the environment's dynamics, and Strategy and
Playbook Summarization, where it distills experiences into an actionable
strategic playbook. We evaluate CEL on diverse grid-world tasks (i.e.,
Minesweeper, Frozen Lake, and Sokoban), and show that the CEL agent
successfully learns to master these games by autonomously discovering their
rules and developing effective policies from sparse rewards. Ablation studies
confirm that the iterative process is critical for sustained learning. Our work
demonstrates a path toward more general and interpretable agents that not only
act effectively but also build a transparent and improving model of their world
through explicit reasoning on raw experience.

AI.tldr: CEL presents a planning-based agent that uses an LLM to build an explicit, language-based model of the environment and its strategy, refining rules and distilling a playbook after each episode; it learns grid-world games from scratch with sparse rewards, showing interpretability and performance gains.
AI.motivation: To overcome reliance on opaque neural weights and data-hungry DRL by introducing explicit reasoning and transparent world models, enabling agents to learn via reflective planning.
AI.method: An LLM-powered agent, CEL, interacts with the environment, then after each episode performs Rule Induction to refine the environment dynamics model and Strategy/Playbook Summarization to create a practical playbook, all within a tabula rasa starting point.
AI.result: In Minesweeper, Frozen Lake, Sokoban, CEL masters games, discovering rules and developing effective policies; ablation studies show the iterative reflection-learning loop is essential for sustained gains.
AI.conclusion: This work demonstrates a path toward general, interpretable agents that not only act well but also build explicit, improving world models through reasoning on raw experience.

title: Merge Now, Regret Later: The Hidden Cost of Model Merging is Adversarial Transferability
summary:
Model Merging (MM) has emerged as a promising alternative to multi-task
learning, where multiple fine-tuned models are combined, without access to
tasks' training data, into a single model that maintains performance across
tasks. Recent works have explored the impact of MM on adversarial attacks,
particularly backdoor attacks. However, none of them have sufficiently explored
its impact on transfer attacks using adversarial examples, i.e., a black-box
adversarial attack where examples generated for a surrogate model successfully
mislead a target model.
  In this work, we study the effect of MM on the transferability of adversarial
examples. We perform comprehensive evaluations and statistical analysis
consisting of 8 MM methods, 7 datasets, and 6 attack methods, sweeping over 336
distinct attack settings. Through it, we first challenge the prevailing notion
of MM conferring free adversarial robustness, and show MM cannot reliably
defend against transfer attacks, with over 95% relative transfer attack success
rate. Moreover, we reveal 3 key insights for machine-learning practitioners
regarding MM and transferability for a robust system design: (1) stronger MM
methods increase vulnerability to transfer attacks; (2) mitigating
representation bias increases vulnerability to transfer attacks; and (3) weight
averaging, despite being the weakest MM method, is the most vulnerable MM
method to transfer attacks. Finally, we analyze the underlying reasons for this
increased vulnerability, and provide potential solutions to the problem. Our
findings offer critical insights for designing more secure systems employing
MM.

AI.tldr: Model merging does not provide robust defense against transfer adversarial attacks; across 336 settings, transfer success remains high, with weight averaging being especially vulnerable.
AI.motivation: Evaluate how model merging affects the transferability of adversarial examples and provide guidance for designing secure MM-based systems.
AI.method: Empirical study spanning 8 MM methods, 7 datasets, and 6 attack methods (336 attack settings), with statistical analyses.
AI.result: MM cannot reliably defend against transfer attacks; observed relative transfer attack success rates exceed 95% in many settings. Three key insights: (1) stronger MM methods increase vulnerability to transfer attacks; (2) mitigating representation bias increases vulnerability; (3) weight averaging, though the weakest MM method, is the most vulnerable to transfer attacks. Analysis of underlying causes and potential remedies.
AI.conclusion: These results highlight the need for secure MM design and evaluation against transfer attacks, including strategies to mitigate representation bias and to reassess the security implications of stronger MM techniques.

title: Sparse-Up: Learnable Sparse Upsampling for 3D Generation with High-Fidelity Textures
summary:
The creation of high-fidelity 3D assets is often hindered by a 'pixel-level
pain point': the loss of high-frequency details. Existing methods often trade
off one aspect for another: either sacrificing cross-view consistency,
resulting in torn or drifting textures, or remaining trapped by the resolution
ceiling of explicit voxels, forfeiting fine texture detail. In this work, we
propose Sparse-Up, a memory-efficient, high-fidelity texture modeling framework
that effectively preserves high-frequency details. We use sparse voxels to
guide texture reconstruction and ensure multi-view consistency, while
leveraging surface anchoring and view-domain partitioning to break through
resolution constraints. Surface anchoring employs a learnable upsampling
strategy to constrain voxels to the mesh surface, eliminating over 70% of
redundant voxels present in traditional voxel upsampling. View-domain
partitioning introduces an image patch-guided voxel partitioning scheme,
supervising and back-propagating gradients only on visible local patches.
Through these two strategies, we can significantly reduce memory consumption
during high-resolution voxel training without sacrificing geometric
consistency, while preserving high-frequency details in textures.

AI.tldr: Sparse-Up is a memory-efficient framework for high-fidelity texture modeling using sparse voxels, surface-anchored upsampling, and view-domain patch partitioning to preserve high-frequency textures while maintaining multi-view consistency under reduced memory usage.
AI.motivation: High-fidelity 3D asset creation suffers from loss of high-frequency texture details. Existing methods trade spatial resolution or cross-view consistency, leading to torn textures or limited texture detail. There is a need to preserve fine textures at high resolution without prohibitive memory costs.
AI.method: 1) Surface anchoring with a learnable upsampling strategy constrains voxels to the mesh surface, eliminating over 70% of redundant voxels compared to conventional voxel upsampling. 2) View-domain partitioning uses image patch-guided voxel partitioning, supervising and back-propagating gradients only on visible local patches, reducing unnecessary computation on occluded or unseen areas.
AI.result: The approach significantly reduces memory consumption during high-resolution voxel training while preserving geometric consistency and maintaining high-frequency texture details. The surface anchoring and patch-based supervision together enable efficient, detailed texture modeling without sacrificing cross-view coherence.
AI.conclusion: Sparse-Up demonstrates a practical path toward memory-efficient, high-fidelity texture modeling by combining surface-constrained upsampling with patch-guided, view-aware training, enabling high-resolution textures on complex geometries with reduced resource demands.

title: HeDA: An Intelligent Agent System for Heatwave Risk Discovery through Automated Knowledge Graph Construction and Multi-layer Risk Propagation Analysis
summary:
Heatwaves pose complex cascading risks across interconnected climate, social,
and economic systems, but knowledge fragmentation in scientific literature
hinders comprehensive understanding of these risk pathways. We introduce HeDA
(Heatwave Discovery Agent), an intelligent multi-agent system designed for
automated scientific discovery through knowledge graph construction and
multi-layer risk propagation analysis. HeDA processes over 10,247 academic
papers to construct a comprehensive knowledge graph with 23,156 nodes and
89,472 relationships, employing novel multi-layer risk propagation analysis to
systematically identify overlooked risk transmission pathways. Our system
achieves 78.9% accuracy on complex question-answering tasks, outperforming
state-of-the-art baselines including GPT-4 by 13.7%. Critically, HeDA
successfully discovered five previously unidentified high-impact risk chains,
such as the pathway where a heatwave leads to a water demand surge, resulting
in industrial water restrictions and ultimately causing small business
disruption, which were validated through historical case studies and domain
expert review. This work presents a new paradigm for AI-driven scientific
discovery, providing actionable insights for developing more resilient climate
adaptation strategies.

AI.tldr: HeDA is an intelligent multi-agent system that builds a large knowledge graph from 10k+ heatwave papers to uncover overlooked risk pathways and validate them, achieving high QA accuracy and identifying five high-impact risk chains.
AI.motivation: Fragmentation in climate-risk literature hinders integrated understanding of heatwave cascading risks; a unified discovery framework is needed.
AI.method: Developed HeDA, a multi-agent system that processes 10,247 papers to build a knowledge graph (23,156 nodes, 89,472 relationships) and applies multi-layer risk propagation analysis; evaluated on complex QA tasks against baselines including GPT-4; validated findings with historical case studies and domain experts.
AI.result: 78.9% accuracy on complex QA, 13.7% improvement over GPT-4 and other baselines; discovered five previously unidentified high-impact risk chains, validated historically and via domain review.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a new paradigm for AI-driven scientific discovery in climate risk, offering actionable insights to strengthen resilience and adaptation strategies.

title: Estimating Time Series Foundation Model Transferability via In-Context Learning
summary:
Time series foundation models (TSFMs) offer strong zero-shot forecasting via
large-scale pre-training, yet fine-tuning remains critical for boosting
performance in domains with limited public data. With the growing number of
TSFMs, efficiently identifying the best model for downstream fine-tuning
becomes increasingly challenging. In this work, we introduce TimeTic, a
transferability estimation framework that recasts model selection as an
in-context-learning problem: given observations on known (source) datasets, it
predicts how a TSFM will perform after fine-tuning on a downstream (target)
dataset. TimeTic flexibly organizes the observed model-data relationships as
contextual information, allowing it to adapt seamlessly to various test-time
scenarios. Leveraging the natural tabular structure formed by dataset
meta-features, model characteristics, and fine-tuned performance, we employ
tabular foundation models to serve as in-context learners. We further introduce
a novel model characterization based on entropy evolution across model layers,
capturing embedding-space distinctions and enabling TimeTic to generalize
across arbitrary model sets. We establish a comprehensive benchmark for
transferability estimation including 10 datasets, 10 foundation models, and 3
forecasting tasks. On this benchmark, TimeTic's estimation demonstrates strong
alignment with actual fine-tuned performance for previously unseen datasets,
achieving a mean rank correlation of approximately 0.6 and a 30% improvement
compared to using zero-shot performance as the transferability score.

AI.tldr: TimeTic reframes model selection for time-series foundation models as in-context learning, using tabular meta-features and an entropy-based model-characterization to estimate transfer performance after fine-tuning. It achieves ~0.6 mean rank correlation on unseen data and ~30% gains over zero-shot transfer scores.
AI.motivation: As TSFMs proliferate, fine-tuning data is scarce; selecting the best model for downstream tasks is crucial but challenging. Existing zero-shot scores are not reliably predictive for fine-tuned performance across diverse datasets; there is a need for a flexible transferability estimator that generalizes across models and test-time scenarios.
AI.method: Construct a transferability estimator (TimeTic) that treats model selection as in-context learning, using context built from dataset meta-features, model traits, and observed fine-tuned performance. Utilizes tabular foundation models as in-context learners and a novel entropy-evolution-based metric to characterize model embeddings across layers, enabling generalization to new model sets. Evaluates on a benchmark of 10 datasets, 10 TSFMs, and 3 forecasting tasks.
AI.result: TimeTic's estimates align with actual fine-tuned performance on unseen datasets, achieving a mean rank correlation of about 0.6 and a 30% improvement compared to relying on zero-shot performance as the transferability score.
AI.conclusion: TimeTic provides a flexible, generalizable transferability estimator for TSFMs, improving model selection for downstream fine-tuning, with entropy-based characterizations enabling better generalization across diverse model families.

title: From $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ to $f(g(x))$: LLMs Learn New Skills in RL by Composing Old Ones
summary:
Does RL teach LLMs genuinely new skills, or does it merely activate existing
ones? This question lies at the core of ongoing debates about the role of RL in
LLM post-training. On one side, strong empirical results can be achieved with
RL even without preceding supervised finetuning; on the other, critics argue
that RL contributes little beyond reweighting existing reasoning strategies.
This work provides concrete evidence that LLMs can acquire genuinely new skills
during RL by composing existing ones, mirroring one of the central mechanisms
by which humans acquire new cognitive skills. To mitigate data contamination
and other confounding factors, and to allow precise control over task
complexity, we develop a synthetic framework for our investigation.
Specifically, we define a skill as the ability to infer the output of a string
transformation function f(x) given x. When an LLM has already learned f and g
prior to RL, our experiments reveal that RL enables it to learn unseen
compositions of them h(x)=g(f(x)). Further, this compositional ability
generalizes to more difficult problems such as compositions of >2 functions
unseen during RL training. Surprisingly, our experiments show that
compositional skill acquired on a source task transfers to a different target
task. This transfer happens even without compositional training on the target,
requiring only prior knowledge of the target's atomic skills. Our qualitative
analysis shows that RL fundamentally changes the reasoning behaviors of the
models. In contrast, next-token training with the same data yields none of
these findings. Our systematic experiments provide fresh insights into LLM
learning, suggesting the value of first building base models with basic skills,
then using RL to incentivize advanced, generalizable skills for complex
problems.

AI.tldr: RL enables LLMs to acquire genuinely new compositional skills by combining learned functions, not just reweighting existing strategies; these skills generalize to longer compositions and transfer across tasks, while next-token training lacks these effects.
AI.motivation: Resolve whether reinforcement learning adds truly new capabilities to LLMs or merely reweights existing strategies; investigate generalization and transfer of compositional skills; mitigate data contamination with a synthetic framework.
AI.method: Define a skill as inferring the output of a string transformation f(x). Pretrain LLMs on f and g, then apply RL to incentivize learning h(x)=g(f(x)). Evaluate unseen compositions, extend to >2 functions, and test transfer to target tasks; compare with next-token training on the same data; analyze reasoning behavior qualitatively; use a synthetic, controlled setting to avoid contamination.
AI.result: RL enables learning unseen compositions of existing skills, including >2-function compositions; compositional skill learned on a source task transfers to a different target task without compositional training on the target; RL changes reasoning behaviors; next-token training yields none of these effects.
AI.conclusion: Build base models possessing basic skills first, then use RL to incentivize advanced, generalizable compositional skills for complex problems; RL can induce genuinely new abilities that generalize across tasks, unlike standard next-token training.

title: Bridging Discrete and Continuous RL: Stable Deterministic Policy Gradient with Martingale Characterization
summary:
The theory of discrete-time reinforcement learning (RL) has advanced rapidly
over the past decades. Although primarily designed for discrete environments,
many real-world RL applications are inherently continuous and complex. A major
challenge in extending discrete-time algorithms to continuous-time settings is
their sensitivity to time discretization, often leading to poor stability and
slow convergence. In this paper, we investigate deterministic policy gradient
methods for continuous-time RL. We derive a continuous-time policy gradient
formula based on an analogue of the advantage function and establish its
martingale characterization. This theoretical foundation leads to our proposed
algorithm, CT-DDPG, which enables stable learning with deterministic policies
in continuous-time environments. Numerical experiments show that the proposed
CT-DDPG algorithm offers improved stability and faster convergence compared to
existing discrete-time and continuous-time methods, across a wide range of
control tasks with varying time discretizations and noise levels.

AI.tldr: A continuous-time deterministic policy gradient method (CT-DDPG) built on a continuous-time policy gradient with a martingale property, yielding more stable learning and faster convergence in continuous-time RL across varying discretizations.
AI.motivation: Discrete-time RL methods struggle with time discretization when applied to continuous-time problems, causing instability and slow convergence. A principled continuous-time theory and algorithm for deterministic policies is needed.
AI.method: Derive a continuous-time policy gradient formula using an analogue of the advantage function and prove a martingale characterization; develop the CT-DDPG algorithm to learn deterministic policies in continuous-time environments.
AI.result: CT-DDPG demonstrates improved stability and faster convergence than existing discrete-time and some continuous-time methods across control tasks with different time steps and noise levels.
AI.conclusion: The work provides a solid theoretical foundation and a practical algorithm for stable, sample-efficient continuous-time RL with deterministic policies, addressing discretization sensitivity and enabling robust performance.

title: ReWatch-R1: Boosting Complex Video Reasoning in Large Vision-Language Models through Agentic Data Synthesis
summary:
While Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Reward (RLVR) significantly
advances image reasoning in Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs), its
application to complex video reasoning remains underdeveloped. This gap stems
primarily from a critical data bottleneck: existing datasets lack the
challenging, multi-hop questions and high-quality, video-grounded
Chain-of-Thought (CoT) data necessary to effectively bootstrap RLVR. To address
this, we introduce ReWatch, a large-scale dataset built to foster advanced
video reasoning. We propose a novel multi-stage synthesis pipeline to
synthesize its three components: ReWatch-Caption, ReWatch-QA, and ReWatch-CoT.
A core innovation is our Multi-Agent ReAct framework for CoT synthesis, which
simulates a human-like "re-watching" process to generate video-grounded
reasoning traces by explicitly modeling information retrieval and verification.
Building on this dataset, we develop ReWatch-R1 by post-training a strong
baseline LVLM with Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and our RLVR framework. This
framework incorporates a novel Observation \& Reasoning (O\&R) reward mechanism
that evaluates both the final answer's correctness and the reasoning's
alignment with video content, directly penalizing hallucination. Our
experiments show that ReWatch-R1 achieves state-of-the-art average performance
on five challenging video reasoning benchmarks.

AI.tldr: Proposes ReWatch, a large-scale video-reasoning dataset with three components (Caption, QA, CoT) and a Multi-Agent ReAct CoT synthesis framework to simulate re-watching. Builds ReWatch-R1 by SFT+RLVR with an Observation & Reasoning reward, achieving state-of-the-art on five video reasoning benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Video reasoning in LVLMs is impeded by data bottlenecks: lack of challenging multi-hop questions and high-quality, video-grounded CoT data to bootstrap RLVR. A high-quality dataset and training paradigm are needed to improve reasoning and reduce hallucinations.
AI.method: 1) Multi-stage synthesis to create ReWatch-Caption, ReWatch-QA, ReWatch-CoT. 2) Multi-Agent ReAct framework to generate video-grounded CoT traces by simulating a re-watching process with explicit information retrieval and verification. 3) After dataset, train a strong LVLM via Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and RLVR with an Observation & Reasoning (O&R) reward that evaluates final answer correctness and policy-aligned reasoning with video content to penalize hallucinations.
AI.result: ReWatch-R1 achieves state-of-the-art average performance on five challenging video reasoning benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The ReWatch dataset and the RLVR framework provide a scalable path to bolster video reasoning in LVLMs, addressing data scarcity and hallucination through explicit video-grounded CoT and reward shaping.

title: The Era of Real-World Human Interaction: RL from User Conversations
summary:
We posit that to achieve continual model improvement and multifaceted
alignment, future models must learn from natural human interaction. Current
conversational models are aligned using pre-annotated, expert-generated human
feedback. In this work, we introduce Reinforcement Learning from Human
Interaction (RLHI), a paradigm that learns directly from in-the-wild user
conversations. We develop two complementary methods: (1) RLHI with User-Guided
Rewrites, which revises unsatisfactory model outputs based on users'
natural-language follow-up responses, (2) RLHI with User-Based Rewards, which
learns via a reward model conditioned on knowledge of the user's long-term
interaction history (termed persona). Together, these methods link long-term
user personas to turn-level preferences via persona-conditioned preference
optimization. Trained on conversations derived from WildChat, both RLHI
variants outperform strong baselines in personalization and
instruction-following, and similar feedback enhances performance on reasoning
benchmarks. These results suggest organic human interaction offers scalable,
effective supervision for personalized alignment.

AI.tldr: RLHI introduces learning from in-the-wild human conversations with two methods: User-Guided Rewrites and User-Based Rewards to align models via persona-conditioned preferences; shows improvements on personalization, instruction-following, and reasoning benchmarks using WildChat.
AI.motivation: Current conversational agents rely on curated, expert-annotated feedback and fixed evaluation metrics, limiting continual improvement and multifaceted alignment. Real-world, long-term human interactions offer scalable supervision for personalized alignment.
AI.method: Two complementary approaches: (1) RLHI with User-Guided Rewrites, which revises outputs based on users' natural-language follow-ups; (2) RLHI with User-Based Rewards, which learns a reward model conditioned on the user's long-term interaction history (persona). Both link persona to turn-level preferences through persona-conditioned preference optimization.
AI.result: Both RLHI variants outperform strong baselines in personalization and instruction-following on datasets derived from WildChat; similar feedback also improves performance on reasoning benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Organic human interaction provides scalable, effective supervision for personalized alignment, and RLHI is a practical framework to leverage such data for continual model improvement.

title: FraudTransformer: Time-Aware GPT for Transaction Fraud Detection
summary:
Detecting payment fraud in real-world banking streams requires models that
can exploit both the order of events and the irregular time gaps between them.
We introduce FraudTransformer, a sequence model that augments a vanilla
GPT-style architecture with (i) a dedicated time encoder that embeds either
absolute timestamps or inter-event values, and (ii) a learned positional
encoder that preserves relative order. Experiments on a large industrial
dataset -- tens of millions of transactions and auxiliary events -- show that
FraudTransformer surpasses four strong classical baselines (Logistic
Regression, XGBoost and LightGBM) as well as transformer ablations that omit
either the time or positional component. On the held-out test set it delivers
the highest AUROC and PRAUC.

AI.tldr: FraudTransformer enhances GPT-like sequence models with a dedicated time encoder and a learned positional encoder to capture irregular event times and order in payment fraud streams, outperforming traditional ML baselines and transformer variants on a large real-world dataset.
AI.motivation: Detecting payment fraud in streaming data requires models that exploit both event order and irregular inter-event times; existing models struggle with time gaps and sequence structure, limiting real-world effectiveness.
AI.method: Introduce FraudTransformer, a GPT-style sequence model augmented with (1) a dedicated time encoder embedding absolute timestamps or inter-event times, and (2) a learned positional encoder preserving relative order. Trained/evaluated on tens of millions of transactions and auxiliary events, compared against four baselines (Logistic Regression, XGBoost, LightGBM) and transformer ablations missing time or positional components.
AI.result: On held-out test data, FraudTransformer achieves the highest AUROC and PRAUC, outperforming all baselines and ablated variants that omit either the time or positional component.
AI.conclusion: Time-aware, order-preserving sequence modeling is effective for real-world fraud detection in streaming banking data, with the approach likely generalizable to other sequential anomaly detection tasks and further improvable via richer time features and model refinements.

title: LLaVA-OneVision-1.5: Fully Open Framework for Democratized Multimodal Training
summary:
We present LLaVA-OneVision-1.5, a novel family of Large Multimodal Models
(LMMs) that achieve state-of-the-art performance with significantly reduced
computational and financial costs. Different from the existing works,
LLaVA-OneVision-1.5 provides an open, efficient, and reproducible framework for
building high-quality vision-language models entirely from scratch. The
LLaVA-OneVision-1.5 release comprises three primary components: (1) Large-Scale
Curated Datasets: We construct an 85M concept-balanced pretraining dataset
LLaVA-OneVision-1.5-Mid-Traning and a meticulously curated 26M instruction
dataset LLaVA-OneVision-1.5-Instruct, collectively encompassing 64B compressed
multimodal tokens. (2) Efficient Training Framework: We develop a complete
end-to-end efficient training framework leveraging an offline parallel data
packing strategy to facilitate the training of LLaVA-OneVision-1.5 within a
$16,000 budget. (3) State-of-the-art Performance: Experimental results
demonstrate that LLaVA-OneVision1.5 yields exceptionally competitive
performance across a broad range of downstream tasks. Specifically,
LLaVA-OneVision-1.5-8B outperforms Qwen2.5-VL-7B on 18 of 27 benchmarks, and
LLaVA-OneVision-1.5-4B surpasses Qwen2.5-VL-3B on all 27 benchmarks. We
anticipate releasing LLaVA-OneVision-1.5-RL shortly and encourage the community
to await further updates.

AI.tldr: LLaVA-OneVision-1.5 is an open, efficient family of Large Multimodal Models that achieves competitive state-of-the-art results at a fraction of typical training costs, using three components: (1) 85M concept-balanced pretraining data (Mid-Training) and 26M instruction data (Instruct) totaling 64B compressed multimodal tokens; (2) an efficient offline data packing training framework enabling training within a $16,000 budget; (3) strong performance across downstream tasks, with 8B model outperforming Qwen2.5-VL-7B on 18 of 27 benchmarks and 4B outperforming Qwen2.5-VL-3B on all 27 benchmarks, with a RL variant forthcoming.
AI.motivation: to reduce the computational and financial barriers to building high-quality vision-language models and to provide an open, reproducible, end-to-end framework for training LMMs from scratch.
AI.method: assemble three components: a large curated pretraining dataset (85M concept-balanced examples; Mid-Training) and a 26M instruction dataset (Instruct), totaling 64B compressed multimodal tokens; develop an offline parallel data packing training framework; train efficient LMMs (8B and 4B) within a $16k budget; evaluate on a broad benchmark suite of 27 tasks.
AI.result: achieves competitive state-of-the-art performance at reduced cost: 8B model beats Qwen2.5-VL-7B on 18/27 benchmarks; 4B model beats Qwen2.5-VL-3B on all 27 benchmarks; indicates meaningful cost-efficiency and strong transfer across tasks.
AI.conclusion: the framework enables open, efficient, and reproducible vision-language modeling from scratch, lowering barriers to entry and enabling rapid community-driven iteration; a reinforcement learning (RL) variant is anticipated to extend capabilities.

title: Vision-and-Language Navigation with Analogical Textual Descriptions in LLMs
summary:
Integrating large language models (LLMs) into embodied AI models is becoming
increasingly prevalent. However, existing zero-shot LLM-based
Vision-and-Language Navigation (VLN) agents either encode images as textual
scene descriptions, potentially oversimplifying visual details, or process raw
image inputs, which can fail to capture abstract semantics required for
high-level reasoning. In this paper, we improve the navigation agent's
contextual understanding by incorporating textual descriptions from multiple
perspectives that facilitate analogical reasoning across images. By leveraging
text-based analogical reasoning, the agent enhances its global scene
understanding and spatial reasoning, leading to more accurate action decisions.
We evaluate our approach on the R2R dataset, where our experiments demonstrate
significant improvements in navigation performance.

AI.tldr: Multi-perspective textual descriptions enable text-based analogical reasoning across images to improve VLN navigation.
AI.motivation: Zero-shot LLM-based VLN agents either reduce visual input to simplistic scene descriptions or operate on raw images, which can miss abstract semantics and cross-image relations needed for high-level navigation decisions. There is a need for richer, cross-image semantic reasoning to enhance embodied navigation.
AI.method: Incorporate textual descriptions from multiple perspectives for each scene and enable analogical reasoning across images to improve global scene understanding and spatial reasoning. This leverages text-based analogical reasoning within the LLM (or an auxiliary module) to guide action decisions.
AI.result: Experiments on the R2R dataset show significant improvements in navigation performance compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: Text-based analogical reasoning over multi-perspective textual descriptions enhances LLM-based VLN agents, yielding better navigation in embodied settings.

title: A Self-Adaptive Frequency Domain Network for Continuous Intraoperative Hypotension Prediction
summary:
Intraoperative hypotension (IOH) is strongly associated with postoperative
complications, including postoperative delirium and increased mortality, making
its early prediction crucial in perioperative care. While several artificial
intelligence-based models have been developed to provide IOH warnings, existing
methods face limitations in incorporating both time and frequency domain
information, capturing short- and long-term dependencies, and handling noise
sensitivity in biosignal data. To address these challenges, we propose a novel
Self-Adaptive Frequency Domain Network (SAFDNet). Specifically, SAFDNet
integrates an adaptive spectral block, which leverages Fourier analysis to
extract frequency-domain features and employs self-adaptive thresholding to
mitigate noise. Additionally, an interactive attention block is introduced to
capture both long-term and short-term dependencies in the data. Extensive
internal and external validations on two large-scale real-world datasets
demonstrate that SAFDNet achieves up to 97.3\% AUROC in IOH early warning,
outperforming state-of-the-art models. Furthermore, SAFDNet exhibits robust
predictive performance and low sensitivity to noise, making it well-suited for
practical clinical applications.

AI.tldr: A deep learning model SAFDNet for intraoperative hypotension early warning that fuses adaptive frequency-domain features with self-adaptive thresholding and interactive attention to capture both short- and long-term dependencies; validated on two real-world datasets with high AUROC and robustness to noise.
AI.motivation: IOH correlates with postoperative complications; existing AI methods struggle to jointly leverage time- and frequency-domain information, model multi-scale dependencies, and resist biosignal noise.
AI.method: SAFDNet comprises an adaptive spectral block using Fourier analysis to extract frequency-domain features, a self-adaptive thresholding mechanism to suppress noise, and an interactive attention block to model long- and short-term dependencies.
AI.result: Extensive internal/external validations on two large-scale real-world datasets show SAFDNet achieves up to 97.3% AUROC for IOH early warning, outperforming state-of-the-art models and displaying robustness to noise.
AI.conclusion: SAFDNet provides accurate, robust IOH early warning with practical clinical applicability, addressing limitations of prior methods by integrating time- and frequency-domain features and noise-robust attention.

title: HIVTP: A Training-Free Method to Improve VLMs Efficiency via Hierarchical Visual Token Pruning Using Middle-Layer-Based Importance Score
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have shown strong capabilities on diverse
multimodal tasks. However, the large number of visual tokens output by the
vision encoder severely hinders inference efficiency, and prior studies have
shown that many of these tokens are not important and can therefore be safely
pruned. In this work, we propose HIVTP, a training-free method to improve VLMs
efficiency via hierarchical visual token pruning using a novel
middle-layer-based importance score. Specifically, we utilize attention maps
extracted from the middle layers of the vision encoder, which better reflect
fine-grained and object-level attention, to estimate visual token importance.
Based on this, we propose a hierarchical visual token pruning method to retain
both globally and locally important visual tokens. Specifically, we reshape the
1-D visual token sequence output by the vision encoder into a 2-D spatial
layout. In the global retaining stage, we divide the image into regions and
retain tokens with higher importance scores in each region; in the local
retaining stage, we then divide the image into small windows and retain the
most important token in each local window. Experimental results show that our
proposed method, HIVTP, can reduce the time-to-first-token (TTFT) of
LLaVA-v1.5-7B and LLaVA-Next-7B by up to 50.0% and 55.1%, respectively, and
improve the token generation throughput by up to 60.9% and 47.3%, without
sacrificing accuracy, and even achieving improvements on certain benchmarks.
Compared with prior works, HIVTP achieves better accuracy while offering higher
inference efficiency.

AI.tldr: HIVTP is a training-free, hierarchical visual token pruning method for vision-language models that uses middle-layer attention to estimate token importance, enabling global and local token retentions to substantially speed up inference without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.motivation: Vision-language models output many visual tokens, many of which are not essential for tasks, leading to slow inference. Prior pruning methods often require training or fine-tuning; a training-free, efficient pruning method is desirable.
AI.method: Compute token importance from middle-layer attention maps of the vision encoder. Reshape the 1-D token sequence into a 2-D spatial layout. Global stage: divide the image into regions and keep high-importance tokens per region. Local stage: divide into small windows and keep the most important token in each window. Prune tokens accordingly to produce a smaller token set for inference, without retraining.
AI.result: On LLaVA-v1.5-7B and LLaVA-Next-7B, HIVTP reduces time-to-first-token by up to 50.0% and 55.1% and increases token generation throughput by up to 60.9% and 47.3%, respectively, with no loss in accuracy and even occasional accuracy gains on certain benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: HIVTP offers improved inference efficiency for VLMs in a training-free manner, outperforming prior pruning approaches while maintaining or improving accuracy.

title: ReasoningBank: Scaling Agent Self-Evolving with Reasoning Memory
summary:
With the growing adoption of large language model agents in persistent
real-world roles, they naturally encounter continuous streams of tasks. A key
limitation, however, is their failure to learn from the accumulated interaction
history, forcing them to discard valuable insights and repeat past errors. We
propose ReasoningBank, a novel memory framework that distills generalizable
reasoning strategies from an agent's self-judged successful and failed
experiences. At test time, an agent retrieves relevant memories from
ReasoningBank to inform its interaction and then integrates new learnings back,
enabling it to become more capable over time. Building on this powerful
experience learner, we further introduce memory-aware test-time scaling
(MaTTS), which accelerates and diversifies this learning process by scaling up
the agent's interaction experience. By allocating more compute to each task,
the agent generates abundant, diverse experiences that provide rich contrastive
signals for synthesizing higher-quality memory. The better memory in turn
guides more effective scaling, establishing a powerful synergy between memory
and test-time scaling. Across web browsing and software engineering benchmarks,
ReasoningBank consistently outperforms existing memory mechanisms that store
raw trajectories or only successful task routines, improving both effectiveness
and efficiency; MaTTS further amplifies these gains. These findings establish
memory-driven experience scaling as a new scaling dimension, enabling agents to
self-evolve with emergent behaviors naturally arise.

AI.tldr: A memory-based framework (ReasoningBank) distills generalizable reasoning strategies from an agent's own successes and failures to improve performance over time, augmented by memory-aware test-time scaling (MaTTS) that generates richer experiences via increased compute per task, yielding improved efficiency and effectiveness in real-world task settings.
AI.motivation: LLM agents operating in persistent, real-world roles face continuous tasks and cannot rely on replaying only raw trajectories; forgetting and repeating errors is costly. A memory mechanism that captures generalizable reasoning patterns from past successes/failures, and scales interactions to create richer experiences, could enable self-improvement over time.
AI.method: ReasoningBank stores distilled reasoning strategies from self-judged successes and failures; at test time, the agent retrieves relevant memories to inform interaction and then integrates new learnings back. MaTTS allocates more compute per task to Generate abundant, diverse experiences, providing rich contrastive signals to synthesize higher-quality memory. This creates a synergy where memory enables better scaling, and scaling enriches memory.
AI.result: On web browsing and software engineering benchmarks, ReasoningBank outperforms existing memory mechanisms that store raw trajectories or only successful task routines, improving both effectiveness and efficiency. MaTTS amplifies these gains by further enhancing learning through richer experiences.
AI.conclusion: Memory-driven experience scaling defines a new scaling dimension in agent learning, enabling self-evolution of agents with emergent behaviors arising from the interplay between stored reasoning memories and test-time scaling.

title: GBSK: Skeleton Clustering via Granular-ball Computing and Multi-Sampling for Large-Scale Data
summary:
To effectively handle clustering task for large-scale datasets, we propose a
novel scalable skeleton clustering algorithm, namely GBSK, which leverages the
granular-ball technique to capture the underlying structure of data. By
multi-sampling the dataset and constructing multi-grained granular-balls, GBSK
progressively uncovers a statistical "skeleton" -- a spatial abstraction that
approximates the essential structure and distribution of the original data.
This strategy enables GBSK to dramatically reduce computational overhead while
maintaining high clustering accuracy. In addition, we introduce an adaptive
version, AGBSK, with simplified parameter settings to enhance usability and
facilitate deployment in real-world scenarios. Extensive experiments conducted
on standard computing hardware demonstrate that GBSK achieves high efficiency
and strong clustering performance on large-scale datasets, including one with
