AI.method: Develop a comprehensive, scalable Visual Privacy Taxonomy aligned with legal notions of privacy; evaluate several state-of-the-art Vision-Language Models on privacy-related tasks to assess their contextual privacy understanding; analyze performance and inconsistencies.
AI.result: The taxonomy provides a foundational framework for future research; experiments reveal notable inconsistencies and limitations in current VLMs' privacy understanding; the work provides a critical benchmark highlighting urgent need for privacy-aware AI systems.
AI.conclusion: Offers foundational taxonomy and benchmark; calls for integrating privacy principles into model design and evaluation to build more robust, privacy-conscious AI.

title: Diffusion Models are Kelly Gamblers
summary:
We draw a connection between diffusion models and the Kelly criterion for
maximizing returns in betting games. We find that conditional diffusion models
store additional information to bind the signal $X$ with the conditioning
information $Y$, equal to the mutual information between them. Classifier-free
guidance effectively boosts the mutual information between $X$ and $Y$ at
sampling time. This is especially helpful in image models, since the mutual
information between images and their labels is low, a fact which is intimately
connected to the manifold hypothesis. Finally, we point out some nuances in the
popular perspective that diffusion models are infinitely deep autoencoders. In
doing so, we relate the denoising loss to the Fermi Golden Rule from quantum
mechanics.

AI.tldr: Diffusion models can be interpreted through an information-theoretic lens: conditioning binds the signal X to Y via mutual information, and classifier-free guidance boosts this mutual information during sampling. This helps image models where image–label mutual information is intrinsically low due to the manifold structure. The work also challenges the view of diffusion models as infinitely deep autoencoders and links the denoising loss to the Fermi Golden Rule, blending ideas from information theory and quantum mechanics.
AI.motivation: To understand how conditioning information is preserved and utilized in diffusion models, connect diffusion models to decision-theoretic criteria (Kelly criterion), and relate the diffusion framework to information-theoretic and physics concepts (manifold hypothesis, quantum mechanics).
AI.method: The authors present a theoretical analysis showing that conditional diffusion models store information binding the signal X with conditioning Y, quantified by the mutual information I(X;Y). They argue that classifier-free guidance increases this MI at sampling time, and discuss implications for image-models where I(X;Y) is typically small due to the manifold structure. They also critique the view that diffusion models are infinite-depth autoencoders and relate the denoising loss to the Fermi Golden Rule from quantum mechanics.
AI.result: Key claim: the conditioning signal Y binds with X to encode mutual information I(X;Y) in conditional diffusion models; classifier-free guidance acts to boost I(X;Y) during sampling. This provides an information-theoretic explanation for improved conditioning, particularly in image tasks where image–label MI is low. The work also refines the interpretation of diffusion models (not simply infinite-depth autoencoders) by linking denoising dynamics to a quantum-mechanical principle.
AI.conclusion: The abstract proposes a cross-disciplinary framework linking diffusion modeling, information theory, decision theory (Kelly criterion), and physics (Fermi Golden Rule), offering new insights into how conditioning information is stored and exploited and urging reevaluation of the diffusion-as-autoencoder viewpoint.

title: Uni4D-LLM: A Unified SpatioTemporal-Aware VLM for 4D Understanding and Generation
summary:
Vision-language models (VLMs) have demonstrated strong performance in 2D
scene understanding and generation, but extending this unification to the
physical world remains an open challenge. Existing 3D and 4D approaches
typically embed scene geometry into autoregressive model for semantic
understanding and diffusion model for content generation. This paradigm gap
prevents a single model from jointly handling both tasks, especially in dynamic
4D settings where spatiotemporal modeling is critical. We propose Uni4D-LLM,
the first unified VLM framework with spatiotemporal awareness for 4D scene
understanding and generation. Our design is guided by two key insights: 1)
Unification requires a shared representation. We extract semantic features for
understanding and noisy-injected appearance features for generation,
incorporate 4D geometric cues, and fuse them into a spatiotemporal-aware visual
representation through adaptive cross-attention. 2) Unification requires a
shared architecture. Both autoregression and diffusion are built on Transformer
backbones, and this enables integration into a single LLM with task-specific
heads. By aligning visual and linguistic representations, our Uni4D-LLM
produces predictions for both understanding and generation within one
Transformer-based framework. We further apply instruction fine-tuning on
diverse 4D vision-language datasets to improve generalization across tasks.
Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that Uni4D-LLM
achieves competitive or superior results compared to state-of-the-art models
and offers the first true unification of 4D scene understanding and generation.

AI.tldr: Uni4D-LLM: a unified 4D vision–language model that jointly handles 4D scene understanding and generation within a single Transformer-based framework, using shared representations and adaptive cross-attention to fuse semantics, appearance, and geometry.
AI.motivation: 2D VLMs excel at image-language tasks but there is no unified model for 4D (spatiotemporal) scenes. Existing 3D/4D methods typically separate understanding (autoregressive) and generation (diffusion), hindering joint tasks in dynamic environments; a shared representation and architecture are needed for joint perception and generation.
AI.method: Introduce Uni4D-LLM with (1) a shared spatiotemporal visual representation built from semantic features for understanding and noisy appearance features for generation, plus 4D geometric cues; (2) adaptive cross-attention to fuse these cues; (3) a single Transformer backbone supporting both autoregression and diffusion, enabling their integration under a unified LLM with task-specific heads; (4) alignment of visual and linguistic representations; (5) instruction fine-tuning on diverse 4D vision-language datasets to improve generalization.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks show Uni4D-LLM achieves competitive or superior performance against state-of-the-art models and, importantly, provides the first true unification of 4D scene understanding and generation.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of a single Transformer-based model that jointly handles 4D perception and content generation through shared representations, a unified architecture, and instruction-tuned generalization across tasks.

title: Brain-language fusion enables interactive neural readout and in-silico experimentation
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have revolutionized human-machine interaction,
and have been extended by embedding diverse modalities such as images into a
shared language space. Yet, neural decoding has remained constrained by static,
non-interactive methods. We introduce CorText, a framework that integrates
neural activity directly into the latent space of an LLM, enabling open-ended,
natural language interaction with brain data. Trained on fMRI data recorded
during viewing of natural scenes, CorText generates accurate image captions and
can answer more detailed questions better than controls, while having access to
neural data only. We showcase that CorText achieves zero-shot generalization
beyond semantic categories seen during training. Furthermore, we present a
counterfactual analysis that emulates in-silico cortical microstimulation.
These advances mark a shift from passive decoding toward generative, flexible
interfaces between brain activity and language.

AI.tldr: A framework (CorText) maps fMRI signals into an LLM latent space to enable open-ended language interaction with brain activity, achieving image captioning and Q&A with zero-shot generalization.
AI.motivation: To move beyond static neural decoding toward interactive, generative brain–language interfaces that can flexibly interpret neural data without explicit external supervision.
AI.method: Train a model to embed fMRI data collected while participants viewed natural scenes into the latent space of a large language model, enabling caption generation and detailed questions; evaluate zero-shot generalization; perform counterfactual in-silico cortical stimulation analyses.
AI.result: CorText generates accurate image captions and answers more detailed questions than controls using only neural data; demonstrates zero-shot generalization beyond training categories; counterfactual analyses emulate cortical microstimulation.
AI.conclusion: Represents a shift from passive decoding to generative, flexible interfaces between brain activity and language, enabling naturalistic interaction with neural data.

title: 2nd Place Report of MOSEv2 Challenge 2025: Concept Guided Video Object Segmentation via SeC
summary:
Semi-supervised Video Object Segmentation aims to segment a specified target
throughout a video sequence, initialized by a first-frame mask. Previous
methods rely heavily on appearance-based pattern matching and thus exhibit
limited robustness against challenges such as drastic visual changes,
occlusions, and scene shifts. This failure is often attributed to a lack of
high-level conceptual understanding of the target. The recently proposed
Segment Concept (SeC) framework mitigated this limitation by using a Large
Vision-Language Model (LVLM) to establish a deep semantic understanding of the
object for more persistent segmentation. In this work, we evaluate its
zero-shot performance on the challenging coMplex video Object SEgmentation v2
(MOSEv2) dataset. Without any fine-tuning on the training set, SeC achieved
39.7 \JFn on the test set and ranked 2nd place in the Complex VOS track of the
7th Large-scale Video Object Segmentation Challenge.

AI.tldr: SeC uses a Large Vision-Language Model to inject semantic understanding into semi-supervised video object segmentation, improving zero-shot robustness; on MOSEv2 it achieved 39.7 and 2nd place in Complex VOS.
AI.motivation: To overcome reliance on appearance-based pattern matching and improve robustness against drastic visual changes, occlusions, and scene shifts by leveraging high-level semantic understanding of the target.
AI.method: Apply the Segment Concept (SeC) framework with a Large Vision-Language Model to obtain semantic representations of the target and perform zero-shot video object segmentation without fine-tuning; evaluate on the MOSEv2 dataset.
AI.result: Achieved 39.7 on the MOSEv2 test set and ranked 2nd in the Complex VOS track of the 7th Large-scale Video Object Segmentation Challenge.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that incorporating LVLM-based semantic understanding can boost zero-shot VOS robustness and persistence, suggesting potential for further improvements through enhanced semantic representations or integration with other cues.

title: Efficient Identification of High Similarity Clusters in Polygon Datasets
summary:
Advancements in tools like Shapely 2.0 and Triton can significantly improve
the efficiency of spatial similarity computations by enabling faster and more
scalable geometric operations. However, for extremely large datasets, these
optimizations may face challenges due to the sheer volume of computations
required. To address this, we propose a framework that reduces the number of
clusters requiring verification, thereby decreasing the computational load on
these systems. The framework integrates dynamic similarity index thresholding,
supervised scheduling, and recall-constrained optimization to efficiently
identify clusters with the highest spatial similarity while meeting
user-defined precision and recall requirements. By leveraging Kernel Density
Estimation (KDE) to dynamically determine similarity thresholds and machine
learning models to prioritize clusters, our approach achieves substantial
reductions in computational cost without sacrificing accuracy. Experimental
results demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of the method, offering a
practical solution for large-scale geospatial analysis.

AI.tldr: A scalable framework to reduce verification needs in large-scale spatial similarity tasks via dynamic thresholds, ML prioritization, and KDE-based adaptive thresholds, achieving lower compute while preserving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Scaling spatial similarity computations on very large geospatial datasets confronts substantial verification costs; while tools like Shapely 2.0 and Triton improve performance, a reduction in candidate clusters is needed to maintain feasibility.
AI.method: Proposes a framework that combines dynamic similarity index thresholding, supervised scheduling, and recall-constrained optimization. It uses Kernel Density Estimation (KDE) to adaptively determine similarity thresholds and machine learning models to prioritize clusters, reducing verifications while meeting precision/recall constraints.
AI.result: Demonstrates substantial reductions in computational cost without sacrificing accuracy; shows scalability and effectiveness on large-scale geospatial analysis tasks.
AI.conclusion: Offers a practical, scalable solution for large-scale geospatial similarity analysis that can operate under user-defined precision and recall specifications.

title: Towards Fine-Grained Text-to-3D Quality Assessment: A Benchmark and A Two-Stage Rank-Learning Metric
summary:
Recent advances in Text-to-3D (T23D) generative models have enabled the
synthesis of diverse, high-fidelity 3D assets from textual prompts. However,
existing challenges restrict the development of reliable T23D quality
assessment (T23DQA). First, existing benchmarks are outdated, fragmented, and
coarse-grained, making fine-grained metric training infeasible. Moreover,
current objective metrics exhibit inherent design limitations, resulting in
non-representative feature extraction and diminished metric robustness. To
address these limitations, we introduce T23D-CompBench, a comprehensive
benchmark for compositional T23D generation. We define five components with
twelve sub-components for compositional prompts, which are used to generate
3,600 textured meshes from ten state-of-the-art generative models. A
large-scale subjective experiment is conducted to collect 129,600 reliable
human ratings across different perspectives. Based on T23D-CompBench, we
further propose Rank2Score, an effective evaluator with two-stage training for
T23DQA. Rank2Score enhances pairwise training via supervised contrastive
regression and curriculum learning in the first stage, and subsequently refines
predictions using mean opinion scores to achieve closer alignment with human
judgments in the second stage. Extensive experiments and downstream
applications demonstrate that Rank2Score consistently outperforms existing
metrics across multiple dimensions and can additionally serve as a reward
function to optimize generative models. The project is available at
https://cbysjtu.github.io/Rank2Score/.

AI.tldr: Introduces T23D-CompBench, a large-scale, compositional benchmark for text-to-3D quality assessment, and Rank2Score, a two-stage learning-based evaluator that aligns with human judgments and serves as a reward for generative models.
AI.motivation: Current T23D QA benchmarks are outdated, fragmented, and coarse-grained, hindering fine-grained metric training and robust evaluation; there is a need for a scalable, compositional benchmark and a metric that better captures human perception.
AI.method: Define five components with twelve sub-components for compositional prompts; synthesize 3,600 textured meshes using ten state-of-the-art T23D models; conduct a large-scale subjective study with 129,600 ratings; introduce Rank2Score with two-stage training: (1) supervised contrastive regression with curriculum learning to improve pairwise signals, (2) refinement using mean opinion scores to better match human judgments; Rank2Score can also function as a reward signal for model optimization.
AI.result: Rank2Score outperforms existing metrics across multiple dimensions in correlating with human judgments; the benchmark enables fine-grained evaluation and can support downstream tasks, including reward-based optimization; a project page is provided for access to data and code.
AI.conclusion: The work delivers a comprehensive compositional benchmark for T23D generation and a robust, human-aligned QA metric, enabling more reliable evaluation and optimization of T23D models.

title: Explore-Execute Chain: Towards an Efficient Structured Reasoning Paradigm
summary:
Chain-of-Thought (CoT) and its variants have markedly advanced the reasoning
abilities of Large Language Models (LLMs), yet their monolithic and
auto-regressive architecture inherently conflates high-level strategic planning
with low-level step-by-step execution, leading to computational inefficiency,
limited exploration of reasoning paths, and reduced interpretability. To
overcome these issues, we propose the Explore-Execute Chain ($E^2C$), a
structured reasoning framework that decouples reasoning into two distinct
phases: an exploratory phase that stochastically generates succinct high-level
plans, followed by an execution phase that deterministically carries out the
chosen plan. Our approach incorporates a two-stage training methodology, which
combines Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) - augmented by a novel data generation
algorithm enforcing strict plan adherence - with a subsequent Reinforcement
Learning (RL) stage that capitalizes on the informativeness of exploration and
reinforces the determinism of execution.This decomposition enables an efficient
test-time scaling strategy: on AIME'2024, $E^2C$ Test Time Scaling reaches
58.1% accuracy using <10% of the decoding tokens required by comparable methods
(e.g., Forest-of-Thought), sharply cutting self-consistency overhead. For
cross-domain adaptation, our Exploration-Focused SFT (EF-SFT) fine-tunes with
only 3.5% of the tokens used by standard SFT yet yields up to 14.5% higher
accuracy than standard SFT on medical benchmarks, delivering state-of-the-art
performance, strong generalization, and greater interpretability by separating
planning from execution. The code and pre-trained models for the project are
available at: https://github.com/yks23/Explore-Execute-Chain.git

AI.tldr: E^2C decouples reasoning into an exploratory high-level planning phase and a deterministic execution phase, enabling efficient test-time scaling, improved interpretability, and cross-domain gains via EF-SFT and RL; achieves 58.1% AIME'2024 accuracy with <10% decoding tokens and up to +14.5% medical accuracy with 3.5% tokens; code released.
AI.motivation: Address the inefficiency, limited exploration, and poor interpretability of monolithic chain-of-thought in LLMs, by decoupling high-level planning from low-level execution.
AI.method: Two-stage training: stage-1 supervised fine-tuning (SFT) with a data-generation algorithm that enforces strict adherence to high-level plans; stage-2 reinforcement learning (RL) to leverage exploration signals and reinforce deterministic execution; test-time scaling strategy demonstrated on AIME'2024; exploration-focused SFT (EF-SFT) for cross-domain adaptation using only 3.5% of standard SFT tokens.
AI.result: On AIME'2024, E^2C achieves 58.1% accuracy with <10% of decoding tokens required by comparable methods (e.g., Forest-of-Thought); EF-SFT yields up to 14.5% higher accuracy on medical benchmarks using 3.5% tokens; claims state-of-the-art performance, strong generalization, and improved interpretability.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling planning from execution yields efficiency, interpretability, and generalization gains; E^2C demonstrates substantial token-efficient performance and strong cross-domain results, with accompanying open-source code and models.

title: CE-FAM: Concept-Based Explanation via Fusion of Activation Maps
comment: This paper has been accepted to ICCV 2025
summary:
Although saliency maps can highlight important regions to explain the
reasoning behind image classification in artificial intelligence (AI), the
meaning of these regions is left to the user's interpretation. In contrast,
conceptbased explanations decompose AI predictions into humanunderstandable
concepts, clarifying their contributions. However, few methods can
simultaneously reveal what concepts an image classifier learns, which regions
are associated with them, and how they contribute to predictions. We propose a
novel concept-based explanation method, Concept-based Explanation via Fusion of
Activation Maps (CE-FAM). It employs a branched network that shares activation
maps with an image classifier and learns to mimic the embeddings of a Vision
and Language Model (VLM). The branch network predicts concepts in an image, and
their corresponding regions are represented by a weighted sum of activation
maps, with weights given by the gradients of the concept prediction scores.
Their contributions are quantified based on their impact on the image
classification score. Our method provides a general framework for identifying
the concept regions and their contributions while leveraging VLM knowledge to
handle arbitrary concepts without requiring an annotated dataset. Furthermore,
we introduce a novel evaluation metric to assess the accuracy of the concept
regions. Our qualitative and quantitative evaluations demonstrate our method
outperforms existing approaches and excels in zero-shot inference for unseen
concepts.

AI.tldr: CE-FAM: a concept-based explanation method using a branched network that shares activation maps with a classifier and mimics Vision-Language Model embeddings to identify concept regions and their contributions, enabling zero-shot concept explanations without annotated data, with a new evaluation metric and strong empirical results.
AI.motivation: Saliency maps are often semantically vague, and existing concept-based explanations struggle to simultaneously reveal learned concepts, their spatial regions, and their contributions to predictions. A unified framework that can identify concepts, localize their regions, and quantify their impact—leveraging VLM knowledge to handle arbitrary concepts without labeled data—is needed.
AI.method: A branched network shares activation maps with the image classifier and learns to mimic embeddings of a Vision-Language Model (VLM). The branch predicts concepts in an image; the corresponding regions are represented by a weighted sum of activation maps, with weights given by gradients of the concept scores. Contributions are quantified by their impact on the image classification score. The framework uses VLM knowledge to handle arbitrary concepts without annotated datasets and introduces a novel evaluation metric for concept-region accuracy.
AI.result: Quantitative and qualitative evaluations show CE-FAM outperforms existing approaches and excels in zero-shot inference for unseen concepts, demonstrating effective identification of concept regions and meaningful contribution attribution.
AI.conclusion: CE-FAM provides a general, dataset-free framework for identifying concept regions and their contributions, leveraging VLM knowledge to handle arbitrary concepts and improve interpretability of image classifications.

title: DiBS-MTL: Transformation-Invariant Multitask Learning with Direction Oracles
summary:
Multitask learning (MTL) algorithms typically rely on schemes that combine
different task losses or their gradients through weighted averaging. These
methods aim to find Pareto stationary points by using heuristics that require
access to task loss values, gradients, or both. In doing so, a central
challenge arises because task losses can be arbitrarily, nonaffinely scaled
relative to one another, causing certain tasks to dominate training and degrade
overall performance. A recent advance in cooperative bargaining theory, the
Direction-based Bargaining Solution (DiBS), yields Pareto stationary solutions
immune to task domination because of its invariance to monotonic nonaffine task
loss transformations. However, the convergence behavior of DiBS in nonconvex
MTL settings is currently not understood. To this end, we prove that under
standard assumptions, a subsequence of DiBS iterates converges to a Pareto
stationary point when task losses are possibly nonconvex, and propose DiBS-MTL,
a computationally efficient adaptation of DiBS to the MTL setting. Finally, we
validate DiBS-MTL empirically on standard MTL benchmarks, showing that it
achieves competitive performance with state-of-the-art methods while
maintaining robustness to nonaffine monotonic transformations that
significantly degrade the performance of existing approaches, including prior
bargaining-inspired MTL methods. Code available at
https://github.com/suryakmurthy/dibs-mtl.

AI.tldr: DiBS-MTL adapts the Direction-based Bargaining Solution to multitask learning to achieve Pareto-stationary solutions robust to monotone, nonaffine task-loss transformations; it provides theoretical convergence (subsequence to Pareto stationary point under nonconvex losses) and empirical competitive performance with robustness advantages over prior bargaining-inspired methods.
AI.motivation: MTL losses can be nonlinearly and nonaffinely scaled across tasks, causing some tasks to dominate training and hurt overall performance. Existing methods often depend on loss/gradient magnitudes and are sensitive to monotone transformations. A bargaining-based approach (DiBS) promises invariance to monotone transformations but its nonconvex convergence in MTL is unknown.
AI.method: Extend DiBS to MTL (DiBS-MTL): a computationally efficient adaptation that (i) yields Pareto-stationary solutions under monotone nonaffine transformations and (ii) empirically validates convergence properties on standard MTL benchmarks.
AI.result: Theoretically, a subsequence of DiBS-MTL iterates converges to a Pareto stationary point even when task losses are nonconvex. Empirically, DiBS-MTL achieves competitive performance with state-of-the-art MTL methods and shows robustness to nonaffine monotonic transformations that degrade other approaches, including prior bargaining-based methods.
AI.conclusion: DiBS-MTL provides a robust, scalable solution for MTL that achieves Pareto-stationary solutions invariant to monotone nonaffine task-loss transformations, with strong empirical performance and theoretical convergence guarantees in nonconvex settings.

title: FairViT-GAN: A Hybrid Vision Transformer with Adversarial Debiasing for Fair and Explainable Facial Beauty Prediction
summary:
Facial Beauty Prediction (FBP) has made significant strides with the
application of deep learning, yet state-of-the-art models often exhibit
critical limitations, including architectural constraints, inherent demographic
biases, and a lack of transparency. Existing methods, primarily based on
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), excel at capturing local texture but
struggle with global facial harmony, while Vision Transformers (ViTs)
effectively model long-range dependencies but can miss fine-grained details.
Furthermore, models trained on benchmark datasets can inadvertently learn and
perpetuate societal biases related to protected attributes like ethnicity. To
address these interconnected challenges, we propose \textbf{FairViT-GAN}, a
novel hybrid framework that synergistically integrates a CNN branch for local
feature extraction and a ViT branch for global context modeling. More
significantly, we introduce an adversarial debiasing mechanism where the
feature extractor is explicitly trained to produce representations that are
invariant to protected attributes, thereby actively mitigating algorithmic
bias. Our framework's transparency is enhanced by visualizing the distinct
focus of each architectural branch. Extensive experiments on the SCUT-FBP5500
benchmark demonstrate that FairViT-GAN not only sets a new state-of-the-art in
predictive accuracy, achieving a Pearson Correlation of \textbf{0.9230} and
reducing RMSE to \textbf{0.2650}, but also excels in fairness. Our analysis
reveals a remarkable \textbf{82.9\% reduction in the performance gap} between
ethnic subgroups, with the adversary's classification accuracy dropping to
near-random chance (52.1\%). We believe FairViT-GAN provides a robust,
transparent, and significantly fairer blueprint for developing responsible AI
systems for subjective visual assessment.

AI.tldr: Hybrid CNN+ViT with adversarial debiasing; achieves state-of-the-art facial beauty prediction accuracy while substantially reducing ethnic bias and improving transparency.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of CNNs (local texture) and ViTs (global context) in facial beauty prediction, and mitigate protected-attribute biases to promote fairer, more transparent models in subjective vision tasks.
AI.method: A dual-branch architecture combining a CNN for local features and a Vision Transformer for global context, coupled with an adversarial debiasing mechanism that enforces protected-attribute invariance in the learned representations; transparency enhanced via visualization of branch focus; evaluated on SCUT-FBP5500.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art metrics: Pearson correlation 0.9230 and RMSE 0.2650; reduces the ethnic subgroup performance gap by 82.9%; adversary classifier accuracy drops to 52.1% (near random).
AI.conclusion: FairViT-GAN demonstrates a robust, transparent, and significantly fairer approach for subjective AI tasks in facial beauty prediction, offering a blueprint for responsible AI in biased domains.

title: Evaluating the Robustness of Chinchilla Compute-Optimal Scaling
summary:
Hoffman et al (2022)'s Chinchilla paper introduced the principle of
compute-optimal scaling, laying a foundation for future scaling of language
models. In the years since, however, valid concerns about Chinchilla have been
raised: wide confidence intervals, discrepancies between its three approaches,
and incongruities with other scaling laws. This raises a critical question for
the field: Can practitioners still rely on Chinchilla's prescriptions? Our work
demonstrates the answer is yes. We begin by uncovering that the model
parameters central to Chinchilla's analyses were ambiguous: three
interpretations are possible, with relative differences between different
interpretations of model parameters as high as 15.2%. We find that, perhaps
surprisingly, which model parameters are used for the analyses do not
meaningfully affect key results: the scaling law estimates and the
compute-optimal tokens-to-parameter ratio. Indeed, under one interpretation,
the tokens-to-parameter ratio becomes more constant with the target compute
budget. We then ask how distorted the Chinchilla model parameters could have
been without meaningfully affecting the key results. By deliberately perturbing
model parameters in four structured ways, we find that key Chinchilla results
are most sensitive to additive or systematic errors, which can alter the
otherwise flat trend of the optimal tokens-to-parameter ratio, but overall,
Chinchilla's key results withstand sizable perturbations. Altogether, our
findings offer the field renewed confidence in Chinchilla as a durable guide
for scaling language models.

AI.tldr: Chinchilla's compute-optimal scaling remains robust to parameter interpretation and perturbations; core scaling-law estimates and the compute-optimal tokens-to-parameter ratio are preserved, supporting its use as a reliable scaling guide.
AI.motivation: Address contemporary criticisms of Chinchilla (confidence intervals, scaling-law discrepancies, and parameter ambiguities) and assess whether its prescriptions remain trustworthy.
AI.method: 1) Re-examine three plausible interpretations of the model parameters and quantify the impact on scaling-law estimates and the tokens-per-parameter ratio; 2) perturb model parameters in four structured ways to test sensitivity; 3) evaluate how these changes affect the observed relationships.
AI.result: Parameter interpretations differ by up to 15.2%, but these differences do not meaningfully alter the key results: the scaling-law estimates and the compute-optimal tokens-per-parameter ratio remain largely intact. In some interpretations, the ratio appears more constant with target compute. Perturbations show that additive or systematic errors threaten the flatness of the ratio more than the core results, but overall the key findings withstand sizable perturbations.
AI.conclusion: Chinchilla remains a durable, trustworthy guide for scaling language models; practitioners can rely on its prescriptions with some caution about potential minor perturbations in parameter choices or additive/systematic errors.

title: Sim-DETR: Unlock DETR for Temporal Sentence Grounding
comment: This work is accepted by ICCV 2025
summary:
Temporal sentence grounding aims to identify exact moments in a video that
correspond to a given textual query, typically addressed with detection
transformer (DETR) solutions. However, we find that typical strategies designed
to enhance DETR do not improve, and may even degrade, its performance in this
task. We systematically analyze and identify the root causes of this abnormal
behavior: (1) conflicts between queries from similar target moments and (2)
internal query conflicts due to the tension between global semantics and local
localization. Building on these insights, we propose a simple yet powerful
baseline, Sim-DETR, which extends the standard DETR with two minor
modifications in the decoder layers: (1) constraining self-attention between
queries based on their semantic and positional overlap and (2) adding
query-to-frame alignment to bridge the global and local contexts. Experiments
demonstrate that Sim-DETR unlocks the full potential of DETR for temporal
sentence grounding, offering a strong baseline for future research.

AI.tldr: A simple enhanced DETR baseline (Sim-DETR) for temporal sentence grounding addresses query conflicts with two decoder tweaks, yielding strong performance gains.
AI.motivation: Standard DETR-based approaches under temporal sentence grounding exhibit degraded performance due to (a) conflicts among similar target moment queries, and (b) tension between global semantics and local localization; understanding and mitigating these conflicts is key.
AI.method: Propose Sim-DETR by adding two decoder-layer modifications: (1) constrain self-attention between queries according to semantic/positional overlap, and (2) introduce query-to-frame alignment to connect global and local cues.
AI.result: Experiments show Sim-DETR unlocks full potential of DETR for temporal sentence grounding and provides a strong, simple baseline for future work.
AI.conclusion: Careful handling of query interactions and alignment between query and frame contexts is crucial when adapting DETR to temporal grounding; the proposed minimal changes yield substantial gains and a solid baseline.

title: Detecting and Rectifying Noisy Labels: A Similarity-based Approach
summary:
Label noise in datasets could damage the performance of neural net training.
As the size of modern deep networks grows, there is a growing demand for
automated tools for detecting such errors. In this paper, we propose post-hoc,
model-agnostic error detection and rectification methods utilizing the
penultimate feature from a neural network. Our idea is based on the observation
that the similarity between the penultimate feature of a mislabeled data point
and its true class data points is higher than that for data points from other
classes, making the probability of label occurrence within a tight, similar
cluster informative for detecting and rectifying errors. Extensive experiments
show our method not only demonstrates high performance across various noises
but also automatically rectifies these errors to improve the quality of
datasets.

AI.tldr: Post-hoc, model-agnostic detection and rectification of label noise using penultimate-layer features to detect mislabels via tight intra-class clusters, enabling automatic corrections and cleaner datasets.
AI.motivation: Label noise degrades neural network training; with ever-larger networks, there is a need for automated, post-hoc tools that can both detect and rectify mislabeled data without requiring model training from scratch.
AI.method: Leverages penultimate features from a trained network. Measures similarity between each data point's penultimate representation and data points of its claimed class versus other classes. If the data point lies in a tight cluster of a different class, flag as mislabeled and possibly relabel to the class with the closest cluster; builds a model-agnostic, post-hoc detector and rectifier.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show high detection performance across various label-noise levels and automatic rectification improves dataset quality.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides an effective, model-agnostic post-hoc solution for label-noise detection and correction, leveraging feature-space clustering to identify mislabeled samples and improve downstream learning.

title: Not All Tokens are Guided Equal: Improving Guidance in Visual Autoregressive Models
summary:
Autoregressive (AR) models based on next-scale prediction are rapidly
emerging as a powerful tool for image generation, but they face a critical
weakness: information inconsistencies between patches across timesteps
introduced by progressive resolution scaling. These inconsistencies scatter
guidance signals, causing them to drift away from conditioning information and
leaving behind ambiguous, unfaithful features. We tackle this challenge with
Information-Grounding Guidance (IGG), a novel mechanism that anchors guidance
to semantically important regions through attention. By adaptively reinforcing
informative patches during sampling, IGG ensures that guidance and content
remain tightly aligned. Across both class-conditioned and text-to-image
generation tasks, IGG delivers sharper, more coherent, and semantically
grounded images, setting a new benchmark for AR-based methods.

AI.tldr: IGG stabilizes AR image generation by grounding guidance in important regions through attention, reducing drift across scales and yielding sharper, more semantically faithful images.
AI.motivation: Autoregressive next-scale generation suffers from information inconsistencies between patches across timesteps due to progressive resolution scaling, which causes guidance drift and unfaithful features.
AI.method: Introduce Information-Grounding Guidance (IGG) that uses attention to identify semantically important regions and adaptively reinforce informative patches during sampling to keep guidance aligned with conditioning.
AI.result: Across class-conditioned and text-to-image tasks, IGG produces sharper, more coherent, and semantically grounded images, outperforming prior AR methods and setting a new benchmark.
AI.conclusion: IGG provides a robust mechanism to reduce drift, improve alignment between guidance and content, and enhance AR-based image generation quality.

title: Curriculum-Guided Reinforcement Learning for Synthesizing Gas-Efficient Financial Derivatives Contracts
summary:
Smart contract-based automation of financial derivatives offers substantial
efficiency gains, but its real-world adoption is constrained by the complexity
of translating financial specifications into gas-efficient executable code. In
particular, generating code that is both functionally correct and economically
viable from high-level specifications, such as the Common Domain Model (CDM),
remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a Reinforcement Learning
(RL) framework to generate functional and gas-optimized Solidity smart
contracts directly from CDM specifications. We employ a Proximal Policy
Optimization (PPO) agent that learns to select optimal code snippets from a
pre-defined library. To manage the complex search space, a two-phase curriculum
first trains the agent for functional correctness before shifting its focus to
gas optimization. Our empirical results show the RL agent learns to generate
contracts with significant gas savings, achieving cost reductions of up to
35.59% on unseen test data compared to unoptimized baselines. This work
presents a viable methodology for the automated synthesis of reliable and
economically sustainable smart contracts, bridging the gap between high-level
financial agreements and efficient on-chain execution.

AI.tldr: Reinforcement learning is used to synthesize Solidity contracts from CDM specifications, optimizing both correctness and gas usage via PPO with a two-phase curriculum, achieving substantial gas savings on unseen data.
AI.motivation: Translating high-level financial specifications (CDM) into gas-efficient, functionally correct on-chain code is difficult. Current approaches struggle to jointly ensure correctness and economic viability, hindering real-world adoption of smart-derivative automation.
AI.method: A PPO-based RL agent selects code snippets from a predefined library to implement contracts from CDM specs. Training occurs in two phases: first optimize for functional correctness, then optimize for gas efficiency. The process handles a large search space via curriculum learning.
AI.result: The agent learns to generate contracts with significant gas savings, reporting up to 35.59% cost reductions on unseen test data versus unoptimized baselines.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates a viable path for automated synthesis of reliable and economically sustainable smart contracts, bridging high-level financial agreements and efficient on-chain execution.

title: PCRI: Measuring Context Robustness in Multimodal Models for Enterprise Applications
summary:
The reliability of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in real-world
settings is often undermined by sensitivity to irrelevant or distracting visual
context, an aspect not captured by existing evaluation metrics. We introduce
the \textbf{Patch Context Robustness Index (PCRI)}, the first systematic and
interpretable score for quantifying MLLM robustness to variations in visual
context granularity, measuring performance changes between localized image
patches and full-image input.
  Applying PCRI to 19 state-of-the-art MLLMs across 15 vision-language
benchmarks, we find that most leading models remain brittle to background
noise, with only a few, such as InternVL2-26B and Qwen2VL-72B, demonstrating
consistent robustness across tasks. PCRI analysis also highlights how different
model architectures handle and integrate visual context, offering actionable
diagnostic insight for both researchers and practitioners.
  PCRI enables rigorous comparison of context robustness, supporting principled
model selection and guiding the development of future architectures and
training strategies for robust, real-world deployment.

AI.tldr: Introduces PCRI, a robustness metric for MLLMs' sensitivity to visual context; shows models often brittle to background noise; identifies a few robust models; provides diagnostic value for model selection and future design.
AI.motivation: Addresses a gap in evaluation: existing metrics overlook sensitivity to visual context granularity and background noise; a systematic, interpretable index is needed to quantify robustness across tasks.
AI.method: Define Patch Context Robustness Index (PCRI) as the performance difference when using localized image patches versus full-image inputs. Empirically evaluate 19 state-of-the-art MLLMs on 15 vision-language benchmarks to analyze how architectures handle visual context and context integration.
AI.result: Most leading models remain brittle to background noise; only a few models (e.g., InternVL2-26B, Qwen2VL-72B) show consistent robustness across tasks. PCRI provides actionable diagnostic insights for model selection and architecture/training choices.
AI.conclusion: PCRI enables principled, cross-model comparisons of context robustness and can guide future architecture design and training strategies for robust real-world deployment.

title: Guide: Generalized-Prior and Data Encoders for DAG Estimation
summary:
Modern causal discovery methods face critical limitations in scalability,
computational efficiency, and adaptability to mixed data types, as evidenced by
benchmarks on node scalability (30, $\le 50$, $\ge 70$ nodes), computational
energy demands, and continuous/non-continuous data handling. While traditional
algorithms like PC, GES, and ICA-LiNGAM struggle with these challenges,
exhibiting prohibitive energy costs for higher-order nodes and poor scalability
beyond 70 nodes, we propose \textbf{GUIDE}, a framework that integrates Large
Language Model (LLM)-generated adjacency matrices with observational data
through a dual-encoder architecture. GUIDE uniquely optimizes computational
efficiency, reducing runtime on average by $\approx 42%$ compared to RL-BIC and
KCRL methods, while achieving an average $\approx 117%$ improvement in accuracy
over both NOTEARS and GraN-DAG individually. During training, GUIDE's
reinforcement learning agent dynamically balances reward maximization
(accuracy) and penalty avoidance (DAG constraints), enabling robust performance
across mixed data types and scalability to $\ge 70$ nodes -- a setting where
baseline methods fail.

AI.tldr: GUIDE is a scalable causal-discovery framework that uses LLM-generated adjacency matrices in a dual-encoder RL setup to improve accuracy and reduce runtime, achieving 70+ node scalability and robust mixed-data handling.
AI.motivation: Modern causal discovery methods face critical bottlenecks in scalability, energy efficiency, and handling mixed data types. Benchmarks show traditional algorithms struggle beyond modest node counts and incur high energy costs.
AI.method: GUIDE couples Large Language Model (LLM)-generated adjacency matrices with observational data using a dual-encoder architecture. A reinforcement learning agent optimizes accuracy while penalizing DAG-constraint violations, enabling robust performance across mixed data types and scalable graphs (≥70 nodes).
AI.result: Runtime is reduced on average by ~42% compared to RL-BIC and KCRL. Accuracy improves by ~117% on average over NOTEARS and GraN-DAG. GUIDE maintains robust performance across mixed data types and scales to 70+ nodes, where baseline methods fail.
AI.conclusion: GUIDE demonstrates that integrating LLM-guided adjacency with an RL-based DAG learner yields scalable, energy-efficient causal discovery with superior accuracy across mixed data, addressing key limitations of traditional methods.

title: Learning Adaptive Pseudo-Label Selection for Semi-Supervised 3D Object Detection
summary:
Semi-supervised 3D object detection (SS3DOD) aims to reduce costly 3D
annotations utilizing unlabeled data. Recent studies adopt pseudo-label-based
teacher-student frameworks and demonstrate impressive performance. The main
challenge of these frameworks is in selecting high-quality pseudo-labels from
the teacher's predictions. Most previous methods, however, select pseudo-labels
by comparing confidence scores over thresholds manually set. The latest works
tackle the challenge either by dynamic thresholding or refining the quality of
pseudo-labels. Such methods still overlook contextual information e.g. object
distances, classes, and learning states, and inadequately assess the
pseudo-label quality using partial information available from the networks. In
this work, we propose a novel SS3DOD framework featuring a learnable
pseudo-labeling module designed to automatically and adaptively select
high-quality pseudo-labels. Our approach introduces two networks at the teacher
output level. These networks reliably assess the quality of pseudo-labels by
the score fusion and determine context-adaptive thresholds, which are
supervised by the alignment of pseudo-labels over GT bounding boxes.
Additionally, we introduce a soft supervision strategy that can learn robustly
under pseudo-label noises. This helps the student network prioritize cleaner
labels over noisy ones in semi-supervised learning. Extensive experiments on
the KITTI and Waymo datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our method. The
proposed method selects high-precision pseudo-labels while maintaining a wider
coverage of contexts and a higher recall rate, significantly improving relevant
SS3DOD methods.

AI.tldr: A learnable, context-aware pseudo-labeling module improves SS3DOD by adaptive thresholding and score fusion, boosting precision, coverage, and recall on KITTI/Waymo.
AI.motivation: To overcome reliance on manually set thresholds and context-agnostic pseudo-label selection in SS3DOD, which can misjudge pseudo-label quality and hurt student learning.
AI.method: Introduce two teacher-output networks that fuse scores to assess pseudo-label quality and produce context-adaptive thresholds; supervise by alignment of pseudo-labels with GT. Add soft supervision to be robust to noisy pseudo-labels, guiding the student to favor cleaner labels.
AI.result: Demonstrates effective selection of high-precision pseudo-labels with broader context coverage and higher recall on KITTI and Waymo, improving state-of-the-art SS3DOD methods.
AI.conclusion: A context-aware, learnable pseudo-labeling framework with soft supervision enhances SS3DOD by better pseudo-label quality assessment and adaptive thresholds, yielding superior performance across benchmarks.

title: Does Weak-to-strong Generalization Happen under Spurious Correlations?
summary:
We initiate a unified theoretical and algorithmic study of a key problem in
weak-to-strong (W2S) generalization: when fine-tuning a strong pre-trained
student with pseudolabels from a weaker teacher on a downstream task with
spurious correlations, does W2S happen, and how to improve it upon failures? We
consider two sources of spurious correlations caused by group imbalance: (i) a
weak teacher fine-tuned on group-imbalanced labeled data with a minority group
of fraction $\eta_\ell$, and (ii) a group-imbalanced unlabeled set
pseudolabeled by the teacher with a minority group of fraction $\eta_u$.
Theoretically, a precise characterization of W2S gain at the proportional
asymptotic limit shows that W2S always happens with sufficient pseudolabels
when $\eta_u = \eta_\ell$ but may fail when $\eta_u \ne \eta_\ell$, where W2S
gain diminishes as $(\eta_u - \eta_\ell)^2$ increases. Our theory is
corroborated by extensive experiments on various spurious correlation
benchmarks and teacher-student pairs. To boost W2S performance upon failures,
we further propose a simple, effective algorithmic remedy that retrains the
strong student on its high-confidence data subset after W2S fine-tuning. Our
algorithm is group-label-free and achieves consistent, substantial improvements
over vanilla W2S fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: W2S generalization with pseudolabels depends on group balance: it occurs when the teacher's and unlabeled data have matching minority proportions, but can fail as their mismatch grows; a simple high-confidence retraining step improves performance without needing group labels.
AI.motivation: Understanding how weak-to-strong generalization interacts with spurious correlations due to group imbalance, and providing a practical remedy to make W2S robust in real-world imbalanced settings.
AI.method: Theoretically characterize W2S gain in a proportional asymptotic limit as a function of the teacher-label minority η_l and unlabeled minority η_u; show gain is guaranteed when η_u = η_l and diminishes with (η_u−η_l)^2; validate with experiments on spurious-correlation benchmarks and various teacher–student pairs; propose a label-free retraining step on the student’s high-confidence subset after W2S fine-tuning.
AI.result: W2S gains vanish or shrink as the mismatch (η_u−η_l)^2 grows; empirical results support the theory across benchmarks and pairs; the proposed high-confidence retraining remedy yields consistent, substantial improvements over vanilla W2S without using group labels.
AI.conclusion: W2S can be reliable under matched group proportions, but fails gracefully with mismatch; a simple, group-label-free high-confidence retraining step provides a practical, effective boost to W2S in the presence of spurious correlations.

title: Tunable-Generalization Diffusion Powered by Self-Supervised Contextual Sub-Data for Low-Dose CT Reconstruction
summary:
Current models based on deep learning for low-dose CT denoising rely heavily
on paired data and generalize poorly. Even the more concerned diffusion models
need to learn the distribution of clean data for reconstruction, which is
difficult to satisfy in medical clinical applications. At the same time,
self-supervised-based methods face the challenge of significant degradation of
generalizability of models pre-trained for the current dose to expand to other
doses. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel method of
tunable-generalization diffusion powered by self-supervised contextual sub-data
for low-dose CT reconstruction, named SuperDiff. Firstly, a contextual subdata
similarity adaptive sensing strategy is designed for denoising centered on the
LDCT projection domain, which provides an initial prior for the subsequent
progress. Subsequently, the initial prior is used to combine knowledge
distillation with a deep combination of latent diffusion models for optimizing
image details. The pre-trained model is used for inference reconstruction, and
the pixel-level self-correcting fusion technique is proposed for fine-grained
reconstruction of the image domain to enhance the image fidelity, using the
initial prior and the LDCT image as a guide. In addition, the technique is
flexibly applied to the generalization of upper and lower doses or even unseen
doses. Dual-domain strategy cascade for self-supervised LDCT denoising,
SuperDiff requires only LDCT projection domain data for training and testing.
Full qualitative and quantitative evaluations on both datasets and real data
show that SuperDiff consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods
in terms of reconstruction and generalization performance.

AI.tldr: Proposes SuperDiff, a tunable-generalization diffusion framework for LDCT denoising using self-supervised contextual sub-data, achieving cross-dose generalization without requiring paired data and outperforming state-of-the-art.
AI.motivation: Current LDCT denoising methods rely on paired data or clean-data distributions and struggle to generalize across dose levels; self-supervised approaches also suffer generalization gaps. There is a need for a method that enables tunable generalization using only projection-domain data.
AI.method: Contextual subdata similarity adaptive sensing in the LDCT projection domain to provide an initial prior; combine knowledge distillation with latent diffusion models guided by the prior; use a pre-trained model for inference; pixel-level self-correcting fusion in the image domain leveraging the initial prior and LDCT image; dual-domain cascade self-supervised training using only LDCT projection-domain data, adaptable to unseen doses.
AI.result: Experimental results on multiple datasets and real data show SuperDiff consistently outperforms state-of-the-art in reconstruction quality and generalization across dose levels.
AI.conclusion: SuperDiff enables effective LDCT denoising with tunable generalization under a self-supervised diffusion framework, reducing dependence on paired data and enabling cross-dose performance.

title: SLA: Beyond Sparsity in Diffusion Transformers via Fine-Tunable Sparse-Linear Attention
summary:
In Diffusion Transformer (DiT) models, particularly for video generation,
attention latency is a major bottleneck due to the long sequence length and the
quadratic complexity. We find that attention weights can be separated into two
parts: a small fraction of large weights with high rank and the remaining
weights with very low rank. This naturally suggests applying sparse
acceleration to the first part and low-rank acceleration to the second. Based
on this finding, we propose SLA (Sparse-Linear Attention), a trainable
attention method that fuses sparse and linear attention to accelerate diffusion
models. SLA classifies attention weights into critical, marginal, and
negligible categories, applying O(N^2) attention to critical weights, O(N)
attention to marginal weights, and skipping negligible ones. SLA combines these
computations into a single GPU kernel and supports both forward and backward
passes. With only a few fine-tuning steps using SLA, DiT models achieve a 20x
reduction in attention computation, resulting in significant acceleration
without loss of generation quality. Experiments show that SLA reduces attention
computation by 95% without degrading end-to-end generation quality,
outperforming baseline methods. In addition, we implement an efficient GPU
kernel for SLA, which yields a 13.7x speedup in attention computation and a
2.2x end-to-end speedup in video generation on Wan2.1-1.3B.

AI.tldr: SLA accelerates diffusion transformer attention by fusing sparse and linear attention, achieving substantial speedups with minimal quality loss.
AI.motivation: In diffusion transformers for video generation, attention is the bottleneck due to long sequences and quadratic complexity. The authors observe that attention weights split into a small high-rank set and a large low-rank remainder, suggesting that we can selectively accelerate different parts of the attention.
AI.method: Propose Sparse-Linear Attention (SLA) that classifies attention weights into critical, marginal, and negligible; applies O(N^2) attention to critical weights, O(N) attention to marginal weights, and skips negligible ones. All computations are fused into a single GPU kernel and SLA supports forward and backward passes. The approach is trainable with a few fine-tuning steps.
AI.result: Achieves about 20× reduction in attention computation; maintains end-to-end generation quality with no degradation and outperforms baselines. An optimized GPU kernel delivers about 13.7× speedup in attention computation and 2.2× end-to-end speedup in video generation on Wan2.1-1.3B models.
AI.conclusion: SLA provides a practical, trainable fusion of sparse and low-rank attention that significantly accelerates diffusion models without sacrificing generation quality, outperforming existing baselines and enabling efficient deployment.

title: AssemblyHands-X: Modeling 3D Hand-Body Coordination for Understanding Bimanual Human Activities
summary:
Bimanual human activities inherently involve coordinated movements of both
hands and body. However, the impact of this coordination in activity
understanding has not been systematically evaluated due to the lack of suitable
datasets. Such evaluation demands kinematic-level annotations (e.g., 3D pose)
for the hands and body, yet existing 3D activity datasets typically annotate
either hand or body pose. Another line of work employs marker-based motion
capture to provide full-body pose, but the physical markers introduce visual
artifacts, thereby limiting models' generalization to natural, markerless
videos. To address these limitations, we present AssemblyHands-X, the first
markerless 3D hand-body benchmark for bimanual activities, designed to study
the effect of hand-body coordination for action recognition. We begin by
constructing a pipeline for 3D pose annotation from synchronized multi-view
videos. Our approach combines multi-view triangulation with SMPL-X mesh
fitting, yielding reliable 3D registration of hands and upper body. We then
validate different input representations (e.g., video, hand pose, body pose, or
hand-body pose) across recent action recognition models based on graph
convolution or spatio-temporal attention. Our extensive experiments show that
pose-based action inference is more efficient and accurate than video
baselines. Moreover, joint modeling of hand and body cues improves action
recognition over using hands or upper body alone, highlighting the importance
of modeling interdependent hand-body dynamics for a holistic understanding of
bimanual activities.

AI.tldr: Introduces AssemblyHands-X, a markerless 3D hand–body benchmark for bimanual activity recognition, with a 3D pose annotation pipeline; shows that pose-based representations and joint hand–body modeling outperform video-only baselines and hand- or body-only models.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of datasets with kinematic-level annotations for both hands and body; existing 3D activity datasets typically annotate only hands or only the body; marker-based motion capture introduces visual artifacts that hinder generalization to markerless videos; thus, it is necessary to study how hand–body coordination affects action understanding and to enable systematic evaluation.
AI.method: Develop AssemblyHands-X and a pipeline that combines synchronized multi-view triangulation with SMPL-X mesh fitting to annotate 3D poses of hands and upper body; evaluate multiple input representations (video, hand pose, body pose, hand–body pose) on action recognition models based on graph convolution and spatio-temporal attention.
AI.result: Pose-based action inference is more efficient and accurate than video baselines; joint modeling of hand and body cues improves recognition compared to using only hands or only the upper body, highlighting the importance of interdependent hand–body dynamics for holistic understanding of bimanual activities.
AI.conclusion: Modeling hand–body coordination is important for robust bimanual activity understanding, and AssemblyHands-X provides a markerless 3D hand–body benchmark and annotation pipeline to enable systematic evaluation of such approaches.

title: Pretraining Scaling Laws for Generative Evaluations of Language Models
summary:
Neural scaling laws have played a central role in modern machine learning,
driving the field's ever-expanding scaling of parameters, data and compute.
While much research has gone into fitting scaling laws and predicting
performance on pretraining losses and on discriminative evaluations such as
multiple-choice question-answering, comparatively little research has been done
on fitting scaling laws and predicting performance on generative evaluations
such as mathematical problem-solving or software engineering. We propose and
evaluate three different pretraining scaling laws for fitting pass-at-$k$ on
generative evaluations and for predicting pass-at-$k$ of the most expensive
model using the performance of cheaper models. Our three scaling laws differ in
the covariates used: (1) compute, (2) model parameters and tokens, (3) log
likelihoods of gold reference solutions. We make four main contributions: (1)
We show how generative evaluations offer new hyperparameters (in our setting,
$k$) that researchers can use to control the scaling laws parameters and the
predictability of performance. (2) In terms of scaling law parameters, we find
that the compute scaling law and parameters\,+\,tokens scaling law stabilize
for the last ~$1.5{-}2.5$ orders of magnitude, whereas the gold reference
likelihood scaling law stabilizes for the last ~$5$ orders of magnitude. (3) In
terms of predictive performance, we find all three scaling laws perform
comparably, although the compute scaling law predicts slightly worse for small
$k$ and the log likelihoods of gold reference solutions predicts slightly worse
for large $k$. (4) We establish a theoretical connection that the compute
scaling law emerges as the compute-optimal envelope of the
parameters-and-tokens scaling law. Our framework provides researchers and
practitioners with insights and methodologies to forecast generative
performance.

AI.tldr: Proposes and evaluates three pretraining scaling laws for generative evaluations (pass-at-k) and for predicting the performance of expensive models using cheaper ones. The three scaling laws differ in covariates: (i) compute, (ii) model parameters and tokens, (iii) log-likelihoods of gold reference solutions. Key findings: generative evaluations introduce a controllable hyperparameter k; stabilization ranges are ~1.5–2.5 orders of magnitude for compute and params+tokens, ~5 orders for gold LL; all three laws show comparable predictive performance with subtle trade-offs; compute-law emerges as the compute-optimal envelope of the parameters+tokens law; framework to forecast generative performance.
AI.motivation: Neural scaling laws have been effective for pretraining and discriminative evaluations, but less so for generative evaluations (e.g., math problem solving, software engineering). The work seeks to fit scaling laws to pass-at-k metrics on generative tasks and to predict the performance of the most expensive model from cheaper ones, enabling better forecasting and design choices for large-scale models.
AI.method: Fit three scaling laws using pass-at-k on generative evaluations, with covariates: (1) compute, (2) model parameters and tokens, (3) log-likelihoods of gold reference solutions. Evaluate predictive accuracy of each law across different k and model scales, and analyze stabilization ranges. Also establish a theoretical connection showing the compute scaling law as the envelope of the parameters+tokens scaling law.
AI.result: All three scaling laws perform comparably in predictive accuracy. The compute-law slightly underperforms for small k, and the gold-reference-log-likelihood law underperforms for large k. Stability thresholds differ: compute and parameters+tokens stabilize over the last ~1.5–2.5 orders of magnitude; gold LL stabilizes over the last ~5 orders. A theoretical link shows the compute law as the compute-optimal envelope of the parameters+tokens law.
AI.conclusion: Generative tasks benefit from scalable laws with tunable hyperparameters (k). The proposed framework enables forecasting generative performance and offers practical guidance for predicting expensive-model performance from cheaper models. The findings illuminate how different covariates shape scaling behavior and highlight that a compute-centric law can serve as an economical envelope for other approaches.

title: LifeCLEF Plant Identification Task 2015
comment:
15 pages, 4 figures, CLEF 2015 Conference and Labs of the Evaluation
  Forum, September 08 to 11, 2015, Toulouse, France
summary:
The LifeCLEF plant identification challenge aims at evaluating plant
identification methods and systems at a very large scale, close to the
conditions of a real-world biodiversity monitoring scenario. The 2015
evaluation was actually conducted on a set of more than 100K images
illustrating 1000 plant species living in West Europe. The main originality of
this dataset is that it was built through a large-scale participatory sensing
plateform initiated in 2011 and which now involves tens of thousands of
contributors. This overview presents more precisely the resources and
assessments of the challenge, summarizes the approaches and systems employed by
the participating research groups, and provides an analysis of the main
outcomes.

AI.tldr: LifeCLEF plant identification challenge (2015) evaluated plant ID methods at large scale using 100K images of 1000 West European species, built via participatory sensing; surveys resources, approaches, and outcomes.
AI.motivation: Evaluate scalable plant ID systems under realistic biodiversity monitoring conditions and leverage citizen-science data to create a large, diverse dataset.
AI.method: Provide an overview of resources and assessments; summarize participating methods and systems; analyze outcomes; describe dataset and evaluation protocol.
AI.result: A comprehensive synthesis of resources, methods, and results from the LifeCLEF 2015 plant identification challenge; insights into system performance and design choices under citizen-science data.
AI.conclusion: Participatory sensing enables large-scale evaluation and dataset growth; findings inform future plant ID research and the design of robust biodiversity monitoring tools; highlights remaining challenges.

title: GPS-MTM: Capturing Pattern of Normalcy in GPS-Trajectories with self-supervised learning
summary:
Foundation models have driven remarkable progress in text, vision, and video
understanding, and are now poised to unlock similar breakthroughs in trajectory
modeling. We introduce the GPSMasked Trajectory Transformer (GPS-MTM), a
foundation model for large-scale mobility data that captures patterns of
normalcy in human movement. Unlike prior approaches that flatten trajectories
into coordinate streams, GPS-MTM decomposes mobility into two complementary
modalities: states (point-of-interest categories) and actions (agent
transitions). Leveraging a bi-directional Transformer with a self-supervised
masked modeling objective, the model reconstructs missing segments across
modalities, enabling it to learn rich semantic correlations without manual
labels. Across benchmark datasets, including Numosim-LA, Urban Anomalies, and
Geolife, GPS-MTM consistently outperforms on downstream tasks such as
trajectory infilling and next-stop prediction. Its advantages are most
pronounced in dynamic tasks (inverse and forward dynamics), where contextual
reasoning is critical. These results establish GPS-MTM as a robust foundation
model for trajectory analytics, positioning mobility data as a first-class
modality for large-scale representation learning. Code is released for further
reference.

AI.tldr: A dual-modality trajectory foundation model (GPS-MTM) uses states (POI categories) and actions (transitions) with masked self-supervised learning to model mobility data, enabling robust trajectory infilling and next-stop prediction and strong performance on dynamic tasks.
AI.motivation: Overcome reliance on manually labeled data and flattened coordinate representations; learn rich semantic correlations in mobility patterns from large-scale data to enable robust downstream analytics.
AI.method: Bi-directional Transformer that jointly encodes states and actions, trained with a self-supervised masked modeling objective to reconstruct missing segments across modalities and learn cross-modal correlations.
AI.result: GPS-MTM outperforms baselines on trajectory infilling and next-stop prediction across Numosim-LA, Urban Anomalies, and Geolife, with especially strong performance on dynamic tasks requiring contextual reasoning (inverse/forward dynamics).
AI.conclusion: Mobility data can be treated as a first-class modality for large-scale representation learning; GPS-MTM provides a robust foundation model for trajectory analytics, and code is released for research use.

authors: Jinghan Xu Yuyang Zhang Qixuan Cai Jiancheng Chen Keqiu Li
title: Preserving Cross-Modal Stability for Visual Unlearning in Multimodal Scenarios
summary:
Visual modality is the most vulnerable to privacy leakage in real-world
multimodal applications like autonomous driving with visual and radar data;
Machine unlearning removes specific training data from pre-trained models to
address privacy leakage, however, existing methods fail to preserve cross-modal
knowledge and maintain intra-class structural stability of retain data, leading
to reduced overall and other modalities' performance during visual unlearning;
to address these challenges, we propose a Cross-modal Contrastive Unlearning
(CCU) framework, which integrates three key components: (a) selective visual
unlearning: employing inverse contrastive learning to dissociate visual
representations from their original semantics, (b) cross-modal knowledge
retention: preserving other modalities' discriminability through semantic
consistency, and (c) dual-set contrastive separation: preserving the model
performance via isolation of structural perturbations between the unlearn set
and retain set; extensive experiments on three datasets demonstrate the
superiority of CCU, and our method achieves a 7.12% accuracy improvement with
only 7% of the unlearning time compared to the top-accuracy baseline.

AI.tldr: Cross-modal Contrastive Unlearning (CCU) unlearns visual data while preserving cross-modal knowledge using inverse contrastive learning, semantic consistency, and dual-set contrastive separation; shows 7.12% accuracy gain with 7% unlearning time across three datasets.
AI.motivation: Privacy leakage in multimodal systems (vision + radar) and limitations of existing unlearning methods that harm cross-modal performance and intra-class structure.
AI.method: Three components: (a) selective visual unlearning via inverse contrastive learning to dissociate visual representations from original semantics; (b) cross-modal knowledge retention via semantic consistency to preserve other modalities' discriminability; (c) dual-set contrastive separation to isolate perturbations between unlearn and retain sets, maintaining performance.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on three datasets show CCU superiority; achieves 7.12% accuracy improvement with only 7% unlearning time relative to top-accuracy baseline.
AI.conclusion: CCU effectively unlearns targeted data while preserving cross-modal knowledge and intra-class structure, yielding better performance and efficiency; suggests strong potential for privacy-preserving multimodal learning; future work could expand to more modalities and real-world deployment.

title: Optimism as Risk-Seeking in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Risk sensitivity has become a central theme in reinforcement learning (RL),
where convex risk measures and robust formulations provide principled ways to
model preferences beyond expected return. Recent extensions to multi-agent RL
(MARL) have largely emphasized the risk-averse setting, prioritizing robustness
to uncertainty. In cooperative MARL, however, such conservatism often leads to
suboptimal equilibria, and a parallel line of work has shown that optimism can
promote cooperation. Existing optimistic methods, though effective in practice,
are typically heuristic and lack theoretical grounding. Building on the dual
representation for convex risk measures, we propose a principled framework that
interprets risk-seeking objectives as optimism. We introduce optimistic value
functions, which formalize optimism as divergence-penalized risk-seeking
evaluations. Building on this foundation, we derive a policy-gradient theorem
for optimistic value functions, including explicit formulas for the entropic
risk/KL-penalty setting, and develop decentralized optimistic actor-critic
algorithms that implement these updates. Empirical results on cooperative
benchmarks demonstrate that risk-seeking optimism consistently improves
coordination over both risk-neutral baselines and heuristic optimistic methods.
Our framework thus unifies risk-sensitive learning and optimism, offering a
theoretically grounded and practically effective approach to cooperation in
MARL.

AI.tldr: A principled framework that treats risk-seeking as optimism in cooperative MARL, introducing divergence-penalized optimistic value functions, a policy-gradient theorem, and decentralized optimistic actor-critics that improve coordination over baselines and heuristic methods.
AI.motivation: Risk sensitivity and optimism are key to effective coordination in MARL. Existing risk-averse approaches can hinder cooperation; while optimistic methods are effective, they lack theory. A principled, grounded framework to integrate risk preferences with optimism is needed.
AI.method: Leverage the dual representation of convex risk measures to interpret risk-seeking as optimism. Define optimistic value functions with divergence penalties. Derive a policy-gradient theorem for optimistic value functions, including explicit formulas for entropic risk (KL) penalties. Develop decentralized optimistic actor-critic algorithms implementing these updates.
AI.result: Empirical results on cooperative benchmarks show that risk-seeking optimism consistently improves coordination compared to risk-neutral baselines and heuristic optimistic methods.
AI.conclusion: The work unifies risk-sensitive learning and optimism into a theoretically grounded framework that enhances cooperation in MARL and provides practical algorithms with solid foundations.

title: Q-FSRU: Quantum-Augmented Frequency-Spectral For Medical Visual Question Answering
comment:
12 pages (9 main + 2 references/appendix), 2 figures, conference
  paper submitted to ICLR 2026
summary:
Solving tough clinical questions that require both image and text
understanding is still a major challenge in healthcare AI. In this work, we
propose Q-FSRU, a new model that combines Frequency Spectrum Representation and
Fusion (FSRU) with a method called Quantum Retrieval-Augmented Generation
(Quantum RAG) for medical Visual Question Answering (VQA). The model takes in
features from medical images and related text, then shifts them into the
frequency domain using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). This helps it focus on
more meaningful data and filter out noise or less useful information. To
improve accuracy and ensure that answers are based on real knowledge, we add a
quantum inspired retrieval system. It fetches useful medical facts from
external sources using quantum-based similarity techniques. These details are
then merged with the frequency-based features for stronger reasoning. We
evaluated our model using the VQA-RAD dataset, which includes real radiology
images and questions. The results showed that Q-FSRU outperforms earlier
models, especially on complex cases needing image text reasoning. The mix of
frequency and quantum information improves both performance and explainability.
Overall, this approach offers a promising way to build smart, clear, and
helpful AI tools for doctors.

AI.tldr: Q-FSRU combines FFT-based frequency spectrum representation with quantum-inspired retrieval-augmented generation for medical VQA, achieving higher accuracy and better explainability on VQA-RAD.
AI.motivation: Tackling medical VQA requires aligning image and text understanding; existing methods struggle with noise, modality gaps, and interpretability; this work aims to boost performance and transparency by leveraging frequency-domain processing and quantum-inspired knowledge retrieval.
AI.method: Introduce Q-FSRU: process image and text features into the frequency domain via FFT using Frequency Spectrum Representation and Fusion (FSRU); integrate a Quantum Retrieval-Augmented Generation (Quantum RAG) with quantum-inspired similarity to fetch external medical facts; fuse retrieved knowledge with frequency-domain features to enhance reasoning; evaluate on the VQA-RAD dataset.
AI.result: Q-FSRU outperforms prior models, particularly on complex image-text questions requiring reading and reasoning across modalities; the combination of frequency-domain representation and quantum-informed retrieval improves both accuracy and explainability.
