AI.conclusion: Frequency-domain processing plus quantum-inspired retrieval is a promising route for robust, explainable medical AI, with potential to support clinicians through clearer, more trustworthy VQA systems.

title: Collaborative Device-Cloud LLM Inference through Reinforcement Learning
comment:
We propose a unified post-training framework that integrates routing
  optimization, enabling the on-device LLM to improve its problem-solving
  ability while learning routing strategies
summary:
Device-cloud collaboration has emerged as a promising paradigm for deploying
large language models (LLMs), combining the efficiency of lightweight on-device
inference with the superior performance of powerful cloud LLMs. An essential
problem in this scenario lies in deciding whether a given query is best handled
locally or delegated to the cloud. Existing approaches typically rely on
external routers, implemented as binary classifiers, which often struggle to
determine task difficulty from the prompt's surface pattern. To address these
limitations, we propose a framework where the on-device LLM makes routing
decisions at the end of its solving process, with this capability instilled
through post-training. In particular, we formulate a reward maximization
problem with carefully designed rewards that encourage effective problem
solving and judicious offloading to the cloud. To solve this problem, we
develop a group-adaptive policy gradient algorithm, featuring a group-level
policy gradient, designed to yield an unbiased gradient estimator of the
reward, and adaptive prompt filtering, developed to enforce the constraint on
cloud LLM usage. Extensive experiments across models and benchmarks show that
the proposed methodology consistently outperforms existing baselines and
significantly narrows the gap to full cloud LLM performance.

AI.tldr: An on-device LLM learns to decide, after solving, whether to offload to cloud LLMs to balance performance and latency. It replaces external binary router with post-training routing, using reward-based learning (group-adaptive policy gradient) and adaptive prompt filtering, achieving better results and approaching full cloud performance.
AI.motivation: To reduce latency and cloud cost while preserving performance by integrating routing into the on-device model; existing routers struggle to infer task difficulty from prompt patterns.
AI.method: Post-training framework where on-device LLM makes final routing decision; formulate as reward maximization; propose group-adaptive policy gradient with group-level unbiased gradient estimation; implement adaptive prompt filtering to constrain cloud usage.
AI.result: Experiments across models and benchmarks show consistent improvement over baselines and significant narrowing of the gap to full cloud LLM performance.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enables effective on-device routing decisions, reducing unnecessary cloud usage while maintaining high performance; the method provides unbiased gradient estimation and constraints via prompt filtering.

title: LifeCLEF Plant Identification Task 2014
comment:
18 pages, 4 figures, CLEF 2014 Conference and Labs of the Evaluation
  Forum, September 15 to 18, 2014, Sheffield, United Kingdom
summary:
The LifeCLEFs plant identification task provides a testbed for a
system-oriented evaluation of plant identification about 500 species trees and
herbaceous plants. Seven types of image content are considered: scan and
scan-like pictures of leaf, and 6 kinds of detailed views with unconstrained
conditions, directly photographed on the plant: flower, fruit, stem & bark,
branch, leaf and entire view. The main originality of this data is that it was
specifically built through a citizen sciences initiative conducted by Tela
Botanica, a French social network of amateur and expert botanists. This makes
the task closer to the conditions of a real-world application. This overview
presents more precisely the resources and assessments of task, summarizes the
retrieval approaches employed by the participating groups, and provides an
analysis of the main evaluation results. With a total of ten groups from six
countries and with a total of twenty seven submitted runs, involving distinct
and original methods, this fourth year task confirms Image & Multimedia
Retrieval community interest for biodiversity and botany, and highlights
further challenging studies in plant identification.

AI.tldr: A real-world, community-driven LifeCLEFs plant ID task benchmarking multimedia-based identification of ~500 species using 7 image types; 10 international groups produced 27 runs, underscoring sustained interest and ongoing challenges.
AI.motivation: to benchmark system-oriented plant identification under realistic, citizen-science-derived conditions and advance biodiversity informatics.
AI.method: datasets: about 500 species; seven image content types including leaf scans and unconstrained views of flowers, fruits, stems, branches, leaves, entire plant. Data collected via Tela Botanica citizen-science network. Evaluation across 10 groups from 6 countries; 27 submitted runs; descriptions of retrieval approaches; analysis of results.
AI.result: confirms sustained community interest in biodiversity/botany within image & multimedia retrieval; reveals ongoing challenges in plant identification under diverse real-world conditions; diverse methods produced results across groups.
AI.conclusion: the task provides a valuable, real-world benchmark for plant identification and will continue to drive methodological advances and assessments in biodiversity informatics, with attention to challenging scenarios and scalable evaluation.

title: On The Variability of Concept Activation Vectors
comment:
26 pages (including appendix), 24 figures (44 panels). Submitted to
  AAAI-26
summary:
One of the most pressing challenges in artificial intelligence is to make
models more transparent to their users. Recently, explainable artificial
intelligence has come up with numerous method to tackle this challenge. A
promising avenue is to use concept-based explanations, that is, high-level
concepts instead of plain feature importance score. Among this class of
methods, Concept Activation vectors (CAVs), Kim et al. (2018) stands out as one
of the main protagonists. One interesting aspect of CAVs is that their
computation requires sampling random examples in the train set. Therefore, the
actual vectors obtained may vary from user to user depending on the randomness
of this sampling. In this paper, we propose a fine-grained theoretical analysis
of CAVs construction in order to quantify their variability. Our results,
confirmed by experiments on several real-life datasets, point out towards an
universal result: the variance of CAVs decreases as $1/N$, where $N$ is the
number of random examples. Based on this we give practical recommendations for
a resource-efficient application of the method.

AI.tldr: Quantifies how sampling randomness affects Concept Activation Vectors (CAVs) and shows their variance scales as 1/N, enabling resource-efficient use of CAV-based explanations.
AI.motivation: Explainable AI methods using high-level concepts (CAVs) can vary with random sampling. The paper aims to quantify this variability to improve reliability and guide practical usage.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of CAV construction to derive the variance scaling with the number of random samples N, supplemented by experiments on multiple real-world datasets to validate the theoretical result.
AI.result: The variance of CAVs decreases as 1/N; empirical validation supports the 1/N scaling. The authors provide practical recommendations for resource-efficient application of CAVs.
AI.conclusion: CAV-based explanations are subject to sampling variance, but this variance is predictable and decreases with more samples, enabling practitioners to plan data sampling to achieve desired precision and reliability.

title: EWC-Guided Diffusion Replay for Exemplar-Free Continual Learning in Medical Imaging
comment:
Accepted at AI That Keeps Up: NeurIPS 2025 Workshop on Continual and
  Compatible Foundation Model Updates
summary:
Medical imaging foundation models must adapt over time, yet full retraining
is often blocked by privacy constraints and cost. We present a continual
learning framework that avoids storing patient exemplars by pairing class
conditional diffusion replay with Elastic Weight Consolidation. Using a compact
Vision Transformer backbone, we evaluate across eight MedMNIST v2 tasks and
CheXpert. On CheXpert our approach attains 0.851 AUROC, reduces forgetting by
more than 30\% relative to DER\texttt{++}, and approaches joint training at
0.869 AUROC, while remaining efficient and privacy preserving. Analyses connect
forgetting to two measurable factors: fidelity of replay and Fisher weighted
parameter drift, highlighting the complementary roles of replay diffusion and
synaptic stability. The results indicate a practical route for scalable,
privacy aware continual adaptation of clinical imaging models.

AI.tldr: A privacy-preserving continual learning framework for medical imaging that combines class-conditional diffusion replay with Elastic Weight Consolidation to mitigate forgetting without storing patient exemplars; shows strong AUROC on CheXpert and competitive performance on MedMNIST with a compact ViT backbone, near joint training.
AI.motivation: Full retraining of medical imaging models is often blocked by privacy constraints and cost, necessitating continual adaptation without storing private patient data.
AI.method: Pair class-conditional diffusion replay with Elastic Weight Consolidation; use a compact Vision Transformer backbone; evaluate on eight MedMNIST v2 tasks and CheXpert.
AI.result: On CheXpert, AUROC 0.851; reduces forgetting by >30% relative to DER++ and approaches joint training at 0.869 AUROC; notes efficiency and privacy preservation.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a practical route for scalable, privacy-aware continual adaptation of clinical imaging models; forgetting relates to replay fidelity and Fisher-weighted parameter drift, highlighting complementary roles of replay diffusion and synaptic stability.

title: In-Context Compositional Q-Learning for Offline Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Accurately estimating the Q-function is a central challenge in offline
reinforcement learning. However, existing approaches often rely on a single
global Q-function, which struggles to capture the compositional nature of tasks
involving diverse subtasks. We propose In-context Compositional Q-Learning
(\texttt{ICQL}), the first offline RL framework that formulates Q-learning as a
contextual inference problem, using linear Transformers to adaptively infer
local Q-functions from retrieved transitions without explicit subtask labels.
Theoretically, we show that under two assumptions--linear approximability of
the local Q-function and accurate weight inference from retrieved
context--\texttt{ICQL} achieves bounded Q-function approximation error, and
supports near-optimal policy extraction. Empirically, \texttt{ICQL}
substantially improves performance in offline settings: improving performance
in kitchen tasks by up to 16.4\%, and in Gym and Adroit tasks by up to 8.6\%
and 6.3\%. These results highlight the underexplored potential of in-context
learning for robust and compositional value estimation, positioning
\texttt{ICQL} as a principled and effective framework for offline RL.

AI.tldr: ICQL reframes offline RL Q-learning as contextual inference using linear Transformers to infer local Q-functions from retrieved transitions, enabling compositional, subtask-aware value estimation without explicit labels.
AI.motivation: Single global Q-functions fail to capture task composition across diverse subtasks; offline RL needs methods that can adapt Q-functions to local context.
AI.method: Represent Q-learning as contextual inference; use linear Transformer to condition Q-function on retrieved transitions; infer local Q-functions without subtask labels; present theoretical guarantees under linear approximability and weight inference accuracy; derive bounded error and near-optimal policy extraction.
AI.result: Empirically improves offline RL performance: up to 16.4% in Kitchen tasks; up to 8.6% in Gym; up to 6.3% in Adroit; demonstrates benefits of in-context learning for robust compositional value estimation.
AI.conclusion: ICQL provides a principled framework for compositional Q-estimation in offline RL, leveraging contextual inference to adaptively compose local Q-functions from data, improving policy quality without requiring subtask annotations.

title: Adversarial Versus Federated: An Adversarial Learning based Multi-Modality Cross-Domain Federated Medical Segmentation
summary:
Federated learning enables collaborative training of machine learning models
among different clients while ensuring data privacy, emerging as the mainstream
for breaking data silos in the healthcare domain. However, the imbalance of
medical resources, data corruption or improper data preservation may lead to a
situation where different clients possess medical images of different modality.
This heterogeneity poses a significant challenge for cross-domain medical image
segmentation within the federated learning framework. To address this
challenge, we propose a new Federated Domain Adaptation (FedDA) segmentation
training framework. Specifically, we propose a feature-level adversarial
learning among clients by aligning feature maps across clients through
embedding an adversarial training mechanism. This design can enhance the
model's generalization on multiple domains and alleviate the negative impact
from domain-shift. Comprehensive experiments on three medical image datasets
demonstrate that our proposed FedDA substantially achieves cross-domain
federated aggregation, endowing single modality client with cross-modality
processing capabilities, and consistently delivers robust performance compared
to state-of-the-art federated aggregation algorithms in objective and
subjective assessment. Our code are available at
https://github.com/GGbond-study/FedDA.

AI.tldr: FedDA enables cross-domain segmentation in federated learning by adversarially aligning feature representations across clients, improving generalization across modalities.
AI.motivation: In healthcare FL, clients may hold images from different modalities due to resource imbalances or data issues, causing domain shifts that degrade segmentation performance.
AI.method: Introduce FedDA with feature-level adversarial learning to align feature maps across clients, within a federated training framework, mitigating domain shift.
AI.result: Experiments on three medical image datasets show FedDA achieves robust cross-domain federated aggregation, enabling single-modality clients to handle cross-modality data and outperform state-of-the-art federated aggregation methods.
AI.conclusion: FedDA effectively addresses cross-domain heterogeneity in federated medical image segmentation and improves cross-domain generalization; code available on GitHub.

title: A Small Math Model: Recasting Strategy Choice Theory in an LLM-Inspired Architecture
summary:
Strategy Choice Theory (SCT)\footnote{``Strategy Choice Theory'',
``Distributions of Associations'', and ``Overlapping Wave Theory'' have been
used to refer to this line of work, emphasizing different
aspects.}\citep[e.g.,][]{siegler1984strategychoices, siegler2000rebirth}
explains important aspects of children's arithmetic learning based upon
principles including learning from developmentally naturalistic data,
probabilistic representation, confidence-based retrieval, and the phase-like
importance of scaffolding strategies, such as finger-counting. Here we recast
SCT as a ``Small Math Model'' (SMM), employing a neural-network-based
architecture analogous to LLMs. The SMM extends SCT to include counting
practice\footnote{The original SCT model was pre-biased in accordance with the
supposed experience of counting.}, symbol (number) embedding, and gated
attention. Similar to earlier work, the SMM demonstrates constructive and
destructive interference between counting and addition, and the ``wave-like''
use of finger-counting as sum recall improves. We plan to extend the SMM to
later aspects of the decades-long SCT program, including adaptive strategy
choice and eventually strategy discovery, providing a unified platform to
investigate the understanding of numerical characteristics and relationships
essential for mathematical reasoning -- as it can emerge in LLM-based agents.

AI.tldr: Reframes Strategy Choice Theory as a Small Math Model (SMM) with neural-network-like components to study arithmetic learning, showing interference between counting and addition and wave-like finger-counting; plans to extend toward adaptive strategy choice and strategy discovery in LLM-based agents.
AI.motivation: To unify cognitive-development SCT with modern neural architectures, enabling investigation of numerical reasoning and strategy use in LLM-like agents.
AI.method: Introduce a neural-network–based SMM that extends SCT with counting practice, symbol (number) embeddings, and gated attention; model constructive and destructive interference between counting and addition and a wave-like finger-counting mechanism for sum recall; set the stage for adaptive strategy choice and strategy discovery.
AI.result: The SMM demonstrates constructive and destructive interference between counting and addition and shows wave-like finger-counting as a mechanism for sum recall, indicating improved numerical processing and alignment with SCT predictions.
AI.conclusion: The work plans to extend the SMM to adaptive strategy choice and strategy discovery, aiming to provide a unified platform to study numerical characteristics and relationships essential for mathematical reasoning as it may emerge in LLM-based agents.

title: EditScore: Unlocking Online RL for Image Editing via High-Fidelity Reward Modeling
comment:
Code, Models and benchmark will be publicly available at
  https://github.com/VectorSpaceLab/EditScore
summary:
Instruction-guided image editing has achieved remarkable progress, yet
current models still face challenges with complex instructions and often
require multiple samples to produce a desired result. Reinforcement Learning
(RL) offers a promising solution, but its adoption in image editing has been
severely hindered by the lack of a high-fidelity, efficient reward signal. In
this work, we present a comprehensive methodology to overcome this barrier,
centered on the development of a state-of-the-art, specialized reward model. We
first introduce EditReward-Bench, a comprehensive benchmark to systematically
evaluate reward models on editing quality. Building on this benchmark, we
develop EditScore, a series of reward models (7B-72B) for evaluating the
quality of instruction-guided image editing. Through meticulous data curation
and filtering, EditScore effectively matches the performance of learning
proprietary VLMs. Furthermore, coupled with an effective self-ensemble strategy
tailored for the generative nature of EditScore, our largest variant even
surpasses GPT-5 in the benchmark. We then demonstrate that a high-fidelity
reward model is the key to unlocking online RL for image editing. Our
experiments show that, while even the largest open-source VLMs fail to provide
an effective learning signal, EditScore enables efficient and robust policy
optimization. Applying our framework to a strong base model, OmniGen2, results
in a final model that shows a substantial and consistent performance uplift.
Overall, this work provides the first systematic path from benchmarking to
reward modeling to RL training in image editing, showing that a high-fidelity,
domain-specialized reward model is the key to unlocking the full potential of
RL in this domain.

AI.tldr: Introduces a benchmarked reward-modeling pipeline for image editing (EditReward-Bench) and a family of reward models (EditScore, 7B-72B) to enable effective online RL; demonstrates that high-fidelity, domain-specific reward models can match or surpass proprietary VLMs and unlock substantial performance gains on base models like OmniGen2.
AI.motivation: Current instruction-guided image editing struggles with complex edits and data efficiency. RL could help, but progress is blocked by the lack of high-quality, efficient reward signals. The work posits that a specialized reward model and benchmark are essential to realize RL in image editing.
AI.method: Develop EditReward-Bench to systematically evaluate reward models on editing quality. Build EditScore models (7B–72B) through curated data and filtering. Employ self-ensembling tailored for generative signals. Benchmark against proprietary VLMs like GPT-5. Apply online RL to a strong base model (OmniGen2) using EditScore as the reward signal.
AI.result: EditScore closes the gap with proprietary VLMs; the largest variant even surpasses GPT-5 on the benchmark. When used as the reward signal, it enables efficient online RL, whereas large open-source VLMs fail to provide a learning signal. The RL-enhanced OmniGen2 shows substantial and consistent performance uplift.
AI.conclusion: A high-fidelity, domain-specialized reward model is key to unlocking RL for image editing. The paper maps a complete path from benchmarking to reward modeling to RL training, highlighting the potential of RL in this domain once suitable rewards are available.

title: AQUAIR: A High-Resolution Indoor Environmental Quality Dataset for Smart Aquaculture Monitoring
comment:
6 pages, 6 figures, 3 tables. Accepted at the 9th IEEE Global
  Conference on Artificial Intelligence & Internet of Things (IEEE GCAIoT)
  2025. Final camera-ready manuscript. Math expressions in this field are
  rendered via MathJax
summary:
Smart aquaculture systems depend on rich environmental data streams to
protect fish welfare, optimize feeding, and reduce energy use. Yet public
datasets that describe the air surrounding indoor tanks remain scarce, limiting
the development of forecasting and anomaly-detection tools that couple
head-space conditions with water-quality dynamics. We therefore introduce
AQUAIR, an open-access public dataset that logs six Indoor Environmental
Quality (IEQ) variables--air temperature, relative humidity, carbon dioxide,
total volatile organic compounds, PM2.5 and PM10--inside a fish aquaculture
facility in Amghass, Azrou, Morocco. A single Awair HOME monitor sampled every
five minutes from 14 October 2024 to 9 January 2025, producing more than 23,000
time-stamped observations that are fully quality-controlled and publicly
archived on Figshare. We describe the sensor placement, ISO-compliant mounting
height, calibration checks against reference instruments, and an open-source
processing pipeline that normalizes timestamps, interpolates short gaps, and
exports analysis-ready tables. Exploratory statistics show stable conditions
(median CO2 = 758 ppm; PM2.5 = 12 micrograms/m3) with pronounced feeding-time
peaks, offering rich structure for short-horizon forecasting, event detection,
and sensor drift studies. AQUAIR thus fills a critical gap in smart aquaculture
informatics and provides a reproducible benchmark for data-centric machine
learning curricula and environmental sensing research focused on head-space
dynamics in recirculating aquaculture systems.

AI.tldr: Introduces AQUAIR, a public 6-variable head-space indoor air dataset from a Moroccan aquaculture facility, with high-frequency logging, calibration, and an open processing pipeline, enabling forecasting and anomaly detection research.
AI.motivation: Public datasets of air around indoor tanks are scarce; need head-space data to couple with water-quality dynamics for smarter aquaculture.
AI.method: Single Awair HOME monitor; sampling every 5 minutes from Oct 2024 to Jan 2025; 23k observations; ISO-compliant mounting height; calibration checks; quality control; open-source pipeline to normalize timestamps, interpolate gaps, export analysis-ready tables.
AI.result: Dataset shows stable conditions with feeding-time peaks; publicly archived on Figshare; provides a reproducible benchmark for ML curricula and sensing research in recirculating aquaculture systems.
AI.conclusion: Fills gap in smart aquaculture informatics; enables short-horizon forecasting, event detection, sensor drift studies; supports head-space dynamics research.

title: MoReact: Generating Reactive Motion from Textual Descriptions
comment: Published in Transactions on Machine Learning Research
summary:
Modeling and generating human reactions poses a significant challenge with
broad applications for computer vision and human-computer interaction. Existing
methods either treat multiple individuals as a single entity, directly
generating interactions, or rely solely on one person's motion to generate the
other's reaction, failing to integrate the rich semantic information that
underpins human interactions. Yet, these methods often fall short in adaptive
responsiveness, i.e., the ability to accurately respond to diverse and dynamic
interaction scenarios. Recognizing this gap, our work introduces an approach
tailored to address the limitations of existing models by focusing on
text-driven human reaction generation. Our model specifically generates
realistic motion sequences for individuals that responding to the other's
actions based on a descriptive text of the interaction scenario. The goal is to
produce motion sequences that not only complement the opponent's movements but
also semantically fit the described interactions. To achieve this, we present
MoReact, a diffusion-based method designed to disentangle the generation of
global trajectories and local motions sequentially. This approach stems from
the observation that generating global trajectories first is crucial for
guiding local motion, ensuring better alignment with given action and text.
Furthermore, we introduce a novel interaction loss to enhance the realism of
generated close interactions. Our experiments, utilizing data adapted from a
two-person motion dataset, demonstrate the efficacy of our approach for this
novel task, which is capable of producing realistic, diverse, and controllable
reactions that not only closely match the movements of the counterpart but also
adhere to the textual guidance. Please find our webpage at
https://xiyan-xu.github.io/MoReactWebPage.

AI.tldr: MoReact is a diffusion-based method for text-driven human reaction generation that disentangles global trajectory from local motion to produce realistic, diverse, and text-consistent reactions, addressing limitations of existing single- versus dual-entity approaches and introducing a novel interaction loss to improve close interactions.
AI.motivation: Existing methods either treat multiple individuals as a single entity or rely on one person's motion to generate the other's reaction, lacking adaptive responsiveness and semantic integration of interactions. There is a need for models that can respond to diverse, dynamic interaction scenarios with semantic guidance from text.
AI.method: MoReact disentangles generation into two stages: first generate global trajectories guided by both the counterpart's actions and a descriptive text, then generate local motions conditioned on the global path. It is diffusion-based and includes a novel interaction loss to enhance realism in close interactions; experiments are conducted on data adapted from a two-person motion dataset, with a dedicated webpage.
AI.result: The approach yields realistic, diverse, and controllable reactions that closely match the counterpart's movements while adhering to the textual guidance, demonstrating efficacy on the adapted two-person motion dataset.
AI.conclusion: The method addresses limitations of prior work by separating global and local generation guided by text, achieving better alignment with actions and textual descriptions, and enabling adaptive, semantically coherent reactions in interaction scenarios.

title: A Family of Kernelized Matrix Costs for Multiple-Output Mixture Neural Networks
summary:
Pairwise distance-based costs are crucial for self-supervised and contrastive
feature learning. Mixture Density Networks (MDNs) are a widely used approach
for generative models and density approximation, using neural networks to
produce multiple centers that define a Gaussian mixture. By combining MDNs with
contrastive costs, this paper proposes data density approximation using four
types of kernelized matrix costs: the scalar cost, the vector-matrix cost, the
matrix-matrix cost (the trace of Schur complement), and the SVD cost (the
nuclear norm), for learning multiple centers required to define a mixture
density.

AI.tldr: Combines mixture density networks with contrastive losses by using four kernelized matrix costs to learn multiple centers for Gaussian mixtures in self-supervised learning.
AI.motivation: Pairwise distance-based costs are crucial for self-supervised and contrastive feature learning. MDNs provide a way to model density via multiple centers. Integrating MDNs with contrastive costs aims to better approximate data density and improve representations.
AI.method: Introduce four kernelized matrix costs within an MDN-contrastive framework: scalar cost, vector-matrix cost, matrix-matrix cost (trace of Schur complement), and SVD cost (nuclear norm) to learn multiple centers defining a mixture density.
AI.result: Proposes a data-density approximation framework that leverages the four kernelized matrix costs to learn multiple centers for a Gaussian mixture density in a contrastive/self-supervised setting.
AI.conclusion: Kernelized matrix costs offer flexible, expressive measures to learn mixture centers, enabling effective data-density estimation within MDN-based approaches for self-supervised and contrastive learning.

title: Revisit the Imbalance Optimization in Multi-task Learning: An Experimental Analysis
summary:
Multi-task learning (MTL) aims to build general-purpose vision systems by
training a single network to perform multiple tasks jointly. While promising,
its potential is often hindered by "unbalanced optimization", where task
interference leads to subpar performance compared to single-task models. To
facilitate research in MTL, this paper presents a systematic experimental
analysis to dissect the factors contributing to this persistent problem. Our
investigation confirms that the performance of existing optimization methods
varies inconsistently across datasets, and advanced architectures still rely on
costly grid-searched loss weights. Furthermore, we show that while powerful
Vision Foundation Models (VFMs) provide strong initialization, they do not
inherently resolve the optimization imbalance, and merely increasing data
quantity offers limited benefits. A crucial finding emerges from our analysis:
a strong correlation exists between the optimization imbalance and the norm of
task-specific gradients. We demonstrate that this insight is directly
applicable, showing that a straightforward strategy of scaling task losses
according to their gradient norms can achieve performance comparable to that of
an extensive and computationally expensive grid search. Our comprehensive
analysis suggests that understanding and controlling gradient dynamics is a
more direct path to stable MTL than developing increasingly complex methods.

AI.tldr: Gradient-norm based loss scaling can balance multi-task optimization without grid search, by aligning task gradients rather than adding complexity.
AI.motivation: Unbalanced optimization in multi-task learning (MTL) degrades performance; existing optimization methods vary across datasets and rely on costly loss-weight grid searches. VFMs help initialization but don’t fix imbalance; more data is not a universal remedy.
AI.method: Systematic experimental analysis across datasets to identify factors behind optimization imbalance, evaluate existing loss-weighting methods and VC/ViGFs, analyze gradient norms of tasks, and test a gradient-norm based scaling strategy against grid-search baselines.
AI.result: Found that optimization methods perform inconsistently across datasets; advanced architectures still require grid-searched loss weights; Vision Foundation Models provide good initialization but do not resolve imbalance; simply increasing data offers limited benefit; a strong correlation exists between optimization imbalance and the gradient-norms of task-specific losses; scaling losses by their gradient norms achieves performance close to grid-search optimization.
AI.conclusion: Understanding and controlling gradient dynamics offers a more direct path to stable MTL than increasingly complex methods; gradient-norm-based loss scaling is an effective, practical remedy to optimization imbalance in MTL.

title: Demographic-Agnostic Fairness without Harm
summary:
As machine learning (ML) algorithms are increasingly used in social domains
to make predictions about humans, there is a growing concern that these
algorithms may exhibit biases against certain social groups. Numerous notions
of fairness have been proposed in the literature to measure the unfairness of
ML. Among them, one class that receives the most attention is
\textit{parity-based}, i.e., achieving fairness by equalizing treatment or
outcomes for different social groups. However, achieving parity-based fairness
often comes at the cost of lowering model accuracy and is undesirable for many
high-stakes domains like healthcare. To avoid inferior accuracy, a line of
research focuses on \textit{preference-based} fairness, under which any group
of individuals would experience the highest accuracy and collectively prefer
the ML outcomes assigned to them if they were given the choice between various
sets of outcomes. However, these works assume individual demographic
information is known and fully accessible during training. In this paper, we
relax this requirement and propose a novel \textit{demographic-agnostic
fairness without harm (DAFH)} optimization algorithm, which jointly learns a
group classifier that partitions the population into multiple groups and a set
of decoupled classifiers associated with these groups. Theoretically, we
conduct sample complexity analysis and show that our method can outperform the
baselines when demographic information is known and used to train decoupled
classifiers. Experiments on both synthetic and real data validate the proposed
method.

AI.tldr: Proposes a demographic-agnostic fairness framework (DAFH) that jointly learns a population group splitter and per-group classifiers to achieve preference-based fairness without demographic data; backed by a theoretical sample complexity analysis and validated via synthetic and real-data experiments, with potential outperformance over baselines that use demographic info.
AI.motivation: Addresses fairness in ML for social-domain predictions, highlighting the tension between parity-based fairness (which can hurt accuracy) and the desire for accuracy-preserving fairness. Aims to relax the need for explicit demographic data while still achieving favorable fairness/accuracy trade-offs.
AI.method: Introduce DAFH: jointly learn a group classifier to partition the population into multiple groups and train decoupled classifiers for each group. Operates in a demographic-agnostic setting (no access to individual demographics during training). Provides sample complexity analysis and demonstrates improvements over baselines when demographic information is known, supported by experiments on synthetic and real datasets.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows favorable sample complexity and potential to outperform baselines under certain conditions. Empirical results on synthetic and real data validate the method, indicating effective fairness-accuracy trade-offs without requiring demographic data.
AI.conclusion: DAFH offers a viable approach to achieving preference-based fairness without explicit demographic attributes, balancing fairness and accuracy in high-stakes domains. Further work could explore robustness, scalability, and sensitivity to the learned grouping.

title: Bridging the Task Gap: Multi-Task Adversarial Transferability in CLIP and Its Derivatives
summary:
As a general-purpose vision-language pretraining model, CLIP demonstrates
strong generalization ability in image-text alignment tasks and has been widely
adopted in downstream applications such as image classification and image-text
retrieval. However, it struggles with fine-grained tasks such as object
detection and semantic segmentation. While many variants aim to improve CLIP on
these tasks, its robustness to adversarial perturbations remains underexplored.
Understanding how adversarial examples transfer across tasks is key to
assessing CLIP's generalization limits and security risks. In this work, we
conduct a systematic empirical analysis of the cross-task transfer behavior of
CLIP-based models on image-text retrieval, object detection, and semantic
segmentation under adversarial perturbations. We find that adversarial examples
generated from fine-grained tasks (e.g., object detection and semantic
segmentation) often exhibit stronger transfer potential than those from
coarse-grained tasks, enabling more effective attacks against the original CLIP
model. Motivated by this observation, we propose a novel framework, Multi-Task
Adversarial CLIP (MT-AdvCLIP), which introduces a task-aware feature
aggregation loss and generates perturbations with enhanced cross-task
generalization capability. This design strengthens the attack effectiveness of
fine-grained task models on the shared CLIP backbone. Experimental results on
multiple public datasets show that MT-AdvCLIP significantly improves the
adversarial transfer success rate (The average attack success rate across
multiple tasks is improved by over 39%.) against various CLIP-derived models,
without increasing the perturbation budget. This study reveals the transfer
mechanism of adversarial examples in multi-task CLIP models, offering new
insights into multi-task robustness evaluation and adversarial example design.

AI.tldr: MT-AdvCLIP enhances cross-task adversarial transfer in multi-task CLIP by using a task-aware feature aggregation loss to generate perturbations that transfer from fine-grained tasks (detection/segmentation) to the CLIP backbone, improving attack success across image-text retrieval, detection, and segmentation by ~39% on public datasets, without increasing perturbation budget.
AI.motivation: Assess CLIP's robustness and generalization limits across tasks under adversarial perturbations; understand how adversarial examples transfer between coarse-grained (image-text) and fine-grained (detection/segmentation) tasks.
AI.method: Propose Multi-Task Adversarial CLIP (MT-AdvCLIP) with task-aware feature aggregation loss; generate perturbations with enhanced cross-task generalization; evaluate on multiple datasets against CLIP-derived models.
AI.result: Adversarial transfer success rate increased by over 39% on average across multiple tasks; effectiveness persists without extra perturbation budget; demonstrated on public datasets.
AI.conclusion: Reveals cross-task transfer mechanisms in multi-task CLIP models; highlights implications for multi-task robustness evaluation and adversarial example design; motivates more robust defenses and careful evaluation in cross-task settings.

title: PEARL: Peer-Enhanced Adaptive Radio via On-Device LLM
summary:
We present PEARL (Peer-Enhanced Adaptive Radio via On-Device LLM), a
framework for cooperative cross-layer optimization in device-to-device (D2D)
communication. Building on our previous work on single-device on-device LLMs,
PEARL extends the paradigm by leveraging both publisher and subscriber states
to guide Wi-Fi Aware (WA) parameter selection. A context-aware reward, which
normalizes latency by application tolerances and modulates energy by device
battery states, provides richer supervision for KL-based finetuning. We study
two lightweight variants: PEARL (Head + Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)) achieves
the best overall performance, while PEARL-Lite (Head-only) delivers sub-20 ms
inference at near-identical objective scores. Across synthetic scenarios
grounded in real measurements, PEARL improves objective scores over heuristic
and compact model baselines and reduces energy by up to 16% in cooperative
low-battery cases. These results demonstrate that peer-aware context,
reward-aligned training, and head-based efficiency make LLMs practical for
always-on, on-device cross-layer control.

AI.tldr: PEARL uses peer-aware on-device LLMs to adapt Wi-Fi Aware cross-layer parameters for D2D, with two lightweight variants; achieves near-20 ms inference and energy savings while improving objective scores over baselines.
AI.motivation: To enable cooperative, context-aware cross-layer optimization in D2D communications by leveraging both publisher and subscriber peer states and on-device LLMs for adaptive parameter tuning.
AI.method: Introduce PEARL framework; use KL-based finetuning on a context-aware reward that normalizes latency by application tolerances and modulates energy by battery; implement two lightweight variants: PEARL (Head + LoRA) and PEARL-Lite (Head-only); evaluate across synthetic scenarios grounded in real measurements.
AI.result: PEARL improves objective scores over heuristic and compact baselines and reduces energy by up to 16% in low-battery cases; PEARL-Lite achieves sub-20 ms inference with near-identical objective scores; PEARL (Head + LoRA) offers best overall performance.
AI.conclusion: Peer-aware context and reward-aligned, head-based fine-tuning make LLM-based cross-layer control practical for always-on, on-device D2D optimization.

title: Token Painter: Training-Free Text-Guided Image Inpainting via Mask Autoregressive Models
summary:
Text-guided image inpainting aims to inpaint masked image regions based on a
textual prompt while preserving the background. Although diffusion-based
methods have become dominant, their property of modeling the entire image in
latent space makes it challenging for the results to align well with prompt
details and maintain a consistent background. To address these issues, we
explore Mask AutoRegressive (MAR) models for this task. MAR naturally supports
image inpainting by generating latent tokens corresponding to mask regions,
enabling better local controllability without altering the background. However,
directly applying MAR to this task makes the inpainting content either ignore
the prompts or be disharmonious with the background context. Through analysis
of the attention maps from the inpainting images, we identify the impact of
background tokens on text tokens during the MAR generation, and leverage this
to design \textbf{Token Painter}, a training-free text-guided image inpainting
method based on MAR. Our approach introduces two key components: (1)
Dual-Stream Encoder Information Fusion (DEIF), which fuses the semantic and
context information from text and background in frequency domain to produce
novel guidance tokens, allowing MAR to generate text-faithful inpainting
content while keeping harmonious with background context. (2) Adaptive Decoder
Attention Score Enhancing (ADAE), which adaptively enhances attention scores on
guidance tokens and inpainting tokens to further enhance the alignment of
prompt details and the content visual quality. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our training-free method outperforms prior state-of-the-art
methods across almost all metrics and delivers superior visual results. Codes
will be released.

AI.tldr: Training-free Token Painter for text-guided image inpainting using Mask AutoRegressive models; introduces DEIF and ADAE to fuse text/background and adapt attention, achieving state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Diffusion-based inpainting models struggle to align fine-grained prompt details and maintain a consistent background due to whole-image latent modeling. MAR offers latent-token generation for localized inpainting, but naive MAR can ignore prompts or clash with background. Resolving prompt fidelity with background harmony in a training-free framework motivates this work.
AI.method: Propose Token Painter on MAR. Introduce two modules: (1) Dual-Stream Encoder Information Fusion (DEIF) to fuse semantic/text and background context in the frequency domain, producing novel guidance tokens; (2) Adaptive Decoder Attention Score Enhancing (ADAE) to dynamically boost attention on guidance and inpainting tokens during decoding. The approach is training-free.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show the method outperforms prior state-of-the-art across almost all metrics, delivering superior visual quality and prompt fidelity; code will be released.
AI.conclusion: Token Painter enables effective text-guided inpainting with MAR by achieving better prompt alignment and background harmony without training, thanks to the DEIF and ADAE modules that leverage background influence on text tokens and adaptive attention control.

title: ADAPT: Lightweight, Long-Range Machine Learning Force Fields Without Graphs
comment: 14 total pages of main content, 4 of references, 3 in Appendix
summary:
Point defects play a central role in driving the properties of materials.
First-principles methods are widely used to compute defect energetics and
structures, including at scale for high-throughput defect databases. However,
these methods are computationally expensive, making machine-learning force
fields (MLFFs) an attractive alternative for accelerating structural
relaxations. Most existing MLFFs are based on graph neural networks (GNNs),
which can suffer from oversmoothing and poor representation of long-range
interactions. Both of these issues are especially of concern when modeling
point defects. To address these challenges, we introduce the Accelerated Deep
Atomic Potential Transformer (ADAPT), an MLFF that replaces graph
representations with a direct coordinates-in-space formulation and explicitly
considers all pairwise atomic interactions. Atoms are treated as tokens, with a
Transformer encoder modeling their interactions. Applied to a dataset of
silicon point defects, ADAPT achieves a roughly 33 percent reduction in both
force and energy prediction errors relative to a state-of-the-art GNN-based
model, while requiring only a fraction of the computational cost.

AI.tldr: ADAPT introduces a coordinates-based transformer MLFF for point defects that outperforms GNNs in accuracy and is computationally cheaper.
AI.motivation: Defect energetics drive materials properties; first-principles defect calculations are expensive; ML force fields offer speed, but GNNs can suffer from oversmoothing and poor long-range interaction modeling, especially for defects.
AI.method: Atoms are treated as tokens; all pairwise atomic interactions are explicitly considered; a Transformer encoder models their interactions in a coordinates-in-space formulation, replacing graph-based representations; applied to silicon point defects.
AI.result: ~33% reduction in both force and energy prediction errors relative to a state-of-the-art GNN model, with substantially lower computational cost.
AI.conclusion: A coordinates-based Transformer MLFF (ADAPT) mitigates oversmoothing and long-range interaction issues common in GNNs for defect modeling, enabling faster and more accurate defect simulations and potentially benefiting high-throughput defect databases.

title: Learning Encoding-Decoding Direction Pairs to Unveil Concepts of Influence in Deep Vision Networks
comment:
80 Pages. The paper's abstract was shortened to fit the character
  limit
summary:
Empirical evidence shows that deep vision networks represent concepts as
directions in latent space, vectors we call concept embeddings. Each concept
has a latent factor-a scalar-indicating its presence in an input patch. For a
given patch, multiple latent factors are encoded into a compact representation
by linearly combining concept embeddings, with the factors as coefficients.
Since these embeddings enable such encoding, we call them encoding directions.
A latent factor can be recovered via the inner product with a filter, a vector
we call a decoding direction. These encoding-decoding direction pairs are not
directly accessible, but recovering them helps open the black box of deep
networks, enabling understanding, debugging, and improving models. Decoder
directions attribute meaning to latent codes, while encoding directions assess
concept influence on predictions, with both enabling model correction by
unlearning irrelevant concepts. Unlike prior matrix decomposition, autoencoder,
or dictionary learning methods that rely on feature reconstruction, we propose
a new perspective: decoding directions are identified via directional
clustering of activations, and encoding directions are estimated with signal
vectors under a probabilistic view. We further leverage network weights through
a novel technique, Uncertainty Region Alignment, which reveals interpretable
directions affecting predictions. Our analysis shows that (a) on synthetic
data, our method recovers ground-truth direction pairs; (b) on real data,
decoding directions map to monosemantic, interpretable concepts and outperform
unsupervised baselines; and (c) signal vectors faithfully estimate encoding
directions, validated via activation maximization. Finally, we demonstrate
applications in understanding global model behavior, explaining individual
predictions, and intervening to produce counterfactuals or correct errors.

AI.tldr: Proposes decoding/encoding directions for vision networks: decoding directions via directional clustering of activations; encoding directions via probabilistic signal vectors; leverages Uncertainty Region Alignment to exploit network weights; demonstrates ground-truth recovery on synthetic data and interpretable monosemantic concepts on real data; enables explanations and counterfactual interventions.
AI.motivation: Improve interpretability of deep vision models by identifying latent concept directions beyond traditional reconstruction-based methods; uncover and align encoding and decoding directions to understand predictions and enable interventions.
AI.method: 1) Identify decoding directions by clustering activation directions in hidden representations; 2) estimate encoding directions as signal vectors under a probabilistic framework; 3) incorporate Uncertainty Region Alignment to leverage model weights for finding interpretable directions; 4) validate on synthetic data (ground-truth recovery) and real data (semantic concepts) and compare to unsupervised baselines; 5) use activation maximization to validate encoding directions; 6) demonstrate applications in explanation, debugging, counterfactuals.
AI.result: (a) On synthetic data, the method recovers ground-truth direction pairs; (b) on real data, decoding directions map to interpretable, monosemantic concepts and outperform unsupervised baselines; (c) signal vectors reliably estimate encoding directions, confirmed by activation maximization.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers interpretable directions that illuminate global model behavior and support explaining individual predictions, with practical interventions to counteract errors or produce counterfactuals, advancing beyond reconstruction-based interpretability methods.

title: GeoFunFlow: Geometric Function Flow Matching for Inverse Operator Learning over Complex Geometries
summary:
Inverse problems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs) are
crucial in science and engineering. They are particularly challenging due to
ill-posedness, data sparsity, and the added complexity of irregular geometries.
Classical PDE-constrained optimization methods are computationally expensive,
especially when repeated posterior sampling is required. Learning-based
approaches improve efficiency and scalability, yet most are designed for
regular domains or focus on forward modeling. Here, we introduce {\em
GeoFunFlow}, a geometric diffusion model framework for inverse problems on
complex geometries. GeoFunFlow combines a novel geometric function autoencoder
(GeoFAE) and a latent diffusion model trained via rectified flow. GeoFAE
employs a Perceiver module to process unstructured meshes of varying sizes and
produces continuous reconstructions of physical fields, while the diffusion
model enables posterior sampling from sparse and noisy data. Across five
benchmarks, GeoFunFlow achieves state-of-the-art reconstruction accuracy over
complex geometries, provides calibrated uncertainty quantification, and
delivers efficient inference compared to operator-learning and diffusion model
baselines.

AI.tldr: GeoFunFlow is a geometry-aware diffusion framework for inverse PDE problems on complex domains, integrating a geometric function autoencoder (GeoFAE) with a latent diffusion model to enable accurate reconstructions, calibrated uncertainty, and efficient posterior sampling on unstructured meshes.
AI.motivation: Inverse PDE problems are ill-posed, data-sparse, and involve irregular geometries, making classical PDE-constrained optimization expensive. Most learning-based methods struggle with irregular domains or forward-only objectives; there is a need for geometry-aware, efficient inference with uncertainty quantification.
AI.method: GeoFunFlow combines a geometric function autoencoder (GeoFAE) that uses a Perceiver module to process unstructured meshes of varying sizes and outputs continuous field reconstructions, with a latent diffusion model trained via rectified flow to enable posterior sampling from sparse and noisy data. Evaluated on five benchmarks, it aims to achieve high reconstruction accuracy on complex geometries while providing calibrated uncertainty and efficient inference.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art reconstruction accuracy on complex geometries, provides calibrated uncertainty quantification, and offers efficient inference relative to operator-learning and diffusion-model baselines across five benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: GeoFunFlow advances geometry-aware inverse problems by marrying a geometry-capable autoencoder with diffusion-based posterior sampling, enabling accurate and uncertainty-aware reconstructions on irregular geometries with improved efficiency over existing baselines.

title: SAR-KnowLIP: Towards Multimodal Foundation Models for Remote Sensing
summary:
Cross-modal artificial intelligence has garnered widespread attention in
recent years, achieving significant progress in the study of natural images.
However, existing methods are mostly designed for RGB imagery, leaving a
significant gap in modeling synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery. SAR, with
its all-day, all-weather imaging capabilities, plays an irreplaceable role in
remote sensing scene understanding. To address this gap, this paper proposes
SAR-KnowLIP, the first universal SAR multimodal foundational model, along with
reusable data and evaluation baselines. Specifically: (1) This work introduces
the critical yet long-overlooked attribute of geographic information into
remote sensing research, constructing SAR-GEOVL-1M (the first large-scale SAR
dataset with complete geographic projection properties), covering multiple
satellite platforms, 120,000 images, and 135 cities. (2) Aligned structured
text is generated through a hierarchical cognitive chain-of-thought (HCoT),
providing more than one million multi-dimensional semantic annotations of
landforms, regional functions, target attributes, and spatial relationships.
(3) We design a Self-Consistent Iterative Optimization mechanism that
continuously enhances cross-modal alignment through a self-supervised closed
loop of contrastive, matching, and reconstruction learning on a transferable
multimodal encoder. (4) A unified evaluation benchmark is established across 11
representative downstream vision and vision-language tasks, with comparisons
against 14 leading foundation models, where SAR-KnowLIP demonstrates leading
performance, particularly in object counting and land-cover classification. We
expect that SAR-KnowLIP's large-scale multimodal data, transferable model
architecture, and comprehensive experimental benchmark will significantly
advance the development of SAR multimodal baseline models.

AI.tldr: SAR-KnowLIP: a universal SAR multimodal foundation model built on a large-scale SAR dataset with geographic projections, HCoT annotations, and a self-consistent optimization loop; shows strong performance on 11 downstream tasks and 14 baselines.
AI.motivation: Addresses lack of cross-modal SAR modeling; leverages SAR's all-weather imaging and geographic information; aims to provide a scalable data- and model- backbone and a unified evaluation baseline.
AI.method: Dataset: SAR-GEOVL-1M with 120k images from multiple platforms across 135 cities; Text annotations via hierarchical cognitive chain-of-thought (HCoT) producing >1M semantic labels; Model training uses Self-Consistent Iterative Optimization integrating contrastive, matching, and reconstruction objectives on a transferable multimodal encoder; Benchmark across 11 tasks and 14 foundation models.
AI.result: SAR-KnowLIP achieves leading performance, notably in object counting and land-cover classification, demonstrating strong cross-modal alignment and transferability.
AI.conclusion: This work advances SAR multimodal AI by providing a large-scale dataset, a transferable model architecture, and a comprehensive benchmark, accelerating development of SAR multimodal foundational models.

title: HyMaTE: A Hybrid Mamba and Transformer Model for EHR Representation Learning
summary:
Electronic health Records (EHRs) have become a cornerstone in modern-day
healthcare. They are a crucial part for analyzing the progression of patient
health; however, their complexity, characterized by long, multivariate
sequences, sparsity, and missing values poses significant challenges in
traditional deep learning modeling. While Transformer-based models have
demonstrated success in modeling EHR data and predicting clinical outcomes,
their quadratic computational complexity and limited context length hinder
their efficiency and practical applications. On the other hand, State Space
Models (SSMs) like Mamba present a promising alternative offering linear-time
sequence modeling and improved efficiency for handling long sequences, but
focus mostly on mixing sequence-level information rather than channel-level
data. To overcome these challenges, we propose HyMaTE (A Hybrid Mamba and
Transformer Model for EHR Representation Learning), a novel hybrid model
tailored for representing longitudinal data, combining the strengths of SSMs
with advanced attention mechanisms. By testing the model on predictive tasks on
multiple clinical datasets, we demonstrate HyMaTE's ability to capture an
effective, richer, and more nuanced unified representation of EHR data.
Additionally, the interpretability of the outcomes achieved by self-attention
illustrates the effectiveness of our model as a scalable and generalizable
solution for real-world healthcare applications. Codes are available at:
https://github.com/healthylaife/HyMaTE.

AI.tldr: HyMaTE is a hybrid Mamba (SSM) and Transformer model designed for long, multivariate EHR sequences, combining linear-time sequence modeling with advanced attention to produce richer, more interpretable representations and improve predictive performance.
AI.motivation: EHR data are long, multivariate, sparse, and riddled with missing values; standard Transformers have quadratic complexity and limited context length, hindering scalability. SSMs like Mamba offer linear-time sequence modeling but focus on sequence-level rather than channel-level information. A hybrid approach aims to exploit the strengths of both to efficiently model long-term dependencies and channel-wise data in EHRs.
AI.method: Introduce HyMaTE, a hybrid model that integrates Mamba-like state-space modeling with Transformer-style attention mechanisms to capture long-range dependencies across channels in longitudinal EHR data. The model aims to produce unified, rich representations, with interpretability from self-attention. The approach is tested on multiple clinical datasets for predictive tasks, and code is released.
AI.result: HyMaTE demonstrates the ability to produce effective, richer, and more nuanced representations of EHR data, achieving competitive predictive performance while maintaining efficiency for long sequences. Self-attention-based interpretability provides insights into model decisions.
AI.conclusion: HyMaTE offers a scalable, generalizable solution for real-world healthcare applications by combining the efficiency of state-space models with the expressive power and interpretability of attention mechanisms. The work provides code for replication at the linked GitHub repository.

title: AutoPrune: Each Complexity Deserves a Pruning Policy
summary:
The established redundancy in visual tokens within large vision-language
models allows pruning to effectively reduce their substantial computational
demands. Previous methods typically employ heuristic layer-specific pruning
strategies where, although the number of tokens removed may differ across
decoder layers, the overall pruning schedule is fixed and applied uniformly to
all input samples and tasks, failing to align token elimination with the
model's holistic reasoning trajectory. Cognitive science indicates that human
visual processing often begins with broad exploration to accumulate evidence
before narrowing focus as the target becomes distinct. Our experiments reveal
an analogous pattern in these models. This observation suggests that neither a
fixed pruning schedule nor a heuristic layer-wise strategy can optimally
accommodate the diverse complexities inherent in different inputs. To overcome
this limitation, we introduce Complexity-Adaptive Pruning (AutoPrune), a
training-free, plug-and-play framework that tailors pruning policies to varying
sample and task complexities. Specifically, AutoPrune quantifies the mutual
information between visual and textual tokens, then projects this signal to a
budget-constrained logistic retention curve. Each such logistic curve, defined
by its unique shape, corresponds to the specific complexity of different tasks
and can guarantee adherence to predefined computational constraints. We
evaluate AutoPrune on standard vision-language tasks and on
Vision-Language-Action models for autonomous driving. Notably, when applied to
LLaVA-1.5-7B, our method prunes 89% of visual tokens and reduces inference
FLOPs by 76.8% while retaining 96.7% of the original accuracy averaged over all
tasks. This corresponds to a 9.1% improvement over the recent work PDrop,
demonstrating the effectiveness. Code is available at
https://github.com/AutoLab-SAI-SJTU/AutoPrune.

AI.tldr: AutoPrune is a training-free, complexity-adaptive token pruning method for vision-language models that uses mutual information to drive per-task logistic retention curves under a compute budget, achieving large token reduction with minimal accuracy loss and outperforming prior methods like PDrop.
AI.motivation: Fixed pruning schedules and layer-wise heuristics fail to match the varying input/task complexities in vision-language models. Inspired by human visual processing, the approach seeks to align pruning with the model's holistic reasoning trajectory to reduce compute while preserving performance.
AI.method: Compute the mutual information between visual and textual tokens and map this signal to a budget-constrained logistic retention curve. Each curve is tailored to a specific task complexity, guaranteeing adherence to a predefined computational budget. It is training-free and plug-and-play, applied to models like LLaVA-1.5-7B, and evaluated on standard vision-language and Vision-Language-Action tasks. Code is released.
AI.result: On LLaVA-1.5-7B, AutoPrune prunes 89% of visual tokens and reduces inference FLOPs by 76.8% while retaining 96.7% of original accuracy averaged across tasks, outperforming PDrop by 9.1%.
AI.conclusion: Complexity-adaptive pruning is effective and practical, offering substantial compute savings with minimal accuracy loss without retraining, and is broadly applicable across V-L tasks.

title: Echo Flow Networks
summary:
At the heart of time-series forecasting (TSF) lies a fundamental challenge:
how can models efficiently and effectively capture long-range temporal
dependencies across ever-growing sequences? While deep learning has brought
notable progress, conventional architectures often face a trade-off between
computational complexity and their ability to retain accumulative information
over extended horizons.
  Echo State Networks (ESNs), a class of reservoir computing models, have
recently regained attention for their exceptional efficiency, offering constant
memory usage and per-step training complexity regardless of input length. This
makes them particularly attractive for modeling extremely long-term event
history in TSF. However, traditional ESNs fall short of state-of-the-art
performance due to their limited nonlinear capacity, which constrains both
their expressiveness and stability.
  We introduce Echo Flow Networks (EFNs), a framework composed of a group of
extended Echo State Networks (X-ESNs) with MLP readouts, enhanced by our novel
Matrix-Gated Composite Random Activation (MCRA), which enables complex,
neuron-specific temporal dynamics, significantly expanding the network's
representational capacity without compromising computational efficiency. In
addition, we propose a dual-stream architecture in which recent input history
dynamically selects signature reservoir features from an infinite-horizon
memory, leading to improved prediction accuracy and long-term stability.
  Extensive evaluations on five benchmarks demonstrate that EFNs achieve up to
4x faster training and 3x smaller model size compared to leading methods like
PatchTST, reducing forecasting error from 43% to 35%, a 20% relative
improvement. One instantiation of our framework, EchoFormer, consistently
achieves new state-of-the-art performance across five benchmark datasets: ETTh,
ETTm, DMV, Weather, and Air Quality.

AI.tldr: Echo Flow Networks (EFNs) extend Echo State Networks with MCRA and a dual-stream memory to efficiently capture long-range temporal dependencies, achieving state-of-the-art results with faster training and smaller models.
AI.motivation: To address the trade-off between computational efficiency and nonlinear expressive power in time-series forecasting, leveraging reservoir computing with enhanced dynamics and selective memory.
AI.method: EFNs consist of a group of extended ESNs (X-ESNs) with MLP readouts and a new Matrix-Gated Composite Random Activation (MCRA) to enable neuron-specific temporal dynamics. A dual-stream architecture selects signature reservoir features from infinite-horizon memory based on recent input history. EchoFormer is one instantiation.
AI.result: EFNs deliver up to 4x faster training and 3x smaller model size than PatchTST, reducing forecasting error from 43% to 35% (20% relative). EchoFormer achieves new state-of-the-art across five datasets: ETTh, ETTm, DMV, Weather, and Air Quality.
AI.conclusion: EFNs provide a scalable, efficient framework for long-horizon time-series forecasting with improved accuracy and stability; EchoFormer demonstrates strong generalization across diverse benchmarks.

title: CrashSplat: 2D to 3D Vehicle Damage Segmentation in Gaussian Splatting
summary:
Automatic car damage detection has been a topic of significant interest for
the auto insurance industry as it promises faster, accurate, and cost-effective
damage assessments. However, few works have gone beyond 2D image analysis to
leverage 3D reconstruction methods, which have the potential to provide a more
comprehensive and geometrically accurate representation of the damage.
Moreover, recent methods employing 3D representations for novel view synthesis,
particularly 3D Gaussian Splatting (3D-GS), have demonstrated the ability to
generate accurate and coherent 3D reconstructions from a limited number of
views. In this work we introduce an automatic car damage detection pipeline
that performs 3D damage segmentation by up-lifting 2D masks. Additionally, we
propose a simple yet effective learning-free approach for single-view 3D-GS
segmentation. Specifically, Gaussians are projected onto the image plane using
camera parameters obtained via Structure from Motion (SfM). They are then
filtered through an algorithm that utilizes Z-buffering along with a normal
distribution model of depth and opacities. Through experiments we found that
this method is particularly effective for challenging scenarios like car damage
detection, where target objects (e.g., scratches, small dents) may only be
clearly visible in a single view, making multi-view consistency approaches
impractical or impossible. The code is publicly available at:
https://github.com/DragosChileban/CrashSplat.

AI.tldr: 3D car-damage segmentation pipeline using 3D-Gaussian Splatting and a learning-free single-view projection method to uplift 2D damage masks into 3D.
AI.motivation: Auto insurance damage assessment benefits from faster, accurate 3D geometry; existing work is mostly 2D; 3D reconstruction from few views via 3D-GS can improve detection, esp. small damages visible in single view.
AI.method: Upscale 2D masks to 3D using 3D Gaussian Splatting; project Gaussians onto image plane using camera parameters from Structure from Motion; apply Z-buffering and a depth-opacity normal distribution for filtering; support a learning-free single-view segmentation; code is public.
AI.result: Demonstrates effectiveness in challenging single-view scenarios (scratches/dents) where multi-view approaches struggle; validated through experiments; code available.
AI.conclusion: 3D segmentation via 2D uplift with Gaussian Splatting is a promising direction for automatic car-damage detection and can handle single-view limitations where multi-view consistency fails; the approach provides a practical, low-data pathway for robust 3D damage analysis.

title: The Impossibility of Inverse Permutation Learning in Transformer Models
summary:
In this technical note, we study the problem of inverse permutation learning
in decoder-only transformers. Given a permutation and a string to which that
permutation has been applied, the model is tasked with producing the original
(``canonical'') string. We argue that this task models a natural robustness
property across a variety of reasoning tasks, including long-context retrieval,
multiple choice QA and in-context learning. Our primary contribution is an
impossibility result: we show that an arbitrary depth, decoder-only transformer
cannot learn this task. This result concerns the expressive capacity of
decoder-only transformer models and is agnostic to training dynamics or sample
complexity. We give a pair of alternative constructions under which inverse
permutation learning is feasible. The first of these highlights the fundamental
role of the causal attention mask, and reveals a gap between the expressivity
of encoder-decoder transformers and the more popular decoder-only architecture.
The latter result is more surprising: we show that simply padding the input
with ``scratch tokens" yields a construction under which inverse permutation
learning is possible. We conjecture that this may suggest an alternative
mechanism by which chain-of-thought prompting or, more generally, intermediate
``thinking'' tokens can enable reasoning in large language models, even when
these tokens encode no meaningful semantic information (e.g., the results of
intermediate computations).

AI.tldr: Inverse permutation learning is impossible for any depth of decoder-only transformers; feasible only under special constructions (encoder–decoder-like masking or padding with scratch tokens), suggesting a potential mechanism behind chain-of-thought like reasoning in LLMs.
AI.motivation: Understand the robustness and limitations of decoder-only transformers for reasoning tasks (e.g., long-context retrieval, MCQA, in-context learning) by studying their ability to invert a permutation.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis proving an impossibility result for arbitrary-depth decoder-only transformers; then present two constructive setups that enable the task: (1) modify the attention mask to mimic encoder–decoder behavior, highlighting a gap in expressivity between encoder–decoder and decoder-only models; (2) pad inputs with non-semantic "scratch" tokens, which makes inverse permutation learning feasible.
AI.result: An impossibility result showing decoder-only models cannot learn inverse permutation; plus two feasible constructions that enable the task: using causal masking (encoder–decoder style) and using scratch tokens; these results imply architectural choices drive reasoning capabilities and motivate a potential role for intermediate tokens like chain-of-thought prompts.
AI.conclusion: Architectural design governs the learnability of inverse-permutation tasks in language models. The scratch-token construction hints at how intermediate reasoning tokens could enable complex reasoning, even if they carry no semantic meaning, shedding light on the utility of chain-of-thought prompting.

title: HunyuanImage 3.0 Technical Report
summary:
We present HunyuanImage 3.0, a native multimodal model that unifies
multimodal understanding and generation within an autoregressive framework,
with its image generation module publicly available. The achievement of
HunyuanImage 3.0 relies on several key components, including meticulous data
curation, advanced architecture design, a native Chain-of-Thoughts schema,
progressive model pre-training, aggressive model post-training, and an
efficient infrastructure that enables large-scale training and inference. With
these advancements, we successfully trained a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) model
comprising over 80 billion parameters in total, with 13 billion parameters
activated per token during inference, making it the largest and most powerful
open-source image generative model to date. We conducted extensive experiments
and the results of automatic and human evaluation of text-image alignment and
visual quality demonstrate that HunyuanImage 3.0 rivals previous
state-of-the-art models. By releasing the code and weights of HunyuanImage 3.0,
we aim to enable the community to explore new ideas with a state-of-the-art
foundation model, fostering a dynamic and vibrant multimodal ecosystem. All
open source assets are publicly available at
https://github.com/Tencent-Hunyuan/HunyuanImage-3.0

AI.tldr: HunyuanImage 3.0 is a native multimodal autoregressive model with Mixture-of-Experts, totaling 80B parameters (13B active per token), open-sourced for image generation, achieving competitive text-image alignment and visual quality and enabling community experimentation.
AI.motivation: To unify multimodal understanding and generation in a single autoregressive framework, scale open-source capabilities to rival state-of-the-art closed models, and foster community research by releasing code, weights, and infrastructure.
AI.method: A Mixture-of-Experts architecture with 80B total parameters and 13B active per token, native Chain-of-Thoughts schema, progressive pre-training, aggressive post-training, and efficient infrastructure for large-scale training/inference; data curation; end-to-end autoregressive multimodal framework with an open image generation module.
AI.result: Extensive experiments including automatic and human evaluations show competitive text-image alignment and visual quality against state-of-the-art models; claims to be the largest/open-source image generative model to date in terms of total scale and active parameters; code and weights released publicly.
AI.conclusion: Releasing code and weights aims to empower the community to explore and advance multimodal foundations, boosting a vibrant open ecosystem for multimodal AI research.

title: A signal separation view of classification
summary:
The problem of classification in machine learning has often been approached
in terms of function approximation. In this paper, we propose an alternative
approach for classification in arbitrary compact metric spaces which, in
theory, yields both the number of classes, and a perfect classification using a
minimal number of queried labels. Our approach uses localized trigonometric
polynomial kernels initially developed for the point source signal separation
problem in signal processing. Rather than point sources, we argue that the
various classes come from different probability distributions. The localized
kernel technique developed for separating point sources is then shown to
separate the supports of these distributions. This is done in a hierarchical
manner in our MASC algorithm to accommodate touching/overlapping class
boundaries. We illustrate our theory on several simulated and real life
datasets, including the Salinas and Indian Pines hyperspectral datasets and a
document dataset.

AI.tldr: Proposes a kernel-based, label-efficient classification framework in arbitrary compact metric spaces using localized trig polynomial kernels to identify class supports and recover the number of classes via a hierarchical MASC algorithm, achieving perfect classification with minimal labeled queries.
AI.motivation: Classification is often treated as function approximation, but this approach seeks label-efficient, distribution-based separation in arbitrary metric spaces. It also aims to determine the actual number of classes and handle overlapping/touching boundaries.
AI.method: Adopts localized trigonometric polynomial kernels originally developed for point-source separation. Treats classes as distributions whose supports are separable by the kernel; applies a hierarchical MASC (multi-class adaptive separation/structure) scheme to handle touching/overlapping boundaries. Provides theoretical guarantees and supports with experiments on simulated data and real datasets (Salinas and Indian Pines hyperspectral datasets, and a document dataset).
AI.result: The theory yields the identification of the number of classes and perfect classification with a minimal number of queried labels. Empirical demonstrations on hyperspectral and document datasets illustrate viability.
AI.conclusion: The work reframes classification as distribution separation in arbitrary metric spaces using localized kernels and a hierarchical scheme, offering a principled, label-efficient method that can handle complex, overlapping boundaries across diverse domains.

title: ColLab: A Collaborative Spatial Progressive Data Engine for Referring Expression Comprehension and Generation
summary:
Referring Expression Comprehension (REC) and Referring Expression Generation
(REG) are fundamental tasks in multimodal understanding, supporting precise
object localization through natural language. However, existing REC and REG
datasets rely heavily on manual annotation, which is labor-intensive and
difficult to scale. In this paper, we propose ColLab, a collaborative spatial
progressive data engine that enables fully automated REC and REG data
generation without human supervision. Specifically, our method introduces a
Collaborative Multimodal Model Interaction (CMMI) strategy, which leverages the
semantic understanding of multimodal large language models (MLLMs) and large
