their computational and storage costs often limit practical deployment.
Pruning-at-Initialization has emerged as a promising approach to compress
models before training, enabling efficient task-specific adaptation. While
conventional wisdom suggests that effective pruning requires task-specific
data, this creates a challenge when downstream tasks are unknown in advance. In
this paper, we investigate how data influences the pruning of pre-trained
vision models. Surprisingly, pruning on one task retains the model's zero-shot
performance also on unseen tasks. Furthermore, fine-tuning these pruned models
not only improves performance on original seen tasks but can recover held-out
tasks' performance. We attribute this phenomenon to the favorable loss
landscapes induced by extensive pre-training on large-scale datasets.

AI.tldr: Pruning-at-initialization of pre-trained vision models preserves zero-shot transfer to unseen tasks and, after fine-tuning, recovers or improves held-out task performance; this is attributed to favorable loss landscapes created by large-scale pretraining.
AI.motivation: Compress vision models before training without task-specific data, while maintaining transferability across tasks.
AI.method: Apply pruning-at-initialization to pre-trained vision models, evaluate zero-shot performance on unseen tasks, then fine-tune the pruned models on some tasks and assess performance on both seen and held-out tasks; analyze the role of pretraining-induced loss landscapes.
AI.result: Pruning on one task retains zero-shot performance on unseen tasks; fine-tuning improves performance on seen tasks and can recover held-out tasks' performance.
AI.conclusion: Extensive pre-training yields loss landscapes that make pruning robust across tasks, enabling data-efficient, task-agnostic compression with recovery via fine-tuning.

title: ELASTIQ: EEG-Language Alignment with Semantic Task Instruction and Querying
summary:
Recent advances in electroencephalography (EEG) foundation models, which
capture transferable EEG representations, have greatly accelerated the
development of brain-computer interfaces (BCI). However, existing approaches
still struggle to incorporate language instructions as prior constraints for
EEG representation learning, limiting their ability to leverage the semantic
knowledge inherent in language to unify different labels and tasks. To address
this challenge, we present ELASTIQ, a foundation model for EEG-Language
Alignment with Semantic Task Instruction and Querying. ELASTIQ integrates
task-aware semantic guidance to produce structured and linguistically aligned
EEG embeddings, thereby enhancing decoding robustness and transferability. In
the pretraining stage, we introduce a joint Spectral-Temporal Reconstruction
(STR) module, which combines frequency masking as a global spectral
perturbation with two complementary temporal objectives: random masking to
capture contextual dependencies and causal masking to model sequential
dynamics. In the instruction tuning stage, we propose the
Instruction-conditioned Q-Former (IQF), a query-based cross-attention
transformer that injects instruction embeddings into EEG tokens and aligns them
with textual label embeddings through learnable queries. We evaluate ELASTIQ on
20 datasets spanning motor imagery, emotion recognition, steady-state visual
evoked potentials, covert speech, and healthcare tasks. ELASTIQ achieves
state-of-the-art performance on 14 of the 20 datasets and obtains the best
average results across all five task categories. Importantly, our analyses
reveal for the first time that explicit task instructions serve as semantic
priors guiding EEG embeddings into coherent and linguistically grounded spaces.
The code and pre-trained weights will be released.

AI.tldr: ELASTIQ is a language-informed EEG foundation model that uses spectral-temporal reconstruction pretraining and instruction-conditioned Q-former alignment to text, achieving state-of-the-art on 14 of 20 EEG datasets and best average across five task categories, highlighting explicit task instructions as semantic priors for linguistically grounded EEG embeddings.
AI.motivation: Existing EEG representation learning lacks language-driven priors to leverage semantic knowledge for unifying labels and tasks; incorporating language instructions could improve robustness, transferability, and cross-task coherence of EEG embeddings.
AI.method: Pretraining with Spectral-Temporal Reconstruction (STR): frequency masking plus two temporal objectives (random masking and causal masking). Instruction tuning via Instruction-conditioned Q-Former (IQF): a query-based cross-attention transformer injecting instruction embeddings into EEG tokens and aligning them with textual label embeddings through learnable queries. Evaluation on 20 datasets spanning motor imagery, emotion, SSVEP, covert speech, and healthcare.
AI.result: ELASTIQ achieves state-of-the-art performance on 14 of 20 datasets and the best average across five task categories. Analyses indicate explicit task instructions act as semantic priors that steer EEG embeddings into linguistically grounded spaces. Code and pretrained weights will be released.
AI.conclusion: Language-conditioned EEG foundation models can unify and structure EEG representations through semantic guidance, improving robustness and transferability across diverse tasks; ELASTIQ demonstrates the feasibility and potential of language-aligned EEG learning and invites further exploration into instruction-guided neuroscience AI.

title: Uncovering Grounding IDs: How External Cues Shape Multi-Modal Binding
comment: Under review as a conference paper at ICLR 2026
summary:
Large vision-language models (LVLMs) show strong performance across
multimodal benchmarks but remain limited in structured reasoning and precise
grounding. Recent work has demonstrated that adding simple visual structures,
such as partitions and annotations, improves accuracy, yet the internal
mechanisms underlying these gains remain unclear. We investigate this
phenomenon and propose the concept of Grounding IDs, latent identifiers induced
by external cues that bind objects to their designated partitions across
modalities. Through representation analysis, we find that these identifiers
emerge as robust within-partition alignment in embedding space and reduce the
modality gap between image and text. Causal interventions further confirm that
these identifiers mediate binding between objects and symbolic cues. We show
that Grounding IDs strengthen attention between related components, which in
turn improves cross-modal grounding and reduces hallucinations. Taken together,
our results identify Grounding IDs as a key symbolic mechanism explaining how
external cues enhance multimodal binding, offering both interpretability and
practical improvements in robustness.

AI.tldr: Grounding IDs are latent, cue-induced identifiers that bind objects to partitions across vision-language modalities, enhancing grounding, reducing modality gap, and improving robustness.
AI.motivation: Large vision-language models struggle with structured reasoning and precise grounding. Simple external cues like partitions and annotations help, but the underlying mechanism is unclear. The paper proposes Grounding IDs as this mechanism.
AI.method: Perform representation analysis to detect robust within-partition alignment of objects to their external cues; use causal interventions to test whether Grounding IDs mediate the binding between objects and symbolic cues; analyze attention dynamics to show strengthened cross-modal connections; assess impact on grounding accuracy and hallucinations.
AI.result: Grounding IDs emerge as robust within-partition alignments in embedding space, reducing modality gap between image and text; causal interventions confirm they mediate binding between objects and cues; attention between related components is strengthened, improving cross-modal grounding and reducing hallucinations; provides interpretability and practical robustness gains.
AI.conclusion: Grounding IDs are a key symbolic mechanism explaining how external cues improve multimodal binding, offering interpretability and tangible robustness improvements.

title: Asynchronous Policy Gradient Aggregation for Efficient Distributed Reinforcement Learning
summary:
We study distributed reinforcement learning (RL) with policy gradient methods
under asynchronous and parallel computations and communications. While
non-distributed methods are well understood theoretically and have achieved
remarkable empirical success, their distributed counterparts remain less
explored, particularly in the presence of heterogeneous asynchronous
computations and communication bottlenecks. We introduce two new algorithms,
Rennala NIGT and Malenia NIGT, which implement asynchronous policy gradient
aggregation and achieve state-of-the-art efficiency. In the homogeneous
setting, Rennala NIGT provably improves the total computational and
communication complexity while supporting the AllReduce operation. In the
heterogeneous setting, Malenia NIGT simultaneously handles asynchronous
computations and heterogeneous environments with strictly better theoretical
guarantees. Our results are further corroborated by experiments, showing that
our methods significantly outperform prior approaches.

AI.tldr: Proposes Rennala NIGT and Malenia NIGT for asynchronous distributed policy-gradient RL, achieving state-of-the-art efficiency; Rennala improves computational and communication complexity in homogeneous settings with AllReduce; Malenia handles asynchronous and heterogeneous environments with stronger theoretical guarantees; experiments show significant performance gains over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap in understanding and designing distributed RL algorithms under asynchronous and heterogeneous computations and communication bottlenecks, seeking efficiency gains and theoretical guarantees beyond standard non-distributed methods.
AI.method: Introduce two algorithms, Rennala NIGT (homogeneous setting) and Malenia NIGT (heterogeneous setting), that perform asynchronous policy-gradient aggregation. Rennala supports AllReduce and provably reduces total computational and communication complexity; Malenia extends the approach to tolerate asynchrony and heterogeneity with stronger theoretical guarantees.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art efficiency in distributed policy-gradient RL; Rennala offers improved complexity bounds with AllReduce; Malenia provides better theoretical guarantees under asynchronous/heterogeneous conditions; experiments show substantial performance improvements over prior baselines.
AI.conclusion: The work advances distributed RL by delivering practical and theoretically-sound asynchronous policy-gradient aggregation methods that perform well in both homogeneous and heterogeneous environments, outperforming existing approaches in empirical evaluations.

title: Autoregressive Video Generation beyond Next Frames Prediction
summary:
Autoregressive models for video generation typically operate frame-by-frame,
extending next-token prediction from language to video's temporal dimension. We
question that unlike word as token is universally agreed in language if frame
is a appropriate prediction unit? To address this, we present VideoAR, a
unified framework that supports a spectrum of prediction units including full
frames, key-detail frames, multiscale refinements, and spatiotemporal cubes.
Among these designs, we find model video generation using
\textit{spatiotemporal} cubes as prediction units, which allows autoregressive
models to operate across both spatial and temporal dimensions simultaneously.
This approach eliminates the assumption that frames are the natural atomic
units for video autoregression. We evaluate VideoAR across diverse prediction
strategies, finding that cube-based prediction consistently delivers superior
quality, speed, and temporal coherence. By removing the frame-by-frame
constraint, our video generator surpasses state-of-the-art baselines on VBench
while achieving faster inference and enabling seamless scaling to minute-long
sequences. We hope this work will motivate rethinking sequence decomposition in
video and other spatiotemporal domains.

AI.tldr: VideoAR shows spatiotemporal cubes for autoregressive video generation that outperform frame-based methods, enabling faster, longer, and more coherent videos.
AI.motivation: Reconsider whether frames are the natural atomic unit for video autoregression; aim to improve quality, speed, and scalability of video generation.
AI.method: A unified VideoAR framework supporting multiple prediction units (full frames, key-detail frames, multiscale refinements, and spatiotemporal cubes), with cube-based predictions that operate across spatial and temporal dimensions.
AI.result: Cube-based predictions yield superior quality, speed, and temporal coherence; surpass state-of-the-art baselines on VBench; faster inference; scalable to minute-long sequences.
AI.conclusion: Encourages rethinking sequence decomposition in video and other spatiotemporal domains, with potential broader implications for how we define tokens in spatiotemporal data.

title: A study of Universal ODE approaches to predicting soil organic carbon
summary:
Soil Organic Carbon (SOC) is a foundation of soil health and global climate
resilience, yet its prediction remains difficult because of intricate physical,
chemical, and biological processes. In this study, we explore a Scientific
Machine Learning (SciML) framework built on Universal Differential Equations
(UDEs) to forecast SOC dynamics across soil depth and time. UDEs blend
mechanistic physics, such as advection diffusion transport, with neural
networks that learn nonlinear microbial production and respiration. Using
synthetic datasets, we systematically evaluated six experimental cases,
progressing from clean, noise free benchmarks to stress tests with high (35%)
multiplicative, spatially correlated noise. Our results highlight both the
potential and limitations of the approach. In noise free and moderate noise
settings, the UDE accurately reconstructed SOC dynamics. In clean terminal
profile at 50 years (Case 4) achieved near perfect fidelity, with MSE = 1.6e-5,
and R2 = 0.9999. Case 5, with 7% noise, remained robust (MSE = 3.4e-6, R2 =
0.99998), capturing depth wise SOC trends while tolerating realistic
measurement uncertainty. In contrast, Case 3 (35% noise at t = 0) showed clear
evidence of overfitting: the model reproduced noisy inputs with high accuracy
but lost generalization against the clean truth (R2 = 0.94). Case 6 (35% noise
at t = 50) collapsed toward overly smooth mean profiles, failing to capture
depth wise variability and yielding negative R2, underscoring the limits of
standard training under severe uncertainty. These findings suggest that UDEs
are well suited for scalable, noise tolerant SOC forecasting, though advancing
toward field deployment will require noise aware loss functions, probabilistic
modelling, and tighter integration of microbial dynamics.

AI.tldr: UDE-based SciML blends physics with neural nets to forecast Soil Organic Carbon (SOC) across depth and time; performs well under clean/moderate noise but shows overfitting and smoothing under severe noise; field deployment needs noise-aware loss and probabilistic modeling.
AI.motivation: SOC prediction is hindered by intertwined physical, chemical, and biological processes; a scalable, noise-tolerant forecasting framework that integrates mechanistic physics with data-driven microbial dynamics is valuable.
AI.method: Scientific ML framework using Universal Differential Equations (UDEs) that couple advection-diffusion physics with neural networks learning microbial production and respiration; evaluated on synthetic data with six experimental cases, introducing increasing multiplicative, spatially correlated noise (up to 35%); performance assessed via MSE and R2 across depth/time.
AI.result: Under noise-free and mild-noise conditions the UDE reconstructs SOC dynamics well: Case 4 (clean terminal profile at 50 years) MSE=1.6e-5, R2=0.9999; Case 5 (7% noise) MSE=3.4e-6, R2=0.99998. Under severe noise, Case 3 (35% at t=0) shows overfitting (R2=0.94) and Case 6 (35% at t=50) yields overly smooth mean profiles with negative R2, indicating limited generalization; overall, UDEs show promise for scalable, noise-tolerant SOC forecasting but require advances to handle heavy uncertainty.
AI.conclusion: UDEs are a promising path for scalable SOC forecasting, but field deployment requires noise-aware loss functions, probabilistic modeling, and tighter integration of microbial dynamics to ensure robust performance under real-world uncertainty.

title: Unified Multi-Modal Interactive & Reactive 3D Motion Generation via Rectified Flow
summary:
Generating realistic, context-aware two-person motion conditioned on diverse
modalities remains a central challenge in computer graphics, animation, and
human-computer interaction. We introduce DualFlow, a unified and efficient
framework for multi-modal two-person motion generation. DualFlow conditions 3D
motion synthesis on diverse inputs, including text, music, and prior motion
sequences. Leveraging rectified flow, it achieves deterministic straight-line
sampling paths between noise and data, reducing inference time and mitigating
error accumulation common in diffusion-based models. To enhance semantic
grounding, DualFlow employs a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) module that
retrieves motion exemplars using music features and LLM-based text
decompositions of spatial relations, body movements, and rhythmic patterns. We
use contrastive objective that further strengthens alignment with conditioning
signals and introduce synchronization loss that improves inter-person
coordination. Extensive evaluations across text-to-motion, music-to-motion, and
multi-modal interactive benchmarks show consistent gains in motion quality,
responsiveness, and efficiency. DualFlow produces temporally coherent and
rhythmically synchronized motions, setting state-of-the-art in multi-modal
human motion generation.

AI.tldr: DualFlow proposes a unified, efficient multi-modal two-person motion generation framework using rectified flow for deterministic sampling, a retrieval-augmented generation module for grounding via motion exemplars and LLM-based decompositions, contrastive and synchronization losses, achieving state-of-the-art in text/music/multi-modal motion generation with better quality and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Generating realistic two-person motion conditioned on diverse modalities is challenging due to modality diversity, temporal coherence, and error accumulation in diffusion-based approaches; there is a need for efficient, semantically grounded multi-modal motion generation.
AI.method: Rectified flow enables deterministic straight-line sampling paths from noise to data for faster inference and reduced error accumulation; Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) retrieves motion exemplars using music features and LLM-based decomposition of spatial relations, body movements, and rhythm; contrastive objective strengthens alignment with conditioning signals; a synchronization loss improves inter-person coordination; evaluated on text-to-motion, music-to-motion, and multi-modal benchmarks.
AI.result: The approach yields consistent gains in motion quality, responsiveness, and efficiency across multiple modalities; motions are temporally coherent and rhythmically synchronized, achieving state-of-the-art performance in multi-modal human motion generation.
AI.conclusion: DualFlow presents a unified and efficient framework for high-quality, diverse multi-modal two-person motion generation, with strong grounding and coordination capabilities; the technique shows promise for advancing graphics, animation, and human-computer interaction applications; potential future work may include expanding modalities and further improving generalization.

title: Rethinking JEPA: Compute-Efficient Video SSL with Frozen Teachers
summary:
Video Joint Embedding Predictive Architectures (V-JEPA) learn generalizable
off-the-shelf video representation by predicting masked regions in latent space
with an exponential moving average (EMA)-updated teacher. While EMA prevents
representation collapse, it complicates scalable model selection and couples
teacher and student architectures. We revisit masked-latent prediction and show
that a frozen teacher suffices. Concretely, we (i) train a target encoder with
a simple pixel-reconstruction objective under V-JEPA masking, then (ii) freeze
it and train a student to predict the teacher's latents on masked regions. This
leads to a two-stage, unregularized scheme that we refer to as SALT
(Static-teacher Asymmetric Latent Training). SALT decouples optimization into
pixel reconstruction (teacher) and masked latent prediction (student),
increasing transparency, efficiency, and scalability while preserving the
ability of representation to generalize under frozen evaluation. Empirically,
our student models outperform recently proposed V-JEPA 2 encoders under frozen
backbone evaluation across diverse benchmarks. They are also more
compute-optimal: at matched pretraining FLOPs, our method achieves higher
probing accuracy, and its scaling curves dominate V-JEPA's accuracy-FLOPs
Pareto frontier. Finally, we find that student quality is remarkably robust to
teacher quality: high-performing students emerge even with small, sub-optimal
teachers. This points to a compute budget allocation that should overwhelmingly
favor the student. These results position SALT as a simple, scalable, and
compute-efficient alternative to EMA-based self-distillation for video
representation learning.

AI.tldr: SALT replaces EMA-based teacher-student distillation (V-JEPA) with a frozen teacher architecture. Train a target encoder via pixel reconstruction, freeze it, and train a student to predict the teacher's latents on masked regions, yielding a two-stage, unregularized scheme that improves transparency, efficiency, and scalability while maintaining strong generalization under frozen evaluation.
AI.motivation: EMA-based self-distillation in video representation learning couples teacher and student and complicates model selection. The work seeks a simpler, scalable alternative that decouples optimization, enabling easier computation budgeting and broader applicability.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (i) train a target encoder using a pixel-reconstruction objective under V-JEPA masking; (ii) freeze the encoder and train a student to predict the teacher's latent representations for masked regions. This yields a static-teacher asymmetric latent-training regime (SALT).
AI.result: SALT-trained student models outperform recent V-JEPA 2 encoders under frozen backbone evaluation across diverse benchmarks, with higher probe accuracy at matched FLOPs. SALT's scaling curves dominate V-JEPA's accuracy–FLOPs frontier, and student quality is robust to teacher quality (even sub-optimal teachers yield strong students).
AI.conclusion: SALT is a simple, scalable, compute-efficient alternative to EMA-based self-distillation for video representation learning, preserving generalization while improving transparency and efficiency.

title: SVAC: Scaling Is All You Need For Referring Video Object Segmentation
comment: This paper is accepted to BMVC 2025
summary:
Referring Video Object Segmentation (RVOS) aims to segment target objects in
video sequences based on natural language descriptions. While recent advances
in Multi-modal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have improved RVOS performance
through enhanced text-video understanding, several challenges remain, including
insufficient exploitation of MLLMs' prior knowledge, prohibitive computational
and memory costs for long-duration videos, and inadequate handling of complex
temporal dynamics. In this work, we propose SVAC, a unified model that improves
RVOS by scaling up input frames and segmentation tokens to enhance
video-language interaction and segmentation precision. To address the resulting
computational challenges, SVAC incorporates the Anchor-Based Spatio-Temporal
Compression (ASTC) module to compress visual tokens while preserving essential
spatio-temporal structure. Moreover, the Clip-Specific Allocation (CSA)
strategy is introduced to better handle dynamic object behaviors across video
clips. Experimental results demonstrate that SVAC achieves state-of-the-art
performance on multiple RVOS benchmarks with competitive efficiency. Our code
is available at https://github.com/lizhang1998/SVAC.

AI.tldr: A unified SVAC model for Referring Video Object Segmentation that scales frames and tokens and uses ASTC and CSA to boost performance with efficient handling of long videos; achieves state-of-the-art results with competitive efficiency; code available on GitHub.
AI.motivation: Address challenges in RVOS: underutilized MLLM priors, heavy cost for long videos, and complex temporal dynamics; need for better video-language interaction and precise segmentation.
AI.method: Introduce SVAC; scale input frames and segmentation tokens to strengthen video-language interaction; Anchor-Based Spatio-Temporal Compression (ASTC) compresses visual tokens while preserving spatio-temporal structure; Clip-Specific Allocation (CSA) allocates resources to handle dynamic object behaviors across video clips.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art results on several RVOS benchmarks with competitive efficiency.
AI.conclusion: SVAC demonstrates that scaling and targeted token compression plus clip-aware allocation can improve RVOS performance while controlling costs; code available at the provided GitHub link.

title: AuON: A Linear-time Alternative to Semi-Orthogonal Momentum Updates
summary:
Orthogonal gradient updates have emerged as a promising direction in
optimization for machine learning. However, traditional approaches such as
SVD/QR decomposition incur prohibitive computational costs of O(n^3) and
underperform compared to well-tuned SGD with momentum, since momentum is
applied only after strict orthogonalization. Recent advances, such as Muon,
improve efficiency by applying momentum before orthogonalization and producing
semi-orthogonal matrices via Newton-Schulz iterations, reducing complexity to
O(n^2). Nevertheless, quadratic costs remain a bottleneck.
  In this work, we study the semi-orthogonal properties of momentum-based
updates and develop a method to bound momentum updates under a spectral-norm
trust region, preserving directional information without requiring explicit
semi-orthogonalization.
  We propose AuON (Alternative Unit-norm momentum updates by Normalized
nonlinear scaling), a linear-time optimizer that achieves strong performance
without constructing semi-orthogonal matrices, while preserving structural
alignment and reconditioning ill-posed updates. Our approach combines
hyperbolic-cosine RMS scaling transformations with normalization, demonstrating
both effectiveness and computational efficiency compared to Newton-Schulz
methods. We further introduce a hybrid variant (Hybrid-AuON) that applies a
single Newton-Schulz iteration. Experiments across vision and language
benchmarks show that AuON and its hybrid variant achieve performance comparable
to strong baselines such as AdamW and Muon.
  Code is available at: https://github.com/ryyzn9/AuON

AI.tldr: AuON is a linear-time momentum-based optimizer that preserves directional information without explicit semi-orthogonalization, delivering competitive results to AdamW and Muon, with a hybrid variant using one Newton-Schulz iteration.
AI.motivation: Orthogonal gradient updates can improve optimization but are computationally expensive (O(n^3) via SVD/QR). While momentum-based methods like Muon mitigate cost by applying momentum before orthogonalization and using Newton-Schulz for semi-orthogonal matrices (reducing to O(n^2)), quadratic costs remain a bottleneck. There is a need for scalable optimizers that preserve directional information without heavy matrix factorization.
AI.method: Introduce AuON (Alternative Unit-norm momentum updates by Normalized nonlinear scaling), a linear-time optimizer that avoids constructing semi-orthogonal matrices. AuON uses hyperbolic-cosine RMS scaling transformations with normalization and bounds momentum updates under a spectral-norm trust region to preserve directional information. A hybrid variant (Hybrid-AuON) applies a single Newton-Schulz iteration. The approach aims to maintain alignment and recondition ill-posed updates while achieving linear-time complexity.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations across vision and language benchmarks show AuON and Hybrid-AuON achieve performance comparable to strong baselines such as AdamW and Muon. The paper claims computational efficiency improvements over Newton-Schulz-based semi-orthogonalization.
AI.conclusion: AuON offers a linear-time alternative to semi-orthogonalization-based momentum updates, preserving directional information and achieving competitive performance with established optimizers. The hybrid variant provides a middle ground by incorporating a single Newton-Schulz iteration.

title: GANji: A Framework for Introductory AI Image Generation
summary:
The comparative study of generative models often requires significant
computational resources, creating a barrier for researchers and practitioners.
This paper introduces GANji, a lightweight framework for benchmarking
foundational AI image generation techniques using a dataset of 10,314 Japanese
Kanji characters. It systematically compares the performance of a Variational
Autoencoder (VAE), a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN), and a Denoising
Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM). The results demonstrate that while the
DDPM achieves the highest image fidelity, with a Fr\'echet Inception Distance
(FID) score of 26.2, its sampling time is over 2,000 times slower than the
other models. The GANji framework is an effective and accessible tool for
revealing the fundamental trade-offs between model architecture, computational
cost, and visual quality, making it ideal for both educational and research
purposes.

AI.tldr: GANji offers a lightweight benchmarking framework to compare VAE, GAN, and DDPM on 10,314 Japanese Kanji, highlighting the fidelity-speed trade-off: DDPM gives the best image fidelity (FID 26.2) but is >2000x slower in sampling; GANji clarifies the core trade-offs, aiding education and research.
AI.motivation: The field of generative image models is compute-intensive, creating barriers for researchers. A lightweight, accessible benchmark using a real-world script and dataset (Kanji characters) helps reveal fundamental trade-offs between model architecture, compute cost, and output quality.
AI.method: Benchmark three foundational generative models (VAE, GAN, DDPM) within the GANji framework on a dataset of 10,314 Kanji characters, evaluating image fidelity (FID) and sampling speed to compare trade-offs.
AI.result: DDPM achieves the highest image fidelity with FID 26.2, but its sampling time is over 2,000 times slower than the other models. GAN and VAE offer faster sampling with lower fidelity, illustrating the trade-offs.
AI.conclusion: GANji is an effective and accessible benchmarking tool that exposes the core trade-offs between model architecture, computational cost, and visual quality, making it valuable for education and research.

title: H+: An Efficient Similarity-Aware Aggregation for Byzantine Resilient Federated Learning
summary:
Federated Learning (FL) enables decentralized model training without sharing
raw data. However, it remains vulnerable to Byzantine attacks, which can
compromise the aggregation of locally updated parameters at the central server.
Similarity-aware aggregation has emerged as an effective strategy to mitigate
such attacks by identifying and filtering out malicious clients based on
similarity between client model parameters and those derived from clean data,
i.e., data that is uncorrupted and trustworthy. However, existing methods adopt
this strategy only in FL systems with clean data, making them inapplicable to
settings where such data is unavailable. In this paper, we propose H+, a novel
similarity-aware aggregation approach that not only outperforms existing
methods in scenarios with clean data, but also extends applicability to FL
systems without any clean data. Specifically, H+ randomly selects
$r$-dimensional segments from the $p$-dimensional parameter vectors uploaded to
the server and applies a similarity check function $H$ to compare each segment
against a reference vector, preserving the most similar client vectors for
aggregation. The reference vector is derived either from existing robust
algorithms when clean data is unavailable or directly from clean data.
Repeating this process $K$ times enables effective identification of honest
clients. Moreover, H+ maintains low computational complexity, with an
analytical time complexity of $\mathcal{O}(KMr)$, where $M$ is the number of
clients and $Kr \ll p$. Comprehensive experiments validate H+ as a
state-of-the-art (SOTA) method, demonstrating substantial robustness
improvements over existing approaches under varying Byzantine attack ratios and
multiple types of traditional Byzantine attacks, across all evaluated scenarios
and benchmark datasets.

AI.tldr: H+ is a similarity-aware FL aggregation method that works with or without clean data by sampling r-dimensional segments of client updates, comparing them to a reference vector via a similarity function, and aggregating the most similar clients. Repeated K times yields robust identification of honest clients with complexity O(K M r) (Kr ≪ p). It achieves state-of-the-art robustness against Byzantine attacks across datasets.
AI.motivation: FL is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks. Existing similarity-based defenses rely on clean data; when clean data is unavailable, their applicability suffers. There is a need for a similarity-aware aggregation method that operates without clean data while maintaining robustness.
AI.method: H+ randomly selects r-dimensional segments from each M client’s p-dimensional parameter vector, uses a similarity function H to compare each segment against a reference vector, and retains the most similar client vectors for aggregation. The reference vector is derived from either existing robust algorithms (when clean data is unavailable) or directly from clean data. The process is repeated K times to reliably identify honest clients. Computational complexity is O(K M r) with Kr ≪ p.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show H+ achieves state-of-the-art robustness, outperforming existing methods across varying Byzantine attack ratios and multiple attack types on benchmark datasets.
AI.conclusion: H+ extends similarity-aware aggregation to FL even without clean data, delivering strong robustness with low computational cost and broad applicability.

title: Generalist Scanner Meets Specialist Locator: A Synergistic Coarse-to-Fine Framework for Robust GUI Grounding
summary:
Grounding natural language queries in graphical user interfaces (GUIs)
presents a challenging task that requires models to comprehend diverse UI
elements across various applications and systems, while also accurately
predicting the spatial coordinates for the intended operation. To tackle this
problem, we propose GMS: Generalist Scanner Meets Specialist Locator, a
synergistic coarse-to-fine framework that effectively improves GUI grounding
performance. GMS leverages the complementary strengths of general
vision-language models (VLMs) and small, task-specific GUI grounding models by
assigning them distinct roles within the framework. Specifically, the general
VLM acts as a 'Scanner' to identify potential regions of interest, while the
fine-tuned grounding model serves as a 'Locator' that outputs precise
coordinates within these regions. This design is inspired by how humans perform
GUI grounding, where the eyes scan the interface and the brain focuses on
interpretation and localization. Our whole framework consists of five stages
and incorporates hierarchical search with cross-modal communication to achieve
promising prediction results. Experimental results on the ScreenSpot-Pro
dataset show that while the 'Scanner' and 'Locator' models achieve only $2.0\%$
and $3.7\%$ accuracy respectively when used independently, their integration
within GMS framework yields an overall accuracy of $35.7\%$, representing a $10
\times$ improvement. Additionally, GMS significantly outperforms other strong
baselines under various settings, demonstrating its robustness and potential
for general-purpose GUI grounding.

AI.tldr: A coarse-to-fine GUI grounding framework (GMS) that fuses a generalist vision-language model as a Scanner with a specialist GUI grounding Locator, achieving 35.7% accuracy on ScreenSpot-Pro, a 10x improvement over isolated components.
AI.motivation: Grounding NL queries in GUIs is difficult due to diverse UI elements and the need for precise spatial localization; existing single-model approaches underperform. A human-like division of labor (scan then localize) can leverage both broad generalization and task-specific precision.
AI.method: Five-stage coarse-to-fine framework; a general VLM Scanner identifies potential regions of interest in the GUI; a fine-tuned GUI grounding Locator outputs precise coordinates within those regions; hierarchical search with cross-modal communication coordinates the two: stages include scanning, region refinement, and final localization.
AI.result: On ScreenSpot-Pro, the generalist Scanner and specialist Locator alone achieve 2.0% and 3.7% accuracy, but their integration yields 35.7% overall accuracy, about 10x improvements over strong baselines and demonstrating robustness across settings.
AI.conclusion: GMS demonstrates strong potential for general-purpose GUI grounding by combining complementary strengths of general VLMs and task-specific models; the coarse-to-fine, cross-modal framework offers a scalable approach to GUI grounding that could extend to other interface tasks.

title: Towards Generalizable PDE Dynamics Forecasting via Physics-Guided Invariant Learning
summary:
Advanced deep learning-based approaches have been actively applied to
forecast the spatiotemporal physical dynamics governed by partial differential
equations (PDEs), which acts as a critical procedure in tackling many science
and engineering problems. As real-world physical environments like PDE system
parameters are always capricious, how to generalize across unseen
out-of-distribution (OOD) forecasting scenarios using limited training data is
of great importance. To bridge this barrier, existing methods focus on
discovering domain-generalizable representations across various PDE dynamics
trajectories. However, their zero-shot OOD generalization capability remains
deficient, since extra test-time samples for domain-specific adaptation are
still required. This is because the fundamental physical invariance in PDE
dynamical systems are yet to be investigated or integrated. To this end, we
first explicitly define a two-fold PDE invariance principle, which points out
that ingredient operators and their composition relationships remain invariant
across different domains and PDE system evolution. Next, to capture this
two-fold PDE invariance, we propose a physics-guided invariant learning method
termed iMOOE, featuring an Invariance-aligned Mixture Of Operator Expert
architecture and a frequency-enriched invariant learning objective. Extensive
experiments across simulated benchmarks and real-world applications validate
iMOOE's superior in-distribution performance and zero-shot generalization
capabilities on diverse OOD forecasting scenarios.

AI.tldr: Introduces iMOOE, a physics-guided invariant learning method for PDE forecasting that achieves zero-shot OOD generalization via an Invariance-aligned Mixture Of Operator Expert and a frequency-enriched invariant objective; demonstrates strong in-distribution and zero-shot OOD performance.
AI.motivation: Existing DL-based PDE forecasters struggle to generalize to unseen PDE system parameters without test-time adaptation; fundamental PDE invariances are underexplored in current models, hindering zero-shot generalization across domains and evolution.
AI.method: Propose two-fold PDE invariance: (1) invariance of ingredient operators across domains; (2) invariance of their composition relationships. Build iMOOE with an Invariance-aligned Mixture Of Operator Experts architecture and a frequency-enriched invariant learning objective to enforce these invariances during training.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on simulated benchmarks and real-world applications show superior in-distribution forecasting and zero-shot generalization to diverse OOD scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Physics-guided invariance constraints coupled with a modular operator-expert model enable robust zero-shot OOD generalization for PDE dynamics forecasting; highlights potential for broader physics-informed forecasting tasks.

title: EYE-DEX: Eye Disease Detection and EXplanation System
comment:
6 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables. Accepted at the 12th International
  Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications 2025 (WINCOM 2025)
summary:
Retinal disease diagnosis is critical in preventing vision loss and reducing
socioeconomic burdens. Globally, over 2.2 billion people are affected by some
form of vision impairment, resulting in annual productivity losses estimated at
$411 billion. Traditional manual grading of retinal fundus images by
ophthalmologists is time-consuming and subjective. In contrast, deep learning
has revolutionized medical diagnostics by automating retinal image analysis and
achieving expert-level performance. In this study, we present EYE-DEX, an
automated framework for classifying 10 retinal conditions using the large-scale
Retinal Disease Dataset comprising 21,577 eye fundus images. We benchmark three
pre-trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models--VGG16, VGG19, and
ResNet50--with our finetuned VGG16 achieving a state-of-the-art global
benchmark test accuracy of 92.36%. To enhance transparency and explainability,
we integrate the Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM)
technique to generate visual explanations highlighting disease-specific
regions, thereby fostering clinician trust and reliability in AI-assisted
diagnostics.

AI.tldr: EYE-DEX is a high-accuracy, explainable retinal disease classifier for 10 conditions, using Grad-CAM explanations on a 21,577-image dataset; the finetuned VGG16 model achieves the top performance.
AI.motivation: To reduce the time and subjectivity of manual retinal image grading and to provide scalable, explainable AI support for retinal diagnostics amid a large burden of vision impairment.
AI.method: Evaluate three pre-trained CNNs (VGG16, VGG19, ResNet50) on the Retinal Disease Dataset (21,577 images). Finetune VGG16 for 10-class classification. Integrate Grad-CAM to produce visual explanations highlighting disease-related regions.
AI.result: Finetuned VGG16 achieved a state-of-the-art global benchmark test accuracy of 92.36% on the dataset. Grad-CAM was used to generate explainable visualizations of disease regions.
AI.conclusion: EYE-DEX demonstrates strong accuracy and explainability for automated retinal disease classification, supporting potential integration into clinical workflows and enhancing clinician trust in AI-assisted diagnostics.

title: Expanding Horizons of Level Diversity via Multi-objective Evolutionary Learning
summary:
In recent years, the generation of diverse game levels has gained increasing
interest, contributing to a richer and more engaging gaming experience. A
number of level diversity metrics have been proposed in literature, which are
naturally multi-dimensional, leading to conflicted, complementary, or both
relationships among these dimensions. However, existing level generation
approaches often fail to comprehensively assess diversity across those
dimensions. This paper aims to expand horizons of level diversity by
considering multi-dimensional diversity when training generative models. We
formulate the model training as a multi-objective learning problem, where each
diversity metric is treated as a distinct objective. Furthermore, a
multi-objective evolutionary learning framework that optimises multiple
diversity metrics simultaneously throughout the model training process is
proposed. Our case study on the commonly used benchmark Super Mario Bros.
demonstrates that our proposed framework can enhance multi-dimensional
diversity and identify a Pareto front of generative models, which provides a
range of tradeoffs among playability and two representative diversity metrics,
including a content-based one and a player-centered one. Such capability
enables decision-makers to make informed choices when selecting generators
accommodating a variety of scenarios and the diverse needs of players and
designers.

AI.tldr: Proposes a multi-objective learning framework for diverse game level generation by treating multiple diversity metrics as objectives; uses a multi-objective evolutionary learning process to optimize several metrics during training, yielding a Pareto front of generators that balance playability with content- and player-centered diversity, demonstrated on Super Mario Bros.
AI.motivation: Diversity in game levels is multi-dimensional and conflicting; existing methods struggle to assess and optimize across multiple diversity aspects; need an approach that jointly optimizes several diversity metrics during model training to better support diverse player and designer needs.
AI.method: Formulate level generation training as a multi-objective optimization problem, with each diversity metric as an objective; introduce a multi-objective evolutionary learning framework that optimizes across multiple metrics concurrently during training; case study on Super Mario Bros. to evaluate performance and Pareto front.
AI.result: The framework enhances multi-dimensional diversity and yields a Pareto front of generative models, offering tradeoffs between playability and two representative diversity metrics (content-based and player-centered); enables decision-makers to select generators for various scenarios and needs.
AI.conclusion: Multi-objective diversity-aware training expands horizons of level generation, providing a principled way to balance multiple diversity dimensions and supports informed generator selection for different design goals and players.

title: Analysis of Bias in Deep Learning Facial Beauty Regressors
summary:
Bias can be introduced to AI systems even from seemingly balanced sources,
and AI facial beauty prediction is subject to ethnicity-based bias. This work
sounds warnings about AI's role in shaping aesthetic norms while providing
potential pathways toward equitable beauty technologies through comparative
analysis of models trained on SCUT-FBP5500 and MEBeauty datasets. Employing
rigorous statistical validation (Kruskal-Wallis H-tests, post hoc Dunn
analyses). It is demonstrated that both models exhibit significant prediction
disparities across ethnic groups $(p < 0.001)$, even when evaluated on the
balanced FairFace dataset. Cross-dataset validation shows algorithmic
amplification of societal beauty biases rather than mitigation based on
prediction and error parity. The findings underscore the inadequacy of current
AI beauty prediction approaches, with only 4.8-9.5\% of inter-group comparisons
satisfying distributional parity criteria. Mitigation strategies are proposed
and discussed in detail.

AI.tldr: AI-based beauty prediction exhibits strong ethnicity-based bias; cross-dataset analysis shows biases amplify rather than mitigate; very few inter-group comparisons meet distributional parity; mitigation strategies are proposed.
AI.motivation: Highlight how AI aesthetic judgments can encode and amplify societal beauty biases, even with balanced sources, and to assess cross-dataset generalization to inform equitable beauty technologies.
AI.method: Comparative analysis using SCUT-FBP5500 and MEBeauty datasets; statistical validation with Kruskal-Wallis H-tests and post hoc Dunn analyses; evaluation on the balanced FairFace dataset; cross-dataset validation to assess bias propagation.
AI.result: Significant prediction disparities across ethnic groups (p < 0.001) in both models, even on FairFace; cross-dataset validation shows algorithmic amplification of societal beauty biases rather than mitigation; only 4.8-9.5% of inter-group comparisons satisfy distributional parity.
AI.conclusion: Current AI beauty prediction approaches are inadequate; the work advocates mitigation strategies and discusses them in detail to pursue more equitable beauty technologies.

title: Watermarking Diffusion Language Models
summary:
We introduce the first watermark tailored for diffusion language models
(DLMs), an emergent LLM paradigm able to generate tokens in arbitrary order, in
contrast to standard autoregressive language models (ARLMs) which generate
tokens sequentially. While there has been much work in ARLM watermarking, a key
challenge when attempting to apply these schemes directly to the DLM setting is
that they rely on previously generated tokens, which are not always available
with DLM generation. In this work we address this challenge by: (i) applying
the watermark in expectation over the context even when some context tokens are
yet to be determined, and (ii) promoting tokens which increase the watermark
strength when used as context for other tokens. This is accomplished while
keeping the watermark detector unchanged. Our experimental evaluation
demonstrates that the DLM watermark leads to a >99% true positive rate with
minimal quality impact and achieves similar robustness to existing ARLM
watermarks, enabling for the first time reliable DLM watermarking.

AI.tldr: First diffusion-language-model watermark; high detection rate (>99%) with minimal quality loss; robustness comparable to ARLM watermarks.
AI.motivation: ARLM watermark methods rely on previous tokens; diffusion LMs generate tokens in arbitrary order, so a non-autoregressive watermarking approach is needed that works with uncertain context while preserving detector compatibility.
AI.method: Embed watermark by taking expectation over the partially known context (unknown future tokens) and bias the choice of tokens toward those that increase watermark strength when used as context for subsequent tokens; detector unchanged.
AI.result: Achieves >99% true positive rate with minimal quality impact; robustness comparable to ARLM watermarks; enables reliable DLM watermarking.
AI.conclusion: Presents a viable, robust watermarking scheme for diffusion language models, filling a key gap and enabling practical detection of machine-generated content from DLMs.

title: Asymmetric VAE for One-Step Video Super-Resolution Acceleration
summary:
Diffusion models have significant advantages in the field of real-world video
super-resolution and have demonstrated strong performance in past research. In
recent diffusion-based video super-resolution (VSR) models, the number of
sampling steps has been reduced to just one, yet there remains significant room
for further optimization in inference efficiency. In this paper, we propose
FastVSR, which achieves substantial reductions in computational cost by
implementing a high compression VAE (spatial compression ratio of 16, denoted
as f16). We design the structure of the f16 VAE and introduce a stable training
framework. We employ pixel shuffle and channel replication to achieve
additional upsampling. Furthermore, we propose a lower-bound-guided training
strategy, which introduces a simpler training objective as a lower bound for
the VAE's performance. It makes the training process more stable and easier to
converge. Experimental results show that FastVSR achieves speedups of 111.9
times compared to multi-step models and 3.92 times compared to existing
one-step models. We will release code and models at
https://github.com/JianzeLi-114/FastVSR.

AI.tldr: FastVSR uses a high-compression VAE (f16) to accelerate diffusion-based video super-resolution, achieving ~111.9x speedup over multi-step models and ~3.92x over existing one-step models, with stable training via a lower-bound-guided objective and simple upsampling.
AI.motivation: Although sampling steps in diffusion-based VSR can be reduced to one, there remains substantial room to improve inference efficiency.
AI.method: Design a high-compression VAE with spatial compression ratio 16 (f16), develop its structure and a stable training framework, apply pixel shuffle and channel replication for upsampling, and introduce a lower-bound-guided training objective to stabilize training.
AI.result: Experimental results report large inference-speed gains (111.9x vs multi-step, 3.92x vs existing one-step models) and a stable training setup; code and models will be released.
AI.conclusion: FastVSR significantly boosts diffusion-based VSR efficiency while preserving stability, with open-source release planned.

title: Evolution Strategies at Scale: LLM Fine-Tuning Beyond Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Fine-tuning pre-trained large language models (LLMs) for down-stream tasks is
a critical step in the AI deployment pipeline. Reinforcement learning (RL) is
arguably the most prominent fine-tuning method, contributing to the birth of
many state-of-the-art LLMs. In contrast, evolution strategies (ES), which once
showed comparable performance to RL on models with a few million parameters,
was neglected due to the pessimistic perception of its scalability to larger
models. In this work, we report the first successful attempt to scale up ES for
fine-tuning the full parameters of LLMs, showing the surprising fact that ES
can search efficiently over billions of parameters and outperform existing RL
fine-tuning methods in multiple respects, including sample efficiency,
tolerance to long-horizon rewards, robustness to different base LLMs, less
tendency to reward hacking, and more stable performance across runs. It
therefore serves as a basis to unlock a new direction in LLM fine-tuning beyond
what current RL techniques provide. The source codes are provided at:
https://github.com/VsonicV/es-fine-tuning-paper.

AI.tldr: Evolution strategies (ES) can scale to fine-tune full large language models (LLMs) and outperform reinforcement learning (RL) fine-tuning on several fronts, suggesting ES as a viable alternative for large-scale LLM customization.
AI.motivation: RL has been the dominant fine-tuning method for LLMs, but scalability concerns and perceived inefficiencies led to neglect of alternative approaches like ES. This work seeks to demonstrate that ES can effectively optimize billions of parameters and offer advantages over RL.
AI.method: Apply evolution strategies to fine-tune all parameters of full-size LLMs, conduct systematic comparisons with RL-based fine-tuning across multiple models and tasks, and evaluate metrics such as sample efficiency, tolerance to long-horizon rewards, robustness to different base LLMs, vulnerability to reward hacking, and stability across runs.
AI.result: ES-based fine-tuning can efficiently search over billions of parameters and, in experiments, outperforms existing RL fine-tuning methods in terms of sample efficiency, handling long-horizon rewards, robustness to different base models, reduced reward hacking, and more stable performance across runs.
AI.conclusion: ES provides a new direction for LLM fine-tuning beyond RL, enabling scalable, robust optimization of full-model parameters; the authors release source code for reproducibility.

title: Accelerating Cerebral Diagnostics with BrainFusion: A Comprehensive MRI Tumor Framework
comment:
6 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables. Accepted at the 12th International
  Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications 2025 (WINCOM 2025)
summary:
The early and accurate classification of brain tumors is crucial for guiding
effective treatment strategies and improving patient outcomes. This study
presents BrainFusion, a significant advancement in brain tumor analysis using
magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) by combining fine-tuned convolutional neural
networks (CNNs) for tumor classification--including VGG16, ResNet50, and
Xception--with YOLOv8 for precise tumor localization with bounding boxes.
Leveraging the Brain Tumor MRI Dataset, our experiments reveal that the
fine-tuned VGG16 model achieves test accuracy of 99.86%, substantially
exceeding previous benchmarks. Beyond setting a new accuracy standard, the
integration of bounding-box localization and explainable AI techniques further
enhances both the clinical interpretability and trustworthiness of the system's
outputs. Overall, this approach underscores the transformative potential of
deep learning in delivering faster, more reliable diagnoses, ultimately
contributing to improved patient care and survival rates.

AI.tldr: BrainFusion combines fine-tuned CNNs (VGG16, ResNet50, Xception) with YOLOv8 for simultaneous tumor classification and localization on MRI, achieving 99.86% accuracy on the Brain Tumor MRI Dataset and enhanced interpretability.
AI.motivation: Early and accurate brain tumor diagnosis with localization and explainability to guide treatment and improve outcomes; existing methods lack integrated high-accuracy classification and precise localization.
AI.method: Fine-tune VGG16, ResNet50, Xception for tumor classification; integrate YOLOv8 for tumor localization with bounding boxes; use explainable AI techniques; evaluate on Brain Tumor MRI Dataset.
AI.result: VGG16-based model achieves 99.86% test accuracy, exceeding prior benchmarks; localization and explainability augment interpretability and trust; approach shows potential for faster, more reliable diagnoses.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates transformative potential of deep learning in brain tumor analysis, supporting improved patient care and survival, with strong performance and added interpretability; future work could expand on other architectures and real-world deployment.

title: AXIS: Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection with Large Language Models
summary:
Time-series anomaly detection (TSAD) increasingly demands explanations that
articulate not only if an anomaly occurred, but also what pattern it exhibits
and why it is anomalous. Leveraging the impressive explanatory capabilities of
Large Language Models (LLMs), recent works have attempted to treat time series
as text for explainable TSAD. However, this approach faces a fundamental
challenge: LLMs operate on discrete tokens and struggle to directly process
long, continuous signals. Consequently, naive time-to-text serialization
suffers from a lack of contextual grounding and representation alignment
between the two modalities. To address this gap, we introduce AXIS, a framework
that conditions a frozen LLM for nuanced time-series understanding. Instead of
direct serialization, AXIS enriches the LLM's input with three complementary
hints derived from the series: (i) a symbolic numeric hint for numerical
grounding, (ii) a context-integrated, step-aligned hint distilled from a
pretrained time-series encoder to capture fine-grained dynamics, and (iii) a
task-prior hint that encodes global anomaly characteristics. Furthermore, to
facilitate robust evaluation of explainability, we introduce a new benchmark
featuring multi-format questions and rationales that supervise contextual
grounding and pattern-level semantics. Extensive experiments, including both
LLM-based and human evaluations, demonstrate that AXIS yields explanations of
significantly higher quality and achieves competitive detection accuracy
compared to general-purpose LLMs, specialized time-series LLMs, and time-series
Vision Language Models.

AI.tldr: AXIS is a framework that enables a frozen LLM to explain time-series anomaly detection by adding three grounding hints: a symbolic numeric cue, a context-aware, step-aligned representation from a pretrained TS encoder, and a task-prior hint capturing global anomaly traits. It also introduces a new benchmark for multi-format questions and rationales. The results show improved explanation quality and competitive detection accuracy against strong baselines.
AI.motivation: Time-series anomaly explanations should reveal not just detection, but the pattern and rationale. However, using direct time-to-text serialization fails to ground long, continuous signals in discrete tokens, limiting explainability. A method that grounds LLMs in time-series context is needed.
AI.method: AXIS augments a frozen LLM with three hints: (i) a symbolic numeric hint for grounding numerical values, (ii) a context-integrated, step-aligned hint distilled from a pretrained time-series encoder to capture fine-grained dynamics, and (iii) a task-prior hint encoding global anomaly characteristics. It also introduces a benchmarking suite with multi-format questions and rationales to supervise contextual grounding and pattern semantics, and evaluates both LLM-based and human explanations against various baselines.
AI.result: Experiments show AXIS produces explanations of significantly higher quality and yields competitive detection accuracy compared with general-purpose LLMs, specialized time-series LLMs, and time-series Vision-Language Models.
AI.conclusion: Structured grounding enables frozen LLMs to perform nuanced time-series understanding for explainable TSAD, with improved explanation quality and robust benchmarking establishing the method's effectiveness across baselines.

title: LatXGen: Towards Radiation-Free and Accurate Quantitative Analysis of Sagittal Spinal Alignment Via Cross-Modal Radiographic View Synthesis
summary:
Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (AIS) is a complex three-dimensional spinal
deformity, and accurate morphological assessment requires evaluating both
coronal and sagittal alignment. While previous research has made significant
progress in developing radiation-free methods for coronal plane assessment,
reliable and accurate evaluation of sagittal alignment without ionizing
radiation remains largely underexplored. To address this gap, we propose
LatXGen, a novel generative framework that synthesizes realistic lateral spinal
radiographs from posterior Red-Green-Blue and Depth (RGBD) images of unclothed
backs. This enables accurate, radiation-free estimation of sagittal spinal
alignment. LatXGen tackles two core challenges: (1) inferring sagittal spinal
morphology changes from a lateral perspective based on posteroanterior surface
geometry, and (2) performing cross-modality translation from RGBD input to the
radiographic domain. The framework adopts a dual-stage architecture that
progressively estimates lateral spinal structure and synthesizes corresponding
radiographs. To enhance anatomical consistency, we introduce an attention-based
Fast Fourier Convolution (FFC) module for integrating anatomical features from
RGBD images and 3D landmarks, and a Spatial Deformation Network (SDN) to model
morphological variations in the lateral view. Additionally, we construct the
first large-scale paired dataset for this task, comprising 3,264 RGBD and
lateral radiograph pairs. Experimental results demonstrate that LatXGen
produces anatomically accurate radiographs and outperforms existing GAN-based
methods in both visual fidelity and quantitative metrics. This study offers a
promising, radiation-free solution for sagittal spine assessment and advances
comprehensive AIS evaluation.

AI.tldr: LatXGen is a radiation-free generative framework that synthesizes lateral spine radiographs from RGBD back images to estimate sagittal alignment in AIS. It uses a dual-stage architecture with an attention-based FFT convolution and a Spatial Deformation Network, introduces a large paired RGBD–lateral radiograph dataset (3,264 pairs), and outperforms GAN baselines in fidelity and metrics, offering a promising tool for sagittal spine assessment.
AI.motivation: There is a critical need for non-ionizing methods to assess sagittal spinal alignment in AIS. While coronal-plane, radiation-free approaches exist, sagittal assessment remains underexplored. The paper addresses this gap by enabling accurate sagittal morphology estimation from surface data and translating RGBD inputs into radiographic representations.
AI.method: A dual-stage framework that first infers lateral spinal structure from posterior surface geometry and then performs cross-modality translation from RGBD to radiographs. An attention-based Fast Fourier Convolution (FFC) module fuses anatomical cues from RGBD images and 3D landmarks to enhance consistency. A Spatial Deformation Network (SDN) models morphological variations in the lateral view. A large-scale paired dataset of 3,264 RGBD–lateral radiograph pairs is constructed.
AI.result: LatXGen produces anatomically accurate radiographs and surpasses existing GAN-based methods in both visual fidelity and quantitative metrics.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a promising radiation-free solution for sagittal spine assessment and advances comprehensive AIS evaluation.

title: Muon: Training and Trade-offs with Latent Attention and MoE
summary:
We present a comprehensive theoretical and empirical study of the Muon
optimizer for training transformers only with a small to medium decoder (30M -
200M parameters), with an emphasis on its mathematical foundations, convergence
properties and synergistic interactions with modern architectural
optimizations. Building on recent work showing Muon's scalability, we provide
rigorous theoretical analysis including: (i)showing the convergence rate under
standard assumptions, (ii) spectral regularization properties that prevent
gradient explosion, (iii) connection to natural gradient descent on the Stiefel
manifold, and (iv) equivalence to steepest gradient descent under the spectral
norm. Crucially, we demonstrate that Muon expands the Pareto frontier in the
compute-time trade-off by maintaining superior data efficiency at large batch
sizes, a key finding of~\cite{essentialai2025muon} that we validate across our
model scales. Empirically, Muon reaches the target loss with 48-52\% of the
training calculated by AdamW while maintaining or improving the final
perplexity, consistent with larger-scale results. When combined with Multi-Head
Latent Attention (MLA) and Mixture-of-Experts (MoE), we observe multiplicative
efficiency gains: MLA+MoE+Muon achieves 68\% memory reduction and 3.2$\times$
inference speedup, while improving perplexity by 8-12\%. We provide detailed
procedures on 15 architectural and optimizer components, stability analyzes
across 100+ training runs, and practical implementation guidelines including
Newton-Schulz coefficients $(3.4445, -4.7750, 2.0315)$ optimized
by~\cite{su2024muonblog}. Our theoretical analysis and comprehensive
experiments establish Muon as a principled, robust alternative to AdamW that
particularly excels when combined with modern efficiency techniques and
large-batch training regimes.

AI.tldr: Muon optimizer enables efficient transformer training with small-to-medium decoders, offering convergence guarantees and spectral regularization; achieves substantial compute savings and memory/tempo improvements, combining well with MLA and MoE; acts as robust alternative to AdamW with large-batch training.
AI.motivation: Address inefficiencies in training large transformers and the trade-off between compute, memory, and performance. Extend prior scalability results to formal theory and practical guidelines for Muon's integration with modern efficiency techniques.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis: convergence rate under standard assumptions; spectral regularization preventing gradient explosion; connection to natural gradient on Stiefel; equivalence to steepest gradient under spectral norm. Empirical: verify Pareto frontier with large batch sizes; report training compute reduction (48-52%) and final perplexity; study synergy with MLA and MoE giving 68% memory reduction and 3.2x speedup; stability analyses over 100+ runs; provide guidelines including Newton-Schulz coefficients.
AI.result: Muon reaches target loss using 48-52% of AdamW's training compute and maintains/improves perplexity; MLA+MoE+Muon yields 68% memory reduction and 3.2x speedup with perplexity gains of 8-12%. Demonstrates broad empirical support across 15 components and 100+ runs.
AI.conclusion: Muon is a principled, robust alternative to AdamW, particularly effective with modern efficiency techniques and large-batch training, expanding the compute-time Pareto frontier.

title: High-Order Progressive Trajectory Matching for Medical Image Dataset Distillation
summary:
Medical image analysis faces significant challenges in data sharing due to
privacy regulations and complex institutional protocols. Dataset distillation
offers a solution to address these challenges by synthesizing compact datasets
that capture essential information from real, large medical datasets.
Trajectory matching has emerged as a promising methodology for dataset
distillation; however, existing methods primarily focus on terminal states,
overlooking crucial information in intermediate optimization states. We address
this limitation by proposing a shape-wise potential that captures the geometric
structure of parameter trajectories, and an easy-to-complex matching strategy
that progressively addresses parameters based on their complexity. Experiments
on medical image classification tasks demonstrate that our method improves
distillation performance while preserving privacy and maintaining model
accuracy comparable to training on the original datasets. Our code is available
at https://github.com/Bian-jh/HoP-TM.

AI.tldr: Shape-wise trajectory matching for medical data distillation using an easy-to-complex parameter matching strategy to exploit intermediate optimization dynamics, yielding better distilled data with privacy preservation.
AI.motivation: Medical data sharing is restricted by privacy regulations; dataset distillation aims to produce compact datasets that retain essential information, including information present in intermediate optimization states which terminal-state methods miss.
AI.method: Introduce a shape-wise potential to capture the geometric structure of parameter trajectories and an easy-to-complex matching strategy that prioritizes parameters by their optimization complexity; evaluate on medical image classification tasks; code released at GitHub.
AI.result: Improved distillation performance while preserving privacy; maintained accuracy comparable to training on the original data.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging intermediate optimization dynamics through trajectory geometry and staged parameter matching enhances dataset distillation effectiveness in medical imaging.

title: ScatterAD: Temporal-Topological Scattering Mechanism for Time Series Anomaly Detection
comment:
39th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS
  2025)
summary:
One main challenge in time series anomaly detection for industrial IoT lies
in the complex spatio-temporal couplings within multivariate data. However,
traditional anomaly detection methods focus on modeling spatial or temporal
dependencies independently, resulting in suboptimal representation learning and
limited sensitivity to anomalous dispersion in high-dimensional spaces. In this
work, we conduct an empirical analysis showing that both normal and anomalous
samples tend to scatter in high-dimensional space, especially anomalous samples
are markedly more dispersed. We formalize this dispersion phenomenon as
scattering, quantified by the mean pairwise distance among sample
representations, and leverage it as an inductive signal to enhance
spatio-temporal anomaly detection. Technically, we propose ScatterAD to model
representation scattering across temporal and topological dimensions. ScatterAD
incorporates a topological encoder for capturing graph-structured scattering
and a temporal encoder for constraining over-scattering through mean squared
error minimization between neighboring time steps. We introduce a contrastive
fusion mechanism to ensure the complementarity of the learned temporal and
topological representations. Additionally, we theoretically show that
maximizing the conditional mutual information between temporal and topological
views improves cross-view consistency and enhances more discriminative
representations. Extensive experiments on multiple public benchmarks show that
ScatterAD achieves state-of-the-art performance on multivariate time series
anomaly detection. Code is available at this repository:
https://github.com/jk-sounds/ScatterAD.

AI.tldr: ScatterAD introduces representation scattering to multivariate time series anomaly detection by jointly modeling temporal and topological (graph-structured) dispersions, using a temporal encoder, a topological encoder, and a contrastive fusion mechanism, underpinned by a conditional mutual information rationale. It achieves state-of-the-art results on public benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Industrial IoT time series exhibit complex spatio-temporal couplings and high-dimensional dispersion, especially for anomalies. Traditional methods model spatial or temporal dependencies separately, leading to suboptimal detection. The paper formalizes dispersion (scattering) and leverages it as a signal to improve anomaly detection.
AI.method: Propose ScatterAD with (1) a topological encoder to capture graph-structured scattering, (2) a temporal encoder that constrains over-scattering via mean squared error between neighboring time steps, (3) a contrastive fusion mechanism to ensure complementarity of temporal and topological representations, (4) a theoretical component showing that maximizing conditional mutual information between temporal and topological views improves cross-view consistency and discriminativeness.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple public benchmarks show ScatterAD achieves state-of-the-art performance on multivariate time series anomaly detection; code is released at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: ScatterAD effectively leverages representation scattering to enhance anomaly detection by jointly modeling temporal and topological dispersion, supported by theoretical justification and empirical evidence; it offers a scalable and performant approach for industrial IoT time series anomaly detection.

title: Combining Discrepancy-Confusion Uncertainty and Calibration Diversity for Active Fine-Grained Image Classification
summary:
Active learning (AL) aims to build high-quality labeled datasets by
iteratively selecting the most informative samples from an unlabeled pool under
limited annotation budgets. However, in fine-grained image classification,
assessing this informativeness is especially challenging due to subtle
inter-class differences. In this paper, we introduce a novel method, combining
discrepancy-confusion uncertainty and calibration diversity for active
fine-grained image classification (DECERN), to effectively perceive the
distinctiveness between fine-grained images and evaluate the sample value.
DECERN introduces a multifaceted informativeness measure that combines
discrepancy-confusion uncertainty and calibration diversity. The
discrepancy-confusion uncertainty quantifies the category directionality and
structural stability of fine-grained unlabeled data during local feature
fusion. Subsequently, uncertainty-weighted clustering is performed to diversify
the uncertainty samples. Then we calibrate the diversity to maximize the global
diversity of the selected sample while maintaining its local
representativeness. Extensive experiments conducted on 7 fine-grained image
datasets across 26 distinct experimental settings demonstrate that our method
achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: DECERN is a novel active learning framework for fine-grained image classification that fuses discrepancy-confusion uncertainty with calibration diversity to select informative and diverse samples; it outperforms state-of-the-art on 7 FG datasets.
AI.motivation: Fine-grained image classification has subtle inter-class differences, making it hard to judge which unlabeled samples are most informative. Existing active learning methods may struggle to capture directionality and diversity of FG samples.
AI.method: DECERN introduces discrepancy-confusion uncertainty to quantify category directionality and local feature-fusion stability, performs uncertainty-weighted clustering to diversify uncertain samples, and calibrates diversity to maximize global diversity while preserving local representativeness.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on 7 fine-grained datasets across 26 experimental settings show DECERN achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art active learning methods.
AI.conclusion: DECERN effectively identifies distinctive FG samples and enhances sample efficiency under limited labeling budgets, with potential applicability to other domains requiring fine-grained discrimination.

title: BiHDTrans: binary hyperdimensional transformer for efficient multivariate time series classification
summary:
The proliferation of Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices has led to an
unprecedented volume of multivariate time series (MTS) data, requiring
efficient and accurate processing for timely decision-making in
resource-constrained edge environments. Hyperdimensional (HD) computing, with
its inherent efficiency and parallelizability, has shown promise in
classification tasks but struggles to capture complex temporal patterns, while
Transformers excel at sequence modeling but incur high computational and memory
overhead. We introduce BiHDTrans, an efficient neurosymbolic binary
hyperdimensional Transformer that integrates self-attention into the HD
computing paradigm, unifying the representational efficiency of HD computing
with the temporal modeling power of Transformers. Empirically, BiHDTrans
outperforms state-of-the-art (SOTA) HD computing models by at least 14.47% and
achieves 6.67% higher accuracy on average than SOTA binary Transformers. With
hardware acceleration on FPGA, our pipelined implementation leverages the
independent and identically distributed properties of high-dimensional
representations, delivering 39.4 times lower inference latency than SOTA binary
Transformers. Theoretical analysis shows that binarizing in holographic
high-dimensional space incurs significantly less information distortion than
directly binarizing neural networks, explaining BiHDTrans's superior accuracy.
Furthermore, dimensionality experiments confirm that BiHDTrans remains
competitive even with a 64% reduction in hyperspace dimensionality, surpassing
SOTA binary Transformers by 1-2% in accuracy with 4.4 times less model size, as
well as further reducing the latency by 49.8% compare to the full-dimensional
baseline. Together, these contributions bridge the gap between the
expressiveness of Transformers and the efficiency of HD computing, enabling
accurate, scalable, and low-latency MTS classification.
