AI.tldr: BiHDTrans unifies binary hyperdimensional computing with Transformer-style self-attention to enable accurate, low-latency multivariate time series classification on resource-constrained edge devices, achieving superior accuracy and dramatically lower FPGA latency than state-of-the-art HD and binary Transformers, while remaining robust to dimensionality reduction.
AI.motivation: IoT edge devices generate large volumes of multivariate time series data, requiring efficient, accurate processing under tight resource constraints. HD computing offers efficiency but struggles with temporal patterns; Transformers supply strong sequence modeling but are computationally heavy. There is a need for a representation that combines expressiveness with efficiency for edge MTS tasks.
AI.method: Introduce BiHDTrans, a neurosymbolic binary hyperdimensional Transformer that injects self-attention into the HD computing framework. The model leverages binary/HD representations and a pipeline-friendly FPGA implementation that exploits the i.i.d. properties of high-dimensional vectors for fast inference. It fuses temporal modeling from Transformers with the representational efficiency and parallelism of HD computing, and demonstrates robustness under substantial dimensionality reduction (up to 64%).
AI.result: BiHDTrans achieves at least 14.47% higher accuracy than state-of-the-art HD models and 6.67% higher than state-of-the-art binary Transformers on average. FPGA-based hardware acceleration yields 39.4x lower inference latency than SOTA binary Transformers. The authors provide theoretical justification that binarizing in holographic high-dimensional space incurs less information distortion than binarizing conventional neural networks. Dimensionality experiments show competitive accuracy with 64% reduced hyperspace dimensionality, with 1-2% higher accuracy than SOTA binary Transformers, while achieving 4.4x smaller model size and 49.8% lower latency compared to the full-dimensional baseline.
AI.conclusion: BiHDTrans effectively bridges the expressiveness gap between Transformers and the efficiency of HD computing, delivering accurate, scalable, and low-latency MTS classification on resource-constrained edge devices, and offering a viable path toward practical neurosymbolic AI for IoT.

title: Tumor Synthesis conditioned on Radiomics
summary:
Due to privacy concerns, obtaining large datasets is challenging in medical
image analysis, especially with 3D modalities like Computed Tomography (CT) and
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Existing generative models, developed to
address this issue, often face limitations in output diversity and thus cannot
accurately represent 3D medical images. We propose a tumor-generation model
that utilizes radiomics features as generative conditions. Radiomics features
are high-dimensional handcrafted semantic features that are biologically
well-grounded and thus are good candidates for conditioning. Our model employs
a GAN-based model to generate tumor masks and a diffusion-based approach to
generate tumor texture conditioned on radiomics features. Our method allows the
user to generate tumor images according to user-specified radiomics features
such as size, shape, and texture at an arbitrary location. This enables the
physicians to easily visualize tumor images to better understand tumors
according to changing radiomics features. Our approach allows for the removal,
manipulation, and repositioning of tumors, generating various tumor types in
different scenarios. The model has been tested on tumors in four different
organs (kidney, lung, breast, and brain) across CT and MRI. The synthesized
images are shown to effectively aid in training for downstream tasks and their
authenticity was also evaluated through expert evaluations. Our method has
potential usage in treatment planning with diverse synthesized tumors.

AI.tldr: A radiomics-conditioned GAN+diffusion pipeline to synthesize diverse, controllable 3D tumor images across CT/MRI, enabling manipulation, placement, and radiomics-guided customization.
AI.motivation: Privacy-driven data scarcity and the limited diversity of existing generative models hinder robust 3D medical image synthesis. Radiomics features are biologically meaningful and suitable as conditioning signals for controllable generation.
AI.method: A two-stage framework: (1) a GAN-based model generates tumor masks conditioned on radiomics features; (2) a diffusion-based model generates tumor texture conditioned on the same radiomics features, enabling placement at arbitrary locations. The system supports removal, manipulation, and repositioning of tumors across four organs (kidney, lung, breast, brain) and two modalities (CT, MRI).
AI.result: The approach yields controllable, diverse tumor synthesis validated across four organs and CT/MRI. Synthesized images improve downstream task training, and expert evaluations support authenticity; the method shows potential utility in treatment planning.
AI.conclusion: Radiomics-conditioned generative modeling can produce diverse, realistic 3D tumor images with controllable attributes, offering practical benefits for training and planning, while enabling manipulation of tumor characteristics and location.

title: Semantic Compression via Multimodal Representation Learning
summary:
Multimodal representation learning produces high-dimensional embeddings that
align diverse modalities in a shared latent space. While this enables strong
generalization, it also introduces scalability challenges, both in terms of
storage and downstream processing. A key open problem is how to achieve
semantic compression, reducing the memory footprint of multimodal embeddings
while preserving their ability to represent shared semantic content across
modalities. In this paper, we prove a strong connection between reducing the
modality gap, which is the residual separation of embeddings from different
modalities, and the feasibility of post-training semantic compression. When the
gap is sufficiently reduced, embeddings from different modalities but
expressing the same semantics share a common portion of the space. Therefore,
their centroid is a faithful representation of such a semantic concept. This
enables replacing multiple embeddings with a single centroid, yielding
significant memory savings. We propose a novel approach for semantic
compression grounded on the latter intuition, operating directly on pretrained
encoders. We demonstrate its effectiveness across diverse large-scale
multimodal downstream tasks. Our results highlight that modality alignment is a
key enabler for semantic compression, showing that the proposed approach
achieves significant compression without sacrificing performance.

AI.tldr: Reducing modality gap in multimodal embeddings enables semantic compression by replacing multiple modality-specific embeddings with a shared centroid, achieving memory savings with preserved performance.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional multimodal embeddings strain storage and downstream processing; aligning modalities creates a shared semantic space that makes compression feasible.
AI.method: Proposes a compression framework that operates on pretrained encoders, leveraging the reduced modality gap so that embeddings expressing the same concept across modalities share a centroid; replaces modality-specific representations with centroids to compress.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on diverse large-scale multimodal tasks shows substantial memory savings with negligible or no loss in performance, underscoring modality alignment as a key enabler.
AI.conclusion: Semantic compression is feasible when modality alignment reduces cross-modal gaps; the proposed centroid-based approach enables effective post-training compression without sacrificing semantic fidelity.

title: Simulating Post-Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy Breast Cancer MRI via Diffusion Model with Prompt Tuning
summary:
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) is a common therapy option before the main
surgery for breast cancer. Response to NAC is monitored using follow-up dynamic
contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (DCE-MRI). Accurate prediction of
NAC response helps with treatment planning. Here, we adopt maximum intensity
projection images from DCE-MRI to generate post-treatment images (i.e., 3 or 12
weeks after NAC) from pre-treatment images leveraging the emerging diffusion
model. We introduce prompt tuning to account for the known clinical factors
affecting response to NAC. Our model performed better than other generative
models in image quality metrics. Our model was better at generating images that
reflected changes in tumor size according to pCR compared to other models.
Ablation study confirmed the design choices of our method. Our study has the
potential to help with precision medicine.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-model–based approach with prompt tuning that predicts post-NAC DCE-MRI changes from pre-treatment scans to reflect breast cancer response, aiding treatment planning.
AI.motivation: To enable early, noninvasive prediction of response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) in breast cancer by generating post-treatment imaging from pre-treatment data, thus guiding personalized therapy.
AI.method: Use maximum intensity projection (MIP) images from DCE-MRI to generate post-treatment images (3 or 12 weeks after NAC) from pre-treatment images via a diffusion-model framework. Introduce prompt tuning to incorporate known clinical factors affecting NAC response. Compare with other generative models and perform ablations.
AI.result: The proposed model achieved superior image quality metrics and better reflected tumor-size changes associated with pathological complete response (pCR) compared with other models. Ablation studies validated design choices.
AI.conclusion: The approach shows promise for precision medicine by enabling prediction of NAC response from pre-treatment data, potentially aiding treatment planning and decision-making.

title: EOE: Evolutionary Optimization of Experts for Training Language Models
summary:
This paper presents an evolutionary framework for the training of large
language models(LLM). The models are divided into several
experts(sub-networks), which have the same structure but different parameter
values. Only one expert is trained at each step. After the classical AdamW
optimization, some evolutionary operators(crossover, PSO, and mutation) act on
the tensor weights between the current expert and the best expert. So current
expert would learn the experience of best expert. The direction of best expert
would help current expert's loss decrease faster. Finally, only save the weight
of the best expert. Experiments show that best expert would achieve nearly the
same accuracy as the full model. This would greatly reduce the size of the
model for inference. Since only one expert is trained at each step, the
training needs much less memory and has much higher throughput. Experiments
show that the throughput would accelerate more than ten times! Our source code
is available. It's a pure c++/cu framework, which is suitable for easy
deployment on PCs and edge computing devices.

AI.tldr: An evolutionary framework trains LLMs by partitioning the model into expert sub-networks; only one expert is trained at a time. After AdamW optimization, evolutionary operators (crossover, PSO, mutation) adjust weights toward the best expert, and only the best expert is saved. The best expert approaches full-model accuracy with significantly reduced memory and over 10x throughput, with a pure C++/CUDA implementation enabling PC/edge deployment.
AI.motivation: To reduce training memory, cost, and inference size for large language models by sharing knowledge across expert sub-networks and transferring improvements via evolutionary operators, aiming for near full-model performance with much smaller, faster models suitable for edge devices.
AI.method: Divide the LLM into multiple identical-structure experts with different parameters. Train only one expert per step using AdamW. After optimization, apply evolutionary operators (crossover, PSO, mutation) on the tensor weights between the current expert and the best expert to transfer the best’s experience. The current expert updates toward the best; finally, only the best expert’s weights are saved. Compare performance against the full model. Implemented in pure C++/CUDA for deployment on PCs and edge devices.
AI.result: Empirically, the best expert attains nearly the same accuracy as the full model, while requiring far less memory and delivering over tenfold throughput improvements during training. The framework claims notable efficiency gains and practical deployment benefits, supported by publicly available source code.
AI.conclusion: An evolutionary-expert framework can deliver competitive accuracy with substantially reduced model size and dramatically higher throughput, enabling efficient training and edge deployment of LLMs. Further work could explore stability, scalability across larger expert counts, and comparison to other model compression/training techniques.

title: Talk in Pieces, See in Whole: Disentangling and Hierarchical Aggregating Representations for Language-based Object Detection
summary:
While vision-language models (VLMs) have made significant progress in
multimodal perception (e.g., open-vocabulary object detection) with simple
language queries, state-of-the-art VLMs still show limited ability to perceive
complex queries involving descriptive attributes and relational clauses. Our
in-depth analysis shows that these limitations mainly stem from text encoders
in VLMs. Such text encoders behave like bags-of-words and fail to separate
target objects from their descriptive attributes and relations in complex
queries, resulting in frequent false positives. To address this, we propose
restructuring linguistic representations according to the hierarchical
relations within sentences for language-based object detection. A key insight
is the necessity of disentangling textual tokens into core components-objects,
attributes, and relations ("talk in pieces")-and subsequently aggregating them
into hierarchically structured sentence-level representations ("see in whole").
Building on this principle, we introduce the TaSe framework with three main
contributions: (1) a hierarchical synthetic captioning dataset spanning three
tiers from category names to descriptive sentences; (2) Talk in Pieces, the
three-component disentanglement module guided by a novel disentanglement loss
function, transforms text embeddings into subspace compositions; and (3) See in
Whole, which learns to aggregate disentangled components into hierarchically
structured embeddings with the guide of proposed hierarchical objectives. The
proposed TaSe framework strengthens the inductive bias of hierarchical
linguistic structures, resulting in fine-grained multimodal representations for
language-based object detection. Experimental results under the OmniLabel
benchmark show a 24% performance improvement, demonstrating the importance of
linguistic compositionality.

AI.tldr: TaSe tackles a key bottleneck in vision-language models: text encoders that act as bags-of-words, failing to separate objects, attributes, and relations in complex queries. It introduces a hierarchical, compositional approach—Talk in Pieces to disentangle objects, attributes, and relations, and See in Whole to aggregate them—into a TaSe framework with a synthetic three-tier dataset. This yields a 24% improvement on OmniLabel, underscoring linguistic compositionality for language-based object detection.
AI.motivation: To overcome the inability of current VLM text encoders to parse complex relational and descriptive queries, which leads to false positives in language-based object detection. The authors argue that disentangling linguistic components and structuring them hierarchically can better align textual representations with visual concepts.
AI.method: TaSe comprises three parts: (1) a hierarchical synthetic captioning dataset spanning category names, descriptive sentences, and beyond; (2) Talk in Pieces, a disentanglement module that decomposes text embeddings into core components—objects, attributes, relations—guided by a disentanglement loss; (3) See in Whole, an aggregation mechanism that combines these components into hierarchically structured sentence embeddings under hierarchical objectives.
AI.result: Empirical results on the OmniLabel benchmark show a 24% improvement, indicating that enforcing linguistic compositionality improves fine-grained multimodal representations for language-based object detection.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcing hierarchical linguistic structure via disentangled, compositional text representations yields stronger inductive biases for VLMs, improving language-based object detection in complex queries.

title: Distributionally Robust Federated Learning with Outlier Resilience
summary:
Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without direct
data sharing, but its performance can degrade significantly in the presence of
data distribution perturbations. Distributionally robust optimization (DRO)
provides a principled framework for handling this by optimizing performance
against the worst-case distributions within a prescribed ambiguity set.
However, existing DRO-based FL methods often overlook the detrimental impact of
outliers in local datasets, which can disproportionately bias the learned
models. In this work, we study distributionally robust federated learning with
explicit outlier resilience. We introduce a novel ambiguity set based on the
unbalanced Wasserstein distance, which jointly captures geometric
distributional shifts and incorporates a non-geometric Kullback--Leibler
penalization to mitigate the influence of outliers. This formulation naturally
leads to a challenging min--max--max optimization problem. To enable
decentralized training, we reformulate the problem as a tractable Lagrangian
penalty optimization, which admits robustness certificates. Building on this
reformulation, we propose the distributionally outlier-robust federated
learning algorithm and establish its convergence guarantees. Extensive
experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate the
effectiveness of our approach.

AI.tldr: A distributionally robust federated learning framework using unbalanced Wasserstein distance with KL penalties to mitigate outliers, solved via a tractable Lagrangian reformulation and a decentralized algorithm with convergence guarantees and robustness certificates, validated on synthetic and real data.
AI.motivation: Federated learning performance deteriorates under distributional perturbations; standard DRO improves robustness but often ignores the adverse impact of local outliers, which can bias models. There is a need for an outlier-resilient DRO approach in FL.
AI.method: Introduce an ambiguity set based on unbalanced Wasserstein distance augmented with a non-geometric KL penalty to suppress outliers. This yields a min–max–max problem, which is reformulated as a tractable Lagrangian penalty problem enabling decentralized optimization. The framework provides robustness certificates and a practical algorithm for distributed training.
AI.result: The method comes with convergence guarantees and comprehensive experiments on synthetic and real datasets demonstrating effective outlier-robust performance and improved resilience to distribution shifts.
AI.conclusion: We present a principled, outlier-resilient distributionally robust federated learning framework with provable guarantees and empirically validated robustness against data distribution perturbations and local outliers.

title: An Efficient 3D Latent Diffusion Model for T1-contrast Enhanced MRI Generation
summary:
Objective: Gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs) are commonly employed
with T1w MRI to enhance lesion visualization but are restricted in patients at
risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis and variations in GBCA administration can
introduce imaging inconsistencies. This study develops an efficient 3D
deep-learning framework to generate T1-contrast enhanced images (T1C) from
pre-contrast multiparametric MRI. Approach: We propose the 3D latent rectified
flow (T1C-RFlow) model for generating high-quality T1C images. First, T1w and
T2-FLAIR images are input into a pretrained autoencoder to acquire an efficient
latent space representation. A rectified flow diffusion model is then trained
in this latent space representation. The T1C-RFlow model was trained on a
curated dataset comprised of the BraTS 2024 glioma (GLI; 1480 patients),
meningioma (MEN; 1141 patients), and metastases (MET; 1475 patients) datasets.
Selected patients were split into train (N=2860), validation (N=612), and test
(N=614) sets. Results: Both qualitative and quantitative results demonstrate
that the T1C-RFlow model outperforms benchmark 3D models (pix2pix, DDPM,
Diffusion Transformers (DiT-3D)) trained in the same latent space. T1C-RFlow
achieved the following metrics - GLI: NMSE 0.044 +/- 0.047, SSIM 0.935 +/-
0.025; MEN: NMSE 0.046 +/- 0.029, SSIM 0.937 +/- 0.021; MET: NMSE 0.098 +/-
0.088, SSIM 0.905 +/- 0.082. T1C-RFlow had the best tumor reconstruction
performance and significantly faster denoising times (6.9 s/volume, 200 steps)
than conventional DDPM models in both latent space (37.7s, 1000 steps) and
patch-based in image space (4.3 hr/volume). Significance: Our proposed method
generates synthetic T1C images that closely resemble ground truth T1C in much
less time than previous diffusion models. Further development may permit a
practical method for contrast-agent-free MRI for brain tumors.

AI.tldr: A 3D latent rectified flow diffusion model (T1C-RFlow) generates synthetic T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI (T1C) from pre-contrast multiparametric MRI, achieving high fidelity across glioma, meningioma, and metastasis datasets with much faster inference than prior diffusion models.
AI.motivation: Gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs) pose risks (nephrogenic systemic fibrosis) and variable GBCA administration can cause imaging inconsistencies. The study seeks a contrast-agent-free method to produce reliable T1C images from pre-contrast MRI to improve brain tumor visualization.
AI.method: 3D latent rectified flow (T1C-RFlow): input T1-weighted (T1w) and T2-FLAIR into a pretrained autoencoder to obtain a latent representation; train a rectified flow diffusion model in latent space to generate T1C. Dataset includes BraTS 2024 glioma (GLI), meningioma (MEN), and metastases (MET) with train/validation/test splits. Compared against pix2pix, DDPM, and DiT-3D; evaluation uses NMSE and SSIM; inference-speed compared to other diffusion models.
AI.result: T1C-RFlow outperforms benchmarks in latent space and image space (GLI NMSE 0.044±0.047, SSIM 0.935±0.025; MEN NMSE 0.046±0.029, SSIM 0.937±0.021; MET NMSE 0.098±0.088, SSIM 0.905±0.082). It yields best tumor reconstruction and dramatically faster denoising (6.9 s/volume, 200 steps) versus 37.7 s (1000 steps) in latent space and 4.3 h/volume in patch-based image space.
AI.conclusion: The method can generate synthetic T1C images closely resembling ground truth with substantially reduced computation time, enabling potential clinical deployment of contrast-agent-free MRI for brain tumors; future work may extend clinical applicability.

title: Interpretable Kernel Representation Learning at Scale: A Unified Framework Utilizing Nyström Approximation
summary:
Kernel methods provide a theoretically grounded framework for non-linear and
non-parametric learning, with strong analytic foundations and statistical
guarantees. Yet, their scalability has long been limited by prohibitive time
and memory costs. While progress has been made in scaling kernel regression, no
framework exists for scalable kernel-based representation learning, restricting
their use in the era of foundation models where representations are learned
from massive unlabeled data. We introduce KREPES -- a unified, scalable
framework for kernel-based representation learning via Nystr\"om approximation.
KREPES accommodates a wide range of unsupervised and self-supervised losses,
and experiments on large image and tabular datasets demonstrate its efficiency.
Crucially, KREPES enables principled interpretability of the learned
representations, an immediate benefit over deep models, which we substantiate
through dedicated analysis.

AI.tldr: A scalable kernel-based representation learning framework (KREPES) using Nyström approximation for unsupervised/self-supervised learning with interpretable representations.
AI.motivation: Kernel methods offer strong theory but scale poorly; there is no scalable framework for kernel-based representation learning on massive unlabeled data, limiting interpretability advantages vs. deep models.
AI.method: Propose KREPES, a unified framework leveraging Nyström approximation to scale kernel representations and support a broad set of unsupervised and self-supervised losses.
AI.result: Large-scale experiments on image and tabular data show efficiency gains; representations learned via KREPES are interpretable, with dedicated analysis supporting interpretability.
AI.conclusion: KREPES enables scalable, interpretable kernel-based representation learning, extending kernel methods into large-scale, self-supervised representation learning and offering principled interpretability over deep models.

title: UniVid: The Open-Source Unified Video Model
summary:
Unified video modeling that combines generation and understanding
capabilities is increasingly important but faces two key challenges:
maintaining semantic faithfulness during flow-based generation due to
text-visual token imbalance and the limitations of uniform cross-modal
attention across the flow trajectory, and efficiently extending image-centric
MLLMs to video without costly retraining. We present UniVid, a unified
architecture that couples an MLLM with a diffusion decoder through a
lightweight adapter, enabling both video understanding and generation. We
introduce Temperature Modality Alignment to improve prompt adherence and
Pyramid Reflection for efficient temporal reasoning via dynamic keyframe
selection. Extensive experiments on standard benchmarks demonstrate
state-of-the-art performance, achieving a 2.2% improvement on VBench-Long total
score compared to EasyAnimateV5.1, and 1.0% and 3.3% accuracy gains on MSVD-QA
and ActivityNet-QA, respectively, compared with the best prior 7B baselines.

AI.tldr: UniVid presents a unified video modeling approach that fuses an MLLM with a diffusion decoder via a lightweight adapter to support both video understanding and generation, addressing semantic faithfulness and cross-modal attention efficiency. It introduces Temperature Modality Alignment and Pyramid Reflection for improved prompt adherence and temporal reasoning, achieving state-of-the-art benchmarks.
AI.motivation: The field lacks a single architecture that simultaneously handles video understanding and generation. Flow-based generation suffers from text-visual token imbalance affecting semantic fidelity, and uniform cross-modal attention across a video sequence is inefficient. Extending image-centric MLLMs to video is costly due to retraining demands.
AI.method: UniVid couples a large multilingual language model (MLLM) with a diffusion-based decoder through a lightweight adapter, enabling joint video understanding and generation. It introduces Temperature Modality Alignment to improve prompt adherence to visual inputs and Pyramid Reflection for efficient temporal reasoning via dynamic keyframe selection, addressing cross-modal attention and temporal complexity.
AI.result: Empirical results show state-of-the-art performance on standard benchmarks, including a 2.2% improvement in VBench-Long total score over EasyAnimateV5.1, and 1.0% and 3.3% accuracy gains on MSVD-QA and ActivityNet-QA respectively over the best prior 7B baselines.
AI.conclusion: UniVid demonstrates that a unified architecture combining an MLLM with a diffusion decoder, complemented by targeted alignment and efficient temporal reasoning techniques, can simultaneously excel at video understanding and generation, pushing forward unified video modeling benchmarks.

title: FS-KAN: Permutation Equivariant Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks via Function Sharing
summary:
Permutation equivariant neural networks employing parameter-sharing schemes
have emerged as powerful models for leveraging a wide range of data symmetries,
significantly enhancing the generalization and computational efficiency of the
resulting models. Recently, Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) have demonstrated
promise through their improved interpretability and expressivity compared to
traditional architectures based on MLPs. While equivariant KANs have been
explored in recent literature for a few specific data types, a principled
framework for applying them to data with permutation symmetries in a general
context remains absent. This paper introduces Function Sharing KAN (FS-KAN), a
principled approach to constructing equivariant and invariant KA layers for
arbitrary permutation symmetry groups, unifying and significantly extending
previous work in this domain. We derive the basic construction of these FS-KAN
layers by generalizing parameter-sharing schemes to the Kolmogorov-Arnold setup
and provide a theoretical analysis demonstrating that FS-KANs have the same
expressive power as networks that use standard parameter-sharing layers,
allowing us to transfer well-known and important expressivity results from
parameter-sharing networks to FS-KANs. Empirical evaluations on multiple data
types and symmetry groups show that FS-KANs exhibit superior data efficiency
compared to standard parameter-sharing layers, by a wide margin in certain
cases, while preserving the interpretability and adaptability of KANs, making
them an excellent architecture choice in low-data regimes.

AI.tldr: FS-KAN generalizes Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks to arbitrary permutation symmetries using Function Sharing, unifying and extending equivariant/invariant KA layers; it preserves expressivity while enhancing data efficiency, especially in low-data regimes.
AI.motivation: There is no principled framework for applying equivariant Kolmogorov-Arnold networks to data with permutation symmetries in a general setting; a unified, interpretable, and data-efficient approach is needed.
AI.method: Generalize parameter-sharing schemes to the Kolmogorov-Arnold framework to construct Function Sharing KA (FS-KAN) layers that are equivariant or invariant to arbitrary permutation groups; provide theoretical results showing FS-KANs have the same expressive power as standard parameter-sharing networks and derive the layer construction; perform empirical evaluations across multiple data types and symmetry groups.
AI.result: FS-KANs demonstrate superior data efficiency compared to standard parameter-sharing layers across several data types and symmetry groups, with larger gains in some cases, while preserving the interpretability and adaptability of KA-based architectures in low-data regimes.
AI.conclusion: FS-KAN provides a principled framework for permutation-symmetric KA layers that matches the expressivity of standard PS networks, extends and unifies prior work, and offers improved data efficiency, particularly in low-data settings.

title: BALR-SAM: Boundary-Aware Low-Rank Adaptation of SAM for Resource-Efficient Medical Image Segmentation
summary:
Vision foundation models like the Segment Anything Model (SAM), pretrained on
large-scale natural image datasets, often struggle in medical image
segmentation due to a lack of domain-specific adaptation. In clinical practice,
fine-tuning such models efficiently for medical downstream tasks with minimal
resource demands, while maintaining strong performance, is challenging. To
address these issues, we propose BALR-SAM, a boundary-aware low-rank adaptation
framework that enhances SAM for medical imaging. It combines three tailored
components: (1) a Complementary Detail Enhancement Network (CDEN) using
depthwise separable convolutions and multi-scale fusion to capture
boundary-sensitive features essential for accurate segmentation; (2) low-rank
adapters integrated into SAM's Vision Transformer blocks to optimize feature
representation and attention for medical contexts, while simultaneously
significantly reducing the parameter space; and (3) a low-rank tensor attention
mechanism in the mask decoder, cutting memory usage by 75% and boosting
inference speed. Experiments on standard medical segmentation datasets show
that BALR-SAM, without requiring prompts, outperforms several state-of-the-art
(SOTA) methods, including fully fine-tuned MedSAM, while updating just 1.8%
(11.7M) of its parameters.

AI.tldr: BALR-SAM: boundary-aware low-rank adaptation of SAM for medical image segmentation that updates 1.8% of parameters and without prompts, achieving SOTA performance with reduced resource use.
AI.motivation: Large foundation models pretrained on natural images underperform in medical segmentation due to domain shift and resource-heavy fine-tuning. There is a need for efficient, low-resource adaptation that preserves or improves performance.
AI.method: Three components: (1) Complementary Detail Enhancement Network (CDEN) using depthwise separable convolutions and multi-scale fusion to capture boundary-sensitive features; (2) low-rank adapters integrated into SAM's Vision Transformer blocks to optimize feature representation and attention with minimal parameter increase; (3) low-rank tensor attention in the mask decoder to reduce memory usage by 75% and speed up inference. The model operates without prompts and fine-tunes a small fraction of the original parameters (1.8% of 11.7M).
AI.result: BALR-SAM outperforms several state-of-the-art methods, including fully fine-tuned MedSAM, on standard medical segmentation datasets.
AI.conclusion: Boundary-aware, resource-efficient adaptation of SAM is effective for medical imaging, achieving strong performance with minimal parameter updates and significant efficiency gains.

title: One-Prompt Strikes Back: Sparse Mixture of Experts for Prompt-based Continual Learning
summary:
Prompt-based methods have recently gained prominence in Continual Learning
(CL) due to their strong performance and memory efficiency. A prevalent
strategy in this paradigm assigns a dedicated subset of prompts to each task,
which, while effective, incurs substantial computational overhead and causes
memory requirements to scale linearly with the number of tasks. Conversely,
approaches employing a single shared prompt across tasks offer greater
efficiency but often suffer from degraded performance due to knowledge
interference. To reconcile this trade-off, we propose SMoPE, a novel framework
that integrates the benefits of both task-specific and shared prompt
strategies. Inspired by recent findings on the relationship between Prefix
Tuning and Mixture of Experts (MoE), SMoPE organizes a shared prompt into
multiple "prompt experts" within a sparse MoE architecture. For each input,
only a select subset of relevant experts is activated, effectively mitigating
interference. To facilitate expert selection, we introduce a prompt-attention
score aggregation mechanism that computes a unified proxy score for each
expert, enabling dynamic and sparse activation. Additionally, we propose an
adaptive noise mechanism to encourage balanced expert utilization while
preserving knowledge from prior tasks. To further enhance expert
specialization, we design a prototype-based loss function that leverages prefix
keys as implicit memory representations. Extensive experiments across multiple
CL benchmarks demonstrate that SMoPE consistently outperforms task-specific
prompt methods and achieves performance competitive with state-of-the-art
approaches, all while significantly reducing parameter counts and computational
costs.

AI.tldr: SMoPE introduces a sparse MoE-based prompt architecture for continual learning, balancing task-specific and shared prompts to improve efficiency and reduce interference.
AI.motivation: To reduce memory and computation of per-task prompts while mitigating knowledge interference across tasks, by leveraging mixture-of-experts within a shared prompt framework.
AI.method: A shared prompt is decomposed into multiple prompt experts arranged in a sparse MoE. For each input, an attention-based scoring aggregator selects a small subset of experts. An adaptive noise mechanism balances expert usage. A prototype-based loss using prefix keys acts as implicit memory. Training spans multiple tasks in continual learning.
AI.result: SMoPE outperforms task-specific prompt baselines and is competitive with state-of-the-art approaches, while reducing parameter counts and computational cost.
AI.conclusion: Integrating MoE-like sparsity with prompt-based continual learning yields efficient, scalable performance, with dynamic expert activation and memory-inspired regularization enhancing specialization and reducing interference.

title: Forge4D: Feed-Forward 4D Human Reconstruction and Interpolation from Uncalibrated Sparse-view Videos
summary:
Instant reconstruction of dynamic 3D humans from uncalibrated sparse-view
videos is critical for numerous downstream applications. Existing methods,
however, are either limited by the slow reconstruction speeds or incapable of
generating novel-time representations. To address these challenges, we propose
Forge4D, a feed-forward 4D human reconstruction and interpolation model that
efficiently reconstructs temporally aligned representations from uncalibrated
sparse-view videos, enabling both novel view and novel time synthesis. Our
model simplifies the 4D reconstruction and interpolation problem as a joint
task of streaming 3D Gaussian reconstruction and dense motion prediction. For
the task of streaming 3D Gaussian reconstruction, we first reconstruct static
3D Gaussians from uncalibrated sparse-view images and then introduce learnable
state tokens to enforce temporal consistency in a memory-friendly manner by
interactively updating shared information across different timestamps. For
novel time synthesis, we design a novel motion prediction module to predict
dense motions for each 3D Gaussian between two adjacent frames, coupled with an
occlusion-aware Gaussian fusion process to interpolate 3D Gaussians at
arbitrary timestamps. To overcome the lack of the ground truth for dense motion
supervision, we formulate dense motion prediction as a dense point matching
task and introduce a self-supervised retargeting loss to optimize this module.
An additional occlusion-aware optical flow loss is introduced to ensure motion
consistency with plausible human movement, providing stronger regularization.
Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our model on both
in-domain and out-of-domain datasets. Project page and code at:
https://zhenliuzju.github.io/huyingdong/Forge4D.

AI.tldr: Forge4D delivers fast, feed-forward 4D human reconstruction and interpolation from uncalibrated sparse-view videos by streaming 3D Gaussian representations and predicting dense motions for novel-time synthesis, with self-supervised losses for motion supervision.
AI.motivation: Existing 4D reconstruction methods are too slow or cannot synthesize novel time representations, especially from uncalibrated sparse views, limiting downstream applications.
AI.method: 1) Streaming 3D Gaussian reconstruction from sparse views; 2) learnable state tokens to enforce temporal consistency across timestamps (memory-friendly); 3) novel-time synthesis via a dense motion prediction module predicting frame-to-frame motions for each 3D Gaussian; 4) occlusion-aware Gaussian fusion to interpolate Gaussians at arbitrary timestamps; 5) self-supervised dense motion supervision via dense point matching with a retargeting loss; 6) occlusion-aware optical flow loss for regularization.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on both in-domain and out-of-domain datasets show Forge4D is effective for fast 4D reconstruction and novel-time interpolation; project page and code available for reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: Forge4D provides a scalable, online-capable framework that enables both novel-view and novel-time synthesis from uncalibrated sparse video inputs by combining streaming Gaussian representations with learned dense motions and self-supervised losses.

title: Guided Uncertainty Learning Using a Post-Hoc Evidential Meta-Model
summary:
Reliable uncertainty quantification remains a major obstacle to the
deployment of deep learning models under distributional shift. Existing
post-hoc approaches that retrofit pretrained models either inherit misplaced
confidence or merely reshape predictions, without teaching the model when to be
uncertain. We introduce GUIDE, a lightweight evidential learning meta-model
approach that attaches to a frozen deep learning model and explicitly learns
how and when to be uncertain. GUIDE identifies salient internal features via a
calibration stage, and then employs these features to construct a noise-driven
curriculum that teaches the model how and when to express uncertainty. GUIDE
requires no retraining, no architectural modifications, and no manual
intermediate-layer selection to the base deep learning model, thus ensuring
broad applicability and minimal user intervention. The resulting model avoids
distilling overconfidence from the base model, improves out-of-distribution
detection by ~77% and adversarial attack detection by ~80%, while preserving
in-distribution performance. Across diverse benchmarks, GUIDE consistently
outperforms state-of-the-art approaches, evidencing the need for actively
guiding uncertainty to close the gap between predictive confidence and
reliability.

AI.tldr: GUIDE is a lightweight, post-hoc meta-model that attaches to a frozen base model to learn when and how to be uncertain, improving reliability under distributional shift without retraining.
AI.motivation: Uncertainty quantification under distributional shift remains unreliable; existing post-hoc approaches either miscalibrate or only reshape predictions. A method is needed to actively teach uncertainty.
AI.method: Identify salient internal features via a calibration stage, then construct a noise-driven curriculum that trains the model to express uncertainty at appropriate times. The approach attaches to a frozen base model, requires no retraining or architectural modifications, and avoids manual layer selection.
AI.result: Out-of-distribution detection improved by ~77%; adversarial attack detection improved by ~80%; preserves in-distribution performance; consistently outperforms state-of-the-art across benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Actively guiding uncertainty bridges the gap between predictive confidence and reliability; GUIDE offers broad applicability with minimal user intervention.

title: Scalable Audio-Visual Masked Autoencoders for Efficient Affective Video Facial Analysis
summary:
Affective video facial analysis (AVFA) has emerged as a key research field
for building emotion-aware intelligent systems, yet this field continues to
suffer from limited data availability. In recent years, the self-supervised
learning (SSL) technique of Masked Autoencoders (MAE) has gained momentum, with
growing adaptations in its audio-visual contexts. While scaling has proven
essential for breakthroughs in general multi-modal learning domains, its
specific impact on AVFA remains largely unexplored. Another core challenge in
this field is capturing both intra- and inter-modal correlations through
scalable audio-visual representations. To tackle these issues, we propose
AVF-MAE++, a family of audio-visual MAE models designed to efficiently
investigate the scaling properties in AVFA while enhancing cross-modal
correlation modeling. Our framework introduces a novel dual masking strategy
across audio and visual modalities and strengthens modality encoders with a
more holistic design to better support scalable pre-training. Additionally, we
present the Iterative Audio-Visual Correlation Learning Module, which improves
correlation learning within the SSL paradigm, bridging the limitations of
previous methods. To support smooth adaptation and reduce overfitting risks, we
further introduce a progressive semantic injection strategy, organizing the
model training into three structured stages. Extensive experiments conducted on
17 datasets, covering three major AVFA tasks, demonstrate that AVF-MAE++
achieves consistent state-of-the-art performance across multiple benchmarks.
Comprehensive ablation studies further highlight the importance of each
proposed component and provide deeper insights into the design choices driving
these improvements. Our code and models have been publicly released at Github.

AI.tldr: AVF-MAE++ introduces dual-modal masking MAE for audio-visual affective video analysis, enabling scalable pre-training and improved cross-modal correlation, achieving state-of-the-art results on 17 datasets across three AVFA tasks, with extensive ablations and released code.
AI.motivation: AVFA suffers from data scarcity and limited exploration of scaling in multi-modal SSL. There is a need to better model intra- and inter-modal correlations in scalable AV representations to boost performance and robustness.
AI.method: Propose AVF-MAE++ family of audio-visual MAE models featuring: (1) dual masking across audio and visual modalities; (2) enhanced modality encoders to support scalable pre-training; (3) Iterative Audio-Visual Correlation Learning Module to improve cross-modal correlation in SSL; (4) progressive semantic injection training staged in three phases to ease adaptation and reduce overfitting.
AI.result: Achieves consistent state-of-the-art performance across multiple benchmarks on 17 AVFA datasets spanning three tasks. Extensive ablations confirm the contribution of each proposed component. The authors also release code and models publicly.
AI.conclusion: AVF-MAE++ effectively advances scalable AVFA by improving cross-modal learning and representation through dual masking, correlation-aware SSL, and staged training, delivering strong empirical gains and reproducibility.

title: LLM DNA: Tracing Model Evolution via Functional Representations
summary:
The explosive growth of large language models (LLMs) has created a vast but
opaque landscape: millions of models exist, yet their evolutionary
relationships through fine-tuning, distillation, or adaptation are often
undocumented or unclear, complicating LLM management. Existing methods are
limited by task specificity, fixed model sets, or strict assumptions about
tokenizers or architectures. Inspired by biological DNA, we address these
limitations by mathematically defining LLM DNA as a low-dimensional,
bi-Lipschitz representation of functional behavior. We prove that LLM DNA
satisfies inheritance and genetic determinism properties and establish the
existence of DNA. Building on this theory, we derive a general, scalable,
training-free pipeline for DNA extraction. In experiments across 305 LLMs, DNA
aligns with prior studies on limited subsets and achieves superior or
competitive performance on specific tasks. Beyond these tasks, DNA comparisons
uncover previously undocumented relationships among LLMs. We further construct
the evolutionary tree of LLMs using phylogenetic algorithms, which align with
shifts from encoder-decoder to decoder-only architectures, reflect temporal
progression, and reveal distinct evolutionary speeds across LLM families.

AI.tldr: LLM DNA: a training-free, bi-Lipschitz, low-dimensional embedding of LLM functional behavior; builds an evolutionary phylogeny over 305 LLMs revealing relationships and architecture-driven evolution.
AI.motivation: The proliferation of LLMs creates an opaque landscape with undocumented lineage; existing methods are task-specific and assumption-bound. A scalable, architecture-agnostic way to compare models and trace their evolution is needed.
AI.method: Define LLM DNA as a low-dimensional bi-Lipschitz representation of functional behavior; prove inheritance and genetic determinism; establish existence; derive a training-free DNA extraction pipeline; apply to 305 LLMs; construct evolutionary trees via phylogenetic algorithms; analyze alignment with architectural shifts and temporal progression; assess evolutionary speeds.
AI.result: DNA aligns with prior subset studies and achieves competitive or superior task performance on certain benchmarks; reveals previously undocumented relationships; evolutionary trees reflect encoder-decoder shifts, temporal trends, and varied evolution speeds across LLM families.
AI.conclusion: DNA offers a scalable, interpretable framework for characterizing LLMs and their evolution, enabling better management, taxonomy, and discovery of hidden relationships among models.

title: EVLF-FM: Explainable Vision Language Foundation Model for Medicine
summary:
Despite the promise of foundation models in medical AI, current systems
remain limited - they are modality-specific and lack transparent reasoning
processes, hindering clinical adoption. To address this gap, we present
EVLF-FM, a multimodal vision-language foundation model (VLM) designed to unify
broad diagnostic capability with fine-grain explainability. The development and
testing of EVLF-FM encompassed over 1.3 million total samples from 23 global
datasets across eleven imaging modalities related to six clinical specialties:
dermatology, hepatology, ophthalmology, pathology, pulmonology, and radiology.
External validation employed 8,884 independent test samples from 10 additional
datasets across five imaging modalities. Technically, EVLF-FM is developed to
assist with multiple disease diagnosis and visual question answering with
pixel-level visual grounding and reasoning capabilities. In internal validation
for disease diagnostics, EVLF-FM achieved the highest average accuracy (0.858)
and F1-score (0.797), outperforming leading generalist and specialist models.
In medical visual grounding, EVLF-FM also achieved stellar performance across
nine modalities with average mIOU of 0.743 and Acc@0.5 of 0.837. External
validations further confirmed strong zero-shot and few-shot performance, with
competitive F1-scores despite a smaller model size. Through a hybrid training
strategy combining supervised and visual reinforcement fine-tuning, EVLF-FM not
only achieves state-of-the-art accuracy but also exhibits step-by-step
reasoning, aligning outputs with visual evidence. EVLF-FM is an early
multi-disease VLM model with explainability and reasoning capabilities that
could advance adoption of and trust in foundation models for real-world
clinical deployment.

AI.tldr: A multimodal vision-language foundation model (EVLF-FM) unifies diagnosis and visual grounding across 11 imaging modalities and 6 specialties, with explainable, step-by-step reasoning; trained on 1.3M samples; validated externally; shows strong accuracy and grounding, enabling trust in clinical deployment.
AI.motivation: Foundation models promise broad medical AI capabilities, but current systems are modality-specific and lack transparent reasoning; EVLF-FM aims to provide a unified, explainable diagnostic tool with visual grounding to support clinical adoption.
AI.method: Develop EVLF-FM as a multimodal vision-language model. Train on 1.3 million samples from 23 global datasets across 11 imaging modalities spanning dermatology, hepatology, ophthalmology, pathology, pulmonology, and radiology. External validation with 8,884 samples from 10 datasets across 5 modalities. Tasks include multi-disease diagnosis and visual question answering with pixel-level visual grounding and reasoning. A hybrid training strategy combines supervised fine-tuning and visual reinforcement learning to achieve high accuracy and step-by-step explanations.
AI.result: Internal validation: highest average accuracy 0.858 and F1-score 0.797. Medical visual grounding across nine modalities: mean intersection over union (mIOU) 0.743 and Acc@0.5 0.837. External validation shows strong zero-shot and few-shot performance, competitive F1-scores with a smaller model. Hybrid supervision plus visual reinforcement fine-tuning yields explainable step-by-step reasoning aligned with visual evidence.
AI.conclusion: EVLF-FM represents an early, multi-disease vision-language model with explainability and reasoning capabilities, potentially accelerating adoption and trust in foundation-models for real-world clinical deployment.

title: Specialization after Generalization: Towards Understanding Test-Time Training in Foundation Models
summary:
Recent empirical studies have explored the idea of continuing to train a
model at test-time for a given task, known as test-time training (TTT), and
have found it to yield significant performance improvements. However, there is
limited understanding of why and when TTT is effective. Earlier explanations
mostly focused on the observation that TTT may help when applied to
out-of-distribution adaptation or used with privileged data. However, the
growing scale of foundation models with most test data being in-distribution
questions these explanations. We instead posit that foundation models remain
globally underparameterized, with TTT providing a mechanism for specialization
after generalization, focusing capacity on concepts relevant to the test task.
Specifically, under the linear representation hypothesis, we propose a model in
which TTT achieves a substantially smaller in-distribution test error than
global training. We empirically validate our model's key assumptions by
training a sparse autoencoder on ImageNet, showing that semantically related
data points are explained by only a few shared concepts. Finally, we perform
scaling studies across image and language tasks that confirm the practical
implications of our model, identifying the regimes where specialization is most
effective.

AI.tldr: Test-time training (TTT) can enable foundation models to specialize after generalization, improving in-distribution performance by focusing capacity on concepts relevant to the test task. The authors propose a linear representation hypothesis and validate it with a sparse autoencoder on ImageNet, then scale analyses across vision and language tasks to identify regimes where specialization is most effective.
AI.motivation: To understand why and when TTT is effective in large, largely in-distribution data settings, moving beyond explanations based on out-of-distribution adaptation or privileged data.
AI.method: Propose a model under a linear representation hypothesis in which TTT reduces in-distribution error more than global training. Validate assumptions by training a sparse autoencoder on ImageNet to show that semantically related data points are explained by few shared concepts. Conduct scaling studies across image and language tasks to identify regimes where specialization via TTT is most impactful.
AI.result: The model predicts significantly lower in-distribution test error with TTT compared to global training. Empirical validation with a sparse autoencoder shows that diverse data points share a small set of concepts. Scaling studies corroborate the practical implications, outlining regimes where specialization yields the most benefit.
AI.conclusion: TTT acts as a mechanism for specialization after generalization in underparameterized foundation models, enabling focused learning on test-task concepts. The linear representation framework and empirical demonstrations delineate regimes where specialization is most effective and scalable across modalities.

title: Trading Carbon for Physics: On the Resource Efficiency of Machine Learning for Spatio-Temporal Forecasting
summary:
Development of modern deep learning methods has been driven primarily by the
push for improving model efficacy (accuracy metrics). This sole focus on
efficacy has steered development of large-scale models that require massive
resources, and results in considerable carbon footprint across the model
life-cycle. In this work, we explore how physics inductive biases can offer
useful trade-offs between model efficacy and model efficiency (compute, energy,
and carbon). We study a variety of models for spatio-temporal forecasting, a
task governed by physical laws and well-suited for exploring different levels
of physics inductive bias. We show that embedding physics inductive biases into
the model design can yield substantial efficiency gains while retaining or even
improving efficacy for the tasks under consideration. In addition to using
standard physics-informed spatio-temporal models, we demonstrate the usefulness
of more recent models like flow matching as a general purpose method for
spatio-temporal forecasting. Our experiments show that incorporating physics
inductive biases offer a principled way to improve the efficiency and reduce
the carbon footprint of machine learning models. We argue that model
efficiency, along with model efficacy, should become a core consideration
driving machine learning model development and deployment.

AI.tldr: Embedding physics inductive biases in spatio-temporal forecasting can substantially improve efficiency (compute, energy, carbon) while maintaining or improving accuracy, suggesting a shift to consider model efficiency alongside efficacy.
AI.motivation: To address the environmental and resource costs of efficacy-driven ML (large models with high carbon footprints) by leveraging physics-inspired priors to trade off accuracy for efficiency.
AI.method: Empirical study across spatio-temporal forecasting models, comparing standard physics-informed designs with modern approaches like flow matching, and evaluating both accuracy and efficiency metrics (compute, energy, carbon footprint).
AI.result: Physics inductive biases yield substantial efficiency gains with retained/improved efficacy; flow matching emerges as a general-purpose, effective method for spatio-temporal forecasting; overall, efficiency gains come with little to no loss in performance and reduced carbon impact.
AI.conclusion: Model efficiency should be a core consideration in ML design and deployment, with physics-informed biases offering a principled route to reduce resource use and carbon footprint without sacrificing efficacy.

title: Latent Visual Reasoning
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have achieved notable gains in
various tasks by incorporating Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning in language
spaces. Recent work extends this direction by leveraging external tools for
visual editing, thereby enhancing the visual signal along the reasoning
trajectories. Nevertheless, these approaches remain fundamentally constrained:
reasoning is still confined to the language space, with visual information
treated as static preconditions. We introduce Latent Visual Reasoning (LVR), a
new paradigm that enables autoregressive reasoning directly in the visual
embedding space. A visual encoder first projects images into visual tokens
within a joint semantic space shared with the language model. The language
model is then trained to generate latent states that reconstruct key visual
tokens critical for answering the query, constituting the process of latent
visual reasoning. By interleaving LVR with standard text generation, our model
achieves substantial gains on perception-intensive visual question answering
tasks. In addition, we adapt the GRPO algorithm to conduct reinforcement
learning on latent reasoning, further balancing LVR and textual generation. We
show that LVR substantially improves fine-grained visual understanding and
perception, achieving 71.67% on MMVP compared to 66.67% with Qwen2.5-VL. Code
base and model weights will be released later.

AI.tldr: Latent Visual Reasoning (LVR) enables autoregressive reasoning directly in the visual embedding space, projecting images into visual tokens and training the LM to reconstruct key tokens, improving perception-centric tasks.
AI.motivation: Current multimodal LLMs perform reasoning in language space and treat visuals as static inputs, limiting fine-grained visual understanding. LVR aims to fuse perception and reasoning by operating in a shared visual-language embedding space.
AI.method: A visual encoder maps images to visual tokens in a joint semantic space with the LM. The LM is trained to generate latent states that reconstruct critical visual tokens needed to answer queries, enabling latent visual reasoning. LVR is interleaved with text generation. GRPO-based reinforcement learning is adapted to optimize latent reasoning alongside textual output.
AI.result: Reported performance gains on perception-intensive tasks, e.g., MMVP achieving 71.67% versus 66.67% for a baseline (Qwen2.5-VL). The code and weights are to be released.
AI.conclusion: Latent reasoning in the visual embedding space enhances fine-grained visual understanding and perception without sacrificing language-driven generation; LVR offers a scalable path for integrating perception and reasoning in MLLMs.

title: LEAF: A Robust Expert-Based Framework for Few-Shot Continual Event Detection
summary:
Few-shot Continual Event Detection (FCED) poses the dual challenges of
learning from limited data and mitigating catastrophic forgetting across
sequential tasks. Existing approaches often suffer from severe forgetting due
to the full fine-tuning of a shared base model, which leads to knowledge
interference between tasks. Moreover, they frequently rely on data augmentation
strategies that can introduce unnatural or semantically distorted inputs. To
address these limitations, we propose LEAF, a novel and robust expert-based
framework for FCED. LEAF integrates a specialized mixture of experts
architecture into the base model, where each expert is parameterized with
low-rank adaptation (LoRA) matrices. A semantic-aware expert selection
mechanism dynamically routes instances to the most relevant experts, enabling
expert specialization and reducing knowledge interference. To improve
generalization in limited-data settings, LEAF incorporates a contrastive
learning objective guided by label descriptions, which capture high-level
semantic information about event types. Furthermore, to prevent overfitting on
the memory buffer, our framework employs a knowledge distillation strategy that
transfers knowledge from previous models to the current one. Extensive
experiments on multiple FCED benchmarks demonstrate that LEAF consistently
achieves state-of-the-art performance.

AI.tldr: LEAF is an expert-based FCED framework that uses a mixture of experts with LoRA adapters, semantic-aware expert routing, label-description guided contrastive learning, and knowledge distillation to achieve state-of-the-art few-shot continual event detection while mitigating forgetting and avoiding risky data augmentation.
AI.motivation: FCED faces two core challenges: learning from very limited labeled data per task and severe forgetting across sequential tasks when fine-tuning a shared model. Existing augmentation strategies can distort semantics. LEAF aims to reduce interference by specialized experts and improve generalization with semantic guidance and distillation.
AI.method: Integrate a mixture-of-experts architecture where each expert is parameterized with LoRA in the base model. A semantic-aware routing mechanism selects relevant experts for each instance. Employ a label-description guided contrastive objective to capture high-level semantic information of event types. Use knowledge distillation from previous models to prevent overfitting on the memory buffer and to preserve prior knowledge across tasks. Evaluate on multiple FCED benchmarks to demonstrate robustness and SOTA performance.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show LEAF consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance across multiple FCED benchmarks, validating the effectiveness of expert specialization, LoRA adapters, semantic routing, and distillation in few-shot continual event detection.
AI.conclusion: LEAF demonstrates that an expert-based approach with lightweight adapters and semantic guidance can effectively tackle FCED, reducing knowledge interference and improving generalization in limited-data, continual settings. The framework offers a promising direction for robust continual learning in event detection and related tasks.

title: When MLLMs Meet Compression Distortion: A Coding Paradigm Tailored to MLLMs
summary:
The increasing deployment of powerful Multimodal Large Language Models
(MLLMs), typically hosted on cloud platforms, urgently requires effective
compression techniques to efficiently transmit signal inputs (e.g., images,
videos) from edge devices with minimal bandwidth usage. However, conventional
image codecs are optimized for fidelity to serve the Human Visual System (HVS)
and ill-suited for MLLMs, in which diverse downstream tasks are jointly
considered. In this paper, we first systematically analyze the impact of
compression artifacts on several mainstream MLLMs. We find that: Compression
distortion unevenly impacts different-level image features, leading to varying
effects on MLLMs' downstream tasks depending on their feature-level reliance.
Motivated by this discovery, we propose an image Codec TAilored to MLLMs
(CoTAM) designed to adaptively protect multi-level features and suit different
demands of downstream tasks. The encoder leverages CLIP's shallow-layer
attention to generate an importance map for bit allocation, preserving critical
semantic regions. Concurrently, the decoder integrates a lightweight adapter
with a multi-level loss function to ensure the faithful reconstruction both of
low-level details and high-level semantic context for robust synthesis of
cross-level features. Extensive experiments validate that our method achieves
up to 35.99\% bitrate saving while maintaining the same performance on the MLLM
tasks, outperforming previous SOTA neural codecs.

AI.tldr: A neural image codec tailored to MLLMs (CoTAM) reduces bandwidth by up to 35.99% without harming MLLM task performance, by adaptively protecting multi-level features using CLIP-based importance maps and a lightweight decoder adapter with multi-level loss.
AI.motivation: Conventional image codecs optimize per-visual fidelity for the Human Visual System (HVS) and fail to account for diverse downstream tasks in Multimodal LLMs (MLLMs). Compression artifacts unevenly affect features at different levels, impacting downstream MLLM performance variably. There is a need for task-aware compression that preserves semantic and multi-level features relevant to MLLMs.
AI.method: Develop CoTAM (Codec TAilored to MLLMs). The encoder uses CLIP shallow-layer attention to generate an importance map for adaptive bit allocation, preserving semantically critical regions. The decoder incorporates a lightweight adapter and a multi-level loss to faithfully reconstruct both low-level details and high-level semantic context, enabling robust cross-level feature synthesis for MLLMs.
AI.result: Experiments show up to 35.99% bitrate savings while maintaining identical performance on MLLM tasks, outperforming previous state-of-the-art neural codecs.
AI.conclusion: CoTAM effectively tailors image compression to MLLMs, balancing fidelity across multiple feature levels and improving transmission efficiency without degrading MLLM task performance.

title: Training-Free Multimodal Guidance for Video to Audio Generation
summary:
Video-to-audio (V2A) generation aims to synthesize realistic and semantically
aligned audio from silent videos, with potential applications in video editing,
Foley sound design, and assistive multimedia. Although the excellent results,
existing approaches either require costly joint training on large-scale paired
datasets or rely on pairwise similarities that may fail to capture global
multimodal coherence. In this work, we propose a novel training-free multimodal
guidance mechanism for V2A diffusion that leverages the volume spanned by the
modality embeddings to enforce unified alignment across video, audio, and text.
The proposed multimodal diffusion guidance (MDG) provides a lightweight,
plug-and-play control signal that can be applied on top of any pretrained audio
diffusion model without retraining. Experiments on VGGSound and AudioCaps
demonstrate that our MDG consistently improves perceptual quality and
multimodal alignment compared to baselines, proving the effectiveness of a
joint multimodal guidance for V2A.

AI.tldr: A training-free multimodal guidance mechanism (MDG) improves video-to-audio diffusion by aligning video, audio, and text embeddings without retraining.
AI.motivation: Current V2A methods rely on costly joint training on paired data or pairwise similarities, which may fail to capture global, multimodal coherence across modalities.
AI.method: Introduce multimodal diffusion guidance (MDG), a lightweight, training-free control signal that leverages the volume spanned by modality embeddings to enforce unified alignment across video, audio, and text. MDG is plug-and-play on top of any pretrained audio diffusion model without retraining.
AI.result: MDG consistently improves perceptual quality and multimodal alignment on VGGSound and AudioCaps compared with baselines.
AI.conclusion: Joint multimodal guidance for V2A is effective; MDG provides a practical, training-free approach to improve diffusion-based V2A with cross-modal coherence.

title: S$^2$NN: Sub-bit Spiking Neural Networks
summary:
Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) offer an energy-efficient paradigm for machine
intelligence, but their continued scaling poses challenges for resource-limited
deployment. Despite recent advances in binary SNNs, the storage and
computational demands remain substantial for large-scale networks. To further
explore the compression and acceleration potential of SNNs, we propose Sub-bit
Spiking Neural Networks (S$^2$NNs) that represent weights with less than one
bit. Specifically, we first establish an S$^2$NN baseline by leveraging the
clustering patterns of kernels in well-trained binary SNNs. This baseline is
highly efficient but suffers from \textit{outlier-induced codeword selection
bias} during training. To mitigate this issue, we propose an
\textit{outlier-aware sub-bit weight quantization} (OS-Quant) method, which
optimizes codeword selection by identifying and adaptively scaling outliers.
Furthermore, we propose a \textit{membrane potential-based feature
distillation} (MPFD) method, improving the performance of highly compressed
S$^2$NN via more precise guidance from a teacher model. Extensive results on
vision and non-vision tasks reveal that S$^2$NN outperforms existing quantized
SNNs in both performance and efficiency, making it promising for edge computing
applications.

AI.tldr: Sub-bit Spiking Neural Networks (S^2NNs) compress SNN weights to less than 1 bit using kernel clustering, with OS-Quant to handle outlier bias and MPFD to distill features, achieving higher accuracy and efficiency than prior quantized SNNs and enabling edge deployment.
AI.motivation: Spiking Neural Networks are energy-efficient but face scaling challenges; binary SNNs help but still demand significant storage/computation for large models, hindering edge deployment; extreme weight compression is needed to enable practical large-scale SNNs.
AI.method: 1) Establish an S^2NN baseline by clustering kernels in well-trained binary SNNs. 2) Identify and mitigate outlier-induced codeword selection bias with outlier-aware sub-bit weight quantization (OS-Quant) that adaptively scales outliers. 3) Improve training via membrane potential-based feature distillation (MPFD) using a teacher model for precise guidance.
AI.result: S^2NN outperforms existing quantized SNNs in both performance and efficiency across vision and non-vision tasks, demonstrating strong potential for edge computing.
AI.conclusion: S^2NN provides an effective compression/acceleration framework for SNNs, enabling more practical and energy-efficient large-scale deployment on resource-limited devices.

title: Short window attention enables long-term memorization
summary:
Recent works show that hybrid architectures combining sliding window softmax
attention layers with linear recurrent neural network (RNN) layers outperform
both of these architectures taken separately. However, the impact of the window
length and the interplay between softmax attention and linear RNN layers remain
under-studied. In this work, we introduce SWAX, a hybrid architecture
consisting of sliding-window attention and xLSTM linear RNN layers.
  A counter-intuitive finding with SWAX is that larger sliding windows do not
improve the long-context performance. In fact, short window attention
encourages the model to better train the long-term memory of the xLSTM, by
relying less on the softmax attention mechanism for long context-retrieval.
  The issue with small sliding windows is that they are detrimental for
short-context tasks, which could be solved with information from moderately
larger sliding windows otherwise. Therefore, we train SWAX by stochastically
changing the sliding window size, forcing the model to leverage both a longer
context window and the xLSTM memory. SWAX trained with stochastic window sizes
significantly outperforms regular window attention both on short and
long-context problems.

AI.tldr: SWAX with stochastic window sizes improves both short- and long-context performance over fixed-window attention by combining sliding-window softmax attention with xLSTM memory.
AI.motivation: To understand how window length and the interaction between sliding-window softmax attention and linear RNNs affect performance, and to address the under-studied interplay in hybrid architectures.
AI.method: Introduce SWAX, a hybrid of sliding-window attention and xLSTM linear RNN layers; train with stochastic (varying) sliding window sizes; evaluate on short- and long-context tasks.
AI.result: SWAX trained with stochastic window sizes significantly outperforms regular window attention on both short- and long-context problems.
AI.conclusion: Window length effects are nuanced: smaller windows can fortify long-context memory by reducing reliance on softmax attention, and stochastic window training enables leveraging both longer context and xLSTM memory, yielding strong cross-context performance.

title: Cycle Diffusion Model for Counterfactual Image Generation
summary:
Deep generative models have demonstrated remarkable success in medical image
synthesis. However, ensuring conditioning faithfulness and high-quality
synthetic images for direct or counterfactual generation remains a challenge.
In this work, we introduce a cycle training framework to fine-tune diffusion
models for improved conditioning adherence and enhanced synthetic image
realism. Our approach, Cycle Diffusion Model (CDM), enforces consistency
between generated and original images by incorporating cycle constraints,
enabling more reliable direct and counterfactual generation. Experiments on a
combined 3D brain MRI dataset (from ABCD, HCP aging & young adults, ADNI, and
PPMI) show that our method improves conditioning accuracy and enhances image
quality as measured by FID and SSIM. The results suggest that the cycle
strategy used in CDM can be an effective method for refining diffusion-based
medical image generation, with applications in data augmentation,
counterfactual, and disease progression modeling.

AI.tldr: Cycle Diffusion Model (CDM) uses cycle-consistent fine-tuning to improve conditioning fidelity and realism in diffusion-based medical image generation, showing better FID/SSIM on multi-site 3D brain MRI and enabling more reliable direct and counterfactual generation.
AI.motivation: Address conditioning faithfulness and image quality gaps in diffusion-based medical image synthesis to support reliable direct and counterfactual generation across diverse datasets.
AI.method: Introduce a cycle training framework that fine-tunes diffusion models with cycle constraints enforcing consistency between generated and original images, improving adherence to conditioning.
AI.result: On a combined 3D brain MRI dataset (ABCD, HCP aging & young adults, ADNI, PPMI), the method improves conditioning accuracy and image quality as measured by FID and SSIM.
AI.conclusion: Cycle-based refinement is a promising approach for high-quality, conditioning-faithful diffusion-based medical image generation with applications in data augmentation, counterfactuals, and disease progression modeling.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning in Action: Real-Time Control of Vortex-Induced Vibrations
summary:
This study showcases an experimental deployment of deep reinforcement
learning (DRL) for active flow control (AFC) of vortex-induced vibrations (VIV)
in a circular cylinder at a high Reynolds number (Re = 3000) using rotary
actuation. Departing from prior work that relied on low-Reynolds-number
numerical simulations, this research demonstrates real-time control in a
challenging experimental setting, successfully addressing practical constraints
such as actuator delay. When the learning algorithm is provided with state
feedback alone (displacement and velocity of the oscillating cylinder), the DRL
agent learns a low-frequency rotary control strategy that achieves up to 80%
vibration suppression which leverages the traditional lock-on phenomenon. While
this level of suppression is significant, it remains below the performance
achieved using high-frequency rotary actuation. The reduction in performance is
attributed to actuation delays and can be mitigated by augmenting the learning
algorithm with past control actions. This enables the agent to learn a
high-frequency rotary control strategy that effectively modifies vortex
shedding and achieves over 95% vibration attenuation. These results demonstrate
the adaptability of DRL for AFC in real-world experiments and its ability to
overcome instrumental limitations such as actuation lag.

AI.tldr: Experimental real-time deep reinforcement learning (DRL) for active flow control of vortex-induced vibrations on a circular cylinder at Re=3000 using rotary actuation. It handles actuator delay and demonstrates strong suppression: up to ~80% with state feedback (low-frequency/lock-on) and >95% with a history-augmented controller that compensates for delay by enabling high-frequency actuation.
AI.motivation: Demonstrate the viability of DRL-based active flow control in real-world, high-Reynolds-number experiments and address practical limitations such as actuation delay, extending beyond prior low-Reynolds-number simulations.
AI.method: Experimental setup: circular cylinder in a flow at Re=3000 with rotary (torque) actuation. A DRL agent receives state feedback (cylinder displacement and velocity) and learns a control policy in real time. Comparisons are made between (i) state-feedback-only, which yields a low-frequency control leveraging lock-on, and (ii) including past control actions in the observation to mitigate delays, enabling a high-frequency control strategy.
AI.result: With state feedback alone, the agent achieves up to 80% vibration suppression via a low-frequency strategy. Actuation delays limit performance. Incorporating past control actions to compensate for lag enables a high-frequency strategy that delivers >95% vibration attenuation.
