models characterized by consistently higher test performance. $\textit{Catnat}$
is simple to implement and seamlessly integrates into existing codebases.
Moreover, it remains compatible with standard training stabilization techniques
and, as such, offers a better alternative to the $\textit{softmax}$ function.

AI.tldr: Replace softmax with a hierarchical binary-split catnat for latent categorical variables; yields diagonal Fisher information, improving gradient descent efficiency; empirically boosts performance across graphs, VAEs, and reinforcement learning; simple to implement and compatible with standard training techniques.
AI.motivation: Softmax-based discretization suffers information-geometric limitations impacting gradient-based learning; need a discretization that facilitates learning and optimization.
AI.method: Introduce catnat: a sequence of hierarchical binary splits; analyze Fisher Information Matrix and show it becomes diagonal; integrate with standard training; conduct experiments on graph structure learning, variational autoencoders, and reinforcement learning.
AI.result: Catnat improves learning efficiency and yields higher test performance across tasks; simple integration and compatibility with stabilization techniques.
AI.conclusion: Catnat offers a simple, theoretically grounded and practically effective alternative to softmax for discrete latent variables.

title: Uni-X: Mitigating Modality Conflict with a Two-End-Separated Architecture for Unified Multimodal Models
summary:
Unified Multimodal Models (UMMs) built on shared autoregressive (AR)
transformers are attractive for their architectural simplicity. However, we
identify a critical limitation: when trained on multimodal inputs,
modality-shared transformers suffer from severe gradient conflicts between
vision and text, particularly in shallow and deep layers. We trace this issue
to the fundamentally different low-level statistical properties of images and
text, while noting that conflicts diminish in middle layers where
representations become more abstract and semantically aligned. To overcome this
challenge, we propose Uni-X, a two-end-separated, middle-shared architecture.
Uni-X dedicates its initial and final layers to modality-specific processing,
while maintaining shared parameters in the middle layers for high-level
semantic fusion. This X-shaped design not only eliminates gradient conflicts at
both ends but also further alleviates residual conflicts in the shared layers.
Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of Uni-X. Under identical
training conditions, Uni-X achieves superior training efficiency compared to
strong baselines. When scaled to 3B parameters with larger training data, Uni-X
matches or surpasses 7B AR-based UMMs, achieving a GenEval score of 82 for
image generation alongside strong performance in text and vision understanding
tasks. These results establish Uni-X as a parameter-efficient and scalable
foundation for future unified multimodal modeling. Our code is available at
https://github.com/CURRENTF/Uni-X

AI.tldr: Uni-X introduces a middle-shared, two-end-separated architecture for unified multimodal models to mitigate gradient conflicts between vision and text. The approach dedicates early and late layers to modality-specific processing while sharing middle layers for high-level fusion, aiming to improve training efficiency and parameter efficiency. Empirically, it claims superior efficiency and competitive performance at 3B params, matching or surpassing 7B AR-based UMMs, with GenEval 82 for image generation.
AI.motivation: Identify and alleviate gradient conflicts arising from training modality-shared transformers on heterogeneous low-level statistics of images and text, which hinder joint learning and scaling.
AI.method: Propose Uni-X: an X-shaped architecture with initial and final layers modality-specific and middle layers shared. Gradient conflicts at ends eliminated; residual conflicts in shared layers reduced. Train under identical conditions; scale to 3B parameters with larger data; evaluate on image generation (GenEval) and vision/text understanding.
AI.result: Outperforms strong baselines in training efficiency. 3B-parameter Uni-X with more data matches or surpasses 7B AR-based UMMs, achieving GenEval score 82 for image generation and strong performance in related tasks.
AI.conclusion: Uni-X is a parameter-efficient, scalable foundation for unified multimodal modeling, effectively mitigating gradient conflicts and enabling competitive performance with fewer parameters. Code available at the provided GitHub link.

title: Who invented deep residual learning?
comment: 12 pages, 2 illustrations, circa 100 partially annotated references
summary:
Modern AI is based on deep artificial neural networks (NNs). As of 2025, the
most cited scientific article of the 21st century is an NN paper on deep
residual learning with residual connections. Who invented this? We present a
timeline of the evolution of deep residual learning.

AI.tldr: The abstract signals a historiographical analysis of deep residual learning, focusing on who invented residual connections and mapping their evolution over time.
AI.motivation: Deep residual learning is a cornerstone of modern AI; understanding its origins and credit distribution helps scholars grasp historical progress and guides future research.
AI.method: Historical literature review and timeline construction: tracing pre‑ResNet ideas (e.g., skip connections/highway networks) and the development of residual blocks, followed by attribution analysis.
AI.result: A proposed timeline of the evolution of deep residual learning, highlighting key milestones and contributions, and clarifying that attribution spans multiple researchers rather than a single inventor, with ResNet as a pivotal milestone.
AI.conclusion: Attribution for residual learning is distributed across several works; the timeline clarifies the lineage from early skip/identity mappings to modern residual nets and informs future research on architectural innovations.

title: Real-Aware Residual Model Merging for Deepfake Detection
summary:
Deepfake generators evolve quickly, making exhaustive data collection and
repeated retraining impractical. We argue that model merging is a natural fit
for deepfake detection: unlike generic multi-task settings with disjoint
labels, deepfake specialists share the same binary decision and differ in
generator-specific artifacts. Empirically, we show that simple weight averaging
preserves Real representations while attenuating Fake-specific cues. Building
upon these findings, we propose Real-aware Residual Model Merging (R$^2$M), a
training-free parameter-space merging framework. R$^2$M estimates a shared Real
component via a low-rank factorization of task vectors, decomposes each
specialist into a Real-aligned part and a Fake residual, denoises residuals
with layerwise rank truncation, and aggregates them with per-task norm matching
to prevent any single generator from dominating. A concise rationale explains
why a simple head suffices: the Real component induces a common separation
direction in feature space, while truncated residuals contribute only minor
off-axis variations. Across in-distribution, cross-dataset, and unseen-dataset,
R$^2$M outperforms joint training and other merging baselines. Importantly,
R$^2$M is also composable: when a new forgery family appears, we fine-tune one
specialist and re-merge, eliminating the need for retraining.

AI.tldr: A training-free model-merging method (R^2M) that aligns multiple deepfake detectors to a shared Real representation and merges per-generator residuals, enabling robust, incremental detection across datasets without retraining.
AI.motivation: Deepfake generators evolve rapidly, making exhaustive data collection and repeated retraining impractical. Different specialists share the same real-vs-fake decision but differ in generator-specific artifacts; simple weight averaging suggests a path, as Real features are preserved while fake cues are attenuated.
AI.method: Real-aware Residual Model Merging (R^2M): a training-free, parameter-space merging framework. It estimates a shared Real component via low-rank factorization of task vectors, decomposes each specialist into a Real-aligned part and a Fake residual, denoises residuals with layerwise rank truncation, and aggregates them with per-task norm matching to prevent dominance by any single generator. The approach argues that a simple head suffices because the Real component yields a common separation direction, while truncated residuals introduce only minor off-axis variation. It is composable: adding a new forgery family involves fine-tuning a specialist and re-merging without full retraining.
AI.result: Across in-distribution, cross-dataset, and unseen-dataset evaluations, R^2M outperforms joint training and other merging baselines, demonstrating strong generalization and robustness.
AI.conclusion: R^2M offers a simple, training-free, composable mechanism to merge deepfake detectors by leveraging a shared Real representation and controlled residuals, enabling effective incremental updates and improved cross-domain performance without retraining.

title: A TRIANGLE Enables Multimodal Alignment Beyond Cosine Similarity
summary:
Multimodal learning plays a pivotal role in advancing artificial intelligence
systems by incorporating information from multiple modalities to build a more
comprehensive representation. Despite its importance, current state-of-the-art
models still suffer from severe limitations that prevent the successful
development of a fully multimodal model. Such methods may not provide
indicators that all the involved modalities are effectively aligned. As a
result, some modalities may not be aligned, undermining the effectiveness of
the model in downstream tasks where multiple modalities should provide
additional information that the model fails to exploit. In this paper, we
present TRIANGLE: TRI-modAl Neural Geometric LEarning, the novel proposed
similarity measure that is directly computed in the higher-dimensional space
spanned by the modality embeddings. TRIANGLE improves the joint alignment of
three modalities via a triangle-area similarity, avoiding additional fusion
layers or pairwise similarities. When incorporated in contrastive losses
replacing cosine similarity, TRIANGLE significantly boosts the performance of
multimodal modeling, while yielding interpretable alignment rationales.
Extensive evaluation in three-modal tasks such as video-text and audio-text
retrieval or audio-video classification, demonstrates that TRIANGLE achieves
state-of-the-art results across different datasets improving the performance of
cosine-based methods up to 9 points of Recall@1.

AI.tldr: Introduces TRIANGLE, a triangle-area similarity for triplet modality alignment, boosting three-modal learning without extra fusion layers and achieving state-of-the-art results on video-text, audio-text, and audio-video tasks.
AI.motivation: Current multimodal models often rely on pairwise or cosine similarities and may not ensure all modalities are jointly aligned. There's a need for a higher-dimensional, interpretable measure that directly captures three-way alignment to improve downstream tasks.
AI.method: Define a triangle-area similarity computed in the embedding space spanned by the three modality embeddings; replaces cosine similarity in contrastive losses; avoids additional fusion modules; yields interpretable alignment rationales.
AI.result: Empirically improves across three-modal tasks; achieves state-of-the-art results on datasets; improves Recall@1 by up to 9 points over cosine-based methods; demonstrated on video-text, audio-text, audio-video tasks.
AI.conclusion: Triangle-area similarity is an effective and interpretable joint-alignment mechanism for tri-modal learning, offering substantial performance gains without extra fusion overhead.

title: From Satellite to Street: A Hybrid Framework Integrating Stable Diffusion and PanoGAN for Consistent Cross-View Synthesis
summary:
Street view imagery has become an essential source for geospatial data
collection and urban analytics, enabling the extraction of valuable insights
that support informed decision-making. However, synthesizing street-view images
from corresponding satellite imagery presents significant challenges due to
substantial differences in appearance and viewing perspective between these two
domains. This paper presents a hybrid framework that integrates diffusion-based
models and conditional generative adversarial networks to generate
geographically consistent street-view images from satellite imagery. Our
approach uses a multi-stage training strategy that incorporates Stable
Diffusion as the core component within a dual-branch architecture. To enhance
the framework's capabilities, we integrate a conditional Generative Adversarial
Network (GAN) that enables the generation of geographically consistent
panoramic street views. Furthermore, we implement a fusion strategy that
leverages the strengths of both models to create robust representations,
thereby improving the geometric consistency and visual quality of the generated
street-view images. The proposed framework is evaluated on the challenging
Cross-View USA (CVUSA) dataset, a standard benchmark for cross-view image
synthesis. Experimental results demonstrate that our hybrid approach
outperforms diffusion-only methods across multiple evaluation metrics and
achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art GAN-based
methods. The framework successfully generates realistic and geometrically
consistent street-view images while preserving fine-grained local details,
including street markings, secondary roads, and atmospheric elements such as
clouds.

AI.tldr: A hybrid diffusion-GAN framework for cross-view street-view synthesis from satellite imagery, using a dual-branch, multi-stage training setup with fusion, achieving superior diffusion-only baselines and competitive GAN-based methods on CVUSA, while preserving geometric consistency and fine details.
AI.motivation: Synthesize realistic, geographically consistent street-view images from satellite imagery to enable urban analytics and geospatial data collection, addressing the large appearance and viewpoint gap between the two domains.
AI.method: Core model is a diffusion-based architecture (Stable Diffusion) deployed in a dual-branch setup; integrated a conditional GAN to enforce geographic consistency for panoramic street views; a multi-stage training strategy; a fusion mechanism to leverage strengths of both models; evaluated on the Cross-View USA (CVUSA) dataset.
AI.result: The hybrid framework outperforms diffusion-only methods across multiple metrics and is competitive with state-of-the-art GAN-based methods; it generates realistic, geometrically consistent street-view imagery while preserving fine-grained details such as street markings, secondary roads, and atmospheric elements like clouds.
AI.conclusion: Combining diffusion with GANs in a dual-branch, multi-stage training framework with a fusion strategy yields improved geometric consistency and visual quality for cross-view synthesis from satellite images, demonstrated on CVUSA with strong qualitative and quantitative performance.

title: Robust Policy Expansion for Offline-to-Online RL under Diverse Data Corruption
comment: 39th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
summary:
Pretraining a policy on offline data followed by fine-tuning through online
interactions, known as Offline-to-Online Reinforcement Learning (O2O RL), has
emerged as a promising paradigm for real-world RL deployment. However, both
offline datasets and online interactions in practical environments are often
noisy or even maliciously corrupted, severely degrading the performance of O2O
RL. Existing works primarily focus on mitigating the conservatism of offline
policies via online exploration, while the robustness of O2O RL under data
corruption, including states, actions, rewards, and dynamics, is still
unexplored. In this work, we observe that data corruption induces heavy-tailed
behavior in the policy, thereby substantially degrading the efficiency of
online exploration. To address this issue, we incorporate Inverse Probability
Weighted (IPW) into the online exploration policy to alleviate
heavy-tailedness, and propose a novel, simple yet effective method termed
$\textbf{RPEX}$: $\textbf{R}$obust $\textbf{P}$olicy $\textbf{EX}$pansion.
Extensive experimental results on D4RL datasets demonstrate that RPEX achieves
SOTA O2O performance across a wide range of data corruption scenarios. Code is
available at
$\href{https://github.com/felix-thu/RPEX}{https://github.com/felix-thu/RPEX}$.

AI.tldr: A robust O2O RL method (RPEX) uses inverse probability weighting to curb heavy-tailed online exploration under data corruption, achieving state-of-the-art results on corrupted O2O benchmarks like D4RL.
AI.motivation: O2O RL is promising for real-world deployment but is vulnerable to noisy or malicious corruption in offline data and online interactions. Existing work emphasizes offline policy conservatism; robustness to data corruption (across states, actions, rewards, dynamics) remains underexplored. Data corruption induces heavy-tailed policy behavior, hurting exploration efficiency.
AI.method: Incorporate inverse probability weighting into the online exploration policy to mitigate heavy-tailedness and propose Robust Policy Expansion (RPEX).
AI.result: Experimental results on D4RL datasets show that RPEX achieves state-of-the-art offline-to-online performance across a wide range of data corruption scenarios; code is available.
AI.conclusion: RPEX provides a simple yet effective approach to robust O2O RL under data corruption, with strong empirical results and practical implications for real-world deployment.

title: DINOReg: Strong Point Cloud Registration with Vision Foundation Model
summary:
Point cloud registration is a fundamental task in 3D computer vision. Most
existing methods rely solely on geometric information for feature extraction
and matching. Recently, several studies have incorporated color information
from RGB-D data into feature extraction. Although these methods achieve
remarkable improvements, they have not fully exploited the abundant texture and
semantic information in images, and the feature fusion is performed in an
image-lossy manner, which limit their performance. In this paper, we propose
DINOReg, a registration network that sufficiently utilizes both visual and
geometric information to solve the point cloud registration problem. Inspired
by advances in vision foundation models, we employ DINOv2 to extract
informative visual features from images, and fuse visual and geometric features
at the patch level. This design effectively combines the rich texture and
global semantic information extracted by DINOv2 with the detailed geometric
structure information captured by the geometric backbone. Additionally, a mixed
positional embedding is proposed to encode positional information from both
image space and point cloud space, which enhances the model's ability to
perceive spatial relationships between patches. Extensive experiments on the
RGBD-3DMatch and RGBD-3DLoMatch datasets demonstrate that our method achieves
significant improvements over state-of-the-art geometry-only and multi-modal
registration methods, with a 14.2% increase in patch inlier ratio and a 15.7%
increase in registration recall. The code is publicly available at
https://github.com/ccjccjccj/DINOReg.

AI.tldr: DINOReg: a patch-level fusion of DINOv2 visual features with geometric features for RGB-D point cloud registration, achieving large gains on RGBD-3DMatch/LoMatch by using mixed image and point-cloud positional embeddings.
AI.motivation: Current RGB-D registration methods mainly rely on geometric cues and often fuse image data in lossy ways, failing to fully exploit rich texture, semantics, and global context available in images. A better fusion of visual and geometric information at a fine-grained level could significantly improve registration robustness and accuracy.
AI.method: Extract visual features from images with DINOv2 and fuse them with geometric features at the patch level. Introduce a mixed positional embedding that encodes both image-space and point-cloud-space coordinates to better capture cross-modality spatial relationships.
AI.result: Significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods: 14.2% increase in patch inlier ratio and 15.7% increase in registration recall on RGBD-3DMatch and RGBD-3DLoMatch. Code released at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that leveraging vision foundation-model features and a patch-level, mixed-embedding fusion with geometry leads to robust and accurate RGB-D point cloud registration, surpassing geometry-only and prior multimodal approaches.

title: In-Context Learning of Temporal Point Processes with Foundation Inference Models
summary:
Modeling event sequences of multiple event types with marked temporal point
processes (MTPPs) provides a principled way to uncover governing dynamical
rules and predict future events. Current neural network approaches to MTPP
inference rely on training separate, specialized models for each target system.
We pursue a radically different approach: drawing on amortized inference and
in-context learning, we pretrain a deep neural network to infer, in-context,
the conditional intensity functions of event histories from a context defined
by sets of event sequences. Pretraining is performed on a large synthetic
dataset of MTPPs sampled from a broad distribution of Hawkes processes. Once
pretrained, our Foundation Inference Model for Point Processes (FIM-PP) can
estimate MTPPs from real-world data without any additional training, or be
rapidly finetuned to target systems. Experiments show that this amortized
approach matches the performance of specialized models on next-event prediction
across common benchmark datasets.
  Our pretrained model, repository and tutorials will soon be available online

AI.tldr: Foundation Inference Model for Point Processes (FIM-PP) pretrained with amortized/in-context learning on synthetic Hawkes MTPPs to infer conditional intensity functions, enabling zero-shot or rapid fine-tuning on real data and matching specialized models on next-event prediction.
AI.motivation: Current MTPP neural nets require training separate models for each target system. A universal, adaptable approach using amortized inference and in-context learning can generalize across diverse event histories and reduce per-system training. Pretraining on a broad synthetic distribution enables robust inference.
AI.method: Pretrain a deep neural network to infer, in-context, the conditional intensity functions of event histories from a context defined by sets of event sequences. Training data comes from a large synthetic dataset of MTPPs sampled from a broad Hawkes process distribution. At inference, the pretrained model estimates MTPPs from real-world data without additional training, or can be rapidly finetuned to target systems.
AI.result: The amortized approach matches the performance of specialized models on next-event prediction across common benchmark datasets.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides a scalable foundation model for point-process inference, enabling zero-shot or rapid adaptation to new target systems, with release of pretrained model resources and tutorials forthcoming online.

title: Mask Clustering-based Annotation Engine for Large-Scale Submeter Land Cover Mapping
comment: Accepted in IEEE TGRS 2025; Project page: https://pubrs.com
summary:
Recent advances in remote sensing technology have made submeter resolution
imagery increasingly accessible, offering remarkable detail for fine-grained
land cover analysis. However, its full potential remains underutilized -
particularly for large-scale land cover mapping - due to the lack of
sufficient, high-quality annotated datasets. Existing labels are typically
derived from pre-existing products or manual annotation, which are often
unreliable or prohibitively expensive, particularly given the rich visual
detail and massive data volumes of submeter imagery. Inspired by the spatial
autocorrelation principle, which suggests that objects of the same class tend
to co-occur with similar visual features in local neighborhoods, we propose the
Mask Clustering-based Annotation Engine (MCAE), which treats semantically
consistent mask groups as the minimal annotating units to enable efficient,
simultaneous annotation of multiple instances. It significantly improves
annotation efficiency by one to two orders of magnitude, while preserving label
quality, semantic diversity, and spatial representativeness. With MCAE, we
build a high-quality annotated dataset of about 14 billion labeled pixels,
referred to as HiCity-LC, which supports the generation of city-scale land
cover maps across five major Chinese cities with classification accuracies
above 85%. It is the first publicly available submeter resolution city-level
land cover benchmark, highlighting the scalability and practical utility of
MCAE for large-scale, submeter resolution mapping. The dataset is available at
https://github.com/chenhaocs/MCAE

AI.tldr: Introduces MCAE, a clustering-based annotation approach that exploits spatial autocorrelation to efficiently label submeter imagery, enabling a large HiCity-LC dataset and city-scale maps with high accuracy; first public submeter city-level benchmark.
AI.motivation: To overcome the scarcity and high cost of high-quality annotated submeter remote-sensing data for large-scale land cover mapping; existing labels are unreliable or expensive; exploit local spatial co-occurrence to accelerate labeling.
AI.method: Develop MCAE that groups semantically consistent masks as minimal annotation units; uses spatial autocorrelation to annotate multiple instances simultaneously; achieves 1–2 orders of magnitude efficiency gains; builds dataset HiCity-LC (~14B labeled pixels).
AI.result: HiCity-LC contains about 14 billion labeled pixels; enables city-scale land cover maps for five major Chinese cities; classification accuracy >85%.
AI.conclusion: MCAE demonstrates scalable, high-quality annotation for submeter imagery and provides the first publicly available submeter city-level benchmark; suitable for large-scale land cover mapping; dataset and tool available online.

title: Neural Message-Passing on Attention Graphs for Hallucination Detection
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) often generate incorrect or unsupported content,
known as hallucinations. Existing detection methods rely on heuristics or
simple models over isolated computational traces such as activations, or
attention maps. We unify these signals by representing them as attributed
graphs, where tokens are nodes, edges follow attentional flows, and both carry
features from attention scores and activations. Our approach, CHARM, casts
hallucination detection as a graph learning task and tackles it by applying
GNNs over the above attributed graphs. We show that CHARM provably subsumes
prior attention-based heuristics and, experimentally, it consistently
outperforms other leading approaches across diverse benchmarks. Our results
shed light on the relevant role played by the graph structure and on the
benefits of combining computational traces, whilst showing CHARM exhibits
promising zero-shot performance on cross-dataset transfer.

AI.tldr: CHARM reframes hallucination detection as a graph learning problem by encoding tokens as graph nodes, attentional flows as edges, and activation/attention features as attributes, using GNNs to unify signals and detect hallucinations. It outperforms baselines and shows promising zero-shot cross-dataset transfer.
AI.motivation: LLMs frequently produce hallucinations; existing detectors rely on heuristics over isolated traces, missing the synergistic information across signals. A unified graph-based representation can leverage multiple computational traces for better detection and generalization.
AI.method: From model traces, build attributed graphs: tokens are nodes, attentional flows are edges; attach features from attention scores and activations to nodes/edges. Apply graph neural networks (CHARM) to classify tokens or sequences as hallucinatory. The approach subsumes prior attention-based heuristics and demonstrates benefits of combining traces.
AI.result: CHARM consistently outperforms leading detection approaches across diverse benchmarks and shows promising zero-shot performance for cross-dataset transfer.
AI.conclusion: Graph-based integration of computational traces enhances hallucination detection; CHARM provides a principled, transferable detector and clarifies the role of graph structure in leveraging multiple signals.

title: REALIGN: Regularized Procedure Alignment with Matching Video Embeddings via Partial Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport
summary:
Learning from procedural videos remains a core challenge in self-supervised
representation learning, as real-world instructional data often contains
background segments, repeated actions, and steps presented out of order. Such
variability violates the strong monotonicity assumptions underlying many
alignment methods. Prior state-of-the-art approaches, such as OPEL, leverage
Kantorovich Optimal Transport (KOT) to build frame-to-frame correspondences,
but rely solely on feature similarity and fail to capture the higher-order
temporal structure of a task. In this paper, we introduce REALIGN, a
self-supervised framework for procedure learning based on Regularized Fused
Partial Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport (R-FPGWOT). In contrast to KOT,
our formulation jointly models visual correspondences and temporal relations
under a partial alignment scheme, enabling robust handling of irrelevant
frames, repeated actions, and non-monotonic step orders common in instructional
videos. To stabilize training, we integrate FPGWOT distances with
inter-sequence contrastive learning, avoiding the need for multiple
regularizers and preventing collapse to degenerate solutions. Across egocentric
(EgoProceL) and third-person (ProceL, CrossTask) benchmarks, REALIGN achieves
up to 18.9% average F1-score improvements and over 30% temporal IoU gains,
while producing more interpretable transport maps that preserve key-step
orderings and filter out noise.

AI.tldr: REALIGN introduces Regularized Fused Partial Gromov-Wasserstein OT for self-supervised procedural learning, jointly aligning frames and modeling temporal relations under partial, non-monotonic conditions. It handles irrelevant frames, repeats, and out-of-order steps, delivering robust performance and interpretable transport maps.
AI.motivation: Procedural videos pose challenges for self-supervised learning due to background segments, repeated actions, and non-monotonic step orders. Existing methods (e.g., OPEL with Kantorovich OT) rely on feature similarity and monotonic assumptions, failing to capture higher-order temporal structure and allowing noise to corrupt alignments.
AI.method: REALIGN employs Regularized Fused Partial Gromov-Wasserstein OT (R-FPGWOT) to jointly model visual correspondences and temporal relations under a partial alignment scheme. It integrates FPGWOT distances with inter-sequence contrastive learning to stabilize training without additional regularizers, avoiding collapse to degenerate solutions while producing interpretable transport maps.
AI.result: On EgoProceL, ProceL, and CrossTask benchmarks, REALIGN achieves up to 18.9% average F1-score improvements and over 30% gains in temporal IoU, demonstrating robust handling of irrelevant frames, repeated actions, and non-monotonic step orders; transport maps are interpretable and preserve key-step orderings while filtering noise.
AI.conclusion: REALIGN advances self-supervised procedure learning by effectively modeling temporal structure through partial, regularized GW-based transport, yielding stronger cross-dataset performance and more interpretable alignments than prior KOT-based methods.

title: MarS-FM: Generative Modeling of Molecular Dynamics via Markov State Models
summary:
Molecular Dynamics (MD) is a powerful computational microscope for probing
protein functions. However, the need for fine-grained integration and the long
timescales of biomolecular events make MD computationally expensive. To address
this, several generative models have been proposed to generate surrogate
trajectories at lower cost. Yet, these models typically learn a fixed-lag
transition density, causing the training signal to be dominated by frequent but
uninformative transitions. We introduce a new class of generative models, MSM
Emulators, which instead learn to sample transitions across discrete states
defined by an underlying Markov State Model (MSM). We instantiate this class
with Markov Space Flow Matching (MarS-FM), whose sampling offers more than two
orders of magnitude speedup compared to implicit- or explicit-solvent MD
simulations. We benchmark Mars-FM ability to reproduce MD statistics through
structural observables such as RMSD, radius of gyration, and secondary
structure content. Our evaluation spans protein domains (up to 500 residues)
with significant chemical and structural diversity, including unfolding events,
and enforces strict sequence dissimilarity between training and test sets to
assess generalization. Across all metrics, MarS-FM outperforms existing
methods, often by a substantial margin.

AI.tldr: MSM Emulators, especially Markov Space Flow Matching (MarS-FM), sample transitions across discrete MSM states to generate surrogate trajectories, achieving >100x speedups over MD and outperforming existing surrogate methods in structural statistics and generalization.
AI.motivation: MD provides rich insights into protein function but is prohibitively expensive due to fine-grained integration and long timescales. Fixed-lag transition models bias training toward frequent, uninformative transitions and struggle to scale to large proteins. A kinetic-aware surrogate that operates on MSM-defined state transitions can dramatically accelerate sampling while preserving essential dynamical statistics.
AI.method: Introduce MSM Emulators and instantiate with Markov Space Flow Matching (MarS-FM). The model samples transitions between discrete MSM states rather than continuous trajectories, enabling fast, kinetically consistent sampling. Evaluation spans proteins up to ~500 residues, including unfolding events, with strict train/test sequence dissimilarity. Structural observables (RMSD, radius of gyration, secondary structure content) are used to benchmark fidelity against MD and existing surrogates.
AI.result: MarS-FM delivers more than two orders of magnitude speedup compared to MD (implicit- or explicit-solvent). Across all evaluated metrics (RMSD, radius of gyration, secondary structure content) and diverse protein domains, MarS-FM outperforms existing methods by a substantial margin, including on challenging events like unfolding and under strict test-set dissimilarity.
AI.conclusion: MSM Emulators, and MarS-FM in particular, offer dramatic computational acceleration for generating biomolecular trajectories while maintaining or improving agreement with MD-derived statistics. The approach scales to sizable proteins and demonstrates strong generalization to unseen sequences, representing a powerful tool for efficient biomolecular modeling.

title: Vid-LLM: A Compact Video-based 3D Multimodal LLM with Reconstruction-Reasoning Synergy
summary:
Recent developments in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have
significantly improved Vision-Language (VL) reasoning in 2D domains. However,
extending these capabilities to 3D scene understanding remains a major
challenge. Existing 3D Multimodal Large Language Models (3D-MLLMs) often depend
on 3D data inputs, which limits scalability and generalization. To address this
limitation, we propose Vid-LLM, a video-based 3D-MLLM that directly processes
video inputs without requiring external 3D data, making it practical for
real-world deployment. In our method, the geometric prior are directly used to
improve the performance of the sceen perception. To integrate the geometric
cues into the MLLM compactly, we design a Cross-Task Adapter (CTA) module to
align the 3D geometric priors with the vision-language representations. To
ensure geometric consistency and integrity, we introduce a Metric Depth Model
that recovers real-scale geometry from the reconstruction outputs. Finally, the
model is fine-tuned with a two-stage distillation optimization strategy,
realizing fast convergence and stabilizes training. Extensive experiments
across diverse benchmarks verified the effectiveness of our method on 3D
Question Answering, 3D Dense Captioning and 3D Visual Grounding tasks,
demonstrating the superior multi-task capabilities.

AI.tldr: Vid-LLM is a video-based 3D multimodal LLM that uses geometric priors and a Cross-Task Adapter to fuse 3D cues into a vision-language model, enabling real-scale 3D understanding from video without external 3D data, trained with two-stage distillation for fast convergence, validated on 3D QA, Dense Captioning, and Visual Grounding.
AI.motivation: 3D-MLLMs often rely on explicit 3D data inputs, which limits scalability and generalization. There is a need for video-based 3D understanding that can operate without external 3D data.
AI.method: Leverages geometric priors directly; introduces a Cross-Task Adapter (CTA) to align 3D geometric cues with vision-language representations; includes a Metric Depth Model to recover real-scale geometry from reconstructions; uses a two-stage distillation optimization strategy to enable fast convergence and stable training; processes video inputs to avoid external 3D data.
AI.result: Demonstrates superior multi-task performance on 3D Question Answering, 3D Dense Captioning, and 3D Visual Grounding across diverse benchmarks; extensive experiments verify effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Vid-LLM offers a practical, scalable video-based 3D-MLLM that achieves accurate 3D scene understanding without external 3D data, preserves real-scale geometry via a depth model, and trains efficiently with distillation.

title: Quantifying Generalisation in Imitation Learning
comment: NeurIPS 2025 Datasets and Benchmarks Track poster
summary:
Imitation learning benchmarks often lack sufficient variation between
training and evaluation, limiting meaningful generalisation assessment. We
introduce Labyrinth, a benchmarking environment designed to test generalisation
with precise control over structure, start and goal positions, and task
complexity. It enables verifiably distinct training, evaluation, and test
settings. Labyrinth provides a discrete, fully observable state space and known
optimal actions, supporting interpretability and fine-grained evaluation. Its
flexible setup allows targeted testing of generalisation factors and includes
variants like partial observability, key-and-door tasks, and ice-floor hazards.
By enabling controlled, reproducible experiments, Labyrinth advances the
evaluation of generalisation in imitation learning and provides a valuable tool
for developing more robust agents.

AI.tldr: A configurable benchmark (Labyrinth) for imitation learning to assess generalization with distinct train/eval/test splits, discrete state space, known optimal actions, and variants
AI.motivation: Current imitation learning benchmarks lack variation between training and evaluation, hindering meaningful generalization assessment. There is a need for controllable, interpretable environments with verifiable splits and known-optimal actions.
AI.method: Introduce Labyrinth: a discrete, fully observable state space environment with precise control over structure, start/goal positions, and task complexity; provides verifiably distinct training/evaluation/test settings; includes variants such as partial observability, key-and-door tasks, and ice-floor hazards; designed for reproducible experiments and targeted testing of generalisation factors.
AI.result: A benchmarking tool enabling controlled generalization testing in imitation learning; supports fine-grained evaluation and interpretable results; facilitates development of more robust agents.
AI.conclusion: Labyrinth advances evaluation of generalisation in imitation learning and provides a valuable tool for developing more robust agents.

title: PCICF: A Pedestrian Crossing Identification and Classification Framework
summary:
We have recently observed the commercial roll-out of robotaxis in various
countries. They are deployed within an operational design domain (ODD) on
specific routes and environmental conditions, and are subject to continuous
monitoring to regain control in safety-critical situations. Since ODDs
typically cover urban areas, robotaxis must reliably detect vulnerable road
users (VRUs) such as pedestrians, bicyclists, or e-scooter riders. To better
handle such varied traffic situations, end-to-end AI, which directly compute
vehicle control actions from multi-modal sensor data instead of only for
perception, is on the rise. High quality data is needed for systematically
training and evaluating such systems within their OOD. In this work, we propose
PCICF, a framework to systematically identify and classify VRU situations to
support ODD's incident analysis. We base our work on the existing synthetic
dataset SMIRK, and enhance it by extending its single-pedestrian-only design
into the MoreSMIRK dataset, a structured dictionary of multi-pedestrian
crossing situations constructed systematically. We then use space-filling
curves (SFCs) to transform multi-dimensional features of scenarios into
characteristic patterns, which we match with corresponding entries in
MoreSMIRK. We evaluate PCICF with the large real-world dataset PIE, which
contains more than 150 manually annotated pedestrian crossing videos. We show
that PCICF can successfully identify and classify complex pedestrian crossings,
even when groups of pedestrians merge or split. By leveraging computationally
efficient components like SFCs, PCICF has even potential to be used onboard of
robotaxis for OOD detection for example. We share an open-source replication
package for PCICF containing its algorithms, the complete MoreSMIRK dataset and
dictionary, as well as our experiment results presented in:
https://github.com/Claud1234/PCICF

AI.tldr: PCICF framework extends SMIRK to MoreSMIRK for VRU situation classification in robotaxi ODDs, using space-filling curves to map multi-modal features to a dictionary; evaluated on PIE; open-source replication with MoreSMIRK.
AI.motivation: Need reliable detection and analysis of vulnerable road users (VRUs) in urban ODDs for robotaxis and robust evaluation across diverse VRU scenarios; high-quality labeled data and structured dictionaries are needed for training end-to-end AI and OOD detection.
AI.method: Augment SMIRK with MoreSMIRK as a structured dictionary of multi-pedestrian crossing situations; transform multi-dimensional scenario features via space-filling curves (SFCs) into characteristic patterns; match patterns to MoreSMIRK entries; validate on PIE dataset with 150+ annotated pedestrian crossing videos; release an open-source replication package.
AI.result: PCICF successfully identifies and classifies complex pedestrian crossing scenarios, including merged or split pedestrian groups; achieves computational efficiency via SFCs, suggesting potential onboard use for OOD detection; open-source MoreSMIRK and PCICF results.
AI.conclusion: PCICF provides a scalable framework for VRU incident analysis within robotaxi ODDs by delivering a structured VRU situation dictionary and efficient pattern matching, enabling improved training/evaluation and potential onboard deployment; the open-source package promotes reproducibility.

title: Assessing the risk of future Dunkelflaute events for Germany using generative deep learning
summary:
The European electricity power grid is transitioning towards renewable energy
sources, characterized by an increasing share of off- and onshore wind and
solar power. However, the weather dependency of these energy sources poses a
challenge to grid stability, with so-called Dunkelflaute events -- periods of
low wind and solar power generation -- being of particular concern due to their
potential to cause electricity supply shortages. In this study, we investigate
the impact of these events on the German electricity production in the years
and decades to come. For this purpose, we adapt a recently developed generative
deep learning framework to downscale climate simulations from the CMIP6
ensemble. We first compare their statistics to the historical record taken from
ERA5 data. Next, we use these downscaled simulations to assess plausible future
occurrences of Dunkelflaute events in Germany under the optimistic low
(SSP2-4.5) and high (SSP5-8.5) emission scenarios. Our analysis indicates that
both the frequency and duration of Dunkelflaute events in Germany in the
ensemble mean are projected to remain largely unchanged compared to the
historical period. This suggests that, under the considered climate scenarios,
the associated risk is expected to remain stable throughout the century.

AI.tldr: Downscaling CMIP6 climate simulations with a generative DL framework to assess Dunkelflaute (low wind/solar) risk in Germany; finds frequency and duration of Dunkelflaute events remain largely unchanged under optimistic and high-emission scenarios, implying stable risk through the century.
AI.motivation: Renewable energy expansion increases weather-driven variability; Dunkelflaute events threaten grid stability and must be understood in a future climate for planning and resilience.
AI.method: Use a generative deep learning downscaling approach to CMIP6 simulations, validate against ERA5 historical data, then project plausible future Dunkelflaute occurrences under SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5.
AI.result: In the ensemble mean, the frequency and duration of Dunkelflaute events in Germany are projected to be largely unchanged compared with the historical period.
AI.conclusion: Under the considered climate scenarios, Dunkelflaute risk is expected to remain stable throughout the century, indicating no large increase in risk and highlighting the need for resilience planning that accounts for persistent but not escalating risk.

title: RapidMV: Leveraging Spatio-Angular Representations for Efficient and Consistent Text-to-Multi-View Synthesis
comment: 18 pages, 13 figures, Accepted to WACV 2026 Round 1
summary:
Generating synthetic multi-view images from a text prompt is an essential
bridge to generating synthetic 3D assets. In this work, we introduce RapidMV, a
novel text-to-multi-view generative model that can produce 32 multi-view
synthetic images in just around 5 seconds. In essence, we propose a novel
spatio-angular latent space, encoding both the spatial appearance and angular
viewpoint deviations into a single latent for improved efficiency and
multi-view consistency. We achieve effective training of RapidMV by
strategically decomposing our training process into multiple steps. We
demonstrate that RapidMV outperforms existing methods in terms of consistency
and latency, with competitive quality and text-image alignment.

AI.tldr: RapidMV is a text-to-multi-view model that generates 32 views in ~5 seconds using a spatio-angular latent space, achieving better consistency and latency with competitive quality and text alignment.
AI.motivation: Generating synthetic multi-view images from text is crucial for scalable 3D asset creation. Existing methods often struggle with speed, consistency across views, or alignment to prompts; RapidMV targets faster, more consistent multi-view synthesis.
AI.method: Proposes a spatio-angular latent space that encodes both spatial appearance and angular viewpoint deviations into a single latent. Trains the model in multiple steps (training decomposition) to improve efficiency and consistency. Produces 32 multi-view images rapidly (~5 seconds).
AI.result: RapdMV outperforms existing methods in consistency and latency, while maintaining competitive image quality and text-image alignment.
AI.conclusion: RapidMV enables fast, consistent text-to-multi-view synthesis, facilitating scalable generation of synthetic 3D assets and streamlining the workflow with efficient training.

title: Fidel-TS: A High-Fidelity Benchmark for Multimodal Time Series Forecasting
summary:
The evaluation of time series forecasting models is hindered by a critical
lack of high-quality benchmarks, leading to a potential illusion of progress.
Existing datasets suffer from issues ranging from pre-training data
contamination in the age of LLMs to the causal and description leakage
prevalent in early multimodal designs. To address this, we formalize the core
principles of high-fidelity benchmarking, focusing on data sourcing integrity,
strict causal soundness, and structural clarity. We introduce Fidel-TS, a new
large-scale benchmark built from the ground up on these principles by sourcing
data from live APIs. Our extensive experiments validate this approach by
exposing the critical biases and design limitations of prior benchmarks.
Furthermore, we conclusively demonstrate that the causal relevance of textual
information is the key factor in unlocking genuine performance gains in
multimodal forecasting.

AI.tldr: Fidel-TS is a live-API-based benchmark for time-series forecasting that fixes data integrity, causal soundness, and structural clarity, showing that causal textual information drives genuine multimodal gains.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks undercut progress due to data contamination and leakage, leading to an illusion of improvement. A principled, high-fidelity benchmark is needed for trustworthy evaluation.
AI.method: Formulate core benchmarking principles (data sourcing integrity, strict causal soundness, structural clarity), construct Fidel-TS from live APIs, and run extensive experiments to compare with prior benchmarks and analyze design biases, especially regarding textual information.
AI.result: The study exposes critical biases and design limitations in existing benchmarks and demonstrates that the causal relevance of textual information is the key factor unlocking true performance gains in multimodal forecasting.
AI.conclusion: High-fidelity, principled benchmarking is essential for meaningful progress in time-series forecasting; Fidel-TS shows the value of data integrity and causal text information, guiding future benchmark design.

title: CLQ: Cross-Layer Guided Orthogonal-based Quantization for Diffusion Transformers
comment:
10 pages, 5 figures. Code is released at
  https://github.com/Kai-Liu001/CLQ
summary:
Visual generation quality has been greatly promoted with the rapid advances
in diffusion transformers (DiTs), which is attributed to the scaling of model
size and complexity. However, these attributions also hinder the practical
deployment of DiTs on edge devices, limiting their development and application.
Serve as an efficient model compression technique, model post-training
quantization (PTQ) can reduce the memory consumption and speed up the
inference, with inevitable performance degradation. To alleviate the
degradation, we propose CLQ, a cross-layer guided orthogonal-based quantization
method for DiTs. To be specific, CLQ consists of three key designs. First, we
observe that the calibration data used by most of the PTQ methods can not
honestly represent the distribution of the activations. Therefore, we propose
cross-block calibration (CBC) to obtain accurate calibration data, with which
the quantization can be better guided. Second, we propose orthogonal-based
smoothing (OBS), which quantifies the outlier score of each channel and
leverages block Hadamard matrix to smooth the outliers with negligible
overhead. Third, we propose cross-layer parameter searching (CLPS) to search.
We evaluate CLQ with both image generation and video generation models and
successfully compress the model into W4A4 with negligible degradation in visual
quality and metrics. CLQ achieves 3.98x memory saving and 3.95x speedup. Our
code is available at
\hyperlink{https://github.com/Kai-Liu001/CLQ}{https://github.com/Kai-Liu001/CLQ}.

AI.tldr: A PTQ method CLQ for DiTs with cross-block calibration, orthogonal-based smoothing, and cross-layer parameter searching, achieving ~4x memory and speedups with negligible quality loss.
AI.motivation: Diffusion transformers (DiTs) achieve high generation quality but are large and slow; post-training quantization (PTQ) could enable edge deployment, but tends to degrade performance; need improved calibration, smoothing of activations, and cross-layer optimization to preserve quality.
AI.method: Three components: (1) cross-block calibration (CBC) to generate calibration data that better represents activation distributions; (2) orthogonal-based smoothing (OBS) that uses a block Hadamard matrix to smooth outliers in channel activations with low overhead; (3) cross-layer parameter searching (CLPS) to search quantization parameters across layers; applied to DiTs for image and video generation.
AI.result: Achieves W4A4 quantization with negligible degradation in visual quality and metrics on image and video generation models; reports ~3.98x memory saving and ~3.95x speedup; code released.
AI.conclusion: CLQ demonstrates that combining cross-block calibration, orthogonal-based smoothing, and cross-layer parameter searching enables effective, low-overhead PTQ of diffusion transformers, enabling edge deployment with minimal quality loss.

title: DSAT-HD: Dual-Stream Adaptive Transformer with Hybrid Decomposition for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
summary:
Time series forecasting is crucial for various applications, such as weather,
traffic, electricity, and energy predictions. Currently, common time series
forecasting methods are based on Transformers. However, existing approaches
primarily model limited time series or fixed scales, making it more challenging
to capture diverse features cross different ranges. Additionally, traditional
methods like STL for complex seasonality-trend decomposition require
pre-specified seasonal periods and typically handle only single, fixed
seasonality. We propose the Hybrid Decomposition Dual-Stream Adaptive
Transformer (DSAT-HD), which integrates three key innovations to address the
limitations of existing methods: 1) A hybrid decomposition mechanism combining
EMA and Fourier decomposition with RevIN normalization, dynamically balancing
seasonal and trend components through noise Top-k gating; 2) A multi-scale
adaptive pathway leveraging a sparse allocator to route features to four
parallel Transformer layers, followed by feature merging via a sparse combiner,
enhanced by hybrid attention combining local CNNs and global interactions; 3) A
dual-stream residual learning framework where CNN and MLP branches separately
process seasonal and trend components, coordinated by a balanced loss function
minimizing expert collaboration variance. Extensive experiments on nine
datasets demonstrate that DSAT-HD outperforms existing methods overall and
achieves state-of-the-art performance on some datasets. Notably, it also
exhibits stronger generalization capabilities across various transfer
scenarios.

AI.tldr: DSAT-HD: a hybrid decomposition dual-stream adaptive Transformer for time series forecasting that combines EMA-Fourier decomposition with RevIN, multi-scale sparse routing to four Transformer layers, and dual-stream CNN/MLP processing of seasonal and trend components, achieving strong accuracy and better transfer generalization.
AI.motivation: Transformers for time series often handle limited time horizons and fixed scales; traditional decomposition methods like STL require pre-specified seasonal periods and struggle with multiple seasonality. There is a need for a model that handles diverse scales and complex seasonality without manual tuning.
AI.method: 1) Hybrid decomposition: EMA and Fourier decomposition with RevIN, noise Top-k gating to balance seasonal and trend components. 2) Multi-scale adaptive pathway: sparse allocator routes features to four parallel Transformer layers; sparse combiner merges features; hybrid attention combines local CNNs and global interactions. 3) Dual-stream residual learning: CNN and MLP branches process seasonal and trend components separately, coordinated by a balanced loss minimizing expert collaboration variance.
AI.result: Experiments on nine datasets show DSAT-HD outperforms existing methods overall and achieves state-of-the-art performance on select datasets, with stronger generalization across various transfer scenarios.
AI.conclusion: DSAT-HD effectively integrates hybrid decomposition, multi-scale adaptation, and dual-stream residual learning to capture diverse time-series features across scales, delivering improved accuracy and generalization.

title: A Data-Centric Perspective on the Influence of Image Data Quality in Machine Learning Models
summary:
In machine learning, research has traditionally focused on model development,
with relatively less attention paid to training data. As model architectures
have matured and marginal gains from further refinements diminish, data quality
has emerged as a critical factor. However, systematic studies on evaluating and
ensuring dataset quality in the image domain remain limited.
  This study investigates methods for systematically assessing image dataset
quality and examines how various image quality factors influence model
performance. Using the publicly available and relatively clean CIFAKE dataset,
we identify common quality issues and quantify their impact on training.
Building on these findings, we develop a pipeline that integrates two
community-developed tools, CleanVision and Fastdup. We analyze their underlying
mechanisms and introduce several enhancements, including automatic threshold
selection to detect problematic images without manual tuning.
  Experimental results demonstrate that not all quality issues exert the same
level of impact. While convolutional neural networks show resilience to certain
distortions, they are particularly vulnerable to degradations that obscure
critical visual features, such as blurring and severe downscaling. To assess
the performance of existing tools and the effectiveness of our proposed
enhancements, we formulate the detection of low-quality images as a binary
classification task and use the F1 score as the evaluation metric. Our
automatic thresholding method improves the F1 score from 0.6794 to 0.9468 under
single perturbations and from 0.7447 to 0.8557 under dual perturbations. For
near-duplicate detection, our deduplication strategy increases the F1 score
from 0.4576 to 0.7928. These results underscore the effectiveness of our
workflow and provide a foundation for advancing data quality assessment in
image-based machine learning.

AI.tldr: A pipeline to assess and improve image dataset quality using CleanVision and Fastdup, with automatic thresholding; shows non-uniform impact of quality issues and significant F1 gains.
AI.motivation: As model performance plateaus, data quality becomes a key bottleneck. There is a paucity of systematic, image-domain studies on evaluating and ensuring dataset quality.
AI.method: Identify quality issues in CIFAKE; build a pipeline combining CleanVision and Fastdup; introduce automatic threshold selection for detecting problematic images; convert low-quality image detection into a binary classification task with F1 as metric; assess deduplication for near-duplicate detection.
AI.result: Quality issues do not affect models uniformly; CNNs are resilient to some distortions but vulnerable to blur and severe downscaling. Automatic thresholding boosts F1 from 0.6794 to 0.9468 for single perturbations and from 0.7447 to 0.8557 for dual perturbations. Deduplication improves F1 from 0.4576 to 0.7928.
AI.conclusion: The proposed workflow is effective for image data quality assessment and provides a foundation for more robust data-quality practices in image-based ML; enhancements yield substantial improvements in detecting low-quality images and near-duplicates.

title: Physics-informed learning under mixing: How physical knowledge speeds up learning
summary:
A major challenge in physics-informed machine learning is to understand how
the incorporation of prior domain knowledge affects learning rates when data
are dependent. Focusing on empirical risk minimization with physics-informed
regularization, we derive complexity-dependent bounds on the excess risk in
probability and in expectation. We prove that, when the physical prior
information is aligned, the learning rate improves from the (slow) Sobolev
minimax rate to the (fast) optimal i.i.d. one without any sample-size deflation
due to data dependence.

AI.tldr: Physics-informed regularization can yield i.i.d.-like learning rates for dependent data when priors are aligned, eliminating sample-size penalties.
AI.motivation: To understand how incorporating physical priors in learning with dependent data affects learning rates and risk bounds.
AI.method: Derives complexity-dependent bounds on excess risk (in probability and expectation) for ERM with physics-informed regularization; analyzes alignment of prior information; compares Sobolev minimax vs i.i.d. rates under dependence.
AI.result: If the physical prior is aligned, the learning rate improves from the slow Sobolev minimax rate to the fast optimal i.i.d. rate; no sample-size deflation due to data dependence.
AI.conclusion: Aligned physics-informed priors enable dependence to be effectively neutralized for learning rate, highlighting the value of integrating domain knowledge in IRM with dependent data.

title: Proxy-GS: Efficient 3D Gaussian Splatting via Proxy Mesh
summary:
3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has emerged as an efficient approach for
achieving photorealistic rendering. Recent MLP-based variants further improve
visual fidelity but introduce substantial decoding overhead during rendering.
To alleviate computation cost, several pruning strategies and level-of-detail
(LOD) techniques have been introduced, aiming to effectively reduce the number
of Gaussian primitives in large-scale scenes. However, our analysis reveals
that significant redundancy still remains due to the lack of occlusion
awareness. In this work, we propose Proxy-GS, a novel pipeline that exploits a
proxy to introduce Gaussian occlusion awareness from any view. At the core of
our approach is a fast proxy system capable of producing precise occlusion
depth maps at a resolution of 1000x1000 under 1ms. This proxy serves two roles:
first, it guides the culling of anchors and Gaussians to accelerate rendering
speed. Second, it guides the densification towards surfaces during training,
avoiding inconsistencies in occluded regions, and improving the rendering
quality. In heavily occluded scenarios, such as the MatrixCity Streets dataset,
Proxy-GS not only equips MLP-based Gaussian splatting with stronger rendering
capability but also achieves faster rendering speed. Specifically, it achieves
more than 2.5x speedup over Octree-GS, and consistently delivers substantially
higher rendering quality. Code will be public upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: Proxy-GS introduces a fast occlusion-aware proxy for 3D Gaussian Splatting that prunes and densifies based on occlusion, achieving >2.5x speedup over Octree-GS and improved quality, with public code.
AI.motivation: Address redundancy in current pruning/LOD methods due to lack of occlusion awareness, especially in heavily occluded scenes.
AI.method: A fast proxy generates precise occlusion depth maps at 1000x1000 under 1 ms. Use depth maps to (1) cull anchors/gaussians during rendering, (2) guide densification during training to avoid occluded inconsistencies.
AI.result: >2.5x speedup over Octree-GS; consistently higher rendering quality, especially in occluded scenarios (e.g., MatrixCity Streets).
AI.conclusion: Occlusion-aware proxy-based approach enhances efficiency and quality of MLP-based Gaussian Splatting; code will be released.

title: DyMoDreamer: World Modeling with Dynamic Modulation
summary:
A critical bottleneck in deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is sample
inefficiency, as training high-performance agents often demands extensive
environmental interactions. Model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL) mitigates
this by building world models that simulate environmental dynamics and generate
synthetic experience, improving sample efficiency. However, conventional world
models process observations holistically, failing to decouple dynamic objects
and temporal features from static backgrounds. This approach is computationally
inefficient, especially for visual tasks where dynamic objects significantly
influence rewards and decision-making performance. To address this, we
introduce DyMoDreamer, a novel MBRL algorithm that incorporates a dynamic
modulation mechanism to improve the extraction of dynamic features and enrich
the temporal information. DyMoDreamer employs differential observations derived
from a novel inter-frame differencing mask, explicitly encoding object-level
motion cues and temporal dynamics. Dynamic modulation is modeled as stochastic
categorical distributions and integrated into a recurrent state-space model
(RSSM), enhancing the model's focus on reward-relevant dynamics. Experiments
demonstrate that DyMoDreamer sets a new state-of-the-art on the Atari $100$k
benchmark with a $156.6$\% mean human-normalized score, establishes a new
record of $832$ on the DeepMind Visual Control Suite, and gains a $9.5$\%
performance improvement after $1$M steps on the Crafter benchmark. Our code is
released at https://github.com/Ultraman-Tiga1/DyMoDreamer.

AI.tldr: A dynamic-modulation MBRL (DyMoDreamer) uses an inter-frame differencing mask to focus on object-level motion and temporal cues, integrated as stochastic dynamics modulation in an RSSM, yielding strong sample-efficient performance.
AI.motivation: Sample inefficiency in deep reinforcement learning remains a bottleneck; standard world models process observations holistically, failing to decouple dynamic objects and temporal features from static backgrounds, which is costly for visual tasks.
AI.method: DyMoDreamer introduces differential observations derived from an inter-frame differencing mask to encode object-level motion and temporal dynamics. Dynamic modulation is modeled as stochastic categorical distributions and integrated into a recurrent state-space model (RSSM), enhancing focus on reward-relevant dynamics.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art on Atari 100k with 156.6% mean human-normalized score, sets a new record of 832 on the DeepMind Visual Control Suite, and shows a 9.5% performance improvement after 1M steps on Crafter.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that explicit dynamic feature extraction via differential observations and stochastic dynamic modulation improves world-model learning and sample efficiency, achieving strong benchmarks; code is released at the provided GitHub URL.

title: Rethinking Unsupervised Cross-modal Flow Estimation: Learning from Decoupled Optimization and Consistency Constraint
summary:
This work presents DCFlow, a novel unsupervised cross-modal flow estimation
framework that integrates a decoupled optimization strategy and a cross-modal
consistency constraint. Unlike previous approaches that implicitly learn flow
estimation solely from appearance similarity, we introduce a decoupled
optimization strategy with task-specific supervision to address modality
discrepancy and geometric misalignment distinctly. This is achieved by
collaboratively training a modality transfer network and a flow estimation
network. To enable reliable motion supervision without ground-truth flow, we
propose a geometry-aware data synthesis pipeline combined with an
outlier-robust loss. Additionally, we introduce a cross-modal consistency
constraint to jointly optimize both networks, significantly improving flow
prediction accuracy. For evaluation, we construct a comprehensive cross-modal
flow benchmark by repurposing public datasets. Experimental results demonstrate
that DCFlow can be integrated with various flow estimation networks and
achieves state-of-the-art performance among unsupervised approaches.

AI.tldr: DCFlow is an unsupervised cross-modal optical flow framework that decouples modality transfer and flow estimation, leverages geometry-aware data synthesis with an outlier-robust loss, and enforces cross-modal consistency to achieve state-of-the-art results while remaining compatible with various flow networks.
AI.motivation: Cross-modal flow estimation faces modality discrepancy and geometric misalignment between modalities. Prior methods rely heavily on appearance similarity and often require ground-truth flow for supervision, which is unavailable in practice. The work aims to provide reliable motion supervision without ground-truth flow and a principled way to align and fuse information across modalities, including building a cross-modal benchmark by repurposing public datasets.
AI.method: Introduce a decoupled optimization strategy that jointly trains a modality transfer network and a flow estimation network. Use a geometry-aware data synthesis pipeline to provide reliable motion supervision without ground-truth flow, complemented by an outlier-robust loss. Add a cross-modal consistency constraint to jointly optimize both networks, enabling mutual improvement. Demonstrate compatibility with various existing flow estimation networks and evaluate on a repurposed cross-modal flow benchmark.
AI.result: DCFlow achieves state-of-the-art performance among unsupervised approaches on cross-modal flow tasks, and can be integrated with a variety of flow networks. The proposed data synthesis, robust losses, and cross-modal consistency significantly improve flow accuracy on the constructed benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling modality transfer from flow estimation, coupled with geometry-aware supervision and cross-modal consistency, yields a flexible and effective unsupervised cross-modal flow framework (DCFlow) that generalizes across networks and improves accuracy on cross-modal benchmarks.

title: Putnam-like dataset summary: LLMs as mathematical competition contestants
summary:
In this paper we summarize the results of the Putnam-like benchmark published
by Google DeepMind. This dataset consists of 96 original problems in the spirit
of the Putnam Competition and 576 solutions of LLMs. We analyse the performance
of models on this set of problems to verify their ability to solve problems
from mathematical contests.

AI.tldr: A summary of Google DeepMind's Putnam-like benchmark, evaluating LLMs on 96 problems and 576 solutions to assess contest-style problem-solving.
AI.motivation: To evaluate whether language models can solve mathematical contest problems and track progress on contest-style reasoning.
AI.method: Descriptive analysis of model performance on the 96-problem Putnam-like dataset using 576 reported LLM solutions; draws qualitative insights from the results.
AI.result: No numeric results are provided in the abstract; the paper presents overall performance notes and trends rather than specific scores.
AI.conclusion: The work aims to verify models' ability to solve contest-style math problems and to use the benchmark as a diagnostic of mathematical problem-solving capability in LLMs.

title: UI2V-Bench: An Understanding-based Image-to-video Generation Benchmark
summary:
Generative diffusion models are developing rapidly and attracting increasing
attention due to their wide range of applications. Image-to-Video (I2V)
generation has become a major focus in the field of video synthesis. However,
existing evaluation benchmarks primarily focus on aspects such as video quality
and temporal consistency, while largely overlooking the model's ability to
understand the semantics of specific subjects in the input image or to ensure
that the generated video aligns with physical laws and human commonsense. To
address this gap, we propose UI2V-Bench, a novel benchmark for evaluating I2V
models with a focus on semantic understanding and reasoning. It introduces four
primary evaluation dimensions: spatial understanding, attribute binding,
category understanding, and reasoning. To assess these dimensions, we design
two evaluation methods based on Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs): an
instance-level pipeline for fine-grained semantic understanding, and a
feedback-based reasoning pipeline that enables step-by-step causal assessment
for more accurate evaluation. UI2V-Bench includes approximately 500 carefully
constructed text-image pairs and evaluates a range of both open source and
closed-source I2V models across all defined dimensions. We further incorporate
human evaluations, which show strong alignment with the proposed MLLM-based
metrics. Overall, UI2V-Bench fills a critical gap in I2V evaluation by
emphasizing semantic comprehension and reasoning ability, offering a robust
framework and dataset to support future research and model development in the
field.

AI.tldr: A new benchmark, UI2V-Bench, evaluates image-to-video models on semantic understanding and reasoning (beyond quality and temporal consistency) using four dimensions, two MLLM-based evaluation pipelines, ~500 text-image pairs, and human alignment validation.
AI.motivation: Current I2V benchmarks emphasize video quality and temporal coherence but largely neglect semantic understanding of input subjects and compliance with physical laws and commonsense; there is a need for evaluating semantic comprehension and reasoning in I2V models.
AI.method: Introduce UI2V-Bench with four evaluation dimensions: spatial understanding, attribute binding, category understanding, and reasoning. Develop two MLLM-based evaluation pipelines: (1) an instance-level pipeline for fine-grained semantic understanding, and (2) a feedback-based reasoning pipeline for step-by-step causal assessment. Include ~500 carefully constructed text-image pairs and evaluate both open-source and closed-source I2V models across all dimensions, supplemented by human evaluations.
AI.result: UI2V-Bench addresses the semantic and reasoning gaps in I2V evaluation, showing strong alignment with MLLM-based metrics and providing a robust framework and dataset to guide future I2V model development.
AI.conclusion: The benchmark fills a critical gap by focusing on semantic comprehension and reasoning in I2V models, offering a practical framework and dataset to support research and model improvement in image-to-video generation.

title: Cell2Text: Multimodal LLM for Generating Single-Cell Descriptions from RNA-Seq Data
summary:
Single-cell RNA sequencing has transformed biology by enabling the
measurement of gene expression at cellular resolution, providing information
for cell types, states, and disease contexts. Recently, single-cell foundation
models have emerged as powerful tools for learning transferable representations
directly from expression profiles, improving performance on classification and
clustering tasks. However, these models are limited to discrete prediction
heads, which collapse cellular complexity into predefined labels that fail to
capture the richer, contextual explanations biologists need. We introduce
Cell2Text, a multimodal generative framework that translates scRNA-seq profiles
into structured natural language descriptions. By integrating gene-level
embeddings from single-cell foundation models with pretrained large language
models, Cell2Text generates coherent summaries that capture cellular identity,
tissue origin, disease associations, and pathway activity, generalizing to
unseen cells. Empirically, Cell2Text outperforms baselines on classification
accuracy, demonstrates strong ontological consistency using PageRank-based
similarity metrics, and achieves high semantic fidelity in text generation.
These results demonstrate that coupling expression data with natural language
offers both stronger predictive performance and inherently interpretable
outputs, pointing to a scalable path for label-efficient characterization of
unseen cells.

AI.tldr: Cell2Text is a multimodal framework that converts scRNA-seq profiles into structured natural language descriptions by merging single-cell foundation-model embeddings with pretrained LLMs, enabling richer, interpretable cell characterizations beyond discrete labels.
AI.motivation: Current single-cell models rely on discrete prediction heads that compress cellular complexity into predefined labels, limiting interpretability and contextual explanations for biologists.
AI.method: Fuse gene-level embeddings from single-cell foundation models with pretrained large language models to generate coherent, structured text describing cellular identity, tissue origin, disease associations, and pathway activity.
AI.result: Cell2Text outperforms baselines on classification accuracy, shows strong ontological consistency via PageRank-based similarity metrics, and achieves high semantic fidelity in generated descriptions, with good generalization to unseen cells.
AI.conclusion: Integrating expression data with natural language outputs yields improved predictive performance and interpretable, scalable descriptions of unseen cells, enabling label-efficient characterization.

title: NeoWorld: Neural Simulation of Explorable Virtual Worlds via Progressive 3D Unfolding
summary:
We introduce NeoWorld, a deep learning framework for generating interactive
3D virtual worlds from a single input image. Inspired by the on-demand
worldbuilding concept in the science fiction novel Simulacron-3 (1964), our
system constructs expansive environments where only the regions actively
explored by the user are rendered with high visual realism through
object-centric 3D representations. Unlike previous approaches that rely on
global world generation or 2D hallucination, NeoWorld models key foreground
objects in full 3D, while synthesizing backgrounds and non-interacted regions
in 2D to ensure efficiency. This hybrid scene structure, implemented with
cutting-edge representation learning and object-to-3D techniques, enables
flexible viewpoint manipulation and physically plausible scene animation,
allowing users to control object appearance and dynamics using natural language
commands. As users interact with the environment, the virtual world
progressively unfolds with increasing 3D detail, delivering a dynamic,
immersive, and visually coherent exploration experience. NeoWorld significantly
outperforms existing 2D and depth-layered 2.5D methods on the WorldScore
benchmark.

AI.tldr: NeoWorld is a single-image-driven hybrid 3D/2D framework that renders foreground objects in full 3D while synthesizing the background in 2D, enabling interactive, text-controlled view changes and progressive detail with superior WorldScore performance.
AI.motivation: To enable on-demand, interactive worldbuilding from a single input image with high realism for explored regions, addressing inefficiencies of full global 3D generation and 2D hallucination.
AI.method: Employs object-centric 3D representations for key foreground objects while continuing to synthesize backgrounds and non-interacted regions in 2D.
