Uses a hybrid scene structure with advanced representation learning and object-to-3D techniques, supports natural language commands for controlling object appearance and dynamics, and progressively increases 3D detail as users explore.
AI.result: Significantly outperforms existing 2D and depth-layered 2.5D methods on the WorldScore benchmark, with flexible viewpoint manipulation and physically plausible animation.
AI.conclusion: NeoWorld delivers efficient, interactive 3D world generation from a single image, enabling natural-language control and progressive 3D detail to create dynamic, immersive, and coherent exploration experiences.

title: Beyond the Hook: Predicting Billboard Hot 100 Chart Inclusion with Machine Learning from Streaming, Audio Signals, and Perceptual Features
summary:
The advent of digital streaming platforms have recently revolutionized the
landscape of music industry, with the ensuing digitalization providing
structured data collections that open new research avenues for investigating
popularity dynamics and mainstream success. The present work explored which
determinants hold the strongest predictive influence for a track's inclusion in
the Billboard Hot 100 charts, including streaming popularity, measurable audio
signal attributes, and probabilistic indicators of human listening. The
analysis revealed that popularity was by far the most decisive predictor of
Billboard Hot 100 inclusion, with considerable contribution from
instrumentalness, valence, duration and speechiness. Logistic Regression
achieved 90.0% accuracy, with very high recall for charting singles (0.986) but
lower recall for non-charting ones (0.813), yielding balanced F1-scores around
0.90. Random Forest slightly improved performance to 90.4% accuracy,
maintaining near-perfect precision for non-charting singles (0.990) and high
recall for charting ones (0.992), with F1-scores up to 0.91. Gradient Boosting
(XGBoost) reached 90.3% accuracy, delivering a more balanced trade-off by
improving recall for non-charting singles (0.837) while sustaining high recall
for charting ones (0.969), resulting in F1-scores comparable to the other
models.

AI.tldr: Streaming popularity is the strongest predictor of Billboard Hot 100 inclusion. Among models, logistic regression, random forest, and XGBoost achieve around 90% accuracy, with audio features like instrumentalness, valence, duration, and speechiness providing measurable but smaller gains, and varying class-wise performance.
AI.motivation: Identify which determinants most strongly predict a track’s inclusion in the Billboard Hot 100 in the streaming era, and compare predictive models using streaming popularity, audio features, and listening indicators.
AI.method: Use logistic regression, random forest, and gradient boosting (XGBoost) on data comprising streaming popularity metrics, measurable audio features, and probabilistic indicators of human listening. Evaluate models with accuracy, recall, precision, and F1, and analyze feature contributions.
AI.result: Streaming popularity is the dominant predictor for Hot 100 inclusion. Instrumentalness, valence, duration, and speechiness contribute meaningfully. Logistic Regression achieves 90.0% accuracy, recall for charting 0.986 and non-charting 0.813, yielding F1 around 0.90. Random Forest reaches 90.4% accuracy, with near-perfect precision for non-charting (0.990) and high charting recall (0.992), F1 up to ~0.91. Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) attains 90.3% accuracy, with non-charting recall 0.837 and charting recall 0.969, F1 similar to the other models.
AI.conclusion: In the streaming era, streaming popularity dominates predictive power for Billboard Hot 100 inclusion, with audio-feature signals providing additional, but smaller, predictive gains. All three models yield high predictive performance (~90% accuracy), with trade-offs in precision/recall across charting vs non-charting classes.

title: Beyond Isolated Facts: Synthesizing Narrative and Grounded Supervision for VideoQA
summary:
The performance of Video Question Answering (VideoQA) models is fundamentally
constrained by the nature of their supervision, which typically consists of
isolated, factual question-answer pairs. This "bag-of-facts" approach fails to
capture the underlying narrative and causal structure of events, limiting
models to a shallow understanding of video content. To move beyond this
paradigm, we introduce a framework to synthesize richer supervisory signals. We
propose two complementary strategies: Question-Based Paraphrasing (QBP), which
synthesizes the diverse inquiries (what, how, why) from a video's existing set
of question-answer pairs into a holistic narrative paragraph that reconstructs
the video's event structure; and Question-Based Captioning (QBC), which
generates fine-grained visual rationales, grounding the answer to each question
in specific, relevant evidence. Leveraging powerful generative models, we use
this synthetic data to train VideoQA models under a unified next-token
prediction objective. Extensive experiments on STAR and NExT-QA validate our
approach, demonstrating significant accuracy gains and establishing new
state-of-the-art results, such as improving a 3B model to 72.5\% on STAR
(+4.9\%) and a 7B model to 80.8\% on NExT-QA. Beyond accuracy, our analysis
reveals that both QBP and QBC substantially enhance cross-dataset
generalization, with QBP additionally accelerating model convergence by over
2.5x. These results demonstrate that shifting data synthesis from isolated
facts to narrative coherence and grounded rationales yields a more accurate,
efficient, and generalizable training paradigm.

AI.tldr: Synthesizes richer supervisory signals for VideoQA by moving beyond isolated facts to narrative coherence and grounded rationales, using QBP and QBC to train with a next-token objective; achieves state-of-the-art results and better generalization.
AI.motivation: Current VideoQA supervision is a bag-of-facts paradigm that fails to capture narrative structure and causal relationships in videos, hindering deep understanding and generalization.
AI.method: 1) Question-Based Paraphrasing (QBP): create a holistic narrative paragraph by paraphrasing diverse inquiries (what/how/why) from existing QA pairs to reconstruct event structure. 2) Question-Based Captioning (QBC): generate fine-grained visual rationales grounding each answer to specific evidence. Train VideoQA models with a unified next-token prediction objective using the synthesized data.
AI.result: Significant accuracy gains and new state-of-the-art results on STAR and NExT-QA: e.g., 3B model to 72.5% on STAR (+4.9%), 7B model to 80.8% on NExT-QA. Improved cross-dataset generalization; QBP speeds convergence by >2.5x.
AI.conclusion: Shifting data synthesis from isolated facts to narrative coherence and grounded rationales yields more accurate, efficient, and generalizable VideoQA models.

title: DRIFT-Net: A Spectral--Coupled Neural Operator for PDEs Learning
summary:
Learning PDE dynamics with neural solvers can significantly improve
wall-clock efficiency and accuracy compared with classical numerical solvers.
In recent years, foundation models for PDEs have largely adopted multi-scale
windowed self-attention, with the scOT backbone in \textsc{Poseidon} serving as
a representative example.
  However, because of their locality, truly globally consistent spectral
coupling can only be propagated gradually through deep stacking and window
shifting. This weakens global coupling and leads to error accumulation and
drift during closed-loop rollouts. To address this, we propose
\textbf{DRIFT-Net}. It employs a dual-branch design comprising a spectral
branch and an image branch. The spectral branch is responsible for capturing
global, large-scale low-frequency information, whereas the image branch focuses
on local details and nonstationary structures. Specifically, we first perform
controlled, lightweight mixing within the low-frequency range. Then we fuse the
spectral and image paths at each layer via bandwise weighting, which avoids the
width inflation and training instability caused by naive concatenation. The
fused result is transformed back into the spatial domain and added to the image
branch, thereby preserving both global structure and high-frequency details
across scales. Compared with strong attention-based baselines, DRIFT-Net
achieves lower error and higher throughput with fewer parameters under
identical training settings and budget. On Navier--Stokes benchmarks, the
relative $L_{1}$ error is reduced by 7\%--54\%, the parameter count decreases
by about 15\%, and the throughput remains higher than scOT. Ablation studies
and theoretical analyses further demonstrate the stability and effectiveness of
this design. The code is available at
https://github.com/cruiseresearchgroup/DRIFT-Net.

AI.tldr: DRIFT-Net is a dual-branch neural PDE solver combining a spectral branch for global low-frequency info with an image branch for local details, using bandwise fusion to preserve global structure while maintaining high-frequency accuracy. It improves stability and efficiency over attention-based baselines, with notable gains on Navier–Stokes benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Multi-scale, windowed self-attention PDE solvers (e.g., Poseidon/scOT) struggle to propagate global spectral coupling, causing error accumulation and drift during closed-loop rollouts. A method ensuring global coupling while preserving local details is needed for stable, accurate PDE dynamics learning.
AI.method: DRIFT-Net uses two branches: a spectral branch for global low-frequency information and an image branch for local, nonstationary structures. It performs lightweight low-frequency mixing, then fuses the branches at each layer using bandwise weighting (avoiding width inflation). The fused output is transformed back to the spatial domain and added to the image branch to maintain both global structure and high-frequency details across scales.
AI.result: On Navier–Stokes benchmarks, relative L1 error is reduced by 7%–54% compared to strong baselines; parameter count decreases by ~15%; throughput is higher than scOT. Ablations and theoretical analyses support stability and effectiveness; code available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: DRIFT-Net delivers improved global–local coupling, stability, and efficiency for neural PDE solvers, outperforming attention-based baselines while using fewer parameters and achieving higher throughput.

title: Generalist Multi-Class Anomaly Detection via Distillation to Two Heterogeneous Student Networks
summary:
Anomaly detection (AD) plays an important role in various real-world
applications. Recent advancements in AD, however, are often biased towards
industrial inspection, struggle to generalize to broader tasks like semantic
anomaly detection and vice versa. Although recent methods have attempted to
address general anomaly detection, their performance remains sensitive to
dataset-specific settings and single-class tasks. In this paper, we propose a
novel dual-model ensemble approach based on knowledge distillation (KD) to
bridge this gap. Our framework consists of a teacher and two student models: an
Encoder-Decoder model, specialized in detecting patch-level minor defects for
industrial AD and an Encoder-Encoder model, optimized for semantic AD. Both
models leverage a shared pre-trained encoder (DINOv2) to extract high-quality
feature representations. The dual models are jointly learned using the Noisy-OR
objective, and the final anomaly score is obtained using the joint probability
via local and semantic anomaly scores derived from the respective models. We
evaluate our method on eight public benchmarks under both single-class and
multi-class settings: MVTec-AD, MVTec-LOCO, VisA and Real-IAD for industrial
inspection and CIFAR-10/100, FMNIST and View for semantic anomaly detection.
The proposed method achieved state-of-the-art accuracies in both domains, in
multi-class as well as single-class settings, demonstrating generalization
across multiple domains of anomaly detection. Our model achieved an image-level
AUROC of 99.7% on MVTec-AD and 97.8% on CIFAR-10, which is significantly better
than the prior general AD models in multi-class settings and even higher than
the best specialist models on individual benchmarks.

AI.tldr: A KD-based dual-model ensemble for general anomaly detection, combining a patch-focused Encoder-Decoder and a semantic Encoder-Encoder with a shared DINOv2 encoder, trained via Noisy-OR to produce joint anomaly scores; achieves state-of-the-art results across industrial and semantic benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Address the generalization gap in anomaly detection between industrial (patch-level defects) and semantic (semantic anomalies) tasks and single-/multi-class settings.
AI.method: A teacher and two student models share a pre-trained DINOv2 encoder. Encoder-Decoder targets patch-level industrial defects; Encoder-Encoder targets semantic anomalies. Noisy-OR objective guides joint learning. Anomaly scores combine local (patch) and semantic cues.
AI.result: State-of-the-art accuracies on eight public benchmarks in both single-class and multi-class settings; image-level AUROCs: 99.7% (MVTec-AD) and 97.8% (CIFAR-10). Generalizes across domains and tasks, often outperforming specialist models.
AI.conclusion: The KD-based dual-model ensemble bridges industrial and semantic anomaly detection, offering strong generalization and robust performance, with potential for broader AD applications.

title: Uncertainty-Guided Expert-AI Collaboration for Efficient Soil Horizon Annotation
comment:
11 pages, 7 figures, presented at ECAI 2025, CLEAR-AI Workshop,
  Bologna
summary:
Uncertainty quantification is essential in human-machine collaboration, as
human agents tend to adjust their decisions based on the confidence of the
machine counterpart. Reliably calibrated model uncertainties, hence, enable
more effective collaboration, targeted expert intervention and more responsible
usage of Machine Learning (ML) systems. Conformal prediction has become a well
established model-agnostic framework for uncertainty calibration of ML models,
offering statistically valid confidence estimates for both regression and
classification tasks. In this work, we apply conformal prediction to
$\textit{SoilNet}$, a multimodal multitask model for describing soil profiles.
We design a simulated human-in-the-loop (HIL) annotation pipeline, where a
limited budget for obtaining ground truth annotations from domain experts is
available when model uncertainty is high. Our experiments show that
conformalizing SoilNet leads to more efficient annotation in regression tasks
and comparable performance scores in classification tasks under the same
annotation budget when tested against its non-conformal counterpart. All code
and experiments can be found in our repository:
https://github.com/calgo-lab/BGR

AI.tldr: Conformal prediction is used to calibrate SoilNet uncertainties in a simulated HIL annotation pipeline, yielding more efficient regression annotation and comparable classification performance under a fixed annotation budget.
AI.motivation: Uncertainty calibration supports better human-machine collaboration and responsible ML deployment; conformal prediction provides statistically valid confidence estimates for ML models.
AI.method: Apply conformal prediction to SoilNet, a multimodal multitask soil-profile model; design a simulated human-in-the-loop annotation pipeline with limited expert annotations triggered by high uncertainty; compare to non-conformal baseline under the same budget.
AI.result: Conformalization leads to more efficient annotation in regression tasks and comparable (or similar) performance scores in classification tasks under the same annotation budget; code available at repository.
AI.conclusion: Conformal prediction is effective for uncertainty calibration in a multimodal soil-description model, enabling targeted expert intervention and efficient use of annotation budgets, thus enhancing human-machine collaboration in this domain.

title: LaMoGen: Laban Movement-Guided Diffusion for Text-to-Motion Generation
summary:
Diverse human motion generation is an increasingly important task, having
various applications in computer vision, human-computer interaction and
animation. While text-to-motion synthesis using diffusion models has shown
success in generating high-quality motions, achieving fine-grained expressive
motion control remains a significant challenge. This is due to the lack of
motion style diversity in datasets and the difficulty of expressing
quantitative characteristics in natural language. Laban movement analysis has
been widely used by dance experts to express the details of motion including
motion quality as consistent as possible. Inspired by that, this work aims for
interpretable and expressive control of human motion generation by seamlessly
integrating the quantification methods of Laban Effort and Shape components
into the text-guided motion generation models. Our proposed zero-shot,
inference-time optimization method guides the motion generation model to have
desired Laban Effort and Shape components without any additional motion data by
updating the text embedding of pretrained diffusion models during the sampling
step. We demonstrate that our approach yields diverse expressive motion
qualities while preserving motion identity by successfully manipulating motion
attributes according to target Laban tags.

AI.tldr: Proposes a zero-shot, inference-time optimization to control diffusion-based text-to-motion synthesis using Laban Effort and Shape components, by updating the text embedding during sampling to achieve target expressive attributes without extra motion data.
AI.motivation: Fine-grained expressive control in text-to-motion remains difficult due to limited motion style diversity in datasets and the challenge of expressing qualitative motion attributes in natural language. Laban Movement Analysis provides a principled, interpretable vocabulary to quantify motion quality.
AI.method: Inference-time, zero-shot optimization that updates the text embedding of a pretrained diffusion model during the sampling step to align generated motion with desired Laban Effort and Shape components, without requiring additional motion datasets.
AI.result: The method yields diverse expressive motion qualities and preserves motion identity by manipulating motion attributes to match target Laban tags, demonstrated during inference without additional training data.
AI.conclusion: Integrating Laban components into text-guided motion generation enables interpretable, expressive control without extra data, offering a path toward richer, more controllable motion generation.

title: Scaling Laws and Spectra of Shallow Neural Networks in the Feature Learning Regime
summary:
Neural scaling laws underlie many of the recent advances in deep learning,
yet their theoretical understanding remains largely confined to linear models.
In this work, we present a systematic analysis of scaling laws for quadratic
and diagonal neural networks in the feature learning regime. Leveraging
connections with matrix compressed sensing and LASSO, we derive a detailed
phase diagram for the scaling exponents of the excess risk as a function of
sample complexity and weight decay. This analysis uncovers crossovers between
distinct scaling regimes and plateau behaviors, mirroring phenomena widely
reported in the empirical neural scaling literature. Furthermore, we establish
a precise link between these regimes and the spectral properties of the trained
network weights, which we characterize in detail. As a consequence, we provide
a theoretical validation of recent empirical observations connecting the
emergence of power-law tails in the weight spectrum with network generalization
performance, yielding an interpretation from first principles.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes neural scaling laws for quadratic and diagonal networks in the feature learning regime, using compressed sensing/LASSO to map how excess risk scales with data and regularization, revealing phase diagrams with regime crossovers and plateaus, and linking these to spectral properties of trained weights and power-law tails.
AI.motivation: To extend theoretical understanding of neural scaling laws beyond linear models, by studying quadratic/diagonal networks in the feature-learning regime and connecting scaling to weight spectra.
AI.method: Leverage connections with matrix compressed sensing and LASSO to derive a phase diagram for the scaling exponents of excess risk as a function of sample complexity and weight decay; analyze spectral properties of trained weights to relate regimes to the weight spectrum.
AI.result: A detailed phase diagram showing scaling exponents across regimes, crossovers and plateau behaviors; a precise link between scaling regimes and the spectral properties of learned weights; theoretical validation of empirical observations that power-law tails in the weight spectrum correlate with generalization.
AI.conclusion: Provides a first-principles interpretation of neural scaling phenomena beyond linear models by tying scaling behavior to weight-spectrum structure, thereby rationalizing observed power-law tails and their relation to generalization.

title: Euclid's Gift: Enhancing Spatial Perception and Reasoning in Vision-Language Models via Geometric Surrogate Tasks
summary:
Spatial intelligence spans a rich suite of abilities, including visualising
and transforming shapes, mentally rotating objects, judging relational
positions and containment, and estimating numerosity. However, it still remains
a critical unresolved challenge for Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs).To
fill this gap, we propose to treat Euclidean geometry problem-solving as a
surrogate task. Specifically, we meticulously constructed a curated multimodal
dataset, called Euclid30K, comprising approximately 30K plane and solid
geometry problems. To enable the model to acquire and apply Euclidean
principles from these geometry problems, we employed Group Relative Policy
Optimization (GRPO) to finetune the Qwen2.5VL family and RoboBrain2.0 family,
inspiring the models to identify shapes, count, and relate entities, and
perform multi-step deductive reasoning using Euclidean principles. Our
experiments demonstrate that the resulting models achieve substantial zero-shot
gains across four spatial reasoning benchmarks (Super-CLEVR, Omni3DBench,
VSI-Bench, and MindCube) without any task-specific adaptations. Notably, after
training on the Euclid30K, the mean VSI-Bench accuracy of all evaluated models
rose from 34.5% to 40.5%, improving by 5.5 percentage points. Among them,
RoboBrain2.0-Euclid-7B achieves 49.6\% accuracy, surpassing the previous
state-of-the-art model, Spatial-MLLM.To our knowledge, this is the first
systematic study showing that geometry-centric fine-tuning can confer
vision-language models with broadly transferable spatial skills. Code and
Euclid30K dataset can be found in https://zgca-ai4edu.github.io/Euclids_Gift.

AI.tldr: Geometry-focused fine-tuning of multimodal LLMs via Euclid30K and Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) yields transferable spatial reasoning skills, with notable gains across multiple benchmarks and surpassing prior state-of-the-art.
AI.motivation: Spatial intelligence is a critical but underdeveloped capability for multimodal LLMs. A geometry-centric approach aims to endow models with broadly transferable spatial skills by teaching Euclidean reasoning.
AI.method: Construct Euclid30K (~30k plane and solid geometry problems). Fine-tune Qwen2.5VL and RoboBrain2.0 family using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to encourage shape identification, counting, relational reasoning, and multi-step Euclidean deduction.
AI.result: Zero-shot gains across four spatial-reasoning benchmarks (Super-CLEVR, Omni3DBench, VSI-Bench, MindCube). Mean VSI-Bench accuracy rises from 34.5% to 40.5% (5.5 percentage points). RoboBrain2.0-Euclid-7B achieves 49.6% accuracy, surpassing Spatial-MLLM. This suggests geometry-centric fine-tuning yields transferable spatial skills.
AI.conclusion: This work provides the first systematic study showing geometry-centric fine-tuning confers broadly transferable spatial capabilities in vision-language models; the Euclid30K dataset and code are released for reproducibility.

title: Adaptive Canonicalization with Application to Invariant Anisotropic Geometric Networks
summary:
Canonicalization is a widely used strategy in equivariant machine learning,
enforcing symmetry in neural networks by mapping each input to a standard form.
Yet, it often introduces discontinuities that can affect stability during
training, limit generalization, and complicate universal approximation
theorems. In this paper, we address this by introducing \emph{adaptive
canonicalization}, a general framework in which the canonicalization depends
both on the input and the network. Specifically, we present the adaptive
canonicalization based on prior maximization, where the standard form of the
input is chosen to maximize the predictive confidence of the network. We prove
that this construction yields continuous and symmetry-respecting models that
admit universal approximation properties.
  We propose two applications of our setting: (i) resolving eigenbasis
ambiguities in spectral graph neural networks, and (ii) handling rotational
symmetries in point clouds. We empirically validate our methods on molecular
and protein classification, as well as point cloud classification tasks. Our
adaptive canonicalization outperforms the three other common solutions to
equivariant machine learning: data augmentation, standard canonicalization, and
equivariant architectures.

AI.tldr: Adaptive canonicalization is a framework where the canonical form of the input is chosen based on prior maximization to maximize predictive confidence, yielding continuous, symmetry-respecting models with universal approximation properties.
AI.motivation: Canonicalization enforces symmetry but can introduce discontinuities that harm training stability and generalization; a method is needed to preserve symmetry while maintaining continuity and universal approximation.
AI.method: Define adaptive canonicalization based on prior maximization: select the input's standard form to maximize the network's predictive confidence. Prove continuity, symmetry-respecting properties, and universal approximation. Apply to (i) eigenbasis ambiguities in spectral GNNs and (ii) rotational symmetries in point clouds; provide algorithms for implementation.
AI.result: The approach yields continuous, symmetry-respecting models with universal approximation guarantees. Empirically, it outperforms data augmentation, standard canonicalization, and standard equivariant architectures on molecular/protein classification and point cloud tasks.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive canonicalization offers a general, theoretically grounded framework to handle symmetry in neural networks, improving stability and generalization, with broad applicability across domains involving eigenbasis and rotational symmetries.

title: Performance-Efficiency Trade-off for Fashion Image Retrieval
summary:
The fashion industry has been identified as a major contributor to waste and
emissions, leading to an increased interest in promoting the second-hand
market. Machine learning methods play an important role in facilitating the
creation and expansion of second-hand marketplaces by enabling the large-scale
valuation of used garments. We contribute to this line of work by addressing
the scalability of second-hand image retrieval from databases. By introducing a
selective representation framework, we can shrink databases to 10% of their
original size without sacrificing retrieval accuracy. We first explore
clustering and coreset selection methods to identify representative samples
that capture the key features of each garment and its internal variability.
Then, we introduce an efficient outlier removal method, based on a
neighbour-homogeneity consistency score measure, that filters out
uncharacteristic samples prior to selection. We evaluate our approach on three
public datasets: DeepFashion Attribute, DeepFashion Con2Shop, and DeepFashion2.
The results demonstrate a clear performance-efficiency trade-off by
strategically pruning and selecting representative vectors of images. The
retrieval system maintains near-optimal accuracy, while greatly reducing
computational costs by reducing the images added to the vector database.
Furthermore, applying our outlier removal method to clustering techniques
yields even higher retrieval performance by removing non-discriminative samples
before the selection.

AI.tldr: Selective representation reduces fashion image databases to 10% of their size while preserving retrieval accuracy, via clustering, coresets, and a neighbour-homogeneity outlier score; validated on three DeepFashion datasets.
AI.motivation: Tackle waste/emissions in fashion by enabling scalable, cost-effective second-hand image retrieval.
AI.method: Propose a selective representation framework: (1) clustering and coreset selection to identify representative samples capturing garment features and intra-garment variability; (2) an efficient outlier removal step using a neighbour-homogeneity consistency score; (3) evaluate retrieval performance with progressively pruned databases on DeepFashion Attribute, DeepFashion Con2Shop, and DeepFashion2; (4) compare against full-database baselines.
AI.result: Database size reduced to ~10% with retrieval accuracy near that of full-scale; clear performance-efficiency trade-off; outlier removal improves clustering and overall retrieval when applied prior to selection; substantial computation and storage savings.
AI.conclusion: Selective pruning and outlier-aware sampling enable scalable, accurate second-hand garment retrieval with much smaller vector databases.

title: Towards Understanding the Shape of Representations in Protein Language Models
summary:
While protein language models (PLMs) are one of the most promising avenues of
research for future de novo protein design, the way in which they transform
sequences to hidden representations, as well as the information encoded in such
representations is yet to be fully understood. Several works have attempted to
propose interpretability tools for PLMs, but they have focused on understanding
how individual sequences are transformed by such models. Therefore, the way in
which PLMs transform the whole space of sequences along with their relations is
still unknown. In this work we attempt to understand this transformed space of
sequences by identifying protein structure and representation with square-root
velocity (SRV) representations and graph filtrations. Both approaches naturally
lead to a metric space in which pairs of proteins or protein representations
can be compared with each other.
  We analyze different types of proteins from the SCOP dataset and show that
the Karcher mean and effective dimension of the SRV shape space follow a
non-linear pattern as a function of the layers in ESM2 models of different
sizes. Furthermore, we use graph filtrations as a tool to study the context
lengths at which models encode the structural features of proteins. We find
that PLMs preferentially encode immediate as well as local relations between
residues, but start to degrade for larger context lengths. The most
structurally faithful encoding tends to occur close to, but before the last
layer of the models, indicating that training a folding model ontop of these
layers might lead to improved folding performance.

AI.tldr: SRV and graph-filtration analysis reveal layer-dependent geometry of PLM representations. Local residue relations are captured early to mid-layers, while long-range structure encoding degrades; the strongest structural faithfulness occurs near the last layer, suggesting folding models might benefit from training on near-final layers.
AI.motivation: To understand how the entire space of protein sequences is transformed by protein language models (PLMs), not just individual sequences, by embedding sequences/representations into metric spaces (SRV shape space) and analyzing structural relations via graph filtrations.
AI.method: Represent proteins and PLM-derived representations using square-root velocity (SRV) coordinates to form a geometric shape space; apply graph filtrations to study context-length encodings; analyze Karcher mean and effective dimension across ESM2 layers (of different sizes) on the SCOP dataset.
AI.result: Karcher means and effective dimensions of the SRV shape space vary non-linearly with layer depth; PLMs encode mostly local residue–residue relations and show degradation for larger context lengths; the most structurally faithful encoding occurs near the last layer, before the final layer, suggesting a folding model built on top of these layers could improve performance.
AI.conclusion: A geometric-interpretable view of PLMs reveals where structural features are encoded, supporting the idea of leveraging near-final layers for folding tasks and guiding future interpretability work that tracks entire spaces of sequences rather than individual instances.

title: Mitigating Visual Hallucinations via Semantic Curriculum Preference Optimization in MLLMs
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have significantly improved the
performance of various tasks, but continue to suffer from visual
hallucinations, a critical issue where generated responses contradict visual
evidence. While Direct Preference Optimization(DPO) is widely used for
alignment, its application to MLLMs often fails to capture fine-grained
semantic differences and encourages shortcut learning. To address these
challenges, we propose Semantic Curriculum Preference Optimization (SCPO), a
novel framework for MLLM alignment. SCPO employs a progressive, easy-to-hard
curriculum built upon our Semantic Curriculum Preference Pairs dataset, which
provides fine-grained semantic contrasts sorted by difficulty. This curriculum
is trained with a dynamic reference model and a novel symmetric, bidirectional
objective to facilitate simultaneous learning from both textual and visual
preferences. To our knowledge, SCPO is the first framework to unify semantics,
symmetry, and curriculum for MLLMs alignment, effectively mitigating visual
hallucinations. Extensive experiments on LLaVA models across various scales and
versions validate that SCPO demonstrates superior performance compared to
baseline models on multiple hallucination benchmarks, reducing the
hallucination rate by up to 62.9%. Moreover, evaluations on generalized
benchmarks show that SCPO improves factuality while preserving general
capabilities, with its performance remaining stable across general
vision-language benchmarks.

AI.tldr: SCPO introduces Semantic Curriculum Preference Optimization for multimodal LLM alignment, addressing visual hallucinations by combining semantics, symmetry, and a curriculum. It uses a Semantic Curriculum Preference Pairs dataset, a dynamic reference model, and a bidirectional objective to learn from both textual and visual preferences. Evaluations on LLaVA show superior results, reducing hallucinations up to 62.9% and maintaining generalization across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Visual hallucinations in multimodal LLMs remain a core challenge, and while Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) is common, it fails to capture fine-grained semantic differences and can foster shortcut learning. There is a need for an approach that integrates semantic understanding, symmetric learning (textual-visual), and curriculum-based training to improve factuality and robustness.
AI.method: Proposes Semantic Curriculum Preference Pairs dataset that orders semantic contrasts by difficulty. Builds a progressive easy-to-hard curriculum (Semantic Curriculum). Uses a dynamic reference model during training and introduces a symmetric, bidirectional objective to learn from both textual and visual preferences. Trains on LLaVA models across scales; evaluates on hallucination benchmarks and general V&L benchmarks.
AI.result: SCPO achieves superior performance over baselines on multiple hallucination benchmarks, reducing hallucination rates by up to 62.9%. It also enhances factuality while preserving general capabilities, with stable performance across various general vision-language benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: SCPO is the first framework to unify semantics, symmetry, and curriculum for MLLM alignment, effectively mitigating visual hallucinations and producing robust general performance across scales and benchmarks.

title: When Greedy Wins: Emergent Exploitation Bias in Meta-Bandit LLM Training
summary:
While Large Language Models (LLMs) hold promise to become autonomous agents,
they often explore suboptimally in sequential decision-making. Recent work has
sought to enhance this capability via supervised fine-tuning (SFT) or
reinforcement learning (RL), improving regret on the classic multi-armed bandit
task. However, it remains unclear how these learning methods shape exploration
strategies and how well they generalize. We investigate both paradigms by
training LLMs with SFT on expert trajectories and RL with a range of tailored
reward signals including a strategic, regret-shaped reward to reduce variance,
and an algorithmic reward that enables oracle imitation. The resulting agents
outperform pre-trained models and achieve performance comparable to Upper
Confidence Bound (UCB) and Thompson Sampling, with robust generalization to 6x
longer horizons and across bandit families. Behavioral analysis reveals that
gains often stem from more sophisticated but greedier exploitation: RL/SFT
agents are more prone to early catastrophic failure than pre-trained models,
prematurely abandoning exploration. Furthermore, agents trained to imitate UCB
learn to outperform their teacher by adopting more exploitative variants. Our
findings clarify when each training paradigm is preferable and advocate
tailored reward design and evaluation beyond average regret to promote robust
exploratory behavior.

AI.tldr: SFT and RL with tailored rewards improve exploration in LLM bandit tasks, rival classic methods, but can cause greedier exploitation; imitation of UCB can outperform teacher; emphasizes reward design and evaluation beyond average regret.
AI.motivation: To understand how supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and reinforcement learning (RL) shape exploration strategies in LLMs for sequential decision tasks (bandits) and how well these methods generalize across horizons and bandit families.
AI.method: Train LLMs with SFT on expert trajectories; apply RL with various rewards, including a regret-shaped reward to reduce variance and an algorithmic reward enabling oracle imitation; compare performance to pretrained baselines and to UCB/Thompson Sampling; test generalization to 6x longer horizons and across bandit families; conduct behavioral analysis of exploration/exploitation.
AI.result: SFT/RL agents outperform pretrained models and reach regret levels comparable to UCB and Thompson Sampling; demonstrate robust generalization to longer horizons and various bandit families; behavior largely due to more aggressive, earlier exploitation, with higher risk of early catastrophic failures; agents trained to imitate UCB can outperform their teacher by adopting more exploitative strategies.
AI.conclusion: Tailored reward design and evaluation beyond average regret are crucial to foster robust exploration in LLM agents; choose training paradigm based on goals; RL/SFT can approach classic bandit performance but may sacrifice exploration; imitation of strong explorers (e.g., UCB) yields strong exploitative policies; emphasize careful evaluation of exploration behavior.

title: Robust Multimodal Semantic Segmentation with Balanced Modality Contributions
summary:
Multimodal semantic segmentation enhances model robustness by exploiting
cross-modal complementarities. However, existing methods often suffer from
imbalanced modal dependencies, where overall performance degrades significantly
once a dominant modality deteriorates in real-world scenarios. Thus, modality
balance has become acritical challenge for practical multimodal segmentation.
To address this issue, we propose EQUISeg, a multimodal segmentation framework
that balances modality contributions through equal encoding of modalities.
Built upon a four-stage Cross-modal Transformer Block(CMTB), EQUISeg enables
efficient multimodal fusion and hierarchical selection. Furthermore, we design
a Self-guided Module(SGM) that mitigates modality imbalance by introducing a
mutual guidance mechanism, enabling each modality to adaptively adjust its
contribution and enhance robustness under degraded conditions. Extensive
experiments on multiple datasets demonstrate that EQUISeg achieves significant
performance gains and effectively alleviates the adverse effects of modality
imbalance in segmentation tasks.

AI.tldr: EquiSeg (EQUISeg) proposes balanced multimodal segmentation by equal encoding and mutual guidance. It uses a four-stage Cross-modal Transformer Block for efficient fusion and a Self-guided Module to adaptively balance modality contributions, improving robustness when a dominant modality deteriorates.
AI.motivation: Multimodal segmentation suffers from modality imbalance where reliance on a dominant modality causes performance collapse when others degrade; practical models need robust, balanced fusion across modalities.
AI.method: EQUISeg introduces four-stage Cross-modal Transformer Block (CMTB) for cross-modal fusion and hierarchical selection, plus a Self-guided Module (SGM) implementing a mutual guidance mechanism so each modality can adapt its contribution, achieving equal encoding of modalities to balance their influence.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple datasets show significant performance gains and improved robustness to modality imbalance, validating the approach across varied conditions.
AI.conclusion: EQUISeg effectively balances modality contributions in multimodal segmentation, mitigating adverse effects of modality imbalance and demonstrating practical robustness improvements.

title: Is Sequence Information All You Need for Bayesian Optimization of Antibodies?
comment: Accepted into the AI for Science Workshop, NeurIPS 2025
summary:
Bayesian optimization is a natural candidate for the engineering of antibody
therapeutic properties, which is often iterative and expensive. However,
finding the optimal choice of surrogate model for optimization over the highly
structured antibody space is difficult, and may differ depending on the
property being optimized. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, no prior
works have attempted to incorporate structural information into antibody
Bayesian optimization. In this work, we explore different approaches to
incorporating structural information into Bayesian optimization, and compare
them to a variety of sequence-only approaches on two different antibody
properties, binding affinity and stability. In addition, we propose the use of
a protein language model-based ``soft constraint,'' which helps guide the
optimization to promising regions of the space. We find that certain types of
structural information improve data efficiency in early optimization rounds for
stability, but have equivalent peak performance. Moreover, when incorporating
the protein language model soft constraint we find that the data efficiency gap
is diminished for affinity and eliminated for stability, resulting in
sequence-only methods that match the performance of structure-based methods,
raising questions about the necessity of structure in Bayesian optimization for
antibodies.

AI.tldr: Structural information can make Bayesian optimization more data-efficient early on for stability in antibody engineering, but overall peak performance matches sequence-only methods; introducing a protein language model-based soft constraint narrows the data-efficiency gap, suggesting structure may be unnecessary for BO in antibodies under these settings.
AI.motivation: Antibody properties optimization is iterative and expensive. The best surrogate model for Bayesian optimization in the structured antibody space is unclear and may depend on the target property. No prior work has incorporated structural information into antibody BO.
AI.method: Evaluate multiple approaches to incorporating structural information into Bayesian optimization and compare them to sequence-only baselines across two antibody properties (binding affinity and stability). Introduce a protein language model-based soft constraint to guide the search and assess data efficiency and peak performance.
AI.result: Structural cues improve data efficiency in early optimization rounds for stability, with equivalent peak performance to sequence-only approaches. When applying the language-model soft constraint, the data-efficiency gap closes for affinity and is eliminated for stability, leading sequence-only methods to match structure-based methods.
AI.conclusion: Structure can aid early data efficiency for some properties but does not confer a lasting advantage in peak performance. A protein-language-model soft constraint can mitigate data-efficiency gaps, suggesting that, at least for antibodies, the necessity of explicit structure in Bayesian optimization is questionable under these conditions.

title: Instruction Guided Multi Object Image Editing with Quantity and Layout Consistency
summary:
Instruction driven image editing with standard CLIP text encoders often fails
in complex scenes with many objects. We present QL-Adapter, a framework for
multiple object editing that tackles two challenges: enforcing object counts
and spatial layouts, and accommodating diverse categories. QL-Adapter consists
of two core modules: the Image-Layout Fusion Module (ILFM) and the Cross-Modal
Augmentation Module (CMAM). ILFM fuses layout priors with ViT patch tokens from
the CLIP image encoder to strengthen spatial structure understanding. CMAM
injects image features into the text branch to enrich textual embeddings and
improve instruction following. We further build QL-Dataset, a benchmark that
spans broad category, layout, and count variations, and define the task of
quantity and layout consistent image editing (QL-Edit). Extensive experiments
show that QL-Adapter achieves state of the art performance on QL-Edit and
significantly outperforms existing models.

AI.tldr: Proposes QL-Adapter for multi-object image editing, introducing ILFM and CMAM to enforce object counts/layouts and enrich text embeddings, plus QL-Dataset and QL-Edit task; achieves state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Existing instruction-driven editing with CLIP struggles in complex scenes with many objects; need to ensure correct counts, spatial layouts, and diverse categories.
AI.method: Two modules: Image-Layout Fusion Module (ILFM) fuses layout priors with ViT patch tokens from CLIP image encoder; Cross-Modal Augmentation Module (CMAM) injects image features into text branch to improve instruction following; also introduces QL-Dataset and defines QL-Edit task.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show SOTA performance on QL-Edit and significant outperformance of existing models.
AI.conclusion: QL-Adapter effectively enables quantity- and layout-consistent image editing across diverse categories; provides a benchmark (QL-Dataset) to evaluate such editing.

title: OAT-FM: Optimal Acceleration Transport for Improved Flow Matching
summary:
As a powerful technique in generative modeling, Flow Matching (FM) aims to
learn velocity fields from noise to data, which is often explained and
implemented as solving Optimal Transport (OT) problems. In this study, we
bridge FM and the recent theory of Optimal Acceleration Transport (OAT),
developing an improved FM method called OAT-FM and exploring its benefits in
both theory and practice. In particular, we demonstrate that the straightening
objective hidden in existing OT-based FM methods is mathematically equivalent
to minimizing the physical action associated with acceleration defined by OAT.
Accordingly, instead of enforcing constant velocity, OAT-FM optimizes the
acceleration transport in the product space of sample and velocity, whose
objective corresponds to a necessary and sufficient condition of flow
straightness. An efficient algorithm is designed to achieve OAT-FM with low
complexity. OAT-FM motivates a new two-phase FM paradigm: Given a generative
model trained by an arbitrary FM method, whose velocity information has been
relatively reliable, we can fine-tune and improve it via OAT-FM. This paradigm
eliminates the risk of data distribution drift and the need to generate a large
number of noise data pairs, which consistently improves model performance in
various generative tasks. Code is available at:
https://github.com/AngxiaoYue/OAT-FM

AI.tldr: OAT-FM reframes Flow Matching as acceleration transport per Optimal Acceleration Transport, yielding an efficient algorithm, a two-phase FM paradigm, and consistent performance gains without extensive noise data-pair generation.
AI.motivation: Flow Matching (FM) learns velocity fields for data generation and is commonly interpreted through Optimal Transport (OT). However, the usual straightening objective is tied to constant-velocity assumptions and lacks a direct connection to acceleration-based transport theory. The work seeks stronger theoretical grounding, improved efficiency, and practical performance in FM by leveraging OAT.
AI.method: Demonstrate that the straightening objective in OT-based FM is equivalent to minimizing the action of acceleration under OAT. Propose OAT-FM, which optimizes acceleration transport in the product space of samples and velocities to enforce flow straightness. Develop a low-complexity algorithm. Propose a two-phase FM paradigm: start from a generative model trained by any FM method and fine-tune it with OAT-FM to improve velocity information while avoiding data distribution drift and the need to generate many noise-data pairs.
AI.result: The paper provides a theoretical connection between FM and OAT, introduces an efficient OAT-FM algorithm, and demonstrates consistent performance improvements across various generative tasks; code is released.
AI.conclusion: OAT-FM offers a principled acceleration-based framework for FM, enabling a practical two-phase training paradigm that enhances velocity quality and generative performance while reducing data drift and noise requirements.

title: CMT: Mid-Training for Efficient Learning of Consistency, Mean Flow, and Flow Map Models
summary:
Flow map models such as Consistency Models (CM) and Mean Flow (MF) enable
few-step generation by learning the long jump of the ODE solution of diffusion
models, yet training remains unstable, sensitive to hyperparameters, and
costly. Initializing from a pre-trained diffusion model helps, but still
requires converting infinitesimal steps into a long-jump map, leaving
instability unresolved. We introduce mid-training, the first concept and
practical method that inserts a lightweight intermediate stage between the
(diffusion) pre-training and the final flow map training (i.e., post-training)
for vision generation. Concretely, Consistency Mid-Training (CMT) is a compact
and principled stage that trains a model to map points along a solver
trajectory from a pre-trained model, starting from a prior sample, directly to
the solver-generated clean sample. It yields a trajectory-consistent and stable
initialization. This initializer outperforms random and diffusion-based
baselines and enables fast, robust convergence without heuristics. Initializing
post-training with CMT weights further simplifies flow map learning.
Empirically, CMT achieves state of the art two step FIDs: 1.97 on CIFAR-10,
1.32 on ImageNet 64x64, and 1.84 on ImageNet 512x512, while using up to 98%
less training data and GPU time, compared to CMs. On ImageNet 256x256, CMT
reaches 1-step FID 3.34 while cutting total training time by about 50% compared
to MF from scratch (FID 3.43). This establishes CMT as a principled, efficient,
and general framework for training flow map models.

AI.tldr: Introduces Consistency Mid-Training (CMT), a lightweight intermediate stage between diffusion pre-training and flow-map post-training that maps solver trajectories to clean samples, yielding a stable, trajectory-consistent initializer and enabling fast, data-efficient training of flow-map models.
AI.motivation: Training flow-map models (CMs and MF) is unstable, hypersensitive, and expensive. Existing pretraining helps but fails to provide a stable, long-jump initializer; a principled intermediate stage could bridge pretraining and post-training to improve stability and efficiency.
AI.method: Insert a compact intermediate training phase (CMT) between pre-training and post-training. Train a model to map points along the solver trajectory from a pre-trained diffusion model, starting from a prior sample, directly to the solver-generated clean sample. This yields a trajectory-consistent initializer that can also initialize post-training. No heuristic tuning needed.
AI.result: CMT achieves state-of-the-art two-step FIDs: CIFAR-10 = 1.97, ImageNet 64x64 = 1.32, ImageNet 512x512 = 1.84, while using up to 98% less training data and GPU time than competing Consistency Models. For ImageNet 256x256, CMT attains 1-step FID 3.34 with ~50% less training time than MF from scratch (FID 3.43).
AI.conclusion: CMT provides a principled, efficient, and general framework to stabilize and accelerate flow-map training, simplifying initialization for post-training and enabling strong performance with significantly reduced resources.

title: Learning Distinguishable Representations in Deep Q-Networks for Linear Transfer
summary:
Deep Reinforcement Learning (RL) has demonstrated success in solving complex
sequential decision-making problems by integrating neural networks with the RL
framework. However, training deep RL models poses several challenges, such as
the need for extensive hyperparameter tuning and high computational costs.
Transfer learning has emerged as a promising strategy to address these
challenges by enabling the reuse of knowledge from previously learned tasks for
new, related tasks. This avoids the need for retraining models entirely from
scratch. A commonly used approach for transfer learning in RL is to leverage
the internal representations learned by the neural network during training.
Specifically, the activations from the last hidden layer can be viewed as
refined state representations that encapsulate the essential features of the
input. In this work, we investigate whether these representations can be used
as input for training simpler models, such as linear function approximators, on
new tasks. We observe that the representations learned by standard deep RL
models can be highly correlated, which limits their effectiveness when used
with linear function approximation. To mitigate this problem, we propose a
novel deep Q-learning approach that introduces a regularization term to reduce
positive correlations between feature representation of states. By leveraging
these reduced correlated features, we enable more effective use of linear
function approximation in transfer learning. Through experiments and ablation
studies on standard RL benchmarks and MinAtar games, we demonstrate the
efficacy of our approach in improving transfer learning performance and thereby
reducing computational overhead.

AI.tldr: A regularized deep Q-learning method lowers positive correlations in hidden representations to improve transfer learning with linear models, achieving better transfer performance and reduced compute.
AI.motivation: Deep RL transfer is costly; linear models on good representations can be data-efficient, but correlated features hinder linear transfer; reducing correlation can unlock simple transfer learners.
AI.method: Introduce a regularization term into a deep Q-learning objective to minimize positive correlations between feature activations in the last hidden layer; train on standard RL benchmarks and MinAtar; evaluate transfer performance when using linear function approximators on new tasks.
AI.result: The approach improves transfer learning performance and reduces computational overhead compared to baselines; ablation studies confirm the role of decorrelation.
AI.conclusion: Reducing feature correlation in learned representations makes linear transfer learning more effective in deep RL and offers computation savings, suggesting a practical path for scalable transfer in RL.

title: CORE-3D: Context-aware Open-vocabulary Retrieval by Embeddings in 3D
comment:
9 pages without the refrences, 4 figures, sybmitted for ICLR 2026
  conference
summary:
3D scene understanding is fundamental for embodied AI and robotics,
supporting reliable perception for interaction and navigation. Recent
approaches achieve zero-shot, open-vocabulary 3D semantic mapping by assigning
embedding vectors to 2D class-agnostic masks generated via vision-language
models (VLMs) and projecting these into 3D. However, these methods often
produce fragmented masks and inaccurate semantic assignments due to the direct
use of raw masks, limiting their effectiveness in complex environments. To
address this, we leverage SemanticSAM with progressive granularity refinement
to generate more accurate and numerous object-level masks, mitigating the
over-segmentation commonly observed in mask generation models such as vanilla
SAM, and improving downstream 3D semantic segmentation. To further enhance
semantic context, we employ a context-aware CLIP encoding strategy that
integrates multiple contextual views of each mask using empirically determined
weighting, providing much richer visual context. We evaluate our approach on
multiple 3D scene understanding tasks, including 3D semantic segmentation and
object retrieval from language queries, across several benchmark datasets.
Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements over existing
methods, highlighting the effectiveness of our approach.

AI.tldr: Progressive granularity refinement with SemanticSAM and a context-aware CLIP encoding boost 3D open-vocabulary semantic mapping, yielding higher-quality object masks and improved downstream 3D semantic segmentation and language-based object retrieval.
AI.motivation: Zero-shot 3D semantic mapping relies on 2D masks from vision-language models, which often are fragmented or inaccurate when directly projected into 3D. The need is to produce higher-quality, more complete masks and richer semantic context for robust 3D understanding in complex environments.
AI.method: Use SemanticSAM with progressive granularity refinement to generate more accurate and numerous object-level masks, mitigating over-segmentation. Employ a context-aware CLIP encoding strategy that aggregates multiple contextual views per mask with empirically tuned weighting to provide richer visual context. Evaluate on 3D semantic segmentation and language-based object retrieval across multiple benchmark datasets.
AI.result: Significant improvements over existing methods across multiple benchmarks, driven by better mask quality and richer semantic context, leading to more accurate 3D semantic segmentation and more reliable language-based object retrieval.
AI.conclusion: The combination of refined object masks and context-enriched embeddings substantially enhances 3D scene understanding for open-vocabulary mappings, with strong potential for broader applications in embodied AI and robotics.

title: Intra-request branch orchestration for efficient LLM reasoning
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly rely on inference-time reasoning
algorithms such as chain-of-thought and multi-branch reasoning to improve
accuracy on complex tasks. These methods, however, substantially increase token
usage and per-request latency. Prior work has largely focused on reducing token
usage, often at the expense of accuracy, while overlooking other latency
factors. We present DUCHESS, an LLM serving system that reduces cost and
latency without sacrificing accuracy through intra-request branch orchestration
guided by predictions. DUCHESS employs a lightweight linear probing model over
LLM layer activations to estimate branch correctness, and its orchestration
policy decides whether to terminate, duplicate, or continue a branch. When
handling multiple requests, DUCHESS further reduces latency by prioritizing
easier reasoning tasks when complexity can be estimated from the prompt.
Experiments on three reasoning benchmarks show that DUCHESS consistently
improves the token-accuracy Pareto frontier, reducing token usage by 42-63% at
matched accuracy compared to self-consistency. In serving with vLLM, DUCHESS
reduces mean, median, and tail latencies by 57-81%, 58-85%, and 52-84% with
First-Come-First-Served scheduling, and achieves additional gains under
difficulty-aware scheduling at higher request rates.

AI.tldr: DUCHESS is an LLM serving system that reduces token usage and latency for reasoning tasks by intra-request branch orchestration guided by a lightweight predictor, achieving better token-accuracy trade-offs and lower latency under various scheduling policies.
AI.motivation: Inference-time reasoning (chain-of-thought, multi-branch) increases token usage and latency; prior work focuses on tokens at the expense of latency and overall efficiency. There is a need to optimize both tokens and latency in serving LLMs, especially under concurrent requests.
AI.method: DUCHESS uses a lightweight linear probing model over LLM layer activations to estimate branch correctness. An orchestration policy decides to terminate, duplicate, or continue a reasoning branch. For multi-request workloads, it prioritizes easier tasks by estimating complexity from prompts. Implemented in vLLM serving.
AI.result: DUCHESS consistently improves the token-accuracy Pareto frontier, reducing token usage by 42-63% at matched accuracy compared to self-consistency. In serving with vLLM, it reduces mean, median, and tail latencies by 57-81%, 58-85%, and 52-84% under First-Come-First-Served scheduling, with additional gains under difficulty-aware scheduling at higher request rates.
AI.conclusion: Intra-request branch orchestration guided by fast, lightweight predictions can significantly cut cost and latency without sacrificing accuracy, and adding difficulty-aware scheduling further boosts performance under load.

title: Diffusion Bridge or Flow Matching? A Unifying Framework and Comparative Analysis
summary:
Diffusion Bridge and Flow Matching have both demonstrated compelling
empirical performance in transformation between arbitrary distributions.
However, there remains confusion about which approach is generally preferable,
and the substantial discrepancies in their modeling assumptions and practical
implementations have hindered a unified theoretical account of their relative
merits. We have, for the first time, provided a unified theoretical and
experimental validation of these two models. We recast their frameworks through
the lens of Stochastic Optimal Control and prove that the cost function of the
Diffusion Bridge is lower, guiding the system toward more stable and natural
trajectories. Simultaneously, from the perspective of Optimal Transport,
interpolation coefficients $t$ and $1-t$ of Flow Matching become increasingly
ineffective when the training data size is reduced. To corroborate these
theoretical claims, we propose a novel, powerful architecture for Diffusion
Bridge built on a latent Transformer, and implement a Flow Matching model with
the same structure to enable a fair performance comparison in various
experiments. Comprehensive experiments are conducted across Image Inpainting,
Super-Resolution, Deblurring, Denoising, Translation, and Style Transfer tasks,
systematically varying both the distributional discrepancy (different
difficulty) and the training data size. Extensive empirical results align
perfectly with our theoretical predictions and allow us to delineate the
respective advantages and disadvantages of these two models. Our code is
available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/DBFM-3E8E/.

AI.tldr: A unified theory and experimental validation show Diffusion Bridge has a lower control cost and yields more stable trajectories, while Flow Matching becomes less effective with limited data. The authors introduce a latent Transformer-based Diffusion Bridge and a matching model with the same architecture for fair comparison, validating claims across multiple tasks and data regimes. Code is released.
AI.motivation: There is persistent confusion about which modeling paradigm—Diffusion Bridge or Flow Matching—is preferable, due to differing assumptions and implementations. A unified theoretical and empirical framework is needed to clarify relative merits across tasks and data regimes.
AI.method: Recast both models in the language of Stochastic Optimal Control and Optimal Transport. Prove that Diffusion Bridge minimizes a lower cost function. Analyze Flow Matching interpolation coefficients t and 1-t, showing diminishing effectiveness under smaller training data. Implement a latent Transformer-based Diffusion Bridge and a Flow Matching model with the same architecture to enable fair, head-to-head comparisons. Conduct comprehensive experiments across Image Inpainting, Super-Resolution, Deblurring, Denoising, Translation, and Style Transfer, varying distributional discrepancy and training data size.
AI.result: Theoretical claims are corroborated by extensive experiments. Diffusion Bridge exhibits a lower cost and more stable trajectories; Flow Matching coefficients lose effectiveness with smaller data; results align with predictions across tasks and data scales. The paper delineates pros and cons of each approach.
AI.conclusion: Provides a unified theoretical and empirical validation of Diffusion Bridge and Flow Matching, clarifying when each approach is preferable and enabling fair comparisons. The authors also release code for reproducibility.

title: Overlap-Adaptive Regularization for Conditional Average Treatment Effect Estimation
summary:
The conditional average treatment effect (CATE) is widely used in
personalized medicine to inform therapeutic decisions. However,
state-of-the-art methods for CATE estimation (so-called meta-learners) often
perform poorly in the presence of low overlap. In this work, we introduce a new
approach to tackle this issue and improve the performance of existing
meta-learners in the low-overlap regions. Specifically, we introduce
Overlap-Adaptive Regularization (OAR) that regularizes target models
proportionally to overlap weights so that, informally, the regularization is
higher in regions with low overlap. To the best of our knowledge, our OAR is
the first approach to leverage overlap weights in the regularization terms of
the meta-learners. Our OAR approach is flexible and works with any existing
CATE meta-learner: we demonstrate how OAR can be applied to both parametric and
non-parametric second-stage models. Furthermore, we propose debiased versions
of our OAR that preserve the Neyman-orthogonality of existing meta-learners and
thus ensure more robust inference. Through a series of (semi-)synthetic
experiments, we demonstrate that our OAR significantly improves CATE estimation
in low-overlap settings in comparison to constant regularization.

AI.tldr: Introduces Overlap-Adaptive Regularization (OAR) to improve CATE estimation under low overlap by weighting regularization with overlap; provides debiased variants that preserve Neyman orthogonality; shows improvements across meta-learners in (semi-)synthetic experiments.
AI.motivation: Low overlap in observational data leads to biased and high-variance CATE estimates with existing meta-learners. Existing regularization is uniform and does not exploit overlap information.
AI.method: Propose OAR that regularizes target models proportionally to overlap weights, making regularization stronger where overlap is low. Compatible with both parametric and non-parametric second-stage models; develops debiased versions that retain Neyman-orthogonality.
AI.result: OAR significantly improves CATE estimation in low-overlap settings compared to constant regularization, across various meta-learners, demonstrated via (semi-)synthetic experiments.
AI.conclusion: OAR is flexible and, purportedly, the first approach to leverage overlap weights in meta-learner regularization, enhancing estimation accuracy and enabling robust inference with debiased variants.

title: Foggy Crowd Counting: Combining Physical Priors and KAN-Graph
summary:
Aiming at the key challenges of crowd counting in foggy environments, such as
long-range target blurring, local feature degradation, and image contrast
attenuation, this paper proposes a crowd-counting method with a physical a
priori of atmospheric scattering, which improves crowd counting accuracy under
complex meteorological conditions through the synergistic optimization of the
physical mechanism and data-driven.Specifically, first, the method introduces a
differentiable atmospheric scattering model and employs transmittance dynamic
estimation and scattering parameter adaptive calibration techniques to
accurately quantify the nonlinear attenuation laws of haze on targets with
different depths of field.Secondly, the MSA-KAN was designed based on the
Kolmogorov-Arnold Representation Theorem to construct a learnable edge
activation function. By integrating a multi-layer progressive architecture with
adaptive skip connections, it significantly enhances the model's nonlinear
representation capability in feature-degraded regions, effectively suppressing
feature confusion under fog interference.Finally, we further propose a
weather-aware GCN that dynamically constructs spatial adjacency matrices using
deep features extracted by MSA-KAN. Experiments on four public datasets
demonstrate that our method achieves a 12.2\%-27.5\% reduction in MAE metrics
compared to mainstream algorithms in dense fog scenarios.

AI.tldr: A physics-informed crowd-counting method for foggy environments that integrates a differentiable atmospheric scattering model, a learnable edge-activation network (MSA-KAN) based on Kolmogorov-Arnold representation, and a weather-aware GCN to adapt to visibility conditions, yielding substantial MAE improvements (12.2%–27.5%) in dense fog.
AI.motivation: Foggy conditions cause long-range blurring, local feature degradation, and reduced contrast, severely harming crowd counting. A hybrid approach combining physical atmospheric modeling with data-driven learning can more accurately account for atmospheric effects and degraded features.
AI.method: 1) A differentiable atmospheric scattering model with dynamic transmittance estimation and adaptive calibration to capture depth-dependent haze attenuation. 2) MSA-KAN, a learnable edge-activation module grounded in the Kolmogorov-Arnold Representation Theorem, within a multi-layer progressive architecture with adaptive skip connections to enhance nonlinear representation in fog-degraded regions. 3) A weather-aware Graph Convolutional Network that builds spatial adjacency matrices from deep features produced by MSA-KAN to capture spatial dependencies under varying weather conditions.
AI.result: Experiments on four public datasets show a 12.2%–27.5% reduction in MAE compared with mainstream crowd-counting algorithms in dense fog scenarios.
AI.conclusion: A hybrid framework that fuses physical atmospheric modeling with data-driven learning improves crowd counting performance under fog, leveraging differentiable scattering, adaptive feature representations, and weather-aware spatial modeling.

title: Double Descent as a Lens for Sample Efficiency in Autoregressive vs. Discrete Diffusion Models
summary:
Data scarcity drives the need for more sample-efficient large language
models. In this work, we use the double descent phenomenon to holistically
compare the sample efficiency of discrete diffusion and autoregressive models.
We show that discrete diffusion models require larger capacity and more
training epochs to escape their underparameterized regime and reach the
interpolation threshold. In the strongly overparameterized regime, both models
exhibit similar behavior, with neither exhibiting a pronounced second descent
in test loss across a large range of model sizes. Overall, our results indicate
that autoregressive models are more sample-efficient on small-scale datasets,
while discrete diffusion models only become competitive when given sufficient
capacity and compute.

AI.tldr: Autoregressive models are more sample-efficient on small datasets; discrete diffusion models require larger capacity and more compute to catch up, and both plateau in the overparameterized regime with no clear second descent.
AI.motivation: To understand sample efficiency in data-scarce settings by directly comparing discrete diffusion and autoregressive models through the lens of the double descent phenomenon.
AI.method: Empirical comparison across model sizes and training budgets, tracking double descent curves for both models on small to moderate datasets. Examine underparameterized vs interpolation threshold and strongly overparameterized regimes, focusing on test loss behavior and the presence of any second descent.
AI.result: In the underparameterized regime, diffusion models need more capacity and longer training to reach interpolation; in the strongly overparameterized regime, both models behave similarly, with no pronounced second descent across a wide range of sizes. Overall, autoregressive models show greater sample efficiency on small datasets, while diffusion models only become competitive with sufficient capacity and compute.
AI.conclusion: For data-scarce scenarios, autoregressive models are the preferred baseline due to better sample efficiency; discrete diffusion models require ample capacity and compute to rival autoregressive performance, and neither shows a strong second descent when highly overparameterized.

title: NeMo: Needle in a Montage for Video-Language Understanding
summary:
Recent advances in video large language models (VideoLLMs) call for new
evaluation protocols and benchmarks for complex temporal reasoning in
video-language understanding. Inspired by the needle in a haystack test widely
used by LLMs, we introduce a novel task of Needle in a Montage (NeMo), designed
to assess VideoLLMs' critical reasoning capabilities, including long-context
recall and temporal grounding. To generate video question answering data for
our task, we develop a scalable automated data generation pipeline that
facilitates high-quality data synthesis. Built upon the proposed pipeline, we
present NeMoBench, a video-language benchmark centered on our task.
Specifically, our full set of NeMoBench features 31,378 automatically generated
question-answer (QA) pairs from 13,486 videos with various durations ranging
from seconds to hours. Experiments demonstrate that our pipeline can reliably
and automatically generate high-quality evaluation data, enabling NeMoBench to
be continuously updated with the latest videos. We evaluate 20 state-of-the-art
models on our benchmark, providing extensive results and key insights into
their capabilities and limitations. Our project page is available at:
https://lavi-lab.github.io/NeMoBench.

AI.tldr: NeMoBench is a scalable, automated benchmark for VideoLLMs built around the Needle in a Montage task to test long-context recall and temporal grounding, featuring 31k QA pairs from 13k videos; 20 models were evaluated, and the data pipeline supports continuous updates.
AI.motivation: There is a need for evaluation protocols that probe complex temporal reasoning in video-language models. Existing benchmarks struggle with long-context recall and precise temporal grounding, especially as VideoLLMs incorporate longer videos and richer reasoning.
AI.method: Develop a scalable automated data-generation pipeline that creates high-quality QA pairs for a Needle in a Montage task. Use this to construct NeMoBench with 31,378 QA pairs from 13,486 videos of varied durations. The pipeline enables automatic data synthesis and ongoing updates. Evaluate 20 state-of-the-art VideoLLMs on the benchmark.
AI.result: The data-generation pipeline reliably produces high-quality evaluation data and enables NeMoBench to be continuously updated with new videos. Comprehensive evaluation of 20 SOTA VideoLLMs yields insights into model capabilities and limitations.
AI.conclusion: NeMoBench provides a scalable, updatable benchmark for evaluating VideoLLMs on complex temporal reasoning tasks, highlighting strengths and gaps in current models and offering a framework for ongoing evaluation as video data evolves.

title: Random Policy Valuation is Enough for LLM Reasoning with Verifiable Rewards
summary:
RL with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has emerged as a promising paradigm for
improving the reasoning abilities of large language models (LLMs). Current
methods rely primarily on policy optimization frameworks like PPO and GRPO,
which follow generalized policy iteration that alternates between evaluating
the current policy's value and improving the policy based on evaluation. While
effective, they often suffer from training instability and diversity collapse,
requiring complex heuristic tricks and careful tuning. We observe that standard
RLVR in math reasoning can be formalized as a specialized finite-horizon Markov
Decision Process with deterministic state transitions, tree-structured
dynamics, and binary terminal rewards. Though large in scale, the underlying
structure is simpler than general-purpose control settings for which popular RL
algorithms (e.g., PPO) were developed, suggesting that several sophisticated
techniques in existing methods may be reduced or even omitted. Based on this
insight, we prove a surprising result: the optimal action can be recovered from
the Q-function of a fixed uniformly random policy, thereby bypassing the
generalized policy iteration loop and its associated heuristics. We introduce
Random Policy Valuation for Diverse Reasoning (ROVER) to translate this
principle into a practical and scalable algorithm for LLM math reasoning, a
minimalist yet highly effective RL method that samples actions from a softmax
over these uniform-policy Q-values. ROVER preserves diversity throughout
training, allowing sustained exploration of multiple valid pathways. Across
multiple base models and standard math reasoning benchmarks, ROVER demonstrates
superior performance in both \textbf{quality} (\textbf{+8.2} on pass@1,
\textbf{+16.8} on pass@256) and \textbf{diversity} (\textbf{+17.6\%}), despite
its radical simplification compared to strong, complicated existing methods.

AI.tldr: ROVER is a minimalist RL method for LLM math reasoning that uses Q-values from a fixed uniform policy to select actions, bypassing policy iteration, and yielding improvements in accuracy and diversity.
AI.motivation: Motivated by instability and diversity collapse in policy-optimization RL (PPO/GRPO); the math-reasoning RLVR setting maps to a finite-horizon, deterministic, tree-structured MDP with binary terminals, suggesting simpler algorithms may suffice.
