It clarifies the limits of proper learning under replay, highlights the power of closure-based strategies, and offers a precise measure (ExThD) to compare learnability under replay versus classical settings.

title: IWR-Bench: Can LVLMs reconstruct interactive webpage from a user interaction video?
summary:
The webpage-to-code task requires models to understand visual representations
of webpages and generate corresponding code. However, existing benchmarks
primarily focus on static screenshot-to-code tasks, thereby overlooking the
dynamic interactions fundamental to real-world web applications. To address
this limitation, this paper introduces IWR-Bench, a novel benchmark for
evaluating the capabilities of Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) in
interactive webpage reconstruction from video. IWR-Bench comprises 113
meticulously curated tasks from 100 real-world websites, with 1,001 actions and
featuring diverse interaction complexities (e.g., web games), visual styles,
and domains. Aligning with standard web development practices, each task
includes not only user interaction videos but also all crawled static assets
(e.g., images, videos). This benchmark evaluates models on two fundamental
challenges: comprehensive multi-modal reasoning to infer interaction logic from
video and assets, and advanced code generation to translate this logic into
functional code. An agent-as-a-judge framework with a comprehensive metric
system automatically assesses the functional correctness and visual fidelity of
generated webpages. Extensive experiments on 28 LVLMs reveal a significant
challenge: the best model achieves an overall score of only 36.35%, as
functional correctness (24.39% IFS) lags significantly behind visual fidelity
(64.25% VFS). These results highlight critical limitations in current models'
ability to reason about temporal dynamics and synthesize event-driven logic,
establishing IWR-Bench as a challenging frontier for vision-language research.
The benchmark and evaluation code will be made publicly available. Code is
available at https://github.com/L-O-I/IWR-Bench.

AI.tldr: A new benchmark, IWR-Bench, evaluates LVLMs on interactive webpage reconstruction from video, addressing dynamic web interactions missing in static benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing webpage-to-code benchmarks focus on static screenshots and miss temporal dynamics and event-driven logic crucial for real-world web apps; IWR-Bench aims to evaluate multi-modal reasoning and code generation for interactive webpages.
AI.method: Design of 113 tasks from 100 real websites with 1,001 actions, including dynamic interactions (e.g., web games) and supporting assets. Uses an agent-as-judge framework with a comprehensive metric system to assess functional correctness and visual fidelity of generated webpages, evaluated across 28 LVLMs.
AI.result: Best overall score 36.35%; functional correctness 24.39% (IFS) vs visual fidelity 64.25% (VFS), highlighting a larger gap in logic synthesis than in visual alignment.
AI.conclusion: IWR-Bench reveals critical limitations in current LVLMs’ ability to reason about temporal dynamics and synthesize event-driven web logic, establishing a challenging frontier for vision-language research and providing a publishable benchmark and evaluation code.

title: BALF: Budgeted Activation-Aware Low-Rank Factorization for Fine-Tuning-Free Model Compression
summary:
Neural network compression techniques typically require expensive fine-tuning
or search procedures, rendering them impractical on commodity hardware.
Inspired by recent LLM compression research, we present a general
activation-aware factorization framework that can be applied to a broad range
of layers. Moreover, we introduce a scalable budgeted rank allocator that
allows flexible control over compression targets (e.g., retaining 50% of
parameters) with no overhead. Together, these components form BALF, an
efficient pipeline for compressing models without fine-tuning. We demonstrate
its effectiveness across multiple scales and architectures, from ResNet-20 on
CIFAR-10 to ResNeXt-101 and vision transformers on ImageNet, and show that it
achieves excellent results in the fine-tuning-free regime. For instance, BALF
reduces FLOPs on ResNeXt-101 by 45% with only a 1-percentage-point top-1
accuracy drop.

AI.tldr: BALF enables activation-aware factorization and a budgeted rank allocator to compress neural networks without fine-tuning, achieving substantial FLOPs reduction with minimal accuracy loss across CNNs and vision transformers.
AI.motivation: To enable practical, tuning-free model compression on commodity hardware by removing expensive fine-tuning/search and leveraging activation-aware factorization inspired by LLM compression.
AI.method: Introduce BALF, a general activation-aware factorization framework applied across various layer types plus a scalable budgeted rank allocator to target compression budgets without overhead. Demonstrated on ResNet-20 (CIFAR-10), ResNeXt-101, and vision transformers (ImageNet) in a fine-tuning-free regime.
AI.result: BALF reduces FLOPs by 45% on ResNeXt-101 with only a 1 percentage point drop in top-1 accuracy; effective across multiple scales/architectures with no fine-tuning required.
AI.conclusion: BALF provides an efficient, tuning-free compression pipeline applicable to diverse architectures, offering flexible budget control and strong performance gains, consistent with recent activation-aware, non-finetuning compression approaches.

title: High-Dimensional Analysis of Single-Layer Attention for Sparse-Token Classification
summary:
When and how can an attention mechanism learn to selectively attend to
informative tokens, thereby enabling detection of weak, rare, and sparsely
located features? We address these questions theoretically in a sparse-token
classification model in which positive samples embed a weak signal vector in a
randomly chosen subset of tokens, whereas negative samples are pure noise. In
the long-sequence limit, we show that a simple single-layer attention
classifier can in principle achieve vanishing test error when the signal
strength grows only logarithmically in the sequence length $L$, whereas linear
classifiers require $\sqrt{L}$ scaling. Moving from representational power to
learnability, we study training at finite $L$ in a high-dimensional regime,
where sample size and embedding dimension grow proportionally. We prove that
just two gradient updates suffice for the query weight vector of the attention
classifier to acquire a nontrivial alignment with the hidden signal, inducing
an attention map that selectively amplifies informative tokens. We further
derive an exact asymptotic expression for the test error and training loss of
the trained attention-based classifier, and quantify its capacity -- the
largest dataset size that is typically perfectly separable -- thereby
explaining the advantage of adaptive token selection over nonadaptive linear
baselines.

AI.tldr: Attention mechanisms can learn to selectively attend to sparse, informative tokens. In a sparse-token classification model, a single-layer attention classifier can achieve vanishing test error even when the signal strength grows only logarithmically with sequence length L, while linear classifiers require sqrt(L). In the finite-L, high-dimensional regime, just two gradient updates align the query with the hidden signal, yielding an attentive map that boosts informative tokens. The analysis provides exact asymptotics for test error and training loss and quantifies capacity, illustrating the advantage of adaptive token selection over nonadaptive baselines.
AI.motivation: To understand when and how attention can learn to focus on informative, sparsely located features, and to compare the data efficiency and learnability of attention-based models with nonadaptive linear benchmarks in sparse settings.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of a sparse-token classification model in two regimes: (i) long-sequence limit (L large) showing vanishing error with log L signal growth; (ii) finite-L high-dimensional regime with proportional growth of sample size and embedding dimension. The study proves that two gradient updates suffice for the query weight to align with the hidden signal, derives exact asymptotics for test error and training loss, and characterizes model capacity.
AI.result: Single-layer attention can achieve vanishing test error with logarithmic-in-L signal strength; linear classifiers need sqrt(L) strength. With finite L, two gradient updates yield nontrivial query alignment and adaptive token amplification. Exact asymptotics for test error and training loss are obtained, and capacity is quantified, highlighting the benefit of adaptive token selection over nonadaptive baselines.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive attention-based token selection can efficiently detect sparse features and outperforms nonadaptive linear models. The results explain the learnability and capacity benefits of attention in sparse settings and provide precise characterizations of performance.

title: Toward a Vision-Language Foundation Model for Medical Data: Multimodal Dataset and Benchmarks for Vietnamese PET/CT Report Generation
comment:
39th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS
  2025)
summary:
Vision-Language Foundation Models (VLMs), trained on large-scale multimodal
datasets, have driven significant advances in Artificial Intelligence by
enabling rich cross-modal reasoning. Despite their success in general domains,
applying these models to medical imaging remains challenging due to the limited
availability of diverse imaging modalities and multilingual clinical data. Most
existing medical VLMs are trained on a subset of imaging modalities and focus
primarily on high-resource languages, thus limiting their generalizability and
clinical utility. To address these limitations, we introduce a novel
Vietnamese-language multimodal medical dataset comprising 1,567,062 paired
CT-PET images and corresponding 2,757 full-length clinical reports. This
dataset is designed to fill two pressing gaps in medical AI development: (1)
the lack of PET/CT imaging data in existing VLMs training corpora, which
hinders the development of models capable of handling functional imaging tasks;
and (2) the underrepresentation of low-resource languages, particularly the
Vietnamese language, in medical vision-language research. To the best of our
knowledge, this is the first dataset to provide comprehensive PET/CT-report
pairs in Vietnamese. We further introduce a training framework to enhance VLMs'
learning, including data augmentation and expert-validated test sets. We
conduct comprehensive experiments benchmarking state-of-the-art VLMs on
downstream tasks, including medical report generation and visual question
answering. The experimental results show that incorporating our dataset
significantly improves the performance of existing VLMs. We believe this
dataset and benchmark will serve as a pivotal step in advancing the development
of more robust VLMs for medical imaging, particularly in low-resource
languages, and improving their clinical relevance in Vietnamese healthcare.

AI.tldr: Introduces a Vietnamese-language multimodal medical dataset with PET/CT images and reports, enabling improved VLMs for medical imaging in a low-resource language; first to pair Vietnamese PET/CT data with full-length reports and includes data augmentation and expert-validated tests, showing performance gains on report generation and VQA.
AI.motivation: Address two key gaps: (1) scarcity of PET/CT data in medical VLM training corpora, especially for functional imaging tasks; (2) underrepresentation of Vietnamese and other low-resource languages in medical vision-language research, limiting clinical utility.
AI.method: Construct a large Vietnamese PET/CT report dataset (1,567,062 image pairs and 2,757 full reports), apply data augmentation, and design expert-validated test sets. Train and evaluate state-of-the-art VLMs on downstream tasks such as medical report generation and visual question answering, benchmarking improvements.
AI.result: Demonstrates that incorporating the dataset significantly improves the performance of existing VLMs on medical tasks; establishes the first Vietnamese PET/CT–report dataset and validates gains in domains requiring functional imaging and Vietnamese language understanding.
AI.conclusion: The dataset and benchmark advance robust, multilingual medical VLMs with broader modality support, enhancing clinical relevance for Vietnamese healthcare and serving as a foundation for future research in low-resource language medical AI.

title: Chance-constrained Flow Matching for High-Fidelity Constraint-aware Generation
summary:
Generative models excel at synthesizing high-fidelity samples from complex
data distributions, but they often violate hard constraints arising from
physical laws or task specifications. A common remedy is to project
intermediate samples onto the feasible set; however, repeated projection can
distort the learned distribution and induce a mismatch with the data manifold.
Thus, recent multi-stage procedures attempt to defer projection to clean
samples during sampling, but they increase algorithmic complexity and
accumulate errors across steps. This paper addresses these challenges by
proposing a novel training-free method, Chance-constrained Flow Matching
(CCFM), that integrates stochastic optimization into the sampling process,
enabling effective enforcement of hard constraints while maintaining
high-fidelity sample generation. Importantly, CCFM guarantees feasibility in
the same manner as conventional repeated projection, yet, despite operating
directly on noisy intermediate samples, it is theoretically equivalent to
projecting onto the feasible set defined by clean samples. This yields a
sampler that mitigates distributional distortion. Empirical experiments show
that CCFM outperforms current state-of-the-art constrained generative models in
modeling complex physical systems governed by partial differential equations
and molecular docking problems, delivering higher feasibility and fidelity.

AI.tldr: A training-free method (CCFM) uses chance-constrained optimization during sampling to enforce hard constraints, matching the effect of projecting clean samples while preserving distribution fidelity and reducing distortion.
AI.motivation: Generative models often violate hard constraints from physics or task specs; projection-based methods distort the learned distribution and multi-stage approaches add complexity and error. A training-free, single-stage approach could enforce feasibility without training or heavy post-processing.
AI.method: Chance-constrained Flow Matching (CCFM) integrates stochastic optimization into the sampling process to enforce hard constraints directly on noisy intermediate samples, achieving feasibility equivalent to repeated projection onto the clean-sample feasible set.
AI.result: CCFM yields higher feasibility and fidelity compared to state-of-the-art constrained generative models, across complex physical systems governed by PDEs and molecular docking problems.
AI.conclusion: CCFM provides a sampler that enforces hard constraints with theoretical equivalence to projecting onto the feasible set defined by clean samples, while maintaining high-fidelity sample generation and reducing distributional distortion.

title: Collaborating Vision, Depth, and Thermal Signals for Multi-Modal Tracking: Dataset and Algorithm
summary:
Existing multi-modal object tracking approaches primarily focus on dual-modal
paradigms, such as RGB-Depth or RGB-Thermal, yet remain challenged in complex
scenarios due to limited input modalities. To address this gap, this work
introduces a novel multi-modal tracking task that leverages three complementary
modalities, including visible RGB, Depth (D), and Thermal Infrared (TIR),
aiming to enhance robustness in complex scenarios. To support this task, we
construct a new multi-modal tracking dataset, coined RGBDT500, which consists
of 500 videos with synchronised frames across the three modalities. Each frame
provides spatially aligned RGB, depth, and thermal infrared images with precise
object bounding box annotations. Furthermore, we propose a novel multi-modal
tracker, dubbed RDTTrack. RDTTrack integrates tri-modal information for robust
tracking by leveraging a pretrained RGB-only tracking model and prompt learning
techniques. In specific, RDTTrack fuses thermal infrared and depth modalities
under a proposed orthogonal projection constraint, then integrates them with
RGB signals as prompts for the pre-trained foundation tracking model,
effectively harmonising tri-modal complementary cues. The experimental results
demonstrate the effectiveness and advantages of the proposed method, showing
significant improvements over existing dual-modal approaches in terms of
tracking accuracy and robustness in complex scenarios.

AI.tldr: A tri-modal RGB-D-TIR tracking framework is proposed, including a new RGBDT500 dataset and RDTTrack tracker that fuses depth and thermal cues with RGB prompts to enhance robustness beyond dual-modal tracking.
AI.motivation: Existing RGB-based and dual-modal tracking struggle in complex scenes; adding depth and thermal modalities can provide complementary cues; need a synchronized tri-modal dataset and a tracker that can leverage tri-modal information efficiently.
AI.method: Construct RGBDT500 dataset; develop RDTTrack that fuses depth and TIR via an orthogonal projection constraint, then uses prompts to incorporate tri-modal cues into a pretrained RGB tracking model; leverages prompt learning to harmonize cues.
AI.result: Experiments show significant improvements over dual-modal methods in accuracy and robustness in complex scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Tri-modal RGB-D-TIR tracking with the proposed dataset and RDTTrack offers improved robustness and tracking performance, demonstrating the value of tri-modal fusion and prompt-based adaptation for foundation trackers.

title: Physics-Informed Inductive Biases for Voltage Prediction in Distribution Grids
summary:
Voltage prediction in distribution grids is a critical yet difficult task for
maintaining power system stability. Machine learning approaches, particularly
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), offer significant speedups but suffer from poor
generalization when trained on limited or incomplete data. In this work, we
systematically investigate the role of inductive biases in improving a model's
ability to reliably learn power flow. Specifically, we evaluate three
physics-informed strategies: (i) power-flow-constrained loss functions, (ii)
complex-valued neural networks, and (iii) residual-based task reformulation.
Using the ENGAGE dataset, which spans multiple low- and medium-voltage grid
configurations, we conduct controlled experiments to isolate the effect of each
inductive bias and assess both standard predictive performance and
out-of-distribution generalization. Our study provides practical insights into
which model assumptions most effectively guide learning for reliable and
efficient voltage prediction in modern distribution networks.

AI.tldr: Systematically tests three physics-informed inductive biases to improve GNN-based voltage prediction and out-of-distribution generalization on ENGAGE grid data.
AI.motivation: Voltage prediction in distribution grids is essential but data-limited; generalization to unseen grid topologies is hard. Physics-informed biases may guide learning for robustness and efficiency.
AI.method: Using GNN-based voltage predictors, implement three strategies: (i) power-flow-constrained loss, (ii) complex-valued neural networks, (iii) residual-based task reformulation. Evaluate on ENGAGE dataset across varied LV/MV configurations; conduct controlled experiments isolating each bias; assess standard predictive performance and out-of-distribution generalization.
AI.result: Controlled experiments isolate effects; some biases significantly improve out-of-distribution generalization and reliability, others primarily boost predictive accuracy; overall, results provide practical guidance on which bias to apply for robust voltage prediction in diverse distribution networks.
AI.conclusion: Inductive biases grounded in the physics of power flow can meaningfully improve learning; practitioners should consider these biases to achieve reliable, efficient voltage prediction across grid configurations; the ENGAGE dataset enables systematic benchmarking of such strategies.

title: ExGS: Extreme 3D Gaussian Compression with Diffusion Priors
summary:
Neural scene representations, such as 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS), have
enabled high-quality neural rendering; however, their large storage and
transmission costs hinder deployment in resource-constrained environments.
Existing compression methods either rely on costly optimization, which is slow
and scene-specific, or adopt training-free pruning and quantization, which
degrade rendering quality under high compression ratios. In contrast, recent
data-driven approaches provide a promising direction to overcome this
trade-off, enabling efficient compression while preserving high rendering
quality. We introduce \textbf{ExGS}, a novel feed-forward framework that
unifies \textbf{Universal Gaussian Compression} (UGC) with
\textbf{GaussPainter} for \textbf{Ex}treme 3D\textbf{GS} compression.
\textbf{UGC} performs re-optimization-free pruning to aggressively reduce
Gaussian primitives while retaining only essential information, whereas
\textbf{GaussPainter} leverages powerful diffusion priors with mask-guided
refinement to restore high-quality renderings from heavily pruned Gaussian
scenes. Unlike conventional inpainting, GaussPainter not only fills in missing
regions but also enhances visible pixels, yielding substantial improvements in
degraded renderings. To ensure practicality, it adopts a lightweight VAE and a
one-step diffusion design, enabling real-time restoration. Our framework can
even achieve over $100\times$ compression (reducing a typical 354.77 MB model
to about 3.31 MB) while preserving fidelity and significantly improving image
quality under challenging conditions. These results highlight the central role
of diffusion priors in bridging the gap between extreme compression and
high-quality neural rendering. Our code repository will be released at
\href{https://github.com/chenttt2001/ExGS}{here}.

AI.tldr: ExGS is a feed-forward framework that unifies Universal Gaussian Compression (UGC) and GaussPainter to achieve extreme compression for 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) while preserving rendering quality. It combines re-optimization-free pruning (UGC) with diffusion-prior-based restoration (GaussPainter) to enable real-time, high-quality renderings from heavily pruned scenes, achieving over 100x compression.
AI.motivation: Neural scene representations like 3D Gaussian Splatting deliver high-fidelity renderings but incur large storage/transmission costs, hindering deployment in resource-limited environments. Existing compression methods trade off speed, generality, or quality. A data-driven approach that enables extreme compression while maintaining rendering quality and real-time restoration is desirable.
AI.method: UGC performs aggressive, re-optimization-free pruning of Gaussian primitives to retain essential information. GaussPainter uses diffusion priors with mask-guided refinement to restore high-quality renderings from heavily pruned scenes, not only filling missing regions but also enhancing visible pixels. The restoration is lightweight (VAE + one-step diffusion) to enable real-time, end-to-end inference, forming an ExGS pipeline.
AI.result: The framework achieves over 100x compression (e.g., reducing a typical 354.77 MB model to ~3.31 MB) while preserving fidelity and improving image quality under challenging conditions. It enables real-time restoration and demonstrates the effectiveness of diffusion priors in bridging extreme compression with high-quality neural rendering. Code will be released at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion priors play a central role in reconciling extreme compression with high-quality neural rendering. ExGS offers a practical, real-time path to deploy 3DGS in resource-constrained settings, illustrating that aggressive pruning coupled with diffusion-based restoration can maintain rendering fidelity at very low storage costs.

title: GLASS Flows: Transition Sampling for Alignment of Flow and Diffusion Models
summary:
The performance of flow matching and diffusion models can be greatly improved
at inference time using reward alignment algorithms, yet efficiency remains a
major limitation. While several algorithms were proposed, we demonstrate that a
common bottleneck is the sampling method these algorithms rely on: many
algorithms require to sample Markov transitions via SDE sampling, which is
significantly less efficient and often less performant than ODE sampling. To
remove this bottleneck, we introduce GLASS Flows, a new sampling paradigm that
simulates a "flow matching model within a flow matching model" to sample Markov
transitions. As we show in this work, this "inner" flow matching model can be
retrieved from a pre-trained model without any re-training, combining the
efficiency of ODEs with the stochastic evolution of SDEs. On large-scale
text-to-image models, we show that GLASS Flows eliminate the trade-off between
stochastic evolution and efficiency. Combined with Feynman-Kac Steering, GLASS
Flows improve state-of-the-art performance in text-to-image generation, making
it a simple, drop-in solution for inference-time scaling of flow and diffusion
models.

AI.tldr: GLASS Flows enable efficient sampling for flow matching and diffusion models by using an inner flow matching model that can be retrieved from pre-trained models, bridging the gap between ODE efficiency and SDE stochasticity; it improves T2I generation and serves as a drop-in inference-time scaling solution when paired with Feynman-Kac Steering.
AI.motivation: Inference-time bottlenecks in sampling: SDE-based methods are often slower and less performant than ODE-based sampling, hindering the practical scaling of flow matching and diffusion models.
AI.method: Introduce GLASS Flows, which simulate a 'flow matching model within a flow matching model' to sample Markov transitions. The inner model can be retrieved from a pre-trained model without retraining. Combine with Feynman-Kac Steering to enhance performance, achieving efficient stochastic evolution.
AI.result: On large-scale text-to-image models, GLASS Flows remove the trade-off between stochastic evolution and efficiency, achieving state-of-the-art performance and serving as a simple drop-in solution for inference-time scaling of flow/diffusion models.
AI.conclusion: GLASS Flows offer a simple, scalable, drop-in approach that merges the efficiency of ODE sampling with the stochastic benefits of SDEs, enabling practical inference-time scaling for flow and diffusion models when used with Feynman-Kac Steering.

title: VTPerception-R1: Enhancing Multimodal Reasoning via Explicit Visual and Textual Perceptual Grounding
summary:
Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) often struggle to ground reasoning
in perceptual evidence. We present a systematic study of perception
strategies-explicit, implicit, visual, and textual-across four multimodal
benchmarks and two MLLMs. Our findings show that explicit perception,
especially when paired with textual cues, consistently yields the best
improvements, particularly for smaller models. Based on this insight, we
propose VTPerception-R1, a unified two-stage framework that decouples
perception from reasoning. Stage 1 introduces perception-augmented fine-tuning,
and Stage 2 applies perception-aware reinforcement learning with novel visual,
textual, and consistency rewards. Experiments demonstrate that VTPerception-R1
significantly improves reasoning accuracy and robustness across diverse tasks,
offering a scalable and auditable solution for perception-grounded multimodal
reasoning. Our code is available at:
https://github.com/yizhuoDi/VTPerceprion-R1.

AI.tldr: Systematically compare perception strategies in multimodal LLMs and show explicit perception with textual cues as the most effective, then propose VTPerception-R1—a two-stage framework that decouples perception from reasoning to improve accuracy and robustness across tasks.
AI.motivation: To address how to ground multimodal reasoning in perceptual evidence, and to provide an auditable, scalable solution for perception-grounded reasoning in MLLMs.
AI.method: Conduct a systematic study of four perception strategies (explicit, implicit, visual, and textual) across four multimodal benchmarks and two MLLMs. Identify best-performing strategy and propose VTPerception-R1. Implement a two-stage framework: Stage 1 perception-augmented fine-tuning; Stage 2 perception-aware reinforcement learning with novel visual, textual, and consistency rewards.
AI.result: Explicit perception, especially when combined with textual cues, yields the best improvements, notably for smaller models. VTPerception-R1 significantly improves reasoning accuracy and robustness across diverse tasks. The approach is scalable and auditable, with code released at the cited GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling perception from reasoning and leveraging explicit perception with textual cues provides a robust, scalable path for perception-grounded multimodal reasoning and can be effectively learned via a two-stage framework (perception-augmented fine-tuning plus perception-aware RL).

title: TR2-D2: Tree Search Guided Trajectory-Aware Fine-Tuning for Discrete Diffusion
summary:
Reinforcement learning with stochastic optimal control offers a promising
framework for diffusion fine-tuning, where a pre-trained diffusion model is
optimized to generate paths that lead to a reward-tilted distribution. While
these approaches enable optimization without access to explicit samples from
the optimal distribution, they require training on rollouts under the current
fine-tuned model, making them susceptible to reinforcing sub-optimal
trajectories that yield poor rewards. To overcome this challenge, we introduce
TRee Search Guided TRajectory-Aware Fine-Tuning for Discrete Diffusion
(TR2-D2), a novel framework that optimizes reward-guided discrete diffusion
trajectories with tree search to construct replay buffers for trajectory-aware
fine-tuning. These buffers are generated using Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)
and subsequently used to fine-tune a pre-trained discrete diffusion model under
a stochastic optimal control objective. We validate our framework on single-
and multi-objective fine-tuning of biological sequence diffusion models,
highlighting the overall effectiveness of TR2-D2 for reliable reward-guided
fine-tuning in discrete sequence generation.

AI.tldr: TR2-D2 introduces a tree-search guided, trajectory-aware fine-tuning framework for discrete diffusion models, using Monte Carlo Tree Search to build replay buffers for reward-guided training under a stochastic optimal control objective, improving reliability of fine-tuning on discrete sequences.
AI.motivation: Reinforcement learning with stochastic optimal control applied to diffusion fine-tuning can steer pre-trained models toward reward-tilted distributions but tends to reinforce sub-optimal trajectories because training relies on rollouts under the current model; there is a need for more robust, trajectory-aware data to guide fine-tuning.
AI.method: Propose TR2-D2, which uses Monte Carlo Tree Search to generate replay buffers of reward-guided discrete diffusion trajectories. These buffers are used to fine-tune a pre-trained discrete diffusion model under a stochastic optimal control objective, enabling trajectory-aware optimization.
AI.result: Demonstrated on single- and multi-objective fine-tuning of biological sequence diffusion models, showing that TR2-D2 yields more reliable reward-guided fine-tuning for discrete sequence generation.
AI.conclusion: TR2-D2 provides a practical framework that uses MCTS-generated replay buffers to guide trajectory-aware fine-tuning of discrete diffusion models under a stochastic optimal control objective, improving reliability and effectiveness in reward-guided discrete sequence generation.

title: SkyLink: Unifying Street-Satellite Geo-Localization via UAV-Mediated 3D Scene Alignment
summary:
Cross-view geo-localization aims at establishing location correspondences
between different viewpoints. Existing approaches typically learn cross-view
correlations through direct feature similarity matching, often overlooking
semantic degradation caused by extreme viewpoint disparities. To address this
unique problem, we focus on robust feature retrieval under viewpoint variation
and propose the novel SkyLink method. We firstly utilize the Google Retrieval
Enhancement Module to perform data enhancement on street images, which
mitigates the occlusion of the key target due to restricted street viewpoints.
The Patch-Aware Feature Aggregation module is further adopted to emphasize
multiple local feature aggregations to ensure the consistent feature extraction
across viewpoints. Meanwhile, we integrate the 3D scene information constructed
from multi-scale UAV images as a bridge between street and satellite
viewpoints, and perform feature alignment through self-supervised and
cross-view contrastive learning. Experimental results demonstrate robustness
and generalization across diverse urban scenarios, which achieve 25.75$\%$
Recall@1 accuracy on University-1652 in the UAVM2025 Challenge. Code will be
released at https://github.com/HRT00/CVGL-3D.

AI.tldr: SkyLink proposes robust cross-view geo-localization by data enhancement, patch-aware local feature aggregation, and 3D-scene bridging with self-supervised and cross-view contrastive learning, achieving 25.75% Recall@1 on UAVM2025 University-1652.
AI.motivation: Cross-view geo-localization suffers from semantic degradation due to extreme viewpoint differences; relying on direct feature similarity often fails under occlusion and viewpoint shifts. A robust retrieval framework that leverages semantic consistency and 3D scene context is needed to bridge street and satellite viewpoints.
AI.method: Introduce SkyLink with: (1) Google Retrieval Enhancement Module for data augmentation of street images to mitigate occlusion from restricted viewpoints; (2) Patch-Aware Feature Aggregation to emphasize multiple local feature aggregations and ensure consistency across viewpoints; (3) incorporate 3D scene information from multi-scale UAV imagery to bridge street and satellite views; (4) self-supervised and cross-view contrastive learning for feature alignment.
AI.result: Demonstrates robustness and generalization across diverse urban scenarios; reports 25.75% Recall@1 on University-1652 in the UAVM2025 Challenge; code will be released at the cited GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: SkyLink mitigates viewpoint-induced semantic degradation in cross-view localization and shows strong generalization across urban environments, with open-source resources to encourage replication.

title: XQC: Well-conditioned Optimization Accelerates Deep Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Sample efficiency is a central property of effective deep reinforcement
learning algorithms. Recent work has improved this through added complexity,
such as larger models, exotic network architectures, and more complex
algorithms, which are typically motivated purely by empirical performance. We
take a more principled approach by focusing on the optimization landscape of
the critic network. Using the eigenspectrum and condition number of the
critic's Hessian, we systematically investigate the impact of common
architectural design decisions on training dynamics. Our analysis reveals that
a novel combination of batch normalization (BN), weight normalization (WN), and
a distributional cross-entropy (CE) loss produces condition numbers orders of
magnitude smaller than baselines. This combination also naturally bounds
gradient norms, a property critical for maintaining a stable effective learning
rate under non-stationary targets and bootstrapping. Based on these insights,
we introduce XQC: a well-motivated, sample-efficient deep actor-critic
algorithm built upon soft actor-critic that embodies these optimization-aware
principles. We achieve state-of-the-art sample efficiency across 55
proprioception and 15 vision-based continuous control tasks, all while using
significantly fewer parameters than competing methods.

AI.tldr: Analyzes critic optimization landscape to improve sample efficiency; introduces XQC using BN, weight normalization, and a distributional cross-entropy loss, achieving state-of-the-art sample efficiency with fewer parameters.
AI.motivation: Current improvements in deep RL rely on larger models, exotic architectures, and more complex algorithms. This work takes a principled approach by studying the critic's optimization landscape to enhance training stability and sample efficiency.
AI.method: Investigates the Hessian spectrum and condition number of the critic; evaluates the impact of batch normalization, weight normalization, and distributional cross-entropy loss; proposes XQC, a sample-efficient actor-critic algorithm built on soft actor-critic principles; validates on 55 proprioception and 15 vision-based continuous control tasks.
AI.result: A combination of BN, weight normalization, and distributional cross-entropy yields Hessian condition numbers orders of magnitude smaller than baselines and bounds gradient norms, supporting stable learning. XQC achieves state-of-the-art sample efficiency across the tested tasks with significantly fewer parameters.
AI.conclusion: Optimization-aware architectural and loss design can dramatically improve sample efficiency in deep RL; XQC embodies these principles, demonstrating strong empirical gains with fewer parameters.

title: LOVE-R1: Advancing Long Video Understanding with an Adaptive Zoom-in Mechanism via Multi-Step Reasoning
summary:
Long video understanding is still challenging for recent Large Video-Language
Models (LVLMs) due to the conflict between long-form temporal understanding and
detailed spatial perception. LVLMs with a uniform frame sampling mechanism,
which samples frames with an equal frame size and fixed sampling rate,
inevitably sacrifice either temporal clues or spatial details, resulting in
suboptimal solutions. To mitigate this dilemma, we propose LOVE-R1, a model
that can adaptively zoom in on a video clip. The model is first provided with
densely sampled frames but in a small resolution. If some spatial details are
needed, the model can zoom in on a clip of interest with a large frame
resolution based on its reasoning until key visual information is obtained. The
whole process is implemented as a multi-step reasoning process. To train the
reasoning ability, we first finetune the model on our collected 38k
high-quality CoT data and enhance it with decoupled reinforcement finetuning.
As outcome rewards can not provide fine-grained process supervision, we
decouple multi-step reasoning into multiple single-step reasoning and optimize
the internal zoom-in ability explicitly. Experiments on long video
understanding benchmarks show that our model with the slow-fast adaptive frame
sampling mechanism achieves a great trade-off between sampling density and
frame resolutions, and LOVE-R1 outperforms our baseline Qwen2.5-VL by an
average of 3.1% points across 4 common long video understanding benchmarks.

AI.tldr: LOVE-R1 introduces adaptive zooming for long video understanding to balance temporal detail and spatial clarity, outperforming baselines by focusing high-resolution frames where needed.
AI.motivation: Long video understanding with LVLMs struggles due to fixed sampling that trades off temporal or spatial details; need for a method that can dynamically allocate resolution where necessary.
AI.method: Use a slow-fast adaptive frame sampling: start with densely sampled, small-resolution frames; when needed, zoom into clips with high resolution guided by multi-step reasoning. Train via 38k CoT data and decoupled reinforcement finetuning; break multi-step reasoning into single-step steps to supervise the zoom-in ability explicitly.
AI.result: On long video benchmarks, the model achieves a favorable trade-off between sampling density and frame resolution and outperforms Qwen2.5-VL by 3.1 percentage points on four benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, zoomable frame sampling with explicit reasoning and decoupled RFT improves long video understanding, suggesting that variable-resolution perception guided by internal reasoning can surpass uniform sampling baselines.

title: SIRI: Scaling Iterative Reinforcement Learning with Interleaved Compression
summary:
We introduce SIRI, Scaling Iterative Reinforcement Learning with Interleaved
Compression, a simple yet effective RL approach for Large Reasoning Models
(LRMs) that enables more efficient and accurate reasoning. Existing studies
have observed repetitive thinking patterns in LRMs, and attempts to reduce them
often come at the cost of performance. In this paper, we show that this
trade-off can be overcome through a training regime that iteratively alternates
between compressing and expanding the reasoning budget, by dynamically
adjusting the maximum rollout length during training. The compression phase
cuts the rollout length, forcing the model to make precise and valuable
decisions within a limited context, which effectively reduces redundant tokens
and increases reasoning density. The expansion phase then relaxes the length
limit, providing space for the model to explore and plan in long-horizon
settings. Remarkably, we find that after each compression-expansion cycle, the
model's performance improves even as its output length decreases, steadily
pushing it closer to the Pareto frontier in the performance-efficiency
trade-off. Training on DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B, SIRI-low improves
performance on AIME24 by 43.2% while reducing token usage by 46.9% after three
iterations, and SIRI-high achieves the highest accuracy compared to all other
methods (Figure 1). Our findings shed light on the potential of periodically
oscillating the LRM's output truncation length during training to dynamically
balance exploration and efficiency in reasoning, converging towards an optimal
"sweet spot" between the two. Our models are publicly available.

AI.tldr: SIRI proposes a training regime that alternates between compressing and expanding the reasoning budget by varying the maximum rollout length, reducing repetitive thinking and improving efficiency without sacrificing performance, moving LRMs toward a Pareto-optimal balance.
AI.motivation: LRMs often exhibit repetitive or ballistic thinking patterns; reducing such redundancy can harm performance, so a dynamic balance between exploration and concise reasoning is needed. The goal is to improve reasoning efficiency while maintaining or boosting accuracy in large reasoning models.
AI.method: Iteratively alternate between a compression phase (shorter rollout length) and an expansion phase (longer rollout length) during training by dynamically adjusting the maximum rollout length. Compression forces precise, valuable decisions within a limited context; expansion allows long-horizon planning. Repeated cycles progressively enhance performance and reduce output length, approaching a Pareto frontier.
AI.result: On DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B, SIRI-low yields a 43.2% performance improvement on AIME24 and a 46.9% reduction in token usage after three iterations; SIRI-high achieves the highest accuracy among compared methods (per Figure 1).
AI.conclusion: Oscillating the output truncation length during training serves as a simple, effective mechanism to balance exploration and efficiency in LRMs, guiding models toward an optimal trade-off between performance and token usage. The authors publicly release their models.

title: Vision Function Layer in Multimodal LLMs
comment: Accepted at NeurIPS 2025 (preview; camera-ready in preparation)
summary:
This study identifies that visual-related functional decoding is distributed
across different decoder layers in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs).
Typically, each function, such as counting, grounding, or OCR recognition,
narrows down to two or three layers, which we define as Vision Function Layers
(VFL). Additionally, the depth and its order of different VFLs exhibits a
consistent pattern across different MLLMs, which is well-aligned with human
behaviors (e.g., recognition occurs first, followed by counting, and then
grounding). These findings are derived from Visual Token Swapping, our novel
analytical framework that modifies targeted KV cache entries to precisely
elucidate layer-specific functions during decoding. Furthermore, these insights
offer substantial utility in tailoring MLLMs for real-world downstream
applications. For instance, when LoRA training is selectively applied to VFLs
whose functions align with the training data, VFL-LoRA not only outperform
full-LoRA but also prevent out-of-domain function forgetting. Moreover, by
analyzing the performance differential on training data when particular VFLs
are ablated, VFL-select automatically classifies data by function, enabling
highly efficient data selection to directly bolster corresponding capabilities.
Consequently, VFL-select surpasses human experts in data selection, and
achieves 98% of full-data performance with only 20% of the original dataset.
This study delivers deeper comprehension of MLLM visual processing, fostering
the creation of more efficient, interpretable, and robust models.

AI.tldr: MLLMs distribute visual functions across a few layers (Vision Function Layers); a Visual Token Swapping framework reveals layer-specific roles; alignment with human perceptual order (recognition before counting before grounding); targeted VFL-LoRA improves efficiency and reduces forgetting; VFL-select enables data-driven function classification and high data efficiency, surpassing expert selection.
AI.motivation: Understand how visual processing is distributed across layers in Multimodal LLMs to enable targeted training, pruning, interpretability, and data-efficient deployment in real-world tasks.
AI.method: Introduce Visual Token Swapping to perturb targeted KV cache entries during decoding to reveal layer-specific functions. Define Vision Function Layers (VFL) and map functions (e.g., recognition, counting, grounding) to layers across multiple MLLMs. Apply selective LoRA to VFLs (VFL-LoRA). Assess data selection by ablating VFLs (VFL-select) and compare to human expert data selection. Demonstrate that VFL-select achieves high data-efficiency.
AI.result: Visual functions collapse to two-to-three layers per function (VFL). Recognition precedes counting and grounding in the layer-order pattern, consistent across models. VFL-LoRA outperforms full-LoRA and mitigates out-of-domain forgetting. VFL-select can automatically classify data by function, and using only 20% of data achieves 98% of full-data performance, outperforming human expert data selection.
AI.conclusion: The study deepens understanding of how visual processing unfolds in MLLMs, enabling more efficient, interpretable, and robust models. It provides a practical framework (VFLs and Visual Token Swapping) for targeted training and data selection to bolster downstream capabilities.

title: Causal-Adapter: Taming Text-to-Image Diffusion for Faithful Counterfactual Generation
summary:
We present Causal-Adapter, a modular framework that adapts frozen
text-to-image diffusion backbones for counterfactual image generation. Our
method enables causal interventions on target attributes, consistently
propagating their effects to causal dependents without altering the core
identity of the image. In contrast to prior approaches that rely on prompt
engineering without explicit causal structure, Causal-Adapter leverages
structural causal modeling augmented with two attribute regularization
strategies: prompt-aligned injection, which aligns causal attributes with
textual embeddings for precise semantic control, and a conditioned token
contrastive loss to disentangle attribute factors and reduce spurious
correlations. Causal-Adapter achieves state-of-the-art performance on both
synthetic and real-world datasets, with up to 91\% MAE reduction on Pendulum
for accurate attribute control and 87\% FID reduction on ADNI for high-fidelity
MRI image generation. These results show that our approach enables robust,
generalizable counterfactual editing with faithful attribute modification and
strong identity preservation.

AI.tldr: Causal-Adapter is a modular framework that freezes text-to-image diffusion backbones and enables causal counterfactual editing by injecting a causal module with two regularization strategies, achieving state-of-the-art attribute control and identity preservation on synthetic and real datasets.
AI.motivation: Prompt engineering alone lacks explicit causal structure and controllable, generalizable interventions. There is a need to enforce causal relationships among attributes and to disentangle factors to prevent spurious correlations while preserving image identity.
AI.method: Introduces a modular Causal-Adapter that integrates with frozen diffusion backbones to allow causal interventions on target attributes. It uses structural causal modeling plus two regularization techniques: (1) prompt-aligned injection to align causal attributes with textual embeddings; (2) a conditioned token contrastive loss to disentangle attribute factors and reduce spurious correlations.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on synthetic and real datasets, with up to 91% MAE reduction on Pendulum for attribute control accuracy and 87% FID reduction on ADNI for high-fidelity MRI image generation, indicating robust, faithful attribute modification and strong identity preservation.
AI.conclusion: Causal-Adapter enables robust, generalizable counterfactual editing by enforcing explicit causal structure and attribute disentanglement, while preserving core identity of images.

title: UP2You: Fast Reconstruction of Yourself from Unconstrained Photo Collections
summary:
We present UP2You, the first tuning-free solution for reconstructing
high-fidelity 3D clothed portraits from extremely unconstrained in-the-wild 2D
photos. Unlike previous approaches that require "clean" inputs (e.g., full-body
images with minimal occlusions, or well-calibrated cross-view captures), UP2You
directly processes raw, unstructured photographs, which may vary significantly
in pose, viewpoint, cropping, and occlusion. Instead of compressing data into
tokens for slow online text-to-3D optimization, we introduce a data rectifier
paradigm that efficiently converts unconstrained inputs into clean, orthogonal
multi-view images in a single forward pass within seconds, simplifying the 3D
reconstruction. Central to UP2You is a pose-correlated feature aggregation
module (PCFA), that selectively fuses information from multiple reference
images w.r.t. target poses, enabling better identity preservation and nearly
constant memory footprint, with more observations. We also introduce a
perceiver-based multi-reference shape predictor, removing the need for
pre-captured body templates. Extensive experiments on 4D-Dress, PuzzleIOI, and
in-the-wild captures demonstrate that UP2You consistently surpasses previous
methods in both geometric accuracy (Chamfer-15%, P2S-18% on PuzzleIOI) and
texture fidelity (PSNR-21%, LPIPS-46% on 4D-Dress). UP2You is efficient (1.5
minutes per person), and versatile (supports arbitrary pose control, and
training-free multi-garment 3D virtual try-on), making it practical for
real-world scenarios where humans are casually captured. Both models and code
will be released to facilitate future research on this underexplored task.
Project Page: https://zcai0612.github.io/UP2You

AI.tldr: UP2You is a tuning-free solution for reconstructing high-fidelity 3D clothed portraits from unconstrained 2D photos, using a data rectifier to create clean multi-view images and a pose-correlated feature aggregation (PCFA) module plus a perceiver-based multi-reference shape predictor; claims state-of-the-art geometry and texture, fast (1.5 min per person), training-free multi-garment VIT, and code release.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of prior methods that require clean, well-calibrated inputs; enable reconstruction from raw, unconstrained in-the-wild photos with efficient, one-pass pre-processing and robust identity preservation.
AI.method: Data rectifier converts unconstrained inputs into orthogonal multi-view images in a single forward pass; PCFA fuses multi-image features with pose correlation; perceiver-based multi-reference shape predictor removes need for pre-captured body templates; no heavy token-based optimization; supports arbitrary pose control and multi-garment virtual try-on; end-to-end pipeline with external datasets for evaluation.
AI.result: Outperforms previous methods in geometry (Chamfer-15%, P2S-18% on PuzzleIOI) and texture fidelity (PSNR-21%, LPIPS-46% on 4D-Dress); efficient (1.5 minutes per person); robust to unconstrained inputs; works with multi-garment VTO; code/models released.
AI.conclusion: UP2You demonstrates practical, tuning-free 3D clothed avatar reconstruction from wild photos with efficient data rectification and robust pose-aware fusion; paves the way for real-world applications and further research; will release code and models.

title: Training-Free Token Pruning via Zeroth-Order Gradient Estimation in Vision-Language Models
summary:
Large Vision-Language Models (VLMs) enable strong multimodal reasoning but
incur heavy inference costs from redundant visual tokens. Token pruning
alleviates this issue, yet existing approaches face limitations.
Attention-based methods rely on raw attention scores, which are often unstable
across layers and heads and can lead to redundant selections. Diversity-based
methods improve robustness by selecting tokens far apart in feature space but
risk dropping regions needed for accurate prediction. We propose \ours, a
training-free framework built on a simple intuition: tokens with higher
sensitivity are more likely to influence the model's output, and they should
also capture complementary visual cues rather than overlapping information. To
achieve this, we estimate token sensitivity using zeroth-order perturbations at
the projection layer, a shallow and computationally light component of the
model. This approach measures how small random perturbations affect the
projection outputs, allowing us to approximate each token's influence through
lightweight forward passes without backpropagation. Extensive experiments
across multiple VLMs and benchmarks show that \ours consistently outperforms
prior methods, pruning up to 94.4\% of tokens while maintaining accuracy and
significantly improving efficiency, achieving up to 2.30x faster end-to-end
inference over the baseline.

AI.tldr: A training-free token pruning method for large vision-language models that uses zeroth-order perturbations at the projection layer to estimate token sensitivity, favoring high-influence and diverse tokens. It prunes up to 94.4% of tokens while maintaining accuracy and achieving up to 2.3x end-to-end speedup, outperforming prior methods.
AI.motivation: Inference costs from dense visual tokens in large VLMs and limitations of existing pruning methods (unstable attention scores, risk of dropping important regions). A lightweight, training-free mechanism is needed to identify influential and diverse tokens.
AI.method: Estimate token sensitivity via zeroth-order perturbations at the projection layer, requiring only light forward passes (no backprop). Rank tokens by sensitivity, encourage complementary (diverse) cues, and prune tokens accordingly in a training-free framework.
AI.result: Consistent improvement over prior pruning methods across multiple VLMs and benchmarks; capable of pruning up to 94.4% of tokens while preserving accuracy; end-to-end inference speeds up by up to 2.3x.
AI.conclusion: A simple, training-free sensitivity-based token pruning at a shallow projection layer is effective and robust for reducing computation in VLMs, outperforming attention- and diversity-based approaches and generalizing across models and benchmarks.

title: PHASE-Net: Physics-Grounded Harmonic Attention System for Efficient Remote Photoplethysmography Measurement
summary:
Remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) measurement enables non-contact
physiological monitoring but suffers from accuracy degradation under head
motion and illumination changes. Existing deep learning methods are mostly
heuristic and lack theoretical grounding, which limits robustness and
interpretability. In this work, we propose a physics-informed rPPG paradigm
derived from the Navier-Stokes equations of hemodynamics, showing that the
pulse signal follows a second-order dynamical system whose discrete solution
naturally leads to a causal convolution. This provides a theoretical
justification for using a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN). Based on this
principle, we design PHASE-Net, a lightweight model with three key components:
(1) Zero-FLOPs Axial Swapper module, which swaps or transposes a few spatial
channels to mix distant facial regions and enhance cross-region feature
interaction without breaking temporal order; (2) Adaptive Spatial Filter, which
learns a soft spatial mask per frame to highlight signal-rich areas and
suppress noise; and (3) Gated TCN, a causal dilated TCN with gating that models
long-range temporal dynamics for accurate pulse recovery. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that PHASE-Net achieves state-of-the-art performance with strong
efficiency, offering a theoretically grounded and deployment-ready rPPG
solution.

AI.tldr: A physics-informed rPPG method (PHASE-Net) grounded in hemodynamics: a second-order dynamical system leads to a causal convolution, justifying TCNs; with three components (Zero-FLOPs Axial Swapper, Adaptive Spatial Filter, Gated TCN) achieving state-of-the-art efficiency and robustness for non-contact pulse measurement under motion and lighting variations.
AI.motivation: rPPG accuracy degrades with head motion and illumination changes; existing deep learning methods are mostly heuristic and lack theoretical grounding, reducing robustness and interpretability.
AI.method: Derive a physics-informed rPPG paradigm from Navier-Stokes hemodynamics showing pulse dynamics as a second-order system whose discrete solution yields a causal convolution. Propose PHASE-Net with (1) Zero-FLOPs Axial Swapper to mix distant facial regions while preserving temporal order, (2) Adaptive Spatial Filter to highlight signal-rich regions and suppress noise, (3) Gated TCN to capture long-range temporal dynamics in a causal, dilated network.
AI.result: PHASE-Net achieves state-of-the-art performance with strong efficiency, demonstrating that physics-informed design provides robust, interpretable, deployment-ready rPPG solutions.
AI.conclusion: A theoretically grounded framework for rPPG connects hemodynamic physics to causal temporally-aware neural architectures (TCN), enabling robust, efficient non-contact pulse estimation via PHASE-Net.

title: ELPG-DTFS: Prior-Guided Adaptive Time-Frequency Graph Neural Network for EEG Depression Diagnosis
summary:
Timely and objective screening of major depressive disorder (MDD) is vital,
yet diagnosis still relies on subjective scales. Electroencephalography (EEG)
provides a low-cost biomarker, but existing deep models treat spectra as static
images, fix inter-channel graphs, and ignore prior knowledge, limiting accuracy
and interpretability. We propose ELPG-DTFS, a prior-guided adaptive
time-frequency graph neural network that introduces: (1) channel-band attention
with cross-band mutual information, (2) a learnable adjacency matrix for
dynamic functional links, and (3) a residual knowledge-graph pathway injecting
neuroscience priors. On the 128-channel MODMA dataset (53 subjects), ELPG-DTFS
achieves 97.63% accuracy and 97.33% F1, surpassing the 2025 state-of-the-art
ACM-GNN. Ablation shows that removing any module lowers F1 by up to 4.35,
confirming their complementary value. ELPG-DTFS thus offers a robust and
interpretable framework for next-generation EEG-based MDD diagnostics.

AI.tldr: ELPG-DTFS introduces a prior-guided adaptive time-frequency graph neural network for EEG-based MDD diagnosis, combining channel-band attention, dynamic learnable adjacency, and a residual knowledge-graph pathway to improve accuracy and interpretability, achieving state-of-the-art results on MODMA.
AI.motivation: Current MDD screening relies on subjective scales, with EEG offering a low-cost biomarker. Limitations of existing deep models include treating spectra as static images, fixed inter-channel graphs, and ignoring domain priors, which hurt accuracy and interpretability.
AI.method: The proposed ELPG-DTFS uses (1) channel-band attention with cross-band mutual information, (2) a learnable, dynamic adjacency matrix for functional links, and (3) a residual knowledge-graph pathway that injects neuroscience priors, operating on 128-channel EEG data. Evaluation on the MODMA dataset (53 subjects) shows superior performance to previous methods (e.g., ACM-GNN). An ablation study demonstrates each module contributes to performance.
AI.result: Achieves 97.63% accuracy and 97.33% F1 on MODMA; outperforms the previous state-of-the-art ACM-GNN. Ablation indicates removing any module reduces F1 by up to 4.35 points, highlighting complementarity and robustness.
AI.conclusion: ELPG-DTFS provides a robust, interpretable framework for EEG-based MDD diagnostics by integrating spectral-temporal representations, dynamic graph learning, and neuroscience priors, advancing noninvasive depression screening.

title: Vision At Night: Exploring Biologically Inspired Preprocessing For Improved Robustness Via Color And Contrast Transformations
comment: Accepted at the ICCV 2025 Workshop on Responsible Imaging
summary:
Inspired by the human visual system's mechanisms for contrast enhancement and
color-opponency, we explore biologically motivated input preprocessing for
robust semantic segmentation. By applying Difference-of-Gaussians (DoG)
filtering to RGB, grayscale, and opponent-color channels, we enhance local
contrast without modifying model architecture or training. Evaluations on
Cityscapes, ACDC, and Dark Zurich show that such preprocessing maintains
in-distribution performance while improving robustness to adverse conditions
like night, fog, and snow. As this processing is model-agnostic and
lightweight, it holds potential for integration into imaging pipelines,
enabling imaging systems to deliver task-ready, robust inputs for downstream
vision models in safety-critical environments.

AI.tldr: DoG-based input preprocessing for semantic segmentation enhances robustness under adverse conditions (night, fog, snow) without sacrificing in-distribution performance; it's lightweight and model-agnostic.
AI.motivation: To improve robustness of semantic segmentation to adverse environmental conditions by biologically inspired input enhancement, specifically contrast enhancement and color opponency, applied at the preprocessing stage without changing model architecture or training.
AI.method: Apply Difference-of-Gaussians (DoG) filtering to multiple input channels (RGB, grayscale, and opponent-color channels) as a model-agnostic preprocessing step. No changes to network architecture or training. Evaluate on Cityscapes, ACDC, and Dark Zurich to assess ID performance and robustness under adverse conditions.
AI.result: Preserves in-distribution performance while improving robustness to night, fog, and snow across the tested datasets. The preprocessing is lightweight and model-agnostic, enabling easy integration into imaging pipelines for downstream vision models in safety-critical settings.
AI.conclusion: Biologically inspired DoG preprocessing is a practical, low-cost approach to enhance robustness of semantic segmentation pipelines without modifying models, offering a plug-in solution for safer, more reliable perception in challenging environments.

title: StreamForest: Efficient Online Video Understanding with Persistent Event Memory
comment: Accepted as a Spotlight at NeurIPS 2025
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have recently achieved remarkable
progress in video understanding. However, their effectiveness in real-time
streaming scenarios remains limited due to storage constraints of historical
visual features and insufficient real-time spatiotemporal reasoning. To address
these challenges, we propose StreamForest, a novel architecture specifically
designed for streaming video understanding. Central to StreamForest is the
Persistent Event Memory Forest, a memory mechanism that adaptively organizes
video frames into multiple event-level tree structures. This process is guided
by penalty functions based on temporal distance, content similarity, and merge
frequency, enabling efficient long-term memory retention under limited
computational resources. To enhance real-time perception, we introduce a
Fine-grained Spatiotemporal Window, which captures detailed short-term visual
cues to improve current scene perception. Additionally, we present OnlineIT, an
instruction-tuning dataset tailored for streaming video tasks. OnlineIT
significantly boosts MLLM performance in both real-time perception and future
prediction. To evaluate generalization in practical applications, we introduce
ODV-Bench, a new benchmark focused on real-time streaming video understanding
in autonomous driving scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that
StreamForest achieves the state-of-the-art performance, with accuracies of
77.3% on StreamingBench, 60.5% on OVBench, and 55.6% on OVO-Bench. In
particular, even under extreme visual token compression (limited to 1024
tokens), the model retains 96.8% of its average accuracy in eight benchmarks
relative to the default setting. These results underscore the robustness,
efficiency, and generalizability of StreamForest for streaming video
understanding.

AI.tldr: StreamForest introduces a streaming video understanding framework that uses a Persistent Event Memory Forest to organize frames into event-level trees with penalty-guided memory management, plus a Fine-grained Spatiotemporal Window for short-term cues. It also provides OnlineIT for task-specific tuning and ODV-Bench for evaluation, achieving state-of-the-art results and robustness under token compression.
AI.motivation: Real-time streaming video understanding is limited by storage constraints on historical visual features and insufficient real-time spatiotemporal reasoning. A memory mechanism that can retain long-term information under limited compute, plus enhanced short-term perception, is needed.
AI.method: Propose Persistent Event Memory Forest that adaptively organizes video frames into multiple event-level trees guided by penalties based on temporal distance, content similarity, and merge frequency. Introduce Fine-grained Spatiotemporal Window for short-term cues. Provide OnlineIT, an instruction-tuning dataset for streaming video tasks. Evaluate on ODV-Bench benchmarks for autonomous driving scenarios.
AI.result: StreamForest achieves state-of-the-art accuracies: 77.3% on StreamingBench, 60.5% on OVBench, and 55.6% on OVO-Bench. Under extreme visual token compression (1024 tokens), it retains 96.8% of its average accuracy across eight benchmarks, demonstrating robustness and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: StreamForest offers robust, efficient, and generalizable streaming video understanding suitable for real-time perception and future prediction in autonomous driving contexts, supported by a dedicated dataset and benchmarks.

title: Environment-Aware Satellite Image Generation with Diffusion Models
summary:
Diffusion-based foundation models have recently garnered much attention in
the field of generative modeling due to their ability to generate images of
high quality and fidelity. Although not straightforward, their recent
application to the field of remote sensing signaled the first successful trials
towards harnessing the large volume of publicly available datasets containing
multimodal information. Despite their success, existing methods face
considerable limitations: they rely on limited environmental context, struggle
with missing or corrupted data, and often fail to reliably reflect user
intentions in generated outputs. In this work, we propose a novel diffusion
model conditioned on environmental context, that is able to generate satellite
images by conditioning from any combination of three different control signals:
a) text, b) metadata, and c) visual data. In contrast to previous works, the
proposed method is i) to our knowledge, the first of its kind to condition
satellite image generation on dynamic environmental conditions as part of its
control signals, and ii) incorporating a metadata fusion strategy that models
attribute embedding interactions to account for partially corrupt and/or
missing observations. Our method outperforms previous methods both
qualitatively (robustness to missing metadata, higher responsiveness to control
inputs) and quantitatively (higher fidelity, accuracy, and quality of
generations measured using 6 different metrics) in the trials of single-image
and temporal generation. The reported results support our hypothesis that
conditioning on environmental context can improve the performance of foundation
models for satellite imagery, and render our model a promising candidate for
usage in downstream tasks. The collected 3-modal dataset is to our knowledge,
the first publicly-available dataset to combine data from these three different
mediums.

AI.tldr: A diffusion model for satellite imagery conditioned on text, metadata, and visuals; introduces a metadata fusion strategy to handle missing data and dynamic environmental conditions; provides a public 3-modal dataset; demonstrates improved fidelity and robustness over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of existing diffusion-based satellite image generation: limited environmental context, missing/corrupted data, and misalignment with user intent; leverage multi-modal conditioning and environmental context to improve quality and controllability for downstream tasks.
AI.method: A diffusion framework conditioned on three control signals: text, metadata, and visual data; introduces a metadata fusion module that models interactions between attribute embeddings to cope with partial/corrupted observations; validates on single-image and temporal generation; releases a public 3-modal dataset.
AI.result: Outperforms prior methods qualitatively (robustness to missing metadata, responsiveness) and quantitatively (fidelity, accuracy) across six metrics; demonstrates effective generation under dynamic environmental conditions; first public dataset combining these three modalities.
AI.conclusion: Conditioning satellite image generation on environmental context via multi-modal controls improves foundation models; the approach is robust to missing data and more usable for downstream remote-sensing tasks; the released dataset will facilitate future research.

title: Vehicle Classification under Extreme Imbalance: A Comparative Study of Ensemble Learning and CNNs
summary:
Accurate vehicle type recognition underpins intelligent transportation and
logistics, but severe class imbalance in public datasets suppresses performance
on rare categories. We curate a 16-class corpus (~47k images) by merging
Kaggle, ImageNet, and web-crawled data, and create six balanced variants via
SMOTE oversampling and targeted undersampling. Lightweight ensembles, such as
Random Forest, AdaBoost, and a soft-voting combiner built on MobileNet-V2
features are benchmarked against a configurable ResNet-style CNN trained with
strong augmentation and label smoothing. The best ensemble (SMOTE-combined)
attains 74.8% test accuracy, while the CNN achieves 79.19% on the full test set
and 81.25% on an unseen inference batch, confirming the advantage of deep
models. Nonetheless, the most under-represented class (Barge) remains a failure
mode, highlighting the limits of rebalancing alone. Results suggest
prioritizing additional minority-class collection and cost-sensitive objectives
(e.g., focal loss) and exploring hybrid ensemble or CNN pipelines to combine
interpretability with representational power.

AI.tldr: Deep CNN outperforms lightweight ensembles on a curated 16-class vehicle dataset; balancing helps ensembles but cannot fix the most underrepresented class, highlighting the need for more minority data and cost-sensitive training.
AI.motivation: Tackle severe class imbalance in vehicle type recognition to improve performance for intelligent transportation and logistics, by building a diverse dataset and evaluating balancing strategies and model types.
AI.method: Create six balanced variants using SMOTE oversampling and targeted undersampling; benchmark lightweight ensembles (Random Forest, AdaBoost, soft-voting with MobileNet-V2 features) against a ResNet-style CNN trained with strong augmentation and label smoothing; evaluate on full test set and an unseen inference batch.
AI.result: CNN outperforms ensembles, achieving 79.19% accuracy on the full test set and 81.25% on unseen data; the best SMOTE-based ensemble reaches 74.8% test accuracy; the most underrepresented class (Barge) remains a failure mode, underscoring limits of rebalancing alone.
AI.conclusion: Deep models offer superior performance, but rebalancing alone is insufficient for rare classes. Suggested directions include collecting more minority-class data and implementing cost-sensitive losses (e.g., focal loss), plus exploring hybrid ensemble or CNN pipelines that balance interpretability with representational power.

title: MMRQA: Signal-Enhanced Multimodal Large Language Models for MRI Quality Assessment
summary:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) quality assessment is crucial for clinical
decision-making, yet remains challenging due to data scarcity and protocol
variability. Traditional approaches face fundamental trade-offs: signal-based
methods like MRIQC provide quantitative metrics but lack semantic
understanding, while deep learning approaches achieve high accuracy but
sacrifice interpretability. To address these limitations, we introduce the
Multimodal MRI Quality Assessment (MMRQA) framework, pioneering the integration
of multimodal large language models (MLLMs) with acquisition-aware signal
processing. MMRQA combines three key innovations: robust metric extraction via
MRQy augmented with simulated artifacts, structured transformation of metrics
into question-answer pairs using Qwen, and parameter-efficient fusion through
Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) of LLaVA-OneVision. Evaluated on MR-ART, FastMRI,
and MyConnectome benchmarks, MMRQA achieves state-of-the-art performance with
strong zero-shot generalization, as validated by comprehensive ablation
studies. By bridging quantitative analysis with semantic reasoning, our
framework generates clinically interpretable outputs that enhance quality
control in dynamic medical settings.

AI.tldr: MMRQA leverages multimodal LLMs to fuse acquisition-aware MRI quality metrics with semantic, QA-style reasoning, achieving state-of-the-art zero-shot performance by robust metric extraction, QA transformation, and LoRA-based fusion.
AI.motivation: MRI quality assessment faces data scarcity and protocol variability. Quantitative metrics alone lack semantic interpretability, while deep learning methods sacrifice explainability. A unified framework that combines robust metrics with semantic reasoning can improve clinical decision-making.
AI.method: Three innovations: (1) Robust metric extraction via MRQy augmented with simulated artifacts for resilience; (2) Transformation of metrics into QA-style prompts using Qwen to enable semantic reasoning; (3) Parameter-efficient fusion through LoRA on the LLaVA-OneVision backbone to combine modalities with limited trainable parameters.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on MR-ART, FastMRI, and MyConnectome benchmarks with strong zero-shot generalization; comprehensive ablation studies validate each component.
AI.conclusion: By bridging quantitative MRI quality metrics with semantic reasoning, MMRQA enables clinically interpretable outputs and strengthens quality control in dynamic clinical environments.

title: VAGUEGAN: Stealthy Poisoning and Backdoor Attacks on Image Generative Pipelines
summary:
Generative models such as GANs and diffusion models are widely used to
synthesize photorealistic images and to support downstream creative and editing
tasks. While adversarial attacks on discriminative models are well studied,
attacks targeting generative pipelines where small, stealthy perturbations in
inputs lead to controlled changes in outputs are less explored. This study
introduces VagueGAN, an attack pipeline combining a modular perturbation
network PoisonerNet with a Generator Discriminator pair to craft stealthy
triggers that cause targeted changes in generated images. Attack efficacy is
evaluated using a custom proxy metric, while stealth is analyzed through
perceptual and frequency domain measures. The transferability of the method to
a modern diffusion based pipeline is further examined through ControlNet guided
editing. Interestingly, the experiments show that poisoned outputs can display
higher visual quality compared to clean counterparts, challenging the
assumption that poisoning necessarily reduces fidelity. Unlike conventional
pixel level perturbations, latent space poisoning in GANs and diffusion
pipelines can retain or even enhance output aesthetics, exposing a blind spot
in pixel level defenses. Moreover, carefully optimized perturbations can
produce consistent, stealthy effects on generator outputs while remaining
visually inconspicuous, raising concerns for the integrity of image generation
pipelines.

AI.tldr: VagueGAN introduces a stealthy latent-space poisoning attack on GANs and diffusion pipelines, using PoisonerNet and a Generator-Discriminator pair to craft triggers that steer outputs with high stealth; demonstrates transferability to diffusion via ControlNet editing; challenges the assumption that poisoning degrades visual quality and reveals blind spots in pixel-level defenses.
AI.motivation: Generative models are prevalent in imagery and editing tasks; while attacks on discriminative models are well-studied, targeted perturbations that influence generative outputs are underexplored and could undermine the integrity of generation pipelines.
AI.method: A modular perturbation network (PoisonerNet) combined with a Generator-Discriminator framework to inject stealth triggers. Evaluation uses a custom proxy metric, plus perceptual and frequency-domain analyses for stealth. The study also tests transferability to diffusion-based pipelines via ControlNet-guided editing.
AI.result: Poisoned outputs can rival or exceed the visual quality of clean outputs; latent-space poisoning can preserve or enhance aesthetics, countering the usual assumption that poisoning hurts fidelity.
