Attacks yield consistent, stealthy effects on generator outputs and can transfer to diffusion-based workflows.
AI.conclusion: Latent-space poisoning reveals blind spots in pixel-level defenses and threatens the integrity of image-generation pipelines; defenses should address latent-space perturbations and consider detection mechanisms beyond pixel-level analysis; raises broader safety and integrity concerns for GANs and diffusion-based editing systems.

title: DWGS: Enhancing Sparse-View Gaussian Splatting with Hybrid-Loss Depth Estimation and Bidirectional Warping
summary:
Novel View Synthesis (NVS) from sparse views remains a core challenge in 3D
reconstruction, typically suffering from overfitting, geometric distortion, and
incomplete scene recovery due to limited multi-view constraints. Although 3D
Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) enables real-time, high-fidelity rendering, it
suffers from floating artifacts and structural inconsistencies under
sparse-input settings. To address these issues, we propose DWGS, a novel
unified framework that enhances 3DGS for sparse-view synthesis by integrating
robust structural cues, virtual view constraints, and occluded region
completion. Our approach introduces three principal contributions: a
Hybrid-Loss Depth Estimation module that leverages dense matching priors with
reprojection, point propagation, and smoothness constraints to enforce
multi-view consistency; a Bidirectional Warping Virtual View Synthesis method
generates virtual training views to impose stronger geometric and photometric
constraints; and an Occlusion-Aware Reconstruction component that utilizes
depth-difference mask and a learning-based inpainting model to recover obscured
regions. Extensive experiments on standard benchmarks (LLFF, Blender, and DTU)
show that DWGS achieves a new state-of-the-art, achieving up to 21.13 dB PSNR
and 0.189 LPIPS, while retaining real-time inference capabilities.

AI.tldr: DWGS is a unified framework that enhances 3D Gaussian Splatting for sparse-view novel view synthesis by adding depth-estimation with multi-view consistency, virtual-view constraints, and occlusion-aware reconstruction, achieving state-of-the-art results on LLFF, Blender, and DTU while maintaining real-time rendering.
AI.motivation: Sparse-view NVS suffers from overfitting, geometric distortion, and incomplete scene recovery due to limited multi-view constraints; 3D Gaussian Splatting is fast but prone to floating artifacts and inconsistencies under sparse inputs. A unified approach that leverages robust structural cues, virtual views, and occlusion handling can improve fidelity and completeness.
AI.method: 1) Hybrid-Loss Depth Estimation: combines dense matching priors with reprojection, point propagation, and smoothness to enforce multi-view consistency. 2) Bidirectional Warping Virtual View Synthesis: generates virtual training views to impose stronger geometric and photometric constraints. 3) Occlusion-Aware Reconstruction: uses a depth-difference mask and a learning-based inpainting model to recover obscured regions.
AI.result: On standard benchmarks LLFF, Blender, and DTU, DWGS achieves state-of-the-art performance, up to 21.13 dB PSNR and 0.189 LPIPS, while preserving real-time inference capabilities.
AI.conclusion: DWGS effectively enhances 3DGS for sparse-view synthesis by integrating robust structural cues, virtual view constraints, and occlusion-aware reconstruction, addressing artifacts and inconsistencies to enable robust, real-time NVS.

title: DAM: Dual Active Learning with Multimodal Foundation Model for Source-Free Domain Adaptation
summary:
Source-free active domain adaptation (SFADA) enhances knowledge transfer from
a source model to an unlabeled target domain using limited manual labels
selected via active learning. While recent domain adaptation studies have
introduced Vision-and-Language (ViL) models to improve pseudo-label quality or
feature alignment, they often treat ViL-based and data supervision as separate
sources, lacking effective fusion. To overcome this limitation, we propose Dual
Active learning with Multimodal (DAM) foundation model, a novel framework that
integrates multimodal supervision from a ViL model to complement sparse human
annotations, thereby forming a dual supervisory signal. DAM initializes stable
ViL-guided targets and employs a bidirectional distillation mechanism to foster
mutual knowledge exchange between the target model and the dual supervisions
during iterative adaptation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DAM
consistently outperforms existing methods and sets a new state-of-the-art
across multiple SFADA benchmarks and active learning strategies.

AI.tldr: DAM: a dual supervision framework for SFADA that fuses ViL-based multimodal guidance with sparse human labels via bidirectional distillation, achieving state-of-the-art results across SFADA benchmarks.
AI.motivation: SFADA relies on limited manual labels; existing approaches treat ViL guidance and data supervision separately, underutilizing their complementary strengths. There is a need to effectively fuse multimodal supervision to improve pseudo-label quality and feature alignment in unlabeled target domains.
AI.method: DAM initializes stable ViL-guided targets and uses bidirectional distillation between the target model and the dual supervisions (ViL guidance and human labels) during iterative adaptation. The process leverages active learning to select a small labeled subset and integrates multimodal supervision to guide learning in a source-free setting.
AI.result: DAM consistently outperforms existing SFADA methods and achieves new state-of-the-art performance across multiple SFADA benchmarks and active learning strategies.
AI.conclusion: Integrating multimodal supervision from a ViL foundation model with sparse human annotations via bidirectional distillation provides an effective dual supervision signal, enabling more accurate and robust source-free active domain adaptation.

title: Accurate Cobb Angle Estimation via SVD-Based Curve Detection and Vertebral Wedging Quantification
summary:
Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) is a common spinal deformity affecting
approximately 2.2% of boys and 4.8% of girls worldwide. The Cobb angle serves
as the gold standard for AIS severity assessment, yet traditional manual
measurements suffer from significant observer variability, compromising
diagnostic accuracy. Despite prior automation attempts, existing methods use
simplified spinal models and predetermined curve patterns that fail to address
clinical complexity. We present a novel deep learning framework for AIS
assessment that simultaneously predicts both superior and inferior endplate
angles with corresponding midpoint coordinates for each vertebra, preserving
the anatomical reality of vertebral wedging in progressive AIS. Our approach
combines an HRNet backbone with Swin-Transformer modules and biomechanically
informed constraints for enhanced feature extraction. We employ Singular Value
Decomposition (SVD) to analyze angle predictions directly from vertebral
morphology, enabling flexible detection of diverse scoliosis patterns without
predefined curve assumptions. Using 630 full-spine anteroposterior radiographs
from patients aged 10-18 years with rigorous dual-rater annotation, our method
achieved 83.45% diagnostic accuracy and 2.55{\deg} mean absolute error. The
framework demonstrates exceptional generalization capability on
out-of-distribution cases. Additionally, we introduce the Vertebral Wedging
Index (VWI), a novel metric quantifying vertebral deformation. Longitudinal
analysis revealed VWI's significant prognostic correlation with curve
progression while traditional Cobb angles showed no correlation, providing
robust support for early AIS detection, personalized treatment planning, and
progression monitoring.

AI.tldr: A deep-learning AIS assessment framework that predicts both superior and inferior endplate angles with vertebral midpoint coordinates, using an HRNet backbone fused with Swin-Transformer modules and SVD-based angle extraction. Introduces Vertebral Wedging Index (VWI). On 630 AP radiographs, achieves 83.45% diagnostic accuracy and 2.55° mean absolute error, with good generalization to out-of-distribution cases and prognostic relevance for progression.
AI.motivation: AIS assessment suffers from significant observer variability in Cobb angle measurements. There is a need for automated, anatomically faithful analysis that can handle diverse curve patterns without relying on predefined scoliosis models.
AI.method: A hybrid deep learning framework: HRNet backbone with Swin-Transformer modules and biomechanically informed constraints to extract vertebral features. SVD is used to analyze angle predictions directly from vertebral morphology, enabling flexible detection of diverse scoliosis patterns without predefined curve assumptions. Output includes superior/inferior endplate angles and vertebral midpoint coordinates per vertebra, plus a novel Vertebral Wedging Index (VWI). Dataset of 630 full-spine AP radiographs from patients aged 10–18 with rigorous dual-rater annotations. Evaluation includes diagnostic accuracy, mean absolute error of angle predictions, and longitudinal analysis of VWI versus progression.
AI.result: The model achieved 83.45% diagnostic accuracy and 2.55-degree MAE. It generalizes well to out-of-distribution cases. VWI shows significant prognostic correlation with curve progression, whereas Cobb angles did not.
AI.conclusion: The framework enables early AIS detection, personalized treatment planning, and progression monitoring. VWI provides a robust, anatomically grounded metric of vertebral deformation with prognostic value, supporting improved clinical decision-making.

title: Attention Surgery: An Efficient Recipe to Linearize Your Video Diffusion Transformer
summary:
Transformer-based video diffusion models (VDMs) deliver state-of-the-art
video generation quality but are constrained by the quadratic cost of
self-attention, making long sequences and high resolutions computationally
expensive. While linear attention offers sub-quadratic complexity, prior
attempts fail to match the expressiveness of softmax attention without costly
retraining. We introduce \textit{Attention Surgery}, an efficient framework for
\textit{linearizing} or \textit{hybridizing} attention in pretrained VDMs
without training from scratch. Inspired by recent advances in language models,
our method combines a novel hybrid attention mechanism-mixing softmax and
linear tokens-with a lightweight distillation and fine-tuning pipeline
requiring only a few GPU-days. Additionally, we incorporate a cost-aware
block-rate strategy to balance expressiveness and efficiency across layers.
Applied to Wan2.1 1.3B, a state-of-the-art DiT-based VDM, Attention Surgery
achieves the first competitive sub-quadratic attention video diffusion models,
reducing attention cost by up to 40\% in terms of FLOPs, while maintaining
generation quality as measured on the standard VBench and VBench-2.0
benchmarks.

AI.tldr: Attention Surgery enables sub-quadratic attention in pretrained video diffusion models via a hybrid softmax-linear mechanism and distillation, reducing FLOPs by up to 40% while preserving quality.
AI.motivation: Quadratic complexity of self-attention in transformer-based VDMs hinders long sequences/high resolutions; linear attention reduces cost but often sacrifices expressiveness and requires retraining. There is a need to adapt pretrained models efficiently without full retraining.
AI.method: Introduce a novel hybrid attention mechanism that mixes softmax and linear tokens (Attention Surgery), plus a lightweight distillation and fine-tuning pipeline that requires only a few GPU-days. Includes a cost-aware block-rate strategy to balance expressiveness and efficiency across layers. Applied to Wan2.1 1.3B DiT-based VDM.
AI.result: Achieves the first competitive sub-quadratic attention video diffusion models: up to 40% reduction in attention FLOPs, while maintaining generation quality on standard benchmarks VBench and VBench-2.0.
AI.conclusion: Efficiently converts pretrained VDMs to sub-quadratic attention without full retraining, enabling scalable video generation with preserved quality; the approach can generalize to other pretrained diffusion models.

title: OpenGPT-4o-Image: A Comprehensive Dataset for Advanced Image Generation and Editing
summary:
The performance of unified multimodal models for image generation and editing
is fundamentally constrained by the quality and comprehensiveness of their
training data. While existing datasets have covered basic tasks like style
transfer and simple object manipulation, they often lack the systematic
structure and challenging scenarios required for real-world applications. To
address this bottleneck, we introduce OpenGPT-4o-Image, a large-scale dataset
constructed using a novel methodology that combines hierarchical task taxonomy
with automated data generation. Our taxonomy not only includes fundamental
capabilities such as text rendering and style control but also introduces
highly practical yet challenging categories like scientific imagery for
chemistry illustrations and complex instruction editing requiring simultaneous
execution of multiple operations. Through an automated pipeline leveraging
structured resource pools and GPT-4o, we generate 80k high-quality
instruction-image pairs with controlled diversity, covering 11 major domains
and 51 subtasks. Extensive experiments show that fine-tuning leading models on
our dataset achieves significant performance gains across multiple benchmarks,
with improvements of up to 18\% on editing tasks (UniWorld-V1 on ImgEdit-Bench)
and 13% on generation tasks (Harmon on GenEval). Our work demonstrates that
systematic data construction is key to advancing multimodal AI capabilities.

AI.tldr: OpenGPT-4o-Image is a large, hierarchically structured, automatically generated dataset (80k instruction-image pairs) for unified multimodal models, spanning 11 domains and 51 subtasks, enabling notable gains when fine-tuned: up to 18% on editing and 13% on generation benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To address the data bottleneck in unified multimodal models by providing a systematic, scalable, and domain-rich dataset that covers challenging real-world scenarios.
AI.method: Introduce a hierarchical task taxonomy and an automated data-generation pipeline that leverages structured resource pools and GPT-4o to create 80k instruction-image pairs across 11 domains and 51 subtasks with controlled diversity.
AI.result: Fine-tuning leading models on the dataset yields significant performance gains: up to 18% on editing tasks (UniWorld-V1 on ImgEdit-Bench) and 13% on generation tasks (Harmon on GenEval).
AI.conclusion: Systematic, structured data construction is key to advancing multimodal AI capabilities, enabling better performance on complex editing and generation tasks across diverse domains.

title: Learning Goal-Oriented Language-Guided Navigation with Self-Improving Demonstrations at Scale
summary:
Goal-oriented language-guided navigation requires robust exploration
capabilities for agents to navigate to specified goals in unknown environments
without step-by-step instructions. Existing methods tend to exclusively utilize
shortest-path trajectories, lacking effective exploration priors for training
navigation agents. To address the above challenges, we present SID, a
goal-oriented language-guided navigation learning approach with Self-Improving
Demonstrations. Specifically, SID learns an initial agent on the shortest-path
data sampled from environments and then leverages this agent to generate novel
exploration trajectories. The novel rollouts provide demonstrations with
stronger exploration strategies to train a better agent, which in turn produces
higher-quality agent demonstrations for the next round of training. We show
that this iterative self-improving pipeline readily scales to new environments,
and the resulting demonstrations can be transferred across a variety of
language-guided navigation tasks, elevating the performance ceiling in diverse
goal-oriented navigation tasks. Extensive experiments demonstrate that SID
significantly boosts the exploration capabilities and generalization of
navigation agents. The resulting agent achieves new state-of-the-art
performance on goal-oriented language-guided navigation tasks, including
REVERIE, SOON, notably achieving a 50.9% success rate on the unseen validation
splits of SOON, surpassing the prior leading approaches by a margin of 13.9%.

AI.tldr: SID is an iterative self-improving demonstrations framework for goal-oriented, language-guided navigation that bootstraps from shortest-path data and progressively learns more exploratory trajectories, achieving SOTA on REVERIE and SOON (e.g., 50.9% SR on SOON unseen).
AI.motivation: Address the exploration bottleneck in language-guided navigation by moving beyond fixed short-path demos and enabling self-generated demonstrations to drive exploration and generalization, with cross-task transfer.
AI.method: Train an initial agent on shortest-path trajectories sampled from environments. Use this agent to generate novel exploration rollouts. Convert rollouts into demonstrations to train a better agent. Repeat iteratively, enabling demonstrations to transfer across language-guided tasks and new environments.
AI.result: The approach yields significant improvements in exploration and generalization, achieving state-of-the-art performance on goal-oriented language-guided navigation benchmarks, including 50.9% success rate on unseen SOON validation splits (surpassing prior approaches by 13.9%).
AI.conclusion: Self-improving demonstrations offer a scalable pathway to generalization across environments and tasks, elevating the performance ceiling for language-guided navigation.

title: Segmentor-Guided Counterfactual Fine-Tuning for Image Synthesis
summary:
Counterfactual image generation is a powerful tool for augmenting training
data, de-biasing datasets, and modeling disease. Current approaches rely on
external classifiers or regressors to increase the effectiveness of
subject-level interventions (e.g., changing the patient's age). For
structure-specific interventions (e.g., changing the area of the left lung in a
chest radiograph), we show that this is insufficient, and can result in
undesirable global effects across the image domain. Previous work used
pixel-level label maps as guidance, requiring a user to provide hypothetical
segmentations which are tedious and difficult to obtain. We propose
Segmentor-guided Counterfactual Fine-Tuning (Seg-CFT), which preserves the
simplicity of intervening on scalar-valued, structure-specific variables while
producing locally coherent and effective counterfactuals. We demonstrate the
capability of generating realistic chest radiographs, and we show promising
results for modeling coronary artery disease. Code:
https://github.com/biomedia-mira/seg-cft.

AI.tldr: Seg-CFT: a segmentation-guided counterfactual fine-tuning framework that enables structure-specific edits in images without pixel-wise labels, yielding realistic chest radiographs and promising coronary artery disease modeling.
AI.motivation: Current counterfactual methods rely on external classifiers/regressors and pixel-level label maps for structure-specific changes, which can cause global artifacts and are tedious to obtain.
AI.method: Segmentor-guided Counterfactual Fine-Tuning (Seg-CFT) preserves scalar, structure-specific variables while using segmentation guidance to produce locally coherent, realistic counterfactuals; avoids requiring full segmentation maps.
AI.result: Demonstrates generation of realistic chest radiographs and offers promising results for modeling coronary artery disease; code available.
AI.conclusion: Seg-CFT enables simple, effective structure-specific counterfactuals with locally coherent outputs, improving practicality for medical imaging data augmentation and debiasing.

title: Scalable GANs with Transformers
summary:
Scalability has driven recent advances in generative modeling, yet its
principles remain underexplored for adversarial learning. We investigate the
scalability of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) through two design
choices that have proven to be effective in other types of generative models:
training in a compact Variational Autoencoder latent space and adopting purely
transformer-based generators and discriminators. Training in latent space
enables efficient computation while preserving perceptual fidelity, and this
efficiency pairs naturally with plain transformers, whose performance scales
with computational budget. Building on these choices, we analyze failure modes
that emerge when naively scaling GANs. Specifically, we find issues as
underutilization of early layers in the generator and optimization instability
as the network scales. Accordingly, we provide simple and scale-friendly
solutions as lightweight intermediate supervision and width-aware learning-rate
adjustment. Our experiments show that GAT, a purely transformer-based and
latent-space GANs, can be easily trained reliably across a wide range of
capacities (S through XL). Moreover, GAT-XL/2 achieves state-of-the-art
single-step, class-conditional generation performance (FID of 2.96) on
ImageNet-256 in just 40 epochs, 6x fewer epochs than strong baselines.

AI.tldr: This work studies scalable GANs by training in a compact latent space and using purely transformer-based generators and discriminators; it identifies scale-related failure modes and offers lightweight, scale-friendly remedies, achieving state-of-the-art fast class-conditional image synthesis on ImageNet-256 with GAT-XL/2 in 40 epochs.
AI.motivation: To unlock scalable, efficient GAN training by leveraging latent-space representations and transformer architectures, and to address failure modes that emerge when scaling GANs.
AI.method: Train GANs in a latent (VAE) space and use fully transformer-based generator and discriminator. Analyze failure modes (early-layer underutilization and optimization instability) during scaling and propose lightweight intermediate supervision and width-aware learning-rate adjustments. Evaluate across model sizes from S through XL, culminating in GAT and GAT-XL/2 on ImageNet-256.
AI.result: GAT (latent-space, transformer-based GAN) trains reliably across various capacities (S–XL). GAT-XL/2 achieves state-of-the-art single-step, class-conditional FID of 2.96 on ImageNet-256 in 40 epochs, six times fewer epochs than strong baselines.
AI.conclusion: Latent-space, transformer-based GANs with simple, scale-friendly interventions enable scalable, high-quality generative modeling. The approach achieves efficient, competitive results and demonstrates how to mitigate scaling-induced instability and underutilization.

title: Perceive, Reflect and Understand Long Video: Progressive Multi-Granular Clue Exploration with Interactive Agents
summary:
Long videos, characterized by temporal complexity and sparse task-relevant
information, pose significant reasoning challenges for AI systems. Although
various Large Language Model (LLM)-based approaches have advanced long video
understanding, they still struggle to achieve both completeness and efficiency
in capturing task-critical information. Inspired by human progressive visual
cognition, we propose CogniGPT, a framework that leverages an interactive loop
between Multi-Granular Perception Agent (MGPA) and Verification-Enhanced
Reflection Agent (VERA) for efficient and reliable long video understanding.
Specifically, MGPA mimics human visual divergent and focused attention to
capture task-related information, while VERA verifies perceived key clues to
mitigate hallucination and optimize subsequent perception strategies. Through
this interactive process, CogniGPT explores a minimal set of informative and
reliable task-related clues. Extensive experiments on EgoSchema, Video-MME,
NExT-QA, and MovieChat datasets demonstrate CogniGPT's superiority in both
accuracy and efficiency. Notably, on EgoSchema, it surpasses existing
training-free methods using only 11.2 frames and achieves performance
comparable to Gemini 1.5-Pro.

AI.tldr: CogniGPT introduces an interactive MGPA-VERA loop for long video understanding, achieving high accuracy with minimal frames and improved efficiency, outperforming training-free baselines and approaching strong training-based models on several benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Long videos contain temporally complex and sparse task-relevant information, making complete and efficient reasoning difficult for AI systems. Existing LLM-based approaches struggle to capture all critical cues without excessive computation or hallucinations.
AI.method: Propose CogniGPT, comprising a Multi-Granular Perception Agent (MGPA) that mimics human divergent/focused attention to collect task-relevant cues, and a Verification-Enhanced Reflection Agent (VERA) that verifies key clues to mitigate hallucinations and refine perception strategies. These two agents engage in an interactive loop to iteratively identify a minimal, informative set of reliable clues for the task.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on EgoSchema, Video-MME, NExT-QA, and MovieChat show superior accuracy and efficiency. On EgoSchema, CogniGPT surpasses existing training-free methods using only 11.2 frames and achieves performance comparable to Gemini 1.5-Pro.
AI.conclusion: An interactive MGPA-VERA framework enables efficient, reliable long-video understanding by focusing on a small set of reliable task-related cues, reducing data requirements and improving robustness against hallucination.

title: Evaluating Temperature Scaling Calibration Effectiveness for CNNs under Varying Noise Levels in Brain Tumour Detection
comment:
Accepted and presented in INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ADVANCING
  SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGIES IN HEALTH SCIENCE
summary:
Precise confidence estimation in deep learning is vital for high-stakes
fields like medical imaging, where overconfident misclassifications can have
serious consequences. This work evaluates the effectiveness of Temperature
Scaling (TS), a post-hoc calibration technique, in improving the reliability of
convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for brain tumor classification. We develop
a custom CNN and train it on a merged brain MRI dataset. To simulate real-world
uncertainty, five types of image noise are introduced: Gaussian, Poisson, Salt
& Pepper, Speckle, and Uniform. Model performance is evaluated using precision,
recall, F1-score, accuracy, negative log-likelihood (NLL), and expected
calibration error (ECE), both before and after calibration. Results demonstrate
that TS significantly reduces ECE and NLL under all noise conditions without
degrading classification accuracy. This underscores TS as an effective and
computationally efficient approach to enhance decision confidence of medical AI
systems, hence making model outputs more reliable in noisy or uncertain
settings.

AI.tldr: Temperature Scaling markedly improves calibration (ECE and NLL) for a CNN brain tumor classifier under multiple noise types, without hurting accuracy, making medical AI outputs more reliable in noisy conditions.
AI.motivation: High-stakes medical decisions require reliable confidence estimates. Deep networks often miscalibrate under noise; TS offers a simple, post-hoc way to improve calibration.
AI.method: Train a custom CNN on a merged brain MRI dataset and introduce five noise types (Gaussian, Poisson, Salt & Pepper, Speckle, Uniform) to simulate uncertainty. Evaluate metrics (precision, recall, F1, accuracy, NLL, ECE) before and after applying Temperature Scaling as a post-hoc calibration step.
AI.result: TS significantly reduces both ECE and NLL under all noise conditions without degrading classification accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Temperature Scaling is an effective, computationally efficient method to enhance the reliability of medical AI systems in noisy or uncertain environments.

title: Social 3D Scene Graphs: Modeling Human Actions and Relations for Interactive Service Robots
summary:
Understanding how people interact with their surroundings and each other is
essential for enabling robots to act in socially compliant and context-aware
ways. While 3D Scene Graphs have emerged as a powerful semantic representation
for scene understanding, existing approaches largely ignore humans in the
scene, also due to the lack of annotated human-environment relationships.
Moreover, existing methods typically capture only open-vocabulary relations
from single image frames, which limits their ability to model long-range
interactions beyond the observed content. We introduce Social 3D Scene Graphs,
an augmented 3D Scene Graph representation that captures humans, their
attributes, activities and relationships in the environment, both local and
remote, using an open-vocabulary framework. Furthermore, we introduce a new
benchmark consisting of synthetic environments with comprehensive human-scene
relationship annotations and diverse types of queries for evaluating social
scene understanding in 3D. The experiments demonstrate that our representation
improves human activity prediction and reasoning about human-environment
relations, paving the way toward socially intelligent robots.

AI.tldr: Extends 3D Scene Graphs with human-centric social semantics and long-range open-vocabulary reasoning; introduces Social 3D Scene Graphs and a synthetic benchmark; shows improvements in human activity prediction and human–environment reasoning.
AI.motivation: Current 3D scene graphs largely ignore humans and human–environment relationships, and typically rely on single-image open-vocabulary relations. This limits modeling of long-range interactions and socially aware robotics. A human-inclusive, open-vocabulary 3D representation is needed for socially intelligent agents.
AI.method: Introduce Social 3D Scene Graphs (S3DG): augment 3D scene graphs with humans, their attributes, activities, and relationships (including remote ones) in an open-vocabulary framework. Build a synthetic environment benchmark with comprehensive human–scene relationship annotations and diverse query types to evaluate social scene understanding in 3D.
AI.result: Experiments show improved human activity prediction and better reasoning about human–environment relations. The synthetic benchmark enables evaluation of long-range interactions and open-vocabulary reasoning in 3D scenes, supporting more socially intelligent robot behavior.
AI.conclusion: Social 3D Scene Graphs advance socially aware robotics by incorporating human-centric relations and open-vocabulary reasoning in 3D, backed by a synthetic benchmark for robust evaluation; future work could extend to real-world data and broader social queries.

title: Event-based Facial Keypoint Alignment via Cross-Modal Fusion Attention and Self-Supervised Multi-Event Representation Learning
summary:
Event cameras offer unique advantages for facial keypoint alignment under
challenging conditions, such as low light and rapid motion, due to their high
temporal resolution and robustness to varying illumination. However, existing
RGB facial keypoint alignment methods do not perform well on event data, and
training solely on event data often leads to suboptimal performance because of
its limited spatial information. Moreover, the lack of comprehensive labeled
event datasets further hinders progress in this area. To address these issues,
we propose a novel framework based on cross-modal fusion attention (CMFA) and
self-supervised multi-event representation learning (SSMER) for event-based
facial keypoint alignment. Our framework employs CMFA to integrate
corresponding RGB data, guiding the model to extract robust facial features
from event input images. In parallel, SSMER enables effective feature learning
from unlabeled event data, overcoming spatial limitations. Extensive
experiments on our real-event E-SIE dataset and a synthetic-event version of
the public WFLW-V benchmark show that our approach consistently surpasses
state-of-the-art methods across multiple evaluation metrics.

AI.tldr: A cross-modal fusion attention and self-supervised learning framework improves event-based facial keypoint alignment by leveraging RGB guidance and unlabeled event data, achieving state-of-the-art results on real and synthetic datasets.
AI.motivation: Event cameras provide high temporal resolution and robustness to illumination but suffer from limited spatial information; existing RGB-keypoint methods underperform on event data, and labeled event datasets are scarce, hindering progress.
AI.method: Introduce cross-modal fusion attention (CMFA) to fuse corresponding RGB data with event inputs, guiding robust feature extraction. Implement self-supervised multi-event representation learning (SSMER) on unlabeled event data to enhance representation without labels. Evaluate on real-event E-SIE and synthetic-event WFLW-V benchmarks, demonstrating strong performance gains.
AI.result: The proposed framework consistently surpasses state-of-the-art methods across multiple evaluation metrics on both real and synthetic datasets, showing notable improvements in facial keypoint alignment accuracy.
AI.conclusion: CMFA plus SSMER effectively addresses modality gaps and data scarcity, enabling robust event-based facial keypoint alignment and strong cross-domain generalization.

title: On-the-Fly Data Augmentation for Brain Tumor Segmentation
summary:
Robust segmentation across both pre-treatment and post-treatment glioma scans
can be helpful for consistent tumor monitoring and treatment planning. BraTS
2025 Task 1 addresses this by challenging models to generalize across varying
tumor appearances throughout the treatment timeline. However, training such
generalized models requires access to diverse, high-quality annotated data,
which is often limited. While data augmentation can alleviate this, storing
large volumes of augmented 3D data is computationally expensive. To address
these challenges, we propose an on-the-fly augmentation strategy that
dynamically inserts synthetic tumors using pretrained generative adversarial
networks (GliGANs) during training. We evaluate three nnU-Net-based models and
their ensembles: (1) a baseline without external augmentation, (2) a regular
on-the-fly augmented model, and (3) a model with customized on-the-fly
augmentation. Built upon the nnU-Net framework, our pipeline leverages
pretrained GliGAN weights and tumor insertion methods from prior
challenge-winning solutions. An ensemble of the three models achieves
lesion-wise Dice scores of 0.79 (ET), 0.749 (NETC), 0.872 (RC), 0.825 (SNFH),
0.79 (TC), and 0.88 (WT) on the online BraTS 2025 validation platform. This
work ranked first in the BraTS Lighthouse Challenge 2025 Task 1- Adult Glioma
Segmentation.

AI.tldr: On-the-fly GliGAN-based data augmentation for robust cross-treatment glioma segmentation; ensemble nnU-Net models achieve state-of-the-art results on BraTS 2025 Task 1.
AI.motivation: Limited diverse annotated data to generalize tumor segmentation across pre- and post-treatment MRI; storage burden of large augmented 3D datasets motivates dynamic augmentation.
AI.method: Dynamic insertion of synthetic tumors during training using pretrained GliGANs within nnU-Net framework; compare baseline, regular on-the-fly augmentation, and customized on-the-fly augmentation; ensemble of three models; leveraging GliGAN weights and tumor insertion from prior winning solutions.
AI.result: Ensemble achieves lesion-wise Dice: ET 0.79, NETC 0.749, RC 0.872, SNFH 0.825, TC 0.79, WT 0.88 on BraTS 2025 validation; ranked first in BraTS Lighthouse Challenge Task 1 (Adult Glioma Segmentation).
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, on-the-fly GliGAN-based augmentation effectively improves generalization to treatment-induced appearance variations, delivering competitive state-of-the-art performance.

title: Wan-Alpha: High-Quality Text-to-Video Generation with Alpha Channel
summary:
RGBA video generation, which includes an alpha channel to represent
transparency, is gaining increasing attention across a wide range of
applications. However, existing methods often neglect visual quality, limiting
their practical usability. In this paper, we propose \textit{Wan-Alpha}, a new
framework that generates transparent videos by learning both RGB and alpha
channels jointly. We design an effective variational autoencoder (VAE) that
encodes the alpha channel into the RGB latent space. Then, to support the
training of our diffusion transformer, we construct a high-quality and diverse
RGBA video dataset. Compared with state-of-the-art methods, our model
demonstrates superior performance in visual quality, motion realism, and
transparency rendering. Notably, our model can generate a wide variety of
semi-transparent objects, glowing effects, and fine-grained details such as
hair strands. The released model is available on our website:
\href{https://donghaotian123.github.io/Wan-Alpha/}{https://donghaotian123.github.io/Wan-Alpha/}.

AI.tldr: Wan-Alpha: a joint RGB+alpha video generation framework that uses a VAE to encode alpha into the RGB latent space and trains a diffusion transformer on a high-quality RGBA video dataset, achieving superior visual quality, motion realism, and transparency rendering, including semi-transparent effects.
AI.motivation: RGBA video generation is increasingly needed across applications, but existing methods often neglect visual quality and fail to model transparency jointly; there is a need for a unified RGB–alpha modeling approach and high-quality training data.
AI.method: A variational autoencoder encodes the alpha channel into the RGB latent space. A diffusion transformer is trained on a new, high-quality RGBA video dataset to support joint RGB–alpha generation.
AI.result: Wan-Alpha achieves superior visual quality, more realistic motion, and more accurate transparency rendering than state-of-the-art methods; it can render diverse semi-transparent objects, glowing effects, and fine details (e.g., hair strands). The model and dataset are released on the project website.
AI.conclusion: Joint RGB–alpha learning via a VAE and a diffusion transformer, combined with a dedicated RGBA video dataset, yields high-quality transparent video generation, representing a meaningful advancement in the field and enabling broader semi-transparent content generation.

title: SDPose: Exploiting Diffusion Priors for Out-of-Domain and Robust Pose Estimation
summary:
Pre-trained diffusion models provide rich multi-scale latent features and are
emerging as powerful vision backbones. While recent works such as
Marigold~\citep{ke2024repurposing} and Lotus~\citep{he2024lotus} adapt
diffusion priors for dense prediction with strong cross-domain generalization,
their potential for structured outputs (e.g., human pose estimation) remains
underexplored. In this paper, we propose \textbf{SDPose}, a fine-tuning
framework built upon Stable Diffusion to fully exploit pre-trained diffusion
priors for human pose estimation. First, rather than modifying cross-attention
modules or introducing learnable embeddings, we directly predict keypoint
heatmaps in the SD U-Net's image latent space to preserve the original
generative priors. Second, we map these latent features into keypoint heatmaps
through a lightweight convolutional pose head, which avoids disrupting the
pre-trained backbone. Finally, to prevent overfitting and enhance
out-of-distribution robustness, we incorporate an auxiliary RGB reconstruction
branch that preserves domain-transferable generative semantics. To evaluate
robustness under domain shift, we further construct \textbf{COCO-OOD}, a
style-transferred variant of COCO with preserved annotations. With just
one-fifth of the training schedule used by Sapiens on COCO, SDPose attains
parity with Sapiens-1B/2B on the COCO validation set and establishes a new
state of the art on the cross-domain benchmarks HumanArt and COCO-OOD.
Furthermore, we showcase SDPose as a zero-shot pose annotator for downstream
controllable generation tasks, including ControlNet-based image synthesis and
video generation, where it delivers qualitatively superior pose guidance.

AI.tldr: SDPose is a diffusion-prior fine-tuning framework that directly predicts human keypoint heatmaps in Stable Diffusion latent space using a lightweight pose head, with an auxiliary RGB reconstruction branch; it achieves state-of-the-art cross-domain pose estimation with less training and enables zero-shot pose annotation for controllable generation.
AI.motivation: Pre-trained diffusion models offer rich multi-scale latent features and cross-domain generalization. However, structured outputs like human pose haven't been fully exploited. There is a need to leverage priors for robust pose estimation and domain transfer, while maintaining training efficiency.
AI.method: Direct latent-space heatmap prediction for keypoints from the SD U-Net features; map latent features to heatmaps via a small convolutional pose head; do not modify cross-attention modules or learnable embeddings; add an auxiliary RGB reconstruction branch to preserve generative semantics and improve generalization; evaluate on COCO and a style-transferred COCO (COCO-OOD) for domain shift robustness; demonstrate zero-shot pose annotation for downstream controllable generation.
AI.result: SDPose achieves parity with Sapiens-1B/2B on COCO val with only one-fifth of Sapiens' training schedule; attains state-of-the-art on cross-domain benchmarks HumanArt and COCO-OOD; serves as a high-quality zero-shot pose annotator for ControlNet-based image synthesis and video generation, providing superior pose guidance qualitatively.
AI.conclusion: SDPose demonstrates that pre-trained diffusion priors can be effectively repurposed for structured outputs like human pose, delivering strong cross-domain robustness and training efficiency, and enabling useful zero-shot pose guidance for generation tasks.

title: PanoWorld-X: Generating Explorable Panoramic Worlds via Sphere-Aware Video Diffusion
summary:
Generating a complete and explorable 360-degree visual world enables a wide
range of downstream applications. While prior works have advanced the field,
they remain constrained by either narrow field-of-view limitations, which
hinder the synthesis of continuous and holistic scenes, or insufficient camera
controllability that restricts free exploration by users or autonomous agents.
To address this, we propose PanoWorld-X, a novel framework for high-fidelity
and controllable panoramic video generation with diverse camera trajectories.
Specifically, we first construct a large-scale dataset of panoramic
video-exploration route pairs by simulating camera trajectories in virtual 3D
environments via Unreal Engine. As the spherical geometry of panoramic data
misaligns with the inductive priors from conventional video diffusion, we then
introduce a Sphere-Aware Diffusion Transformer architecture that reprojects
equirectangular features onto the spherical surface to model geometric
adjacency in latent space, significantly enhancing visual fidelity and
spatiotemporal continuity. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our
PanoWorld-X achieves superior performance in various aspects, including motion
range, control precision, and visual quality, underscoring its potential for
real-world applications.

AI.tldr: PanoWorld-X introduces a high-fidelity, controllable panoramic video generator that uses a Sphere-Aware Diffusion Transformer and a large Unreal Engine–generated dataset to enable diverse camera trajectories, achieving improved motion range, control precision, and visual quality.
AI.motivation: Current 360-degree video generation is hindered by narrow field-of-view and limited camera controllability, making it hard to synthesize continuous, holistic scenes. A geometry-aware model that respects spherical data can improve fidelity and temporal continuity.
AI.method: 1) Build a large-scale dataset of panoramic video–exploration route pairs by simulating camera trajectories in virtual 3D environments using Unreal Engine. 2) Develop a Sphere-Aware Diffusion Transformer that reprojects equirectangular features onto the spherical surface to capture geometric adjacency in latent space. 3) Train and evaluate the model on diverse camera trajectories to assess motion range, control precision, and visual quality.
AI.result: PanoWorld-X achieves superior performance across motion range, control precision, and visual quality, with enhanced spatiotemporal continuity due to geometry-aware latent space modeling.
AI.conclusion: The framework demonstrates strong potential for real-world applications in immersive panoramic video generation and exploration, addressing spherical geometry misalignment and enabling controllable, high-fidelity panoramic content.

title: LVT: Large-Scale Scene Reconstruction via Local View Transformers
comment:
SIGGRAPH Asia 2025 camera-ready version; project page
  https://toobaimt.github.io/lvt/
summary:
Large transformer models are proving to be a powerful tool for 3D vision and
novel view synthesis. However, the standard Transformer's well-known quadratic
complexity makes it difficult to scale these methods to large scenes. To
address this challenge, we propose the Local View Transformer (LVT), a
large-scale scene reconstruction and novel view synthesis architecture that
circumvents the need for the quadratic attention operation. Motivated by the
insight that spatially nearby views provide more useful signal about the local
scene composition than distant views, our model processes all information in a
local neighborhood around each view. To attend to tokens in nearby views, we
leverage a novel positional encoding that conditions on the relative geometric
transformation between the query and nearby views. We decode the output of our
model into a 3D Gaussian Splat scene representation that includes both color
and opacity view-dependence. Taken together, the Local View Transformer enables
reconstruction of arbitrarily large, high-resolution scenes in a single forward
pass. See our project page for results and interactive demos
https://toobaimt.github.io/lvt/.

AI.tldr: A Local View Transformer (LVT) is proposed to scale 3D vision and novel view synthesis by using local, neighborhood attention instead of quadratic global attention, decoding into a 3D Gaussian Splat representation for view-dependent color/opacity, enabling large, high-resolution scene reconstruction in one forward pass.
AI.motivation: Standard Transformers have quadratic attention complexity, hindering scaling to large scenes in 3D vision. The insight that nearby views carry more useful local signal motivates a locality-biased architecture.
AI.method: Process information in a local neighborhood around each view using attention over nearby tokens. Introduce a novel positional encoding conditioned on the relative geometric transformation between the query and nearby views. Decode outputs into a 3D Gaussian Splat scene representation with view-dependent color and opacity. Enables large-scale, high-resolution reconstructions in a single forward pass.
AI.result: The approach enables reconstruction and novel view synthesis for arbitrarily large, high-resolution scenes in a single forward pass. The abstract emphasizes qualitative results and references a project page with results and interactive demos rather than providing quantitative metrics in the text.
AI.conclusion: Local View Transformer offers a scalable alternative to standard Transformers for 3D vision by restricting attention to local neighborhoods with pose-conditioned encoding, achieving scalable, high-resolution scene reconstruction and novel view synthesis in a single forward pass.

title: CLASP: Adaptive Spectral Clustering for Unsupervised Per-Image Segmentation
summary:
We introduce CLASP (Clustering via Adaptive Spectral Processing), a
lightweight framework for unsupervised image segmentation that operates without
any labeled data or finetuning. CLASP first extracts per patch features using a
self supervised ViT encoder (DINO); then, it builds an affinity matrix and
applies spectral clustering. To avoid manual tuning, we select the segment
count automatically with a eigengap silhouette search, and we sharpen the
boundaries with a fully connected DenseCRF. Despite its simplicity and training
free nature, CLASP attains competitive mIoU and pixel accuracy on COCO Stuff
and ADE20K, matching recent unsupervised baselines. The zero training design
makes CLASP a strong, easily reproducible baseline for large unannotated
corpora especially common in digital advertising and marketing workflows such
as brand safety screening, creative asset curation, and social media content
moderation

AI.tldr: Training-free unsupervised image segmentation (CLASP) using DINO features, affinity-based spectral clustering with automatic cluster count via eigengap silhouette, and DenseCRF refinement, achieving competitive results on COCO Stuff and ADE20K; a strong reproducible baseline for large unannotated corpora.
AI.motivation: To develop a lightweight unsupervised segmentation method that does not rely on labeled data or fine-tuning, enabling practical use in large unannotated corpora (e.g., advertising, content moderation).
AI.method: Extract per-patch features with a self-supervised ViT encoder (DINO); build an affinity matrix; perform spectral clustering; automatically determine segment count with an eigengap silhouette search; sharpen boundaries with a fully connected DenseCRF.
AI.result: Attains competitive mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and pixel accuracy on COCO Stuff and ADE20K, matching recent unsupervised baselines; zero-training design enhances reproducibility and practicality.
AI.conclusion: CLASP provides a simple, training-free framework for unsupervised segmentation that is competitive with supervised baselines in some cases, offering a robust, reproducible baseline suitable for large unannotated datasets and practical workflows.

title: GeoVLM-R1: Reinforcement Fine-Tuning for Improved Remote Sensing Reasoning
summary:
Recent advances in reinforcement learning (RL) have delivered strong
reasoning capabilities in natural image domains, yet their potential for Earth
Observation (EO) remains largely unexplored. EO tasks introduce unique
challenges, spanning referred object detection, image or region captioning,
change detection, grounding, and temporal analysis, that demand task aware
reasoning. We propose a novel post training framework that incorporates task
aware rewards to enable effective adaptation of reasoning based RL models to
diverse EO tasks. This training strategy enhances reasoning capabilities for
remote sensing images, stabilizes optimization, and improves robustness.
Extensive experiments across multiple EO benchmarks show consistent performance
gains over state of the art generic and specialized vision language models.
Code and models will be released publicly at
https://mustansarfiaz.github.io/GeoVLM-R1/ .

AI.tldr: Post-training, task-aware reinforcement learning with tailored rewards to adapt reasoning-based models to Earth Observation tasks, achieving consistent gains across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Earth Observation tasks have unique challenges (e.g., referred object detection, captioning, change detection, grounding, temporal analysis) that demand task-aware reasoning; standard RL/VLM methods may underperform due to domain-specific requirements and stability issues.
AI.method: Introduce a post-training framework that injects task-aware rewards into reasoning-based RL models to adapt them to diverse EO tasks (detection, captioning, change detection, grounding, temporal analysis), improving stability and robustness.
AI.result: Consistent performance gains over state-of-the-art generic and specialized vision-language models across multiple EO benchmarks, with enhanced robustness and more stable optimization.
AI.conclusion: Task-aware reward-driven RL adaptation is effective for EO reasoning tasks, enabling better generalization and robustness; code and models will be released publicly.

title: STAGE: Stable and Generalizable GRPO for Autoregressive Image Generation
summary:
Reinforcement learning has recently been explored to improve text-to-image
generation, yet applying existing GRPO algorithms to autoregressive (AR) image
models remains challenging. The instability of the training process easily
disrupts the pretrained model capability during long runs, resulting in
marginal gains, degraded image quality, and poor generalization. In this work,
we revisit GRPO for AR image generation and identify two key issues:
contradictory gradients from unnecessary tokens and unstable policy entropy
dynamics. To address these, we introduce STAGE, a stable and generalizable
framework that leverages two targeted solutions: 1) Advantage/KL reweighting.
Similarity-aware reweighting to alleviate conflicting updates; and 2) Entropy
reward. An entropy-based reward corresponding to reference model to stabilize
learning. With the help of alleviating conflicts between tokens and an entropy
reward for stabilizing training, we reduce disruption of the pretrained
distribution and mitigate reward hacking, which in turn improves generalization
and transfer better to other benchmarks. Experiments across multiple benchmarks
show that STAGE consistently improves visual quality, stability, and cross-task
generalization compared to baseline GRPO.

AI.tldr: STAGE is a stable GRPO framework for autoregressive image generation that uses (1) similarity-aware Advantage/KL reweighting to reduce conflicting token updates, and (2) an entropy-based reward relative to a reference model to stabilize training. It improves visual quality, stability, and cross-task generalization compared with baseline GRPO.
AI.motivation: Applying reinforcement learning with GRPO to autoregressive (AR) image models is unstable and often disrupts pretrained capabilities, due to contradictory gradients from unnecessary tokens and unstable policy entropy dynamics. A robust, generalizable solution is needed to maintain pretrained performance while gaining sample efficiency and generalization.
AI.method: STAGE introduces two components: (1) Advantage/KL reweighting with similarity-aware weighting to alleviate conflicting updates from tokens; (2) An entropy reward that aligns the learned policy's entropy with that of a reference model to stabilize learning and reduce reward hacking.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations across multiple benchmarks show that STAGE consistently improves visual quality, training stability, and cross-task generalization over baseline GRPO approaches.
AI.conclusion: By mitigating token-level gradient conflicts and stabilizing entropy dynamics, STAGE reduces perturbations to pretrained distributions and enhances generalization, with strong transfer to other benchmarks.

title: VT-FSL: Bridging Vision and Text with LLMs for Few-Shot Learning
summary:
Few-shot learning (FSL) aims to recognize novel concepts from only a few
labeled support samples. Recent studies enhance support features by
incorporating additional semantic information or designing complex semantic
fusion modules. However, they still suffer from hallucinating semantics that
contradict the visual evidence due to the lack of grounding in actual
instances, resulting in noisy guidance and costly corrections. To address these
issues, we propose a novel framework, bridging Vision and Text with LLMs for
Few-Shot Learning (VT-FSL), which constructs precise cross-modal prompts
conditioned on Large Language Models (LLMs) and support images, seamlessly
integrating them through a geometry-aware alignment. It mainly consists of
Cross-modal Iterative Prompting (CIP) and Cross-modal Geometric Alignment
(CGA). Specifically, the CIP conditions an LLM on both class names and support
images to generate precise class descriptions iteratively in a single
structured reasoning pass. These descriptions not only enrich the semantic
understanding of novel classes but also enable the zero-shot synthesis of
semantically consistent images. The descriptions and synthetic images act
respectively as complementary textual and visual prompts, providing high-level
class semantics and low-level intra-class diversity to compensate for limited
support data. Furthermore, the CGA jointly aligns the fused textual, support,
and synthetic visual representations by minimizing the kernelized volume of the
3-dimensional parallelotope they span. It captures global and nonlinear
relationships among all representations, enabling structured and consistent
multimodal integration. The proposed VT-FSL method establishes new
state-of-the-art performance across ten diverse benchmarks, including standard,
cross-domain, and fine-grained few-shot learning scenarios. Code is available
at https://github.com/peacelwh/VT-FSL.

AI.tldr: VT-FSL: a cross-modal framework that uses LLM-conditioned prompts and synthetic data to ground few-shot learning, with a geometry-based cross-modal alignment that fuses textual, support, and synthetic visuals; achieves state-of-the-art on ten benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Addresses semantic hallucination and noisy guidance in few-shot learning due to reliance on limited support data. Seeks stronger grounding by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) and cross-modal synthesis, plus a geometry-aware alignment to ensure coherent multimodal integration.
AI.method: Two components: 1) Cross-modal Iterative Prompting (CIP): condition an LLM on class names and support images to generate precise, structured class descriptions in a single reasoning pass; these descriptions enable zero-shot synthesis of semantically consistent images and provide high-level semantics for textual prompts. 2) Cross-modal Geometric Alignment (CGA): align the fused textual, support, and synthetic visual representations by minimizing the kernelized volume of the 3D parallelotope spanned by them, capturing global nonlinear relationships and enabling integrated multimodal representations.
AI.result: Reported state-of-the-art performance across ten diverse benchmarks, including standard, cross-domain, and fine-grained few-shot learning scenarios; code released at the provided GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: VT-FSL demonstrates effective grounding of novel-class semantics via LLM-guided prompts and a geometry-aware fusion mechanism, using complementary textual and synthetic visual prompts to compensate for limited support data and robustly unify multimodal information for few-shot learning.

title: Fast Real-Time Pipeline for Robust Arm Gesture Recognition
summary:
This paper presents a real-time pipeline for dynamic arm gesture recognition
based on OpenPose keypoint estimation, keypoint normalization, and a recurrent
neural network classifier. The 1 x 1 normalization scheme and two feature
representations (coordinate- and angle-based) are presented for the pipeline.
In addition, an efficient method to improve robustness against camera angle
variations is also introduced by using artificially rotated training data.
Experiments on a custom traffic-control gesture dataset demonstrate high
accuracy across varying viewing angles and speeds. Finally, an approach to
calculate the speed of the arm signal (if necessary) is also presented.

AI.tldr: A real-time dynamic arm gesture recognition pipeline that uses OpenPose keypoints, 1x1 normalization, and an RNN classifier, with coordinate- and angle-based features and rotation-based data augmentation to improve robustness to camera angle variations; includes an optional arm-speed estimation component.
AI.motivation: To enable robust, real-time recognition of dynamic arm gestures across varying camera angles by leveraging robust pose estimation and normalization, while reducing annotation burden and improving generalization through augmentation.
AI.method: Pipeline stages: (1) OpenPose-based keypoint estimation, (2) keypoint normalization using a 1x1 scheme, (3) extraction of two feature representations (coordinate-based and angle-based), (4) recurrent neural network classifier for sequence modeling. Robustness to camera angle is enhanced by artificially rotating training data. An optional module computes the speed of the arm signal when needed.
AI.result: Evaluations on a custom traffic-control gesture dataset show high accuracy across different viewing angles and arm speeds, indicating strong robustness and real-time capability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed pipeline effectively enables real-time dynamic arm gesture recognition with robust performance under viewpoint and speed variations; rotation-based data augmentation is beneficial, and a speed estimation component provides additional utility when required.

title: A Scalable Distributed Framework for Multimodal GigaVoxel Image Registration
summary:
In this work, we propose FFDP, a set of IO-aware non-GEMM fused kernels
supplemented with a distributed framework for image registration at
unprecedented scales. Image registration is an inverse problem fundamental to
biomedical and life sciences, but algorithms have not scaled in tandem with
image acquisition capabilities. Our framework complements existing model
parallelism techniques proposed for large-scale transformer training by
optimizing non-GEMM bottlenecks and enabling convolution-aware tensor sharding.
We demonstrate unprecedented capabilities by performing multimodal registration
of a 100 micron ex-vivo human brain MRI volume at native resolution - an
inverse problem more than 570x larger than a standard clinical datum in about a
minute using only 8 A6000 GPUs. FFDP accelerates existing state-of-the-art
optimization and deep learning registration pipelines by upto 6 - 7x while
reducing peak memory consumption by 20 - 59%. Comparative analysis on a 250
micron dataset shows that FFDP can fit upto 64x larger problems than existing
SOTA on a single GPU, and highlights both the performance and efficiency gains
of FFDP compared to SOTA image registration methods.

AI.tldr: FFDP introduces IO-aware non-GEMM fused kernels plus a distributed framework to accelerate large-scale image registration, enabling multimodal, high-resolution registration on modest GPU clusters with significant speedups and memory savings.
AI.motivation: Image registration is fundamental in biomedical imaging but scales poorly with data size; current model-parallelism ideas from large-scale transformer training don't address non-GEMM bottlenecks and tensor sharding for convolution-heavy workloads.
AI.method: Develop FFDP: IO-aware non-GEMM fused kernels that optimize IO and convolution, plus a distributed framework enabling convolution-aware tensor sharding; complements existing model parallelism; demonstrated on ex-vivo brain MRI at native resolution.
AI.result: Registrations at 100 micron ex-vivo brain MRI at native resolution on 8 A6000 GPUs in about one minute; speedups of 6–7x over SOTA pipelines; memory usage reduced by 20–59%; on 250 micron data, FFDP can fit up to 64x larger problems than current SOTA on a single GPU; shows both performance and efficiency gains.
AI.conclusion: FFDP substantially improves scalability and efficiency of image registration workflows, enabling unprecedented large-scale multimodal registrations; indicates practical impact for biomedical imaging; further work may address generalization to broader hardware/datasets and real-world deployment.

title: GEM: 3D Gaussian Splatting for Efficient and Accurate Cryo-EM Reconstruction
summary:
Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) has become a central tool for
high-resolution structural biology, yet the massive scale of datasets (often
exceeding 100k particle images) renders 3D reconstruction both computationally
expensive and memory intensive. Traditional Fourier-space methods are efficient
but lose fidelity due to repeated transforms, while recent real-space
approaches based on neural radiance fields (NeRFs) improve accuracy but incur
cubic memory and computation overhead. Therefore, we introduce GEM, a novel
cryo-EM reconstruction framework built on 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) that
operates directly in real-space while maintaining high efficiency. Instead of
modeling the entire density volume, GEM represents proteins with compact 3D
Gaussians, each parameterized by only 11 values. To further improve the
training efficiency, we designed a novel gradient computation to 3D Gaussians
that contribute to each voxel. This design substantially reduced both memory
footprint and training cost. On standard cryo-EM benchmarks, GEM achieves up to
48% faster training and 12% lower memory usage compared to state-of-the-art
methods, while improving local resolution by as much as 38.8%. These results
establish GEM as a practical and scalable paradigm for cryo-EM reconstruction,
unifying speed, efficiency, and high-resolution accuracy. Our code is available
at https://github.com/UNITES-Lab/GEM.

AI.tldr: GEM introduces a real-space cryo-EM reconstruction framework using 3D Gaussian splatting, representing proteins with compact 3D Gaussians (11 parameters each) and a novel voxel-wise gradient, achieving faster training, lower memory, and improved local resolution.
AI.motivation: Scalable, high-fidelity 3D reconstructions are needed for large cryo-EM datasets; Fourier-space methods are fast but limited in fidelity, while NeRF-like real-space methods are accurate but memory-intensive.
AI.method: Model density with a set of 3D Gaussians (11 parameters per Gaussian). Employ a novel gradient computation for voxel-contributions to accelerate training, and operate directly in real space via 3D Gaussian splatting (3DGS).
AI.result: Benchmarking shows GEM: up to 48% faster training, ~12% lower memory usage, and up to 38.8% improvement in local resolution over state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: GEM offers a practical, scalable cryo-EM reconstruction framework that balances speed, efficiency, and high-resolution accuracy; code is available at the provided GitHub repository.

title: BRIDGE -- Building Reinforcement-Learning Depth-to-Image Data Generation Engine for Monocular Depth Estimation
summary:
Monocular Depth Estimation (MDE) is a foundational task for computer vision.
Traditional methods are limited by data scarcity and quality, hindering their
robustness. To overcome this, we propose BRIDGE, an RL-optimized depth-to-image
(D2I) generation framework that synthesizes over 20M realistic and
geometrically accurate RGB images, each intrinsically paired with its ground
truth depth, from diverse source depth maps. Then we train our depth estimation
model on this dataset, employing a hybrid supervision strategy that integrates
teacher pseudo-labels with ground truth depth for comprehensive and robust
training. This innovative data generation and training paradigm enables BRIDGE
to achieve breakthroughs in scale and domain diversity, consistently
outperforming existing state-of-the-art approaches quantitatively and in
complex scene detail capture, thereby fostering general and robust depth
features. Code and models are available at
https://dingning-liu.github.io/bridge.github.io/.

AI.tldr: BRIDGE: RL-optimized depth-to-image generation creates over 20M realistic RGB images each paired with ground-truth depth; training with hybrid supervision (pseudo-labels + GT) yields state-of-the-art, robust monocular depth estimation with strong generalization.
AI.motivation: Overcome data scarcity and quality limits in monocular depth estimation by leveraging large-scale, diverse synthetic data and robust supervision.
AI.method: RL-optimized depth-to-image (D2I) generation to synthesize >20M RGB-depth pairs from diverse source depth maps; train depth estimation model using hybrid supervision combining teacher pseudo-labels and ground-truth depth.
AI.result: Consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in quantitative metrics and in capturing complex scene details; demonstrates improved scale and domain diversity leading to more robust depth features.
AI.conclusion: BRIDGE offers a scalable data-generation and training paradigm for robust monocular depth estimation; code and models are provided online.

title: UniLat3D: Geometry-Appearance Unified Latents for Single-Stage 3D Generation
summary:
High-fidelity 3D asset generation is crucial for various industries. While
recent 3D pretrained models show strong capability in producing realistic
content, most are built upon diffusion models and follow a two-stage pipeline
that first generates geometry and then synthesizes appearance. Such a decoupled
design tends to produce geometry-texture misalignment and non-negligible cost.
In this paper, we propose UniLat3D, a unified framework that encodes geometry
and appearance in a single latent space, enabling direct single-stage
generation. Our key contribution is a geometry-appearance Unified VAE, which
compresses high-resolution sparse features into a compact latent representation
-- UniLat. UniLat integrates structural and visual information into a dense
low-resolution latent, which can be efficiently decoded into diverse 3D
formats, e.g., 3D Gaussians and meshes. Based on this unified representation,
we train a single flow-matching model to map Gaussian noise directly into
UniLat, eliminating redundant stages. Trained solely on public datasets,
UniLat3D produces high-quality 3D assets in seconds from a single image,
achieving superior appearance fidelity and geometric quality. More demos \&
code are available at https://unilat3d.github.io/

AI.tldr: UniLat3D introduces UniLat, a unified geometry-appearance latent space via a geometry-appearance Unified VAE, enabling single-stage 3D asset generation from a single image using a flow-matching model; outputs 3D Gaussians or meshes; fast and high-quality, trained on public data.
AI.motivation: Current 3D generation pipelines are diffusion-based and per-geometry staged (first geometry, then appearance). This decoupled design leads to geometry-texture misalignment, increased cost, and slower generation. A unified latent approach aims to align geometry and appearance in one stage for faster, higher-quality results.
AI.method: Propose a geometry-appearance Unified VAE (UniLat) to compress high-resolution sparse features into a compact latent (UniLat) that fuses structure and texture into a dense low-res latent. Decode UniLat into multiple 3D formats (e.g., 3D Gaussians, meshes). Train a single flow-matching model to map Gaussian noise directly to UniLat, enabling one-shot generation from noise. Trained solely on public datasets and capable of generating from a single image.
AI.result: UniLat3D produces high-quality 3D assets in seconds from a single image, with superior appearance fidelity and geometric quality. The approach outputs diverse formats (Gaussians, meshes) and provides demos and code on the project site.
AI.conclusion: A unified geometry-appearance latent enables efficient single-stage 3D asset generation, addressing geometry-texture misalignment and cost of multi-stage pipelines. By learning a compact UniLat with a single flow-matching model, UniLat3D achieves fast, high-fidelity 3D content from minimal input, with broad applicability across formats.

title: MANI-Pure: Magnitude-Adaptive Noise Injection for Adversarial Purification
summary:
Adversarial purification with diffusion models has emerged as a promising
defense strategy, but existing methods typically rely on uniform noise
injection, which indiscriminately perturbs all frequencies, corrupting semantic
structures and undermining robustness. Our empirical study reveals that
adversarial perturbations are not uniformly distributed: they are predominantly
concentrated in high-frequency regions, with heterogeneous magnitude intensity
patterns that vary across frequencies and attack types. Motivated by this
observation, we introduce MANI-Pure, a magnitude-adaptive purification
framework that leverages the magnitude spectrum of inputs to guide the
purification process. Instead of injecting homogeneous noise, MANI-Pure
adaptively applies heterogeneous, frequency-targeted noise, effectively
suppressing adversarial perturbations in fragile high-frequency, low-magnitude
bands while preserving semantically critical low-frequency content. Extensive
experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-1K validate the effectiveness of
MANI-Pure. It narrows the clean accuracy gap to within 0.59 of the original
classifier, while boosting robust accuracy by 2.15, and achieves the top-1
robust accuracy on the RobustBench leaderboard, surpassing the previous
state-of-the-art method.

AI.tldr: MANI-Pure is a magnitude-adaptive purification framework for diffusion-model defenses against adversarial attacks. It uses the input's magnitude spectrum to apply frequency-targeted, heterogeneous noise, suppressing high-frequency, low-magnitude perturbations while preserving low-frequency semantic content, improving robustness with minimal loss in clean accuracy, achieving SOTA results on RobustBench.
AI.motivation: Existing adversarial purification with diffusion models often injects uniform noise that distorts semantic structure and harms robustness. Empirical evidence shows adversarial perturbations are concentrated in high-frequency regions with varying magnitudes across frequencies and attack types, motivating a frequency-aware purification strategy.
AI.method: Introduce MANI-Pure, which leverages the magnitude spectrum of inputs to guide purification. Rather than uniform noise, it applies heterogeneous, frequency-targeted noise, suppressing perturbations in fragile high-frequency, low-magnitude bands while preserving semantically important low-frequency content during diffusion-based purification.
AI.result: The method, evaluated on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-1K, closes the clean-accuracy gap to within 0.59 of the original classifier, boosts robust accuracy by 2.15, and achieves top-1 robust accuracy on RobustBench, surpassing prior state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: A frequency-aware, magnitude-guided purification framework effectively mitigates adversarial perturbations with limited impact on clean accuracy, setting new SOTA performance and highlighting the importance of matching purification noise patterns to the perturbation spectrum.

title: Triangle Splatting+: Differentiable Rendering with Opaque Triangles
summary:
Reconstructing 3D scenes and synthesizing novel views has seen rapid progress
in recent years. Neural Radiance Fields demonstrated that continuous volumetric
radiance fields can achieve high-quality image synthesis, but their long
training and rendering times limit practicality. 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS)
addressed these issues by representing scenes with millions of Gaussians,
enabling real-time rendering and fast optimization. However, Gaussian
primitives are not natively compatible with the mesh-based pipelines used in VR
headsets, and real-time graphics applications. Existing solutions attempt to
convert Gaussians into meshes through post-processing or two-stage pipelines,
which increases complexity and degrades visual quality. In this work, we
introduce Triangle Splatting+, which directly optimizes triangles, the
fundamental primitive of computer graphics, within a differentiable splatting
framework. We formulate triangle parametrization to enable connectivity through
shared vertices, and we design a training strategy that enforces opaque
triangles. The final output is immediately usable in standard graphics engines
without post-processing. Experiments on the Mip-NeRF360 and Tanks & Temples
datasets show that Triangle Splatting+achieves state-of-the-art performance in
mesh-based novel view synthesis. Our method surpasses prior splatting
approaches in visual fidelity while remaining efficient and fast to training.
Moreover, the resulting semi-connected meshes support downstream applications
such as physics-based simulation or interactive walkthroughs. The project page
is https://trianglesplatting2.github.io/trianglesplatting2/.

AI.tldr: Directly optimize triangle meshes in a differentiable splatting framework (Triangle Splatting+) to enable real-time, mesh-based novel-view synthesis with state-of-the-art fidelity and ready-to-use outputs for graphics engines.
AI.motivation: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) offers fast rendering but relies on primitive Gaussians not native to mesh-based pipelines; existing conversions add complexity and degrade quality. There is a need for an end-to-end mesh-native, differentiable approach that yields production-ready geometry.
AI.method: Introduce triangle parametrization with shared vertices to ensure mesh connectivity; develop training strategy to enforce triangle opacity; integrate into a differentiable splatting pipeline; produce semi-connected meshes that require no post-processing for graphics engines.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art mesh-based neural view synthesis on Mip-NeRF360 and Tanks & Temples; surpasses prior splatting methods in visual fidelity; efficient training; outputs usable in standard graphics engines; supports downstream tasks like physics simulation and interactive walkthroughs.
AI.conclusion: Triangle Splatting+ provides a mesh-native, differentiable rendering framework that delivers high-fidelity, fast-training, production-ready geometry for mesh-based NVS and related applications.

title: Score Distillation of Flow Matching Models
summary:
Diffusion models achieve high-quality image generation but are limited by
slow iterative sampling. Distillation methods alleviate this by enabling one-
or few-step generation. Flow matching, originally introduced as a distinct
framework, has since been shown to be theoretically equivalent to diffusion
under Gaussian assumptions, raising the question of whether distillation
techniques such as score distillation transfer directly. We provide a simple
derivation -- based on Bayes' rule and conditional expectations -- that unifies
Gaussian diffusion and flow matching without relying on ODE/SDE formulations.
Building on this view, we extend Score identity Distillation (SiD) to
pretrained text-to-image flow-matching models, including SANA, SD3-Medium,
SD3.5-Medium/Large, and FLUX.1-dev, all with DiT backbones. Experiments show
that, with only modest flow-matching- and DiT-specific adjustments, SiD works
out of the box across these models, in both data-free and data-aided settings,
without requiring teacher finetuning or architectural changes. This provides
the first systematic evidence that score distillation applies broadly to
text-to-image flow matching models, resolving prior concerns about stability
and soundness and unifying acceleration techniques across diffusion- and
flow-based generators. We will make the PyTorch implementation publicly
available.

AI.tldr: Unifies diffusion and flow matching via a Bayes-based derivation, extends score distillation (SiD) to pretrained text-to-image flow-matching models with DiT backbones, and shows SiD works broadly across data-free and data-aided settings with minimal adjustments and no teacher finetuning.
AI.motivation: To determine whether distillation techniques like score distillation transfer to flow-matching models, given their theoretical equivalence to Gaussian diffusion, and to accelerate text-to-image generation.
